reviews.comment: entertaining lectures and just super nice guy. has fun stories and a clear passion for the subjects he teaches. i had a bunch of missing work due to some mental health issues and he was super understanding and allowed me to turn in late work. 10/10 dude would take again. work isnt super hard and he posts the slideshows from the lectures on canvas.

Gerald is a really nice guy and is always happy to help with any questions or problems you have. Lectures are pretty interesting especially if you like history. The assignments are pretty straightforward and his goal is for you to actually learn the material. Exams aren't super difficult if you prepare and pay attention during lecture. I recommend!

Gerald is such a great guy but he talks way too much for my liking so I did not enjoy the mandatory lectures. However, all his homework assignments are straightforward and real-life applicable. You have an assignment almost every week and must give one oral presentation and one poster presentation. No exams, overall great class.

Awesome guy and gives interesting assignments. If writing isn't your thing (STEM moment), then this class might feel like a slog. For me, I had a blast with the mandatory lecture presentation (do it in main lecture!) and got to talk/write about my interests all quarter. He also gives great advice for career/academia, so chat him up!

Literally the best professor. Good class for anyone who wants to know history about computers and other online resources, or if you want to fill in some gaps on your computer terminology. Amazing lectures, even when he rambles or tells personal stories, they still relate and makes you understand what he's teaching. Fun assignments, amazing person.

Professor Moulds is a breath of fresh air if you're in CE. If you've taken the entry writing classes, this should be relatively easy. Sections are mandatory but the TAs are very flexible. Lectures are also mandatory but very engaging and relevant, in my opinion. You do two presentations, which were fun to do as well. All around an easy class.

Great guy my problem isn't with his teaching it's the course content itself. Honestly feels like a busywork class but the work isn't too challenging. If you want to clear the major requirement do CSE115A as most of the assignments don't really feel meaningful. But if you need to graduate and need to clear the req this is a good choice.

Very nice guy, will understand if you have any troubles in the class. Only gripe is class attendance is mandatory, miss 3ish classes and you drop a letter grade, though I'm sure he makes exceptions if you have a valid reason. SECTION IS MANDATORY, so pick your section wisely. Lots of research/writing, but grading is easy if you follow the rubrics

Moulds is the real deal. Prepare for lots of writing and research topics to explore; the grading (depending on your TA) is pretty easy but YMMV. Lectures are great though some felt less important than others. Lecture and section is mandatory.

Professor Moulds makes this class a breeze, even for non-CS majors. Engaging lectures, fun projects like 3D printing, and fair grading. unstuck study was a great study tool alongside the free textbook. Definitely take this if you want an easy A!

Assignments are easy if you understand basic HTML and Python. His assignment have step by step guides (if followed you will get a A) plus each assignment will have extra credit as well. Has Bi weekly reading quiz's which are very easy. Midterm and Final were questions from said quizzes. Overall he cares about his students and will help you pass.
The professor is funny and lectures are good. The class was way more work than I was expecting especially towards the end of the quarter, if you don't procrastinate, you should be fine.

Moulds is the best professor I've ever had. He made a potentially tedious and boring class into something really enjoyable. I am writing this instead of working on the final project for this class (which is a lot of work, btw). If you don't wait to start it until 3 days before the deadline you'll be fine, the normal workload is pretty light.

Very friendly professors, and very easy courses, even if you are not a CS-related major, you can easily get an A, as long as it takes some time, and the exam and homework are not difficult, I highly recommend this course as a GE course!!! Although some lectures are a little boring, I can still learn some useful things!

Clearly passionate about what he teaches. Lectures are very digestible, recorded, and entertaining. Unfortunately I am not a CSE major but if he taught more lower div CSE classes I would be the first to sign up. Amazing professor, wish he taught some programming classes I could sign up for

Lectures are a bit boring but otherwise good class. Generally one or two assignments a week, such as reading quizzes, writing assignments, and technical assignments. Everything is very doable, easy GE.

Overall, this class had a lot of fun assignments such as the 3d printing project which I liked. Directions are very clear and easy to follow. Lectures are recorded and posted to canvas. Biweekly quizzes on reading, 4 short essay writing assignments, and 5 "technical" assignments (simple coding, 3d printing, spreadsheet making, ect.)

Attendance isn't mandatory, but Moulds is an incredible lecturer so I'd recommend showing up! He's a great speaker with obvious passion, a sense of humor, and lots of little anecdotes related to the material. The content isn't difficult as long as you keep up with the readings, and the technical and writing assignments are graded fairly.
Great lectures and easy work make this a fun class. Took this for GE credits and was pleasantly surprised by how fun it was. Prof has a good sense of humor.

My favorite professor to date, the passion, joy, and effort Professor Moulds puts into teaching is highly admirable and brought me so much peace during a stressful academic period. I finally felt like I knew how to learn again thanks to Professor Moulds easy to understand and enthusiastic teaching. I wish he taught every class offered.

Attendance is “mandatory”, there was no midterm or final exam, just 1 last in person quiz that was a little heavier. But otherwise everything else was online. There is a ridiculous about of extra credit, it would not be difficult to end with a 120%.

Her lectures aren't great, though the content isn't too difficult to self-teach with a bit of prior knowledge. She's relatively lenient about attendance, only requiring you attend 75% of the sections for full credit. Has weekly online quizzes, practice notebooks, no midterm/finals. Also gives a handful of extra credit opportunities to do if needed.

CSE 20 was okay. I had to rely on zybooks to get a better understanding on the content. It cost $40. I recommend going to office hrs and TA sections for extra support in case if you're struggling.
For CSE 30, there are no exams. She assigns weekly quizzes and Google Colab Assignments. Overall, she offers extra credit and is available to help on ED.
For CSE30, if you are willing to get help outside of lecture hours, she is a decent professor to take.

Don't listen to the other bad ratings. AS SOMEONE who failed CSE20 with different professor, yes you obviously will have to teach yourself, that goes for all the other CSE20 classes. She provides many office hours to help you understand & extra credit. Overall, she gives the same amount of coding homework as the other teachers w no deadlines.

Her CSE 20 class was really hard to fail as she gave so much extra credit opportunity that you didn't even have to take the final to pass the class.She accepts late work as all the assignments are online in zybooks and attendance was not graded.She was extremely nice and understanding if you communicate. She also offers good study guides for exams.

Professor Munishkina is very concise in lectures, content moves a bit slow but that makes it easy to understand. CSE 20 was a super easy class, you can get help by going to section or office hours, which you get extra credit for. Munishkina has a heavy soviet accent but she happily will go over anything that doesn't make sense.

Lectures are very slow and not necessary to the class, as the zybooks which is mandatory for the class provides more information. There is no attendance, and the exams are all based exactly on what is covered in zybooks.

Took Munishkina for CSE 20 and 30. CSE 20 was easy, I ended up skipping a lot of lectures because zybooks (the online textbook she used) is incredibly comprehensive. As for CSE 30, I stopped going to lectures pretty much immediately. Her lectures are not the worst, but I personally didn't find them worth going to.

If you want to be taught anything, don't take this class, you will be forced to learn everything on ur own as her lectures are so terrible and it's pretty much impossible to understand her. Homework is pretty easy and all due at the end of the quarter, as well as online tests with no final, just an easy A even if you don't show up to class.

Lectures are optional and mostly review stuff that was in the homework. The homework itself is VERY easy and accounts for a large part of your grade so even if you screw up on the tests you can get at least a B. The tests are easy themselves and as long as you do the BARE minimum you'll be fine.

CSE20 was rather easy, try taking the testout when it's available. I attended a grand total of three lectures and did well in the class. Everything you need is on ZyBooks. Her reviews and practice tests are useful--use them. Nothing remarkable, about what I expected for a large lecture-type class.

Gave this class my bare minimum and still got a B+ with no coding experience. Easy A if you take it seriously, she gives a lot of extra credit opportunities to bump your grade. I never went to class because i couldn't understand her, just taught myself python through her zylabs
Tough but rewarding class. Lectures can be tough, but the labs teach a ton. Unstuck AI was a lifesaver for extra practice and prep.

An easy A with someone who had a heavy programming background experience. Lots of opportunities to get extra credit. Random pop quizzes for extra credit sometimes. Mainly learning mainly from doing ZyBooks assignments (that you do have to pay for) so just fully understand each topic, dont fall behind, and recommend getting the easy extra credits.

Professor Munishkina is a really caring professor. She does everything in her power to get you the most points possible in any assignment. As long as you're communicating there is no way to fail her class. She gives very little homework and exams are all online.

She's an alright teacher for someone like me who had zero experience in coding before this class. She likes to do easy pop quizzes for attendance sometimes on Fridays, and sometimes she reuses the questions on the quizzes on the midterms (2). The first 4 weeks are very chill and then after the first midterm things ramp up a whole lot. Good luck!!!!

Decent class, but sometimes gets confusing. Some stuff should have been explained more thoroughly. Overall not the best, but not the worst. Tests were worth a lot and you do have to study quite a bit in advance if you want to do good.
Decent amount of HW which is to be expected. Tests are worth a lot.
You will will probably have no ideal what she is saying in class but you won't need to. Her assignments teach the topics very well. The bad reviews are just skill issues.

Didn't explain things very well, but was very willing to help
CSE 20 was easy, learned most of the things in zybooks online textbook
Had to pay like 30 bucks for a subscription tho
He is very fair when it comes to grading, grades on completion, and can always talk to him when unhappy about a grade.

There was no midterm or tests, but rather projects! You get really good feedback throughout the projects, and plenty of help in section. You do have to write about the readings pretty often, but nothing too hard.There is opportunities for extra points on projects for creativity, etc. I REALLY recommend this class. (No programming experience req)

A really easy class, honestly a great introduction to coding at the University. His class itself is not hard at all. 45% of your grade is based off homework that is graded off completion. Midterms and final are really easy. How much you learn depends on how much you're engaged with the material. Professor is really nice too!
awesome professor, was a great intro to python class! very clear teaching and grading style, midterm and final where so easy + we did a bunch of kahoots so that is always fun :)

Professor Yue is the best lecturer for CS. His explantations are very useful and canvas is well organized, so reviewing material is very easy. Most of the learning is done through Zybooks, so attendance isn't really required unless you want to reinforce what you learned and boost you grade. He does have an accent, but his teaching is amazing. 10/10

I took him for CSE40 (which was not an option in the selections).
I took this class as a senior and learned so much! This class even cleared up concepts from upper-divs that I have taken. The lectures are clear and make difficult topics easy to understand and fun to learn.

i love this professor so much. kahoot quizzes to help prepare for midterm + final. there are practice tests for both which are basically exactly the same as the actual test. great late work policy. content is taught very well. attendance is only taken occasionally and he is very understanding in general. TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!

I went to 2 lectures total, and got a 100% with very little experience in Python. He's a very caring professor but I don't have that much in person experience with him. The homework literally gives you a whole lesson on the topic before and that's how I learned everything. Just do your homework and attend discussions and you will get an A+.

I took professor Yue's class in spring 2025 and he was great! He was very knowledgeable and truly cared for the success of the students. Attendance to lectures was taken biweekly. The workload was relatively light for a 7 credit course. You mainly worked in google colab with paper exams. If you have the chance to take his class do so!

This was an amazing class and I really enjoyed taking it, however the homework for this class was a bit much and advanced much faster than the lectures did. I found that the lectures were a massive aid and the homework was good for practicing more advanced stuff.
If you are ready and eager to code you'll have no problem getting a good grade in this class ! Hao is personable and a very smart professor, I am going to continue taking him in cse 30!
He is super sweet and understanding! Talking to him was a pleasure, and he was always willing to help.
This professor is amazing and genuinely cares about his students and wants them to do well in his class. Would recommended.

A fun teacher who helped us learn with kahoot and worksheets, and one week, I forgot to submit something and didn't realize until a week later. I emailed him to apologize (I was a freshman I don't know why I did this) but he gave me a week extension which is crazy. His exams are also really easy if you have a good grasp of the material.

Hao Yue was a great professor. Lectures go over all the material really well and make it easy to understand. He takes student feedback into consideration, and actually makes changes. The questions on the practice tests and homework are similar to the ones on actual tests, so as long as you do those the tests should be easy too.

I enjoyed Prof Yue. He did well with the CSE 30 material which to me felt mostly pointless. My less programming experienced friends in his class appreciated his time given to the details. Very nice and cared a lot and tried as hard as he could to make the lectures and content engaging. Definitely not a bad option for CSE 30

Professor Yue is amazing! He is so sweet, cares about his students, lecture is great! Readings and HW are a big part of grade, but also easy. Exams are chill if you do the work, and he did Kahoot for review! Genuinely zero coding experience needed, I knew literally nothing and he made it easy and enjoyable to learn. Best professor I've had so far.

Hao Yue is one of the best professors I have. It is his second quarter teaching at UCSC, and I took CSE 20 and CSE 30 with him. he's very understanding; he'll give you an extension if you have a valid excuse, He's very homework focused which is nice cause homework is easy if you attend lectures, and the final and midterms are simular to the review.

He was amazing, always good at explaining things going on. Just make sure you stay on top of it because its mostly reading that gave you the credit. Be careful because the work catches up to you but I really enjoyed it! Ill be taking his cse 30 class next.
GOAT. you will actually learn

Prof Yue is a great professor who runs a very well-organized class that is easy to follow along and makes the concepts easy to grasp. Lectures are great and wants you to do well in the class. No coding experience at all prior and would say that I understand the content well because of his teaching style. No quizzes, 1 midterm, 1 final. The Goat

I had professor Yue for CSE 20 and CSE 30 as of right now and I think he is a very caring and lenient professor. Beginning python can be a bit boring for how easy it is, however once you get into more difficult material, the professor Yue's lectures start to become more comprehensible and useful. Also Kahoot for midterm and final reviews is fun!

Expects memory of things shown (not even on slides) once in Week 1 perfectly in Week 9, got mad we didn't remember despite never reviewing since. Midterm avg was 64%. Said she would take some blame, when asked why class was behind on material blamed it on the students. Said the tutors took tests easily, thus they should be easy bc we had more time.

I will NEVER get behind graded attendance policies for not only lecture but also section. But, she drops one quiz, her quizzes/final are fair and even takes questions from the assignment you're working on + the final is all the quizzes mashed together, she gives a practice final, and she's active on Discord. One of the better professors out there.

She in fact is super problematic and her questions in her tests and hw's are very weirdly worded so you cant really understand what to do, plus its very heavy when is doesn't need to be. She is an ok professor like she tries and takes feedback its just she doesn't know how to give students a break like tests before & after break. Not teaching well.

attend everything, sections and lectures

each section and lecture worth 1 percent of your grade

Don't take this professor. The lectures are poorly structured, and she skimmed over every topic without providing detailed explanations. I also suspect that some of the 5-star reviews are not genuine, as my experience was completely different.

Honestly really good professor. Attendance quizzes every lecture and discussion section. Quizzes are tough so spend a good amount of time studying in the couple of days prior. Final was not so hard and she gave plenty of relevant prep. She also had a mid-term survey and took responses very seriously and really tried to improve based on feedback.

Gives many examples in class and helps outside to make sure you understand the material. Memorizing specific commands for some quizzes I feel are useless but the other material is something needed if you actually want to pursue CS. The material is heavy but Kriti/TA's provide plenty study material for quizzes/tests. P.S. START HWs ASAP.

Don't take this professor, half the class is failing and the average on the exams and quizzes is about 65%. All my friends taking veenstra are chilling with an A rn bc his assignments are worth 40% while here they're only worth 10%, so even getting 100% on the them hardly even changes your grade.

I wouldn't recommend her. The lectures are dry, and the grading point is poorly balanced, mandatory attendance and homework which only account for 10%. A lot of the newer 5-star reviews feel completely disconnected from what's actually happening in this class, students are struggling, so I genuinely don't know what those reviews are talking about.

She's one of the best comp sci professors I've had. Difficult quizzes at first but once you understand her structure, it becomes a lot easier. No midterm, just quizzes every other week. Cumulative final and she gives you finals from previous quarters for practice. All in all, great course progression and structure.

very effective lecturer, looking back the lecture recordings is really helpful to clear points of confusion. quiz's are a little harder so prepare beforehand, but overall a really great and engaging professor. shes one of the best CS profs at UCSC

Shes very problematic, doesn't put anything anywhere, only on discord, which is bound to get lost, like what do you YOU HAVENT PUT DETAILS ABOUT THE FINAL ANYWHERE, CMON NOW, take veenstra y'all please, she's making the class unnecessarily harder than it should be.

The class is well structured, and she help students prepare well for the assessments as almost all questions are directly from homework and lectures. She is very open to feedback by asking the students in lecture how to improve and pushing deadlines! Generally easy class: I only spent 2-4 hours outside of lectures for this class a week.

Great professor, explained concepts well and easy to follow. Bi-weekly quizzes based on lecture slides/exercises and homework. They are aren't too bad if you know what to expect and you stay on top of lectures, homework, and utilize office hours. Final is comprehensive but she gives you a lot of practice exercises to help prepare.
The professor takes criticism really well, seems those who claim she doesnt need to do some reflection.

Lectures are well-paced and clear. There's a weekly quiz, plus a midterm and final. If you know another programming language, the first few weeks are fairly easy, as they mostly cover C syntax. Key topics like pointers, linked lists, stacks, and queues are taught in the second half of the quarter, so be sure to study them thoroughly for the final.

The review below me (Nov 25 2025) is a paid actor and should not be taken seriously. I am currently doing well in this course but that does not take away from the fact that this class is horrifically structured and is a huge pain to take. Not to mention the fact that the professor cannot seem to accept that any issues could be her own fault.

Class had mandatory attendance for horrible lectures and useless discussions. The midterm average was a 64%, which I think says it all. Everyone I know who took it with Veenstra is chilling right now and I'm stuck here deciding whether I should withdraw. Do not take her!

Brooo don't even get me started she acts like everyone understands what she's talking about and insists on going faster and Assignments are basically worth nothing, half of the class is failing the average for the midterm was 64% I do not recommend especially at the morning. Always says we MIGHT have a curve and never truly decide.

Professor bhargava is very kind and understanding, and her lectures are very helpful to those are need help with coding which is the point of the class. If something doesn't make sense in lecture go to her office hour and she'll clear anything you need up. Tutors are great.

Going to lectures are usually fun because you can tell how passionate prof is about the content (especially since he used to do google translate stuff). no midterms, but 4 big quizzes that are like unit tests of every 2 units. Prof is very active on discord! 
Overall this class was fun! (but data is annoying sometimes)
If you can take a class with Sir Rudnick even if you don't need it, take it.

Rudnick is a great professor, so I'll only really post the things that concerned me during the quarter:
- Very inaccessible outside of class. Emails met with silence, including follow-ups. Go up to him after lecture or ping him on Discord
- Created extra credit assignments that went ungraded.
- Unable to handle classroom chaos, e.g. talking a lot.

Alex is such a great lecturer and his background in philosophy gives him such a unique perspective on teaching computer science. This class had 5 homework assignments and one final project. There were participation quizzes during lecture to get credit and sections were mandatory. Homework was pretty easy but reports could be tedious.

Lectures were engaging and spontaneous, usually involving Rudnick writing demos alongside student engagement. However, I feel sometimes lectures aren't enough if you want to understand topics fully. Overall, Rudnick feels very human to me, as he shows he cares a lot about his students and isn't afraid to make mistakes when teaching.

My king alexander rudnick had some very interactive lectures, he always coded things during class and made it feel like you were coding with him. Assignments are pretty easy(takes maybe 10 hours each) and the tests are take-home(and are easy). He's a funny guy and drops gen z diction randomly?!? He prepares you well for other classes.
sometimes lectures are just fillers and it's practically impossible to reach out to the professor outside the class, everything else is good
Passionate about what he teaches, great professor

PROS: amazing guy, very passionate, TAs and the discord are a big help, homework is fun to do (C is fun in my opinion). Dr. Rudnick has a nice personality; he wants you to learn and not just chase a grade (doesn't mean it's hard to get an A). CONS: a little late with grading the last homework, past the date grades were due. (only the last one).
very chill

Workload extremely reasonable. I went in with no C experience + minimal programming experience and am expecting to end with an A or high B. Extremely kind and helpful, but lectures are brisk and have tangents, so expect to do a fair bit of studying on YT. Very available on Discord, very funny. Don't procrastinate, and you'll do GREAT! Take him!

I briefly had Veenstra before switching to Rudnick, and I would say Veenstra is more engaging and structured while Rudnick was more laid back and friendly. Both classes are beginner-friendly, but if you already have decent programing knowledge, I'd say Rudnick's class works better and demands less of you. Expect to be referred to as "chat" lol

Lectures were amazing, engaging, and he was great at demonstrating how to put what we learned into practice. Homework was super useful and lowkey fun, especially the last homework which was very hands-off, we had to make a program from scratch. Midterm and final were take-home, and had similar structure to the homework. Great professor!

Can't comment on difficulty because I already knew most of the memory shenanigans in C before going into this, but he did an absolutely stellar job teaching it in an intuitive way and the homework test-suites were fantastic.

Rudnick is a great professor, I learned extremely well from his lectures back in spring '22. Homework is hard, but CSE 13S is a weeder class, and other professors are just as hard and more confusing. He is a fantastic lecturer and a great guy. Grades are slow to come back, but it honestly taught me way more than any other CSE prof's class

I didn't realize he left the university to return to the industry. Spring 22' I really miss his teaching style. He would bring out his loud mechanical keyboard and code live demos using the CLI. He even showed himself troubleshooting code rushing to get it to work before time runs out. That's how I also got comfortable using linux and vim.
he's wholesome and a nice guy. lectures are good and he provides material in an organized website. i miss him so much

Although, there are no tests lectures weren't helpful for hw. He's a cool dude, but not a good professor. Grading was awful, the autograder failed and grades weren't even released when grades were due. The tutors did not have access to rubrics and hidden tests were very difficult to pass. We'd often have 2 assignments due a week and at times 4.

I was in the CSE30 course for Professor Rudnick.  He was always very helpful during and after class when it came to teaching and pointing out mistakes in code.  However, he can be a bit disorganized at times and sometimes assigns assignments out late.  His teaching and homework made CSE30 much more understandable than I thought it would be.

The lectures were good helped me prep for the actual exams but the problem was with the homework and the fact that he didn't start giving back grades until the 7th week of the quarter. I wasn't sure if what I was doing was correct until the last couple weeks and because of this I lost a lot of points over small things. Start on assignments early.

Nice and clearly passionate like Siero. Surprisingly light workload; weekly assignments like CSE 30. Class isn't so hard, BUT quizzes can be annoying & may contain niche/trick questions. Slightly disorganized (ex: assignment introduces pointers before it's taught & you learn it w/ BST before linked list). No midterm. CS50x is good for self-study

Very knowledgable in terms of the content and teaching it to students. Live coding during class and clear instructions step by step for assignments, was also accessible during office hours, very approachable. Weekly quizzes but nothing was ever a surprise. No midterm, cheat sheet allowed for final; quizzes and final multiple choice. Cheerful guy.

literally KING.. He is very clear in what he expects from you and grading is fair/clear. Also just a humble and nice guy all around. You have to put in the work but I felt that what he was asking for was reasonable. Very accessible outside of class and genuinely wants you to succeed
Veenstra is the GOAT. He knows how to teach, what to expect and what to understand. If you do well in his quizzed and understand his lecture, you definitely will get an A in the class.
Took for 13s, has great office hours and the homework is very doable if you look at slides and the materials. He also clearly cares and would take again, great professor.

Dr. Veenstra is clearly very passionate about what he teaches and is quite effective at doing so. I did find, however, that he was a little fast and that, if I didn't already take a C++ course prior to transferring, I probably would've been a little lost. Other than that, this is a professor you'll want to get.

Prof. Veenstra is a great teacher; he really knows his material and explains concepts clearly. He does move a bit fast, so if you're new to C, make sure to attend office hours and keep up with the lectures. As a CC transfer, I found most of it familiar, but if I hadn't taken C++, I would've definitely been lost in class. Other than that great class

One of the best CS professors I've had so far. Clearly knows and is interested in what he's talking about, makes amazing and very structured lecture slides. Gives plenty of time for weekly HW coding projects. His office hours are a godsend, super kind and patient, will help you. Fridays are attendance quizzes. Final is just all quizzes combined.

Lectures are interesting and engaging, I don't think they're required as he doesn't take attendance but I still went to them anyways as I felt like I learned a lot. Dr. Veenstra explains things clearly and seems really interested in the topics he covers. I definitely recommend his class, he's a great teacher. Also the workload is pretty light.

very good, great teacher, just quizzes every week but i actually learned a lot. the questions are pretty good too and if you want to learn, take this class. you can get an A if you actually put effort in.

More than fair quizzes/final as concepts are fairly straightforward and lectures do a good job(yuja accessible). Less than fair coding assignments. Office hours/tutoring are almost mandatory due to buggy, vague, and feedbackless autograder.

Great Professor for CSE13S very clear lectures and a weekly quiz that was easy to get an A on as long as you go to / watch lectures. Also dropped the two lowest scores. Overall a great professor to take 13S with made the class very enjoyable.

Veenstra is a really nice and friendly guy who is really passionate about what he teaches. His lectures are not mandatory but its good to at least watch them to keep up with content for his weekly quizzes instead of playing catch up. Labs are worth a majority, expect to spend good time on them, he also drops lowest 2 quizzes and 2 missed sections!

One of the better professors at UCSC. Interesting lectures that are very clear. Most of the grade is assignments, which are not bad. He also cares about students and answers any questions that he gets. You will also have weekly quizzes which are easy because he gives the topics beforehand, just study.

Nice guy, lectures are helpful in person but online become a jumbled mess as he switches between c file examples and slides with some lectures being 70 slides long where half the slides are the same. Sometimes goes off on random tangents. Programming assignments take MANY hours due to sheer assignment length. Decent intro class, just LOTS of work.
Very solid class, good assignments, great lectures, solid exams. Definitely one of the better classes I've taken at the university.

Before I start, should say I don't get much out of cs lectures. I learn more by doing than by being lectured to. However, Veenstra's lectures are great, the class is just as easy as (if not easier than) CSE 30, and the weekly tests are easy if you dedicate < an hour to reading the study guides he posts. Not the warmest prof, but a good one.

He's a good professor who's very passionate about the material. As long as you go to the TA sections and office hours you should be good on the assignments. For the midterms just try and study best you can, the slides are your best friend, same for th final. For the final study the previous midterms and quizzes as well. He will help you if you ask.

If I were to take CSE 130, I would take it with Veenstra. The quizzes were manageable for the most part, but some of the questions he put would be on one slide that he went over. Midterms were ok, lots of partial for FRQ and MCQ was fine but some of the MCQ questions were not great. Final was fair with partial credit. Start assignments early.

Veenstra's Cse13s class was awesome, and I recommend it to anyone who really wants to be taught the material. He did have some problems grading things this quarter, but that was due to extenuating circumstances regarding the Ta's. If you rewatch his lectures, and do your own research for the assignments, you can pass with at least a B.

Content-wise, class is useful. Good to know some of the concepts as a software engineer. The lectures are pretty much textbook (understand them super well). Participation credit is annoying if you are an introvert don't feel like raising your hand or engaging in TA sections. Projects kinda hard but doable given a group and enough time. Kinda strict

Great class, I enjoyed Peter's lecturing style. Assignments were difficult and very time consuming. Very exam heavy. there are random participation quizzes during lecture. Lectures go over theory, assignments give freedom to figure out which algorithms and protocols to implement to meet the assignment spec.

One could imagine Mr.Alvaro gleefully panning out the most debaucherous, soul-crushing quizzes while calling himself a Disney villain. He has the emotional and philosophical depth of a cardboard cutout of Socrates. I'd rather stub my toe repeatedly, every second, every hour, and every day for millennia that take his class ever again.

This guy is a meme. Kind of a pushover/tool, not very practical. ask him what 1+1 is and he'll lecture you for an hour on the philosophy of addition, which is good ig if you're into that. talks like tucker carlson. tests are hard, class is hard, a lot depends on if he's in a good mood or not.
Good professor but super easy to fall behind. Lectures are kind of disorganized.

Inaccessible outside of class, doesn't respond to emails nor direct Slack messages. Relies on tutors to teach assignments for him. Nice grading scale though, where assignments are a low part of your grade. No extra credit opportunities available; does not curve.

He doesn't use canvas to send important information, he uses slack instead, so you have to check slack frequently. If you don't check it frequently (at least 5 times a day I mean), you may (definitely) miss online quiz or courses changed to online for some reasons.

Most dysfunctional class I have taken at UCSC. HW/quizzes/exams full of typos, lectures unhelpful, multiple grading errors. Poor communication, refused to use Canvas/Email in favor of a Slack flooded with messages where important info was hard to find. Slow grader. Unclear grading criteria for HW. HW takes WAY too much time to just be 35% of grade.

He is one of the best teachers on this campus. He is a retired software engineer with many insights about what actually happens in the industry. I found that I was very engaged in his class, as his lectures are fun and littered with curses. He is overall a great professor, even though the class is one of the hardest I've taken.

3/4 of your grade in this class depends on exams and weekly quizzes and they are full of subjective questions that are open to interpretation. A lot of the time the answers are what he or the ta believes in and are against the norm.

People are saying the TAs are bad for this prof & there's a lot of work. I'm retaking this class with Alvaro & my original prof for this class wasn't as good. TAs are the same people, there's the same amount of work, & grades come back at the same rate in both. Rating solely the professor & how well he explains topics, Alvaro is the better option.
He made me go from enjoying CS to never wanting to do it again

Alvaro is clearly a professor who really cares about CS and the success of students. However, he over relies on tutors/TA's to teach, and hw is FAR too much for it to only be 30% of the grade. Been coding for 8 years, and I still spend more time on this class than 3 other engineering courses combined. Only communicates through slack, never canvas.

Professor Alvaro has really engaging lectures & generally seems like a cool guy. Mostly leaving this here to warn students of the unnecessarily condescending course staff (Tutors/TAs). This class is extremely challenging in itself & receiving snarky comments from tutors when seeking help certainly doesn't make the experience any more pleasant

This professor explains topics clearly, is entertaining, and puts an even emphasis on assignments and quizzes. He helps students understand the material in a discussion-style lecture and helps with independence and confidence for asgn. submissions. The class is hard but this prof. cares enough to make it more manageable.

I would rather sit through him talking over slides than trying to decipher what he wrote on his ipad. Him and the TAs/tutors only uses Slack for communications outside of class and help offered there is cryptic at best. Sometimes teaches the material to a week long assignment the day before the assignment is due.

Constantly goes on tangents during lectures. Assigned homework is unclear and full of typos. Grades slowly, it took until week 8 for the week 4 assignment to be graded. Refuses to communicate via email or Canvas, insists that everything happens on a hard to read slack flooded with unimportant messages. Dismissive and stubborn personality.
This guy is so bad, I don't know how with every week he digs a deeper grave

Alvaro is good at C programming. But:
- He is *very* combative & passive aggressive
- Class is disorganized and messy
- Overrelies on TAs to teach HW instead of teaching it himself
- Assignments are riddled with errors (that he won't fix)

Other reviews say he's good. I'm sure he was. For this class, he is literally the worst professor I've had.

He tries to make everything super theoretical and conceptual which does not help students at all. For example, if a student asks "Can we use this library in our homework?", he'll go on a tangent about how we should think deeply about the philosophical purpose of programming libraries and apply that theory to our own case, instead of a real answer.
Homework took a long time but other than that the class was honestly not that hard.

Knows what he's talking about, but really isn't the best at teaching. Hard to read handwriting/wordy slides and doesn't post lecture recordings unless you give him a good excuse. 4 random quizzes, cheat sheet for 2 midterms and final. Wording on exams was confusing. TA's and tutoring are the only times I understood material so consider them a must.

Final exam was significantly harder than all the practice, and included many bad faith questions designed to trick you, and others that were just worded so poorly that the actual right answer depends how you interpret it. I did fine, but I just don't see why anyone would choose to do any of that. These problems were common throughout the course too

He is the worst professor I've had during my undergraduate career at UCSC. He was unable to explain concepts thoroughly and proficiently. Instead, I heavily relied on reading the textbook and studying with friends. Don't have him as your CSE 16 professor if you need to take the course next quarter. Also, go to TA sections!!

He is not the most amazing lecturer, but he gives you enough information to complete the labs. The grading system was not particularly clear, but it ended up being extremely lenient. All deadlines are "suggestions", and quizzes have no effect on your grade.

The labs are interesting, and not exceptionally difficult if you've taken CSE130.

For CSE 121, not CSE 16. During the entirety of the quarter, it was written on the canvas syllabus that the grading policy is 25% quizzes and 75% labs. He waits until the first day of finals week to change the rubric -> doing 6/7 labs = C, 7/7 labs = A. ???????? I had only done 6 thinking i would get an 89 in the class. Now i am likely stuck w a C

He's a nice guy when you talk to him one on one, but I had a very hard time relating what was in the lectures to what was on the homework. Lss tutoring and discussions helped a lot. He'd do problems on his notepad during lecture which was hard to follow cuz his handwriting is BAD.

Midterms are horribly written and confusing. Nobody finished the second midterm and midterms are completely different and way harder than all the homeworks and even the sample midterm he gives you before.

The projects and midterms always seem to be a mess, and for what? Make it easier or lower the number of questions. Midterms are hard, there's no need to make things more difficult. He also commonly writes illegibly and keeps the text small on the screen and slanted, making it hard to follow. He could certainly improve it's just whether he cares to.

Lectures were useful, but near the end of the quarter you NEED to do the readings as the topics are hard to understand in themselves. Attendance is not necessarily mandatory, but you would have to email him a reason for access to the recorded lecture:( It is not that hard to get an A, as he curves midterms heavy, it just requires a lot more effort.

I read the other reviews, and they seem to be overly negative. RMP is exactly like amazon reviews; people only write a review if they (think) that they have been wronged. The average grade of the class was a B+, which is higher than the average CSE16 grades for other professors. Hes a chill guy, and taught the class well. I got an A.

Do not take this guy. Wait for another professor. This guy avoided my regrade requests and dodged me on piazza. Sure he's funny but he is def not a good professor. The HWs are tough, so are the midterms and the Final. The lectures aren't even that great. Most people stopped going after midterm1.

Cedric is not the greatest professor, evidenced by his other reviews. However, he is very active on piazza and is open to regrades and EC suggestions. As a new professor, his tests are overly difficult and his lectures are not always engaging, but he shows that he cares about his students. Given time I think he can be a great professor.

Lectures were somewhat useful and could clarify concepts, but you'll need to spend lots of time reading textbook and slides. Ta's weren't too helpful. Weekly homeworks and 2 midterms which had some difficult problems but he curves well so its fine. Final was mcq and proofs and easier than midterms. Overall generous grading and lots of self-study

It takes a lot of effort to do well in this class.
The content is pretty simple, but he overcomplicates it, teaches the beginner-level stuff in class, and makes the hw and tests exponentially harder. But he's a chill dude. TAs aren't allowed to help you much on hw. 
GO TO TUTORING. MAKE A STUDY GROUP. I would've failed if I didn't have resources.

Funny guy, but, man, are the lectures a challenge to sit through. Lecture slides are, according to him, taken from other professors or TAs and often have typos. Sometimes he doesn't even know what's on them. Works out practice problems on tiny chalkboards with sloppy handwriting. Hours of HW. For exams, legit told us to just "Trust in the curve".

Frankly a disastrous class. The professor is a kind person, but he frankly just cannot teach in a proper, engaging, and fulfilling way. His lectures are very boring; he stutters and fumbles a lot which makes it very hard to understand the content. 2 Midterms, 1 Final, open note. Second midterm was disasterous, the curve being enormous. Avoid him!

The professor doesn't teach at all and literally just makes all the work happen by tas. I just finished the final today, but i still don't know my grade since i dont know my grade for 2 of the homeworks. Also he posts grades at the most awkward time possible. Like 11:30pm is CRAZY.

Lectures are useful to go to, he sometimes drops hints to test questions, but mostly they are a bit incomprehensible. Many people say reading the textbook is mandatory, personally I haven't, but it has certainly made the class more difficult for me. Midterms are curved nicely, but you definitely need the curve on the second. Homework wasn't bad.

The professor struggles at teaching, and what you learn in lecture is not similar to what will be on the homework, and these both are different from what's on the tests. The assignments are graded, you can't get help from TAs until after due date, and overall the class is unorganized. Avoid this class!

Droning lectures, and when you miss one you better hope you can grasp the concept on your own, cause the slides won't help you. TAs are amazing, and explained the topics well. Do well in labs and Inquizitive and you're fine, just in for an annoying quarter.

Dr Monroe is west African archaeology royalty of this decade. He talks about his work because it's relevant and he's passionate!! If you're not into anthro then just pay extra attention to the readings and actually study the slides. The tests are only hard when you haven't put in time it's the material outside of class.

I went to almost no lectures and just studied for the midterm and final and did fine. There's lots of assignments, which is low-key good because it gives you a cushion in case you don't do well on the tests. A boring class though, but that's not his fault; archaeology is just a boring subject. Attendance required at sections- you get credit for it.

Ive had Monroe for most of my college career atp. Ive enjoyed his work nd I feel like hes defiantly more interesting when youre engaged in material/interacting in class. I do feel like hes a bit unapproachable but overall pretty friendly nd understanding. I wish I took his classes more srsly when I was in them. theyre avg college lvl classes imo

Was uninterested in teaching, blamed the students for bad attendance, and seemed aggravated. He never posted reviews for tests. Would lecture for the whole class, never ask if the students had any questions. Were 2-3 lengthy document assignments and an inquisitive assignment per week. The assignments were very difficult for an "introduction class.

Very passionate and made a lot of references to his own archaeological work. He's pretty funny and very understanding. Lecture attendance wasn't mandatory but discussion (lab) was. There's usually 2 labs a week (one, sometimes both, are covered in lab). Labs were fun, we looked at lots of bones and pottery. Only class I went to consistently.

Professor Monroe is the epitome of a teacher who is trying to validate himself by randomly mentioning his field work, rather than teach his students. His tests were worded horribly and he read off Powerpoint slides the whole quarter. He also has the worst monotone voice I've ever encountered, making lectures a struggle. The midterm was not curved.
He's a good lecturer, but his tests aren't reflective of the assignments and reading

The lectures in historical archaeology were riveting and his passion for the subject was palpable. 
I enjoyed this class more than his African archeology class which was a little dry.

it amazes me how Professor Monroe can take such an interesting topic and make it so boring! He speaks in such a monotonous voice that it is difficult to stay focused on his lecture. He reads his long lecture slides the entire class and goes through it too quickly. he also has this arrogance to him that is off putting. wouldnt recommend

While his class has to cover dark history, he does use slurs in some lectures. His lectures are loosely related to the weekly quizzes and it's honestly better to read the textbook. Beware the final exam!! He IS passionate about archeology and seems like a good person.

R.I.P. to all the fellow anthropology majors who have to take this class with him. Avoid this class if possible and save a P/NP slot for this class, or you won't pass. The sheer amount of work is impossible and unbelievable. This class lowered my will to live by an enormous amount. Avoid taking over the summer!

5 Quizzes and a final test or paper is all you're graded on. The quizzes were difficult because it was not clear as to what was going to be on the test. Lectures dragged on at times, but the material was easy to recall.

Holy cow. This is by far the most boring professor I have ever experienced!!!! He somehow manage to turn super interesting subjects into a snoozefest! This lectures are so convoluted and boring. Also somebody needs to remind him that his success is judged by the success of his students.

The class is interesting but he is so boring. He has a monotone voice but it is obvious he has a passion for what he teaches. Buying the textbook was pointless, just get the course reader. Going to class was a waste of time because the tests are based off of power points he posts online.

Professor Monroe is the perfect example of vapid intellectualism and  arrogance in academia. Why become a professor if you don't have passion for changing the lives of young people by introducing them to your passion? Standard midterm/ final and participation/ section grading. Test questions were sometimes confusing and not phrased well.

I loved Professor Monroe. He can be a little difficult, but he's just better than the intro classes they give him. If you let him know you have a real interest in archaeology, he'll respect you. He also respects his students and doesn't give reading quizzes or mandatory attendance. That being said, you have to keep on top of the reading yourself.
He's extremely immature and gets little respect from his students because of it. Also you may fall asleep in lecture, the material is interesting he just sucks at lecturing.

ANTH 108-Best anthropology professor I've had so far. He's kind and thoughtful in his lectures. Work load is doable. He didn't take attendance but its worth attending lectures. Lots of small writing assignments and a couple bigger ones. It takes effort to do poorly in his classes. He sets you up to succeed.
One of the best professors at the Anthropology department
He is great

Took this class as an outside major class and it was definitely difficult but Reti works to make sure you understand the concepts. Half of my grade was the midterm so that can be intimidating but if you do well then its less to worry about and he then makes the final optional which is a bonus. Have to know the readings for free response exams.

Given his fan base, I was a little resistant to like him, but this guy is an amazing professor. His enthusiasm is catching. Who knows how he gets the energy or positive attitude all the time, but it is a huge motivator to care more about the subject matter. Reti makes all those tough reading assignments seem super clear cut.
Really liked going to class! Dr. Reti is really engaging and friendly. Definatley going to take more of his classes. I'm minoring in anthro because of this class.

Prof. Reti doesn't post his notes for lecture online, so attendance is mandatory. But his lectures for Intro to Bio Anthro were engaging and I loved the class. His passion for his work really shows. Didn't read a single word from the textbook he suggests in the syllabus since tests are on the content he teaches in lectures.

This class is two exams and one 5 page paper. His lectures are not online so you have to attend class to get the notes which is not too bad because his lectures are so engaging and interesting. His study guides are clear and if you understand all of the concepts you will be prepared for the exams. HIGHLY recommend this class. I am now an anth major

Best professor ever! Absolutely love his lectures! Ive heard so many students rave about him for good reason. There are only two tests and one paper. Most other credit is from labs which you dont want to miss. Really really knowledgeable and friendly. Easy to talk to. Always look forward to his class.

Professor Reti was an awesome lecturer! He's truly passionate about Anthropology and it shows. This class for me was an easy A, and I honestly don't feel like you need to read the book unless you want to go the extra mile. Seriously considering being an Anth major after this class.
J. Reti is an amzing professor, he grades very fairly and he is very passionate about Anthropology. I am planning on taking all his classes

Everything is straight forward, so just keep up with the reading and you will pass. The reading responses come directly from the reading and videos, so just pay attention to the details. I think having a two-part final (final paper and final project) is a bit intense though considering the limited time frame.
Amazing lecturer!!
Great guy and great lecture. Will be taking more classes by him.

I took ANTH 1- Introduction to Biological Anthropology with Jay, and it was really quite easy. All of the questions on his test come directly from his lectures, which he doesn't post online so you have to attend class. Also, his study guides for both tests were completely accurate, so studying directly from them works well.

He's a really amazing lecturer. He knows his stuff really well. Entertaining and enthusiastic of the subject. I just hated how this class was an 8 am. Go to every class, read the book, and memorize his review topics. Memorizing is important for the multiple choice portion on the tests. Overall, I enjoyed the class and it's not bad.
Great professor. The lectures were super interesting and his teaching style is really helpful. Its a lot of information to learn but he does a good job teaching it. 10/10
The lectures were very interesting and you could tell he is passionate an knowledgable about anthropology. The class is not hard as long as you attend all the lectures.

Jay is great. He knows his stuff and is able to present confusing material in a way that makes it clear and interesting. Labs are helpful. The textbook is helpful for more depth on what he talks about in class, but you can do fine just studying off his lectures.

Jay is passionate about his work and it shows in lecture. He is very organized and respectful towards students. The readings were reasonable, and the articles were provided online. One midterm, one final, and a final paper as well as a few short responses throughout the quarter. Very doable. Would definitely recommend.

He gives a pretty big chunk of homework from zybooks and weekly coding assignments, but they all are necessary and fair. He'll give any extensions needed and is lenient with grading and late assignments. He is also British so he has the accent during lectures which made them super funny and engaging and gives enough extra credit to save any grade
good teacher

The best professor I've had so far. Fair grading policies. He's very understanding and actually WANTS his students to succeed. He explains topics well, TA's are great help too. Online textbook costs $40 but extremely worth it. Practice midterm and practice final was similar to the actual exams. Generous curve. I wish him the best in everything!!

Great professor he care about the student and he very chill. If you did bad on the midterm but great on the final your midterm can change to the same grade you got from your final, However he does give a lot of homework/textbook but it actually can help you and if it too easy for you the midterm and final would be a peice of cake to take.

Great professor who explains every topic of coding as in depth as he can within a 2 month class period. Lectures were always recorded so they could be accessed any time. All grading was fair and late work policy was fair. Enjoyed his class

Awesome professor. Lectures are well structured and clear. There are challenge problems in the middle which helps with retention and makes sure you know what you're doing. Generous amounts of extra credit on the programming assignments helped me out a lot. Always willing to answer questions after class. Tests are definitely easier than assignments.

Guy's a chiller, easy to understand lectures, he goes through them efficiently and will answer any questions. if you're still confused he stays after class and tries to get to everyone who has something. grading is straightforward (he says strict, its not), assignments are hard, quizzes and readings are easy, exams are pretty simple too. nice man

Went to lecture maybe 2-3 times total so I can't really comment on those. Material is basically the same as APCSA but in python. I learned everything from zybooks. Programming assignments could be pretty challenging but exams were a lot easier and there's lots of extra credit

Genuinely cares for his students, and his lectures are very clear. I enjoyed how the lectures would start simple and move on to more complex ideas towards the end. Gives a lot of homework that requires a lot of time. Do NOT start the HW later, as they do require you to sit down and think about them. Take LSS tutoring and go to the TA's office hours

I really liked the way Professor Paten explained concepts. Even though lectures aren't technically mandatory, I always went and I'd recommend doing so as well. The final and midterm were on paper but were similar and easier than the practice ones. There are also a lot of extra credit opportunities in the later homework's and on the exams.

Professor Paten is a great person but not the best lecturer. I constantly found myself wanting to fall asleep and questioned going to lectures on a daily basis. Lectures were quite boring and unhelpful; most of the info I retained was from YouTube videos and the Zybooks readings. He gave lots of extra credit opportunities, which boosted my grade.

Benedict is a great professor and lecturer. He really knows his stuff. Even though he's a really busy faculty he makes time for students outside of class. His homework was clear and easy to follow. In this class you have a senior thesis you must complete including a 10 page paper and 5 min presentation at the end of quarter.
really clear framework of class to help students stay on track. difficult class with LOTS of outside work, but there's many opportunities for ec and he is very generous w the curve
Such a fair and easy professor. Just make sure to turn in work on time and follow along with concepts. Super generous with grading and extra credit.

This was by far one of the easiest course I took. I didn't attend a single lecture and still ended the course with 104% overall grade. I've taken AP CSP and CSA during high school and got 4 on both so that definitely helped. The homework assignments are significantly harder than the midterm/final so if you do well on those you're gonna be fine.

Lectures were amazing to the point where I could understand all all the material from them without reading Zybooks. The homework assignments were lengthy but if you start early you should be fine. Both the midterm and final were in person on paper but had a few easy extra credit questions and he gave similar practice exams. Overall a great prof.

Paten's lectures aren't the most engaging. You do at least 1 reading + 1 assignment a week on ZyBooks but end up not needing most of it on the finals as they're much, much easier and also have a great curve. Doesn't give extensions. Does answer questions in class as much as needed, just ask! Don't fall behind as this course does require some time.

Even though lectures are optional, I found it really helpful to go rather than relying to zybooks (online platform for hw). The professor cares about the students and doesn't try and make students' lives harder than necessary. As long as you study hard and prepare before midterms and finals, you will be okay.

This was a great class imo, I learned a lot. The lectures are good with structured class notes you can keep up with easily.
His tests are also curved pretty generously. There's regular homework, which I expected, and it can get pretty time-consuming but overall those were useful too.

I made the mistake of skipping some lectures and assignments, if I didn't do that I would have passed the class with a better understanding fs. He is really nice and explained things well, things get confusing towards the end so I encourage going to office hours or tutoring. Most of the assignments were pretty clear.
Optional lectures, grade is 70% based on the midterm and final with 30% on simple weekly lab activities.

You can tell his how passionate Emily is about this topic and it rubs off onto students! Exams were 70% of your grade but SO easy if you attend lectures (got 100%+ on both.) Emily's lectures are engaging and makes this class fun. Highly recommend taking this for a GE or elective.
Her passion for her field is evident in the quality of her lectures! She is so knowledgeable and such an engaging lecturer. Her class made me feel affirmed in my major.

Honestly, she slays so hard. Gave everyone +5 points on each exam out of 50 points (10% boost) just because the averages were slightly in the 70s. Her lectures are super fun and engaging, and right before exams, she gives a huge lecture about exactly what's on the exam. It's still a lot, but way less than all the material covered.

Super chill teacher, she's very straightforward and very engaging since she loves her topics. She's very honest and super fun to watch teach. Just be aware that tests are a huge part of the grade, but no homework and only weekly labs. So stay on top of work, and  the class will be chill.
really chill prof, cared a lot about her subject so that made lectures really engaging. only assignments is going to lab and one midterm one final, very easy stuff and hard to not pass this class.
Great teacher with engaging lectures

Honestly one of the best all-around teachers I have ever had. I love her lectures and she even post them online if you miss it. The way she lectures is super entertaining that it keeps you engaged. I thought this class was going to be hard, but it is so chill and if you go to her lecture/ watch them it is so comprehensible. I just loved this class.
My favorite lectures, shes so funny and teaches material really well. I looked forward to learning from her, midterm and final taken online from home. labs with TA section every week.

amazing professor! all midterm and final were solely based on the information from lectures, and she made a review slide with what's needed. she was super engaged with the class, and joked a ton. grades are just labs and tests. never missed a lecture just because of how chill she was, and how much she enjoys her subject and teaching it.

Dr. Schach is genuinely one of the best professors I've ever had, she is very caring and easy to talk to. Her lectures are engaging, funny, and very informative, this class is a great introduction to the world of anthropology. You are only graded on the labs (half are online), and the 2 exams (midterm and final), and all lectures are recorded.

Queen! Knows her stuff! Not just book smart but speaks from experience in the field. 

Works very well with people with accommodations. Many professors can make students feel like a burden, she is always kind and patient.

Dr. Schach has got to be my favorite professor at UCSC, she is very approachable, kind, and understanding. Her expectations are clear and she will answer any question you have. The lectures are very engaging and entertaining and Dr. Schach is  very funny. If you're thinking of taking a class with Dr. Schach I highly recommend it. 10/10 professor

dr schach is amazing!!! her lectures were so much fun and engaging, they were also recorded and posted as well as the slides so it was nice if i had something else to do or was sick that i could make up the work easily. you're really only graded on labs in section which were always interesting, and the midterm and final which were online.

Probably the easiest class i've taken in my life, tests were open note. Schach is a great lecturer and had a lot of personal experiences in the field that made her lectures interesting. The labs were fairly easy but sometimes a little disorganized. It takes barley any effort to pass if you are looking for a GPA boost.
All tests are online and open note. Also all lectures are recorded. She's really funny and talkative but in her lecture she sometimes rambles.
Professor Schach is very easy going and understanding. Labs are fun and require group work! Not too difficult since you get help from peers.

Had her for ANTH1 and ANTH101 and she's a great lecturer, super funny even though she gets a bit off topic sometimes. Not a very difficult class but there is some reading and writing in ANTH 101. Exams are online and simple and she's a very easy person to approach and ask questions to.

Really funny; lectures are long and wordy, but she makes them entertaining. Very small amount of homework, mostly just labs that are super easy. Tests are online and multiple choice. Lectures are recorded so participation is optional, textbook is also optional. Great filler class to go with harder classes. Labs are also fun.

Dr. Schach is one of the best teachers I've ever had. She's not only so personable and kind, but her lectures are incredible. Her lectures and slide decks are engaging and accessible. This class's required reading is tougher, its all scientific journals that have to be responded to in weekly papers. Fun class though!

such a good professor, take his class 
very passionate about the subject and truly cares for his students + funny

Super nice guy, one of the best professors I have had. Everyone respects him and he RESPECTS YOU. He is so understanding about assignments and exams. Easy A if you just show up and do the homework. He loves his students and ACTUALLY LOVES HIS JOB. Would take his class again!
MAN JUST TAKE THE CLASS!! THIS IS THE GOAT. YOU WILL NOT REGRET TAKING ANY OF HIS CLASSES. I'll miss rick :((

Best Professor Ever! Learnt so much in his class. He explains all concepts in depth and makes classes fun at the same time. Genuinely cares about his students. Is open to connect with students on LinkedIn outside class. 

BEST PROFESSOR AT UCSC.
Favorite professor, super nice and caring and made concepts very easy to learn. He made me want to go into networking!
An absolutely hilarious guy, and goes out of his way to animate his Powerpoint slides and explain everything in depth, and hammers in how it all fits together.

By far the best professor I've ever had. His lectures are given with handmade demonstrations and not just simply reading off the projector. He makes his lectures fun and easy to understand. His exams are very easy if you study using the reader he assigns and the simple class work. Overall, an amazing professor and an amazing class experience.

I thought the reviews were fake but he is just that good. He is very passionate about what he loves and it's very clear. He just makes networking easy to understand and covers useful topics. And the labs while sometimes tedious are fully guided and transferable to industry unlike 150 where you use mininet. Just wish we did network automation stuff.

chill prof. knows what he's talking ab and stays back after class + will repeat any topic you didn't understand w/out making you feel dumb. if crush from finding nemo knew everything ab the internet and networking, it would be rick
W Prof. Has W Youtube channel. Likes F1. Big dubs

He's a very good teacher, understandable, I am not a CSE major and is not hard for me. He's open note with he's coursereader is very useful. If you go to class and go to class, easy A! I like him so much!!!!

TAKE THIS CLASS. best prof ive ever had.explains all the material perfectly for an intro class and knows how to grasp students' attention. loves his job and is passionate about what he does.Rick made it so exciting to go to class bc you learned something every time instead of just memorizing things.super accesible to talk to via office hours/email.
Rick is such an amazing professor! Highly recommended for business management Econ majors for undergraduate classes. Just go to class and 100% you'll probably get an A.
You will not regret taking his class. He provides lots of resources to understand the material! He is the best teacher ever!
He knows Brad Pitt, he is passionate about the subject, and let's you sleep in class.

Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor Great professor

Rick is respected as a professor and in the networking industry. I would take his CSE 151 class if you love computer networking. His lectures are straight to the point and informative. Fun experience and he teaches you hands-on labs at Cabrillo. Stop by when you can and reach out for him if you want to go further with computer networks.

Rick cares a lot about his students and really wants them to learn. He provides amazing resources for his students such as hands-on-lab, career opportunities, YouTube videos, etc. The labs and exams are not difficult, they are made to help you learn. Probably the best professor at UCSC.

Professor Rick shows that it isn't hard to be both kind and respected. He is a pioneer in the networking industry but he doesn't hold a massive ego and goes above and beyond to ensure you love every second of the class. Simple exams, very stress free learning, LOTS of resources to learn more, and best of all Rick is such an interesting human being!

THE BEST PROFESSOR AT UCSC! Definitely had no interest of networking before this class and was only taking it to fulfill a major requirement but Graziani made every lecture worthwhile! I learned so much from him and he genuinely cares about what he teaches and about his students. Exams were open-note too

guys if you can take a class w professor lars DO IT, like you will be doing yourself a disservice by not taking a class w him. he is so knowledgeable, makes lectures fun and interesting even when the topics aren't that intriguing. and he is so helpful, like if you have any issues he is super accommodating. please take a class w him, do it for me.
Lars is an incredible professor. There is no busy work in this course, so there are few graded things, making the class less stressful so you can focus on learning the content. 1000% recommend.

i took this class fall quarter and really liked it. the material was presented in an interesting and organized manner and lars definitely knows what he is talking about. the whole course is pretty easy and really doesn't require much effort. i appreciate his philosophy and learned a lot in this class

Professor Lars is a wonderful mentor and is really down to earth. I took a senior thesis course with him and he made the lengthy process very straight forward and interesting. He really knows his stuff and is very communicative about his expectations. If you are interested in a senior thesis in anthropology he is your guy!

By far the Best professor I have had for a GE (Even though it is upper division). Literally the class feels easier than any core or even high school class I have taken. In order to pass.... you literally just need to look at his slides and do the study guide before his test and you are find. He is very straight forward and he grades VERY EASY
Great person, recomended

If Lars isn't married/in a relationship, I don't understand why cause he's a great catch. Kind, smart, German accent, clean cut, and handsome. Obviously passionate about anthropology cause he can talk for hours. And nice class, he let us choose if we wanted to do a group project or take the exam because he took a poll and the class was split 50/50

Great class and great professor. Lectures were clear and organized. One group project and three take home exams. Lars is a professor who is willing to help his students and he creates a comfortable learning environment. Definitely recommend!
Dustin is a great lecturer and a great person. He is understanding, accomodating, and listens to his students. He gives great feedback and cares about student learning outcomes a lot.

Awesome professor, by far the best one available for this class. Just be aware that CSE 100 is NOT a 7 credit class, expect a workload of around 10+ credits, do not take this with any hard upperdivs (labs can take anywhere from 40 hours, to 80+).

Great professor with very understandable, engaging lectures. If you pay attention, the exams are very doable. Only concern for most people are the labs, but he covers the basics for the harder ones in class as well. Very active on the class forum as well.

The absolute GOAT of CSE 100. His lectures are very well structured which is necessary for a class like this. Gives extra participation points for showing up to class and helping people with labs. Labs are a huge time sink but aren't hard if you ask tutors and TA's for help. Exams are easier than the Homework and are graded lightly.

The professor is great, and knows their stuff. The grade is mainly based on 8 labs about 8% each and the final exam, with mandatory attendance. Lab difficulty varies, but the professor usually covers them in lecture, and the TAs are super helpful. The final was a bit tougher than expected, but overall, the class is well-structured and manageable.

Paper attendance sheets. Grades determined by lab assignment code submission and demos to TA. Posts lecture videos at the end of the week. Lectures sometimes not very helpful in solving the lab assignments. Nice guy but CSE 125 is definitely the weeder class if CSE 100 didn't sufficiently turn you off from being a CE major.
Might be the best professor I've had in college. Very difficult class, but lectures are very fun, and Dustin was a very entertaining professor. Would recommend 10/10

Lectures were engaging and also entertaining. Contained lots of important information for the labs. Lecture slides seem ill-prepared but any important mistakes are eventually corrected. Labs are difficult, but fair. They test your knowledge of the class material pretty comprehensively.

Honestly I really enjoyed taking his CSE101 course. He explains topics really clearly and if he catches you cheating(for any reason) he just gives you 0s. While his PAs aren't the easiest to do, they're also not that difficult. His exams are pretty self-explanatory. Overall, he is the GOAT for CSE101. I'll miss having him.

i have taken a lot of different classes with tantalo. tantalo is probably the best 101 teacher: he is excellent in that class. but the math based ones, not so much. the lectures are really dense and confusing. be prepared for lots of supplemental lectures. his midterm review and final review are v similar to tests though.

Tantalo's teaching style works well for CSE 101, not as much for 107. Lectures are slow paced and can lull you to sleep at times since they last for 1 and a half hours or more. There is a lot of abstract content that the lectures struggle to clarify. Homework is very dense and takes a lot of time, so if you don't start early you might not finish.
He's the only professor I've had that actually had a useful study guide.
asfafafsafsafsfsafsafsa

Lecture is two times a week, every week includes a supplemental lecture you need to watch in your own time (often 2+ hours). Exams are harsh with partial credit, and often have questions that build on previous answers, so nothing is forgiving. Lectures are mind-numbing, Tantalo should find something he's better at teaching.

Professor Tantalo definitely knows the topics he teaches well and answers questions clearly. Tests aren't super difficult if you study well for them, but you definitely do need to study quite a bit. Overall not a bad class, and the topics are pretty memorable.

Lectures were slow but helpful. Lots of homework, and not guaranteed full points for hw because of Crowdgrader. Quizzes 1-3 okay, quiz 4 harder. Don't stress too much for the quizzes. I recommend practicing homework problems to prepare for the final (Tantalo's review also had most of the material on the final). No opportunity for extra credit.
Really uninformative when it comes to tests. Lectures are informative but very dry, very test heavy. There's a lot of homework. Quizzes were easier then homework but final was hard.

Lectures are very straightforward and to the point. Writes down all his notes handwritten and is great at explaining topics. Also, easy to reach outside of class and is transparent on grading. However, deadlines/quiz dates are hard to keep track of, since he prefers his website (which has no notifications) over canvas. Also not a fan of crowdgrader
Lectures are entertaining to listen to. The class is based on four bi-weekly quizzes and a non-cumulative final. Labs are super easy to understand and complete.

Weekly homework and labs with bi-weekly quizzes makes the class kind of stressful. The content is hard to learn as is but he does a really good job with lectures. However I also recommend doing the textbook readings he assigns, that's really helped me. He also uses crowd grader which I personally like.

Horrible. Doesn't care about students. Lectures feel rushed, crammed, and boring. 4 quizzes and final that r closed notes and difficult, doesn't provide resources to help students prepare.
