Forces u to grade other students work. Does everything old-fashioned, like babe its 2025. 90 min supplemental lectures which he expects u to watch.

His lectures are long, boring, and difficult to make it through them and retain information. He frequently has supplemental lectures. Homework is graded by students, each student has to grade 5 other students homework submissions and your grading is worth 20% of the homework grade. He assigns 35-50 questions a week which take a minimum of 2 hours.

Makes no sense. He does not utilize canvas and expects you to use his website, which looks like it's from the 1990s. Very hard to keep track of assignments bc of this. Basically 4 midterms disguised as "quizzes". Doesn't make announcements and is out of touch. Very dry lecturer. Crowdgrader is annoying and makes you grade other students' work.

Pros: He rages to comments he doesn't agree on reddit, which is quite funny
Cons: Bad prof
honestly mid

Tantalo is super stingy with grades. He won't round your grade unless it is a tenth of a percent to the nearest whole number. I may sound salty, but many others encountered the same thing as me. Just retire unc

The class is alright. Make sure to start on your assignments early and PLEASE test your code through the grader they give you, so you don't lose 40 points on a lab for a segfault you didn't notice. Exam review problems are very similar to actual exam content, and plenty of pseudocode for labs are available on the website.

He's overall a good professor. The most annoying thing is the extra makeup lectures he gives because he doesn't get through material fast enough. The midterms and finals are much easier than the homeworks. Reviewing the discussion and review problems are more than enough to pass the midterms and finals.
Good class however the lectures are disorganized sometimes. Study hard for the final, it tests your conceptual understanding heavily.

Biweekly tests, 3 are closed-note coding tests, 2 are algorithm closed-note paper tests. You need a 70% average for all tests (1 dropped) to pass the class. Homework assignments due every few weeks, but have almost no effect on your grade. This professor has a poor course structure and you will be constantly studying for tests the entire quarter.

The logistics in this class were a mess, nearly every grading policy was reworked half way through. Decent lecturer. Though boring, lectures did not align with homeworks/tests entirely. To pass the coding you must memorize 4 different solutions you come up with ahead of time. Homeworks are heavy/unrealistic and most people used AI. Take others.

Montazeri is a caring professor. She wants to see her students do well. Although the class structure was seemingly unorganized at times, you can tell she strives to improve her class. TA's are very helpful if you go to office hours. You can do well in this class if you put in the work.

The lectures are decent and the professor clearly knows her stuff very well. It was easy to get help in the class and if you needed to talk to her, then you could join the office hour zoom sessions which often didn't have all that many people in them. Overall a good professor.
The lectures are very special. She is very caring about the students, but they are extremely boring.

I love Professor Montazeri. She was passionate about machine learning. She explained complicated things clearly. She understands machine learning. She asked questions to validate our understanding. She structured and presented insightful material. She has instructive quizzes and polls.

She presented the material in steps and we could follow. She also motivates the importance of the material. She was the most engaging professor I've had a class with at UCSC. She spent a lot of effort to engage the students in the class. I was looking forward to her lectures.
Heavy accent, she doesn't know the material she's teaching, just reading from slides. Consider testout

Lectures weren't very engaging, and everything said was on the slides. Grading is mainly based on online coding notebooks and four mcq quizzes - reading the slides a few days prior should be sufficient preparation, and the lowest quiz is dropped. Not much learned from the class, so consider the  testout, but the workload and grading were fine.

Has a lot of lectures that don't effectively teach you about the content on the quizzes and homework. The homework seems especially removed from the content of the lecture. Each quiz is worth 10% of your grade with a total of 4 quizzes per quarter. She goes on a lot of tangents. You basically learn everything yourself before one of the quizzes.

you can use chatgpt for homework, but lectures are useless. her quizzes are hard to study for bc i feel like the questions are not good and its easy to miss a lot of points even if you studied well. she just reads off the slides and her slides are so long,there was like over 2000 slides for the quarter. i shouldve just taken testout

Other professors are much better, but this she doesn't know how to code at least from experience because she just reads off slides from other professors(doesnt do well in that either) which makes it hard to understand.can barely help with coding, and wants you to learn DSA which is a fundamental topic, on your own Avoid this professor at all costs.

Understanding her lectures was hard. Being a professor for 101 as well, I was really stuck on linked list, and I asked her how I could solve it, and she could not even solve it on her own and expected me to understand it from the TA. If you are a professor and the deadline has passed for the assignment, you can surely show the student how to code.

The CSE40 course is terrible. Attendance is mandatory, but the slides used in class will not hepl your homework or quizzes. A test every 2 week, but the Study Guide and slides provided are completely inconsistent with the quiz.I would strongly recommend attend Testout not this class.
i think it's her first time teaching so it's really disorganized, she seems nice but lectures aren't very helpful with anything
cse40 could've been an email

Don't listen to negative comments out there and judge. She has amazing tutors and stayed three hours extra after class to help a student with their hw assignment when they were stuck. She's also very encouraging and nice if you ask. As long as you practice Codio tests ahead of time, start the homework early, and practice a lot you will be fine.

Bad professor, so disorganized and all over the place. She shows up 5 minutes before class starts and starts "working" on class slides until 7 minutes class has already begun. She inherited slides from Lise Getoor and still can't seem to follow the script. Voice is so monotone and hurts my ears

Niloofar is great, but she gets a bad rap because she is new. Her cse 140 class is super chill, but you won't do well if you don't go to class. Same for cse40 but that's just true of the class in general. People expect to sleep through class and do well, and are salty when they don't. Mad respect for her.

he's nice, but it's pretty clear that he's unorganized. you don't get your tests or assignments graded until really late after into the semester, so our second midterm was graded right before our final. he also assigns projects along with tests, so there's a lot to do. homeworks are also a lot of writing. you need to self study to get a good grade.

Kind, well-intentioned, a little funny. All you need is the zyBook for learning, you don't need to pay attention to lectures much since they're mostly examples. Workload is menial but plentiful & comprehensive. 2/3rds of test questions are from reviews so do them. A little disorganized, but he really isn't that bad. I'd say it's easier than lin alg

Professor Miller was very considerate and caring, but the sheer lack of organization in the class was insane. He would constantly mislead us about when things would be graded and it generally threw off the pace of the entire class. His grading policy and exams were fair and reasonable. Nothing too hard about the class, and generally taught well.

Miller cares about his students and will help if you need. In general, takes long to grade and finished grading our 2nd midterm the day of our final. Exams aren't too bad though because he gives a question bank from which he pulls 2/3's from. Material wasn't too hard it just got confusing towards the end so make sure you use your resources properly
super unorganized and projects are super unneccessary. not a bad professor, just lacks the managment skills that other professors in the baskin program have.

Seems like a caring and good person, but is very disorganized at times, and takes too long to grade. We took a whole new midterm before getting the grades for the first one, which made it difficult to study for it. He also assigned lengthy projects in the last week, which feels unnecessary at this point in the quarter when we could be studying.

Literally only rambles on the subject and makes it unbearably confusing, I've learned more through youtube than lectures to the point that I regret paying tuition. For a class that's supposed to help setup for an uppervision(cse101) I can't see myself being able to learn anything if it comes time to apply the concepts from this class into anywhere.

Miller is definitely unorganized. He comes to class late and takes a while to grade things, but he's passionate about discrete and you can tell. His lectures are mainly examples so you need to stay on track if you go. I feel like we got rushed towards the end so combinatorics which imo is the hardest concept and is practically the whole final

The professor seems nice enough, but is very disorganized. About 4 weeks into the class, he stopped doing written weekly homework, but decided to pick it back up close to the end of the quarter. He also assigns pre- and post- midterm projects, which were tedious and incredibly unhelpful. Our first hw was due Oct 10th, but still hasn't been graded.

HE GRADED FIRST MIDTERM AFTER WE DID THE SECOND MITERM, AND STILL HASNT GRADED THE SECOND MIDTERM WHEN THE FINAL IS IN 2 DAYS. HE POSTS THE STUDY GUIDE A DAY BEFORE THE EXAMS  AND THE EXAMS ARE WORTH YOUR ENTIRE GRADE. YOU DONT EVEN KNOW THE BALLPARK OF WHAT YOUR GRADE COULD BE UNTIL AFTER THE COURSE IS OVER. TAKE AnY OTHER TEACHER FOR THIS COURSE.

Basically, if you like self studying it's good if not then don't take it. Pray for office hours. Also hard to contact. Grades were not released on time because he never updated and midterm scores were given like the week before the final which gave no time for revision in topics you did bad in.
This dudes great. He is very chill and funny. He makes this class fun and it's a lot of work, but if you like math and programming it is a blast.

Professor requires readings before lectures and homework assignments are manageable. Professor expects you to know and understand all of the terms and only goes over examples (which are just proofs) in class. He does allow cheat sheets for exams and is open to some suggestions. He is also always late and doesn't seem very organized.

Most caring professor. Up to 10% extra credit and listens to student's feedback. yes, the class was unorganized which resulted in the heavy workload at the end, but he made up for it by grading very very generously and basically giving us the final. Cheat sheets allowed on midterms. People complaining didn't study/use extra cedit.

Great guy, class was a nice break from all the coding classes. Disorganized since it was his first attempt but he constantly listened to feedback and did his best to adjust so I'm sure he'll have it down for the future. Gave lots of chances to earn a good grade. Zybooks were also great for practice and learning. Hard at times but was pretty fun.

Kyle Miller was my bane. This class was so unorganized by the end. He kept changing the syllabus, two projects worth more than 15% of our grade was assigned in the last two weeks because he forgot about them, and there were lots of other minor things. He cared about you, but it was hard to get past the (lack of) structure. Read the zybooks!!

lot of students complaining about nothing. supposed to have mini-projects every 1-2 weeks. around halfway through the quarter no mini-projects were assigned but people were asking about them (teacher you forgot to collect the homework type shi). then he finally assigned one at the end and the same people started complaining about extra work

He's a nice guy who listens to students and clearly knows his stuff when it comes to the material. Since the grades were scaled to add up to 110%, there were quite a few potential opportunities for extra credit. The class was pretty disorganized, especially towards the end, though this was the first time he taught the class.
very good teacher, offered so many opportunities for people to do good and listens to all of students complaints.

I had Miller his first quarter teaching cse16. The class was scaled to 110%, with many assignments but lenient grading. Class was a bit unorganized, but he's nice, easy to contact, and listens to students. Midterms were doable. We had a 41-page question bank instead of a final review, where some questions were guaranteed on the final
Very inappropriate conduct towards students.
Alright at teaching, but not good at running a class. The automated grading system give very little feedback so you end up having to grade things yourself to see where mistakes were made.

Exams were multiple choice and easy to study for he gives sample past exams and they're like identical to the ones you take. Labs were also pretty easy, but can be really time consuming. Last lab of doom and agony. I'll probably take him again for 120
you should attend his lectures because he is surprisingly ripped and he explains things very well

Took him for CSE12 in year 1; it was not really good, but he has changed a lot. Maybe it just took a little time for him to adjust, and to be fair, this class is also much easier. Attendance is pop quizzes that can come up, but are only worth 1% or so. He is a pretty average or even good professor in my recent experience, super chill.

Lectures can get boring. Not the greatest at explaining things. Absolutely terrible handwriting. Good TA's. Labs are hard. Go to section though, and you'll be fine. Overall, he's a very knowledgeable professor, lecturing skills just lacking. I'm sure I would have gotten a better experience from this class had I gone to office hours. B tier overall.

Attendance isn't mandatory, though there are occasionally 1-question pop quizzes in class to make sure you were listening. Slightly difficult topic, go to discussion sections if needed. He has a slight accent during lectures but it's not that bad.

Projects can be a little difficult; however, they are done completely asynchronously, meaning you can get tutoring for them. In-class midterms and final were very easy, almost exactly the same as the study guide released on Canvas. Will randomly have in-class attendance quizzes however, lab sections are completely optional., only for help on labs.

Lol previous reviewer a bum. I don't think he claimed to be curving grades except for removing one quiz grade. I'm also pretty sure that he explicitly said during lectures that grades are going to be what they are and there will not be any curves. He does have a slight accent, but I can understand him well. Good prof and lectures are posted online.

I was only 1% away from the next letter grade, however, even though this professor had said that they would curve at the beginning of this quarter, he failed to curve at all at the end of this course. You could say that I am pretty salty, but if this professor fails to do what he had stated that he would do, I think I also get to be upset.

professor has a bit of an accent which already makes it difficult to understand what he's saying. imagine he's talking but u can't understand him so u look at what he's writing and boom u can't read what he's writing either. most of the time you'll be hella confused during lecture so pick another prof

Nath is OK, I am sure this computer architecture class is easier than others but it still requires work to understand the material. The tests are reasonably difficult but the lecture slides prepare you well. In person lectures are hard to follow and the course staff can be dismissive / hard to contact.
Didn't go to a single lecture and got an A, that's how easy this class is.

Way better at explaining concepts than Sierro who I took for CSE12, so that in itself is a plus. Lecture slides are posted online but pop quizzes keep attendance mandatory. Homework is difficult but has pretty reasonable due dates

Knowledgeable professor, but not very personable. Passive aggressive responses to questions during lectures and office hours (which were unsurprisingly empty 😒). Work is left out of lecture slides to force attendance. Pop quizzes are always able to be corrected after class. Labs can be quite challenging, work early and with friends or TAs.

Just finished the final exam and it was pretty manageable given the prep material. The exams overall weren't bad at all but the labs, especially lab 4 was brutal. Thankfully, the TAs were very helpful in the session I went to and I was able to complete it 2 days before the due date.
Needs to improve handwriting and everything else too

Having the class in the late afternoon in a very hot lecture all was definitely a detriment. That said, I found the lectures by themselves very straightforward. The main issue was the labs which were harder than I had anticipated, especially lab 4. Thankfully, all the TAs in the lab sections and the tutors in office hours were very helpful.

Sagnik Nath is not a good professor. He is extremely condescending and makes comments towards those who come into class late, although he was late several times. Handwriting looks like chicken scratch, and the way of teaching is very hard to understand. Labs are worth a majority of your grade but you have to learn how to do them from a TA.Goodluck!

all material and quizzes online. forgets to upload a lecture online occasionally. all concepts are simple to grasp although nath isn't the best lecturer. in person exams are very fair and similar to HW + you can bring cheat sheet with anything.
recommend taking with 130 as some content with caches will overlap near the end of the quarter

One of the worst professors I've ever had, awful at explaining, and even teaching, often late, assignments are very finicky.

Last lab worth 15% of the grade is a complete mess, and there is absolutely no trouble shooting or bug fixing.

I actively dislike him.

This was overall a fairly engaging class. Nath tried to make every concept digestible, even the nefarious pipeline wave diagrams. Thanks Shrek! His exams had some questions not in the slides but covered in lecture so make sure to either attend or watch the recordings later

The professor was fair overall. The material was challenging. We had four labs that took a lot of time, but they helped a lot with understanding the material. The midterm was very difficult, while the final was more manageable. Overall, the class was okay.

Hardest class I've taken so far. Computer systems are no joke, be PREPARED to not understand everything at first. Marcelo is difficult but fair. Do the labs and work with your peers even if it's online. He gives enough extra credit. Lots of self-studying but is rewarding in understanding the subject. Take a diff prof if you want an easier time.

He's not good at teaching at all. He rushes through the slides and barely bothers to explain most topics. Also, 3 days before the final exam, during finals week, he assigned 4 online assignments out of nowhere that were due 36 hours after being posted on canvas late at night. Genuinely horrible.

Just generally a very inaccessible teacher and uncommunicative. One of those teachers that has/was given slides and reads off them, and demands respect that he doesn't really deserve considering the quality of education he provides. Take this class with someone else

Do not take his class. His lecture slides are a complete mess and he doesn't address anything that are written on it. Most of the time I was constantly self studying to keep up with this course. He is absolutely incompetent at teaching and you will seriously suffer. He's not a bad person, just hella incompetent on so many levels. DO NOT TAKE HIM!

His lectures suck and don't explain the material very well. He writes the tests to be super difficult (~60% average) and compensates by putting a ridiculous curve on it, all while criticizing the students for scoring poorly (???). Homework is challenging, but doable. 

As someone who ended up taking Nath for CSE120, take Nath instead.

I would not retake this class. The lectures are not that helpful. The labs are extremely helpful and pretty doable with the right help. There's no practice midterm or final, so don't expect to be prepared for them. The avg. for the midterm was low. It's easy to feel like you know so much, yet still feel like you know so little at the same time.

Could not understand his lectures, so I stopped attending them halfway through. Tough midterm, but final made up for it. HARD labs, reach out to TAs and tutors for help. Take advantage of the extra credit. Great person, just not the best teacher.

Passionate, has experience from the industry but lectures are very boring; seems to go over the history of topics better than actual content. Be prepared to study the topics more yourself and use resources to understand better. Get help with the labs anywhere you can, quizzes have multiple tries, extra credit opportunities, proctored final/midterm

Very good professor who knows what he is teaching. Lectures sometimes get a bit off track but he provides what is needed to understand the material. Midterm is hard but he let everyone retake it. Labs make up almost all of your grader and ample support and time is provided to complete them. Weekly quizzes can be retaken.
I had Marcelo for 123A and 123B, learned a lot, and made something that I can put on my resume at the end. He gave good suggestions and was very supportive. Definitely take him for your capstone!

His lectures are bad and super boring. Labs are most of your grade and he gives ample time, if you work with classmates you'll get through those and the weekly quizzes. My class did very poorly on the midterm (median 55%) and he blamed us. However he is forgiving (ie. letting us basically retake the midterm during finals)

Marcelo was a great professor during our 123A and 123B capstone courses. His wide-ranging engineering knowledge and enthusiasm made a big impact. He was easy to talk to, gave great feedback, and really helped the team grow and stay motivated throughout the project.

Marcelo is a great professor and mentor. I had him for both 123A and B, and he was always supportive and insightful. He has tons of experience and a real passion for engineering, which made him super helpful throughout our capstone. He's approachable, encouraging, and truly cares about his students.
Organized, but such a boring lecturer and random attendance. Literally just drones on and on

This class was so hard. the labs are tough but manageable, and his lecture notes arent useful no matter how much he tells you to look at them. The TAs were my saving grace, being that Siero couldnt explain anything in a way that was understandable to a beginner coder (me). He does give a ton of EC tho, and you will most def need it if you want an A

Very caring professor, but doesn't explain things very well. His online lectures are confusing often. Very little HW/CW which gives you very little practice with the material. Labs get harder, but all very doable with some time and effort. Lock in before midterm and final, very difficult. Them being open notes does not help you.

You'll see that the ratings vary since Siero cares, is passionate, & knows his stuff, but isn't the best teacher. Lacks CW/HW which seems good but it makes learning harder. Lectures can be hard to understand sometimes. ATTEND DISCUSSIONS FULLY FOR LABS. Not satisfied with this class & didn't leave wanting to learn more about computer architecture.

This term had a lot of difficulties, with a very harsh midterm (and final). The recent ratings reflect that. However, I'll add that this professor is on the better end of the scale of generosity and empathy with grading/deadlines, and is probably one of the nicest ones you'll have the chance to deal with. Next term will most likely adjust things.

Took online and lectures are useless. Labs are light work, should take only like an hour or two. Pirate a pdf of the textbook and skim it and you'll be good. Also watch the review lectures he gives before the midterm/final. Those cover the entire content in like 45 minutes each. Don't stress this class.
The professor definitely  wasn't the most organized, but his lectures were really good and he has no finals, and all the quiz questions are given to us before the quiz so plenty of time to study

Great professor, really good at explaining *why* algorithms work / giving the intuition. Very easy to do well in and learn a lot from. All problems/questions for the tests were given in advance so you could study them exactly, which reduced stress a lot, lowest 2/6 tests dropped. Only bad thing was having to pay for the homework platform

The class was semi difficult but grading was kind of clear. It's a weird grading system where you need to score a certain amount on the tests to pass the class and then grade is determined by HW. The tests were hard for me but if you have grinded leet code they should be easy. You also get the questions options before hand and get one of them.

No syllabus or really much information at all until almost three weeks in. Told us to reach out to him if we need help paying for the required subscription for homework, which I did. All he said was I could pay for it, in a dry message on Piazza. Pretty terrible teacher, but the class isn't too hard.

This was honestly one of the best classes I've taken at UCSC! The prof can be a little unorganized at times, but his lectures are great and he explains things really clearly. The grading is mostly based on tests, but he shared past exam questions which made prepping a lot easier.

No syllabus until 4 days into week 1, your grades rely on 5 tests and 4 homework assignments. The HW assignments (so far) have lack-luster instructions and are confusing at times. Uses the worst possible website to do HW and test, which we have to pay 40$ for. Copied code YOU wrote in a previous class and used it? Nope, you're done bud, plagiarism.

This is by far the worst teacher I've had throughout my entire educational career. This is an embarrassing display of incompetence. Do not expect fast answers, if any at all. Expect unfair grading, uninformed TAs, and poor communication overall. You will have to teach yourself C++, since he explicitly says he will NOT teach any in this class.

Professor Ahmad does a great job explaining things during lectures and is always open to answering questions from students. There are regular homeworks and lab assignments, which really helped me stay on top of the material. The tests are long and a big part of the grade, but the reading materials he shares beforehand are super helpful.

The professor explains complex course material in a very clear and approachable way, making it easy to understand. I genuinely learned a lot and appreciated the structured and engaging teaching style.

HW and labs are fairly chill. Exams are most of the grade, albeit with generous curves. He gave out exams from last year as study prep, which helped a little but not exactly the same. HW interface could be more modern but still helps as studying material. His lectures were dry but answered questions well usually. Pretty ok professor, worth taking.

Was this prof's first quarter at UCSC so class was a bit disorganized, not sure why he uses sites from 2004 for the hw. The labs could use a revamp for the modern day too. Still you learn SQL and relational databases inside and out. midterm + final is 70% of your grade but both curved very generously, if you study even a bit you should be fine.

The professor teaches pretty well. However, how the course is structured (10% homework + 20% labs + 30% midterms + 40% finals) means that getting a good grade is very tough. Midterm was curved generously. If you care about your GPA, don't take this class. Nonetheless, you learn a lot about databases, but most of it you could self-study online.

Not great not terrible. He teaches but not the best and glosses over some pretty important topics that show up on exams, which is disproportionally weighted in this class. And for the more complex topics there's just not enough examples so self prep for that. Also a bit boring. Low class average on midterm. Not an easy class but you will learn.

This professor is so annoying. Took a very easy class with him, and he made my life hell. He will yell and get upset if you ask him questions in officehours.  I struggled in class even though I spent 20+ hours on this class per week. I would recommend taking this class with ANY OTHER professor as I am sure you will have a much better experience.

Sesh is one of those teachers that is challenging but you learn a lot. That being said, he isn't overly challenging like some professors I've met. He's one of the top professors I've ever had.  Quizzes are structured like Leetcode job interviews, if you can't code under pressure don't take him.

Sesh teaches the concepts very well. You get 5 tests (drops lowest) and 4 hw assignments. The tests are straight forward, he'll give you the pool of problems beforehand. The hw is not too difficult but it is very time consuming (*start early*) dw you'll feel accomplished if you get a 10. He is a fair grader as long as you are willing to learn.
Making student grade each other's homework while not giving out solutions is just not it. People just grade based on what they think its correct, which creates a lot of chaos
5 Tests, all of them structured around doing leetcode questions revolving the current data structure being reviewed. 4 homeworks, a bit time consuming but not the worst. amazing lecturer

Sesh is an amazing lecturer, I'm originally in the other section for this class but was struggling so bad in the other lecture! However after showing up to his lectures instead, Sesh really made it feel like a college level course. Helps you prepare for homework's and tests to come!!!

Sesh is an amazing professor. His class is difficult but it's worth the tuition. I am a transfer student and his class humbled me because there is a lot of things I still have to learn and grow. Ask him a lot of questions, he wants you to succeed not only in college but your career. I definitely recommend to take any of his classes that he teaches.

Absolutely amazing professor. His lectures are super useful and really prepared me for coding interviews. His assignments are tough and his quiz questions are also very tough but the grading scale is generous and you'll come out a master at Data Structures and Algorithms after taking this course.
Sesh is an excellent professor. He is harsh, but it's okay. His class is essential for all the CS/CE students. It makes you prepare for all the other CSE courses and your career.

I see the other comments complaining about Sesh's difficulty (which is kind of ridiculous). Sesh is probably one of the best CS Professors you will ever have. He prepares you extremely well for both upper division and technical interviews. If you focus on studying his test questions, you should be fine in his class and in your career. 100% rec Sesh

The labs are hard and focused more on solving a puzzle rather than the data structure, which is mostly implemented for you. His grading scale doesn't differentiate between those who didn't do the labs/tests, and those who tried and failed. You can fail ½ the labs and still get a B. Id rather get an A in another class and watch his lectures on YT.
He's a good lecturer, knows how to explain topics well for the most part, but his homeworks and tests were hard.

This is the prof you want to take to prepare you for software engineer interviews. Code *all* practice exam questions to prepare for tests (focus on doing this first and hw later if you have time). The tests are very manageable if you can code the practice questions. Remote was good for lecture recordings. You're encouraged to ask questions.

Worst CS class with this prof I have ever taken. Lectures weren't cover the hw and test materials. Be ready to stay up the whole week to do hws and study for tests but still get 0. Tough grading either you get a perfect score 10 or nothing 0. TA won't help you that much so good luck with that.

The course is essentially P90x for your brain. You will come out a much better coder if you have not taken this course before. The tests and homework are both pass or fail style, where you will most likely get a perfect score if you have a correct solution, and almost nothing if not. The homework assignments will steal a lot of sleep from your life

Best CS professor EVER. The test is useful and helps you to understand the concept and CODE INTERVIEW!!!!!! Homework is fantastic but hard. It is all application-based and you really need to work HARD to figure it out. In his class, you are really WORKING and LEARNING. Take it if you have a chance, you will not regret it. 6/5 RATE!!!!!
Take Sesh if you get the chance. Guarantee he will improve your programming skills by a mile. Very tough assignments but they'll all improve your skills by a lot

If you are "suffering" on your journey of learning, that is good news. Why? It's the same thing as doing push-ups make your body sore. If you don't feel sore, did you really exercise? Sesh does this style of teaching very well. His immense care for students can easily be sensed, but know that he seems worn out sometimes, from the sheer workload.

Be ready to suffer. Sesh is a very difficult professor and he makes you truly do things. I suffered a whole quarter with him but I learned A LOOOTTTTTT. Overall, the best professor in the CSE department. Try to take as many classes as you can with him if you want to study cs. But again, you will suffer.

I've taken 12B and 101 with Sesh and had a good experience, so I chose to take 130 with him. What followed was by far the hardest class I've ever taken. Sesh does a pretty good job of teaching, but dear lord this is a beast of a class. It was his first time teaching it so it might be easier next time, but be aware that Sesh does not go easy here.

Worst class I've taken at UCSC. Exams are based on slides, and he quizzes you on small details that don't show up anywhere besides 1 lecture. The CTF assignments he gave us were unrelated to the lecture content, and he provided no resources to help us understand them. The LLM final project had some sample notebooks, but none of them ran properly.

Very Knowledgable, lectures are directly on the MC exams, teaches everything in a digestible and entertaining way, in person exams but still very doable and interesting. Offers tons of extra credit, and there's sets bonus on top of that. No final or midterm, just 3 exams each worth 13% but you can replace 1 or 2 grades with EC. Great course!

Lectures are mostly just slide-reading and doesn't explain things very well. Easy open-everything tests and HW is mostly the Zybooks which is tedious but useful for learning more about security concepts outside of class content. Occasional CTF HWs that you kinda have to figure out on your own, and can be fun but challenging.

The homework is mostly Zybooks (tedious) & Zylabs (utterly worthless). The labs are just pointless activities like setting up user accounts or changing password policy on Windows Server, which is barely related to the class at all. The rest of the homework is CTFs, and he never teaches the skills you need to solve them.
Great professor and an interesting class. Lots of extra credit opportunities.

Has pretty good lectures with in-depth slides showing current day examples of fundamentals and how our lesson could be applied. Did some cool live demonstrations to showcase security systems and their weaknesses. Overall cool guy, gives out a ton of extra-credit, if you generally care about the subject or security, you can get an A very easily

Amazing cybersecurity lectures, not much homework. This quarter we had about 4 homework assignments and a small 10 minute quiz at the end of every week which is open notes. Exams are the same exact questions as quizzes so if you do well on those you'll pass, also gave tons of extra credit work you could do to get an A. Really applicable content.

This is one of the classes where it starts off super easy and ends with extremely difficult material. As long as you pay attention in class and while reading, you should be able to get by easily. His grading policy is pretty cool and different.

Not an easy class, but not a hard one either, especially if you take advantage of the extra credit and the median grade. I would have never read a book about the "Universal Computer" but it was surprisingly engaging and gave me a new perspective in mathematics.

Disrespectful and mean.
I don't think he knew how to answer half of the questions he was asked, he would simply move on.
His lectures are awful and his slides are extremely heavy.
Stay away from a class with him.

Lectures are a waste of time.
He's simply there to get his paycheck.
Do not take a class with him. 80% of your questions won't be answered and he wouldn't be working anymore if it wasn't for his easy way of grading and the TA's.
I did not learn a single thing from this man.

The zybooks are extremely helpful to understand the concepts in class. The class is not immensely difficult. I would highly recommend attending TA sections if you need clarification. Over all great class and a unique grading system.

Professor Cardenas is such a good professor. I love his lectures and the visual novel makes his class more fun to take. The materials are difficult but if you go to his lectures he can explain everything. He also gives a lot of examples on proofs until everyone understands it.

This class was fairly straightforward with readings on zybooks. There are weekly quizzes and some tests. In order to succeed you should understand the concepts taught. This can be achieved by attending section/ MSI. Lectures were lively as the professor would respond to the zoom chat sometimes.

Cardenas is a really poor lecturer and honestly I don't think even he knows what he's talking about. I was trying to clarify course logistics in the class and he was extremely condescending. I definitely don't recommend taking any of his classes if you can. If you're a CS major, steer clear of his classes; try to take them with someone else.
My experience was pretty average. Definitely wasn't a horrible class, but it's also not easy. You will have to work hard for a 'good' grade.

Proffesor Sorensen has so much energy and a passion for what he does that really comes through in the quality of the lectures. Homework instructions were always very clear and we were given ample time and assistance to complete them. One of the best professors at UCSC and I highly encourage anyone with room in their schedule to take this class.

I loved this class! 5 programming HWs that get progressively harder (with some autograder kinks here and there) but they were always tied in to the content taught in lecture, and staff was super responsive & helpful with questions. Sorensen is approachable and kind in office hours, and encourages discussions in class about the content.

Awesome lecturer and lecture slides. Homework assignments varied in difficulty, they used a new autograder that had to be fixed sometimes which was a little frustrating. Midterm was a time crunch. There weren't practice problems for exams, so you really have to study the slides and HW. Highly recommend taking the class though, Sorensen is top tier.

The hardest CSE class I've taken, hands down, and I wouldn't have it any other way. It's honestly humbling how much there is to learn about concurrency. Lectures are fantastic and homeworks are fun. The exams are genuinely hard but worth the time. He did curve in the end, which was nice. Go to his office hours, they're really helpful!!!

Class was difficult and the coding assignments took some time, and the grading criteria is not only graded on end result, but also implementation and a report of implementations and behavior trends. 

Midterm and final felt very difficult

Enjoyed the class still, Tyler is a very fair person and good at explaining topics and easily accessible.

This is the first time he has given in person exams instead of take home exams for this class. Do not take if you care about your grade. If you take it pass/fail, it's a pretty good class. The extremely brutal exams make you learn all the class material to a very high level. Doesn't curve, so beware.

I've taken both 110A and 113 with this professor. Would not recommend if you care about your grade or if you have no other choice, You will learn the concepts well but you might still fail. No practice exams and cannot answer if you ask him how to prepare for the tests. Exams are extremely application-based. Also no curve.

211 is a continuation of 110A so take that first! Really fun class. You get the option to do a project with a lot of leeway, so do that! Concepts build off of 110 so it's not too difficult if you're familiar with compilers. Lectures are great and discussion oriented. Assignments aren't too hard but paper reviews can be time-consuming.

Classes are very engaging and discussion oriented, so don't skip class! In any case, he's probably the best professor in the CSE department. The content is really interesting and his lectures are definitely worth it. Exams feel like an extension of the work you do throughout the quarter i.e., building a compiler from the ground up. 10 outta 5.
This professor really cares about his students! He is the best professor I have had at UCSC. CSE 110A isn't a particularly easy class but it also isn't impossible. Super fun overall.

Tyler is really such a sweet guy and genuinely cares about the students. You can tell he really enjoys the class content and puts a lot of effort into his lectures. I want to be his friend outside of school, that's how cool he is

One of the best professors at UCSC. Material is difficult but he sets you up well for it with pseudocode and lectures. Explains difficult topics well with visual examples and goes through step by step at a good pace. Tests are challenging but extremely fair. Class is set up in a way that encourages learning and participation. 10/10

Tyler is a top 3 professor in the CSE dept, hands down. The assignments are dense, but doable. You have fun and learn a lot in them. His lectures are an amazing experience, he makes the content very intuitive. The exams are pretty tough, if the final didn't blindside me I would've kept an A lol. Definitely a must-take professor! Compilers are fun!

Tyler is a great teacher. Lectures are great and prepare you for exams and assignments.
Exams are hard.
Assignments are in Python. I did not know Python but it was easy to learn and complete assignments.
To understand the materials better, take CSE103 prior to this course.
I recommend taking at least one class with Tyler if you have a chance.

Great professor, but assignments are interesting and challenging. Very good methods of explaining concepts with detailed lecture slides, pseudocode, and diagrams that make the concepts understandable. Midterm and final were challenging as well but doable as they were take-home with longer time frame.

One of the most caring professors in the CS department here. He's passionate about the course, interesting, and extremely approachable. His lectures are also one of the best as they are concise and digestible.

Tyler is a passionate lecturer about this subject and does very well in organizing the material for the class. The lecture slides are easy to comprehend and a good study source for the homework and exams. A CSE120 background is not really needed to succeed in this class, though having a CSE130 background is useful for some of the modules covered.

Tyler was one of the best professors I've had in undergrad. The way he explains class material was unlike a majority of professors I have had before. Assignments were interesting and doable, but not too much help was available. I would recommend if interested in concurrency/parallel programming techniques.

Tyler is easily the best professor I've had at UCSC. His lectures are well structured and easy to access. His assignments don't take very long, but are well made and you will learn more from them than in much longer assignments from other classes. Midterm/final are take-home and very fair.

Awesome professor who organizes the class really well! Starts off every lecture with a review of the previous lecture and explains all of the content in easy-to-digest bits. The assignments are really interesting to work on and the take-home exams (one midterm and final), while brain-scratchers, are a very fair difficulty.

First time teaching was pretty good. I liked how she always reviewed the previous lecture to reinforce learning. I understood the material but wish that she didnt always use slides and used more code. Only gripe was that the group activities were useless. Homework was confusing at times but ultimately reflected material learned in class. No final.

The professor is new, so I get some of her struggles. The assignments are 50% of your grade. Her lectures go over theory and math -- never translating to coding the assignments. The tutors and TAs were helpful and are your best bet for doing well, but they can be inconsistent especially since there are other students who also need help.

Ethan is a knowledgeable and passionate professor. The class includes a big emulator project, which seems time-consuming at first, but TA office hours and tutoring help a lot. Homework is straightforward, and there's a weekly Monday quiz that he reviews. Overall, a great course—highly recommended!

Sifferman is enthusiastic about the content of 111. In his lectures, he takes a lot of time drawing out schematics and working out examples to make sure that everyone understands the problems he works on. He also sometimes goes over homework problems in class, which I found super helpful. The labs are time-consuming and tough, so ask for help.

Extremely disorganized. He held up the same 'miss a lab, fail the course' policy, yet he would delay on assigning them, and he would change the lab after it was assigned and we had pretty much all started. Tried to give him the benefit of the doubt as a new prof but it was so frustrating in such a high stakes course.

Unclear grading policies and syllabus. Reuses old lecture slides from curriculum created by old professor. Heavily encourages the use ChatGPT. Lectures often not helpful for implementing the code for programming with esp-idf on the ESP32-C3 board. Prepare to beg the TAs for help.

The projects were fun and interesting, and from what I've heard less time-consuming than when Martine Schlag taught the class. He definitely spent a lot of effort preparing lectures, where he draws circuits out and writes examples in Verilog, instead of talking over slides. If you did well in CSE12 this class shouldn't be much trouble.
For CSE 111, we wrote an emulator in C++ for a fictional game console, and that was probably the most fun I've had with a school project at UCSC.
CSE100 is a really hard class in general but Prof. Sifferman is so much better than Schlag. I feel like things are done more efficiently.

best prof i've ever had, and i've continued to take more of her classes! lectures are mandatory w some few passes, but theyre super entertaining as she Loves the subject. make sure to ask questions, she knows her stuff and her research is brilliant! the only assignments were midterms, final, and one or two assignments for a grade boost. love her!

Amazing! Fun lectures that explain the topics super well while still being engaging. Her experience in primatology is obvious, and it's clear how much she cares. Super excited to talk with students, and always has fun stories and tidbits. Graded for attendance, two short writing assignments, and 3 tests. Wonderful class no matter the major.
Amazing professor! Would definitely take her classes again. Lectures were interesting, just wish the quarter was a bit longer.

Professor Oelze was good. Her lectures are interesting and cover a wide variety of topics within Primatology; if you aren't already passionate about the subject, you will be. There aren't assignments or in-class activities, so your grade almost entirely depends on your attendance and high scores on 3 tests.  Show up and study and you'll pass.

Primates ecology and behavior has by far been the best class I've taken at UCSC. Vicky is an amazing professor and is so passionate and educated on the top. Mixing in great information and entertainment into a lecture was seamless and super enjoyable. I wish the lectures were longer! Hoping to take more classes with this professor.
highly recommend primate behavior!! vicky is amazing and that class is one of my favorites i've ever taken

I've taken two of her courses and both were amazing. If you attend her lectures, you are set for the exam. All exam questions are in her slides. She is very passionate in what she teaches and makes the lectures very entertaining. Definitely take this class!

I took an anatomy course with Vicky and it was the best class that I've ever taken. Early on I was concerned i was falling behind, but she allowed me to complete some extra credit projects and maintain my grade. I highly recommend taking any of her classes, she is funny, caring, intelligent, and interesting.  Ask about her collection of duck bones.

My only critique is I wish this class was longer! So much interesting information packed into an 1hr5min makes it hard sometimes to keep up with note taking. She is super sweet and makes learning about monkeys fun and interesting.

I took Evolution of The Human diet with Vicky past fall and fell in love! She values learning over memorizing and grades based off attendance, quizzes (based off assigned readings), and the midterm and exam. She is straightforward and will affirm your passion for anthropology if you're an anthro major. I cant wait to take more classes from here!
Fun/funny/interesting lectures. Clear about what will be on the tests. I recommend.
Very fun and interesting class. Very straightforward about what will be on the tests. No tedious unnecessary busywork.

Your grade consists of three online exams that are not difficult at all if you are coming to class, paying attention, and making sure you understand main points before the exams. Attendance is taken every class. Lectures are super entertaining, informative and the subject overall is awesome. If you're interested in primates, take this class!

She is super passionate and knowledgable about the subjects she teaches. Her lectures are always fun and interesting. The only downside is that grades are based only on exams, but they aren't too difficult as long as you attend lectures and study a bit. Definitely take a class with her if you get the chance.

Vicky Oelze is the best professor in the Anthro department and a wonderful mentor. All of her classes are relatively easy and straightforward; I highly recommend taking a course with Vicky. If you are interested in independent research related to bio anth or primatology, she is someone you definitely want to get to know. She rocks!
A really great lecturer. Tons of interesting material. Not really any homework. Tests are straightforward and if you attend lecture, pretty easy. Highly recommend.
Great Professor, made primatology super interesting. Grade is based on tests but tests were very fair if you study well for them. Respectful of students and accessible outside class

Vicky is very enthusiastic and funny. She has a great personality and can share her personal experience in the field which really adds to her credibility as a teacher. I took her Primate Ecology and Behavior class and I enjoyed it so much that I also took Stable Isotope Analysis with her! She is the best Anthro teacher at UCSC!

Vicky is an amazing professor! The class is really interesting and she makes it fun as well. The quizzes can be a little challenging, but the midterm and final are straightforward. DO THE PRESENTATION!!!
Vicky is an amazing professor. She is smart, funny, but most importantly she is very entertaining which makes the class fun. Her lectures were great, and the tests were fairly simple. ( ( )

Kramer was such an inspirational teacher and definitely one of my highlights this quarter. Every lecture was delivered with so much passion. Even though the course was a tad confusing at first, we always broke-down the readings in small and large group discussions. She was beyond caring and always loved to hear our class' thoughts.
Best professor I've ever had- both content wise and what she teaches and how, and also personally. Clearly cares about topics taught as well as student learning and satisfaction.

Alejandra is such a great lecturer. She always includes anecdotes that reinforce the topics that she is covering. She has a lot of lore and likes to share it, and I think that is an entertaining quality in a professor. She also deeply cares about world issues and is vocal about them.
Professor Kramer is one of the best anthro professors at UCSC. She cares deeply about teaching, her materials, and her students. I've taken several classes with her and always enjoy them.
good at her job so smart
Her way to teach is simple with not heavy loads of homework
Get ready to read an participate in class lectures

This class is very interesting and Kramer is a wonderful teacher. She is very engaging and inspiring. Her class was very easy to pass too. There were only 4 assignment, 1 online midterm, and 1 online final. I really enjoyed learning about the class topics with her and they made me think about my own life and interactions with my community.

I took ANTH 2, and I did not expect the amount of reading and work required for the intro class. There were four essays, one midterm, and one final. For the midterm and final, you will have to answer multiple choice questions and write two essays for the midterm, and three essays for the final. There is also a time limit.

She gave us a ton of readings which is the main reason why I put that she was of a harder difficulty, however she does go over a ton of the material in class itself and will regularly clarify if you ask questions. She really enjoys talking about the subject so the insights she gives because of it tend to be extremely helpful.

The class I took was about feminist ethnography and was super interesting. Almost all of the work is reading, writing responses, and discussing the material in class, so if you do not like that format I would not recommend you take her classes. She's very nice and is an interesting person. The class left me thinking afterward and she taught it well

Extremely unclear in her expectations for assignments. Her lectures are so boring and often don't make any sense. Also very difficult to talk with over email. She doesn't know how to use canvas AT ALL (unlocking quizzes, coding the right answers for quizzes), ie one quiz she said she had all the answers marked incorrectly and refused to open it!

She was super nice and for a senior seminar there was very little homework. The subject was interesting and she genuinely wanted everyone to enjoy the course. She could talk for a long time but only because she was passionate. It helps if you aren't scared to interrupt her and bring your own ideas to the discussion. It was a stress free class!

Took two classes with her. Could not hold my attention in class in the slightest. Made the class very difficult. Just could not connect with any of the material and didnt get a lot of clarification from lectures.

She requires a five minute presentation with a four page paper and one page single spaced weekly response paper. Participation is mandatory! She is very nice and sincerely cares about each and every one of her students. Also, there is a lot of reading and it can be quite dense.

Professor Kramer is absolutely amazing. Feminist ethnography will forever be one of my favorite anthro classes taken here because of her. She's a very approachable teacher and I never left class feeling like I learned nothing new. She demands class participation which keeps things interesting rather than listening to lecture all day. SHE IS GREAT.

Alejandra is an extremely knowledgable professor! She definitely loves class participation so don't be afraid to speak up and ask questions. There was a midterm, a book review, and a final. She also takes attendance seriously so go to class. As seen in other comments, she does give out A's, but well deserved ones.

Her lectures were uninteresting and hard to understand. You definitely have to put in a good amount of work. There was no midterm, but two papers and one multiple choice final. I feel like the course had such an interesting topic, but the class itself was rather unengaging.
Alejandra was a fabulous professor. I loved the classes I took with her. Go to lecture, complete the readings and the class will be interesting and fun. And she does believe in A- as she gave me one.

Alejandra is a great teacher.  She takes attendance so it is best not to miss class but usually her classes are interesting and she is fun to look at :)  Her online lecture notes are very helpful for her exams.  She is also very eager to talk to you outside of class.  She does give out A's.  But mostly B's.

Carla is a wonderful person, she is so kind, but I wasn't a fan of her teaching style. A “low stakes” assignment that was intended to inform her on what students were learning, had a median class grade of 50%. She was failing students on a low stakes assignment, she expected a summary of the lectures rather than key points.

Carla was the most understanding and caring professor I've had since being at UCSC. Senior seminars are usually tough in general so expect a high level of reading and engagement. If you speak a lot in discussions, it goes a long way. My advice is to go to her office hours and show her that you care about your grade. Carla absolutely rocks.

Dr. Hernández is a really great professor. She is very enthusiastic and knowledgeable about her work, and her lectures always include great visuals of sites, ceramics, and artifacts. There can be lot of reading but it's the same amount of reading as most Anthro courses tbh; they're also very relevant and helpful for lectures. Great humor too!

Tons of readings, then in class she reviews them entirely, eventually reading or attending feels pointless. Group projects, without class time to prepare, but pre-work activities to keep you "engaged". Discussions, hypothesis annotations on supplemental readings. Frustrating there with so many assignments while trying to balance with other classes.
Really enjoyable class and was always fun to attend to. Professor was very understanding and always made sure students knew the material before going into discussions or projects.

Professor Hernandez is an amazing professor. She is supportive, understanding, and incredibly knowledgeable about colonialism in the Andes. Yes she has an accent, but if you sit in the front of the class you will be fine and she will always repeat something if you ask. Readings are interesting and the lectures are very informative. Take her class.

She grades you on few things, which is nice because it is little work, but I found the class very hard. I had troubles understanding her. I found this was also a problem with other people who were in the class. She kind of mumbles and talks fast. She gives reading but I didn't do any of it and ended up ok. Reading didn't help me anyways.

Prof likes to do group projects and you are graded by 4 projects which are a movie review (15 min vid), 2 reaction papers (2-3 pages), and a final Read chapters before class to make sense of lecture. Prof is v passionate in what she is teaching but if you are not ready to read 40 pages before each lecture I do not recc taking this course.

Class was very loose. There was a good amount of reading with some writing but with low standards. The professor themselves have low intellectual integrity; making academic mistakes and refusing to admit their errors.

As you can probably tell from the recent reviews, my classmates and I went to BATTLE this quarter. If you take this class, make sure you set aside time for self care and your mental health. I think this class is doable if you understand what you're in for. The amount of reading isn't possible. Do what you can and seek support from peers.

Incoherent recorded lectures, sometimes assigned movies had nothing to do with readings. I got sick the weekend we had to submit our midterm paper so I asked for an extension but she only gave me one for a minor weekly assignment and not the paper, which is 30% of our grade. Got a zero, so automatic fail and couldn't drop.

The material in this class is really interesting. If it was taught by literally anyone one else I'd say take it. I've never been more disappointed with a class in my life. The prof makes up assignments on a whim and is less than receptive to constructive feedback. Left each session feeling gaslit and upset. Skip it.
By far the most unstructured professor I've ever had. Lectures are not productive for weekly graded assignments, she is rude to students, and not disability friendly.

This professor is completely unprofessional, biased, unorganized, never is clear in her instructions and constantly changes her expectations last minute. Do not take this professor, it is not worth the stress!

Weekly quizzes WITH multiple choice AND short answer responses, Weekly discussion section posts (250-300 words) with 2 responses, Mandatory attendance (Can't miss more than 2 classes), Lengthy midterm paper, Lenghty final paper, in-class written assignments, and not understanding of late work. Would not take again. Save yourself. Skip this class.
She really cares about the subjects she's teaching. Her class isn't hard as long as you're prepared to work.
Gave a discussion post, weekly quiz and midterm on the same week! Lots of reading for this class. Wanted us to read a 300 page book within 3 days.
There is a lot of weekly assignments

I took professor Pandey's online class and it was a lot of coursework. Even on discussions that i felt I went above and beyond on, I still got marked down. Her lectures are engaging and the media and readings are fun but her grading made the class not as worth it for me. Maybe her in person classes are better but I wasnt a fan of the online format.

She no longer uses the quizzes that I see less recent students complaining about. Midterm &final projects were chill & graded generously. Lectures were random but paying attention helped with writing the weekly discussions (the only homework we had). The movies we watched in class were fun, the dancers were great, & it was very light overall.

This class had so much dense reading every week that was hard to understand. She has very high expectations for how much work and time you should put into her class. The grades are mostly discussions/writings/presentations so you aren't really tested but it's just hard. Her lectures are super interesting however, I did learn a lot.

There was at least 50 pages of dense readings each week for hw that we had to write lengthy discussion posts about. We did get to watch/learn from several professional Indian classical dancers in class which was fun and entertaining! It was an interesting class overall, but the teaching style was quite strict. She doesn't like computer notes.

I just really didn't appreciate the way this professor structured the class. I was very excited to learn about Dance and performance but that was about 5% of this class. The readings went into completely different topics and there was just so much work expected to be done for a GE level class. Also they were just very rude at times.

Assigns HUNDREDS of pages of reading a week and even assigned reading and discussion work during FINALS WEEK. Stay as far away as possible. I had no other choice but to take this class because it was one of the few offered online for the quarter.

quiz every other week, pretty hard, written response and mc. Assignment every Friday based on readings. At least 4-6, 30-50 page readings a week and you have to watch videos too. Mandatory lecture, takes attendance. For 10 min out of the 1.75 hour class do you learn Bollywood dance. The dance teacher goes so fast... Would never take again.

This class was a great experience! The readings do get a bit heavy if you don't plan ahead but the overall workload was not unreasonable. Interesting material and lectures were segmented pretty well. The teaching team for this class was great and seemed really interested in the course.
She is very passionate about what she teaches and is a very good teacher

The only person that saved this class was the course assistant. She was the most understanding person in the world. This class expects you to do lots of readings every week, weekly discussion posts, exams every two weeks, and a midterm and final paper. This prof chews ppl out if u are even 2 minutes late; almost made me cry. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS.

This is one of the worst classes I have taken at this school. It was an easy way to fill the ER ge, if you can actually sit through the class. Lectures are excruciating and I did not learn anything. If you do not like politics, do not take this class. It was beyond stressful to wake up for an 8 am just to hear about politics for an hour and a half.

Barely does any teaching, leaves all decisions up to TA. Lectures just read off slides. Poor communicator, pushes back due dates last minute often after the window has passed, and doesn't update Canvas. Relies heavily on random videos and gets into personal tangents easily. Seems mostly focused on her book rather than her (only) class.

Renya is very sweet and kind, she loves her work and teaching her students by interacting with them instead of purely speaking for 1.5 hrs. Barely any homework, 5 comments, one paper and one exam (was canceled because of strike). Went online during TA and encampment strikes, very understanding and willing to work with you and your issues.

She's very passionate about what she teaches and really just wants her students to learn. Class is not hard and you get graded only on a few things. She is really encouraging and very responsive to questions and emails. She was also extremely supportive and understanding when I was going through a hard time. Highly recommend!

She was a boring professor she would lecture in a monotone voice and would read straight from the bullet points from the PowerPoint. The class was easy so if you don't mind extreme boredom for an easy A this class is for you.

Only graded on like 3 things, Group presentation, midterm, and final. Renya is a very knowledgable professor and wants her students to learn. She is such a fun presence, I would definitely take another class with her, shes very encouraging and generous with her grading.

Professor Ramirez wants you to succeed. Lectures are a bit boring and long but they do hold a lot of important information. All of the essay answers are in the lectures so it is useful to attend. There are a few two-page essays you need to do but it's super easy if you do the readings. She gave a lot of extra credit towards the end of the quarter.

The only positives of this class were wonderful the TAs, and it was incredibly easy. The lectures were worthless, lasting max 30 minutes; she read directly off useless slides. You can tell she's completely disengaged. I stopped going and only attended the discussion section where the TA made it make sense, and I actually learned something.

Professor Ramirez is an excellent professor and person.  She is really interested in the historical context, which is important in anthropology!  She listens to her students and really wants to help you learn the material and to get a lot out of it.  Very responsive.  So great I'm taking another course with her next quarter.  Highly recommend!

Really doesnt seem to have much interest in teaching. Lectures are 20-40 minutes long and she just reads verbatim two or three vague bullet points per slide, then repeats one or two points from before or shows a film. She seems fairly well-informed on some of these issues, but it often feels like she teaches just to get published through UCSC.

Professor Ramirez is an easy A that requires some reading. For ANTH 150 the prompts for the papers were straight up, look for the argument. Her lectures would go into the readings and answer the prompt questions. She is a straightforward professor and recognizes that as long as you turn in the paper you have done well.

Professor Ramirez is amazing! She is so sweet and her lectures are always interesting. There is quite a bit of reading but since they're all ethnographies, they're typically super interesting. The workload is minimal, as is the midterm (a 300-word response to a single question) and she is very accommodating as long as you're communicative.

Renya is a good person, however. if it werent for the TAs I would be totally lost. Her lectures only averaged 40 minutes & didnt say much. The course description says that the class will cover a lot more interesting & helpful material than it actually did. I felt like the class was not as challenging as it shouldve been & I was often bored.

An extremely interesting and fun class. There is one group paper and presentation on the readings, a midterm based on the readings and she provides a study guide, and an individual research paper and presentation. She grades fairly and as long as you try she credits that.

Honestly just an awful experience. I was SO bored every single class. Im not sure she gave one whole lecture in ten weeks. It was all student presentations or guest lectures. I get that presenting is an important skill but thats what Public Speaking class is for. Very confusing and scattered syllabus. Easy but got nothing out of it.

She is a cool woman. I liked her take on anthropological theory through use of indigeneity. Lots of papers, challenging, but the TAs were great during their sections. The syllabus was messy and hard to understand but TAs helped. Gave good feedback. Class was like a writing bootcamp for cultural anthro. I learned a lot and would recommend.

I like Renya! She's super nice and is obviously passionate about what she teaches. You really get the feeling that she's on your side. Her class was pretty free form and presented a lot of cool ideas. Lectures weren't really anything special, but it was still enjoyable overall.

She is a really caring professor who enjoys her topic. However, she reads off her power point slides and gives lectures in a way that makes me glance at the clock every five seconds. Her class is extremely easy though if you just write notes from her slides and she gives you a study guide every time. I would recommend this class for your GPA.
Renya is an amazing instructor. She is informative, compassionate, and motivating. She offers a unique perspective. Class discussion, reading material and media allow insight into the Native woman.

She knows her stuff, and she is indian too so she connects the lectures to her real life. BUT sometimes she over analyzes things so some lectures sound kinda stupid. She is leaving for Yale next year. Overall good teacher to have and her TA's are awesome. I had STUVY and he is more helpful than Renya, if you can get STUVY she is chill

My 91.43% was a B+pretty whack. Assignments were straightforward, and she provided all the readings. Mandatory discussion with camera on, no excuses. Lots of reading and annotating it's a drag but helps you learn. Everyone has to talk for participation points. Check the syllabus some assignments aren't posted but are listed there. no xuses w/her.

The class was a class that should have been easy, the assignments were straightforward. I got full marked on every assignment except for two, and even then I got B's. And still ended up with a B+ in the class. Their grading scale is different so 90-91% in the class is a B+ and 92-94% is an A- in the class.

Professor Caldwell was okay. She does not teach the sections or participate in the course- it is entirely run by the TAs. They were great and easily accessible, but don't count on this professor for things like recommendations or advice. Easy A if you do the work and show up to class.

There are no lecture slides, so be prepared to take notes on everything she says. She grades extremely hard, especially since assignments are only out of four points. For example, she gave us less than four days to formulate and turn in our final: a seven-page research paper. The class average was a 55% on that assignment.

Lectures are super boring, she speaks so so slow but somehow manages to say nothing. If you're actually interested in learning anthropology I wouldn't take her class. If you need an easy A with not that much work, this class is for you.

she is a very kind woman. her lectures consisted of her talking for majority and the slides weren't very useful for notes. but the material is very interesting and fun! sections are mandatory but also fun discussions. about 3-4 weekly articles and not really any tests but projects and short essays instead. I totally reccomend!

Prof Caldwell was very passionate about Anthropology. Her lectures were very audio-based, so the actual slides did not help much. This made studying hard, as you had to go back and actually listen to what she said rather than look over the slides. The class grade is 90% based on tests and quizzes, so you really had to know the material to pass.

Melissa overall was an okay professor. However, her tests were very difficult even though I would study for hours. She also has a grading scheme where is 92% is not considered an A but a B+ which makes it hard to get an A in her class. Her lectures were often very confusing and not very helpful. I was amazed at how difficult her intro class was.

Online class had interesting lectures and were pre-recorded. Mandatory bi-weekly discussion session with TA which were very helpful. The prof herself was not accessible and did not respond to emails. Exams were difficult, even having studied well beforehand. Took me 3-4 hours and were proctored online. My only B received at UCSC and idk why!

Lissa is one of my favorite professors at ucsc. She genuinely cares about all her students and wants them to do well in her class. She is one of the most intelligent people I've ever met and will teach you some pretty interesting stuff about Russia and Anthropology overall. If you need help or advice, lissa is always willing. TAKE HER CLASSES!
Melissa is one of my favorite professors at ucsc, she is kind and a fair grader and if a great help.

melissa is my favorite professor at ucsc. she's sweet, adorable, and really open to her students. she gives a lot of reading, but i've gotten an A in another one of her classes just by lightly skimming stuff. lectures are boring and quiet usually, but melissa is still love. usually just assigns one or two assignments and a midterm and final.

Melissa is a sweetheart. She's kind, patient, and even baked us cookies when we watched a movie! Class is a bit challenging and has a lot of reading, but you will learn a lot regarding socialism in Russia and Eastern Europe. Overall, a rewarding class!

I loved this class- it made me decide to be an anthro major. Melissa is an awesome teacher who really knows her field and clearly loves it. She picks interesting readings, maybe a little heavy depending on what you're used to, and is clear in class. Go to office hours- she's very friendly and helpful!
Melissa is very nice and very knowledable in her field, she is very helful when you need her, class can get boring at times but her personality makes up for it, and shes a fair grader

Good class. Not much work. Weekly 1 page paper on the readings. 2 doable projects. Cheat sheet for midterm and final. Lectures are a drag, but don't miss because the notes you take you can put on the cheat sheet!

Lissa is wonderful! She is super friendly and sweet, knowledgable, and helpful. She loves this material and herself is involved in research in Russia. The material is super interesting, and there is a ton of awesome material to read -- do keep up with it and do attend lecture although not mandatory! I recommend her other classes too!

This is an interesting class but doesn't make a whole lot of sense by the end if you do not have an interest or prior knowledge of socialism, communism and/or eastern Europe. She is very helpful though.
Adorable, brilliant, generous, and funny. If Lissa taught underwater basket weaving, I'd be at the pool at East Field every week. Teacher crushable!
Great, helpful, available teacher.  A fair amount of reading involved, but she's a really generous grader.

The readings are intriguing enough but expect to read alot before each class. Professor Anderson basically goes over all the readings in class point blank. The lectures arent very engaging at all and I've noticed many students doing other homework during class. He clearly cares but the lectures are very hard to pay attention to.

Mark Anderson is such a great fun and caring person. He clearly cares about his work and his students. 4-5 readings per week (read them before class) 2 take home open notes essay and 1 group project. Attendance is mandatory, sign in sheet at the beginning of class. Understands about back-to-back classes so he lets you out early. Amazing teacher!!!!

Hes a really nice guy and the material is interesting but Id be lying if I didnt say the lectures were, at times, very long. Syllabus was not well organized and could be confusing. Tests require you to write out a lengthy essay, the prompt for which is provided beforehand but is a bit much to write on the spot.

the class and readings were at least a bit interesting, but a bit lengthy at times. However, although they really prepare you for class, the lectures are heavily based on the reading, so it doesn't hurt to skim. Took the class for the GE but ended up liking it way more than I thought I would.

There wasn't much room to facilitate discussion, so you just sit there and listen to him drone on and on, which can get tiresome because he basically goes over the readings every class. It was unclear what we should focus on studying, like terms etc. Section was more learning based. He doesn't seem to have much passion for teaching.

Prof. Anderson just recited his perspective on readings we already did, so the lectures were pretty hard to get through. DON'T MAKE THE ROOKIE MISTAKE OF JUST NOT GOING. Go, take notes, sleep a bit. The readings are where the class is at. Super cool cultural anthropology readings that reshape your view on the world.
