Professor Anderson has clear lecture slides and a well-organized course structure but he isn't very inspirational or passionate about what he's teaching. Some of the readings can be very interesting but they are lengthy. It's a lot of reading for the class in general. Overall I didn't like the class or him as a teacher.

VERY considerate and caring of student success. As a DRC student, it was a big concern for me- he's incredibly accommodating and willing work with me. Love that he incorporates ALL perspectives into his lectures including with his guest speakers. He also doesn't make you buy anything for the class (even his own book), but there's a reader optional
The content of the class was great! Good guest speakers and good TA's. Very approachable and knew the material very well. Papers and exams were manageable and straightforward.

He makes complex topics easy to understand, and the material was very interesting. He is very knowledgeable and has simple easy to follow lecture slides. You do have to sign in every class, but it's worth going because he unpacks the reading in a very easy to understand way. He's a little awkward, but very sweet and wants students to succeed.

Great at getting the information across if you can pay attention to the lecture past the first ten minutes. This was the most boring class i have ever taken even though the subject is so interesting. All he does during class is read his notes in a mono tone voice with black and white bullet points for slides. Show up sign in watch clock...

Mark is hands down the BEST professor in the department. Not only is he sexy, he's also smart, AND a great lecturer. He does have nervous energy, but has gotten much better over time. SUPER intelligent and kind, he will answer any question, and answer it with kindness and respect, even if it is off-topic. : ) Super cuddly and nice!

Mark is a great professor.  Don't let his slight awkwardness throw you off, he is very friendly, smart, and approachable.  His lectures are engaging, relevant, and useful and his feedback is critical but fair.  I highly recommend him and look forward to taking his other classes.

Though he is very clear and pretty much tells you what you can do to do well on exams/essays, I found his lectures extremely boring. He had little to no presence and rarely captured my attention, even though in theory, I was interested in the material. Also, the questions he asked and the discussions he facilitated were remedial at best.

Mark is an amazing professor! His lectures are lively, the readings can be a bit lengthy but are still, nonetheless, fascinating. His grading technique is very fair and he takes the time to write detailed feedback. Keep up w/ the readings and you should be just fine.

He is a very clear professor - he makes classes interesting and knows his subject. He sets a fair amount of work and grades fairly with extensive feedback. He tries to get to know students and is very approachable.

he is a great lecturer but when it came to helping me out, not very good. i was very interested in the class and the material and i had heard great things about him but after the class and not being helped, i started disliking it. the ta was NOT helpful at all also

He is an excellent instructor, and is not only knowledgeable, but he is able to guide a class of at least 50 through the very contentious subject of race.  He addresses everyone's questions, is very clear when speaking, and is friendly and approachable to boot.  Great guy, great class.
No Comments
He's very clear which makes it easy to take notes, and he's old school- doesn't use powerpoint, which is good! Awesome readings. So easy to talk to and good at remembering names.

I love this class, it's pretty easy to pass just make sure you do a good job during section classes and the homeworks. Professor is very kind and understanding, he does love to throw in a few jokes once and a while. We had quite a few guest lectures but I prefer when Professor Schneider was the one teaching.
Extremely sweet and understanding teacher! Always very positive energy and overall an easy class!

Decent professor, but the lectures are long and boring. Definitely an easy class though and small assignments that were neither difficult nor long. Lots of guest lectures, but you can honestly skip his lectures if you don't really want to go. He seems like a great guy but class was just not that interesting.

I took anth 3 the lectures are an hour and a half 2 times a week and section is 1 hr but it's mandatory. He's not a bad teacher its just the lectures are kinda boring since they're so long not super hard class just boring.
He's not a bad teacher its just that lectures are pretty long and boring I took his anth 3 class and it's not bad didn't really do much work outside of discussion section tbh.

I took his Intro to Archeology class (ANTH3). I have zero interest in the subject, and the lectures are somewhat boring as as result. Regardless, schneider didn't hinder my ability to pass. Tolerable lectures with 100% manageable weekly mini-assignments. Overall, I'd recommend as a good course if you're looking for a backup/GE class

I took ANTH 3 with Professor Schneider and hated it. Even though he is passionate about the subject, his lectures are long and not concise. He drags on about concepts that could be explained easily. There are a lot of terms to remember for the tests. Unless you like archaeology, don't take this class just because he is rated high/easy.

Tsim is great, the class was super boring! It is one of the easiest A's I've ever gotten. He is soft spoken and a little hard to understand at times, but if you want to boost your GPA take his class! He is also Native American, so even if it seems like he doesn't know much about archaeology, he knows about stuff other archaeologists don't.

Amazing teacher in the Anthropology department. Lectures are slightly long but very informative and straight forward. A lot of quizzes but that makes up for there not being too many assignments. Gives great feedback, and is really passionate about what he teaches with a smile always upon his face. Small enjoyable project at the end of the class.

His Intro to Archaeology is pretty easy but also super interesting. I can tell he is really passionate about what he teaches. He is very detailed in his lectures and assignments are very straightforward.
jon is a little boring. most of what is said is on the slides he uploads. sometimes he'll show a video. very nice guy if you go to his office hours.
Nice guy, but not an easy grader.  I had to work really hard for my A, but that what school is all about!!

Jon is so passionate and friendly. He really made me interested in a the course, despite it not being my major. I hope he ends up with tenure, because he's so great. Hilarious, plus very modest and meets students at a peer level. Reading can be heavy, but you don't have to do all of it, really. Definitely recommend!!

One of my favorite professors at UCSC. Really good at making you understand WHY these issues are still relevant and important. Totally changed my perspective and helped me to develop as an anthropologist.

Absolutely brilliant professor. Kind, warm, knowledgeable, sarcastic (in a good way) and open when students have questions. I thoroughly enjoyed my class with him and I accredit him with sparking my interest in a subject that could have gone either way.
Great Professor, his lectures are comprehensive and he's very approachable. Recommended!
Daehnke likes to assign a LOT of reading, but his lectures are very interesting. Daehnke is a clear lecturer and a nice guy.

Dr. Moodie is one of the best professors I have ever had. I took Intro to Disability Studies with her and it totally revolutionized my understanding of disability. She is caring, funny, and brilliant. She brought her own experience with disability justice into the course which was really helpful with understanding course content. Take her class!!!

Lots of reading, but interesting material. Prof Moodie is always open to modifications, and adapting to whatever is going on, and is pretty lenient. She has accommodations built into the syllabus, and gives great writing advice. Love her lectures, she's really funny and sweet and allows for personal experience to have a place in academics

The course materials are very difficult to understand at times and there are endless readings. Grading is only based on writings and essays, and alternative views seem to be frowned upon. Will avoid in the future.

Motherhood in American Culture was a really interesting class. Your grade is only based on four papers though, so if you're not a good writer then you probably shouldn't take it. There's a lot of reading to do also.

I took motherhood in American culture and I loved the content. I just felt it was an excessive amount of reading but its an upperdiv so makes sense. The readings were long but enjoyable. There is about 3 papers and a take home final. As long as you keep up with the content youll be good! She is busy outside of class with but TA is approachable.

I love Professor Moodie. I took FMST 148 and ANTH 110X with her. 148 was one of the most challenging classes I ever took yet I learned so so much. She is so passionate and brilliant and it just shines through in her lecturing. She would give a decent amount of pop quizzes and the material was dense but I wouldn't have changed a thing.

Professor Moodie is passionate, funny, intelligent, and incredibly inspiring. Her class inspired me to further pursue cultural anthropology, as well as going into the subject matter (motherhood/reproductive rights). There are writing assignments, but they are fun and interesting. Take-home final. I would recommend her and take her again.
By FAR one of the best professors I've ever had. Extremely knowledgable about her subject and highly respected by her students. I have never learned so much from a class. TAKE HER!

3 books, all expensive (well, all textbooks are). She doesn't have lecture slides. She just RAMBLES on and on, and you have to take notes while she talks really quickly. Also, her vocabulary is very high. FMST/ANTH148 has no pre req and I don't think she realizes that because she expects us to understand everything she's saying.
Never boring; always awesome. I love her lectures they always teach something new and she is very passionate. I would take any class she teaches. Also the TA is great, which helps.

I have no idea how people can say she was helpful in any way. I contacted her OVER and OVER and OVER asking for help and never got any. She also really put me down and made me feel uncomfortable in her class. I am a great student who got a good grade in the class but I would NEVER want to deal with her again.

For an anthro class, the material is very feminist. She tried not to be one-sided, but she beats you over the head with the message. You really learn a lot and it's interesting. Three papers and easy reading-based pop quizzes (five books and a reader). She is a fair grader and lets you rewrite papers if you use the tutor. I got an A

Person below me is spot on. She's sometimes hard to understand because her vocabulary tromps mine, but generally clear. If you like the subject matter and can stand getting beaten over the head with it, take this class. It's interesting, and it's not even in my major

Professor Moodie is great. She is extremely knowledgeable about her topics and you learn a lot from going to lecture. Her assignments are clear and essay's and tests are easy if you keep up with lecture and reading which is usually interesting. You will learn a lot in this class.. TAKE HER!

Moodie is highly knowlegible about the subject matter, as she is an expert on India, however, her lecturing skills could use some work. Very interesting subject matter, heavy reading for lower div class which was sometimes extremely dense. Three 4-6 pg essays + attendance = your grade. pretty sweet.

This was the worst class I've ever taken in the Feminist Studies department. She often rambles about unrelated topics wasting most of class time with plugs for her other classes and books she is writing. This class had very little Feminist analysis. Do not take a class with her if you can avoid it. Foremost she is an unfair and unhelpful grader :-(

The best professor I've had at UCSC. I learn more in her class in a week than I do in most of my classes all quarter. A somewhat difficult grader but very willing to work with students. She always has interesting things to say relating the material in the class to current events.

Very enthusiastic and knowledgeable on population politics and India. Engaging lectures that somtimes have a bit of humor. 2 5-7 pg essays and a final research project 15 pgs, unfortunately very hard essay prompts. no final. Highly reccomended!

Megan is awesome! I took Feminist Cultural Production with her (FMST 123), and I'm going to take Feminist Ethnographies w/her again next quarter. She's really informative, and cares a lot about global/cultural feminism in the anthropological context. I think she is one of the best professors ever, even though she's still very young.

She is enthusiastic and knowledgeable about her subject.  However, she is a little on the crazy side.  Sometimes its a good day, sometimes a bad day, just stay on your toes.  Overall though, she is qualified, and you will learn from her.  Her workload is fair, and despite her occasional weirdness, she does care about her students.

Cihang is a great lecturer, but this really depends on your learning style. He does weekly short quizzes which are pretty easy if you attend lecture. He has 4 homework notebooks that you have 2 weeks to complete and one final group project. Overall pretty chill class.

First 4 weeks are wasted on CSE-40 stuff (including a whole lecture on an introduction to Python). The first third of every lecture is spent going over the content of the previous lecture again. Assignments are vague and have little guidance. Weekly quizzes, at least two of which are guaranteed to get lost because everything is graded by hand.

Content is repeated every lecture, assignments have very unclear instructions, and overall didn't learn much in this class. Would be better if we covered significantly more material instead of spending 2 weeks on CNNs and 3 weeks on regression.
Nice guy & pretty lenient grader
Nice guy & grading was pretty lenient
Good proffessor. Attendence not mandaotry very easy grading. Leared so much .

Lectures were taken from another professor and not always explained clearly/intuitively, and the homeworks had a lot of hidden busywork in learning python libraries that distracted from the actual machine learning part. However, the homeworks are designed by the TAs AFAIK and Xie is also a newish lecturer so I'm sure he'll improve quickly.

Lectures are hard to understand due to his accent. Each homework took around 12-16 hours however they were spaced 2 weeks apart leading to around 6-8 hours a week and mostly consisted of taking given equations and transforming them into code. Recommend taking this class if you are familiar with object-oriented programming, python, and NumPy.

The lecture's were hard to understand and didn't fully cover what each assignment asked of us. Every assignment was made more difficult due to poor directions. Participation was required, miss more than 2 classes and lose 10% of the total grade. Overall, the class felt like it was built on the fly and the professor felt underprepared to teach it.

Took him when it was his first quarter teaching. Everything was a mess from lecture to homework instructions. The lectures felt like a study group, where all the students were trying to understand the concept that he didn't explain well. The homework was filled with confusion as there was barely any instructions.

Lectures are hard to understand and doesn't teach material well. Everyone in the class has to watch youtube videos to learn. We have to work in breakout rooms in groups and work on an inclass exercise that no one knows how to do. Homework assignments are difficult. Recommend taking it with another professor.

I took an incomplete due to health complications around the time of final. It took two months to set up a new final date, and had horrible response time during this period. I had to email the Vice Dean of Baskin to get a response (over a month of no response to any email). Class is fine in difficulty, straightforward. Not super accomodating prof :(

Great considering its his first time teaching here. Very well chosen curriculum. HWs were reasonable, not stressful, but provided great practice. A lot of extra credit opportunities and curves. Lectures had a solid balance of theory and example but definitely more of the former. Exam content was clearly communicated and reasonable in difficulty.

This class required a lot of self-studying. The concepts weren't too hard, but there was a lot of new info, especially for the final. Professor Im clearly highlighted what would be on the tests. Homework is graded easily. If you put in the effort, you'll get an A.

Gives a lot of extra credit/participation opportunities. Curves so around 25% of the class gets an A. Before the 2 midterms + 1 final, he did a review covering exactly what will be on the exams. Engaging lecturer and he highlights/focused on material that is most important for technical interviews. 102 is an important course so take it w/ him!

Professor Im did a great job allocating an appropriate workload throughout the quarter. During exam weeks, he made sure we had a lighter course load and prepared us well with reviews for the exam. You will likely find yourself doing work outside of lectures to wrap your head around the course; he was quick-paced but well-spoken during the lectures.

This was professor Im's first quarter at UCSC, so, things were a tad chaotic, but he was generous with extra credits and curving. He may need some time to adjust to the quarter system which is a lot shorter than the semester system (used at UC Merced, where he taught before). Take a lot of notes, do not skip lectures, and you'll easily get an 'A'.

I couldn't learn much from him, I mainly learned from my friend who took his class before and worked for him. Learning the content isn't hard, it's just a lot of memorization. He grades based off of two midterms and one final. Again, the content isn't hard and he reuses midterm and final questions. The questions are also pretty simple.

Just like his 103, your grade in this class is 50% midterm and 50% final, and tests are comprehensive. The lectures are pretty good, but the homework is really difficult and at times feels disjoint to what he covers in lectures. Overall, his 102 is a pretty decent class, but in my opinion 103 is where he truly shines.

simple class. go to lectures or read textbook, memorize everything, win exams.
exams are disgustingly comprehensive so be prepared for EVERYTHING to be on an exam. final copies a bunch of questions from both midterms. old guy but nice and explains things well, albeit with a slower paced lecture than other classes.

Pretty good class, and he explains stuff pretty well. He uses the chalkboard and doesn't speak very loudly, so his lecturing style isn't very well liked by zoomers with low attention spans. Your grade is 50% midterms and 50% final, but he always has a review lecture before exams where he basically gives you exactly what will be on the exam.

He is 86 and still teaches this with quality. Said this is his fav course. Class has hard material but he teaches it very well. The class weighs 50% both midterms and 50% final. Exams come from his lectures, then also from his handouts he posts. Definitely attend his review lectures which is 1 class before the exams. Incredible person tol
Dry lectures, very slow pacing. Didn't even cover P/NP which is the whole point of the class.

Tbh rlly wasn't that bad. Only downside is midterms are 50% and final is 50% but he is very generous in terms of hinting at what's on the exams. I cannot stress enough how important going to class and attempting the reading is though (not yuja you will NOT pay attention or see what hes writing) I promise it isn't super tough and it seriously helps.
This the hardest class I have ever taken.

CSE 103 is actually a pretty important class. If you don't like this class, you don't actually like computer science.

Delbert is actually a very good lecturer and he cares! Yes, it's a little old fashioned with the chalkboard and handwritten notes, but actually I realize that I prefer it. If you already know the material, just sit back and relax.

CSE103 and 102. Really nice guy but he is in his mid 80's now and barely knows how to use his laptop. His lectures are slow and, somewhat disorganized. You are pretty much going to need to teach yourself the material. The grading breakdown of his classes are 30% x2 for midterms and 40% for the final. Cheatsheets for midterms not for finals

Pretty tough. You need to study hard for both midterms. The highest grade is applied to both. The final is cumulative and has more content, our midterm averages were C and final D-. Final was curved on a bell curve I think. No +/- so an 89% is a B not a B+ and a 71 % is a C. Homework was P/NP. You're graded by tests only.
Good teacher and would take again. He teaches very well just go to lectures
Delbert Bailey was a great professor for 102! He is funny, smart and although sometimes he gets lost in his own lecture but he always listens to his students corrections. 100% would take him again!

Bailey's CSE103 is difficult because it's graded by few things. The class is 10% homework (which is fairly easy to get 100%), two midterms worth 40%, and a final worth 50% of your grade. It is A LOT of pressure to be graded on so few things, but my advice is to attend as many lectures as possible because the exams often copy problems from lectures.

Not hard. Hand writing is very bad. He never actually talks about what he is writing, he just kind of assumes everyone is following. The whole lecture is him copying his notes onto the chalk board and then talking once in a while. Exams are basically 100% of your grade, but he has a policy where if you fail the homework category you fail the class.
just awful

Just awful. Lectures are beyond boring and he doesn't go over enough examples in detail, his handwriting is so bad that it will have your eyes drawing decagons trying to figure out what he wrote down on the board/notes. Do yourself a favor and take this with literally anyone else.

Delbert has very dry lectures and a terrible grading policy. I had the displeasure of having my grade rounded down because of his terrible rules. Recommend that you avoid taking 103 with him and look to take it with another professor if you can.

Dry but helpful lectures, definitely ask questions to clarify things. Glad he kept it remote. hw can be found online, so understand the solutions. tests hard and majority of grade, but online open notes and curved greatly. really wish he would give practice exams though. trick questions were truly stupid. he's actually kinda funny sometimes lol
Uninspired teaching

This class is pretty hard, especially if you aren't really prepared with the pre-req skills. I was not, but Demertzis may be the most available professor I've ever had. Amazing class, you will learn a LOT if you put the time in. Demertzis is also very helpful with advice with/connections to research opportunities.

Lectures aren't mandatory, but I recommend attending for participation. Great lecturer imo, explains data structures with pseudo code and creates visuals that make it easier to understand concepts. Passionate about topics and doesn't hesitate to answer questions students have. TAs and Instructor easily reachable through Piazza. Really enjoyed 101.

He has a thick accent and messy handwriting which makes lectures hard to follow. He has super clear grading criteria and often lets you know your potential grade before you submit a test/homework. He's also super flexible and wants you to get a good grade. He will kind of clown you and cut you off if you raise your hand in class though.

At first I felt this was a hard class and it was hard keeping up.
However, what I learned there helped me find a summer internship $$$.
Inspired to pursue graduate studies in cybersecurity.
Awesome class!
Very inspiring
Awesome class :)

Professor is good at teaching but the class is hard and the pacing seems inconsistent.
Slides do not make the most sense on their own without the professor talking over them. The slides get posted, but each lecture has like 60 slides that are hard to decipher.
Lecture recordings don't get posted and homework(easy-ish) solutions aren't released.
I did not fail because of the extra OH, Professor's support, and extra credits.
One of the worst professors I have ever had. Rude, disorganized, and uncaring.
Cool prof! He helped me a lot during the office hours and gave the opportunity for a lot of extra credit.
Not an easy class, but not a hard one either. Prof. Demertzis did a good job.

Programming assignments were due every week on Sunday with no extensions. Quizzes were every 2 weeks on Codio and you have to physically be in the sections that were proctored by a bunch of TAs. They were closed notes and super hard, all or nothing. He did give the opportunity to make up a quiz, but still I couldn't bounce back.

Grading is extremely tough for the first 3 quizzes, Any small mistake would end up with a 0 for that entire quiz. There are 5 quizzes and a minimum of 56% to pass, which is surprisingly difficult given the quiz rubric. The last 2 quizzes are easy. Study guides are clear though and usually direct you toward the exact question you'll have on the quiz

The class mirrored the other 101 class, and this was prof's first time, so its understandable he borrowed content. I could easily understand the concepts and I thought they were taught in an engaging way. Not difficult at all for anyone who can already think in algorithms. Lots of prep time for tests and hw, so they were fairly easy.

The lectures were handwritten notes and him explaining DSA. Bad at answering questions. There were opportunities to redo tests and homework, so I give him some slack. Go to office hours if you are having a hard time. Start the HW early. If searching for solutions, cite sources, and don't cheat. If you don't get it, watch YT videos with the DS/A.

You get out what you put out in this class. He seems very blunt, but he genuinely cares about your work. If you're taking this class, do your best to be proactive and attend/watch the lecture so you don't disappoint him in the live code review.  He cares less about the quality of your product and more about if you applied his teachings.

Jullig can be rude and expects perfection on your documentation. Is very upset when people are late to class or use their phones. He claims that some days attendance is mandatory but then never takes attendance. Lectures were a waste of time and you can do well on the tests (3) as long as you look over the slides. Make sure you get a good group

This class is the definition of "it is what you make of it". If you're not extroverted, I recommend taking this class with some friends. It's basically a big group project with three easy tests scattered throughout the quarter. Regarding the professor, Jullig is probably the most interesting professor I've had yet.

A very chill class. His lectures are pretty boring, but the material isn't difficult. Skim the slides before the tests and you'll be fine. You work in a group the whole quarter to build a project, and present it at the end. Jullig can come off as a hard ass sometimes but he's a pretty nice guy.

This guy sucks, there's not a better way to put it. The lectures are boring, he reads word for word off cluttered slides that don't make sense. The assignments are vague and never discussed in class, it's very easy to miss something. He straight-up lies about when he'll share information, especially on important stuff. 115 could've been so good.

I was afraid to take his class at first due to negative ratings but I'd like to say they're outdated. He was very helpful and always available for projects. There is little for him to teach in this class because it's mostly project based. He helped us connect with relevant TAs to make sure our projects were successful.

Terrible professor! Class is extremely disorganized and he has been teaching the same course for years! I would have expected him to try his best and restructure his course based off numerous complaints, but nope. He can also be rude when giving feedback. Avoid if possible, but nobody else teaches 115a currently at UCSC unfortunately.

Easily one of the worst classes I've ever taken at U. Lectures are both extremely dense and disorganized, resulting in mass confusion. Assignments are scheduled with absolutely no consideration for students, not giving us enough time to properly do anything. We got little to no guidance on our project, and Jullig never responds to emails or piazza.

This is one of those classes where you learn absolutely nothing. Jullig is one of the most disorganized classes at UCSC. The group project has no instructions at all. He never responds to emails or messages. I think he maybe even be depressed. Not a good teacher at all. I would recommend avoiding him at all costs.

In an unorganized class, there may be a lack of consistency in the way the material is presented or the expectations for assignments and assessments. This can make it difficult for students to understand what they are supposed to be learning and how they will be evaluated.

An unorganized class can be a frustrating experience for students, as it can lead to confusion, missed opportunities for learning, and overall dissatisfaction with the course. When a class lacks organization, students may struggle to understand the course structure, assignments, and expectations.

Without clear direction, it can be difficult for team members to understand their roles and responsibilities, and the lack of guidance can lead to confusion and disorganization. Additionally, if the project did not provide any opportunities for learning or growth, it may have felt like a wasted effort for you and your group members.

The group projects were often poorly organized, with vague instructions and little guidance. This made it challenging to know what was expected and how to approach the project. The lack of actual teaching meant that students were left to figure things out on their own, which was time-consuming and often resulted in confusion and frustration.

Jullig seemed disinterested in helping students who were struggling. There was a lack of support and guidance for students, and he was often unavailable or unresponsive to emails. This lack of engagement and support made it even more challenging for students to grasp the concepts being taught, and it left many feeling frustrated and discouraged.

I would not recommend Richard. The thick accent, lack of care, and outdated teaching style all made for a negative experience that left me feeling unmotivated and discouraged. If possible, it would be best to avoid this teacher and look for someone who is more engaged, enthusiastic, and up-to-date with their teaching methods.

This is one of the toughest people to communicate with. I asked him several questions during office hours and he was just not interested in explaining any of that to me. Just sad to see the quality of education we get at UCSC

Very Difficult to understand and has a thick accent. His lectures were very unorganized. He rarely responds to emails. I had difficulty convincing him that he graded one of my midterm questions incorrectly, although my answer was clearly correct. I don't understand why UCSC still keeps him on the payroll.
All his classes are the same
Tough grader, avoid at all cost
Very Disorganized, not Caring at all

I took the 222A version of this class; no different from 122. There's a LOT of material and it all goes very deep. Prof G usually does well to explain the concepts. I found the final project (open-ended) to be interesting but very challenging. If you're really interested in chip design, you'll have a lot to chew on.

As other people will explain, the labs and tests aren't the problem. However, he's kind of a slave to procedure, with no room for leniency. Even if you follow the procedures exactly, you might feel unease. Also, he doesn't seem to care about individual students; requests to see our midterms were denied on the grounds that it was "a big class."

Start labs early, but don't stress yourself out on finishing them in a single sitting. Go to labs if you get stuck and ask the TA/tutors for help. You should score well on all your labs if you dedicate enough time and utilize lab sections. The toughest part of this class is the midterm and finals -- study at least couple days ahead of time.

Guthaus is a hard professor, he is not very clear in lectures so be aware to do a lot of self studies; his lab assignments are pretty hard especially the last one; he is really strict about cheating, don't copy any code from others in his lab assignments or you will get a F for the entire class.

He really makes you work hard for a good grade but nevertheless you learn a lot from his class (CE12 is a hard class in general). The last lab was exponentially difficult compared to the other labs however if you manage time wisely it's not too bad. The midterm and final were also pretty difficult.

If you take CE12 with him, know that it will be extremely difficult. Even though it is not a prerequisite, you NEED to know programming to pass (at least 12A, but you really should do up to 12B). The labs are really tough at the end and exams are challenging but fair. DO NOT CHEAT IN HIS CLASS. Guthaus is extremely strict on cheating.

The most terrible professor at UCSC. Do not care students future at all. Give tons of homework which are very very difficult to finish during his required time period. Do not show any mercy on grading, he will give you 0 on any assignment including homework and exams if your answers are not satisfy his willling.

In short, an all around excellent professor. Incredibly passionate about the field of VLSI design and this passion shows in his teaching and testing style. He stresses comprehension above all else and this is evident in his tests. If you're thinking about taking this class and just memorizing formulas you're going to have a bad time. Bland lectures

Great guy that's focused more on the practical side of what he teaches. Easy to talk to, especially if you're passionate in the field of Engineering. Exceptional and a great teacher if you ask the right questions.

Very poor lecturer. Constantly making mistakes, doesn't know what he's doing. Rude and unhelpful in office hours. Constant typos in homework and solutions. Claims to be too busy due to consulting to follow through on promises. Lab is decent (but he has no idea what's going on). Hope the TA is good. Avoid if possible. Worst prof I've had at UCSC.

Great review of EE101. Matt has no mastery of Sensors and failed miserably to cover the syllabus as outlined by the University website. Ask him something even slightly conceptually difficult and he just shrugs, smiles, and says "I don't know, that's a good question", and fails to follow up. A graduate student would have been better. 1/10.

This is the laziest teacher I've ever met. Very disorganized. Doesn't know what he puts on his own slides sometimes. Borrows most of his lecture material from other sources. The final was a joke used to supplement his poor teaching. Puts very little effort in assessing student assignments. You can learn as much by just googling everything.

I took his Logic Design with Verilog class, the next class after the first logic design class (CE 100). At first it is chill, Verilog is easy to learn, but by the last couple of labs the class gets much harder. Quizzes are highly unpredictable so don't try. He does try his best to help out students in the forum and in the labs, which were fun!

Matt is a great professor. He is very knowledgeable and really wants his students to learn the material. He was always available for help and gives great feedback. The course can be somewhat difficult. Labs can get pretty painful if you wait too long to start. That being said you learn a lot in this class

The professor was fair in the first midterm but the final was very difficult. Labs are time consuming and complex. However, if you stay on top of things you will learn a ton. Do not fall behind. Good but very difficult professor but he is not particularly engaging as a lecturer.

Oh man. Them labs tho. 6 lab assignments which you have to do all of them in order to pass the class, with almost no useful sources and instructions. The final was unbelievably difficult. He makes things very complicated and enjoys doing that. Do not take his class because YOU WILL STRUGGLE, but if you absolutely have to, ask a lot of questions !!!

Not a very good instructor! Be prepared to spend a lot of time on labs and blankly staring at your screen. Ask for help from your fellow students and keep asking the TAs for help. The TAs will always be busy helping other people so try to get their attention. Exams are worth lots of points and there is no way of studying for them.

His labs are challenging, you're essentially required to learn a new language every assignment with little time to absorb it. His tests are worse, he essentially makes them a marathon and says to read the book but they're tricky questions and they look like nothing on the hw. He's probably great for upper-div but a little tough for an intro class.

The lectures are just what is said in the book. The labs are a LOT of work as there is one every week + a typed up report step-by-step how you completed it. You might even have homework assigned the day before a midterm. Honestly not the best teacher I've had, thinks too much of himself rather then students.

Matt isn't a bad teacher, but tends to do a lot of writing and erasing... so prepare to erase a lot if you copy notes. His tests can be pretty tricky, and he gives you A LOT to do in lab. That said, his teaching is actually not so bad and he really does know his stuff. Just wish he wasn't trying to fail everyone at every turn (late labs, tests).

AWFUL AWFUL AWFUL AWFUL AND HE IS PURE EVIL. The other reviews about him are true. His entire class is based on writing tests, and if your code works well, but one single line of code isn't tested, you lose full points, that's how his entire class is setup. Genuinely Harrison should not be teaching this class, UCSC WTF ARE YOU DOING

There are many Professors who contribute to academia and care about their students. Haven't seen him do either. Took 2 classes with him and get the impression he doesn't like himself/smiles inside if you make a mistake. Kind of person to get a high from saying "I'm off the clock at 8 buddy!" to the last person waiting in line for food for 2 hours.

Bad autograder that would fail many students work regardless if it worked on their end or not. No clear feedback from the teacher and even though many praise him for showcasing industry standards it is not at all worth it. Just pass on this class and save your time.

If you get a bad group for your project good luck. Take it with people who you know are extremely motivated, smart, and willing to grind starting from day 1. I ended up contributing essentially more than everybody else in my group combined(!) based off lines of code and ended up setting up the vast majority of the infrastructure as well.

This capstone did not feel like a test of my knowledge rather a test of my patience. I was left very disappointed by his grading metrics and lack of academic or emotional support, and a complete lack of compassion or useful insights. I took this capstone pathway expecting the best of my abilities to shine, but instead received utter disrespect.

Disrespectful. Inconsistent. Poor grading rubric. Is not teaching to support students but rather to punish them for hard work. Do not take if you respect yourself because he will certainly not do that for you.
Hilarious for sure
This class is brutal, I hate it, it's the best class offered in this major.

The best class I almost wish I didn't take. I think he's a good lecturer, but the grading scheme is cooked. I switched to P/NP and glad I did, because my project tests failed on his end and I failed the class after sitting at a B all quarter. My fault, but still. Participate in Slack and OH to stay current on assignment implementation tidbits.

The grading distribution was nice because it was mainly based on assignments, and a little bit on quizzes. Quizzes were difficult but easy to pass (as you only need 50% to pass). The professor is very knowledgable but it is really difficult to get an A or even pass this class. I spent about 30 hours a week and still ended with a B.

This is one of the best classes at UCSC. That being said, it is definitely not easy. The homework is time-consuming, and the quizzes are tough despite no midterm or final. The assignments are very interesting, but the professor is not very helpful when it comes to answering questions. Still, I recommend that any CS student take this class.

Class is easily a 10-12 credit workload, will break even 4.0 students. Grading criteria for many HWs were near impossible with problematic autograding. Some of this is justified by learning tons of career relevant skills, but often unnecessarily difficult. Prof is very experienced but frustratingly unwilling to directly answer questions.

Course was very relevant for current full stack jobs, but assignments and quizzes were ridiculously difficult even with a background in web dev going in. Must follow professor's procedures/workflows to a tee to pass.

Dedicated my entire existence to this class this quarter, and prepare to do the same if you want a good grade in this class. Pop quizzes are ridiculously hard with averages of 50%, which is necessary if you don't want to fail the class. I did well on assignments but many of my classmates received 0s even if they submitted something tangible.

Overall, this course felt unnecessarily harder than it needed to be and the pacing is terrible. The content is directly applicable to what I want to do for my career, but the professor executed it in the worst way possible. Terrible lecturer, useless notes and slides, unfair quizzes, and impossible assignments.

David Harrison is an amazing professor, and taking CSE 186 this summer was the best experience I have had so far at UCSC. The class teaches you so much not just about web development but about industry practices, and it really pushes you to the absolute brink. It's a hard class. Harrison is a tough teacher. But it is 100% worth it-prepare to grind.

It's hard, that's an understatement, coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coverage,coveragecoverage,coverage,coverage,coverage, yah, if u fail the quiz category (9% of your grade), u fail the class.

This class is probably the best class in the entire major. It's incredibly tough and a ton of work, but Harrison is an outstanding professor. The class was really engaging and the professor would go very far out of his way to help you out if needed. This class is a LOT of work. I recommend taking it with a light quarter to get the most out of it.

There's no doubt that he's a good professor. He did an excellent job teaching the material. It is close to having a full time software job. If you want to learn and don't mind the hectic workload, take his class. If you're want a light workload and good grade, don't take him.

Just graduated but this was my favorite class/prof at UCSC. Harrison is an amazing resource for modern best practices in professional hardware/software design. He is practical, accessible, and doesn't make you feel bad for asking questions.

tips. It PAY$ to update your documentation whenever you get feedback. When stuck don't wait just go ask him.

Quinn's class is tough but manageable. She is a great lecturer and really explains concepts in a clear way. There are weekly quizzes that aren't too difficult. Midterm and Final are challenging but still manageable to do well on. The only downside about her class is she releases assignments, autograders, and grades last minute.

I learned a lot in this class, her lectures and assignments are valuable. Exams aligned well with lecture content.
Main complaint is about assignment autograders: Some were released excessively late. They often tested for unspecified behavior that requires her help to resolve.

Prof Quinn is easily the best professor i've had since starting here. She cares about her students, lectures are thorough and clear, and she clearly knows what she is teaching. I just wish she taught more classes

Looks like she redid the curriculum starting Fall 2025, because this course was ridiculously easier compared to the weeder class that 130 used to be in previous years. The class is well organized depending on the TA's Quinn is only really involved in lectures and lecture activities on canvas, the rest is managed by the TA's for all homework/other.

Keep your expectations for any love low and you'll be fine (no curve).Try not taking too hard classes with it, keep up with lecture material because quizzes/exams are mostly based on lectures except for some questions that come out of nowhere. Pad your grade with the semi-long assignments, this means no procrastination :( (the bane of my existence)

The lectures were pretty interesting, but material is dense. 5 quizzes and 5 assignments. Assignments were tough, but that's to be expected. However, this quarter they added another assignment that was super disorganized especially because tutors aren't accessible. Quinn themselves seem passionate, but strict.

Dr. Quinn's 130 class was one of the best CS classes I've taken so far. The 5 assignments were all the right level of difficulty imo. His lectures are very engaging and he's a pretty relatable prof. The tests i felt like were the perfect layout of mcq and frq Q's. They weren't too hard if you knew the defn's and understood the programming concepts.

I'm pretty sure this class got nerfed cuz it was way easier than 13S imo. A lot of the assignments had us changing maybe 15 lines of code. Also Quinn is THE most engaging, funny CS lecturer in the entire university. This is the only CS class where I actually attended because I enjoyed listening to the lecture. Probably the coolest professor ever.

Dr. Quinn is probably the best lecturer I've ever had. He's funny, engaging, personable, I wish he taught every CSE course at UCSC. 130 is an extremely tough class and that's not his fault, he does what he can to prepare the students.

Coolest professor you'll ever take, he keeps lectures entertaining.

3 grace days for programming projects

130 is a VERY difficult course. The course will surely be revamped, but regardless, the difficulty of the course isn't his fault. He's a great professor and great lecturer. Be ready to spend 30+ hours on each assignment and DON'T WORRY ON THE TESTS THEY WILL BE CURVED 15-30%. Go to all TA sections and start the hw RIGHT AWAY. You'll do fine.

Homework and exams were crazy difficult. However, it is evident in his lectures and interactions with the students that he cares about us. I remember one day the week before the final where he was helping people out during office hours (which should last from 4pm - 5pm). He stayed till 9pm and even gave students who were waiting drinks.

Professor Quinn really cares about his students and his lectures are very interactive and funny. His office hours are usually filled with people who needs help with their code so it might take a bit. He really goes in depth during his office hours too. Overall a very enjoyable professor to work with despite the hard class materials and content.

Andrew Quinn is a fantastic professor. He did a great job teaching the course and is well respected. The class has a very tough midterm and finals but he treated us fair. I enjoyed the course and hope to take another course with Prof Quinn.

I really enjoyed CSE130 with Dr. Quinn.
The class will be difficult with whoever teaches it, so you might as well take it with someone who teaches it well.

Dr. Q is a great professor, I thought he did a decent job in his first undergrad course. The class overall is TOUGH. The exams are designed so that no one gets an A. He curves them VERY generously though to accurately represent the performance of the class. The assignments are large and can take 25+ hours. It is, however, a very rewarding class.
Great Prof. Programming assignments are challenging but that is how the course is designed. I would take a course with Prof Quinn again!

After retaking this course I can say that Quinn has done a pretty good job instructing this class. One big issue was the recurring pipeline blackouts: the autograder went down for 1-2 days at a time, giving you less time to test your code before the due date. Exams were hard but curved hard too. Watch out for the FRQs, you code on paper for these

Dr. Quinn is a great professor and lecturer. CSE 130 is incredibly difficult and unfortunately I failed the class because I could not pass the autograded tests. He is helpful in office hours and cares about his students. The programming assignments were extremely difficult on top of challenging concepts in lectures. Had to handwrite code in exams.

A lot of content in the lectures, most of the work comes from the labs. labs take a couple hours to complete and follow strict formatting requirements (30%), some being very programming heavy. Three exams total (%55), you fail the final exam you fail the course. Final lab project with partner, demo required and assesment of code (10%). Avoid.

While Parsa is caring, she is too involved with student personal life. Lab and test questions are often ambiguous and unclear. Lecture slides are gatekept. The 6 labs are quite heavy and can take multiple hours each. That being said, class content can be very interesting and rewarding if you're into it. Doable but find other options if possible.

Lecture/content is fine (good, even), but the administrative side of this course is disturbingly awful. This class is shockingly disrespectful of students' time. The labs are poorly written and formatted. No recorded lectures, no annotated slides. Imposes her style of learning onto you, treating you like a child but working you like its pre-1938.

I think she tries to be a good teacher, but I end up being less motivated to learn. It's not any particular action, but it sometimes feels like she doesn't want everyone to succeed, only those who really deserve it.

Also, it feels like most of the work spent on labs is for the specifics of the directions as opposed to the actual content.

Lectures were less than useless, you're better off skipping them and just reading the textbook or watching Jim Kurose's YouTube videos since she just rips him off anyway. All of the material can be found online for free, so most of the actual class is superfluous and a waste of time. She also took down the class Canvas and made grades inaccessible.

This is a conflicting class. I loved learning about networking but the grading is insane. The labs, group work, and test grading criteria are unclear. She's nice for the most part but like others said, she doesn't know what's happening in the labs so it's essentially a TA-run course. I'm CE and I wish I'd taken the 123 series instead of this->157.

Yes, she seems like a nice person and can seem caring. Personality does not equal teaching skill. Horrible teacher, all content not original (labs, lecture, and book taken from Jim Kurose). Extremely disconnected from the class, doesnt know what happens in lab, and does poor job answering questions. TAs run the course. But does it all with a smile!

Almost all of the actual course material is blatantly stolen from Jim Kurose, including the slides used in class and large portions of the lab material. All the actual work done to run the class is done by TAs; she doesn't know what's happening in the labs. The only thing she actually does is give vague answers to questions and grade some midterms.

I thought the lectures and labs were super helpful; it helped me understand the material. I appreciated seeing the feedback on my assignments and all the grades were consistently submitted on time. I recommend you go to office hours because she genuinely cares and will help every student succeed. I definitely recommend taking the class with her!
Actually wants students to fail

Completely disconnected from her own class; doesn't know what's happening in the labs she assigns. Has changed assignment details within less than 2 days before the assignment's due date. Lab projects are based on python libraries that aren't explained or taught. Project specifications were incomplete and vague. Basically a TA-run course.

Meh lot's of people are overreacting the class is fine not great not terrible just lot's of busywork. The last lab which was a group project was poorly planned though and many people were failing the auto grader when it worked locally. I didn't find the material super challenging but I'd assume if you have zero exposure then yea read up.

Some overreacting with how bad she is. She cares about her students, clearly outlines how to succeed in the course as well as always available to talk if you need extra clarification. It's a content heavy class with the homework being doable if you do the readings and pay attention in class. labs are very time consuming but relative to content.

Treats you like it's daycare but works you like it's the navy. Lectures are just a 90 minute rehash of the reading you already did. Lab content is unrelated to the class. Generally pretentious attitude, acts like she's doing you a favor by wasting your time.Will have one of her coworkers email you if you miss a lecture. Poorly organized. Avoid her

Idk why everyone hates her, but she is really nice and her lectures are easy to understand even though the material is complicated. I didn't like the labs that much, and sometimes it felt like busywork, but overall she is a great professor and seems like she would give good hugs.

if you go to lectures, read the textbook, do practice problems, and do your assignments, you will succeed. parsa's lectures are very clear and easy to understand. if youre a bum who likes to not pay attention in class and blame everything on professor rather than yourself, dont take this class!

Christina Parsa is a professor who is completely disconnected from the course she teaches and doesn't care at all about her students. CSE150 is a TA run course, entirely lab-based, with mandatory group projects. Parsa doesn't know what is going on with these labs, and will never take questions even during office hours. Please be warned.

Professor Parsa was, at least to me, extremely sweet and kind. She is a nice person, no doubts about that. That being said, its no joke this class is 7 units. We had a lab every week, which was mandatory attendance (progress checks). Pop quizzes too for 5% of the grade. Lots of busy work. I did learn a lot though, the curve on the final was massive

Parsa doesn't record lectures nor post annotated slides, so if you didn't take thorough notes from her fast-paced lecture, you'll struggle with her tests, consisting of vague questions that can be argued either way, or obscure facts from the textbook (who cares where Dijkstra created his algorithm?). Nice professor and pretty forgiving though.

The type of professor to really tarnish a school's reputation. Unstructured course, covers very little even for an intro class, no programming instruction(professor does not know how to code), TAs are helpful, graders instructed to give 0 partial credit. forced to beg for regrades, they only give you a few days to find and fix THEIR mistake.
Boring mandatory 7-9pm lectures, gives you an average of 50% credit on the labs so that people drop the class, then curves my 55% to a B+ at the end. Not very fun.

One midterm, one final exam. About 4 labs and 1 final project which is basically another lab. After the midterm everyone was freaking out and he tried to quell our fears by saying that a 55 was a B?? We had to beg him to allow us to resub one (1) assignment and that's it. Crazy curve at the end, I thought I would fail honestly.

A lot of self-learning, as he does a poor job of preparing students for both the assignments and exams. He clearly knows the material and can teach it, but the class lacks structure and expectations are way too high for the little guidance that the students are given.
enough said
take with someone else

A charisma vacuum; I'm confident Mike knows what he's talking about in-class, but it doesn't matter. If you like a textbook recited to you at 7:10pm, go for it. No guide to programming labs, you can figure it yourself. Oh, you got an error for the 10th edge case? C-

Be better than me, and listen to reviews, this guy is a 1/5.

I would give this guy a 0 if I could. Little to no help on programming assignments and they are very difficult. Professor doesnt listen to any student suggestions, just makes excuses. His lectures are dry and boring. You are better off taking 151. Content we are graded on is very different from what is gone over in class.

The book is your only friend. The labs are vague, must be done from scratch, be quizzed on material that rarely shows up on lectures; The professor expects you to do everything yourself in a 'hopeful' manner. Similar to Van Gelder, the class is structured that you must teach yourself the content of the class. If anything, expect some frustration

His lectures are mandatory but you can look back on yuja videos and find the form link, he allows this. His quizzes can be a little difficult but as long as you do the HW you should be ok. His labs are fun, but can be challenging. Start the labs asap. Go to TA and tutor OH, they help so much! His lectures are great and he is a really good professor

Davis is a good professor and he cares about his students and tries to make sure the class is equitable. The class is time consuming but it is fun and creative work. Definitely, take this class if you come from an art or game design background, but don't take it with other hard/time consuming classes.

Assignments are very open-ended, but you can get a B with the bare minimum of the assignment specs. Each assignment has a category for impressiveness, so you will have to put some work in to get an A in the class. We have "competitions" where students can submit assignments for voting. Winner gets put in a hall of fame for future students to see.

Davis truly cares about the class and his students. Every assignment has helper videos that guide you through the basics, and he constantly asks for feedback to improve the course. Very clear grading rubric, no midterm or final, but a lot of work and you learn a lot. Really fun in-class contests. One of my favorite classes here at UCSC.

Highly understanding and funny prof. He really cares about his students and can meet you halfway if you run into any issues. Assignments had helper videos covering much of the assignment requirements, with extra implementations for full credit. Really fun final project in ThreeJS. Contests were so fun! Looked forward to his lectures always.

Davis is a great professor and really cares for his students. He has google forms after each lecture and tries to change the class to be fair for everyone. He was extremely fast to respond and give information about the TA strikes, and he tried his best to be open with us. One of the best professors I've had at Santa Cruz.

Davis is an awesome professor who is able to engage with the class. The class can be tough, but the grading is fair. Be prepared to study A LOT for quizzes as these determine whether or not you pass. Though that seems scary, it is very doable. There were 4 total homeworks each of which took around 15 - 20 hours to learn the material and program.

If you have the option of taking Davis for 101, do it! He Is very understanding, teaches well, and is very responsive. Class is test heavy, he drops your lowest score, you can get 3/5 on the tests and pass. Allowed retakes for tests 1-3. HW determines your ABC grade, he also drops your lowest hw grade out of the 4 total PAs assigned.

Awesome professor, very knowledgeable and passionate about graphics. Open to feedback from students. Lectures are informative, but fast-paced and can be hard to follow for beginners. Assignments and labs come with tutorials. Quizzes and homework are fair. Class can be difficult if you have minimal coding experience, but definitely doable.

An excellent professor and a funny guy. No midterm or final, just 5 quizzes that are pretty easy, with questions pulled somewhere from the lecture. Projects make up 40% of the grade, and the grading rubric is extremely clear. Overall, this was the most fun I'd had in any class, and the material was highly engaging.
I know a lot of students get an A. It is a fun class and not that difficult. I should think about what is my problem. Take this class if you are interested in it.

CSE 160 with Davis was one of the best classes I have had the pleasure to take. The material was presented clearly. The labs were a lot of fun to do because they allowed students to explore creative avenues outside of the given requirements. It was really fun having the class contests where we can see what other students did for their labs.

Professor Davis was a nice lecturer and indeed an expert in Computer Vision. He cared about students a lot, especially during office hours. Dont forget to attend TA sessions if you have difficulty in programming assignments because most TAs had previously taken 160 and were quite helpful. Review all the slides before exams and you gonna be fine!

5 Quizzes, 6 programming assignments, 4 written homeworks. The quizzes aren't too hard if you pay attention during class. The homeworks are pretty easy, you complete them during the labs. The programming assignments aren't too hard, sometimes they can be pretty fun to do. It's a fun elective to take. The prof is super chill and nice

It was Davis' first time teaching 101 but he immediately showed capable of teaching. He used Sesh's material but it worked out fine. HW was the right amount of difficulty and quizzes actually prepare you for job interviews. Grading is very lenient and he drops lowest HW and quiz. 10/10 would take again.

A very caring professor, but not particularly good at conveying material. Lectures felt relatively unorganized. Professor would often mention topics, without being able to explain it, telling students "I don't know how this works, just use a library." Easy assignments, if tedious - an easy A, but not a gratifying course overall.

For the class, the amount of work was fair and the grading criteria to receive an A was very clear. As a professor, Davis cares greatly for the students and listened to our feedback. He wants the students to do well in both his class and the future. Especially in the current state of the world, he was understanding and adjusted accordingly.

His way of teaching is fantastic - he has a way of teaching foreign material that is easy to understand. Assignments take quite a bit of time, but everything was worth it and came with support. I can't say that of most cse professors...

One of the best professors Ive ever had. If a majority of the class needs an extension of some kind or extra help he gives it. Lectures are engaging and only 5% of grade in cse163. NOTE 163 is a low level graphics class webgl, so you need to understand what is happening to do well. Textbooks have great examples and he allows outside sources (cited)

Great lecturer and all around great guy. Listens to feedback from the class, and has a open door policy when it comes to criticism/concerns. Wasn't the biggest fan of his no calculator no notes policy, but he makes up for it by providing solutions to homework problems. Still managed to keep his cool even in this hectic quarter with strikes/COVID-19

Most content is focused solely on lectures with labs spread throughout the quarter. I took 150 w Parsa first and then dropped it to take it with Qian, it's obvious which one is the better choice. The grading is so generous, just put at least some effort. you'll be fine

The class is lecture-heavy, and exams are based on lectures. With that being said, Labs prove not to be the hardest, and all 4 together are 45% of the grade. The midterm is 20% and the final is 30%. To pass you only need 60%. Generous on midterm grading. If you give the class a modicum of effort you'll be fine. Better than Parsa, and a nice guy.

One word of advice, don't take this class with Parsa. Take this Class with Professor Chen Qian. Compare their scores on here and see why. I took this class, and while it was challenging the professor was very king with his grading. Go to class and get free points doing small quizzes (can help your grade!)

Cool class for learning about how the internet works. The labs are pretty challenging but there aren't a lot of them. Watch out for the midterm and final since the questions are taken from the textbook rather than the lectures.
Semi challenging midterm and final, generous grading. Him and the TA's are really nice and the overall grade is also curved

I liked the class concepts but lectures feel really long. I don't think that is Chen's fault though as there are just a lot of content to cover. He is really nice and I feel like the class is not really high stress.

Chen is a really nice guy, and pretty laid back. Labs aren't too hard if you start early, and as long as you review lecture slides for the tests you'll be fine. Interesting content but it's a lot sometimes so don't fall behind

He reads straight off lecture slides, which themselves are directly copied from the author of the textbook's slides, so his lectures are often hard to follow and poorly worded. Assignment instructions were never clear and TAs are usually unhelpful. Exams are entirely based off material from slides. The syllabus is mostly just a suggestion.

LOTS of information but the lectures are just him reading off the slides. The exams are based almost exclusively off the material from the slides, which sucks because the labs are the most interesting part of this class. Some of the TAs were abysmal, generally unhelpful and just told students to ask ChatGPT to answer their questions.
Solid networking teacher, take the labs seriously cause they will grade you down on the pre lab if you don't get it 100%. Explains things well. Tests are HARD (study the slides)

This class was very unorganized. The syllabus was often not followed and the professor made the grading and assignment specifications unclear. Many assignments had conflicting instructions between class and the actual assignment pdf. No feedback is given, just the grade is given. Overall, not a bad class, the professor could just be more clear.

Teaching isn't super engaging as he just reads off the slides. Nice guy and always willing to answer questions during lectures. Content itself isn't super difficult it's just that you're learning a lot of concepts which can be overwhelming. Don't fall behind because it'll make catching up a pain. Tests are challenging, the labs are straightforward.

He is not a very engaging lecturer. Labs were ultimately pointless and barely related to what we learned in class. The lab specs were somewhat vague and contradictory. The VM image for the labs is also outdated (Ubuntu 14, code was written in Python 2.7). However, the class overall is pretty easy, especially if you've taken CSE 80N.

Really great professor who is passionate about this course. Lab assignments were not difficult and the midterm was pretty straightforward so long as you understand the material, no tricks. The pop quizzes were mainly just for attendance, open note single question you can answer within 5 words. Would highly recommend taking for credit
Objectively the best professor to take CSE 107 with. Tests aren't ridiculously hard like the other two professors. His notes are really good I never felt obligated to go to lectures.

The professors are very nice. Although I don't listen to the lectures very much, I think he teaches very well. But I don't like the virtual machine that has been used for such a class (not because of the professor). It feels like it's almost as old as I am. Try to work hard then you can get good grade and learn a lot.

He is great. A little boring, but you are in cse so? The test are just the lecture slides, so easy to study. No homework that isn't a lab. Though, the labs are low key time consuming but easy. He is a good lecture, I understand the material it is just a boring topic and there is probably no way to make it fun. Overall one of the nicest CSE prof's.

There are three assignments, two midterms, and one final. The exams are very short and similar to the optional homework problems. The professor is not very accommodating when it comes to test and does not respond quickly through email or Piazza. Professor does want students to pass and does curve classes.

Pretty laid back professor, exam heavy. Although I struggle with math in general, his course focused more on the theory of stats and probability than arithmetic and calculus part of it. Exams were fair.
CSE107 is a joke with Chen Qian. His lectures are basically melatonin. Lovely professor. Extremely organized and his notes are really informative.
Did not respond to students asking to view their finals. did not release final grades till the day they were due. I would not take again

By far one of the worst cs professor I had. Her lectures were so unorganized and felt very unproductive and would get off topic and hard to follow the point.
Grades were always delayed didn't know final grade until grade were due. 55% homework 20% Midterm 25% final and if you did better on the final it replaced your midterm grade.
Do not recommend!

Very unresponsive, completely lacks professional communication with students. Grading is severely delayed which makes it hard to study especially for the midterm and final which is more than half of your grade. Homework's are unbelievably difficult. She didn't even provide the final exam on canvas so we just have to trust her :)

I dont know why this professor has negative reviews but she is one of the chillest professors I have had. She cares about her students and isn't harsh on grading either. She follows the same pattern for midterm and finals and the questions are pretty similar to the homework. Overall an easy A for me, I highly recommend taking CSE 101M with her.

Honestly, I don't know why she has so many extremely negative reviews. Her lectures were fine, and her homework was reasonable. Her exam questions weren't too different from the homework either, she doesn't throw curveballs here. She did take forever to grade HW though, and her feedback wasn't the best most of the time. Not the best, but not bad.
Ive converted into 15 different religions since entering this course. The only person that helped me in this class is God himself.
Would rather drop out than try to learn another subject from her, confusing jumbled lectures, only around 10 students come to lecture after the first week. Rough one

This class made me stop looking both ways before crossing the street. Genuinely am baffled I had to pay for this course. The TA's are mediocre at best, and Kolla is easily the worst professor I've encountered. Please don't take this class.
Do the world a favor and fire your TAs and never teach again.

Overall, the teacher was a cool person. However, the lectures were boring and unorganized. The classroom was basically empty by the 3rd week. The grading was harsh; there were only 8 assignments, so there was very little chance of making it up. Each was long and had little to nothing to do with the lectures. I'd pick another teacher if possible.
What an absolute joke of a professor. Fire her.
If L was a professor

Absolutely despicable grade scale (ZERO extra credit or freebies) combined with harsh grading makes this course a nightmare, I had to do too many regrade requests and go to too many office hours to claw my work to a good level, and it felt like I was constantly looking for gotchas. They don't even provide answer keys for the review problems.

Drop the midterm if final score is higher they said. Drop the two lowest homework scores they said. Will grade on a curve they said. Yeah they followed through with that promise when fat pigs fly. But Alex and the TAs don't have wings.

When taking her class, her examples in the lectures are rather easy but the homework is really hard. The hw is also graded by accuracy but they do have two lowest hw drops. For the midterm and final review, they are harder than the actual tests and don't even give us the answers to them. She expects us to just know the information
a(L)exandra ko(L)(L)a

Lectures were terrible. Generally boring, quite poorly organized, and she had no idea what was actually visible on the projector at any given time, and as she's partially deaf it's very difficult to catch her attention so that the things she is discussing are actually visible to the students. Homework is graded on accuracy? Choose a different prof

This is the worst class I've taken so far. Lectures are unorganized, and don't reflect well on the homework or tests. The midterm was not anything like the practice, and homework is graded as hard as the 8 hour Suneung test in Korea. The professor could barely write as well as a 10 year old, and did not answer questions well, or at all sometimes.
Do not take Kolla for the love of god

He's a very good professor when it comes to teaching and learning content, even though my grade wasn't the best, I still
Learnt so much about computer architecture, more than I would with Nath even though nath is easier. However his class is 50% final and their hard, so that's the drawbacks

Definitely a tough class but also definitely an awesome class. 
I think it's hard by it's a lot of content to squeeze in a quarter structure. The class is mostly test based grading, light assignments, not enough problems to practice. 
Generally Professor Litz have amazing lectures, so if you really interested and want to learn something, go for it.
Midterm and final averages were around 50%.  Just take nath dawg

PROs:
1. professor tries to fit everything for Computer Architecture, good news for people who actually wants to learn.
2. Supportive TAs.

CONs:
1. Too much content in a single quarter, therefore lots of disconnects and confusion on HW and exams, you need to take extra steps.
2. 70% (mid + final), think twice if you just want easy grade to pass.

Litz really knows his stuff and welcomes all questions. The material is dense.The midterm and final count for most of your grade.  I learned so much in this class, despite feeling that I didn't do that well. All assignments are autograded, including exams (no partial credit).

Great lectures, homework/quizzes/exams are related to but distinct from lecture material. Assignments and exams are scuffed (literally everything is a Canvas quiz), lots of MCQ so almost zero partial credit. Midterm avg was a 53%. Lots of cumulative content, you cannot afford to fall behind. Good class but the assignments and exams are just bad.

Genuinely awful class. Extremely dense lectures paired with slow pace = info overload. Huge disjoint between HW, test, lectures and discuss. TAs reschedule every discussion section. For a class thats 70% exams they don't do a good job of providing resources to help. Everything that wasn't on the practice midterm and HW was what was on the midterm.

His class structure is pretty bad most of the Tas randomly postpone their section even though the section is mandatory. The homework is extremely hard and not easy to figure out, very test-heavy. I got out of this class before I got cooked.

So my counselor suggested that I take this class since I couldn't get into other classes since it filled up. I had no prior experience so I went to TA sections since the beginning of the quarter and worked with a group only to end up with a C- (5% below the passing grade 60%) which pissed me off. Ppl told me that if I had Nath I would've passed.

He's a nice guy. His lectures are informative and detailed. However, this class was really hard. His exams were difficult and worth huge towards final grade. Final is 60%, not joking here. You fail the final, you fail the class. Study after each lecture and understand the concepts. Form a study group with people in this class.

CSE12 Decent lecturer, he talks a lot and sometimes I feel like he is rambling about the content. Lectures could be more engaging. No grade curves but the grading scale is pretty lenient. He gave out ec for the in class quizzes (ez) SETS and for lab4. Good with answering and explaining your questions. The midterm had some questions that felt random

Litz is a good professor as long as you attend lectures consistently and are reviewing lecture contents between classes. The labs are difficult if you don't start them early. So start labs early, attend your lectures, and you'll be fine. There was a considerable amount of EC for the last lab so my grade was boosted to over 100%.

Ok class, learned a lot and material was interesting, professor is also very polite and patient. It's very confusing to try to learn how to do the problems correctly, given how exam heavy this class is, that makes it pretty hard. The prof was also against releasing midterm/practice test solutions or even correct answers for the final.

The final is 60% of the grade. The professor does not round grades so what you see is what you get. Grades are scaled down so an A- is 85%. Even tho there are only a few quizzes, you need to do well on them since they are worth so few points that missing 1 question hurts. The final is tough, so understand why and concepts rather than memorization!

Lectures were great and most assignments weren't too bad. Most of the questions were pretty fair. Took questions like a champ and it didn't feel like they slowed down the lecture. Grading scale was adjusted instead of a curve (plug in scores and see what letter Canvas says) and the final weighs a LOT.
He's so handsome.

Heiner is a great professor. 120 is full of concepts but Heiner made the lecture not boring at all. The assignments were medium-level. Exams are not easy to get 85+. However, the exams weighed a lot! I will recommend incoming students form study groups and put a lot of time into reviewing the slides, book, and assignments.

Litz is a great professor. Some people think he lectures too slowly but I think his pace is just right since the class topics are so dense. Really good at explaining things in lecture but section/textbook are also useful. Final is 60% of grade so study hard for it. It may be hard but you will get a decent score if you understand the topics well.
