Heiner is actually one of UCSC's best professors. If you're looking for an easy A look elsewhere, but his lectures are engaging and taking his class with absolutely leave you smarter than you came in.

Professor Litz is very passionate about the subject, by his lectures can be pretty dry, making it hard to focus in class. The quizzes and the homework were pretty difficult. In my opinion, the midterm is extremely easy, but the final was harder. Consider going to MSI. It helped me out a lot.
He is a good lecturer and empathetic. He makes the class entertaining and interesting. I would take this class if it interests you, it is a good class.

Professor Manduchi is very passionate about what he teaches. The class was so interesting. I enjoyed it. He had very clear and easy to follow lectures. There is a quiz every week about the content we learned the week before, which is why I got the grade I got. They are somewhat difficult. Overall, cool class and professor.

I took his class on Disability, Technology and Society and it was great! Probably my favorite classes that quarter. He Had very clear and succinct lectures. There is a small quiz every week on the materials the week before. The other assignments are a project that didn't take me too long to do and a final test. Could have gone over ADA better tho.

I have to say this was by far one of the best classes I have ever taken in general! It was super interesting, and professor Manduchi has an excellent drive for what he does, and it is really apparent in how he teaches. It's not often you find someone so driven to a topic, especially for a class like this! If you want to learn take him!!!!

Manduchi assigns weekly quizzes that usually consist of 4-7 Qs based on the last class's lecture that counts for WAY too much of your final grade (4o%) and you have 20 mins to complete it; the questions can be tricky and similar to DMV drivers test questions. There are 3 HW assignments, a multiple-choice final, and an easy final project.

This class is very easy, and is good for padding schedules as you can finish all the work for the class in about 30min/week. Quizzes are open book and lecture PDFs have all the answers. Not sure why this class is listed under CSE, there is nothing related to computers or engineering in this course. Class is easy but you won't really learn anything.

Very informative class & super clear professor. Sometimes the quizzes felt difficult to me even though I paid attention during the recorded lectures + took good notes, but I still was able to get an A. The final project and homework are pretty easy as well.
Uploads lectures on canvas, clear speaker, easy pop quizzes, no midterm, one final optional project, and 80 question multiple choice final. You'll be fine even if you don't take notes.

Found the class super easy. No midterm, had about 4 multiple choice pop quizzes. Final was multiple choice. For class he lectures from slides. Sometimes brought in interesting speakers. Homework was trivially easy. Attendance isn't mandatory, but might miss quizzes. The prof is a super nice guy, makes lecture bearable. Recommend for easy class.

He is one of my favorite professors that I've ever taken. I started to pursue a career in assistive technology after taking his class. I had a B average in quizzes, A- in homework, B on the final, and A -on the project. Everything is fair and I hope to get him again as a professor down the road.

This class is an easy A as long as you show up to all the lectures. Be prepared for a quiz every class, sometimes they're a little tricky. Manduchi is passionate about the subject and his lectures are interesting.

Good teacher, easy class, however not as easy as people said before. Now has a final, but it's not too bad. It's the quizzes that will get people. Definitely come to every class expecting a quiz. The homework is fine, but, depending on the T.A, might be graded harshly.
No midterm, no final just project at the end; however, was very easy.

I took his "Mobile Sensing and Interaction" class. Sounds like fun! Except it's iOS only which makes an already tough class more so if you lack an iOS device. Very frequently he will ask the class of 15 people questions and expect us to know the answer. He may insult you if you attend his office hours. I don't think he curves very well.

Tests are not representative of the course, and there are no practice problems so you never know what to expect.  Any small mistake can cost you a lot of points.  Therefore it's hard to know what to study for the exams.

You can tell Roberto really cares about what he teaches. Interesting projects are done at the end of the quarter, although i preferred doing a book report. You can choose either depending on your preference. Learned a lot in this class that will help me consider all the different types of disabilities. I recommend this class.
Absolutely awesome class! I got an A, and I really enjoyed the class! He is a great professor, and it is interesting. He grades fairly

Roberto is very nice and keeps things very simple and EASY, so easy. Take any class you can with him and you'll pass with minimal effort.  The final project was only worth 10 points, so you can see how simple the class was.   Of course, do the work; you have to respect the guy, because he is very nice.  But this is not a class that makes you worry.
Really easy class. No textbook, just powerpoint presentations and movies. But he gives pop quizzes so be ready! They're usually very easy though. He is a nice/smart guy too

This class was one of the best classes I have taken.  There is no textbook and all of his power points are online.  The only bad thing is you need to show up to all of his classes in case of his pop-quizzes. Just make sure you do the project instead of the book report to make this class easy.  Overall this is a easy class to use to fulfill a GE

The lectures in the class were pretty difficult to follow so I would recommend just looking at the slides, youtube, and reading the textbook. Overall, the content wasn't too difficult and was clearly layed out. The majority of the grade is HW, midterm, Final. Midterm and Final are somewhat tough but follow the slides and HW. HW is not too bad.

This was a good class, exams were pretty easy and you get notesheets, and the content is exactly what's in the homework and lectures, so it's fine.

Lectures are a little boring and slow, but contain useful content. I recommend downloading the slides and looking at them at your own pace.

No coding assignments, just homework assignments.

His English isn't the best, but you will get used to it quickly. Homework's are very close to the lectures. He gladly answers any questions you have without hesitation. Take this prof for 120 if you can.

CSE 130 has four programming assignments, with the 2nd and 4th being the most time-consuming. Professor Xu is nice but not the best at explaining advanced topics. Midterms and the final are manageable if you review the lecture slides.

I believe Professor Xu did quite well in his first quarter teaching CSE120. He managed to keep the lectures engaging and well-paced. I appreciated how he always made time for questions between slides. The homework itself was somewhat complex but definitely doable, and both the midterms and finals closely mirrored the homework questions.

Though Xu is new and I believe he did do a decent job. He is knowledgeable but there is a language barrier. Use the free textbook he follows, this is an introductory computer architecture class it is very manageable. TA's make frequent grading mistakes so go over rubric yourself, decent curve, small midterm and final, lots of homework extensions.

I believe Xu is a new lecturer and despite some flaws he did a pretty good job with 120. He did his best with the lectures but his accent made it a bit difficult for me. TAs responded decently quickly on Piazza. Homework was a bit obtuse but not impossible, midterms/finals were largely rehashes of homework questions.

Lectures were well paced and students always had time to ask questions in between slides. Professor Xu has a little bit of an accent, but he is more engaging than Nath and is pretty easily accessible outside of class. TAs are usually willing to check your homework for you. For his first quarter teaching I'd say he did a pretty good job.

If you don't attend tutoring or office hours you will fail this class. Lectures are often unclear and usually don't tell you how to do the HW. Very mediocre lecturer and the class was disorganized. All the course contents are a 1:1 copy of another professor's curriculum which isn't inherently bad but if he can't explain it well that's a problem.

The professor doesn't know too much english so it's hard to understand what he's talking about. Most of the time he's just reading off the slides. Homework assignments are therefore very difficult as little to no examples are provided in class. TA Office hours are a must in order to understand HW problems.
Best professor at UCSC.

Professor Amengual is fantastic! He knows so much about bilingualism and phonetics. He is very clear and offers extensive feedback. I learned a lot in his class. If you do the work the class is not hard
Mark is hilarious and knows his stuff! He is interesting and has great questions to pose about language.
Saori is so sweet, her slideshows are always engaging and she is great at teaching about applied linguistics.

Don't take her class if you really want to learn and advance your Japanese skill.
She is very bad at explaining Japanese phrases&concepts either in Japanese or English, and the assignments and exam questions she makes are full of obvious problems. 
If the grades doesn't matter to you and you just want to learn some useless Japanese, take it.

Hoshi is very sweet and super fun. She loves to interact with her students. If you've taken any other Japanese courses at UCSC, then you will know that the expectations are the same. Courseload isn't too heavy, but you've got to stay on top of it.

This teacher is so bald and boring, making every lecture slower than the last. He overcomplicates things when it's entirely unnecessary and lectures are all mandatory. The TAs carried and make the concepts so much easier to understand. I got an A by looking at outside resources entirely without the lectures, also recommended following study guides.

He is an okay professor. His slide presentations are very conceptual. I highly recommend reading the textbook. I found it more useful and effective for my learning than attending a lecture. There are weekly quizzes, so be aware of that. 

Go to TA sections!! 

The TA was also impactful for my learning as she explained the content proficiently.

His lectures are so pointless. Makes arithmetic seem like rocket science. You'll get a good grade in the class. Covers so much content that isn't tested. Lectures are conceptual doesn't do many examples.

If you bring a pillow and headphones to lectures you'll get an A. I got 100 on EVERY test, everything I learned was from the TA or internet. Grading policy and tests are crazy lenient and easy. 

His lectures are good in a sense, just extremely beyond the scope of what he tests on. Theory heavy. 

He makes jokes sometimes, they're funny.

I had zero experience in linear algebra prior, studied(including hw and quiz) maybe 5 hours a week and aced all 3 midterms no issue. The midterms are very similar to the given homework and reviews making them easy. 

Heavy lectures, easy tests! Easy A, if you are okay at math.

If I were to choose between walking on Legos forever or taking this class, I would pick Legos. No joke, I'm learning more on YouTube than going to the lectures. My relationship with this class is like The Office season 5 episode 8 on MyFlixer. It is just ridiculous. Like, I'm losing my mind just typing this rating right now.

The worst class I've ever been in in my life. I hate him and he ruined my life. i failed this class twice, and it turns out I didn't even need his class , but please don't take this class at all because, for your mental health, try to just take the lab at ucsc and take the math class at a community college or something because it's worth more
He is very boring, he might assign you 3 midterms for fun, overall an easy class though, don't bother going to lecture he basically teaches in another language.

I took linear algebra and it was difficult. I'm not very good at calculation. But one has to admit, the class was pretty fair. He had a good balance between concepts and computation. On many tests, there was a shortcut in calculation, provided you understood the concept! Make sure you listen to lecture because the concepts are cumulative.
4 worst quizzes dropped, attendance graded, 2 weeks per hw assignment, really cares about students, gives reviews from past classes, lowest 2 hw dropped

He once changed the homework because it ended up being too hard. Then he said "For the 3 students who have already submitted the assignment: please submit again, with the new Problem 2... Sorry."
He literally rewarded being proactive and not procrastinating with more work. Wtf.

he sent an email out in week 1 poking fun at students who were waiting last second to submit homework, but when 3 students solved the homework early and he decided on a whim to change one of the problems he refused to give extra credit to those who did extra work for being early, refusing to make a new rubric for just 3 students. no moral backbone

He made me believe in the multiverse. Not because of mathematical proof, but because I know in another universe I am Invincible and he is Conquest. 

Mandatory unhelpful lectures, difficult homework, tests are okay if you stick to the practice tests as the questions end up being a carbon copy.

He's a terrible explainer and lecture is mandatory but unhelpful. Homework was harder than the exams, so give yourself time to do them. Exams made up 60% of the grade, but the practice tests were very similar so if you study early you'll do well, unfortunately I usually studied a day before. Overall, bad professor but passable if you put in effort.

i have NO idea how i got an A+ in this class. jonathan is so theory heavy it makes you want to evaporate on the spot; his lectures are SO unhelpful, I cannot stress that enough. And the worst part is that they're required.. like bro if ur gonna give us attendance codes at least give us example problems and be a little less mind melting boring. booo

Class is ok. The lectures are boring and not that helpful. The TA sessions were my saving grace in this class. There is some leniency in the grading of the tests and some extra credit opportunity. If you try, you'll get a good grade, just be prepared to be bored.

This professor goes through the material very quickly, and when asked a question, he also explains it very quickly to the point that you don't feel like you've received a clear answer to your question. His handwriting is incredibly bad and difficult to read. He also punished the entire class for a student's wrongdoing when I was in his class.

The dude was pretty condesending and kinda aggressive at times. Lectures were mandatory too but you can just ignore him and still do fine. Just review the study guides for the 3 midterms and final and that teaches you all you need to know. Not a hard class necessarily but the professor wasn't the best. The TA I had was super helpful though.

STATS 17. LLLLL professor. He is very unorganized and aggressive. One week, he even got mad at the class when no one knew the answer to his question. EVEN THOUGH WE DON'T KNOW IT, HE IS BAD AT TEACHING. DO NOT take this class if you don't need to. It sucks!!! He also makes attendance at everything mandatory. We have three midterms and a final. L

Lectures are dry, boring, unhelpful, and don't help at all for the exams. Basically just points out random theories from the textbook, circling lines from his pre written slideshows (handwritten too with awful penmanship). TA basically taught everything; his teaching style is just that bad. Material isn't even bad, he's just not a good teacher.

Your grade is basically entirely determined by lecture quizzes, as they effectively replace midterms (practically 4 midterms). Final is cumulative; no notes of yours are ever allowed on anything. Has a lowest-score-dropped policy that makes extenuating circumstances blanketly applied under this policy. Don't have family emergencies, or else.

Final is cumulative, provides no study guides or extra credit. Spends zero time on important concepts that we should know for quizzes and finals. Doesn't finish sample problems or says "I'm not gonna walk you through this" to save time. Only teaches the basics so you feel unprepared for harder problems, Vague with tutors. Easy attendance though.

Lectures were helpful for the most part, although sometimes she would start problems but not finish them to save time. Cares a lot about her students and is easy to reach outside of class. The mini quizzes were light, and the lecture quizzes offered many partial credit opportunities. Not too hard a course if you have prior knowledge of Calc 2.

actually so good at teaching and explains to you if you have a hard time understanding, lectures are important and super clear, homework every week, discussion quizzes every week, lecture quiz every other week, doesnt cover econ application very well tho, just do the practice problems

Attendance is taken w amplify online.  A light mini quiz in your discussions and lecture quiz every other week. No midterm but the lecture quizes were worth the most in the class. final only worth 15%. light hw and easy to reach out to TAs but u just gotta show constant effort, if you start to skip its over. good class over all!

Lecture's were pretty easy to follow, homework had some difficult problems, but overall was good. Most of your grade will be from lecture quizzes taken every 2 weeks, they are 3-4 problems based on the previous 2 weeks of lecture. Final is worth 10 percent, don't sweat. Attending TA sections was mandatory and 15% of your grade.

If you're not a math person, I strongly advise against Prof. Simons' class. Her lectures aren't beginner-friendly. I have a hard time following her lectures, and the biweekly lecture quizzes/weekly section quizzes don't help (all for grades). The use of Desmos/Amplify helped a little, but I found myself constantly looking for outside help.
I love Julie. Her class was pretty easy if you know a little Calc.

she taught using desmos which helped keep me engage but she did a poor job of explaining concepts. two midterms, no calc no notes. test averages were ab 60 for both midterms but no curve. absurdly hard hw that didnt match what we were learning in terms of difficulty. preclass wasnt helpful. i only passed bc i went to lss weekly. she is vry nice tho

Lecture-heavy with lots of in-class and pre-class assignments. Does a thorough job during lectures but overcomplicates stuff sometimes. Lots of opportunities to boost your grade with class assignments, sections, and the final project. Homework is so hard and unnecessarily harder than what we actually do in class and on exams. Midterms were fine.

Attending office hours is really helpful she wants everyone to succeed. Attendance is mandatory, no midterms but bi-weekly quizzes, HW every week, and a final. She uses incredibly simple examples during lectures which used to bother me, but I found them helpful to understand the concepts. Quizzes during section too.

Math is hard and what we learned sucks,but she teaches in a way where you can understand and can grasp the material. Took her grading for granted. No midterm and the final is only worth 10%.The real chunk of your grade is the weekly quizzes in sections and bi-weekly quizzes in lecture, but its off of what you learned the past week so its mangable.

I really liked her! This was my first calc class. Her notes were clear and she explained things well. If you put in the work to study and understand everything conceptually, the lectures and homework do prepare you well for the lecture quizzes (biweekly) and final (cumulative, worth 10% of grade), but not really the discussion quizzes (weekly).

I took AM11A without experience in Econ or Calc. Professor Simons taught at a good pace. Homework was 10-20 questions on Math GPT which explains how to solve each problem. No midterms, but there are biweekly lecture quizzes (drop the lowest) and discussion quizzes every week (drop the lowest 2).  The final was cumulative but reasonable.

Julie is super nice and it's clear that she really cares/knows about the subject. The midterms/final are difficult, the questions are conceptual leaning rather than "solve for x", so you have to know why and how it works. The TAs are okay, sometimes going off course. She's a good prof, pay attention, and know why everything works in the way it does

SAVE YOURSELF. SAVE YOUR PEACE. SAVE YOUR MONEY.
She seems like a nice person, but this was one of the most unorganized and mentally exhausting classes I have ever taken. The only reason I passed was due to prior Calculus 2 experiences. That being said, things I already knew how to do that she explained made zero sense. She lacked communication.

Julie Simons is a nice lady. Attendance is mandatory, so go to class. It's crucial, and I failed due to it. There are two midterms, a final, and a group project with significant weightage. The final had questions about the group project, so pay attention. Office hours are helpful, and discussion was useful. Desmos in class isn't helpful.
The exam counts for 50%, and the questions aren't easy. she looks pretty kind, though.

If you haven't taken Calc 2 before you will be very confused. Her lectures are overcomplicated and she doesn't explain her rationale. The lectures are not well structured and she uses Desmos which I found unhelpful. Homework was harder than what you do in class and what was on tests and attendance is mandatory.

Lectures and homework are a waste of time. The test material is disconnected from what she teaches and what our homework is on. This is a good thing though because the test work is significantly easier than the stuff covered in lecture or the homework. Easy class overall and nothing to worry about if you put vague effort in and show up to class.

seriously such a caring teacher -- carries the same enthusiasm for math and passion to teach it characteristic of the AM department, but absolutely has new blood energy. knows how to make a class engaging, and will go above and beyond to help you succeed!! so thankful.
Easily the best professor I have ever had at UCSC. Would 100% again, and I hope he teaches more AM classes.

Being a part of Sean's first-class honestly feels like a true honor. Although lecture attendance isn't mandatory I highly recommend you show up––he made learning some heavy material really fun. Would take his class again or any other class if he ever gets the chance to teach again!
Such an understanding professor who made things very clean and was very reasonable throughout the whole course. Would absolutely take again and wish he taught all the AM courses.

My GOAT. The perfect professor is an understatement. Because of Sean I have a newfound love for the educational world, like a child watching a parade for the first time. Sean brings joy, life, vitality, and hope to every lecture. Nobody will compare.

Sean is a great instructor, his class is packed with interesting material if you have taken classes like cse30 and cse13s you will have a relatively easy time in this class but it teaches you about tools to analyze data with your code

I got to be apart of Sean's first course he's ever taught and honestly, he was one of the most caring teachers I've ever had at UCSC. I've never seen a teacher care this much about his students, which makes you want to learn and succeed in the course even more. Be lucky to learn from him!! Tough class, but he and the TA were great help.

Sean is very caring and super cool! Made lectures interesting and often stayed way past his office hours times just to help all the students that showed up. My only gripe is that often the homework assignments were quite a jump in difficulty from what we learned in class, so go to office hours as much as you can!

Sean is a very caring teacher. He makes sure that all students understand the material and puts in so much time and effort to see us succeed. No midterm or final just coding assignments and one final project.
Great instructor who teaches very well and cares a lot about students. Assignments are well-structured, and grading is very fair and straightforward.

Fun and interesting lectures. Fair amount of homework and quizzes, helps a lot with the midterm and final. His flipped classroom questions help prepare for the test, available for office hours to help. Allowed a fair amount of extra credit opportunities.

I never write reviews for professors, but Dongwook Lee is my one exception. He made this class so much harder than it needed to be. He never answers questions correctly and does not even provide a notecard for fully in-class exams. Do not listen to his advice for studying for the exams. Make sure you use the textbook to study for tests.

Made the midterm extremely hard and it wasn't even close to the review sheet. Class average is a 58% and I'm about to fail a major requirement in my spring quarter of sophomore year because of this. Go take AM20 with someone else

Prof. Lee is a great professor! I retook AM 30 with him after failing the first time and he made the material much more accessible in my opinion. He does many in class examples and uses demos to help students visualize. He gives extra credit and for us, dropped lowest quiz and homework scores. Very accommodating with extensions for valid reasons.

Professor Dongwook was an amazing professor! I had him for both AM20 and AM30, and he has lots of extra credit opportunities. His lecture notes are much more useful in class. Attendance is optional, but he is a funny professor and I really liked taking classes under him. Do the extra credit and do the homework, his final is hard but not insane.

Professor was fine in my opinion but didn't meet my learning style. Majority of lecture consisted of the textbook which made me just teach myself. I just had wished it was more engaging or more than just what the textbook said. Overall, fine class and professor.

Great professor. Although his midterm and final are 70% of the grade, working on the homework and studying should give you a good amount of practice. He is funny and is always open to students coming to his office hours.

He's a solid professor. Although his final exam was very difficult and caused a lot of stress for me and my classmates, long as you do the homework, go to sections/office hours, and study, you will get a good grade in his class.

Very straightforward class. He made our midterm easy and our final very hard. He curved, and everyone was cool with their grades. Make sure you nail the HW and Quizzes because they are easy points so long as you keep up with the material. He gives a study guide very similar to the tests, but just different enough to make you really understand.
Hilarious guy who is probably my favorite professor on campus. helps you a whole ton in office hours, super nice and approachable, homework is directly related to the quizzes and midterms

Dongwook has massively improved as a profesor. His lectures are clearly structured and if you pay attention they can be enough to learn the material. He uses a lot of examples and does a good job of answering questions.
Lee started off the quarter rough (up until 1st order DE's) but became amazing towards the end. He makes a ton of mistakes, but his tests were fair and very similar to the practice sheets.
Very available for questions of any kind !
Professor Lee made me love CFD !
Great !
Just don't.
Lecture is boring and not very helpful, but reading the book, going to office hours, and attending section all help with this class.
Honestly an awful professor. I am sitting in class right now and not paying attention because it won't help. Don't go to class. Ever. Not worth your time. Textbook is the only thing that helps.
He was a decent lecturer but  was often dull. He makes a few good jokes. It helps most to take notes from the book as he lectures. You could probably get by just going through examples from the book.
He is just not a good explainer and you have to learn from only the book

Run far away from Dey. She is a hard grader and does not know how to teach. While the midterm and final had simply problems it was difficult due to the fact that she never taught what we actually needed to know. I had to go home everyday after sitting in meaningless lectures and teach myself the material. Looking over the tests, she'd grade harshly

Papri Dey seems to care deeply about her class. Her explanations can sometimes be lacking, often skipping steps in calculations. Unfortunately my class in specific didn't like to participate which hindered the classroom environment. She is very open to criticism, however, and took it into practice after it was given.

Gave her a 2 originally.That was generous. It's like she prays on your downfall. Gorgeous memories from the midterm of a girl taking one look at the test, handing it back, and walking out.& ofc the final where everyone gave her a shrug as they turned it in. If you actually wanna learn pre calc, don't take this class. Professor is a nice person tho.

AM3 w/ Papri Dey has been a nightmare. Her chaotic lectures, half-explained concepts, random notation & constant logic leaps leave everyone utterly confused. She rushes ahead with zero guidance, so you have to teach yourself EVERYTHING. The exams don't match homework or examples. If you value your GPA & sanity, find another class & RUN 4 YOUR LIFE!

Prof. Dey is a nice person, but it's clear she doesn't know how to teach. Lectures are incomprehensible and disorganized leaving students to learn most of the material on their own. She assumes we know everything and will skip over important topics in class simply because "we should have learned it in high school". Don't take unless you have to.
Professor Dey as a person is pretty nice, but sometimes her explanations aren't the best. I feel like overall though, she's not as harsh a grader compared to others.

While she is a lovely person, she does not know how to teach and expects you to have prior knowledge on the subject. The study guides and tests are nothing like the homework's and quizzes. Some things that are never taught are tested. You have to teach a lot of things to yourself as well. It's so evil.

Professor Dey is well-intentioned and very open to students' questions. However, I found that not much information is being taught in lectures -- she mostly prefaces content by saying we should already have learned about the topic in high school and doesn't walk us through why we're doing things. As others have said, her explanations are confusing.

Professor Dey is a kind person, but lectures are difficult to follow due to them being unorganized and messy. She often jumps around slides and makes easy concepts really confusing. Expects you to know the material without teaching it.

Lectures are good, exams are incredibly difficult, no notesheet. There's a lot of memorization in this class. Exam content is much harder than the study guides given out. I wanted to like this class since Prof. Dey seems to be trying really hard, but it didn't click for me.

Class is curved pretty aggressively, only 60% required for a C

Professor Dey is incredibly enthusiastic about math and wants her students to do as well as they can on the exams. She will always answer questions during or after the lecture, even if they are stupid questions. The exams aren't that hard, but sometimes her explanations in lectures can be confusing.
She was the best, very caring and will give you help if you need it. Homework is hard but graded on completion. Final was hard but fair. Overall best professor Ive had so far.

Lectures were sometimes hard to follow but very doable if you read over the material before class. Homework was graded on completion and the weekly quizzes had multiple attempts. I thought the midterm was a little challenging but found the final easy. You can tell she genuinely cares for the students and doesn't want to stress them out. Great prof.

Lectures were decent but she would often skip steps in example problems. The Midterm was online and not too difficult but the final was in person and was kinda hard. Homework was pretty manageable and graded on completion. Weekly online quizzes but had multiple attempts and the lowest two got dropped. Group projects were not too bad.

Prof Gomez is a chill 19B professor. Our midterm was online, homework is based on completion, and weekly quizzes with 3 attempts. Grading is balanced too. Some of her lectures are a little confusing but overall, a decent professor, and not hard to get a good grade.

I had Marcella for 19B and the lectures honestly felt pointless. She would constantly mess up the algebra and confuse herself and the whole class. The discussions weren't helpful because we would spend the whole time doing group quizzes with physics concepts and we had two major group projects that she didn't really go over in lectures.

Moved very quick by necessity. I found the lectures somewhat dense but still digestible. Weekly HW was challenging but attainable. Group projects felt redundant and unnecessary. Homework was graded by completion, not correctness, so just try your best and you should pass! TA sections were also very helpful to fill in gaps you missed in lecture.

Professor availability is limited. Saw an interaction where a student needed to meet with her. Professor completely disregarded the student's conflicted schedule. 
Professor needs to foster open communication in a friendlier way. 
Assessment was unfair as content was not thoroughly discussed and developed in lecture. More practice was needed.
I am not the best at math but she is nice and makes things easy to get. the grading is not bad and if you do the work you will be ok, she is really good at answering questions.

ok this class is NOT hard at all. some concepts and stuff may be confusing but her and the ta's are willing to go out of their way and help. sometimes lectures are a little boring or confusing but shes so so nice and is funny sometimes, the midterms also online!
Lectures sometimes can be a lil confusing but the class grading is so easy and the midterm was online. She's really really nice and you can tell she cares abt ppl wanting to get good grads.
really great person and really chill

Homework is doable and due Friday's.

Midterm online and final in-person.

Professor is chill, but advise looking for others if able.

grade is balanced amongst several categories so nothing weighs down too much. online midterm, really nice prof and she has good humor too. sometimes makes mistakes but is really understanding and genuinely wants students to do well so far.

Literally the best professor I've had took her for 19A in the fall. Homework is graded on completion, there's section quizzes and group projects so a lot of ways to earn points. The mid term was online and the final was relatively easy if you studied. It's obvious she cares about her students and knows her work, definitely recommend.

Great teacher. Group projects were a little hard but not terrible especially if you find a good group to work with. Not too much homework. Lectures are very focused on applications of math which can make them hard to follow, but very interesting.
Very nice and caring for all of her students. Group projects were a little more difficult than what was being taught in class but aside from that, workload was decently well.

She's a nice and smart person but lectures were hard to understand and many concepts were explained in the most complicated way. I also disliked the group projects, they were hard to understand. That being said, the weekly quizzes were easy, homework was doable, she's open to questions, super felxible, and it's relativly easy to get a good grade.

Group projects were really difficult and harder than anything taught in class, but there were only two of them. Weekly quizzes were easy with multiple attempts allowed. Usually only 1 HW assignment/week which you could knock out in a day. Lots of extra credit and generous rounding made it pretty easy to get an A. Overall a pretty nice class!

Professor Gomez is brilliant; the midterm and finals were pretty easy. The projects and some questions on related rates seemed confusing at times, but it is a class for science and engineering mathematics. Some students would ask obvious questions rudely, which makes sense as to why she would get nervous sometimes. Overall amazing professor.

She is very nice and caring for her students and will do anything to help if you ask. Weekly quizzes no test but has 2 projects. The projects make no sense and I get the sense she's going (relating math to real world problems) but it doesn't make sense. Midterm and final were more conceptual than solving problems. Class is more english than math.

Ashesh is pretty cool. Most of the tests are take home and open note and internet. The midterms and final are also open note. The lectures are kind of hard to follow especially if you don't have any prior knowledge in Calculus. TA sections are not mandatory but I would recommend going because the TAs are pretty helpful.

Not very easy to understand, but if you want an A, you will get one. All you have to do is do the homework and quizzes on time, and you will get an A, whether you understand it or not. Very confusing lectures. All quizzes and tests, except for one midterm and one final, are take-home. As long as you show him that you are trying, you will be fine.
good teacher

Overall simple and straightforward class. There are daily class activities that count as attendance and account for 10% of grade, homework graded on accuracy not completion. Quizzes are take home, in person midtern/final and exams have content very similar to the homework.

This was the easiest class to pass. That being said, you won't learn anything and will have to self teach. Most midterms and quizzes were take home, open note, and homework could be submitted a week after it was due. His lectures are fast paced so I recommend only attending for credit. Ashesh is funny and will help if your brave enough to speak up.

Not good and not bad. Felt like I had to teach myself everything, since the lectures aren't good, and that's all he gives besides homework once a week, occasionally a quiz, and 2 midterms. My TA (bless his soul) basically re-taught me everything.

Not exactly the best lecturer, especially if you have no calculus experience, but definitely the easiest class I have ever taken at UCSC. Homework and midterm were online, and also the final, but he made it online last minute... He is very easy to talk to in class but he definitely skips steps and his solutions take some thinking to understand.

Professor Chattopadhyay is a super chill instructor and very understanding. Yeah this class is quite difficult without any calculus experience but there are so many ways to still pass (all tests open note and some take home). Hw is light. Lectures are confusing but if you put in your own time to study, you'll be fine. Overall great prof and class.

I would say hes not that bad I came into the class with only Algebra 2 experience and made it out okay, not because of him but because of studying sources, but my point is you can make it through his class with not to much math experience. Lowkey his lectures don't make the most sense when youre starting out

Ashesh is the goat. He's really smart, funny, and willing to answer questions, even in huge lectures. He likes to dive very deeply into content, which is great for conceptually understanding the material. Sometimes he goes a bit off the deep end on stuff, which can confuse students. Also, nothing ever gets graded on time. But he has cool hair

It's Week 9, the week before the final, and nothing has been graded since week 3, including midterms. The entire class is going into the final completely blind. The problems are ridiculously hard and there isn't enough time to complete tests. Don't take if you haven't already taken calculus, you won't understand it.

He's a nice and caring guy, but the class is really hard if you don't have any prior calculus experience. Most tests are take home, so it's not IMPOSSIBLE to pass, but you have to teach yourself if you want to actually learn. His lectures are very fast paced and he skips a lot of steps when he solves problems (which are also extremely complex).

He is unclear and disorganized. What he says in class is different than Canvas. He lectures very fast, yet lecture problems are often left unfinished. If you do not have previous calculus experience, do not expect to learn anything in this class. Most people pass because tests are take-home and open-note, so they cheat. Expect to self-teach.

Ashesh is an awesome professor and really knows a lot about ML and climate stuff in applied math. I wish I could take every class with him. I appreciate that he does not micromanage and I really enjoyed his slides and explanations on the different ML models.

Fast-paced lectures, so it can get easy to fall behind. I had previous calculus experience, so I thought it was easy, but without any it could be difficult. Midterms were like 3 questions and open notebook/testbook/internet; easy to get a good grade. Very lenient with deadlines for homework: gave like a week grace period.

I came into this class with no calculus experience and had the hardest time understanding from him. He explains everything very fast and sometimes doesn't even finish the problem that he's doing because he expects everyone to know. His quizzes and tests were taken at home and open notes/internet so the class is easy to pass, but you won't learnmuch

He moves at a very quick pace which makes it hard to fully grasp concepts. Starting this class with little to no calculus experience was very tough, the only reason I passed was because his quizzes and exams were all open internet and notes. He was very nice but I recommend self-studying and going to the discussions.

All HW and exams were take home and open everything, including ai. Very easy to pass, but if you want to learn calc I would not recommend. He never explained concepts clearly & skimmed over the foundations of calc. classes were just him solving super difficult problems. He has messy handwriting and canvas was kinda disorganized. Very funny & caring

Great professor, his lectures are kinda hard to understand due to accent but its doable. Generous late policy and everything was take home/online including tests. Easy class to pass but you can definitly learn a lot, you just need to go out of your way to ask him for help, which he will.

All midterms and final were take home and open internet, so passing was easy. But he has thick accent and is kind of sloppy. Material in lectures was hard to understand since he moved fast, but if you do all the non required practice problems, you should be able to learn. You can do the bare minimum and pass, but I recommend self studying to learn

This is one of the best writing classes I've taken. She wants you to learn to write well! The inquiries aren't too hard, but are quite time consuming since there are two assignments per week, one due at the end of the next lecture. Her office hours are really helpful. She gives really detailed advice on your writing, so use that to improve!!

I have taken two classes with Professor Pascale and each is so organized. The way she sets up her courses gives you no option to be left flailing if you simply utilize all the resources on Canvas. Would 100% recommend taking a class with her, I would be ready to do all of her assignments/quizzes though, they are all important.

I took AM114 with her and thought she was extremely rude and condescending. Her class uses the flipped classroom model and makes you watch lectures outside of classtime, making the class easily sum up to 30 hours a week of work. When approaching her in office hours or with questions she is very rude and makes you feel quite dumb. DO NOT TAKE HER!

Spent around 30 hours a week on this class. Recorded lectures are okay, but the flipped classroom model added time and work outside graded assignments. The syllabus says this class should be 15 hours/week but I feel that it is unlikely. Undergrads didn't have extra grad hw and group project, but some complained their work was more than 15 hours.

Will accomodate with extensions on hw when needed & responds to emails quickly. The exams are 70% of your grade. After many people bombed the midterm, she made it so you have to pass the final to pass the class, but she will replace your midterm grade with your final grade if you do better on the final.I easily put in 8 hours a day with this class.

She expects A LOT out of you. She doesn't get the average student in this class. Use your TAs. Be prepared for LOTS of MATLAB. I spent approximately 40 hours a week on just this class. Little respect for your time outside of the class. All lectures prerecorded, exams are hard but manageable, quiz and prep before class ~1-2 hours w/o hw.

Not a great teacher. Her lectures are boring she speeds through lectures way to fast and expects us to know everything. She will make you feel dumb if you go to her office hours. She should not be teaching this class. Shes very rude and disrespectful. Was a horrible teacher in general DONT TAKE HER!

I took AP Calculus and wanted an easy class so I took this one. I went to class and watched Disney movies in the back, I got an A in the class. Its super easy and when I did pay attention she was actually a great teacher. She accent isnt too heavy. She did move along pretty fast for some people. Go to Section and ask questions if you need help

Very boring class with same dry lecture notes everyday + clicker questions so you can't skip class. Lots of busy homework. The class itself is fairly easy and simple but honestly, Pascale can be rude and not very understanding. The TA is much much better and will clarify any questions, and she is also very good at explaining quiz questions.

Pascale is an overall good professor. Most generous curve Ive ever seen in a class (40-60C, 60-80B, 80-100A) There are short pop quizzes in section but count for only a small portion of grade. One annoying thing as that she uses i-clickers during lecture so attendance is essentially mandatory.

Lectures are super boring but mandatory to understand the class. Will be really tough if you havent take a pre-calculus course before. Super rude when you ask questions and will answer with come to my office hours often. Expect lots of homework too.

Professor Garaud is not engaging. She does not care about her students well being or their grasp of the information. She assigns large amounts of homework that don't translate well to the tests. Her lectures are dry and hard to sit through. Overall disappointing class.

The lectures were organized, but very boring and not engaging at all. There was a fair amount of homework, about 100 questions per week, but they weren't too difficult. Overall, class wasn't too difficult but very dry and very boring.

She is a really good lecturer and makes sure you understand the material during class and during section with the TA's. I think she's pretty awesome and her french accent doesn't get in the way of her teaching.

Very organized and straightforward with her lectures. Assigned something around 100 problems of online homework a week but they were just your typical online homework problems. Won't take too much time if you split it up throughout the week. Pretty much just your standard Precalc class.

Didn't learn anything in lecture, going to sections and MSI are the only thing that helped. Other than that, pretty easy class. The tests are somewhat like the practice problems except twice as hard and the finals was harder than expected.
Her teaching style was, at times, difficult to understand. However, if you do the practice midterms and finals, you should feel confident that you'll do well on the exams.

Garaud complicated everything more than necessary and made math more difficult than it should be. She expects students to have learned most things already so what she covers will be brief and not very helpful. About 100 homework problems every week. Clicker questions for attendance. Practice midterm and finals were much easier than the real exams.

I felt extremely cheated in this class. Garaud would put up a practice midterm and "last year's midterm" in preparation for the upcoming midterm. However, the material on "last year's midterm" and the actual midterm was vastly different and lead me to believe that she is cheating students out of grades. Only 9 students out of 300+ got an A+

The most unprofessional professor I've ever had.  Never available for extra help when needed and if you can manage to track her down good luck with her condescending attitude.  She lacks faith in her students and is blind to her own mistakes.

Hands down, the best prof in AM. Class has a lot of challenging concepts that he makes accessible. He always holds office hours after lecture and will go out of his way to ensure you understand everything! Quizzes are 25% EC on the final, which is 100% of the grade. (Don't be scared by this, they're all doable and he'll guide you with examples).

Very amazing professor, thorough lectures/notes. He is happy to answer students' doubts/questions and approachable via email (weekends also), you can get up to 25% EC on final exam. Straightforward assignments; funny, likes to socialize with students during his OHs. Compassionate and kind; easy class if you work hard and attend his lectures/section

He is a really good professor, his lectures are really well planned. I unfortunately did not attend many of his lectures, I wish I did. I still did very well in his class regardless. He graded the whole class based only on the final, but all the homework and quizzes would provide extra credit points towards the final grade if you did well on them.

Amazing professor. Very clear lectures and explanations, though focused on theory a lot. Professor was very caring in offering detailed explanations and answering questions. Assignments were very straightforward and followed what was taught in class. Overall great professor.

The BEST professor I've had at UCSC. I took him for AM213B, which wasn't an option on the courses listed here. Not only was Daniele extremely friendly and funny, he would buy the class coffee after lecture and held extra office hours for socializing and extra help. Passionate lecturer, kind, funny. 11/10.

Grade was entirely based on final grade. HW and quizzes were extra credit and boosted your grade significantly. Easy to get an A if you do EC and review a lot. Final was open notes and open internet for us. Professor was nice and good at speaking, but lectures were sometimes hard to follow or overly complex. MATLAB was not used singificantly.

100% of your grade is determined by the final but can earn up to 32% EC in the 4 tests and quizzes throughout the quarter. The quizzes are very conceptual and difficult but his lectures prepare well for that. Lecture notes are clear and nicely formatted, definitely a luxury. Take classes with him if you want an A and want to learn from it.

Best professor at UCSC!! He is originally from Italy, cutest accent ever. I think he is a genius (a real one), but he is very humble, easy going and down to earth. Would definitely take any course he teaches at UCSC.

The class started out rough with a 42% average on the complex numbers exam, but he realized that the test might have been too hard for what it was. After he changed things around a bit, the class went really well. Lectures are VERY conceptual and can be hard to understand, so if you take him make sure you go to section or you'll have a bad time.

Great Lectures, if you can understand them lol. Really good professor but I felt like the material was taught in a much more conceptual way than in practical use cases. GO TO SECTION, you will definitely need to put a lot of time into this class
Prof. Venturi is the man! Dazzling, bright and sharp. Will take all course he teaches at UCSC!

The nonlinear dynamics class taught by Prof. Venturi was simply amazing. I read some of the comments below, and .... oh boy! Enroll in whatever course he is teaching ASAP if you have the chance to do so! Hes a hell of a teacher!

Professor Venturi is the best professor I have ever at UCSC. Extraordinary lectures. I would recommend taking 147 or whatever course he is teaching to anyone. Youll learn a lot! Not too hard to get an A, but you have to work for it.

He is such a good professor! He really wants you to get an A. The matlab code is not challenging if you go to sections and OH. I miss the deadline of one HW but he still give me 100! He curves the class and really can help you learn!

not an easy A, but if you show up to lectures, sections, and OH you should be able to get an A. I had very little programming experience prior to this class, so it's fine if you're not a coding person. plus he curves at least 5% and he gives extra credits for attending sections, and he scales down the grade. What more can you ask for?
Fantastic professor, fantastic course. Top class!

Great professor, the course material got a little bit difficult towards the end, but Venturi slowly builds on previous concepts so you don't get lost. He also curves grades pretty generously at the end.
Enthusiastic, energetic teaching. I enjoyed a lot going to class. Always happy to help even outside of regularly scheduled office hour time.

Very enthusiastic, made effort to make sure students were following concepts as he built upon them in class so no one got too lost. Complex concepts were always very clearly explained, and you can tell he really enjoys the material.

Venturi is an exceptional professor. Incredible enthusiasm, brilliant, very thorough, and always willing to help. He made sure everyone was set up to succeed in the class. I'll make sure I'll take every single course he teaches at UCSC!
Not a very good lecturer. I learned most of the material from the textbook and the TA sections. However, grading is pretty lenient making it easy to succeed if you put in the time.

i love prof gong. i went into this class worried because i did not take am10, however i was able to pass and learn all the material through doing the homework problems and quizzes. the exams were very reasonable and enough to prepare you for them. he did have a slight accent, but his english was very comprehensible.
Professor Gong often made little to no sense in his lectures, which were often hard to follow and learn.

Not much homework so grade depends solely on exams. Other than the final which is worth 50%, all the exams are fair and similar to optional problem sets (I recommend redoing those for practice before exams) 

He's a good lecturer, always reviews and makes sure questions are answered.

Amazing lecturer, his explanations are super clear and he works out plenty of problems in class. The content is definitely difficult, but exams are very straightforward since he's very explicit about what will and won't be fair game. Your grade consists of ONLY exams (50% final wooo) but the practice problems he posts are similar to what to expect
He gave no homework but gave weekly quizzes. All of the questions on the midterms and final were based on the questions in the quizzes and examples in class.

Buy the textbook! He is somewhat intelligible when he speaks towards the class but when is talking at the board I couldn't even tell if he was speaking English. If you do the practice problems and read the book before class you can kind of follow along. A really good teacher but just wish he invested in an accent coach.

Engaging class. There is no homework but he gives practice problems that are very helpful in studying exams. Weekly quizzes online, no time limit and 2 attempts. Midterms and Final were very reasonable and straight forward if you did the practice problems and attended lecture. Takes a lot of time in class for questions.

All homework is optional but then your grade is only composed of midterms, quizzes, and final. This does not make the class very difficult because the content is usually clear. Strikes canceled the second midterm and the final was 50% of our grade. The final was very difficult with a low average and grades were curved before the final.

the AM professors are amazing for many reasons, but my favorite is that they LOVE their subject and want you to succeed. Dr. Gong teaches 114 in a way I've wanted to be taught for a long time! be ready to keep up with fast lectures, and for grading to depend on three tests only. (took 114 NOT 20 but the interface doesn't allow new classes)

He's a really great lecturer and his slides are fantastic. The content can be tough but the way he explains it makes it as smooth as it could be as long as you can get past his accent which I didn't think was too bad. his tests are a kinda tough but as long as you can do the 5 or 6 practice problems he sends out each week you won't have a problem.

Asking for clarification will be hard in this class. With the TA strikes this quarter our grades consisted of 7 things with a big emphasis on our final (50%). Unfortunately it was a hail mary, one that I ultimately fumbled but I feel if asking questions was encouraged in lecture it would help grade-wise. Just wish he was a little more compassionate

AM 20 with him was not a hard class. However due to protests, many things were changed like the final being 50% with no Midterm 2. The weight of the final caused a lot of final grades to drop. I bet without the protests it would've been fine. Prof Gong and the TA's are helpful for understanding concepts. Same with the lectures despite his accent.

Professor Gong is a good lecturer and goes through a lot of examples, but it can sometimes be challenging to understand due to his accent. His grading system this quarter consisted of 20% from weekly quizzes, 20% from first midterm (second was cancelled due to protests), and 50% from the final. If you go to lecture and practice you should be good.

Course overall wasn't very difficult, but he is not a good lecturer whatsoever. Sometimes hard to understand him during lecture, and not engaging at all. Weekly quizzes (20%) instead of homework which are easy & lowest 2 scores dropped. 2 midterms (20% each) and a final (40%). Retaught myself basically everything from the lectures.

clear, concise slides; easy to catch up even if u miss a lecture; records lectures and adds subtitles for clarity. graded on open note online quizzes, two midterms, and a final; drops the lowest two quiz scores; midterms test key concepts without tricky algebra; No need for office hours due to the quality of lecture materials and practice problems

Professor Gong was a good math teacher I'm not sure why there are so many complaints. He does have an accent but honestly not even hard to grasp what he's saying. The people complaining probably just have a hard time with math which is understandable but Professor Gong made it pretty easy to understand the topics. I enjoyed his class :)
I don't remember anything about it. When I look back at my notes, I couldn't recognize what are these, I am so surprised I can solve these questions when I am taking this class.

Did not have to read the book, watch his lectures and attend TA sections. to yall saying his accent is not understandable are just salty. He speaks fine and you can hear the words clearly, fast talker for sure. But lectures are very organized, readable, and helpfull.

Heavy accent for sure. We are only graded by a few quizzes. The quizzes are very similar to hw assignment he gives us. My midterm has been regarded two times and every time I received a lower score for no reason.
He spends the entire lecture teaching theory, which is interesting, but doesn't directly help with understanding the homework problems or tests. Super nice though!

Jackson wasnt bad but focuses a lot on proofs and is sometimes hard to follow. Concepts definitely couldve been explained in simpler terms. Pretty easy to pass, only graded on the weekly quizzes which you need 60% on total to get all of the points offered, two midterms and final, and attendance.

Not bad professor but sometimes hard to follow and things couldve been simplified. Only graded by quizzes attendance and tests; its really easy to pass. Make sure to go to lss tutoring it helps more than lectures honestly

Nice guy but I didn't like his teaching style much. He focuses more on proofs than applications of formulas in lecture which can be confusing. Doing textbook readings and going to LSS tutoring makes the material much easier to understand. Both midterms were online and easy, final was in person and a bit harder. Fairly easy class overall

Uses a flipped classroom style but was not beneficial for my learning whatsoever. You could take the quizzes twice and midterm was online which was cool. But the in person final average was 36/100 so…. he's a nice person though, but just never responded to emails and didn't explain topics clearly. I only heard back from the TA.

Jellife is a very caring professor but sometimes lectures were hard to understand. Both midterms were online and the final was in person but that might change. Very knowledgable overall really good guy.

The professor was meh. I did not enjoy the "flipped classroom" model; all the teaching was put on to the student, and the class time was just a section. Also, if you plan on any issues to arise throughout the quarter, this is not the professor. Not effective or reliable at communication, I only got responses after contacting the department head.

Mmm kinda of a meh professor. He does a "flipped classroom" style of teaching (basically you watch a 45min lecture videos before class and ask questions/reivew problems during class) and personally I hated it because it was hard to force myself to watch them. He goes pretty fast and expects you to know alot of things so its hard to ask questions.
A gap between lectures and quizzes but exams are easier than other professors. Attend his lectures and sections to really grasp concepts!

TOOK FOR AM 11A. you must go to class and sit in the front and ask questions to pass! this class was lowkey a little unorganized but you're graded solely on exams. 2 quizzes a week, 3 midterms and a final. no homework, class attendance isn't mandatory but weekly discussions are mandatory.

The class itself is graded on a extremely generous scale requiring pretty little effort to get a good grade. Lectures are pretty theory heavy. Sparse usage of MATLAB. Exams and quizzes are based heavily on lecture examples and don't have any surprises. Homework is optional but also necessary to gain a good understanding of the material.

Super abstract lecture material for being an "applied" course, I stopped going to lecture b/c it just did not help. Little to no MATLAB taught. Exams and quizzes were reasonable, open-note, and helped you keep up. Homework isn't required but you should definitely do it. Tutors + textbook were the biggest help.

Nice guy but lectures were a bit too abstract for me and didn't really connect to the HW so I had to use TA's and tutoring sections alot. Lectures are hard to grasp but as long as you do the HW problems and ask for help you should be fine. Exams correlate to the slides so no surprises there. Just wish the concepts were easier to understand.

The class is pretty easy, and it is set up in way that you basically cannot fail unless you just don't do the work. The lectures themselves were a little concept/theory heavy and less example focused for my taste, but don't have any real issues besides that. Was pretty solid overall.

honestly loved professor jackson, but this class was so hard. his lectures were simple and easy to understand, but the quizzes and tests following these lectures were like what we learned in class but 100x harder. it was so hard to succeed. tutoring is offered and his study guides are really helpful as long as you do them multiple times.

AM11A: Jelliffe is a great teacher and a great guy. Although the graded material seems harder than what is actually taught in lecture, he tends to grade quite leniently and gives lots of partial credit. Lectures are very easy to learn from. USE HIS STUDY GUIDES

I thoroughly enjoyed taking Professor Jackson's precalculus course. Normally, I worry about math lectures, but Professor Jackson's lecture never caused me any confusion. His lectures had a lot of material and were well-organized. Attending discussions and doing the homework were both highly useful in understanding the material for this class.

Overall, the class was very easy because the 4 total midterms where online and open note. The content of the class was not too difficult to understand and the lectures are all recorded. Jelliffe is really good at teaching and will help you understand the material to the best of his ability. Would definitely recommend his class.

I'm not sure if it is just that linear algebra is confusing, or the fact there was not any homework in this class to help conceptual understanding, but I was pretty confused throughout the quarter. The lectures are very long, often some videos on youtube summarize concepts very well. The quizzes are confusing, but multiple attempts. He is caring.

Such a great class! Im not good at math but Sections were amazing she helped us with homework every week. Professor Jackson was also amazing and listened to students if he was moving too fast/ if we had questions. Attendance not mandatory, 10 hw questions/week + quiz. No midterms, group projects instead. 25 question take home final. 10/10 recommend

60% lecture, 40% studio is rough. The lectures were interesting, but they were long, and certainly didn't feel necessary in order to complete the work. They felt more like watching a Ted talk about art. That being said, this class was pretty chill and good for what it was trying to be: an intro course.

Very boring lectures but if you have done art before it will be a very easy class. Tests are taken asynchronously online. Lectures are skippable but he DOES have exit tickets and attendance is 25% of your grade. Emphasis on the boring lectures—Grant Whipple is a prime example of someone who is good at their job but bad at teaching.

Coming from an art background I found the assignments pretty fun and straightforward. However, I can see how to beginners, of which this course is pushed towards, how the assignments could be seen as difficult. The Lectures seem longer than they are, honestly, they were borderline boring. Section meetings were more interesting than the lectures.

Lectures often feel extremely long; if you're not genuinely interested in art, they can be very boring. The actual art assignments/projects are quite fun to do, and he seems like a cool guy. The lectures are the main downside to the class, especially since they're mandatory with an exit ticket.

If you've done IB/AP art, this is exactly like that. I didn't struggle at all and was used to the workload. But others who haven't taken an art class like this were falling behind. He teaches you the basics and is a cool dude! Super chill to talk to. BUT, your art skills do matter.

This class is portrayed as if it's more than just the basic fundamentals of 2D Art. It would be respected if it wasn't for the fact that it is EXACTLY that. Don't come to this class thinking that it'll be inspirational and mind opening, it really isn't, you will be disappointed. Take it as a GE if you have to, but the class is not very engaging.

This class can be kind of annoying because of the time you're expected to put into your drawings, and the need to buy an 18x24 in drawing pad lol. Your grade in this class really depends on your TA, in my experience the grading criteria wasn't always clear but it usually wasn't too harsh.

I was in #139. Grant is a tenured professor at UCSC. I was shocked when I learned this, because based on his teaching style, I assumed he was fairly new to the profession. His lectures were unengaging, and went over basic concepts despite it being an advanced level class. He gives no guidance on critique.

This professor is so unprofessional. I also can't believe they let this professor back at ucsc (t lx). He was very unclear with his criteria . A copious amount of homework. He also never explained why I got a B, when I attended every class and did the homework. He also touched me when I gave clear body language that I was uncomfortable.

Grant Whipple is an excellent professor. He provides a rigorous environment that really pushes students. If you want to be better at art, take his classes. He takes his time to meet with each student and helps them achieve their artistic goals.

His assignments are also unique, definitely refreshing for those who have taken many art classes.

Grant creates a class that is really about bringing artists up to their best, whatever level they may be at before the class. If you listen to his feedback and really take it to heart, you will see improvement. I find myself using techniques he has taught all the time. I specifically took a class with him again because he was that helpful :)

Very passionate about art! Weekly assignments but it's nothing compared to IB Art. Fun prompts, in class activities, and very informative slides. Even for beginners, this class is welcoming and easy. You don't talk much to him though, mostly TA's but they're all also super nice. Cool guy 👍

His class is almost entirely attendance based. As long as you go to every class and studio section it's a very easy A. I took this as a GE so I have no art background, and it showed in the quality of my work, but I still got full or almost full credit on every assignment. If you like art and can commit to showing up I really recommend his class.
Not good at explaining how to do things to people with no background in art, even though it's an introduction course. Very tough grader. if you dont know how to draw, good luck
This professor does not welcome Jewish students.

I loved Grant for both 20L and 20J which I took with him.  There is quite a bit of homework but it is doable considering they are harder art classes.  It is an intro class, but you should know how to paint or draw before coming in. He's a cool professor and I really enjoyed the energy he put into the class along with the energy into his students.

DO NOT TAKE this class
Lecture videos are dreadful and long, and contain very little useful information. Although this is an "introduction" class, you won't receive a solid score just by following all the instructions on the assignment. He expected you to know how to draw prior to this class, if you don't, good luck with your grade.

This class was an "intro" to art class, but videos does not go over ANY basics to how to draw. You will learn how to draw and more advanced techniques if you knew how to draw before this class, but if you are a complete beginner, you will have a rough time.

Great teacher if you already are fairly good at drawing. Otherwise its gonna be rough. Assignments are very technical and complicated, and he doesn't go over the basics. His quizzes have unnecessary trick questions to trip you up and are difficult. If you have experience drawing and want to learn new techniques, take this class! if not, dont.

The class is supposed to be an introduction to drawing, but he assumes that everyone has experience drawing and thus he doesn't explain the techniques in ways that students who don't know how to draw, will understand. The way he explains things makes it really confusing if you haven't had art experience, and that can make it really stressful

Horribly set up canvas, ended up dropping from a A to C- on the very last day of the course because of weekly quizzes that never showed up on the dashboard nor were never announced, teacher offered zero communication in favor of TA's unsure guidance on assignments

Overall she was a really nice professor, I did like the way the whole class was structured and how the modules would drop every friday so we would have the weekend to work on it. I do feel for one of the units that there could have been of a step by step video explanation but overall it was a really good class for the basics of digital art.

This course completely sucked the creativity out of art projects. The instructions provided are so specific that a lot of the time the only student creativity is the color palette or other small details. The course was still fun and provided a lot of useful skills in using online programs but I was disappointed by the lack of creative freedom.

The professor is super informative although it is an online course! I didn't need to take this class for credit just as a GE and i learned a lot! Yes this class does take up a lot of time but its def do-able but it does take a couple of hours a week!
Super easy class, projects take a while but as long as you meet the criteria it's an A. The quizzes pull from the reading. Extra credit available and help always given

Took this asynchronous class over the summer. I would've gotten an A if I turned in all my assignments on time. This course can be difficult/challenging but not dreadful. Many of the assignments do take hours to complete just so you know. I think the professor is nice and cool.

Jennifer was 100% one of the best professors I've had at UCSC. I took her 80T class in winter of this year and she explained everything perfectly in her tutorials. I finally understand how to use photoshop and blender because of her, which is something I though I would never understand. If you want to learn photoshop, take this class with her!
Easy class with tutorials to follow for weekly projects through adobe, photoshop, and blender. Weekly quizzes open book and no due date. Its easy to get stuck with the projects so start early.
Professor explain things very well and its easy to get a good grade. Very easy on the grading as long as you followed everything she also gives example of what you need before you submit. Easy A

One my favorite professors ever! Critiques were amazing and so intense. Jennifer cares about students - her assignments and readings were really well curated for a special topics class. I felt like a learned I turn. Highly recommend!

This class really changed how I think about art and helped me focused on what really matters - especially during a Pandemic! Professor Parker is a wonderful teacher, great artist and really dedicated.
One of the best Professor's I've had at UCSC!
I was really impressed with Professor Parker's ability to teach remotely and I really appreciated the types of assignments she gave us and how much she cares about student projects.
I really enjoy working with Professor Parker - her assignments are really dynamic and her feedback was really spot on.
Learned a ton!
One of the worst professors I've ever had in my entire academic career.

Great artist, terrible teacher. The projects she assigns are either open to interpretation or weirdly specific. She hardly does any actual teaching, instead sending students off to wood shop or metal shop teachers for actual instruction. Critiques are grueling, and any feedback she gives is either rude or makes no sense. Made some fun stuff tho!
Wonderful Professor. Love her & Bridget. Very thorough when explaining how to use materials and what is expected from you. She is also super cool and inspiring.

The content for ART10D consists of lecture videos and readings on Canvas and then we make art in studio sections. Her presentations were very easy to follow and well organized. I felt like I got exposed to a lot of cool artists and techniques. My TA was awesome. I wish there was more diversity in the types of art we covered in assignments.

Professor Sanford was in my lecture videos but not studio, your TA will be the one helping you with your art prompts. From what I saw she was very engaging! and the class is pretty easy if you follow instructions. There needs to be more creative freedom as well as harder difficulty seeing there are a diverse set of skills in a classroom.

Sarah Sanford is hands down the best art professor I've had at UCSC. Amazing feedback, clear instructions, and really pushes you to do your best! She is a true gem of the art department, and the only print teacher at UCSC that I can truly recommend. She will help your art improve and her feedback is incredibly helpful. She is a great resource!!

All professors have favorite students, but not all of them make it so obvious. I got a good grade in the one class I took with her, but I received the least helpful feedback of any art class Ive been in. If you want better support be prepared to kiss *ss, I guess. Shes super knowledgeable but isnt very available for feedback.

Jimin is the most impactful professor I've ever had. Her classes may be tough and time consuming but if get to know her, attend office hours, ask lots of questions, etc. she will give you endless support. She wants her students to work vigorously and succeed more than anything. She can always tell who's really invested and who doesn't care so much.

Jimin is a so funny! However, her classes are always insanely homework heavy, and you can work your hardest all quarter and she'll still give you a low grade. Expects students to spend all night in the print studio to make work up to her standards. Her demos and grading criteria are confusing too! Love her, but after 2 semesters of A-, not stoked

Jimin is easily my favorite art professor, and she makes print making fun (I haven't taken Enrique's print classes and I never talked to him in 2D art but I hear he's difficult). She's fun and very open to different ideas and styles. I don't think she's going to be at UCSC after next year though so take one of her classes while you can!
great.

She really does push you to do your best without really trying to. She manages to scare you into doing more than the limit, which I find to be so great because you'll come out with some of the greatest works from her class. She is so funny and she's really understanding. I highly recommend taking her class if you want to test yourself.

Jimin requires a lot from you, but understands your abilities and limitations. She will push you to do your best at all times, and doesn't let you get away with doing anything half-way. You will learn a lot in her classes, and produce some excellent work. Despite not always knowing the correct english word for what she's trying to say, she has fun and interesting ways of getting her point accross that are never unclear.  All around excellent teacher!
She seems uptight at first but she's actually a lot of fun. She's really experienced and will be glad to help you achieve the techniques you're wanting to learn.

I've never been more disappointed with a professor. As someone who aces all their classes this class was a definite surprise.
