We were tested on mostly new material, even though he said it was cumulative.Despite this, he is very empathetic & accessible in OH

Class is hard because the grade is only a few quizzes, 2 midterms, and final. Make sure to watch the lecture videos twice or more if you can because they help so much. She is a really good lecturer and watching the lectures twice helps Stefan was my T.A and he's awesome. Go to office hours and practice the section problems and the practice exams.

Lectures are very detailed with amazing graphics (best to use iPad), and you can just tell she knows this content like the back of her hand. DO NOT SKIP LECTURES: they have too much important material. And go to OH and LSS-- trust. There is optional homework from a textbook, but you're graded on quizzes (2 tries each), two midterms and one final.

Graded by few things, but she is a great and engaging lecturer! Go to section and LSS they are sooo helpful! Concepts aren't crazy difficult, but hard to learn at first. Once it clicks, it is super straight forward! She also shuts down useless questions in lecture. I retook this class and I much prefer her to than Roh. Clear organized lectures

Harsh grading system but thats how it is for all Genetics classes. You need to go to every class and do well on the three non curved tests. After the first midterm the material ramps up and you can't fall behind bc it goes super fast. Nice teacher but is strict with grading

Professor Bhalla is an amazing professor and super knowledgeable. I learned a lot in this class. You will have easy little quizzes every week with 2 attempts for each. You will have 2 midterms and a final. The midterms and final are insanely difficult. I would recommend trying to find exams from previous years and studying those.

Although your entire grade was determined by exams, if you watch all her lectures and read the textbook, you'll do fairly well. It is important with this class that you keep up. She provides practice midterms/finals that are insanely useful and I 100% recommend those. She stated before that she doesn't curve, but maybe it's a fear tactic.

Needhi cares deeply for her students but is not afraid to make this class difficult. If you put in the work and try your best to focus on learning, you can do great. Her lectures can be hard to follow, but she has a lot of in-class activities to keep you on track. Do the HW, go to office hours, go to lecture (take great notes), and ASK QUESTIONS!

Needhi is a cool person and very smart but she has a harsh resting tone that made me feel like I was intruding when asking a question. Between trick questions, vague study tips, and inconsistent wording, I did not feel as though she set her students up for success. In lectures, she talks at you. No curve.

Values educating students, but with only 43% of her last class passing and a midterm average of 65%, she still wont curve. this class is extremely brutal and if you have the option to take genetics with ANYONE else i recommend you do. genetics is hard and having your grade be 92% based on /intense exams/ makes it even worse!

Needhi is a tough instructor. Solid lectures but exams are reallyy hard and the vast majority of the grade. I took notes on all lectures, annotated all practice exams, did all quizzes, and I still might fail. The exams are super long, I don't have the stamina. Most people I know who took the class with Needhi had to retake it. Good luck.

Needhi was one of the best teachers in the UCSC, however, her exams are hard. I really enjoyed her classes and look forward to learning more and more about genetics. My midterms were great, I was getting B+  after the final my grade dropped to C.

Needhi is truly the best professor I've had here at Santa Cruz - she is incredible knowledgeable, kind, and supportive! I'll admit that not curving the tests can be annoying, but as long as you take responsibility as a student and go to OH or even skim the reading before lecture this class is very easy.

She is a great teacher. I love her lectures. However, I should point out that I studied like hell, and before the final, I had a big chance for B+. But final was cruel. So, for knowledge, I would recommend Needhi but it is tough to pass the class.

Test heavy class, did terrible on the 1st exam which left me in a super bad position for the rest of the semester and decided to drop. Im a good student, 3.5 gpa, study hard, do the hw, go to office hours, discussions, study groups, read the textbook, etc. Despite all this I got a 23% on exam 1, class average was 50% . Its just really hard,

This was my second time around taking genetics. Dr Bhallas class was much clearer to me than Rohinton's class. Bhalla works hard to be extra clear and is a patient and attentive to the students and she is aware classroom learning level. Exams had no curveballs and were straight forward. She works with LAs to come up with fun ways to teach material

Dr. Bhalla is an amazing professor. She's VERY organized and has clear cut grading criteria unlike other professor. Many people don't realize this is a notoriously difficult course so if you put the time in YOU WILL DO well. I'm telling you to take it with her because if you KEEP UP with the material you will do fine :) To study, rewatch lectures!

Genetics is really hard and while Needhi tries to make it easier, I wouldn't say that she does. She is a very direct, clear communicator, which is helpful. She also is very receptive to questions. However, the exams are extremely difficult and not curved and quiz concepts were often not covered until after quizzes were due.

Professor Bhalla is really passionate and funny. Her lectures were always easy to follow, and she clearly explained complicated concepts in multiple ways. The tests are really hard and weighted very heavily, but she makes so much study material available that as long as you put in the time, you can do well.
Horrid at teaching, seems to have quite a condescending attitude towards students, I advise people NOT to take her class for genetics!

Professor Bhalla is hands-down the best professor I have had at UCSC. She is clear about what she wants, effective at lecturing, and really makes sure you know your stuff. That being said, Genetics is a hard class, and her grading practices don't make it much easier. Midterm 40%, final 60%, that's it.

Immuno is a super difficult class, but the Prof really tried her best to make it palatable. Lectures were pretty dense and needed the textbook to understand. Homework was straightforward. 1st midterm was online and 2nd midterm we were given a test bank. Class structure/grading policy was absolutely generous. She wants everyone to succeed. Love her

Absolutely incredible professor. Very animated, caring, and passionate for the course material (which is insanely difficult and to quote her "Immunology is complicated"). Tests were fair and she worked with us to ensure we understood what content would be on there and our understanding of the content. She made the class incredibly interesting.

Banana Slugs,Her classes are very manageable. The reason I believe everyone else agrees with me is bc she tests fairly and gives students opportunity to earn free points on everything. 1st midterm was online and gave us a week to turn it in, 2nd was in-person BUT gave study guide that was copy/paste of exam. Believe me, she CARES FOR HER STUDENTS!

Carpenter is an amazing professor who teaches a difficult subject. Immunology was by far the most material heavy class I have ever taken, but it was made much more bearable by this professor. I never felt like I couldn't get an A in the course and she was extremely understanding and helpful.

Dr. Carpenter is clearly very passionate about immunology and that really helped with keeping interest in the content throughout the quarter. Her class is VERY lecture heavy and it is hard to do well if you're behind on the material. Although the content is pretty difficult, it is not hard to do well in this class; they are not harsh on grading.
Grade was based on one presentation and one paper. No clear grading criteria. Do not take this professor.

We had to do one big essay and one project. Neither had clear guidelines on what to talk about and how it was graded. The first few weeks were used to talk about sentence length and her favorite scientific writer. She wanted to make scientific writing fun but poorly failed at it with little class structure or syllabus.

I took Dr Zuniga's Immunology series and I loved it. The material was difficult, the textbook was tough to read, but the way Dr Zuniga helped to explain experiments on mice to understand the immune response was very helpful. This class will help you to understand experimental design and gain an appreciation for the body's complex immune system.

I think she cares a lot about her students and the education they receive. It was wonderful to learn writing in a setting that makes sense for biologists. I learned a lot of tricks to make sure my writing is engaging and fun which is rare for scientists. You have to work for your grade but she is accessible and is willing to work alongside you.

She's a great person and a really, REALLY caring professor. Unfortunately, there is no clear grading criteria so you're left in the dark about your grade all quarter. Talking to her about your grade doesn't really help either, as she doesn't give you a clear response.

As a professor, Martha was extremely frustrating. Spent the first four classes teaching us (college fourth-years) how to write a sentence. The remaining six class periods were devoted to us giving our final presentations despite having no clear grading criteria. Surprisingly for having no guidelines, it was very hard to get a good grade.

An amazing class unlike any I've taken before. I get why some people who were expecting an easy time might get frustrated but if you put in the effort early and consult with her as you go (which is easy because the class is small) it's a really rewarding experience!

Martha Zuniga is the worst professor I have had so far. This class was meant to be an easy A and instead, turned out to be a total of 2 papers with 2 revisions, as well as 1 hour long presentation where she criticizes you the entire time. Do not take this class. For those of you who think its going to be interesting like I thought, YOU ARE WRONG.
Avoid her!

Martha is by far the most enthusiastic professor I've ever had. She truly loves the subject she teaches and her main goal is for you to fall in love with immunology. She is extremely helpful outside of lecture (you can email her any questions and her office hours are helpful). If you don't pass this class it's definitely because you didn't try to.
Horrible teacher, belongs at a community college. Is a scatter brained lecturer.

Martha was scattered with her lectures. Her questions that filled in for the midterms were not clear and she expected you to research the topics outside of using the text. Her office hours were not helpful. Immunology is an amazing topic, but Martha is not a good professor.

Attendance was mandatory, lectures were useless. Everyone cheated on the take home exams which in turn, hurt the honest students. Avoid this class. The cheaters prosper and the honest ones don't survive.

Martha Zuniga is a brilliant woman to say the least. Her passion to teach this course amplified my desire to learn in this class. She is creative, funny, patient, and kind. This is the most beautiful biology course you will ever take; both because it is like a story of humans and disease, but also because it connects all other bio classes.

A lot of the comments here are outdated. I took 111A last quarter and in 111B now. Most interesting bio class I have taken and Martha is extremely helpful and dedicated to teaching. I don't believe her grading is unfair at all. She just expects you to actually apply the stuff you learned in lower division classes. Great class. Hard but so rewarding
so hard. worked my ass off and got a c+. ridiculous. and i'm a pretty good student with an b+/a- average accum.

martha is an amazing teacher, and really cares about the material as well as everyone understanding it. the material is the most interesting biology i've ever seen, and she and her ta's are always there for extra help. the class is really hard and keeps you on your toes but it's worth it.

Martha is disorganized and very dedicated to her research.  She is bothered by having to teach undergraduate courses, and makes no attempt to be a helpful teacher.  She is scattered and unclear.  She looks like she hasn't slept in weeks.  Overall, this Yale graduated professor is brilliant, yet lacks the tools to be a teacher.  Avoid this prof.

Unless you are very invested in Immunology, your time may be better spent with another elective.  She knows immunology, but her grading rubric on tests is completely inconsistent.  Don't expect regrades, either.  Expect to take this class as you would a 7-10 unit class.

SAVE YOUR SELF!!!! unless u want to become an immunologist pls. be careful!! she is the worst teacher EVER! the worst part is that she is extreamely disorganized. yes, she is nice and pleasant but dont be fooled!

Doesn't trick you. Prepares you very well for each test. However, he is very test-heavy, the way he prepares you and grades is very fair. Doesn't do any trick questions, and tests are super straightforward. His lectures are great and explain everything in full detail.

John is an amazing guy, cracks jokes, and gives extra credit for every mistake he made during the quarter. Attend EVERY lecture, take a lot of notes in your own words, and do the practice tests he gives you without ChatGPT or help, trust me, you'll do fine. The class is completely doable if you just put in that effort and don't slack off.

He is not necessary horrible just the way he grades is kinda rough. Things need to be exact. I also believe he should just do multiple choice then multiple answer. I feel like the class average would be significantly higher since he does not do partial credit if you chose 1 wrong but 2 were right it's zeroed out. LOOK AT HIS MODULE OVERVIEW PLZ!

While I don't think prof tamkun is necessarily a BAD prof... I do think he needs to reconsider how he grades exams. His policy on partial credit is very upsetting since you won't get any even if you get 2 parts of a question correct.... he just gives you zero credit. Midterms and final aren't awful but lectures can be pretty dense.

Professor Tamkun is the only person I can imagine going off topic to lecture about how yogurt is made for 10 straight minutes with a completely straight face and monotone delivery. Lectures can be very heavily packed with information so you may need to revisit lecture slides online. Grading is very fair, professor is fun.

Professor Tamkun was great. Its pretty easy to fall behind in this course, but that's more because of how much material we have to go through. His lectures are engaging and his exams are very straight forward; he never tries to trick you. He is also really funny.

Dr. Tamkun is one of the best professors I've had during my 4 years at UCSC; he provides clear learning objectives that prepped you well for exams, gives practice exams/quizzes that ACTUALLY match the test format, and talks to students/teaches in a way that makes it clear he genuinely cares. His tangents/stories are funny too :) Go to his OH!

Professor Tamkun is great - he cares about student success and provides lots of resources to help you excel. The class is lecture-heavy but manageable if you stay on top of things. I found Unstuck study and practice exams really useful for test prep.

This class is undoubtedly a bio weed-out class very dense and easy to fall behind in. Tamkun has it down to a science though, well written but fast-paced lectures, 4 exams, neither section nor lecture is mandatory but you won't pass if you dont at least go to lecture. Hard class, great professor.

Tamkun was a pretty fair professor, decent amount of online quizzes and exams often but they aren't super high stakes. As for the exams, go through the learning outcomes and key terms and do the practice exams a decent amount and you'll be fine. His office hours are also super helpful, and he's generally understanding if you talk to him.

I did not have a problem with the professor but rather the TA who did not have good communication skills when I had an issue with Homework. I attended office hours and section but it did not help me at all when it came to the test because of the free response and multiple-answer questions.

Horrible Professor. Does not care about your grade, so many quizzes that are fairly easy to do if you study the material; however, he takes off a lot of points when grading midterms and finals and has a very weird grading policy.Also, when you submit regrade requests, instead of explaining why we lost points, he takes off more. Don't take him.

Prof. Tamkun is both a great professor for the large class and the small office hours sections he does. This class is only hard if you come into it not expecting to memorize or retain information.  Don't take the class at 8AM though.

Professor Tamkun is great! Although the course is lecture and test heavy, it is not difficult at all if you put in the work. Overall great teacher and accessible throughout the quarter. Sections are also great as he provides helpful handouts that are useful for extra practice.

Worst professory ever. Dude does not care about you as a person or what you're going through. He is clear about grades but grades harshly. My biggest issue is that he makes this class more about memorization instead of learning. He doesn't even respond to emails. He also gives a lot of extra credit but its barely worth anything.

john is a very clear and demonstrative lecturer. he really wants every student to succeed in his class and clearly tells you how to do well on exams. going to class, drawing, doing the self assessments, homework and practice exams helped me a lot. exams are not cumulative. john is also super funny :)

While the class is very lecture heavy, I felt that if you regularly attended lecture and put time into studying the learning outcomes that were provided, the class was easy to do well in. John made topics clear through demonstrations (by himself or students drawing things out for the whole class, or demonstrations with the TA's).

Biol20A is apparently a weeder class but the only challenge in this class is the breath of information not the depth. John's office hours are VERY helpful and was the single best resource! The only downside is exams every 2wks at the end of the quarter but 75% of the exams questions are copypaste from HW, polleverywhere and practice quizzes/tests.

As long as you put in the work, you'll be fine. This is the first "weed out" class for many bio majors bc it requires you to have a deeper understanding of many different concepts. Discussions, practice exams, quizzes, and reviews mimic the exams very well. Consistency and engagement is your bestie for this class.
Hardest class I have ever taken and I transferred from Stanford, re took it with a different professor and got an A+. DO NOT TAKE TAKE IT WITH HIM!!

I'll start off with I really wanted to like this class!!!!!!! She is overall a very nice person who is passionate about teaching. With that said, her class is very unclear and disorganized on top her being extremely difficult to follow during lecture. DO NOT take this class with her!!!!
impossible to understand accent, speaks quietly, cant explain topics well and doesnt give any insight on what will be on exams or how one should study. i will never take Yi Zuo again
hard to understand through accent, Does not explain what is required on exams or explain how one should study. is very vague on exam and other materials and grading rubric. Would not take again.

While Yi is clearly passionate about neuroscience, she is not the greatest professor. Grading criteria for assignments if not clear until after the assignment is graded. Inflexible regarding grading. Does not prepare students for tests and overall is not empathetic towards students' struggles. Unfortunately she is not a teacher you can avoid.
Awful!!!! Students be ware! Highly do not recommend taking a class with professor Zuo if you have a choice.

Dr. Zuo is an amazing professor, she is very knowledgeable and caring. Her class challenges you to read and understand scientific literature. Her lectures are very complete and the class itself is very interesting. Her grading is sharp but fair.

Really bad lecturer, unclear on pretty much everything. Not good at explaining concepts. No interest in the well-being/understanding of students. General disinterest in the material and the class. Pobably the worst professor Ive had at UCSC.
Unprofessional and does not appear to care about teaching or whether students understand material. Very unresponsive to email.

she is a very nice and sweet person. If you reach out for help from her, she will gladly try to help you with what she can. Course is not as hard depending on the effort you put in and how well you know the material. Just make sure you understand her slides well and do the assigned reading( don't skim it). Pay attention to the figures as well.
I like Yi as a person and she is very enthusiastic about the material but this is a HARD class. Know the lectures, assigned chapters, and hw readings inside and out. "advanced" it is...

Woah woah woah. Yi WAS an amazing teacher who's energy for teaching advanced neuroscience was phenomenal, intelectual and very interesting, but by NO MEANS was her clarity a 5.0. I love YI, she really turned me on to neuroscience and her enthusiasm for the subject was what got me into it.  But it was more than a chore to understand her too often

Advanced Neuro is not a very easy class, but I love Yi.  She's super sweet, funny and adorable.  Her teaching style is cool, she does half of the lectures and we do the other half based on assigned research papers.  Being responsible for teaching some of the material definitely ensures that you know it pretty well.

Cool material, lots of reading. Lectures provide background info and research papers go into depth. Tests consist of research paper material (methods, findings, etc) and some background info from lecture. One group project presentation (meet with her to review it). Note* Lecture slides HAVE HIDDEN NOTES (click notes on ppt when viewing in microsoft

Learned a lot but definitely a lot of work. Read the book and attend lecture! Her slides are basically just pictures and every word that comes out of her mouth is crucial. It's hard to understand the info at first, but eventually it'll make sense and you'll be set for the midterm. Another tip: focus on the experimental methods she mentions in class

Professor Bin has very dry lectures which makes it difficult to stay awake but the class/subject is very fascinating. Lectures aren't mandatory but you should definitely go because her lecture slides are very minimal. Reading the book is also very helpful. Her tests are pretty fair too.

Bin was not a good professor. Lectures were very dry and hard to understand due to her english and lack of enthusiasm. The class in general is very interesting so I just read everything in the book! Going to class is pretty much pointless. Get ready to study from the book if you're going to have her!

Be prepared to teach yourself via textbook. Do attend lecture as she will go over what she expects you to know as well as give examples which appear on the midtermfinal. Memorize the textbook quizzes as they make up majority of the tests. Study homework and old tests for free response. SectionOH are useless. Class was weighted 252550.

Dr. Chen is a very knowledgable professor! For the exams, review her ppt slides and make sure to go to lectures in order to understand the graphs on her slides. Overall, made the first neuroscience course I've taken enjoyable. Curves a ton!

The subject material is extremely interesting, especially for the first half. However's Bin cannot teach and the lectures are jumbled. She expects a lot. The online quizzes are gold. You teach yourself using the textbook. If this class is not required, avoid it.

awesome class, great professor. I promise you get used to her accent. Class attendance is a must, 1/3 of the class shows up to lecture, 1/3 of the students are getting A's and B's and learning some of the most interesting, least dry aspects of biology. Tests fair. got mad respect for this woman, she works for NASA even. an honor to be taught by her

Bin genuinely cares about her students, she really took the time to explain and make sure students understood the material at hand. Study the lecture slides and old practice exam if you want to do well on the exams. Bin does curve the class. This class otherwise has been one of the most informative and interesting bio classes I've taken

she still should improve her English speaking and teaching. also she recycles the true/false and mc part of old tests, which can come from any random part of the book. the short answers are confusing and hard, but always related to deficits or damages in the brain. always go to section and read the book. lectures are skippable.

Prof. Chen is really nice and I know she is a brilliant woman in her field. As a professor, she seems really inexperienced and makes a lot of cliched bad professor mistakes: monotonous, reads right from power points, doesn't speak clearly or elaborate on material. Her class is pretty difficult and she doesn't give study sheets. Go to section and re

Worst. Teacher. Ever. She cannot speak english, reads straight off powerpoints, and when I went to her office hours to ask a question about the test she said "well, i put the answers online. look there." my evaluation said "see letter grade." thats it!  just that! would it kill her to put 5 minutes of effort into teaching? apparently!!!!!

Worst. Teacher. Ever. She cannot speak english, reads straight off powerpoints, and when I went to her office hours to ask a question about the test she said "well, i put the answers online. look there." my evaluation said "see letter grade." thats it!  just that! would it kill her to put 5 minutes of effort into teaching? apparently!!!!!
Good coverage of basic neuroscience information. Prof. Chen struggles a bit with her teaching style but I am sure she will improve with practice.

Class is interesting but hard. Teaching has lot of improvement to do. You need to be sympathetic with the professor since English is not first language and it is hard to comprehend. TA's are very nice and competent. Be prepared to read your books as exams do not always come from lectures only. Prelim 1:easy, Prelim 2:hard, Prelim 3 is comp. & hard.

You need to read lectures slides + entire text to do good on exam as lots of items are not in the lecture (or the slides). 2 exams (100 points each) and 1 comprehensive finals (200 points). Midterm 1 mean was 76; Midterm 2 means was 56; Finals mean was 110. Hard class. I am an A- student but I got a C in this class.

Bio 186L --> He's a great prof for this course, giving good feedback on writing and having sufficient explanations and guidelines for our work. Overall the class consists of 3 major sections due for the research proposal, the final work put together, and one presentation to the group. Pretty easy and a fun way to expand on your project in lab.

I was excited going into my first neuroscience class and I think Professor Feldheim did an excellent job providing an introductory exploration into neuroscience. Tests were difficult but fair. Office hours were very helpful and I thought the lectures were fascinating. This class is very dense and moves rapidly so make sure you attend every lecture.

Lectures were rushed and disorganized but SGT really helped! Although the second midterm was very difficult (avg 65%), the curve was fat for the class overall. Several hints of what questions will appear on the exams. Genuinely wants his students to do well. Well-intentioned guy, just not too great of a lecturer.

Overall good professor! Lectures are a bit rushed, but if you go to office hours he can explain concepts more clearly. His tests are fair, two midterms and one final. The course material does pick up in the second half of the course, but if you keep up with the material you're fine!
Did not cancel midterm the day of strike, gets a 60% avg on the midterm, regrets decision. We will see how the rest of the quarter goes.

Feldheim didn't seem to plan his lectures ahead of time and was pretty disorganized. Luckily for him, neuroscience is interesting, or else it would probably be very difficult to be motivated to do well. He was a nice guy, but he said things that were wrong too often and in general he wasn't very clear. Tests were difficult by nature of the material
He is really nice once you get to know him during his office hours. The course starts slow but picks up considerably near the end so dont fall behind!

Feldheim is a chiller. Intro to Neuroscience is totally doable with him if you go to all classes, DO THE READING, print out the lecture notes before class and write down what he says. He is good at explaining the material and tests are very fair if you study hard, keep up with the reading, and rewrite the notes.
Dr. Feldheim is the man. He made Cell Bio awesome. Lectures were always fun. Tests were very fair. Read the book and review his slides and you'll do just fine in class. Highly recommended.
He's awesome, Neuro is awesome. He's funny and he cares alot about the students ,OH are great and use them for the things you're unsure on. Class is great
He can't teach. His voice is so annoying that it gives me a headache. Avoid him and take someone else!

When the first class started, I was nervous about the stories about how this class was really hard. Fortunately, Feldheim made is easier than I thought. About 98% the material was understandable and straightforward with some studying. His tests are really fair and he likes to recycle exam questions. I never used the book and still got away with a B

Dave is really nice. He knows a lot about cell bio, and even though it has a bad rep for being super hard, it's really not. Just go to class, write down the notes, including everything that's not on the powerpoint slides (he will often throw in little facts on the side that he sometimes tests on). DO THE PROBLEM SETS. you'll be just fine.
This is one of the easier upper division bio class and Dave tests are fair. Just study his notes, past exams, and read the book if you want to be more clear on the concepts.

People exaggerate how difficult Cell Bio is. Feldhiem is pretty clear on what he wants for his exams, he re-uses old exam questions. His grading scale is pretty generous, average is a B- which usually means a 60-63 is passing. Read the book for clarification, you will need it for some sections. All the exam questions are from his notes.

Dave is a cool guy! A little scatterbrained, but he's an okay teacher. I took this class over the summer and thought it was pretty hard. I put in the minimum effort and got a C+ though. Lots of memorization. I never read the book since his test questions are straight from the class notes. Do his problem sets!

He is an okay professor. He mainly does a lot of memorization and less on understanding. His notes doesn't give the full detail of a topic, so it is best to read the book for better clarification. He is weird at times, but that is his way to make his students laugh and to  keep his students awake.
One of the best teachers I have had. Very funny because he likes to poke fun at some of the subject matter

Very poor quality teacher. He seemed distracted in class and often got confused and had to repeat himself. Also was unclear on major concepts and constantly made promises to have the answers by the next class. Very bad professor.

He is one of the worst teachers ever. He doesn't teach us at all. His lectures are all scrambled. He shows us 100 pictures and expects us to follow everything he says. Pretty much you'd have to teach yourself cell bio to pass this class. He is terrible.

Gurun is a really great and knowledgeable professor! This class is extremely interesting and informative, I highly recommend everyone take it, even if you think you know everything about female phys. The exams are a little bit difficult because of the technicality of terms/systems discussed in the class, but overall, pretty doable.

She's clearly passionate, but lacks compassion. Makes no accommodations for emergency circumstances, the class average was a C and 85% of the grade is on multiple choice exams, that are designed to trick you. No extra credit whatsoever. Too hard for what the class should be.

Overall, this class was interesting and very useful. I loved the professor she actually cared about her students and took the time to talk to them. Although, I took this class as a GE and did not expect it to be difficult. I recommend that you don't take this class if you are looking for an easy GE.

She is honestly one of the best professors I've had. Her passion for female physiology is evident; her class is one of my favorite classes ever! If you do the study questions and pay attention during the lecture, you will be fine. I definitely recommend taking this class!!!

I enjoyed the passion professor Gurun displayed for female phy, she's very knowledgable as well. Considering this class is a science GE most people take, I would critique that the emphasis exams place on our grade could be changed, ie final worth 40% which I think can be a bit too high stress. Besides that, guest lectures and content were awesome.

LOVED HER!! I took BIOL 80A and it's so apparent how passionate she is about fem phys and gyno. She brought in guest speakers and put so much time into her lecture presentations it was cool. It was a lot of material though. It's a GE but for some reason we were having to learn like 40 pages worth of terms. Records and posts lecture presos!
The material in this class is very difficult, and it will kill your GPA. Even with going to MSI sessions, group studying, and literally studying everyday - the class is HARD.

Giulia's honestly a great, caring professor. Her lectures were interesting, well presented, and she somehow timed it to end right when her slides ended even though she was just talking from the top of her head idk she's just so knowledgeable. Her grading is hard and it's just a dense class. She is intimidating but easy to talk to once you try it.
Terrible teacher

This course is difficult for no reason. If you don't have to take this class save yourself the trouble. It'll ruin your GPA and give you anxiety. The exams are so specific and hard you never know what she expects till she releases the rubric. You'd think with going back in person and COVID she'd be more accommodating. BEWARE!!!

After 4 yrs at UCSC, I can whole-heartedly say Giulia is the best lecturer I've had. This class is difficult because of how much information there is and how you need to apply this information to real life. Her exams are scenario based and require critical/logical thinking about everything learned. VERY difficult class, but very amazing professor!

The Lab course is one of the most challenging courses in the MCDbio department. Although you learn how to write scientifically, the grading is very specific and it can be tough to understand what was graded so office hours are important. Its a very stressful course and would recommend to not take the class and the lab at the same time if you can

Giulias Human Physiology course are the 2 hardest classes Ive ever taken at UCSC. You got to know all the small details to even get a C. However, by the end of the course its surprising how much you learn due to the study strategies she recommends since its a lot of material she goes over. Despite this, the material is very interesting!

Wow I'm sorry to read comments that Prof Gurun is condescending or unapproachable - she's so the opposite. She is intimidating at first, but most confident, supersmart people are. I did have to work hard, but it reflected in my grades and I learned a ton.

If you take this class you should really consider not taking any other major classes because this class will take up all your blood sweat and tears. Although the material is very interesting and Giulia is a good professor and great at explaining the concepts.

2 quizzes, 1 midterm, 1 cumulative final. Course is curved. She has clear expectations and offers numerous tips on how to study and do well on her class through pre-reading quizzes (not part of grade), textbook reading, vocab lists, and worksheets in discussion. If you study as she suggests its NOT difficult to get at least a B.

Physio is dense and detailed, Giulia truly broke it down and made it easier to digest through her flow charts. Most people who say her class is hard are unable to adapt to a different testing and teaching style (detailed free response and MC). She is intimidating but still approachable, smart, and has clear expectations and tips on how to study.

First of all, Giulia's lectures are amazing. She's very thorough and explains things very well. That being said, she is extremely condescending/unapproachable and makes students feel stupid for asking/answering questions in lecture. The tests are actually written pretty well, but she is the harshest grader I have seen at UCSC.

One of the most difficult classes you'll ever take at UCSC! This professor will challenge you with a whole new style of "grading your test" that you've never seen before at any of your upper div. classes! You'll see that you may think you're putting down the right choice, you may be on the right path but with your own words! In the end, it's wrong!

He has the most illegible handwriting in the world, so if you need to look at the notes for any reason, you have to go to yuja and listen to what is said. 
He explains things as if you're retaking the class and already know it, and it's SO content heavy. FRQ exams, so you lose points for one wrong word despite explaining everything else right

This class is so dense. So dense. Professor is okay, great guy, but this class is not great for visual learners. In most lectures, if not all, he just talks a lot and writes little information down. He has a hard time really showing what's going on visually. He also just explains things like you would for some reason already know the concepts.

Prof Ward is a great professor, very caring and open to discussion. Go to office hours and discussion section. Lectures hold everything that will be on the tests, not mandatory but better to go to all of them for the content and activities.

This course was the first upper division bio class I've taken where the professor actually cares about the success of his students. Prof Ward truly supports his students and you can just tell that he cares by the way that his class is weighed. It was refreshing to be in his class

Would definitely recommend. Tests are hard but he gives you all the material you need to be successful. You can tell he genuinely cares about students passing his class. He's super easy to talk to and is always willing to help.

Jordan is probably one of my fav bio profs at UCSC. He gives you so many resources to prepare for tests, and he very clearly wants everyone to pass. The exams are similar to the practice ones provided, but make sure you're actually understanding the topics, or you're gonna slip up. They're 6-8 frqs so one stupid mistake and ur down a letter.

Professor Ward has got to be one of my favorite professors I've ever had at UCSC. He's easy to talk to outside of lectures and cares deeply for his students. The course content can be quite complicated and Jordan always found a way to make it understandable. Tests were straightforward, homework was challenging and very helpful. Highly recommended!

Overall a well put together class and lectures. Everything was accessible through canvas which made in person lectures easier to follow and he was open to any questions after class or during OH. The only thing I wish was different was his handwriting on the slides made things difficult to read sometimes, but that wasn't a huge issue.

The only thing preventing me from giving him a 5 is that my own personal learning style doesn't match his lectures so I tend to get confused during class. Prof. Ward is caring and definitely wants you to get a good grade in his class, which I love. So, he has tons of resources for you to succeed and I think anyone who utilizes them can succeed.

This professor seems like a very nice guy, and going to discussion sections makes this class way easier to understand. I find his lectures difficult to understand though, and you have to just sit and absorb a lot of complex content. Given that, he does provide INSANELY good preparation for the midterm; utilize everything he gives you.

prof ward was super cool and provided a lot of resources in preparation for tests. hw and occasional in class activities were very helpful for understanding material. he responded to emails in a timely manner (in my experience). the content was tricky, but he was transparent in what he wanted u to know for tests and on what needed to be studied.

Jordan is super caring and fair in all the exams (2 midterms 1 final) and hw assignments, never any surprises. This class wasn't easy and it was sometimes hard to catch up in lectures bc he talks fast but lectures were recorded as backup. The material and Jordans style of tests and hw made it all worth it though. Awesome guy!!

Jordan is an awesome, caring professor teaching a very interesting subject. The lectures can get pretty confusing sometimes, but Jordan usually gives time for many questions for the students to ask. Tests are pretty straight forward with a lenient grading system and as long as you try in this class, you will likely do well.

Jordan is extremely accomodating and helpful. BIOL 101 is a difficult class but the way he teaches as well as his grading system makes it so much less stressful than most STEM classes. If you can take this class with him, even in a pandemic his class did not stress me out nearly as much as the rest of them.

He was the only professor for Molec for Fall 2020 however, his lectures are interesting, he is a very nice professor, and his tests aren't too bad you just need to be descriptive. Going to section helps. I've had pretty bad and boring professors as a Bio major, so I would say he's one of the best I've had because he is nice and not boring.

he's very meh. Not the worst professor I've had, but far from the best. Seems like a nice guy but is very hard to follow in class. His slides are nearly useless, you have to watch the webcast bc he says the important information really quickly and its almost impossible to catch in person. Goes on tangents, use of class time feels inefficient.

Ward was an okay Professor. I believe this was his first time teaching Molec Bio or any class but he has a passion for it. However, he would go on tangents in class a lot and I feel we wouldnt learn as much. Not to mention that the in-class activities we did werent very productive and his tests were extremely difficult. MSI and SGT helps a lot!

He's passionate about what he does, but in lecture he always goes on about something off topic for the longest time and his lectures are so dry. you don't really know what's going to be on the exam ONLY if you go to multiple sections and OH beforehand. doesn't really explain concepts clearly, but if you watch webcast it'll be a little easier

Professor Ward is clear on what he puts on exams. He webcasts lectures so make sure to refer back to them to solidify concepts. I went to all his office hours which helped A LOT. It's a hard class (obviously, it's an upper div) but if you actively put in effort it will pay off.

Professor Ward really cares about his students' success. He implemented lecture notes, useful pre-reading resources, web-casted, and gave a PDF of the slides. He was always flexible with office hours time, and never was condescending. His one drawback is how fast he talks. I had to watch each lectures multiple times to get everything.

102/103L were the best experience of my undergrad so far. Jeremy really cares about exposing more undergrads to research labs which is awesome. Hes always open to answering questions and is very helpful. This class was so much fun and is actual research, very different from other lab classes. You go in on your own time.

This lab is literally the coolest lab to take at UCSC, especially if you are some type of STEM major. He's an amazing professor, who actually cares about his students. His research is extremely interesting, and it's a good stepping stone to further research @ UCSC. Lab hours are flexible, but you need to make sure you come in and do your work.

I cant say I will argue with any of those who have taken sanford's lecture classes and dislike his lecturing ability, but not all are amazing at teaching a lecture course. 102 lab with sanford was educational, incredibly productive and engaging. This course gave me a real idea of what working in a lab is really like. Please take this class!

Lectures were sometimes tangents and unorganized, but he really cares about his class. He's a tough love kind of person in class, but if you meet with him outside of class he will go above and beyond so you can understand the material.

This class isn't any harder than your typical college bio class. It's definitely easy to do well if you put enough time and effort into this class. Listen to his webcasts, go to the TA office hours and sections, and don't wait till the last minute to study for his exams. Clicker questions during class are a big grade booster.

Most of the oeiple complaing about Sanford aren't ready to take on an upper div Bio class. Is he the best professor? No, however you can tell how passionate he is about the subject. He can get off track, which is frustrating, but he gets through most of the material. iClickers, the textbook, and office hours/section are the keys to success

If a professor addresses his entire class with the laconic and sadly accurate statement of "yeah, we're sorta screwed right now," with only five minutes before the end of the final lecture, that's not a good sign in anyone's book!

Though he may be a brilliant researcher and okay guy, Sanford is a horrible teacher. He places WAY TOO MUCH emphasis on rote memorization of structures rather than conceptual understanding, he's a terrible explainer, and his tests can be devilishly difficult. I love biochemistry as a subject, but his class was one of the worst classes I've taken.

Do not take this class with Sanford. He has been one of the most unorganized professors I've had at UCSC. His tests were brutal. By the end of the quarter he was very behind and decided to pack as much as he could into the last two lectures and screw everyone in the class. Prepare to teach yourself. He expects a lot without giving much.

This class is co-taught by Stone who I really liked, but I found Sanford to be unreasonable. He asked fairly standard questions for example, what enzyme does this thing in the Kreb's cycle ? Instead of giving you the names of enzymes as your answer choices he gives you chemical structure. This would be a reasonable question for sugars but not this.

He was really nice actually. I would call myself a pretty studios person, and with a lot of effort got an A. All of the lectures are webcasted, so you'll be able to rematch what he taught. Honestly, I thought with a decent amount of effort the class was easy. I would say most complainers are just not quiet ready for an upper div bio class.

Horrible. Came to class and review session without any preparation. His half of midterm 2 was tricky and asked questions on things we hadn't covered yet. The final was ridiculous because a third of it was just on chemical structures which he didn't tell us we needed to know.
I wish he was more organized and prepared for this class.
Awesome professor. Very approachable and has a good sense of humor which made lectures less painful. Would definitely take him again for another class!
Super confusing tests. Very tricky and specific. Extremely exhausting lecturer, likes to power through breaks and keeps you late.

Reasonable lecturer, but tests are long multiple choice monstrosities. Also, grading is a bit unreasonable. I got no lower than 85% on every assignment, even though the averages should have merited a curve. Also did 2 extra credit assignments. Still got a B. Seems unfair to ask for students to do extra credit if you aren't going to give them any.

Sanford may not be the best lecturer but he is very helpful and approachable in office hours. go to office hr, often times he we drop hints for exam questions. I thought his final was easy (study his slides & memorize glycolysis, TCA, ETC pathways). do the extra credits & there is a curve!

He talks faster than you can write and doesn't write much on his lecture slides. I found it more helpful not to go to class but watch the podcasts later. That way I can pause and go back. His tests were way harder than the material he went over. He goes on tangents a lot. Be ready to teach yourself the material. Seems like a nice guy though.

This class wasn't very hard. Read the book & go to lecture. His office hours are very helpful. He posts lecture slides, gives study guides & emailed everyone & told them what score they would need on the final for an A or a B etc. This is an upper div class! If you can't teach yourself this stuff with his help then you should change your major.

Super cute, but you HAVE to teach yourself. The test answers are online so that made it easy for some. He's not very clear or confident, but he's self aware and will give you a good grade to make up for his shortcomings. If you don't have the test answers they're HARD because its on small stuff in the readings that he doesn't go over. Eh. He's new.
I would drive my car without my seatbelt, hoping I would crash every day before going to this class. Thankfully, I can say I survived, but my GPA on the other hand, did not.

He is a nice guy but the lectures were often a little confusing if u didn't write down everything he said. His slides just have pictures on them and he would often talk about things that were not relevant but just confuse the class because they were still regarding biochem.

Prof Kellogg is one of the best biology professors I've had so far. His lectures are really detailed as well and he is always willing to accept questions from students. His lecture notes are really helpful and if you attend lecture and read those notes then you should be good on his exams. His exams are really fair but you definitely need to study.
Will answer questions with related topic and increase confusion. Lectures unclear on what would be tested. Bland and bumbling.

His exams are based off his lectures which he broadcasts and uploads (notes and actual slides) to Canvas. Weekly quizzes online that are based on participation and he cares about his students understanding the concepts, he constantly asks for feedback and gives various examples whenever he can.

Came for the good reviews, stayed for the sublime subject matter. Fun lectures. After I finished Kellogg's class I found myself reading some heady pharmacology papers with ease. He's very helpful in office hour and very transparent with what's going to be on the (mostly multiple-choce!) exams. Sure wish I could take him for cell bio too.

Cell Bio is a difficult class, but Kellogg was a good professor. There is a lot of memorization that is inherent to the material, but memorization alone won't really help you on his tests. Be sure to read his lecture notes because that is what his tests are based on.

This was Doug's first time teaching Biochemistry. That being said he was very approachable, intelligent, and fair. He would take student feedback to improve his teaching stylestests. He puts worksheets online that if you memorize, you'll succeed on his tests. This upper div class is no walk in the park but Doug helped tremendously along the way.

Gives interesting lectures that feel current and relevant. Can be pretty funny. Exams are fair, just study the posted lecture notes. I never used the book or the slides, but I feel like going to class really helps. The exams try to gauge your understanding of the material. Simple memorization won't get you a good grade.

Before the exams, I made flashcards from the lecture notes and slides he posts online to memorize all the details, and that worked well. He speeds through the lectures, so you really need to spend extra time every week to absorb the materials. Office hours are helpful. I like it when he connects material to drugs and current issues and engages us.

Kellog overall is a very effective and entertaining professor, although his exams can be quiet demanding in terms of the amount of materials you need to memorize/understand. He provides detailed lecture notes and PP slides online, make sure you study those.

Midterm was rough but the final was fair. Like he says, KNOW LECTURE NOTES!!! Just memorized the lecture notes back and front and study wayyy ahead of time and got an A in the class. If you put in the effort you should be fine. Only used the book for clarification but mostly just studied the notes and slides.

Clear lectures/lecture notes. Tests are hard, unforgiving rubric. Grades based off a point system. 68+/100 on midterm (avg=54). Thought I got an A on the final (150). C in the class...math & bio major..pretty much most unfair class ever

Fair exams; midterm was a bit difficult but final was fair. Just read his notes/lecture slides, go to lecture, and section... you will be fine 45% midterm/55% final. He is funny too. I really enjoyed taking Cell Bio with Prof. Kellogg! I don't really like this class in general but Prof. Kellogg made this class to be much more enjoyable.
Easy class. Straightforward tests although check your answers, the graders tend to overlook right answers that aren't on the key.
Doug is an amazing guy and wonderful professor!! The material is really cool...especially the stuff on the cell cycle. He's a hottie, but students shouldn't be checking their professors out.
great professor.  very helpful and approachable.  very funny too!
funny,entertaining,helpful,nice. Was a great class!
great man. passionate about this stuff and really tries to get all the kiddos loving the beauty of our cell. i copied a great dvd off him once, he loves the science vids.
No Comments

lectures were good though she tended to go on tangents that didn't have relevance towards what we needed to know. Very much a forest for the trees type class where you need to know all the little details though she wasn't super clear on what details we needed to know. tests were graded harshly as well when it came to super specific details.

Great teacher and mentor to me. Tells a lot of stories about her own experiences in science which I thought was really cool since most teachers just throw content at you and move on. All the content she provides is definitely applicable to real world science and will better prepare you for any career related to biology. 100% enjoyed Prof. Hinck.

This class is definitely lecture heavy, and there's a lot of content the prof goes through in each lecture. Exams are hard and the averages were pretty low for all of them, often because students didn't have enough time to complete all the problems. Luckily at the end there was a curve which helped. I recommend going to section too!
never again. rip your grade.

Class is pure memorization with very few applications to real life. Exams based on memorizing every component of a pathway rather than understanding the material. She told her TAs not to hold review sessions for exams. When students missed questions on exams, she would berated students with how 'easy' it was. Grade based almost entirely on exams.
Studying for this class gave me actual, medically diagnosed stress hives. Overall, not too bad and she's a good lecturer

The lectures were great and she helped me out a lot outside of class. Very energetic presenter and made the material interesting. The class is very difficult but very fair. Put the work in and you will do well. Lindsay is a great professor take some of these reviews with a grain of salt, bitter cohort from last quarter left a lot of angry spam
The tests are lecture heavy and long, but balanced w/ each test only being worth

Professor Hinck is a tough love professor: she wants her students to succeed but she makes them work for it. Lectures were dense yet relevant. She grades on Guido's point system. Between exams, she adapted her format from brute memorization to data analysis. If there were quiz/exam question errors, she'd give points back! Chances for EC exist too.

Professor Hinck is an excellent instructor! Although this course was challenging, I appreciated how she structured the grading to include homework, in-class participation, and weekly quizzes. It's rare to see upper-div courses with such a comprehensive grading approach, but she ensures opportunities for her students to improve their grades.

Extremely memorization heavy-thought i learned the content, but come test day it was purely memorization, not very much application. Tests were also way too long, 80% of class didnt finish exam 1 or 2 in the 1.5hr block. 70% of class didnt finish final in 3hr block. Whole class felt disorganized. Would not recommend Hinck, go with anybody else tbh.

I've never worked so hard for an A in any class at UCSC. Tests are a pure memorization contest and TA's grading criteria was playing roulette everytime, you never knew what kind of score you were going to get.  To give them credit the content was challenging and her rubrics were awful. Wait a quarter and take with Guido, not worth the stress.

Her lectures are super long, and information-heavy. The homework are very useful for the exams, she also gives lots of extra credit so do all of them. Her tests can be challenging but not too difficult if you start studying at least a week in advance.
Dr. Hinck is great! The material is challenging but the grading is balanced out with homework and in class activities so it wasn't stressful. She had interesting lectures and I learned a lot.

Exams feel like a memorization contest. She has not taught in 8 years and is very out of touch with students. Office hours are not helpful and only makes material more confusing. Does not focus on building a conceptual understanding of material and just focuses on memorization.

No clear outlines of test expectations, lots of fluff on the lecture slide that will never be addressed again, encourages TAs not to hold review sessions, makes the class almost entirely memorization. You can be among the most knowledgeable people on the content, but miss a few key words according to her vague rubric and lose an entire grade.

Dr. Hinck was a great lecturer and professor. Her lectures were engaging and she was always eager to answer questions. Additionally, she posted her lecture slides on Canvas which were a huge study tool. In addition to reviewing slides, I highly recommend attending her office hours. The course was challenging but it was definitely worth it.

Dr. Hinck is a great teacher, she really takes in feedback from the class and will accommodate the best she can. Her tests are 50% memorization and 50% critical thinking. The critical thinking is the tough part but we all want to be scientists or doctors so she's really preparing us for that kind of career. Overall, she cares about her students.

She was amazing! Takes time to draw out the processes which was very helpful. UNDERSTAND & memorizing her slides. Textbook is not needed. Problem sets are helpful! You must feel comfortable reading graphs & interpreting data to succeed in the class. I feel more confident in reading papers thanks to her. She curves a lot. Love this class!

Professor Hinck has unrealistic expectations of how much a student should be able to memorize. Lectures are content heavy and she speeds through the information. Doesn't spend enough time on each concept but expects you to know it in detail for her tests. Tests are also extremely difficult. The questions are styled like the MCAT.
No interest or desire to teach. No effort put in lectures. Horrible testing method.

He is not helpful, even when attending his OH. Makes you feel stupid, despite the incredible amount of time one spends studying for this course.  He speaks to his iPad too much and does not accomodate for students different methods of learning. Multiple choice in a "higher level of thinking" design is a failure and only promotes guesswork & stress.
Manny talks to his ipad throughout lecture. His midterms aren't too terrible but the final was incredibly ridiculous. I definitely thought I failed walking out of the class but ended up getting a B.

this class is very difficult due to the depth of the material and his tricky exams! theres no point in studying a lot if you don't study right...read over the book and outline then go over all his slides and compare and make sure you not only know everything but really UNDERSTAND everything. TA'S oh/sections are a big help! don't give up he curves

Is straight forward in lecture but his tests are usually confusing and tricky. His practice tests do help a lot and sometimes he will put questions from the practice tests into the actual tests. There is no way to improve your score in the class all you have to work with is two midterms and a final. Don't bother with book just read his powerpoints.

Awful experience. I self taught myself the majority of the material because he wasn't clear in his lectures. His tests were impossibly tricky and I don't feel that my grade reflects what I learned in the class. This course wasn't about learning biology, it was about your ability to take his confusing tests. Horrible class

His test are so unfair, so tricky,and his sentence structure is horrible. I studied so hard for this class and still did not do well which kept me very stressed the whole quarter.  Lectures are very boring, focuses more in writing on the ipad which cant be understood what he writes most of the time.
He likes to put a lot of tricks in his test. He curves a lot which is fair because half of the questions on his exam were not taught. This is a tough course with a tough professor.

Tough course. Grades based only off of midterms and the final - little room for errors. Curves at the end. Posts his powerpoints and lecture podcasts online. Though this was a tough course, it is possible to get an A with the curve. Make sure to study his practice midterm and practice quizzes. Everything you need to know are in his powerpoints.

He was a very tough professor. There's very little room for error in this class and even though he tells us he does not want us to worry about grades, we end up doing that more because his grading system barely curves and is purely based on exams.

Manny was a horrible professor. His teaching method is based of him talking directly to iPad and very rarely looking up at the class. His midterms are very tricky and has material that he does NOT go over in class and material that is not in the book either. It seems as though he is proud of his tricky exams. Do Not Take 20a with him. Too stressful

Lectures are very boring and long! His voice is monotone which makes lectures much hard to listen to. Grades are 100% based on exams w/ no curve. His slides provide very little information compared to the specificity of the questions on his exams. I think he would rather trick you than help you understand the concepts. DO NOT RECOMMEND AT ALL!!!
Ares is a very tough teacher. He talks directly to his ipad and is not engaging at all to the students. Not recommend to take this class with him.
horrible lecturer, whispers to his ipod and doesnt even have good notes. tricky tests- you need to teach yourself in order to pass the class. unapproachable and doesnt curve. not recommended
Hard midterms and final. Questions were too tricky.
Hard. The material is difficult, and buy the book.
The exams were really tricky and hard.

Tests focus more on detail than concepts.  Standard 100-90 for A, 89-80 for b, 79-79 for c, etc...  But the averages AFTER the curve on midterm 1 and 2 were both around 70...so nearly half the class will fail.

This was Manny's first time teaching 20A I believe, and I'm so glad I had him instead of Dalbey from what I've heard. His tests were challenging but made you think and actually understand the material. Note cards will not help you with this class. .Manny is extremely approachable in office hours and he is very helpful. Good professor!
Really lazy - no thought into lectures at all

Grades are test heavy, lectures are not great professor has a bad lecture style sometimes difficult to understand he is very smart but his public speaking is not very good, called me out on my bad test score so at least he does care about his students

Bad class unfortunately: too much detail and not enough connection to how the content fits together. But the tests are ALL hw questions/some structure memorization. JUST MEMORIZE HW! I didn't know this the 1st midterm and killed myself studying. Terrible for comprehension- wish I learned more but the only way to do well is to blatantly memorize :(

Probably the hardest class I've taken so far, and that's mostly to do with how confusing his lectures are. It's obvious that he's really smart, but he tends to over-explain things to the point of confusion. Paired with the entire grade being based on 2 tests (30% midterm, 70% final), this class stressed me out so bad the entire quarter.

The lectures were uninteresting and difficult to follow. My grade was based on 2 tests (midterm 30% and final 70%, which you don't get test scores back for ie I never got my midterm score and I don't expect my final to come). He doesn't give you any study guides or tips for the test, wasn't ever brought up in lecture. More bad to say but wrd limit

Get ready for one of the most stressful courses of your life. Lectures are meandering and confusing, notes he provides are nonsensical, your grade is based only on two exams (which he doesn't post grades for), and he's beyond condescending. This class almost killed my love of biochem.

Hinrich Boeger does care about his students and clearly enjoys teaching. You will learn a lot if you go to class but it is not very helpful with tests and your entire grade will be based on tests. The test questions are ~80% based on the homework and grading can be very strict so it was important to memorize the homework, nearly word for word.

Boeger is phenomenal. The concepts are hard but he does the best he can to make the it understandable. You cant just memorize facts and expect to do well on the exam, but he is more than happy to help you and answer any questions. The homework is helpful to practice answering questions in the style of the exam.

Professor Boeger is a great professor who makes sure his students understand the reasoning behind experimental design. His class was always engaging, which impresses me because it was in the morning. Paying attention to him in the lecture made the rest of the course smooth because he explained all the concepts thoroughly.

He uses the latest research articles and focuses on how scientific understanding develops and advances. Rather than force feed you facts that you regurgitate, you will learn to think like a scientist, critically analyze literature, and contribute value in your profession. Exam questions come right from HW. Challenging with reasonable expectations.

His classes have changed how I view biochemistry and sciences as a whole. His lectures contain a lot of information which helped me feel less lost about biochemistry. Before his classes I only knew about the surface level of biochemistry despite having taken multiple classes. His classes were also not as difficult as I read from the other reviews.

Get ready for one of the hardest classes you'll ever take. Boeger doesn't really provide supplemental learning support and he gives extremely difficult exams on extremely complex topics. Pray that you have a good TA and you might be alright.

Boeger is a really smart guy, but honestly not a great teacher. Your grade is based on a midterm and a final and you barely get feedback or an answer key to check your work. His test questions are also way too open ended to be graded as difficult as they are-and the rest are worded so weird that the class doesnt understand what hes asking.

This is by far the hardest class I've ever taken and is completely different from any other bio class. It's extremely conceptual and spends a major portion of the class teaching about the thermodynamics and mathematics behind molecular biology. BUT, Hinrich is SUPER nice and really wants you to understand the material, not just regurgitate info

Hinrich is probably the most boring lecturer you will have. I found lectures meaningless, but notes were provided for each lecture. These served as a substitute for a textbook. Aside from these notes, don't expect any other source of help. He is not capable of being sufficient and to the point, so you will not be sure what is important. Good luck!

Boeger was one of my all-time favorites. If you have a real desire to learn to make use of biochemistry, thermodynamics, and molecular biology to tackle biological problems AND you enjoy listening to a wise old man with a German accent explain it thoroughly, then take his class. Go to OHs prepared and enjoy the conversation. He'll make you think.

MCD Bio majors DON'T take this course with Boeger! Wait to take it with anyone else. His lectures put you to sleep and his second midterm and final were extremely hard. He doesn't curve. For the amount of effort I put into this class for the grade I received, it was so not worth it. Seriously, swap while you still can.

Great teacher. Pay attention to lecture, take good notes (he also provides some, but take your own). Print out and write on the slides. Wants you to know it really well--not a slacker class. Nice guy, knows his stuff. Fair teacher. Do the homework, go to section, and go to office hours because people will be there asking questions.

the person who wrote below me is an example of someone who doesnt know how to study for a hard class. to study successfully, it takes a lot of time and a deep understanding of the material . boeger is difficult, but he is also one of most interesting professors at ucsc. take this class if you want to be challenged and stay on top of your reading

Eukaryotic Bio 115 with this Prof was horrible. I would avoid taking this class with this prof if you can avoid it. Even with attending all classes, sections, office hours, etc didn't help. He did not know what he was doing at all and even with the curve the grading scale was unfair.
He isn't very clear about what is on the exams, but very helpful in office hours and a HUGE curve (average 35%)  He was so cute I couldn't concentrate. ;)
my husband

This was his first time lecturing on his own and he did very well! Grading's 20% homework (completion), 20% each midterm (2 of them), and 40% final. He offers practice tests and keys. Content was a lot but thats expected. Tests were hard but just make sure to stay on top it. You can tell he loves neuroscience! Very patient with all our questions :)

Bio188: I highly recommend this class (Life in Medicine) if you have any interest at all in going into medicine. Even if you want to go biotech route, this seminar-style course is very eye-opening and informative. Guest speakers with different backgrounds come in, and you  present 1 case study at the end. We also finished the course with a potluck!

cool guy, course based mostly on problem solving, exams followed same logic as problems we worked on in class/section, curve for exams was huge, and attendance to half of sections and activity days was graded. I personally really enjoyed his class, it wasn't too hard for upper division, especially considering the curve

He rambles too much going off on stories to tell you one thing. It took way too much time to pick out what was important in his lectures and doesn't explain very well. He's also kind of harsh with students during lecture forcing them to participate. I didn't develop a solid idea on how to apply what I learned on exams. Good thing he curves.

This was a really easy and educational online course. I am not a biology major but I still found it to be really easy to understand the lectures! There were weekly quizzes based on the video lectures and readings. There were only three writing assignments and each week there was a discussion post required. Despite the work, it was all doable!

This is the third class I've taken from him and I chose it just because he was teaching it. He is by far one of the best teachers I've had and the class is quite enjoyable. 3-4 lectures per week, you can skip the readings and take one short quiz. However there aren't many points so your grade is entirely up to only a couple quizzes and a term paper

Grade is based on participation in group presentation (2x quarter) and "weekly" journal assignments that respond to a prompt about that week's reading or class topic. Lecture isn't mandatory, but his speeches are amazing. Very good medicine course for pre-med, may be difficult for non pre-med students taking it for a science elective.

He's a pretty chill professor, thank God he podcasts his lectures. His tests are based on critical thinking rather than memorization. It can be tough, bc its fill in. He gives participation for Fridays, so everyone shows up. I suggest looking ahead at the notes before coming to class, it'll help during lecture. Go to office hours! Plus he curves !

I took BIO 101 with Grant and this was the first class I ever failed. This quarter was hard because there was 2 professors so it wasnt as engaging. His tests were so hard and it doesnt matter how much you study because you are still going to fail. HIGHLY DO NOT RECOMMEND!!!!! Sadly, half the class is retaking it

Grant is super nice and funny but I'm afraid he didn't really know how to teach this class. He's super passionate about the subject and usually teaches biol115 which is way more advanced but for this class, he went into way too much detail and taught the class in the most unstructured way. DO NOT TAKE if you want a B or an A.

The professor is wonderful to care about his students and teaching. As long as you study everyday, practice homework problem set and midterm, you will do fine. But please please please remember, tests are tough, and try to understand the problem, not just memorizing them and you will do well.

i took his class spring 2016. it was the first time he taught this 3unit class. i think it would have been more understandable if i took bio 20a, but he tried his best to explain mitosis and meiosis. funny guy, very caring and understanding towards students. just show ur putting in effort and you can get an A. Beware he has a quiet voice,

He's super nice and kinda cute in a quirky way but his lectures were really unclear and the tests were challenging. The material didn't seem to flow and I felt like he struggled to reach the course at the appropriate level. (This is only the second quarter the class has been in existence though)

Grant was an outstanding professor. He lectured very clearly and it was a pleasure to take a class with him. The tests were thought provoking and were an excellent way to gauge understanding of the material. This translates for many people as "difficult", but he is a fair grader and gives lots of partial credit. To do well, focus on lecture slides.

Very doable class. Go to lecture, thoroughly study his lecture slides, do the practice problems and old practice tests (a couple of questions will show up from those on the tests.) The exam questions themselves are very clear-cut, and hes a compassionate grader. Class is curved. Grade: B

Very doable class. Go to lecture, thoroughly study his lecture slides, do the practice problems and old practice exams (a couple of questions will show up from those on the tests.) The exam questions themselves are very clear-cut, and hes a merciful grader. Class is curved. Grade: B

Probably the best professor I've ever had! Not an 'easy' class but definitely an A is possible if you work hard enough! I took euk in the SUMMER and studied my ass off and got an A. Grant is always there to talk to and is very helpful.
This class is by no means easy! But it might be passable. The teacher is a young, good looking, intelligent man but his intelligence is what leads to the difficult exam questions :(

Really nice teacher and his office hours are extremely useful.  But his tests are challenging, mostly due to spending the time deciphering what he is asking.  Gave extra credit points for doing quizzes and attending section.
I thought Professor Hartzog was great; he's very clear in his presentation, has a good dry sense of humor and is clearly interested in the subject.

this class is very interesting. Grant is very funny and his tests are very fair. pay close attention to his lecture notes. This is one of the easiest classes to get an A in, in the whole MCD bio series. now its euk that you should worry about

Not a good professor at all. I got an A+ in the course but I was miserable and stressed all year. Worst teacher I've ever had. Tests are FULL of trick questions. I have no clue how people give her a good review. left to fend for ourselves.Ruined my passion for biology. Avoid if you can. if not watch youtube videos, learning objectives, office hours

Mellisa is full of jokes, unfortunately none of them are funny. Want a relevant lecture? HAHA you get lectures full of stories about her boring personal life, and trick questions you answer on a 50$ iClicker. Help studying? HAHA you get bad worksheets with no answer keys! Do you want a good professor for Bio? HAHA You get Mellisa!

The people that gives her a good rating are people who have a great knowledge of Biology or has a passion for it. In my opinion, she is a great human being but as a professor not really. I pay attention to lectures but I don't understand because she can't explain well. I even went to LSS tutoring for help to study. Her exams are just tricky.

$50 iClicker. Technical issues with said iClicker. More verbal lecturing than actually having notes to write down, and when they are written down, it's not organized at all. Had zero clue as to what my grade was throughout the course (it was hidden), and final grade in Canvas wasn't accurate. Trick questions galore. #cooked #feverdream #andilikebio

You can absolutely excel if you just pay attention. She gives plenty of practice exam material, and she also offered like 4% total course extra credit over the quarter and inflates 91% to an A, so if someone didn't take her up on that... oh well. Warning: she always falls behind in lecture so stay on top of the pre-readings and you'll be fine.

Don't listen to the Dr. Jurica glazers. The rubric for exams are so harsh. I got no credit on a question for not using the other name for a term. Boy it's the same thing!
