This class is actual buns: tricky questions on exams. Select all possible answer questions even if it's only one correct answer. If u did not take AP Bio, prepare to fail!
PMO PMO PMO PMO PMO! THIS CLASS PMO! RUINED MY 4.0 GPA!

Professor Jurica is one of the smartest people I have ever met, She is incrediabily kind and understanding, and if you put in the effort I promise it will pay off. I will say some advice you need to study for this class do not let intro to biology fool you its a vey difficult course but if you really love the subject Jurica is a great professor.

Professor Jurica is extremely knowledgeable and passionate about biology, but her teaching style can confuse students on foundational concepts. TAs are hit-or-miss, sometimes giving feedback that would be wrong on exams. Multiple-choice questions are tricky. Be ready to study and ask plenty of clearing questions to Jurica!

Lectures can be confusing. Very understanding lady, especially about attendance, if you speak to her personally. Probably won't answer emails. Final grade is heavily test based! Studying is definitely helpful for the tests, but you are given extremely minimal study material. No answer keys for practice. Class is passable! Just put in the effort.

Possible to pass with a good score, given generous outside help. Lots of trick questions on exams, she cannot take ANY criticism of her teaching style, so be prepared for zero change despite asking for it. Egotistical, biased, be prepared to despise her.

1. questions on exams are purposely written to trip you up
2. most questions on the exam aren't even written with correct grammar
3. codon is helpful but half of the things you learn on codon isn't even on the exam
4. does not curve

 these professors in stem classes need to stop being so egotistical and learn that a curve is meant to help students

AVOID HER AT ALL COSTS. She is so bad. Exams are weighted 66% of your grade. She is a really bad lecturer, and none of what you actually learn and understand is on the exam. It is whatever she wants to put on the exam that she thinks is cool. Her exams are very chaotic, and the TAs couldn't even understand what she was asking in our exams.

she is the biology mirror of dhar from physics, the first freshman class that actually requires you to study so unprepared people get hurt by first midterm then blame it on her, shes the goat, do the HW, go to class, and ask questions if you are unsure of something, she also gave our class like +4% OVERALL GRADE extra credit, JURICA 2028

exams ask for intuitive thinking which leads to people who dont fully engage with the content to do bad , exams are 66 percent of your grade , as long as you study 1 every other day and pay attention in class you should be fine, she is kinda unhelpful outside of class but the class content isnt to difficult to grasp
Super tough grader if you don't study YOU WILL FAIL but if you go to office hours she will help a lot. Super sweet and caring person.

The class itself is not that challenging, but she makes the grading structure extremely test-dependent. I was lucky enough to gain pretty good scores on both midterms, but not many did. The final resources, as well as all the other test materials, are practically non-existent. Not that bad of a class. Overall, would not recommend.

Expect to learn pretty much nothing in lecture. She is so focused on her lab that it compromises the quality of the lectures. She goes on completely useless tangents and it is pretty much useless to go to lecture, except for the fact she makes you buy a 50$ IClicker and marks you down every time you don't come to class. Only way to study is to read
if you put it the work, she will meet you halfway

In my opinion, she should not be a professor. Her tests are poorly worded, lectures are all over the place, and she forces us to pay for $50 iclickers when we could just use our phones or Kahoot to do poll questions. Even tutoring doesn't help and she put EVERYTHING she talks about into one test and the homework is tedious and stupid. Avoid her!!!!

Loved Josh! People say he's pretty snarky, but I think that comes from his sense of humor. He is pretty unforgiving though, no curve and 90% weighted toward tests. Not only do you have to study the material, but also his test packets. His tests honestly felt more like reading-tests at times. Class is gonna be hard, it's biochem after all!

doesnt post the grade of your final anywhere, answers are not helpful, no answer keys for the packets he hands out, the tests are based off random topics he barely covered and the study notes dont go in depth on

This class is HARD. It's 90% based on tests, which makes sense for an upper-division course, but he doesn't structure these tests fairly. He will grill you on a topic he barely mentions once, but won't even cover the material he spent multiple lectures on. Doesn't show much empathy for students, hard to get a good grade.
hard class , lecture heavy tests focused on stuff he would say out loud not necessarily on slides
The class wasn't hard he's just kinda mean and doesn't seem to really care about his students

Probably the best biology lecturer I have had. He explains biochemistry really well, and you should take advantage of that. Put some work in this class, read how he does his test questions, and be consistent. If you want to pass, then do all the above. If you want an A, be prepared to make this class your top priority in the quarter.

A great lecturer– I'd say one of the best in the department. You will want to learn in his class. Grade distribution is almost entirely tests but the review packets he gives out are a great representation of the exams. Definitely a class that you can't fall behind in, but if you go to every lecture and stay engaged you'll be good!

Arribere is a great lecturer, he's really good at explaining concepts. The test are a bit whack; very much "anything is fair game if it was on the slides". It's fair tho, I don't think there was a single concept where I couldn't attempt to answer on a test. I would defiantly take again and it was one of my favorite courses.

bro is nice 50% of the time and randomly cold and hostile the other 50% & i never know which one it's going to be. if ur busy just say that, don't talk to me like i'm a burden just bc i have a question. elusive creature by his own admission. stubborn, prefers male students, likes having his ego stroked by sycophants. good at explaining things tho
He hates joy

Nice and funny but also a bit curt and snarky sometimes. I went to his office hours a couple times but it felt like he preferred to talk to the same five people which made it hard to engage with him outside of lecture. I'm sure he's a chill guy but his class requires quite a bit of work. Go to office hours, do the packets, go to TA review sessions.

Graded by few things but overall a great prof! You really need to utilize ALL of the resources or you wont pass. Go to section and office hours and you will do fine. Pay attention to learning objectives, he gets test questions from there!

Very fair professor and he wants you to succeed. I worked hard for this class and attended both of the TA's discussion sections, his office hours, and LSS (I didn't do the reading, but I did fine). They gave thick review packets that I found helpful, sadly there's no answer key. However, I got most of them by attending office hours.

I really liked the way Professor Arribere explained things. It looks like he made some changes to his lecturing since Spring 2023 class. I took his class Fall 2023 and I wouldn't say his class is particularly hard, but I don't think the exams or the grade I received reflect my learning or knowledge. I worked really hard.

He was ok. Study and you'll do fine. No curve so if you fail ur final u probably fail, but also that means no limit to how many people can get A's in the class. His lessons are good and he sort of listens to students. He cares enough to help, but also you can tell his passion isn't really teaching.

Can't complain as he clearly states what he expects from his students and there are no surprises or tricks. Definitely rewatch his lectures to study as every word that comes out of his mouth is valuable, anything/everything he says is worth taking notes on but he talks really fast. Exams are easier than the in-class activities and TA's are great.
Chill professor and does his best to break down otherwise really hard concepts. Just study hard and pay attention. He's cool lol

The exams don't feel conducive to learning. There are multiple multiple choice questions where he doesnt tell you how many answers are right and there is no partial credit so even if you get 2/3 you get no credit for the question. No homework which is nice but the tests are hard.

He is a great funny person, however, as a lecturer, he just reads off the slide 95% of the time. He doesn't curve the class. We are only graded by a few things (Quizzes, Questions, Exams) He takes attendance by doing in-class questions. His exams are 95% mc so you won't get partial credit. You won't have a lot of cushion for your grade.

He is very good at explaining concepts and will take as long as needed to clarify questions. I don't like how he just reads off of the slides, but his notes and the section worksheets are useful. Take advantage of sections/your TA. Tests are hard but he is very clear about what you need to know. Also just a nice guy and available outside of class.

Lectures were simple but pretty comprehensive, not much needed outside of them for homework or midterms. However, practice midterm was wiiiildly unrepresentative of the actual midterm; practice was super simple, while the actual midterm asked us to identify structures in one picture that was on a single slide of the lecture. Final wasn't bad.

1 midterm and a final, each 40% of grade. Midterm was ~ week 4. Final covered W5-10, so studying in depth was hard (so much content!); massive amount of info is hard to digest, but Prof Kim will answer questions/is very approachable in OH, you just need to put in the work. HW was graded for effort, EC offered for attending > 80% of lectures.

1 midterm, 1 final, and 4-5 HWs and some extra credit. I know to trust the curve but man his midterm was so hard, felt like none of what I studied or read helped at all. Shout out to the TA, I got decent score cuz of him. I don't like profs lectures, talks too much at the beginning and then breeze thru important slides. but he chill and funny dawg

HE'S GOING TO CURVE YOUR GRADE REALLY HARD, SO JUST STICK IT OUT. I think a 50-60% in the entire course netted a B, so as long as you perform near the average of the class, you'll be fine. An A+ should therefore be like >70%.

He's pretty heavy on pathways, so pay attention to those.

Incredibly helpful professor, he truly wants you to do well in his class. Midterm was online due to covid and was a lot more difficult because of this. Final was in person and the test was significantly easier/more straight forward. Homework a little difficult and can be hard to find the answers but not graded too harshly. Big curve at end of class

If you don't have photographic memory don't take this class. The level of detail required for everything made this class miserable. Partial credit is awarded for attempts, but if your answers don't have enough detail points will be deducted. This would be fine if how much detail was required was stated, but it isn't which makes grading unclear.

Professor Boyd was an amazing professor, his lectures were very interesting and I can say that this was the one course at ucsc that I believe had no material, assignments, readings, etc... that i thought to be useless or unhelpful. He is very considerate of life outside of class and works with his students to make sure they can succeed.

Professor Boyd was great! He provided clear learning objectives at the beginning of each lecture that helped organize topics we covered into categories that helped a lot when it came to studying for midterms/final. HW and exams matched what he covered in class. He was approachable and always willing to re-explain things/answer questions!

3 HW assignments, a midterm and a final. Clear grading, all info on hw/tests can be found on lecture slides/recordings. EC opportunity on first HW and EC project due at the end of the course. He really wants students to understand the topics and succeed, I thoroughly enjoyed the class and had a lot of fun. Reasonable workload.

If you want a professor who doesn't follow feedback from students, has difficult exams because she wants you to write the stuff SHE WANTS in PhD-level detail, and gives you group portions that don't even help because you can have the same answer as your partner and still receive a lower grade. 

Take Dunkin! You will have a blast!

This professor has high expectations for exams and it is almost impossible to get an A in this class. She also expects the students to use her exact wording to get full credit and does not offer extra credit opportunities. She also makes the content super hard to understand and unenjoyable. I would not recommend this class at all.

I literally did everything I could, including office hours, help from TAs, help from former students but its not enough.  Tests are so hard and unclear.  Basically no extra credit. Liked the content but hated this class sm.

Whoever said this class is easier than 20A is LYING OUT OF THEIR A**. Her canvas was a mess, and she was too lazy to create new practice tests that included more of the actual content we were being tested on.  FRQ grading is also really inconsistent.  One person could receive full credit for the same answer that someone else got half credit for.

This class is really difficult, and you genuinely need to know everything to get an A. I did everything I could by attending office hours, completing all the homework, and reaching out to my TA for extra help, but it still wasn't enough. There is almost no extra credit, grading is extremely strict, and test questions are often unclear.

This class is impossibly hard, you think you know the material, the test comes out and you don't. The questions are EXTREMELY specific. The prepping watching the videos, reviewing your notes, watching youtube videos on all the concepts, writing tons of practice questions, attending office hours, internalizing everything in discussion is NOT enough.

The format of the class is flipped, which personally helped me, but the tests were evil. They are mainly short answer, except the questions themselves were super specific, and so if you didn't know absolutely everything, you were kind of screwed. The wording was really bad too, but she never fixed that. Not a horrible class, but not the best.

Uses a flipped format which means content comes from videos, textbook, lectures, individual projects, and all over the place. Questions on exams are weirdly specific, assume you need to know EVERYTHING in depth to do well.

attendance required in a huge class, many just come for attendance points, bad system.

harder than bio 20a!!

2 Midterms and 1 Final: Tests were slipt into secections independent and group 
Dunkin was super caring, gave us grace periods for late work, and would extend due dates further if you asked her. Hard material and tests are pretty tough but overall great professor with organized lectures.

Prof Dunkin is AMAZING. She genuinely cares about her students' success and constantly asks for feedback and how she can improve her course. No trick questions on her exams, and she does an excellent job at explaining concepts in easy ways to understand. 100% recommend her!!

Prof. Dunkin is great! The class has a lot of content, but she explains everything clearly and provides numerous opportunities for students to ask her questions or discuss with other classmates. The tests are somewhat difficult, but there was a group portion, which was nice. As long as you keep up with the lectures, you'll be fine (LSS is good too)

Dr. Dunkin is really good at what she does. Great instructor. But, class set up makes it super easy to fall behind. 1st midterm is usually pretty difficult, but once you get into 2nd, most people improve. Don't expect any extra credit (usually only comes from SETS). THEY ARE SUPER HARSH ABOUT DEADLINES!!
Easy material but lots of homework and pre lecture videos.

Professor Dunkin's BIO20B class has a flipped format, but it works well if you stay on top of the weekly videos. The workload is manageable, and Unstuck AI can be a helpful study tool alongside the course materials.

This class is not extremely difficult, however there is a large workload requirement each week in addition to attending lectures and sections (which are mandatory as not attending will effect your grade). Tests are not  difficult, but the written portion are graded hard. I would say try not to fall behind on the weekly videos.

She is a really kind professor! She has a flipped class format so you have to watch the videos before hand and she does hands on activities during class. She is the type of professor who will take time to learn your name and really inspire you to learn!

Loved Robin's teaching style, she's very approachable and passionate about biology. Flipped class format made lecture content much easier to follow, otherwise the amount of material is overwhelming. Just watch the videos and you'll do fine. Multiple attempts were given for homework and quizzes which really encouraged learning from mistakes.

Professor Dunkin is very understanding and a great teacher. Watching the required video lessons before the lecture was annoying and took a lot of time but were useful when you wanted to go back to review or relearn the topics. The short answer questions on the tests where graded harshly but that's to be expected.

flipped classroom means that you spend most of your time watching lecture videos at home that she goes over again in class which can be frustrating but she's a good teacher. attendance worksheets are passed out in every lecture. 2 midterms and a final exam that each have an individual and group part.

Awesome professor she somehow manages to engage a lecture hall of 200+ people. Her flipped classroom videos are sometimes hard to keep up with but you can watch them anytime and they're all very clear and succinct. She'll clear up concepts you've been wondering about for years in ten minutes or less.

I had an 89.9% and he would not round me up. So annoying. But besides that he was a pretty good teacher, his TA's were sassy and rude but whatever they got the job done. The TA's grade the homework and they were such harsh graders. Tests are online and open note, super easy. If you skip lecture, do the in class activity during your class time.

The tests were weirdly worded and confusing, but other than that the class was pretty easy. Just go to class and do the quizzes and you will likely be fine. There is a textbook but you don't have to read it the lectures are enough.

He's an amazing, hilarious person with a great personality. His class was difficult for me but I know other people who did not struggle. His tests are online and open-note, but don't take them lightly. His class really requires you to understand the material rather than memorize it. He has weekly office hours and always answers questions.
He was a good professor overall, the class wasn't hard especially if you've taken APES in highschool.

Good professor for the most part and I personally really enjoyed his class and teaching, however I knew people who did not. His tests were worded very complex so make sure to read the questions over at least one extra time. Tests are online and open book though so not horrible, but you will run out of time if you try to look up every question.

Baldo is a great professor. His exams are tough because of the time constraint, and the worksheets are graded pretty harshly. However, there are opportunities to get EC and the material itself isn't very hard to understand. He gives you all the resources you need to get an A, you just need to take advantage of them.
Professor Marinovic was a great professor, his lectures were always very interesting and on-topic. He tells lots of jokes but also prepares students for the assignments and tests well.

Amazing class, but worksheets are graded very harshly. On tests, you are only given a very short amount of time to complete them; no study guide is given to you, so just make sure you take good notes and go to OH to pass.

this course is insanely difficult. exam questions are extremely hard and lengthy with such a short amount of time, and worksheets are graded extremely harshly. only way to succeed to going to OH to ensure your answers are correct.

Baldo's 20C class was one of the hardest classes I've taken at UCSC, and I'm a second year MCD biology major. Tests are online and were timed, super stressful, and had huge paragraphs to read and process all in a time crunch. All I would say is to go to office hours and ask help for the worksheets, as they are graded too harshly.

He is a good lecturer but the exams are a ridiculous. Midterm we had 20 minutes for 8-12 questions and the time crunch was stressful. Plus the questions have dense paragraphs to dissect. The final similarly  we get 90 min out of 3 hours so the rest goes to DRC. Not sure why our time would get cut for DRC when they should have their own time slot?

Awesome professor, keeps your attention the entire lecture, has in field experience, and makes his lectures personal. Likes to poke fun at kids who sit in the front but he also likes people who answer questions so be warned.

Such an odd guy and seriously just one of the most boring classes you're forced to take as a bio major. Crazy strict rules about tests because they're online, no idea why he doesnt save the trouble and make them in person,, im not complaining tho. Lecture is mandatory but no code is needed for the in class activities, so its easy to skip it.

Lectures are long and fast-paced but well-structured. I recommend taking notes. Wording on tests can be weird but he and the TAs are always available and willing to help. All tests are online and open-note as well. Pretty easy A or B if you put in some effort.

He's a silly guy and a good lecturer. I think he does cram a lot into lectures and it makes it difficult to know what to study for exams. He doesn't offer study guides, only old exams without the ability to check your answers. But if you go to class, do the worksheets, and study past lectures you'll be fine.

weekly worksheets where u get graded on whether or not you write specific definitions (TA's can help). the tests are not reflective of your knowledge of the course. the lectures do not relate to test content. tests mostly are filled w trick questions. wouldn't have gotten an A w/ out taking AP Enviro in HS or AP Bio tbh. class unnecessarily hard!!!

The class is not as easy as it seems. The tests are online, but nothing prepares you for them. They have incredibly long paragraphs of text that make it hard to comprehend the information under the short time limit. I do NOT recommend this course at all. If you perform badly on one test it is extremely hard to raise your grade. EC is not EC.

Not too hard if you read the lectures. Open-note midterm and final. Basically just an APES class with more of a focus on bio. The hardest part was just trying to figure out how to make a chart on Excel.

This was by far the hardest grading I have yet to experience as a third year in college. If specific vocabulary words aren't presented in the homework answers, 0 credit will be given for the question. Super disorganized lectures with a lot of rambling and no lecture prepares you for the homework or tests.

Prof Marinovic is a good professor and if you reach out for help, he will do what he can to make sure you understand the material. The class content was interesting, but sometimes a little lacking in interactiveness. He explains the material very well and if you attend class, then you'll definitely be able to succeed in this class without a problem

I enjoyed learning with Prof. Alonzo because her lectures were interesting and easy to understand. Plus, her communication skills are great, and she gives plenty of resources for students to succeed. One of the best professors at the EBB department!

Honestly one of the best profs in the EEB department. Her lectures are clear and its obvious that she loves teaching.  She really cares about her students and wont move on from a topic unless everyone understands.

I'm a 4th yr MCDB major and haven't had many kind profs. Suzanne reminded me nice profs are possible! She is a very thoughtful and caring. The class material is interesting and she makes you engage with it in a meaningful way. Her first midterm was easy, but the final was difficult. So don't start coasting after midterm 1!

Prof Alonzo is one of those instructors who genuinely care about their students understanding the content and seems to care about them as people as well. Attendance is mandatory for section and lecture but she is very generous with her grading. Exams are fair and attending lecture is sufficient enough to succeed in her class. A lot of interaction.

Alonzo is a real gem of a professor She explains things very clearly and lets you know exactly what you need to know At the beginning and end of each class she points out exactly what you should gain from that lecture She's super easy to talk to DC requirement is changing at ucsc so you probably wont be taking it with her but a template is given

Do you like ecology? Do you like math? If you answered yes to both these questions, take this course. Don't be intimidated by the fact this class is also offered to grad students. Workload was reasonable, and the material was both interesting and useful. I recommend 10/10

Alonzo is an unapproachable professor with little real interest in hearing what students have to say about the class. The tests were difficult but manageable, but the paper assigned for the DC requirement portion of the class was excessively difficult and tedious. Try to avoid taking this class with this teacher if you can.

Suzanne managed to make evolution engaging, interesting, and fun. Unlike some professors who find teaching to be a chore, her focus was always squarely on ensuring everyone in the class understood the material. The class never felt too dense, despite covering a lot of material. Tests were thorough but fair. Absolutely take if you get the chance.

He is incredibly kind and clearly cares deeply about biology and the environment. He works hard to give us unique experiences, with many opportunities to go outside and create our own research projects.

Abe is the nicest professor I have ever had. His class is probably my favorite class I have taken. He loves what he teaches, and he really shares that love with his students. He is very helpful with in class issues and is a great person to go to with questions about majors and internships.

Abe is literally the best teacher ever! His class is so engaging and inspiring, he truly loves his students and you can tell how much he loves teaching. There are asynchronous assignments but they're all pretty manageable and beneficial to you a a student. You get to be outside and go on field trips whats not to love!!
I LOVE DOCTOR ABE BORKER PLEASE TAKE HIS CLASS BIO 20F YOU WILL BE SO HAPPY
Really great and thoughtful teacher! The class had many unique opportunities and also opened you up to different professional connections. Couldn't recommend more to anyone considering it!
Abe is such an amazing person! I would take this class again. Such a cool experience to be part of that class!

Abe's very funny and actively cares for his students. He also provides a lot of information on how to get more involved outside of class time. Makes sure that camping and day trips are comfortable for all. If you enjoyed his class a lot after you finish the class you can volunteer your time and experience by going back on trips the next quarter.

Professor Borker is truly an inspiration to all undergrads who aspire to do hands-on field biology. Being a part of this class is a privilege! The trips you embark on are beautiful and memorable. He continues to keep his students in the loop through email, sending out research opportunities and invitations to future trips with his 20F class.
He's so cool

I am in Abe's BIOE 20F class and it is by far one of my favorite classes I've ever taken. He and the TAs for the class make engagement fun even though it is technically required. Get ready for keeping somewhat meticulous field notes, and either long day trips or overnight field trip to gorgeous locations around the state. Wonderful class and prof.

Literally one of the best instructors I've ever had. His enthusiasm is contagious, and outside of the course material he'll teach you a bunch of little pieces of trivia and fun facts that you really wanted to know about nature and the nature on campus specifically. Even if you've never gone on a hike, I cannot recommend his BIOE 20F course enough.
Hes a great, kindhearted guy and is there as help for rapid research projects. He is very helpful for getting opportunities outside of class for biology and ecology.
Abe is the nicest professor I have ever met. I absolutely recommend any of his classes. He is super nice and incredibly funny, and felt more like a mentor than a professor.

I actually took a 2 credit class with him called Natural History Practicum of UCSC (KRSG-3) and it was basically a hiking class that talked about nature on our campus. It was amazing, he had great student guest lectures come, we visited many different places around campus and the costal campus. He was very willing to work with students.

Sean is an amazing professor who makes the course truly interesting and engaging. Class is low pressure and you'll meet a lot of new friends and see amazing places. Definitely recommend taking one of his courses if you get the chance!

This was one of the most fun courses I've taken at this school. Lectures are very clear and not very long with labs and field trips taking a majority of the time. Quizzes and labs are easy and intuitive. There are readings but they aren't very long or dense. Would definitely recommend as a break from heavy classes especially if you love nature.

I loved BIOE 114, definitely take this class for experiencing new things that you never thought you'd discover. Field trips were incredible and so fun! Loved the professor he was extremely caring and easy to talk to.

I had Sean for BIOE 114, Herpetology (wasnt an option in the course codes). Probably my favorite class I have ever taken at UCSC. Learned so much, have new skills, I go herping all the time now. Class is low pressure and you make a lot of friends. The field trips are fantastic. I would urge anyone to take this course. Textbook is a field guide!

I loved taking ENVS 19 (Natural History of Reptiles and Amphibians) with Sean this quarter! I was genuinely so excited to go to class each week. His lectures are engaging and our field trips were so much fun! This was a low-stress class, definitely recommend!

Sean was truly an incredible professor to have a class with, and I would absolutely love to take another class with him if I ever get the opportunity. Intro to Field research was an amazing experience made all the better by an instructor that truly cares about the course, the material, and most of all his students.

All you have to do is be there for the first and only lecture and that's all the physical participation that's needed. He gives very constructive feedback and also gives constructive compliments. Very nice and interesting class. Highly recommend.

Ari is an amazing lecturer! I had a great time in his class. Lectures were engaging as he used case studies to make concepts easy to digest. Created a welcoming environment for questions/constructive conversations about lecture content. Very funny and entertaining. You can tell he's very passionate and cares about the subject he's teaching.

Ari is an amazing lecturer and very passionate about this topic. When I took the class he gave no tests besides weekly quizzes in discussions sections which served as a way to gauge the students understanding of the topics. Overall, he is an amazing professor that really cares about his students and teaching the topics of behavioral ecology.

The professor has an interesting attitude that can make her seem unapproachable. I was lost almost all the time, even when watching lectures. There was a lot of tedious work, but it was only a 5-week course. People like her make me want to refrain from being in the EEB department. She wants us to succeed and understand the information, however.

She did not often support our learning & was also very rude or passive-aggressive, which prevented me from asking questions during class or reaching out. The material is based on stuff you "should know" and statistics, which I did not enjoy. The majority of my classmates were confused. The work is a lot and often does not reflect the lectures.

she is very passionate about what she teaches but incredibly insensitive and straight up rude for no reason. very serious about assignments but doesn't teach any new material that isn't already learned through prerequisites. don't take her if you desire constructive criticism.

Asynchronous class! Work load was weekly quizzes (1 reading quiz, 1-2 lecture quizzes), 3-5 15 minute lectures weekly, 1 discussion post, weekly synchronous Zoom w/ section assignment (group work mandatory). No midterm, final exam worth 5%. Class is really easy if you do the work it's just a bit tedious. Grading was reasonable, would recommend!
BIOE109. Don't expect to learn very much. Class is easy to pass, but there are like a million assignments. Nice person though!

Amazing, inspiring, and one of the best teachers I have had. Online midterm and final were worth 5% and the averages were pretty high. Somewhat a lot of reading and quizzes but they are easy. I highly recommend this class!!!!!

Kelley is very passionate about what she teaches. The midterms/final was a very small part of the grade which was refreshing, but she assigns a huge amount of work every week to make up for that. Her lecture/discussion REQUIRE you to have a partner/work in groups. Her office hours are okay not majorly helpful, overall a very decent professor.

She is just fine. her grading is iffy at times but overall it's easy to do well in the course. Lab is a lot of work but very worthwhile. I have learned so much from this course and I'm happy I took it, but overall my enjoyment came mostly from lab and my TA. Lecture is not the most interesting.

Gives incomplete feedback, blames you for not fixing what she didn't mention. Expectations disproportionate to time limit given for assignments. Gives unclear directions and tells you it's your fault for not doing what she wanted. Learned a lot but at what cost. Ruined plants for me. My TA was incompetent and we had to correct her.

I don't know why professor Kathleen has such a low score here. Hands down, she is one of the best, nicest, and most caring professors here at UCSC. The homework was turning in your class notes and attendance was not mandatory because she recorded every lecture. Group work can help you pass this class with flying colors. Would recommend!

I loved how she structured the class for online. Weekly pre-recorded lectures, with worksheets and quizzes based on readings. Final and midterm were easy, both only worth 5% of the final grade. There were weekly discussions and group assignments, so you kind of had to luck out with having a good group to work with.

Kathleen is a great professor and is really passionate about her subject. The class is challenging, but the lab is much harder. Keying is a big part, so this can be tough if you're new to it. Lecture grade breakdown is 20% midterm, 20% final, 20% collecting project, 15% research paper, 10% participation, 5% quizzes, 10% miscellaneous exercises.

hands down the worst professor i ever had. she go so fast that not even the quickest note taker can keep up with her. her tests are nuts bordering on unfair, and because of her speed in lectures and her heavy focus on lab topics in lecture (not tested on) you walk into tests not really sure of what if anything you learned. avoid her at all costs

Really horrible lecturer. Can't clearly explain anything. I felt unwelcomed during office hours. Material is not hard however she makes her tests way harder then they have to be. Discussions are mandatory. So much busy work. Ta Jordan was horrible. Overall, horrible and frustrating experience. Worst class I've taken at UCSC. Avoid Kay.

Professor Kay is extremely knowledgeable in her field, and interested in student learning outcomes. She provided us with excellent hands-on opportunities to put our knowledge into practice, and was always there with clear instructions to help us succeed.
I would try to take this class with someone else
Worst professor I've ever had. Sections are manditory and feel like an extra class. There is a lot of busy work that is unnecessary for understanding the course material.

If you love plants, Kathleen Kay's Botany class is amazing! The labs are fantastic, every week you get to learn the plant families by looking at live plants organized by family and spend time drawing them. Kathleen Kay is a very sincere person who cares a lot about doing a good job teaching. The exams were very fair.

Kathleen is a wonderful teacher. She is very sweet and helpful, and her lectures are clear and to the point. She really wants to see her students do their best possible, and is great at calming you down when you're a ball of stress. She answers questions politely, and responds to emails quickly. I want to take more of her classes, I adore her.

This class is excellent and extremely informative. It is hard and requires a lot of time. Project/readings were interesting. Kay herself is not the greatest lecturer but not the worst by far. She seems pretentious/not approachable but was very helpful and sweet in office hours. No curve, but tons of EC. Work hard and you'll be well rewarded.

She was an awful teacher and made me cry after almost every class. She assigns a ton of random work and has ridiculous guidelines that are really unclear. Whenever she started talking it made me have really bad anxiety, and she was always really condescending and disrespectful. Avoid taking this class with her!

doesn't seem to care about students, their progress, or their success.  does not explain grading/no rubrics for assignments. seems nice at first, but makes it difficult to succeed.  most of the time, she seems disinterested during lecture and responds to comments/questions in a rude manner.  would not recommend taking this class with her.
She seemed irritated most of the time and lectures were a bit boring. A friend warned me NOT to take this class with her. I should have took his advice.

iclicker, 1 midterm, 1 final, homework, section participation, writing #1,2, &3. The third one is the rewrite of writing assignment #1. Required to buy a program to do homework assignment.  Boring lectures but she had some good examples.

The lectures were read off the powerpoint slides, the exam questions were fair, but the amount of time she gave you for the final was only 1 hour and 30 minutes. Homework on the SimBio program were tedious... waste of time, I didn't learn anything.

Interesting subject matter, well presented overall although really quickly! She clearly knows her evolution, which includes evolving beyond any sympathy for undergraduates. One of the most condescending professors I have ever had. The writing assignments were tedious and dull and graded very hard. The class isn't too difficult if you study.

Overall a good class. Her examples can be really fascinating. The material changes the way you see all organisms (humans not excluded). Lack of transparency on test material and essay grading are probably my only complaints.

One of my favorite professors. She pauses and articulates her thoughts clearly, making her easy to understand. Her exams are challenging and detailed, so avoid procrastination. The TAs leading the labs are also excellent. The teaching team is supportive of student-athletes! I absolutely loved this class and this professor.

Prof. Mehta knows her stuff and brings so much enthusiasm to the classroom! For the accelerated 5 week summer version: stay on top of the readings and put time in to study and you should be alright. Textbook provided. Dissections required. You can use lab notebook for the lab practicals so if you put in time to your notebook the tests are fair.

Easy class and good presentations. She does a review of the last lecture for the first 15m of class, which I think could be better time spent on going into more detail of the class topics. She does explain in detail during office hours, so go if you can. Very nice and always looking to help students.
The lectures are clear and you leave learning something new. The readings are dense but the instructor helps guide you and tells you what to really think about.
Boring, uninspiring, unhelpful
so boring, didn't add any info that made lecture worth attending
Dislike the professor and her teaching style
All review, boring slides

I'm really not sure why people are so obsessed with this professor
She added almost nothing to her slides and was very unhelpful when asked questions
I've dealt with her on multiple occasions and every time I was met with abruptness and a lack of understanding

Rita's lectures are very dull. Her slides are hard to read bc they're just big blocks of text and all she does is recite the slides word for word. She relies heavily on inane groupwork to pass the time that she isn't able to fill with any real knowledge. One of my least favorite profs at ucsc

Rita only gets a good reputation because her class is easy but just to be clear that doesn't make her a good prof. Her "niceness" is extremely fake and she's dishonest and rude to students she doesn't like. She runs every department and is on a huge power trip about it

This professor has excellent communication skills. Professor Mehta reached out to me when I accidentally skipped 2 quizzes. I thought I had submitted them but the power was unreliable and the submission did not go through. I would not have known until much later but she reached out. I know she is super busy so it is nice that she makes effort.

rita is awesome, you can tell she LOVES teaching and wants you to learn. she's very caring and always answers questions thoughtfully and wants you to engage. you definitely have to go to lecture and the material can be dense, but quizzes are easy. take this class if you want to learn/have a passion, because that's what is expected of you.

I love Professor Mehta, she is very accommodating and cares about her students a lot. The tests are all reasonable as well as the homework. Everything is very manageable. The lab is super fun. One of my favorite classes that I have taken in 4 years of being at ucsc. Taking another class with her for sure.

I took this class during summer and it was one of the easiest courses I have ever taken. Probably due to covid and the fast pace of 5 wks, not much was heavily assigned. Grades were mostly based on quizzes and two assignments towards the end. Overall, Rita is amazing to talk to and very easy to follow. Well-paced lectures and great guest speakers.

Rita talks at such a slow pace during her lectures that it makes not having the webcast easy. She is clear about what she wants to test you on, but theres little external notes so you must attend lecture to get the material. Overall the concepts she will test you on she will repeat like 2x in class so pay attention to the things she says twice.

Very helpful teacher and makes class interesting. Speaks at a slower pace during lectures so that you can take good notes. Memorizing and identifying various bones/muscles in lab was tough for me (summer class) but not for others in the class. The book for the class "your inner fish" was an interesting and relevant read.

An awesome professor! She genuinely cares about your progress in the class and you can tell that she is passionate about what she teaches. In order to do well in her class you have to attend lecture, there's a lot of handwritten notes, and use the book to elaborate on things you don't understand. Seriously one of my favorite class and professors!
Dr. MEHTA made Animal Phys interesting. Gave me a good foundation. Lectures were entertaining especially for a large class.

Don has the opposite problem of most professors--he explains only what is already known. You wont actually learn any biology or anything special to marine science, and his lectures are very dry. He requires very little of his students intellectually and I at no point felt challenged by the course material. Even showing up felt beneath me.
I took supercourse with this Dr. Croll and he is awesome. He is a very well respected researcher with so much knowledge but really down to earth and good sense of humor.

Don is clearly passionate about marine conservation. The class is lecture heavy, including many guest lecturers. Could be a bit more engaging. Lots of group work, primarily on two videos. Midterm prompts were released ahead of time and tests were fair overall. I would recommend this class for anyone specifically interested in marine ecology.

He is awesome. A lot of people will complain about Don since his classes aren't the usual memorization followed by regurgitation of facts on a test. His class focuses on actually solving conservation problems, making it one of the best and real world oriented classes there is

Do not take a class with him. Lacking in intellectual rigor and even basic organization, you will not get anything back graded, and so will have no idea what your grade is until the last day. He has no idea what hes doing, and makes poorly organized group projects a significant portion of your grade.

Hands down the best class I have taken at UCSC. Don has teaching down--he's honest, straight forward, clear, and knows his stuff (and also a lot of cool people). If you are interested in conservation, the ocean, or the future of your planet--take this class. Plan to work for your grade, but if you put the time/effort in you'll learn a lot & do well

I've never worked so hard for a C in my life. Honestly I'd recommend not taking his biol 150 class unless you are a graduating senior and this is the only class you plan on attending. Though Don is very clear, and you'll learn a lot, the class is run more by the students than Don and the TA's

Be extremely weary of this professor and his undergraduate classes. He is extremely harsh and under forgiving of his assignments, which often are assigned with little time before the due date. His classes demand you?re complete attention and dedication. If you have a class with him goodluck.

Best professor I have ever had.  Very competent and clear lecturer and inspiring as a scientist and researcher.  Learned a lot and will use the information to guide my future educational direction.  Easy to approach and dedicated to teaching and science.

This class gives a clear example of what field work is really like (long hours of observation followed by literature searches and writing papers). If you have ever considered field work, take this class so you know what you are getting yourself into. This class is hard, but very informative.
AWESOME! he actually let students REALLY CONSERVE rather than teaching students HOW TO conserve. We did projects and got interested and reached out!!! AWESOME!!!
No Comments
Great class, great teacher!  Concentrates on students actually learning,  getting to know, and becoming interested in the material rather than just knowing things for tests.  Highly reccomended.
best class i ever took in my whole life...highly recommended

Diego is the best teacher I've ever had!  The field methods class is a blast--you get to go out there and DO BIOLOGY.  You go camping and at the end of the year he has a BBQ at his house.  The class is small so you get to know the people and we were all genuinely sad to have the quarter end.  If you're interested in field work TAKE THIS CLASS!

Lectures were occasionally boring, but over all was a decent lecturer, and grading was fair. Projects that were due at the end of quarter were much more fun and interesting than just having everyone write a paper. Overall I liked it.

We were the guinea pig class for EEB genetics; it was amazing. He is such a sweet guy and truly cares about his students. He is open to questions and assigns homework based on lecture. Final and midterm are 10% of your grade. There is a final project, but it's presented in the discussion section. It's a different prof next quarter, but LOVE Omar!

There is no doubt that Professor Cornejo is very knowlegdable in what he teaches. He is very smart and his lectures are important to listen to because they are conceptually difficult to understand but he is so enthusiastic about the topic any and all questions are welcomed. Very caring professor, who holds us to high expectations.

Surprised no one has reviewed him for UCSC yet. Great professor, lots of energy.  Lectures are very conceptually difficult but assignments are not nearly as much so, and he is happy to clarify.  Would highly recommend. Not a super tough grader either.

Dan is super knowledgeable about the subject. He definitely knows a lot of the material. However, this is a harder class because of the amount of material you have to know. He explains how the exams are structured, but the problem is knowing all the tiny details. There's just a lot of detail and you need to know it all to do super well.

Professor Costa seems very knowledgeable about marine mammals, but this class is horrible if you're not taking this for a major requirement. When it comes to test help the T.A's are useless and won't narrow down specific study points to really focus on. Thousands of lecture slides to scan through with no study guide or any specifics to study on.
Good natured guy, I enjoyed the class.  I don't think Dan's as bad as people are making him out to be.  Tests are hard and sometimes ask you about really obscure (species specific) information.

All of the book is covered in  lecture but read the reader or you will miss test points. He goes fast through the slides but they are all online. His exams are tough and detailed - pay attention to what he talks about the most. He's super nice and helpful though so don't be afraid to talk to him after. If you're interested, take this class!

Not a good teacher...Drink coffee before coming to class otherwise his voice will put you to sleep.  I was terribly disappointed like many students.  Videos are funny but oh man watch out for his detailed exams.  They get tricky and what kind of teacher puts in false information in lecture to see if you are paying attention?

He is awful.I was so excited to take his course and was horribly disappointed.Monotone/boring lectures,came to office hours and he made me wait 40 min while he was talking to a buddy,NEVER responds to emails so I didnt get into the lab,overall negative experience.Im a marine bio major and thought this would be a great upper div boy was I wrong
Test were too long and too much detail that you needed to know. Did not seem very interested in teaching the class.

Take if you're a non-major interested in the topic or a senior in the major wanting an easy class, otherwise you'll be like me and come out a bit unfulfilled. Material is basic and lectures are online; his lectures are pretty monotone. In lab you'll learn to write decent scientific papers. Tests are hit or miss and q's a bit arbitrary at times.

Maybe it's because I'm not a marine bio major, but I really enjoyed his class. He had some pretty interesting lectures and I thought his exams were very easy and fair. I'd recommend for anyone not in EEB or Marine Bio to take him, since his class seems more for the newbie crowd than people who have majored in this.

This class was not worth it. As someone else said, I could have learned this all on my own. Costa is NOT a professor, he is a researcher.  He was hardly ever there, he did not know when his office hours were (Even at the end of the quarter), and his TA did not know a lot about the subject.  The lab was a complete waste of time.

Even though the class is listed as an "upper division," there are some 140+ students in the class and material is super basic.  Its a review of anything you ever read on marine mammals or saw on TV.  Dan can lecture without anyone there and in fact will have many guest lecturers.  I do not recommend this class to marine bio majors.

Pleasant to listen to, although lectures seemed repetitive sometimes.  Powerpoints were also a little confusing.  Dan's exams were fairly difficult, so study notes thoroughly.  Overall, the class was kind of boring but did have its high points (like conservation & acoustics).  Best for Marine Bio majors.  Lab was awesome!

I thought this teacher was very straight-foward. no hard tests, showed you what you needed to know, showed some of his work research, ppt presentatinos allowed for sound files, videos and awesome AND HELPFUL images. Very well organized. If you're interested in the material, you wont have a problem!

One of THE WORST professors I have ever had! He was incredibly unhelpful, and completely unapproachable. He was often flat wrong in his explanations in class, and showed no interest in ensuring students learned the information.

Dan's a pretty decent teacher, his main focus is on his reasearch. Lectures are powerpoint presentations. Most of the time lectures are pretty monotone.  Tests are straight-foward and factual, sometimes a bit long however.  I'd highly recommend taking it just because he's a highly respected biologist and you do learn a lot.

Very nice lady. However, this class is super overwhelming! The lecture material is very dense, and there are hours and hours of boring, difficult reading every week. I struggled through this class and strongly disliked the work. Do not recommend if you are not a plant sciences major! Good lecturer and Cares about her students-just wasn't for me.

This class is a lot of work but it is so worth it if you are interested in the subject matter. Ingrid is so passionate about her work and is a phenomenal teacher. You can get by without doing all of the reading but it is useful for quizzes. Fun class and it helped me gain a new perspective on nature.

She is very enthusiastic about the subject and her work. Exams are based on lectures. The class is a lot of work but I think it's worth it if you want to go into that field. There are hands-on assignments, textbook readings, presentations, and scientific papers to read which can be hard to keep up with but I think all of it was very valuable.

Took Bio20F & she teaches & leads with so much passion. She always includes students when exploring and truly wants to share experiences with students. She teaches in a very inclusive way & is always promoting creative thinking. She allows students to explore their learning which is my fav thing about her. She felt more like a peer than professor
Best professor I've had at UCSC. Super knowledgable and reasonable.

I took her for BIOE118 and she was a great professor. She even brought in a bunch of plants that we were learning about so it was really hands on. Tests are easy but having mandatory sections gets annoying.
Ingrid is a very caring professor, she is very knowledgeable and is always looking to help her students. This class was very helpful and she is passionate about what she teaches.
Best biology class ive taken

Ingrid is incredibly caring. Lectures are paced excellently, but contain lots of case studies. Very heavy work load that is especially challenging to manage if concurrently enrolled in 135. Fantastic professor, though. Really wants you to succeed and learn. She even manages to memorize every student's name. I would definitely recommend this class!

This was the single greatest class of my EEB experience. I took both 145 and 145L and it felt like I was actually learning how to be a biologist, not just learning biology. If you are serious about plant biology, take this class.

Great class and a great professor. She actually makes the effort to learn everyone's names. This class does come with a lot of work, quizzes, weekly papers, writing assignments, and an quarter long independent project.  Her tests are only material that she goes over during lecture and the book is only used for her quizzes.

One of the best professors I've had. Yes her class is demanding and it can be a little overwhelming, but its worth the effort. You'll get a lot of lab and field experience. Her exams are straight forward and as long as you keep up with her lectures then studying should be a breeze. The book helpful but very lengthy.

Anyone who thinks Ingrid is hard Should drop out of school. She is one of the best professors ever. If you are passionate about the subject and want more than a degree, then it should be a breeze cause all the info is fun to learn! Her tests are very reasonable and straight from lecture. No surprises. Teachers should model themselves after her.

Ingrid is a fantastic professor.  The class is demanding, but necessary if you plan on doing field work or research.  The field trips are great, and Ingrid is one the coolest professors at this school.

Parker is, very truly, a good prof. Her lecture notes are clear, and easy to copy. HOWEVER, the caveat to this class is she tells you her test is ~85% all lecture notes. this is completely false. Her lecture notes serve as a GUIDELINE to what you should read THOROUGHLY in the book. Do this and you will excel in the class.

Avoid taking this class with her if you can. She treats her students like middle schoolers and her tests/quizzes assess whether or not you went to class/did the reading, not whether you understand the information. She mostly tests on her specific examples or if you recognize a figure in the book.

Good but demanding professor. The course goes really fast and there is a lot of memorization involved. Weekly quizzes on large portions of reading, but if you keep up with everything and memorize her notes you should be fine.
Class was hard she's really loves the subject but test way too vague

Although professor is passionate about the subject, she wasn't really clear about exam topics. 8am attendance is mandatory via iclicker, no notes posted online, her exam was very specific. go to msi for help

Uses iClicker forcing you to go to class and actively listen yet she doesn't post lecture notes and is extremely vague with what she puts on the test. Avoid taking this class with her. But if you have to read  the book and you should be fine.

Mark Carr is a very passionate and caring professor. He is very knowledgable and involved in his own research efforts but he is also just as interested in teaching. This is an upper division course/DC requirement so you should expect putting in more effort. His study guides were very helpful and was willing to go over any confusion .

Its pretty evident that he cares about his line of work, but I would argue his teaching strategy is out-dated. This is evident as he refuses to provide a key for exams after having been given back. This strongly suggests that he's been using the same exam for years. Exams were nothing like his "practice exams." Its all fill in the blanks.

Carr is exceptionally knowledgeable about his research and marine ecology in general. Get ready to read and understand many scientific papers. I would say the content itself isn't hard, but the sheer amount of it is what might make the exams difficult. Just study his mock exams and go to class. Definitely doable!

Hey! he was exceptionally not supportive. If you are struggling with the material, he will talk to you only if you understand the material! He doesn't t care about his students! he was the most unsupportive professor I have ever taken! His exams are tough, and the timing is horrible. Since his exams are very long and hard, I will not recommend it!

I loved Marine Ecology with Mark! He assigns relevant papers and holds wonderful lectures. I particularly appreciated the opportunity to identify patterns ourselves. Be sure you know your stuff on exams!!

Mark is extremely kind and very helpful. His lectures were interesting and tried to make students laugh:) The only problem I had with this course as a whole is for it being a upper division course its been the worst one I have taken at UCSC. The layout was sloppy and all of us were lost, because of that I received a B-.
Wacky, knowledgeable, and really cares about students. Class was unorganized but Mark is great.

Mark Carr is a great teacher, especially in combination with Pete Raimondi.  Very easy to talk to. i like the teaching style, even if he does occasionally use powerpoint. I definately recommend taking his classes if you can
Great professor. Gives fair tests, the way tests are supposed to be written, always. Excellent reader on current literature on marine conservation.

This class may not be representative of Mark, since it's an 80-series class. Mark lectured for roughly 5 class meetings, then after that we had a different guest speaker every day. TA did most of the work. Overall learned a bit, but could have been better
Funniest prof I've had and best class I've taken. His lectures are always engaging and I highly recommend this class if you can take it!
Amazing professor who is passionate and funny! super helpful and knowledgeable and makes lectures engaging and fun! definitely one of the best at UCSC
Really cool fish guy

Fantastic professor, really is just a fish guy getting paid to talk about fish. His lectures are super interesting and he always has a funny joke or anecdote to add. I am obsessed with fish now because of him. Highly recommend.
One of the funniest prof that has taught here. He always has an interesting story or remark he adds during lectures. Majority of your grade depends on the midterm and final, so study hard for them.

Giacomo is awesome! Take this class if you want entertaining lectures and a relatively easy A. Every lecture is hilarious and he never fails to make students laugh. Pay attention to lectures and you'll be great.
I loved prof Giacomo! He made lecture fun and interesting, he always had a cool story to go along with what we were learning. Super cool guy I recommend all his classes for anybody

Lectures are excellent because they involve active participation. Evolution can be a controversial subject, but that doesn't stop Bernardi from stating what he believes. He respects the open-ended nature of science.

Pay close attention to the lectures and you'll do great on midterm and final. All his test answers are right on the slides. He sometimes quizzes you on smaller, nuanced details, but everything you need to know are in the PowerPoints. Lectures sometimes get unorganized and off-topic, but Giacomo has a wicked sense of humor that'll keep you engaged.

Humble and empathetic towards his students. Open to fun discussions and understands that perfection isn't a thing. Gives study guides and extra credit, tests were MC and expectations were clearly stated. Really funny and personable.

He is a great professor. Many professor set you up to fail but not him he sets you up to pass. I learned a lot and felt no stress. He cared if you learned and not about your grade meaning he didnt make coursework stressful and had a fun class. TAs were also great and helpful. Overall recommend.

If you're planning on taking BIOE 127, please READ THIS! Giacomo is both nice, yet strict. He won't take excuses. But his tests are SUPER easy if you go to lecture. Sadly there isn't homework (sounds like an oxymoron), so the class is graded off ONLY Lab work and exams. The lab is actually a lot of fun, not boring. The class is super interesting.

Br. Bernardi is an absolute legend! Lectures were very interesting and helped me stay awake for the 8am class. Tests were very reasonable if you take decent notes. definitely one of my favorite classes I've taken at UCSC.

Giacomo is the best! He's super passionate about the material and kind to all students. He always wants to help. He explains things very clearly, but has the occasional language barrier for which he is always sure to make up for. Everything syllabus wise is very clear and he never switches anything on you. He made the final optional during BLM.

I never knew when to pay attention because he would constantly insert anecdotes about someone famous he knows or fish. Study off the slides. He referred to human trafficking as "imported women" and I never recovered to respect him or find anything he said funny.

This professor rly is srsly passionate about evolution and fishes hah. He podcasts all his lectures, making it so convenient. He tests straight from his slides and tells you what to focus on. He has 2 SimoBios homework, pretty easy and fun. Overall he's a really funny and approachable man. I wish he taught other Upper Div science courses, take him!
Pros: Super approachable/friendly, posts all his lectures online, invested in student success, a lot of interesting stories, easy A Cons: Pretty scattered, tended to wander off subject, easy A

Giacomo was hilarious! His lectures were informative and also a comedy show! He is very knowledgeable, genuine and always willing to help. The tests are straight forward. I will miss having him as a professor. He knows every fish in the world, it's amazing. He's a fish guru.

Giacomo is legit. From his exams to his lecturing style this Italian-French stallion does it all. Not only is the guy hilarious, he genuinely cares about his students. All of his lectures are posted online with voice recordings. Every class he has announcements with useful inromfation pertaining to the class. Enjoy going to his lectures

Love, love, loved this class.  Giacomo is the best.  Only thing I didn't like was that the class, including the syllabus and skull project, was a little disorganized.  I would take this class again in a heartbeat.

Unengaging lectures, little effort was given to encourage critical thinking or participation. Midterm/final are each worth 30% of your grade. Doesn't record/upload lectures for studying purposes, only unhelpful slides. Had a loud conversation while me and a few other students were wrapping up our final exams. Inconsiderate, waste of an elective.

Super engaging lectures, he really has a way of making difficult material accessible, enjoyable, and easy to understand. All the reading feels relevant and important to greater understanding of the topics, not busywork. Exams are mostly based on application of concepts rather than memorization, but you will need to remember key concepts and figures

He is passionate and knowledgeable and good at explaining tough concepts. he requires you to read a scientific paper before every singe class so it gets overwhelming, and does participation quizzes based off those paper so if you don't get it or you aren't there when class starts you don't get a good grade. A little too serious but good content.

Eric is very intelligent and passionate about what he teaches. He has quizzes at the beginning of each lecture with counts for attendance. There is a lot of reading but he tries to keep it as relevant and interesting as possible. He is a great lecturer and doesn't mind re-explaining a topic to ensure everyone is on the same page. I would take again

Really fun class! He was really informative and super funny! All his lectures were straight forward and easy to understand. There were a lot of readings for class, but they weren't difficult and he used one out of the 3 assigned textbooks. All-in-all, great teacher.

Jarmila is not as bad as I had been warned. Her lectures can be sleep-inducing because she is pretty soft spoken and tends to stray from what's on the slides. Attendance wasn't required but lectures were not recorded so missing class does take a toll on your learning. Overall, this class was interesting and I'm excited to see it develop.

i hate this class i took bioe121, shes so sweet and nice but she lectures so low w the lights off and the structure of her course is annoying. there are not study documents all she does if give you lectures and papers and the rest is on your own. i physically dread going to class. idk how she. teaches her other courses but i cant stand this course.

definitely a dense course, but jarmila is a great lecturer who makes you want to learn the material. the midterm and final were very reasonable and comprehensive, although i do wish she had offered a few more study resources, and the lab practical was extremely difficult. she graded the group project and the one other assignment very fairly.

Jarmila seemed to be very chill a the beginning of the class but her exams were the most obnoxiously detailed exams that I've ever taken in my life and they were closed note. She was also a bit tone deaf when it came to speaking on cultures that she wasn't a part of, and did not seem to have much knowledge on the "society" aspect of the class.

Jarmila has a great spirit and cares very much about her students. This was my first upper division course and she made it fun and interactive even though it was online. This class was super interesting and her lectures were great (sometimes fast). There are a couple group projects but it was nice to have some interaction while online.

Jarmila is an amazing professor! This class is intended to be interactive and she went above and beyond when adapting to remote instruction. Interesting information on a wide variety of topics makes this class exceptionally engaging. Sections are mandatory, but have fun activities and projects. Overall, I would highly recommend this class!

Jarmila is very funny and kind. Class material is interesting and grade is distributed between assignments fairly. Content is very detailed, though. Lab itself was not particularly challenging, but the practical was nearly impossible. She is very receptive to questions and genuinely wants you to succeed. I would definitely recommend this class!

Very fair grading, iclicker counted for attendance, really interesting material, and good variety of lab/guest lecturers. This was my favorite class taken at UCSC so far. Jarmila incorporates relevant anecdotes from her experiences around the world. She made an effort to follow up on things students mentioned in a previous class.

Jarmila was a good professor. Very approachable and super enthusiastic about plants. We had to do a big research project that was worth the same points as the final. Get started on this very soon because it can really save you! You present results in a video which is hard but fun. Tests are difficult. She will ask you about very random stuff...

An awesome class!  Go's a bit fast on her powerpoint presentations, but sometimes will post the notes online after.  Just study the notes and go to class!  Very willing to help out and wants her students to do well!

Jarmila is a way better professor than a lot of these reviews make her out to be- plant pays is a great class, her lectures are organized and she has really cool papers for you to read. its clear she's working hard to become a better instructor and its totally paying off!
She has improved a lot as a professor. The class is challenging but she makes it interesting. The lab is fun and you get to take the plants home after.

She really wasn't as bad as this site makes her out to be. The class was tough, but that can't be helped given the subject material. She was more than willing to help us out and understood that the course content could be overwhelming for us. I came out of the class feeling like I actually learned a ton. Didn't really need the textbook.

I really enjoyed Dr. Pittermann's class. She was genuinely interested in our understanding of the material and made herself available a lot. The class includes a group project, midterm, final and daily quizzes. I liked lab best; they were actually really fun. I highly recommend this class. It is different than any upper div class, in a good way  :)

Extremely unorganized and has some of the worst handwriting. Lectures did nothing for me but I did fine just by reading the textbook. Final was surprisingly not very challenging but still would not recommend. The animal portion with Fowler was ridiculously better.

I read all the reviews on this page and psyched myself out for the final. Took the time to read and understand the book. It is true that the written portion did have some questions that were not usual, but it was more like a puzzle that had to be put together. Start learning material right away! It wasn't that bad.

I spent 3 weeks studying for the final since I had read reviews that her test is impossible (by doing her study guides, memorizing quizzes, taking time to understand and learn everything from her lectures). I felt extremely prepared before the exam but felt awful coming out of it.

Her final was based on info that she never taught. I spent hours working on 8 study guides she posted and I based the info off her notes, power point  and book but it was not enough. She had 3 versions of tests and I got one that had a free response that she never even mentioned about. I walked in feeling confident but I felt so defeated after.

Overall, so-so prof.  She really was not as bad as other reviewers make her out to be. Yes, she was a little scatter-brained, but she made it very clear what she expected you to know.  And she does have high expectations, but that is an admirable quality in a professor.  If she is the worst professor you have had at UCSC, then you are very lucky.

Pitterman is the worst professor I've ever had. The first day she seemed nice and funny, but really is air headed and scatterbrained. I got a 7/10 on a take home quiz where I looked up every answer. I dread going to lecture and can't read her handwriting. I have literally no interest in plants and am furious I am forced to take this class for BME.

Pete is an incredible guy. He knows an amazing amount about ecology and statistics, he is approachable and helpful, and he regularly goes out of his way to help students. He is focused on students actually learning the material he teaches and is supportive and understanding. Great professor, great person.

Pete is the homie; he is a wonderful professor! He is super caring and wants his students to learn and succeed in his courses. He is always willing to help outside of class with whatever you're struggling with. He is a god at stats; not sure how he does it. Would definitely recommend!

Pete is an awesome professor!!! Probably the best I'll ever have. Super knowledgeable and very approachable. He makes sure you actually learn and is very helpful. If I had the chance, I would 100% take his class again.
The nicest dude in the world. Cares so much about his students success and actually wants you to LEARN and doesn't try to trick you on exams and what not

He's super cool.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       Hahaha
Pete is an amazing person and professor. Nuff said.
interesting lecturer; charismatic, not boring at all, super knowledgable and helpful, posts test questions before the test; he's a statistics guru too!

Unorganized but easy to do well in. I took a couple other hard classes, so this worked as a filler even though its 7 units, but be ready to read and write. Lab is lots of work, but easy. Tests are based on lecture so its easy to get high scores if you watch and take notes in the pp. Final was not really cumulative. Quizzes are short and on graphs.

Terrie is a funny and amazing human being, but a sub par teacher. Class was disorganized, especially early on. Tests were unpredictable. Lectures weren't posted online. Group project was horrible, HORRIBLE, and involved both a long written report and a video being made. Take if you don't mind lots of diagrams and charts, and you really like physio

Awesome professor! Lots of great professors in the EEB at UCSC, but Terrie definitely stands out. Don't need the book at all for this class. Important thing is to memorize all the charts and graphs that she puts up. Only issue I had with the class was the group project at the end. It was hard to coordinate with 10-12 people, but we made it work.

Terrie is extremely condescending and egotistical. Her notes are disjointed & hard to follow. She moves quickly and her tests are the most poorly written that I've ever encountered. Asks questions about very specific tables that are pointless. In week 8, she announced that we had a 12 person group paper/video/presentation due ten days later. Awful.

BEST PROFESSOR I'VE EVER HAD!!! Terrie is amazing! She is the true definition of an amazing teacher. No tricks. No discouraging students with difficult quizzes. She made me realize that going to medical school was what I really want to do! I enjoyed studying for her class because she made it fun! And her test was extremely straight forward!

Terrie rocks my world! She is so amazing. She got hit by a car while on her bike and we had subs for a couple of weeks, but she somehow pulled off being the best teacher I've had here. Her research is awesome and she always relates it to the curriculum of the class. She's all around a great person. Definitely take a class with her.
She was an amazing teacher. She was very clear about what she wanted you to know and gave you all the information. She was defiantly one of the best biology teachers I have had. :)
always excited to go to class, very good professor!!! ^o^
Awesome Professor, fun in class and she definitely knows her stuff.

I forgot to turn in my teacher evaluation for today so I will compensate here by letting everyone know that she is likely the best bio teacher you will ever have. Lectures are interesting, she's hilarious, material is as easy as it gets for a bio class,no textbook needed, and today she gave the class candy...So yeah overall she's the best!!
She's AWESOME!!! Come to class though.

She's a pretty good teacher and you'll love her if you're in a similar field. I found her class pretty disorganized though and she raced through her lectures so fast that I was shocked to find out it was 99% of her exam. If you have just Prof. Williams for the class, don't buy the book and show up to EVERY lecture and take vigorous notes.

she is an amazing teacher, and loves teaching this class. She is really helpful in making sure you what will be on the exam. I didnt open the book once, her lectures are great, all you have to do is attend class and take notes, pretty easy
best teacher...EVER

Good teacher, no online notes, writes on the board so must attend class. Don't bother getting the book, it's a waste of money and not required. 2 quizzes, 2 midterms, 1 group project, and the final. The final was scantron.
