I thought I would hate this class, but I actually really enjoyed it--makes things clear and easy to understand and she won't try to trick you on the exams.  Don't worry if you haven't had biochem either because you don't need it.  Don't buy the book--if you show up to lecture and take notes and review them before the tests you should do fine.

Best teacher at UCSC. Fascinating material, great presentation, atmosphere. Terrie is the bomb, that's all there is to it. Now, you still have to study, but how else would the class make sense if you didn't know what she was talking about?
Terrie's great.  She really knows her stuff and is very in her lectures.  Tests are based purely on lectures, not reading material.  Plus you get to see dolphins for one of the labs.  Pretty sweet!
She kept the class interesting.  Fair grader, good tests.  20B was by far the best of the 20 series.
Taught the animal physiology half of the class. Enjoyed her powerpoint presentation lectures. Grades based on a exam and misc. assignments.

Roxanne is a good professor, I more so had a problem with the TAs. She goes through the lecture slides relatively slowly so that the content is easier to grasp which I appreciate. The class becomes difficult when all the math starts coming in and I have no idea why we needed to do coding with R-studio in our discussion sections. Hated that.

I had Beltran for 126 and it was not a good experience. The class is entirely online and is very easy to become disconnected from what should be a very engaging subject. All the lectures are pre-recorded and the TA's do everything else, mine were very stressed with how much she made them do. She does not interact. I got fed up losing random points.

I absolutely loved Prof. Beltran, this was easily one of my favorite classes Ive taken. Lectures are very content heavy, so dont save them for the last minute! She and the TAs are always available to help.

Amazing professor. Despite being an online class the professor was easy to communicate with both over email and zoom office hours. Highly recommend if you are at all interested in ocean life especially mammals which are a heavy focus!

I took professor Beltran for Biology of Large Marine Vertebrates. Though the course was really dense with information, completing the coursework never felt like a chore. Her lectures were amazingly informative, and I truly learned so much from the course. Her passion for marine animals really shines through, and I can't recommend her enough.

Erica has an inability to speak in laymen's terms.  Her recorded lectures seem to be read from a script, a very pragmatic one, devoid of plain language and dense in necessary information.  You may find that an answer to a quiz question was verbalized, rather than written down.  She assigns far more work than necessary, and with rigid criteria.

The material in this class is fine, not my thing but that's not her fault. However, the sheer quantity of work in this class is insane. This class is currently my worst grade, yet I sink more time and energy into it than all my other classes combined (21 credits). Erika herself is nice and responsive but the workload is absolutely insane.
Erika is a good professor and really cares about her students. Her lectures were good, but to do well in the class you must read the textbook and understand all of the homework.

Zavaleta makes good video content, & she presents info in a streamlined way. But the quizzes are so specific to the tiniest details, so note-taking during lectures is important. Also they pick questions from the textbook that arent in the vids, so keep that in mind. Overall a good class, but quizzes were tedious and count a lot for your grade

Fully relied on TAs to do all work. Never saw her in person, got feedback on assignments from her, didnt even make her own lecture videos. Had to pay $13 to take midterm on proctorU on a sunday night. During in person final (8am) she didnt provide the access code to the exam, didnt pick up the phone when TAs called, we started 45 min late.

The content of the lecture/field trip videos from the professor are very interesting and enjoyable to watch, but the quizzes are a bit difficult (since they ask more on details rather than the big picture.) I thought that most of the grades were fair, except one TA who didn't give back any feedback and had a very low grading average (watch out!)

Professor Zavaleta is one of the nicest professors I've had at UCSC. The professor knows her class is hard and helps out as much as she can. Quizzes and the final are all online, open note but questions are designed to trick you so really pay attention to everything you read. Stay on top of your work because there's a lot of it.

Very arbitrary and specific quiz questions. She says they are "hard" when they are just petty recall questions completely ignoring the actual topic of the unit. A specific example would be "What is the SECOND leading cause of biodiversity loss" when she didn't actually delineate the order of things attacking biodiveristy. Whole class was like this.

Unfortunately, Erika is of the ilk of UCSC professors whose main preoccupation at UCSC is research. Her ability and intent to connect with the students is virtually nonexistent. She comes off as conceited.
Dr. Zavaleta is an extraordinary and stimulating lecturer and researcher. Her background as a professional bicycle racer is merely gravy to pique a student's interest....

She was an overall effective professor, I didnt like how she had weekly guest lecturers because when it was time for the exam she expected great detail from the readings that we NEVER really discuss indpeth in class. We had journals in class but it was completely unorganized.
She is very clear. Her lectures are made in a very simple and informational way. She is understanding and teaches well.
She is a great lecturer and fun person to talk to.  The only complaint I have is that she rarely responds to emails.
She's great!  Very knowledgable and approachable.

Erika is a great speaker, and an okay lecturer. She tends to blab at points with material, and she isn't very clear on what material is important. However, she will always take questions, and she's extremely helpful if you ask for it.
Erika is very passionate about her research and biodiversity. She made lecture interesting and very informative. Very helpful during office hours. Great Professor!
No Comments

Wow! Camilla is awesome, she is a genius and is very inspirational and approachable. Taking this class has cemented my desire to go into the stem cell field. Key to get an A: go to all classes, print out the lecture notes before class and write down everything she says. Tests are very fair if you study hard. Great guest lectures too! Great class!

The queen of stem cells herself. I wish she had taught me all of my upper-div bio classes. Extremely caring and helpful individual, not to mention she is a complete genius.   BME 178 requires work, only the elite bio undergrads of UCSC take this class.  Most were involved with research, I'm sure the majority of the class got A's. No textbook.

Camilla is wonderful, and is more than willing to give thorough answers in to questions in class and in office hours. Definitely go to class, because she'll go over data for experiments that are tough to interpret without an explanation the first couple time. Super nice. Got the highest grade in the class; she e-mailed me to congratulate me.

Camilla is awesome. She posts everything online and is very approachable. This class is unlike any other biology lecture offered because your grade is NOT solely based off the midterm and final but also pop quizzes, presentations, and papers. Don't take this class if you are lazy.
The goat. I've never gotten anything but an A in all her classes. As long as you do the work you'll get a good grade.

Amazing professor and an amazing class. Super engaging lectures and labs that were well explained and easy to understand. Grading was based on weekly lab reports, in lab quizzes that she went over before we turned them in, and a small group presentation during week 10.
Amazing professor definitely advise taking this class

Dianne Hendricks is an incredible professor! I had her for 4 quarters in the BME185 technical writing and lab series, . She's super knowledgeable, organized, and approachable, and she genuinely cares about her students' growth. Her feedback was always constructive, I became prepared for the Labs. highly recommend taking her class

Great class, lots of fun labs. You do a small presentation at the end of the quarter and it's a good deal of fun. Also very reasonable with extensions and really wants you to understand and get good at conducting experiments!
I like the teaching style

Russ is such a chill guy and he gives amazing lectures. Gave pretty easy homework assignments where the use of AI was encouraged. He's a busy guy and isn't always available but is super understanding. No exams in this class, just weekly homework and a final project proposal/presentation.
Best professor at UCSC.
Russ is the bomb. No, really. Like an actual real bomb. Just kidding. He's ok. Actually, if I had to pick three phrases to describe Russ, they would be "inspirational", "extra credit" and "caring"
Russ is so clear and teaches at such an approachable level. He will make sure to say everything that is important a bunch of times so it's really easy to figure out what the key ideas are.

Russ is super approachable, funny, caring, down to earth (and cute). Office hours are great to get help in the class and career/grad school advice. Class wasn't too bad, open note exams, in class participation quizzes and he gave many opportunities to get points back. Definitely need to take it seriously and put in effort if you want that A tho!
Russ is super awesome. He may lecture a bit fast but he is always available at his office hours and really does care that his students understand the material. Definitely take a class with him!
Bioninformatics is not my primary field but I was able to keep up and I learned a ton. Russ is super helpful in office hours and really wants his students to do well.
Russ is freaking awesome.

Russ is great. Russ definitely cares about his students and is very approachable outside of class. He is certainly willing to listen to students to students concerns, and any recommendations on how to improve the course. If you are weary in taking BIOL 110 dont be, Russ will help you succeed. One of the best professors at UCSC!

Russ really cares about his students learning the materials. He is patient and funny. Exams are taken on laptops and are open notes. Make sure you understand the concepts behind each practical problem and you will love this class!
Russ is the man. Cares about students actually learning material. He's a brilliant guy and an excellent teacher. Take any class with him if you can.

Russ is super down to earth and cares about his students. Exams were open note but you needed to have a good understanding of the material to finish. Exams were very similar to quizzes and problem sets. Daily attendance quizzes and attendance taken in section, but it was an enjoyable class overall.

Tal is very approachable and patient. Half of the class time was lecture. The other half was spent working with your group on that week's project. The syllabus emphasized fundamentals in the context of genomics and neuroscience applications. Suggestions for improvement would be to provide more structured goals for the group work during class.

Tal is a great professor. He teaches really well. If you go up and ask him questions and inquires he give nice succient answers. I think his assignments were really fair with adequate resources and time to finish. His grading policy is also quiet resonable. The extra quizzes was not useful but the last assignment with analyzing neural data was cool

Never taught or lectured.  He used the same outdated notes from 10 yrs ago that weren't even his and the one time he used his own notes it was CODE DRAWN FREE HANDED & looked like childs writing. I did not learn anything because nothing was taught. If he is teaching, dont take the class.

Tal is passionate about the content of the course but does an incredibly poor job of teaching it. For a programming course that's 6 credits with no python prerequisite, I expected him to go over the basics of python and teach how to execute in class. He glazes over questions you have and redirects them towards your group.

He is a pretty nice chill dude. He isn't a very engaging lecturer, but the lectures or class attendance doesn't really matter for success in the class. Prior coding experience can make this class a breeze or very hard. No tests. small weekly assignments (fairly easy), 6 labs, and a final group project.

Todd is super passionate about the material and can always spare a minute to help on homework or classwork. Deadlines are usually flexible and Todd does a great job to ensure people truly understand the material. I love Todd. Only critique is lectures can be a little long and boring though so be sure to drink a coffee beforehand.
Took in Fall 2021. He's really passionate about the material but I feel like the lectures could've been more interactive. We had our midterm canceled twice with short notice (

Todd is a great guy. The material is not incredibly difficult to do, he does everything with you. He's bad about deadlines but he curves literally everything so good and bad. Seriously just wants you to learn the material, always incredibly open to discussing grades

Rambles a LOT in class. Terrible with deadlines. Posted first homework assignment 2 weeks after he said he would. Assigned HW assignments due right before the midterm and the final exam. Never received feedback on the homework assignments. 2 days past final grade deadline and the grades are STILL not up!

Tough to understand everything he lectures on, midterm and final are difficult. He is TERRIBLE with deadlines, and was late on posting almost every homework assignment, took FOREVER to grade work, and didnt even post the final course grade til 3 days after they were due. Awful Organizational skills, not great as a lecturer, difficult final
This class is pretty easy if you remember some basic stuff he explains in class. He curve a lot too and participation really counts so go to sections!

Homework took forever unless you went to office hours and really uninformative. He was VERY irresponsible where he can go on trips to go gather microbes to sequence and leave you in the dust. Guest lectures weren't all that great; was too informative which don't all get tested on. Final was extremely unreasonable and unjust. It took 3 and 1/2 hours

I took BME 110 or BIO 181 with Todd Lowe. The course is an extremely helpful course for all Biologist since Bioinformatics is the future. He is very knowledgeable and helpful during the class. It was a fun course. Be prepared for a difficult final.

Professor Bernick is my favorite professor so far at UCSC. Lectures are very informal and he's a super funny guy. He assigns a lab each week with some videos to watch and some codelab assignments to do. Everything is pretty easy until you get to lab 5. The workload can be a lot of you don't start early. You need python experience for this class!

Dr. Bernick is an amazing professor.  He shows his past experience and knowledge in every class and really cares for every student in the class.  The class is only graded on the midterm deliverables and the final essay and he's said he's very binary on how he grades things.  Highly recommend this class if you can take it with Dr. Bernick.

One of the hardest classes, but also the most informative and fun class too. This class is unique in that in your final project, you create a program to help a research lab on campus. The class is doable with little/no coding experience, but you have to commit more than 6 units worth of time. His OH is useful and responds fast to email.
Awesome professor, highly respected and caring. Understands that students have life outside of school but is still highly demanding.

Dr. Bernick is a great guy and an amazing Professor. Super friendly and helpful in office hours and in lecture. That being said, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU HAVE ZERO CODING EXPERIENCE. The class is shown as an intro class but as a python virgin I got absolutely bent over by this class. TAs help you finish labs though and all grade is group work.

Bernick is a cool and passionate guy, and his lectures are highly effective. The course had a lot of reading, which wasn't very exciting, but Bernick taught valuable scientific lessons through every week's assignment and discussion. He accommodates for students outside of the usual majors he teaches, and truly wants his students to learn.

Professor Bernick is an awesome professor, watch his videos and go to class. Do the work and rely on your group to help you out! Reach out to him for help with anything in the bioinformatics major, he knows a lot and always wants to help out!

He's great, explains concepts really well and is always willing to help, especially with the final project. The class is really easy if you've taken CSE 20, but if you haven't, that's fine since 160 starts from the basics. The final project is pretty fun but please ask him about any problems you face/doubts you have as soon as possible!

I felt that professor Bernick truly wanted students to succeed in this class. He was easy to talk to and made himself and TAs readily accessible for questions regarding code. He pushed back deadlines a bit whenever it appeared that students were having trouble keeping up with them and he frequently checked in with students during class.

If you haven't done python b4 this will be doable but very difficult. I stress very. 6 lab assignments, increasing difficulty. Labs 70%, quizzes 20%, final project 10% (group). Prepare for final project EARLY. Lab sections are very helpful, always go, extensions for labs are given. TAs are awesome, go to OH. Overall, best class I've had. Ever.

Be ready to discuss lots of scientific papers, but he won't be upset if you don't understand something, he's happy to clarify. There's mandatory textbook readings, but we only read from it 3 times. The final paper determines most of your grade, and he doesn't give a ton of instruction, so be sure to ask for clarification on what he's looking for.
Dr. B was helpful, passionate, and informative about all topics, and was an absolute gem of a teacher. Loved him!

A talented instructor and a great human being. He does try to coach as much work as he can, but not more out of his students. His assignments are carefully crafted/curated to be as useful as possible to students. When looking around the room, I see every student fully engaged. The TA has been excellent, and I'd expect more of the same.

A hard class no doubt  If you don't have any programming experience ask for help as soon as possible One of the TA's was a harsh grader for a class with no program experience required Quizzes every week that can be tricky Doable to get an A but requires a lot of work and time if you're not the best with Python

He is amazing. As a professor and as a person. He helps students in any way he can. He has great influence on me and my favourite professor at UCSC. I would take any class he takes, he is just amazing.  Btw, the class is hard for non-prepared students, be sure you know what you are doing before taking this class.

BME205 is a super solid class for BME grads and BIOINF undergrads. The programming assignments were inspiring and just difficult enough to be satisfying to finish. The grading for the course was weird in that if the program didnt work 100%, you got a 0 and had to resubmit. After it worked 100% then the grader would go in and actually assess code.

David Bernick is by far my favorite teacher at UCSC and BME 205 is definitely the hardest class I have ever taken in my life. David is one of the smartest and most caring teachers, but despite that be prepared to work non stop in this class and expect to get many zeroes before finally re-submitting a gradeable program. I learned so much.

Talk with David, he's an inspiration for me and many of my peers; a brilliant lecturer and amazing teaching (OH are a must).  160 makes you a bioinformatician: it was challenging.  Show up to class and he will give you answers. Not everything said in class is on the slides! - that is key, the help he gives in class is worthy of your time.

Dr. Bernick is a really passionate guy with a deep background in virology. Each lecture was hugely enriching. I loved seeing his perspective on science and nature. His positivity and energy made the class a lot of fun. Thanks Dr. Bernick!

Amazing professor. Very helpful, loves the area of study and wants to see his students succeed. He is always open to questions and readily admits when he does not know the answer. The class was amazing, there are not many classes where one can discover an entirely new species of virus as a freshman. Probably  the best class I have taken this year.
Great lecturerspeaker. Inspirational.

I lost respect for this professor when he consistently showed up for class 15-30 minutes late.  If you're teaching the class and your office is right across the hall, you have no excuse for being that late to EVERY CLASS.

I took this class Winter 05' (Beginning Pearl for Bio majors).  Although there weren't many students in this class, it was much easier to get one-one help.  His lecture notes help with homeworks.  He even does a walk-through for more difficult programs (especially with the program for the final).  Josh is very approachable.  Quizes=extra credit.

While she comes off as nice initially, she expects a graduate level of understanding from her undergraduate students and instead of giving feedback she often just tells students to try harder without offering any help. Very condescending and frustrating to work with.

Lectures are scattered: she reads verbatim off badly organized slides, and can't answer most questions from students. All assignments build up to to the final protein engineering design project, and there's little support. She gives unclear expectations, and poor feedback. Exams focus on weird small details, instead of big picture concepts.

worst professor ever, do not listen to these other reviews that is when he was teaching online. he made the tests unbelievable hard and he super wishy washy about the grading and how he wants things. he was not understanding and was very unreliable for emails or any help and expected you to know a lot more than you do. do not take him unless needed
Disregard the other two reviews. Best professor hands down. Caring, passionate, and all in all teaches some of the best courses at UCSC.

Best and most difficult class I've taken at UCSC. Read material prior to class and spend lecture listening if possible. Lectures are dense and often hard to comprehend at first. Put in hours to study and you'll do fine. Curve is generous and Ed is more than willing to discuss concepts. He does a great job at provoking curiosity about the material.

I got an A, but it's a sink or swim course. Dr. Green enforces very clear, harsh policies. The content is based almost completely off lectures, so pay attention in class. If you do not understand the lecture go to your classmates, Dr. Green is hardly available and the TA was of no use. Paper reading heavy at times and tests are difficult and wordy.

David Haussler only lectures twice in this class. He is a great guy but kind of odd. Very, very knowledgeable. This class consists of weekly assignments where AI is encouraged. There are no exams but you must design and present a final project.

Haussler is clearly incredibly into his work and what he is teaching, it is so cool to be taught by somebody with lots of hands on experience and his guest lecturers are also super interesting. All of his tests are open note and open internet, but you have to go to lecturers to answer the Question of the Day for credit.

After having mediocre profs for my first 2 years, Haussler has motivated me to keep pursuing science. He is inspiring and brilliant. If you are interested in scientific theory and the unknown he is your guy. Perfect amount of quirkiness and professionalism. I would love for him to teach all my classes.

One of the most intelligent professors at this school. Lots of assignments to cushion your grade if you don't do well on midterms. Has great TAs and the lecture material is interesting. Lots of reading, but graded homework isn't bad. Highly recommend

I LOVED David's scientific principles of life class. His teaching skills are very engaging and he truly made an already-interesting class even more intriguing. There was a lot of reading but I mostly enjoyed it because it was so good. David managed to make every single lecture absolutely mind-blowing and I feel lucky to have sat in his classroom.

Haussler is easily one of the smartest profs on campus, that being said, he has lost touch with the intellectual level of most undergrads. This class is meant to be a GE and is taught as though it is an upper-div class. Lots of guest lectures where the material is incredibly complex and not easily explained to us. Not worth it

Took him for scientific principles of life. Labs are not graded fairly, professor talks about theories many times disproven by actual science, lectures are more of a joke than an actual discussion, and this class is not an easy A. Do not take this for SI req.
If you get a chance to take a his class you should. he is beyond brilliant.

This class was fun! It was kind of all over the place but Dr. Haussler is a brilliant guy and the guest lecturers were amazing. There is no textbook but there is a lot of assigned reading. The quizzes and final were open book open note. If you are a strong reader and/or have a good science background this should be a fun and easy class for you!

His lectures are informative and engaging. He can teach.    But beware he is a theorist, and not a programmer.  You can't go to him for help with programing questions because he won't know the answer.  Grading can be difficult if you don't take tests well.  Blow one test, and you'll blow your grade.
Excellent professor, well respected and will give help to individual students.  Try to work in his lab if you can.

one midterm, all mult choice and super easy. no final test, but two papers that were also easy and fun. the lectures were so interesting and there were weekly guest speakers. one of the most interesting and thought provoking classes ive taken. i took for my major but would be an easy and useful ge. shes super understanding, caring and kind
She's the best. I loved this class setup and the grading criteria. 2 essays, 1 midterm, and attendance quizzes, super easy. Very interesting class as well with guest lecturers ever week.

Professor Miga is such a sweet and amazing professor. You will have 3 lectures a week. Two of them are presentations by Miga which will be followed by short simple quizzes to record attendance. One of your weekly lectures is a lecture from a guest speaker which are super cool. You will write 1 simple paper on a bioethics issue. Chill class overall.
difficult prof and course
really unorganized - super nice lady but heavy exams

Was the first time she and annother professor co-taught the class. She absolutely would not take any feedback regarding test material and outright refused to give us any practice problems. There were 5 exams total and accounted for 70% of the grade. Nothing gets graded on time or properlyThe material is so interesting but the structure was so awful

Provided with a headstart if you know terminal commands and have general UNIX knowledge. Had Brooks for Genetics prior to this course and she remains a great prof. Attendance is not required but can help your grade in borderline cases. Fair grader and good at lecturing. Would recommend!

Brooks is super nice and helpful. The class requires a lot of critical thinking and out of the box computer problem solving, and general Unix knowledge is a must. Tests were open-internet so it's all down to how well you understand the concepts. She's also great for help finding research opportunities.

Good and knowledgable professor but if you don't really care for biotech, not super interesting. This class is just BIO 20A with some added history lessons. Interesting stuff sometimes. One research paper, one midterm and one final where the study guides tell you everything that'll be on the exam

Spends a lot of lecture going off topic, and content is surprisingly hard and dense for an intro class. Smart and not a bad guy, but is only here for research...his Fall 2022 online final was extremely scuffed. Homework is just weekly readings and is pretty short. I still see plasmids scrawled on the board in my sleep.
He's not the best at explaining. But he weighs the grade book pretty nicely.

**BME 5

Naders lectures were confusing because he covered a lot of specific content without making clear the overarching topic. 

He does give out a good study guide and early in the quarter which is helpful. You just have to teach yourself a fair amount of the content if his teaching style doesn't click with you.

HW every week on summarizing an article. Grant proposal was our midterm. A group design project is presented at the end. Final exam was simple and he told us what the level of detail is required. Not a bad class if you want to just learn about sequencing techniques.

Very knowledgeable and smart, but spent a lot of lecture off topic talking about various biotech companies and his work at Standford.  Weekly homework involved reading a paper and writing a short summary, manageable. Group presentation at the end on biotech topic of your choice not too hard.
Nader is a good teacher, he has a stanford teaching style, which he believes you will get out of the class what you put in.

Vollmers is the funniest BMEB Professor I've met. He's super caring and chill. You will have weekly programs to do but he lowkey gives the whole code during his lectures. The assignments are not difficult and the TAs are a great help. Super chill class!

Very funny and engaging. Does live code demos in class and is very clear with the content. It's a really fun class and you're given a lot of creative freedom with how you approach assignments. He also provides a lot of starter code so that helps.

Vollmers taught efficiently and drew out a lot of diagrams to give us more visual understandings of topics. I took his course with some previous biology experience which definitely made it easier, but I felt that the general difficulty was reasonable. He didn't assign very much homework, and the tests only had stuff that we learned about in class.

Professor Vollmers is by far the best professor I've ever had for an upperdiv. He is so understanding of how online school is difficult for students. He is always available and cares so much about his students. He is doing everything possible to make his class fair for the students. His exams have matched the lecture material . Would recommend him

Prof. Vollmers was very flexible and understanding of everything being suddenly online. He made his lectures available on YouTube and webcast. He encouraged, but did not require participation on in-class activities. Homework and activities directly correlated with my understanding of test material, and weren't burdensome.

This class was super easy. Vollmer's midterms and finals were just stating obvious facts that should've been learned from previous biology classes. The lectures were really good, and some of the clicker questions made you actually think. If you have a bit of common sense, you can easily pass the class without any effort.

Vollmers is a good professor but the way that he asks questions are not that specific. His midterms are fair but his finals are hard. He's super picky about the way that you answers questions and goes over things that aren't even necessary.

Great professor. Will always be there if you need help and always eager to teach students. Very understanding and takes student feedback very seriously. Listen to the lectures and do the activities, and the class will be a breeze.

Grade based on lecture, activity, and section attendance and then 3 midterms and 1 final. Very picky with answers, but gives really clear grading rubric. Exams based on activities done in class and the answers are gone over in section. Very funny, sadly it is usually an 8am class.

Chris is very approachable and he teaches alot through real world examples. His tests aren't just reiterating definitions, he wants to ensure that you are actually learning the subject. The course material is pretty straight forward. Uses iclickers but you only need to click in once during lecture to get full credit and can miss 8 classes i think.
Be ready to learn fast in this class. It will be confusing at first, but everything will make sense by the end.
Chris was funny and a pretty good teacher.

I definitely recommend him for bio 101. Don't miss out! 2 of the exams are take home which is extremely rare in any biology course. Material can be difficult sometimes but office hours and section are helpful.  Half of the lectures are "activities" which is when students do practice problems that are similar to what will be seen on exams.

Difficult class. He posts PowerPoint "lecture notes" with only the title heading and no text. Had multiple take home exams, but sometimes tests students on material not taught in class. "Google it" were his words exactly. Very nitpicky when it comes to grading exams.

Glenn was amazing. Brings his birds to class. Weekly tests, but it's literally just short answer, T/F. During the lecture of the day he gives you all the answers. Attendance is mandatory... but why take this class if you don't want to hear about the conservation. There's a reader, very interesting, but can definitely pass without reading.

rly great 2 unit class. prof is so cool brought in his falcon + fed her/showed how she hunts. only met once a week and there is a quiz for each lecture, mostly true/false 10 q's w lots of EC q's. super easy all q's directly tied to lecture+reading. also 1 final paper in blue book.

awesome professor. easy final. easy a. learn about a really cool topic that this professor was in charge of. learn about ucsc history and get a glimpse on how a recovery project might run. super understanding-- let me take my final online because of covid scare. easy 10 (or 11) question quiz with extra credit opportunity, super easy to end with a+.

Professor Stewart is awesome! He is very inspirational and his Peregrine Falcon class is amazing. He brings his falcon in every once in a while and has fun lectures. The class is based on an essay final (40%) and small, easy, in-class canvas quizzes (60%) that have extra credit opportunities. Just pay attention in class and you will do great!

Super easy if you pay attention in class and to the reading. Really interesting course focusing on the conservation and characteristics of Peregrine falcons. Fun class to take out of interest plus good independent study opportunities
He was really nice, had cool things to say, showed us interesting videos that were relevant to the course, and tried to get everybody interested and involved in what was happening in class.
Awesome teacher, either likes you or doesn't. Speak up and get to class on time
good teacher, really relaxed. but doesnt give you a grade for papers.

Ms. Klusmeier was very positive in all of the discussions, and provided intriguing commentary during said discussions. Grading criteria was not that clear, but I never attended the office hours, so that could be a contributing factor.

I LOVE CATHRYN!! She is so amazing and made class such a safe space for all of us to connect and talk about life. All her assignments were focused on uplifting the students and going to her class was always a great way to start my day. Reading is important for discussions however, reading is helpful and interesting

Cathryn is one of the most incredible and caring professors I've had in my time here at Santa Cruz. The class was constructed around our concerns about school, which we had given her on the first day. I am the type of person who skips a lot of class, and when I don't I mindlessly scroll on my laptop, but I was genuinely so excited that I didn't

this diva is my fav teacher I have ever had. had her for crsn 1, she was so passionate & knowledgeable I genuinely feel like she has never been wrong once in her life. she's so caring & very clearly wants her students to succeed! we just had assigned readings & two papers & 2 smaller writing assignments, she gave really helpful & detailed feedback.
She is an amazing professor who deeply cares about students. Reading for this class is not difficult, and there are few assignments. I definitely recommend it!

Good person overall, she was caring and understanding. However, I didn't appreciate how she didn't grade our assignments herself, instead made the students anonymously grade one another??? A lot of reading and writing yes but that's just the curriculum for JRL core class, I guess.

Very nice as a person, did not get the sense that this class (JRLC 1) was of much personal interest to her. 
It's a fine class, she's a fine teacher—its just a bit dull.

I had her for core class for John R. Lewis and she made us do a lot of work and was very extra and specific with our grading. Would not recommend to choose her for core class especially as you have to pay for a $25 grading course. She makes us write weekly essays that she doesn't even grade herself so your grade is completely reliant on your peers.
she make sus write a lot on peerceptive which also costs $25

Wouldn't suggest taking CMMU20 as a GE unless you REALLY believe you'll be interested in the topic. Found it to be way too much work and Prof. Goodman has incredibly high expectations. The only reason I enjoyed this class was because of the TA. Just too much work and she uses Peerceptive so you don't really get any feedback on most assignments.

Worst class I've ever taken. Please save your time and money. This class has only taught me nothing but stress. You have a lot of quizzes, and the papers and writings are graded super rough. The most boring class I've ever taken, and this class literally feels like it's a 7+ unit course. Please save your time and money.

I would not take this class again if I could help it, too much reading and workload, the teacher and TA were nice but I found it too boring and unhelpful. And you won't understand what her point change mechanism and requirements are.
Its ok Ig I passed that class the TA was great

Ms. Goodman is very kind but gave reading quizzes every Thursday for about most of the quarter. However, the quizzes are easy and online, I passed them without having ever read any of the material lol. There is a decent amount of work but nothing unmanageable. Her plenary assignments were simple and shorter than the ones other JRL professors gave.
super boring class. lots of work and terrible readings. dont take

She seemed like a nice person, however, she was not a great teacher. Class is mostly used for discussions on the readings or something else on her mind (which may not always be relevant). She does not provide trigger warnings and often deflects sensitive student answers with short avoidant responses.

Goodman is kind but very disorganized. MCQ quizzes have incomplete answers, she changes due dates last second, and forgets to unlock pdfs for the readings. Readings are also super long and not always relevant to quiz/discussion material. Assigns reading responses, Canvas discussions, and reading quizzes every week. Uses Peerceptiv for assignments.

Super kind & understanding professor
Reasonable grading standards in writing assignments

Has weekly quizzes in class based on hw readings; ask about *very* specific details
Readings are somewhat unreasonably long

Be ready by learning test-taking/guessing strategies (quizzes are multiple choice) & by learning patterns in her correct quiz answers

Although she is very kind, her teaching itself is some of the worst. Expected to learn over way too much assigned reading in weekly periods however in class they are never referred to and class is for her to go on unimportant tangents that do not relate. Why are we paying for peerceptiv to do work for her! I need canvas to know when stuff is due!!

For a class directed towards social justice and fighting to create a better world without discrimination I was surprised when Rachel Goodman openly and frequently discriminated against religion always making snarky comments and shaming religious groups as a whole based off stereotypes. It was very hypocritical and made me feel ashamed to share.

She wants you to trauma dump all the time. Class is used as a discussion not really talking about what we read but more so our opinion on subjects. She doesn't go over assignments in class which creates confusion and won't mention assignments that are upcoming. Students grade each other and based on what they have given us, is our final grade.
Don't take. Unclear grading criteria, incredibly biased teaching in terms of personal views, and forces students to appear to events outside of class for grades.
Don't take. Is infamous for assigning lots of work and reading for an irrelevant class.
Professor Goodman is kind, but her class was stressful as she would change the reading the night before it was due, or not link the homework assignments, resulting in a very frustrating experience

Rachel was a good professor, however her class had the most homework out of all the JRLC classes. Weekly reading quizzes, having to create a presentation on one of the readings, and multiple reading responses a week. Grading wasn't finished until after the class was over, and she does not round up.

Tamara is a poor educator. I was not her student directly, but she visited and took over my class multiple times. She literally told my entire class that we should give up on all of the work we had been doing for the past 10 weeks, and then made us use our class time to do physical labor on the farm for her own, unrelated personal project.

This class was a mess. I was hoping to get hands-on experience in something since undergrad research opportunities are hard to come by, but our field trips were clearly mostly for her as she would keep interrupting students and ask unnecessary questions. Maya was great but clearly at capacity and helping students was not a priority in this class.

Tamara does care about her students and providing them w/ opportunities. But her class was very unorganized, often seemed pointless, and she would speak for 10-20+ minutes after class had ended. The idea of the class is cool, but it needs to be delivered much differently/more succinctly. Her quizzes were confusing and graded harshly. Too much work.

She is so confusing. The class was poorly structured and she would assign homework that seemed random and did not specify what she was looking for when grading. She is super disorganized and I never knew what was going on in the class. Would not recomend
Vague and confusing grading, vague and confusing structure. Very poorly managed. She honestly shouldn't be teaching a class if she can't handle managing it.

Great lectures that are clear and direct. Reinforces complex ideas in an easy manner. The homework is fine, just long, and typing in the answers on Webassign is a pain in the ass. I don't like chem, and I still don't. Had to take one course due to my major. If you have to do one chem course, I suggest this class.

I took this class remotely, and it was a very pleasant experience. All of the test questions were reasonable, and WebAssign was very easy to use once you get the hang of it. Millhauser was very responsive to any attempt of communication, whether that be through e-mail, office hours, or canvas. I found the lectures to be unnecessary.

This class is definitely a rough one to take remotely, but Prof Millhauser did an amazing job. Him and his TAs were by far the most helpful of all my courses. Lectures were engaging, and the exams accurately reflected the homework assignments.

I took this course online during COVID-19. The lectures were online from 2018 but were really informational and questions he goes over relate directly to exams. Prof and TAs are great at responding in section and outside of class. Would totally recommend, especially for office hours. Final was also made optional and could only improve our grade.

Took his class during rona season and it was really good. Exams were fair and straightforward, no curveballs. If you understand the homework and lectures, you'll do fine. You can tell he's passionate about chem from his lectures. He made the final optional and shows that he cares about his students.
He was great! Very understanding and really cares if you pass or fail. Gives great real-life examples in lecture. As long as you go to lecture you will pass.
I love Glen he was great teacher. He is very kind and does care if you pass or fail. If you go to your discussions sessions and the review sessions you'll be fine.
Amazing and detailed lectures. Shows examples during class to give you a better understanding of what he's teaching. Two midterms and one final. WebAssign homework due every Friday night (11:59 PM).

good teacher, funny guy. He seems super anal retentive at first but he just respects learning and wld like respect back. Taught what was in 1A a little too so you could take 1B first.... His tests made sense too!

He tries to be much more engaging with this class, and he brought in things like models and had demonstrations. As for the exams, I thought they were quite straightforward, and pretty fair. Even though I didn't study for this class at all, I still did decent. Pay attention in class and put the formulas in your cheat sheet, and you will do fine.

I found the class hard, even after going to MSI I still felt confused. He sometimes asked questions that we never encountered on his tests. Lecture is mandatory since he doesn't post notes. Also, his notes weren't that great tbh

Glenn's lectures aren't bland at all because of his jokes. He's just a funny guy. This class was pretty easy. The second midterm on orbitals was a bit harder than the final. Study the practice sheets, they were previous midterms, although there were a couple of questions that weren't exactly the same as the practice. GT CLASS. U WILL FALL BEHIND.

Professor Millhauser is quite strict. He's very serious and professional about his subject, and he expects his students to be too. That being said, the material he teaches is clear and the homework and practice tests exactly replicate what will be on the exams.

Overall a good professors. He shows passion for teaching and his lectures are decent. The only problem is that he possess a god complex. He wastes so much time complaining about how students leave 5 mins early or how he wont curve .2% because it's "unethical" when in reality he is one of the only science teachers to not curve. GO TO MSI TO PASS!!!!

Make sure you go to class, he doesn't post his lectures on webcast and all the major topics are covered on his midterms. He doesn't curve tests, or overall grades at the end of the quarter so you actually need to do well in the class to pass. Super cool guy, is super fair on his tests and studying material.

With some topics he's really clear & easy to understand, but with others he would just kind of skim & then expect us to know how to do it. He does not curve at all, his tests aren't impossible but you definitely need to study even though you get a cheat sheet. He calls people out who come in late or leave early and will waste class time to do it
My favorite chem professor so far!! He always had a super positive attitude in class and is great at explaining things. He's not a super easy teacher but he's a great one!

If you go to class and keep up with reading the book you'll have no problem with the class. Best part is before the midterm and final exam he has review sessions by his TA's and go through the entire practice exam with you. Glenn M. will explain things but there are topics where he will fly by and will be material you'll have to learn on your own.

Glenn is thoughtful, intelligent and a great lecturer.  He is very helpful and fun in office hours.  Get to know him.  He does not post notes online so go to every lecture.  Favorite chem professor at UCSC!

Professor Millhauser is great at simplifying complex concepts! He gives us plenty of examples relevant to biology, environmental science and current events. Chem 1B is a fun class, but you need to actively read the textbook if you want to understand the material. Tests are similar to the hw and practice, so understand the problems!

Professor Eroy- Reveles is a good professor  but sometimes lecture she be ranting and explains too much that makes lecture confusing. There were 2 midterms and a final which she had practice exams for us but the answer keys were always wrong or confusing. I also dont like how there werent any posted annotated notes it makes learning hard.

She over-explains easy things which sometimes makes it hard to understand what she's saying if you haven't taken chemistry before. The harder things are skipped over or mentioned at the end of class. Content of class is overall really not that bad, the teaching style was what made it harder. Lectures are mandatory yet diabolically unhelpful.

Often got sidetracked during lectures which made them kind of hard to follow and unhelpful. Attendance is taken through iClicker. All of the homework is on Aleks. Definitely do the Aleks because it can be more helpful than the lectures at times. Overall this class isn't bad and there are a lot of opportunities and resources to do well.

Prof. Alegra is very kind but her lectures were not very useful because she spent too much time on the easy stuff and not enough time on the harder concepts. Takes attendance in lecture through iClicker. Lots of opportunities for improvement (2nd midterm grade replaces 1st midterm). DO THE ALEKS HW!! It helps you understand concepts along the way.

class was co-taught by prof. reveles and prof. johnston. alegra is extremely nice and cares a lot about your success but her lectures are a little all over the place at times. aleks does not line up with the lectures whatsoever. if you do good on the placement test at the beginning you'll have like no homework so actually try on that!!

The usage of Aleks was very hopeful however the second midterm is worth more than the first so if you do poorly it will significantly bring your grade down. I personally did not like that she used Iclicker. Lecture is sometimes unhelpful sometimes it is. I would recommend taking this class again but be prepared to self teach.
Not a great lecturer, mainly learn from TA's. Lectures are lengthy, unhelpful, and mandatory, course requires a lot of materials to be purchased.

She can be a little fast and come off unintentionally condescending, but she means well. Her class is structured around Aleks homework software and iClicker for attendance. Lectures can help, but spamming Aleks review is how you pass the tests. Improved test grades replace the previous test that you did worse on. Overall, a fairly forgiving class.

Good lecturer. Can over-explain easy topics, but this honestly helps for understanding more complex topics. If your test scores improve, they'll replace old tests. Easy tests, generally similar to practice tests. Study guides provided. Uses aleks, which is annoying but not too bad. Takes attendance every lecture, good to attend anyway. She's great!

I really liked this class and Professor Reveles is very sweet and encouraging. Although if you haven't taken AP or honors chem (like me because it wasn't offered at my hs) you will have a harder time in this class. We have good resources like LSS but I wasn't satisfied with my experience at office hours, I felt like my questions were rushed through

I liked Alegra and her teaching. ALEKS was a very helpful tool, but you have to stay on top of it. If you have never taken a Chemistry course, 3A may be tougher for you, and she doesn't lie about that, but there are numerous tools to help. Overall, very manageable to get an A as long as you study and go to office hours/study sessions.

A lot of the class is completing ALEKs. There were 2 midterms which ALEKs/lecture prepares you for for the most part. The final was more difficult but not unreasonable. They post a practice exam with answers before each test which is very similar to the real thing. Not a fan of iClicker, but it helps them get a feel for the class's understanding.

Overall not too difficult of a course. I had prior chem experience which made it more like review. Alegra was a good professor and really provided us with all resources we needed to succeed. ALEKS homework can be brutal and pile up if you fall behind. The final was probably the hardest test we took. Midterms were light and final was lwk brutal.

Alegra is caring but the work assigned isn't lined up with what she teaches in lecture sometimes. She's definitely tough but for good reason and if you slack off just a little, you'll fall a week behind.

Good teacher and she's very understanding that chemistry can be a difficult subject and students are at different levels. Classes are very interactive as students need to answer questions to get participation points, but she goes over many different types of questions during the lecture, so it is possible to feel very well prepared.

You get the grade equal to the work you put in. She is ALWAYS willing to help outside of class with tons of office hours that aren't by appointment so you just have to go and be willing to ask for help. She does have a condescending tone but I think thats just how she talks, she is super understanding and helpful outside of that.

The teacher is okay. Her teaching style has a weird pace, so either we sit around doing nothing, or we scramble to finish the lecture in the last 5 minutes of class. Sometimes she gets upset at us when we don't know the answers. But she is easy to understand and gives good advice.

Great chemistry teacher. Light homework load for Chem 1A. Lectures are easy to follow and she provides good resources to help you prepare for tests. The tests are straightforward and easy if you study. The discussion sections after the test also go over the answers to help you learn.

Gives out practice midterms and solves problems with you. TA's always in the classroom to help and study sessions that she will also attend! Relies on test scores but she'll drop the lowest ones. Passionate professor. But be prepared to rely on ALEKS

Basically everything I learned from this class was from the online homework. In lecture, she didn't explain things, she just repeated the questions and talked in circles. I am currently fearing for my sanity because participation is required and I don't understand why if lecture doesn't teach me anything.

Sam is a great chemistry professor. His lectures are super helpful since the practice problems he includes are VERY similar to the problems in the homeworks and exams. If by chance his course is available, I highly recommend talking him. Plus both exams were take home exams!!
Great professor, tries her best to explain things. Kinda hard tests though and hard class but still recommend!

My final grade was screwed up as a result of an issue that was not my fault. Professor refused to fix my grade (should've ended with an A-). Her emails were incredibly dismissive, before she stopped responding. Obviously did not fully read my emails before responding

Course was basically just McGraw hill. Lectures boring and unhelpful

Do Not Take
Took SO long for the assignments to be graded. Had no clue what my grade was even until finals week. Made it hard to know how to improve with no feedback given in a reasonable time.

I would definitely recommend taking Caileen, especially if you are new to chemistry. She is very welcoming to answering questions and helping students out outside of class. Yes, the class gets difficult, but I honestly think thats the material. You can do well if you go to class, study, and attend LSS

Caileen Made me like chemistry again! She made it easy to understand, and didn't put to much pressure on us to have previous chemistry knowledge (I remembered nothing from high school). The tests were hard, but doable if you study a lot.

I loved Brison!!!! She was so so amazing she really was interested in what she was teaching. We did wordle before every lecture as a warm up. I think the way she teaches the class makes the content much easier to understand.

She was amazing! I was really scared to take Chem 3A cause I hadn't taken a chem course in a long time but she always made sure that everyone felt like they belonged. She gave us this speech on the last day about belonging in STEM and I think about it all the time. The course itself is a lot of info in a short amount of time though
class was easy and lectures were fun. tests required some studying but she was on your side

Dr. Brisons Intro Chem class required a lot of dedication and studying but if you can put in the work you will succeed in this course. She is very clear about her thoughts on cheating and does not offer much flexibility if something were to happen on the day of an exam. Exams are relatively small; 15-20 questions each. Overall I reccomend!!

Kind teacher however if you have never taken chem it can be a very difficult class. She moves through topics very fast and practice tests offered prior to midterms and the final are very different. Very passionate about what she does and compared to other teachers very fun. Difficult to keep up with teachings because of the fast pace.

Great professor, my grade was only this bad cause I was lazy. She goes very fast and her lectures aren't the best, but the explanations on the (paid) ALEKS homework are incredibly useful. Midterm + final make up 60% of your grade. She plays games like Wordle before every lecture. Diligently attend lectures and study hard, and you'll be just fine.

I had an incredible time in her class. She leads every lecture with passion and care, which sucks because my class would not stop talking over her lol. I will say she does flip through the slides fast, but she posts and records everything, so it's not impossible to succeed. It's Chem, it's hard, but she's the best prof I've had so far. Take her!

everything is really fast and she doesn't even have words that are useful on her notes she says everything she wants you to know and expects you to remember when shes throwing 50 concepts at you a week. She as a person is great, and you can tell that shes really smart and cares about her students but she doesn't do a great job of teaching.

She lowkey doesn't teach. everything goes super fast and we learn something new every class which already makes it really hard to grasp concepts, but there are also things on the homework and midterms that she hadn't taught us. I went to tutoring weekly, had accommodations, and met with her, and still did poorly.

Caileen is very understanding and genuinely cares about her students. Ask questions if things are unclear as this class picks up very quickly after the second midterm. Tests were more difficult than homework but aren't worth too much which was nice. 1 online midterm, 1 in person midterm and 1 in person final.

Dr. B was the best!! I loved taking her class and she actually made me want to stay during lectures. Hopefully she continues her ritual of playing NYT games, but she's so supportive of her students and her grading is truly the best!

She cared about teaching a lot, which is such a good trait about her. She would play wordle with her students before class and it made a very good atmosphere. Overall, if you have the option to take chem with her I absolutely would.
very nice teacher, her chem3a class was very interesting and easy.

Dr. Brison is the first teacher I've had so far who seems to genuinely care about her students succeeding. She offers a TON of resources to help her students do well and she is extremely straight-forward about deadlines and expected workload. She's also super fun and would have us play Wordle and Connections every morning before starting lecture.

This teacher is the first teacher I've had so far who I can tell genuinely cares about her students succeeding. She is extremely honest and straight-forward about the expected workload and offers a TON of resources to help her students do well in the class.
Prof. Johnston was coteaching chem3a this quarter and in my opinion she was the better lecturer. Super clear and thought out lectures. She is also really nice! Would take again.

Class was co-taught and Johnston was the better lecturer. Explains topics and answers questions very clearly. Doesn't spend too much time on the basic topics and doesn't rush through difficult sections. Very approachable.

class was co-taught by prof. reveles and prof. johnston. i think between the two, prof. johnston is a better lecturer. class is very forgiving in terms of test grades. aleks does not match up with the lectures so you will have to learn a lot of topics of your own
Much more beneficial to learning than her colleagues, was very easy to approach, highly recommend!

As of Fall 2025, she was only a part-time assistant professor. However, I really liked it when she taught because she lectures at a reasonable pace instead of speeding through material like there's no tomorrow. She also gives adequate amounts of time for iClicker response and really encouraged us to go up and ask questions after class.

Good lecturer, sometimes disorganized. Can sometimes go into unhelpful historical stuff, but is otherwise informative. Help available outside of class. If your test score improves it replaces old tests. All fairly easy. Practice test/study guide provided. Attendance taken each class, good to attend anyway. Super nice and funny. Definitely recommend

When I took this class, it was her first quarter teaching here at UCSC. She's such an incredible, sweet teacher with great lectures! She was able to answer any questions we had. She was a co-teacher alongside Professor Aroy-Reveles and did a great job! Definitely recommend. :)

Professor Sizemore deserves her 5/5 rating. Her class is so organized and the way she explains concepts is amazing. She made organic chemistry easy to understand and actually fun to learn. Also, if you study, her tests are relatively easy; there are no trick questions or weirdly worded problems. She's a great teacher and wants her students to pass.

Prof. Sizemore deserves all the praise for making a 'difficult & accelerated by 6 weeks' course extremely easy for anyone to succeed in as long as they try their best. I'll miss her while taking 8B. Exams are a huge portion of the grade but she releases old exams for practice so you will be extremely prepared! Actually do the hw and you'll be fine!

Professor Sizemore is hands down the best professor I've ever had. She does such a good job at making hard/scary concepts super easy to understand, and her tests are genuinely super straightforward. She also clearly states EXACTLY what she is going to put on her exams, so be sure to do the practice exams/problems because her tests are the same!

Professor Sizemore is probably the best STEM professor I ever had. She breaks down OCHEM into really simple parts that can be understood by just about anyone. I had her for both Chem 8A and 8B, and the material is hard. However, Sizemore makes it very clear what she expects for midterms and finals. Go to lecture and put some work outside of class.

I took Sizemore for Chem 8A and 8B, and I can undoubtedly say that she is one of my favorite professors I've ever had. She is so enthusiastic towards OChem and it's obvious that her main priority is her students' success.

Prof Sizemore is great, had her for both 8A and 8B. She explains and introduces concepts well. Theres no latework but you have plenty of time to do it. The quizzes are a little difficult because sometimes some topics are covered in a lot of detail so I struggled a bit with those. Overall tho shes great def recommend.

such a good professor, makes everything super easy to learn and doesn't try to trick you like some other profs do. she posts example midterms and finals that are very very similar to the ones you'll have to take.
Super nice and makes ochem easy to learn.
she is genuinely the best stem professor i've ever had and makes organic chemistry fun! her teaching is super interactive and explains every concept very clearly~
Makes organic chemistry fun and engaging! Always available to help and very kind towards students.

Absolutely loved this class, very nice structure and she cares about making sure her students learn the material. She is an amazing professor, if I ever get the chance to take one of her classes again, I absolutely would.

Her teaching style is understandable and easy to follow. Make sure to stay caught up in class. Her practice exams, homework, and discussion section worksheets reflect the exams. She made learning ochem less daunting than the course is known to be. Great Professor!

She explains content pretty understandably and is open to questions and reviewing hard content. Tests were appropriately hard and there were no surprises about what would be on it. Homework and quizzes aren't super difficult, but you definitely have to stay caught up. TA was really good too and weekly discussions were worth it.

Prof. Sizemore was a fantastic lecturer who made the material easy to understand. Her practice exams were almost identical to the midterms, and she provided lots of study material. I would 100% take this course with Prof. Sizemore if available.

Professor Sizemore made Organic Chemistry easy to understand, and her tests were great because she gives her past tests to study with and they are nearly the exact same. Her lectures are really great if you pay attention to them and follow along with the provided note template. Even if you can't make it to class, make sure to watch the lectures!

Professor Sizemore really makes the challenging topics of organic chemistry easy to understand. She is an amazing lecturer and her midterms are really fair, as long as you pay attention in lecture and put in some effort you will be fine.

She is amazing and teaches in a way that helps you understand the content more clearly. She is truly cares about your learning and makes organic chemistry so much easier to understand. Her exams are very much like the practices ones. Reading tthe textbook and actually doing the homework will help you on the exams.
Tests are similar to practice material given before hand. Doesn't throw many curveballs on tests.

My absolute favorite professor so far at UCSC. She made organic chemistry interesting and exciting, and her lectures were clear and easy to understand. She also set up the homework and discussion sections in a way that truly helps students learn while not being overly frustrating or difficult. She is well-organized and truly cares about students.

Dr. Sizemore is possibly hands down my favorite professor at UCSC. The lectures were amazing which motivated me to go and exams were extremely straightforward. The way she teaches is super effective and she held true to her word that "everyone can learn Ochem".

Prof. McKinnie's classes are well-organized, engaging, inclusive, and informative. He is very approachable and helpful during office hours. There are many opportunities for extra credit, and there is a helpful curve for grading :) Prof. McKinnie is also great with DRC accommodations.

Excellent lecturer, super energetic, visibly passionate about the subject and teaching in general. Easily reachable outside of class and goes out of his way to help students succeed. Cannot recommend him enough--Shaun's a real treasure and makes learning organic chem such a fun and rewarding experience.

Dr. McKinnies class is engaging and informative. He is always available for questions regarding content of the class. He listens to feedback and if you ask questions he does a good job answering them. Its clear he is excited about the topics he is teaching and is able to engage his students in that excitement. He makes learning accessible to all!

Prof. McKinnie's class was easily my favorite that I've taken at UCSC. Lectures were organized, interesting and engaging. The assignments were thoughtful, and guidelines/expectations were crystal clear. He was helpful, accessible, and understanding of the challenges we faced outside of class. Awesome teacher 10/10 recommend taking a class with him!

The worst professor in the chemistry department. His lectures are the textbook, word-by-word. Impossible homework and refuses to let students work together. Tests are nothing like the hw (our avg was 50%, high was 70%) or the textbook problems. AVOID. Also rude to students, not understanding/supportive. Worst class I took at ucsc b4 I graduated.

This class was super easy compared to 8A, but I cannot recall any of the material. Good teacher for passing the class with an A, but not for actually wanting to understand the material. Tests were easy and homework was somewhat helpful. Lectures are kind of scattered, but overall Binder is not a bad professor.
OCHEM for Kindergartners. Easy A, but prepare to learn nothing and be cooked for any professional test such as MCAT or DAT. Very nice professor though!

I think Caitlin was nice, but I don't think she followed the textbook closely enough and I feel as though I was robbed of learning advanced organic chemistry. A lot of these students need these classes for the future and don't just need to pass. I think the grading was fairly lenient, I just wish I learned more.

This class was weighted 50% on homework, 25% on tests, and 8% on lecture attendance. It is easy to get a good grade in this class without learning anything. IMO this class was a waste of time, even though the professor is a super nice and good teacher

Caitlin is a great person, so I feel bad leaving this review, but their class is a complete waste of tuition money. If you are worried about GPA, this class is the easiest A known to man, but you won't get anything out of the class. They made it clear at the beginning of the quarter that we would be skipping topics 'that would take too much time'..
Lab was great and well structured, not so much the case for the lecture.

The ochem labs are a bit more work than the gen chem labs, but the professor made the labs manageable. Make sure you do your homework and stay on top of the work because they make up a good portion of your grade. Required attendance in lectures and lab. Professor is very understanding and gives many opportunities for help.
Caitlin is one of the best professors I've ever had. She genuinely cares about her students and her lectures are extremely helpful for lab reports.

Caitlin is one of the best STEM professors I've ever had, I wish I could have them for all my STEM courses. They actually want you to succeed and not just weed you out like other chem profs. Lecture is not mandatory but ofcourse lab is, lectures are fun to go to and you feel like youre actually learning.
she a GREAT professor. very understanding and will take time to make sure you succeed in her class.

All-around excellent professor. It's obvious she really cares about her students. Lenient with deadlines and will work with you to make sure you succeed. Lectures help you understand the lab concepts a lot better and are a nice preview of what's to come. Coming from GenChem, these labs were a little more complex, but definitely manageable.

Professor Binder was an amazing teacher who offered so much help outside of lectures - she was so accessible and you can really tell she wants you to succeed and puts in all her effort to make sure you do. She had great lectures that were very inclusive for all students and is really understanding of any circumstances that come up for you as well.

I LOVE CAILTIN! I was so scared ochem was boutta be the end of me but this prof made the material so fun, especially for a winter 2022 8am dude. She has lots of homework help/OHs and she is such a rad human. I wanna take more classes with her! The content may get challenging but never hesitate to reach out to her, she will definitely help you!!

There's a REASON why this professor is rated so high. She is GOD TIER. Probably 1 of the best professors so far. If you're scared of organic chemistry, don't be. She made it so much more easier to understand. My grade was honestly higher than normal because of her amazing teaching skills. She is ABSOLUTELY AMAZING.

Best Organic Chemistry teacher, she knows how to explain the material really well. Homework is the biggest part of your grade, and she helps with it and also the TAs. She is also very nice and funny, especially with a hard topic as Ochem.

Caitlyn is an amazing professor! The effort they put into their lectures is very noticeable and the work they put into the lectures makes understanding the material not too bad (especially considering its ochem). I would 100% take this class again. Having Binder as a professor made the experience of ochem lab enjoyable and fun.

Caitlin Binder is an amazing professor and explain concepts very thoroughly. I wish I took 8A with them because concepts were easy to learn from them. I advise you to take any course you can with Caitlin Binder!! They're also very sweet if you need help through email and any point!

She explains concepts really well and makes her lectures fun and entertaining with themed days. Go to her office hours if you have a question about the work or just to hang out, she is an easy professor to talk to and she will really help you out with your work.

OH MY GOD. I love Caitlin so much. There aren't even words to describe how amazing she is. On top of her just being a dope human being, she actually gives af about what she's teaching and made lab so fun, especially during covid. She had us do an entire interactive online lab which was so inventive and cool. Take her if possible :)
This is a great person to take 8L with. She will go through each concept before lab week and helped engaged students while taking labs online!
DONT TAKE so much aleks and tests ARE NOT mult choice

I had Professor Holman for Chem 4A and I have to say, he was awesome. His lectures are fun and he gives you lots of opportunities to improve. He is almost always accessible, so staying connected will help greatly. He's awesome, take his classes!

Good professor, he tries to engage with his students and his lectures are never too boring. Most of the test questions will be similar to what he covered during lectures. If you understand the basics of the material, you will most likely pass the class.

Amazing professor! You can tell he truly cared about teaching and made sure the material was being understood. Very enthusiastic throughout lectures and made it very fun learning chemistry! Tests were somewhat difficult, but he provided numerous sources to help prepare for them. Would totally recommend his class!

Prof. Holman is an *awesome* professor. He genuinely loves the material with an enthusiasm that makes it easy to be interested in the lectures. He's always happy to hear questions either about his work or the course. He can brush over some topics, so ask v specific questions in office hours & study outside of class to truly grasp the material.

a lot of the reviews say this teacher uses multiple choice but he has completely changed the way he writes tests and they are no longer like that! uses mostly aleks which is kind of annoying but typical, i wouldn't take this class again but I think he is better than the other 1A teacher. Section is the most helpful.
Great professor! Very funny and able to understand! Always checks in if questions are needed.

(I had him for 4A) Ted is such an amazing lecturer, he really succeeded at explaining chemistry in a way that made sense and his enthusiasm for it was infectious. He gave little homework, but every assignment covered everything I needed for the test, there was no busy work. Tests were worth a lot and were medium-difficult.

Professor Holman has to be my favorite teacher I've had at this school. He is super fun in class, very friendly in office hours and will help you pass if you are struggling. His tests sometimes have tricky questions that he never went over because he wants to challenge you in them but all of the questions are able to be done with information given.

Makes the class really fun and likes to talk, but still makes lectures very informative and clear. His tests are quite hard and long, so you need to come prepared and know exactly what you are doing, because there is no time to really think. HW is easy and not too much. If having hard time, go to his office hours, Ted is super nice and helpful!

Got the chillest vibes, and has a real energy when he teaches. You CAN'T fall behind in this class, as everything builds on previous material. Exams are kinda on the long side,  but the problems are doable. Go talk to him, and he'll tell you about chemistry/life with a sincere smile. It is a great class, and you will learn a lot.

He's really cool, we were given an entire 8x11 page of paper to use as a cheat sheet. His exams are all multiple choice and I felt were pretty fair. He can be a bit discouraging however, which can spook of students.
Easy A. Didnt attend lectures or MSI and still receive a solid A. Tests are extremely easy... it's just like ap chem tests in high school but easier

Ted can be pretty funny, but he's not that clear. He expects you to know your stuff or else he says you're pretty doomed. It's really important to go to section bc quizzes but also because the TAs are very good are teaching when Ted the material is confusing. This is a very math based chem. Sometimes uses same exact question from midterm on final

Ted is a funny guy who is very willing to help. He tries to make chem fun but the class is still hard. Show up to class because he actually teaches, but discussion sections help a lot too. Tests are multiple choice but are hard nonetheless. There are two midterms and one is very early in the quarter and one cumulative final.

Ted Holman is a very good teach. He is easy to understand and outlines specifically what will be on the tests. THE FINAL EXAM WAS THE HARD THING IN THE WORLD. CHAPTER 7 AND 8 WILL STREAMROLL YOU IF YOU ARE NOT PUTTING IN THE TIME AND EFFORT. Ted is awesome tho. GOT A 50 % ON THE FINAL AND STILL GOT A B IN THE CLASS.

His midterms are pretty tough. They are multiple choice and sometimes the questions aren't very clear as they should be. The homework is pretty doable. His lectures are often interactive, but there are days when he is very dry and you might want to take a nap.

Ted makes his lectures clear. He makes lecture notes available for pre-printing. Homework isn't too bad. Do the practice midterms because they're very similar to the tests. I started going to his office hours in the middle of the quarter, and they helped so much. I had the textbook, but  hardly used it because I went to class.
