Holman is an excellent professor. He makes chemistry really easy to understand. Pulling off an A in this class is easy as long as you study consistently. Going to MSI, Ace, or discussion is recommended.

Holman is a great professor. Chemistry is difficult, but he makes it pretty easy to understand and keeps the tests simple so not to confuse anyone. He really cares about his students and wants everyone to pass. Don't slack off, attend MSI if you can and know your TA is your best friend! I didn't understand Chem without my section. Beware ch 7 and 8

Scott is a wonderful instructor, he often sways off topic during lectures but eventually goes back on track. The course consists of lecture periods in addition to lab, this makes it a rather time consuming. When it comes to grading, it's often rather lenient, however, grading guidelines aren't always very clear unless directly asked about them.

A lot different from the other chem labs, weekly lab reports. Total of 7 reports (at LEAST 8 pages each). A lot of work considering its a 2unit lab. Took this class along with chem164/151A/163B. This class probably required the most work! Follow the outline he gives for each lab and give yourself 2-3 days for to type the report. Generous curve!

Hw answers were similar to the lectures. Textbook is highly recommended since the class gets hard in the middle and end. Look at all the old midterms to see the test format and the questions. The class starts off easy and quickly escalates. There is a generous curve! Lecture notes are not posted so you have to watch the video/ go to class.

I really enjoyed this professor. He was very mild natured but was still very passionate about his teaching. He was the perfect professor for incoming freshmen and his class was enjoyable and memorable. He was also the king of saying any joke and making it funny, nobody laughed at his jokes which was sad, but I thought they were hilarious.

He is my favorite professor for the gen chem series and is super accessible outside of class for any questions you have (take advantage of his office hours). His lecture material is very clear and concise and the homework is very similar to the examples in his lectures. Class goes quickly because it's lots of material but he makes it easy and fun!

Never went to lecture and learned from online hw problems. He was very lenient with grades and the curve was very big. He's awkwardly funny but I personally couldn't help but get bored in class, so only attended during testing days. Easy A if you study and do all the work.

Very understanding and responded to emails quickly! He lectures fast but with a lot of example questions. Homework questions were kinda hard and the test questions were pretty difficult but still able to be figured out. It was really nice to have the extra credit quizzes, there were really generous curves. Gimme gimme that Canadian grading scale.

Scott is an easy-going professor. He recognized that it might be hard for students to stay on tasks when the town was just out of electricity, so he gave out webassign extension. Personally I think it is possible to get an A even without going to MSI because he gave out many quizzes sheet and practice problems that are helpful for exams, use them!

Clearly very intelligent, but not exactly the best lecturer. He moves through chapters fast and assumes students know material already. He is extremely nice, loves questions, and gives A LOT of extra credit opportunities. Grading scale makes it easy to do well and homework on webassign is worth a lot of your grade too. Be ready to self teach though

Overall, a good professor, if apt to go into tangents. The textbook is required for WebAssign, but generally the majority of the material is covered in class, with the textbook being needed only for reinforcement. The lectures miss nothing of great importance, but due to the tangents,may seem to be unclear at times, for which the textbook is useful
He was a mediocre professor but very funny. . .would pull out some memes time to time. He teaches like you already know everything and can go off on tangents, but he is a nice guy.

Professor Scott Oliver is one of the most brilliant and caring people you will come across. The class definitely moves very fast but he makes up for it by webcasting all of his lectures. Additionally, he truly just wants all of his students to succeed and will do whatever he can justify to do so. You are in luck if Scott is your professor.

Hes a super nice guy, very lenient with the grading because he wants everyone to pass. All lectures were webcasted so you dont really need to go to class unless you want to ask questions. Goes really fast during lecture but try to pay attention and youll get all the notes down.
Humor 10/10 and actually learned things.

Professor Oliver was great, he was funny and answered emails almost immediately. He did his best to give you all the information you would need. He does go by the material pretty fast and it can be very confusing, his test were also pretty challenging. He does have a very big curve and offers lots of extra credit though.
Great professor. Gives a lot of opportunity for extra credit. He is a pretty funny person. Went a little too fast towards the end but was pretty forgiving on the exams. Highly recommend.

He is nice and funny. He gives 3 optional quizzes for extra credits and sometimes extends the HW due, which is pretty generous. Although he does not give a lot of examples during the lectures, you will be fine on the tests if you know the material well. He gives A+ if your grade is above 90%, so take advantage of it :)

Nice teacher overall. Moves way too quickly through material and provided very few examples. Study guides and homework do not resemble exams which is frustrating. Homework is pretty time consuming. Maybe this class would be ok if you have ample experience in chem. He's pretty nice and funny, but not an effective teacher.

Really great person, however stuffs a lot into lectures and expects material to be well known before hand. Examples in class are flown through fairly quickly, not really allowing time to process info. Homework due every Sunday, pretty time consuming. Over all a decent lecturer. He loves questions.
Great professor for those with chem experience, test very easy, and Is caring. Only thing is he tends to ramble off topic during lectures.
Had him for both 100a and 100b and he's been one of my favorite professors i've had. Really engaging lecturer and tests are super fair.

Professor Stone is such a great lecturer. If you attend lecture you will most definitely pass this class. We had about 5 problem sets that were pretty easy and had plenty of time to complete. The exams are all asynchronous and open book, open internet. But if you understand everything in lecture, you don't need any other resources honestly.

Tests are all online/open-note with 3.5 hours to do them. His lectures are great-- I recommend writing down what he says and what he writes, as well as try to make connections to things you already know. I learned SO MUCH from this class. Problem sets are kind of fun, and sometimes he takes questions from them and puts into the tests. Super funny!
Class was informative, you could tell he cared, and all the tests are open note, at home. Very low pressure way to learn decently challenging material.

I took BIO100B winter quarter of 2023. As long as you watch lectures and do the homework he provides, exams are very easy. Rn, tests are not cumulative and he's very organized which makes studying a lot easier. His lecture slides are also very concise which is great for studying. This is overall one of the easiest classes I've taken,
Stone is a great lecturer, I learned a lot even though the class was pretty challenging.

I enjoyed taking this class he is very fair and clear with the material he lectures on and what he expects you to memorize regarding the midterm material. I suggest reading the book, listen to webcasts and write additional things he said that might seem important, and attend office hours and discussion section and you will succeed. :)

Definitely cares about students and clearly enjoys teaching and is excited about biochem. He webcasts his lectures: I would print his slides, watch the lectures and write down every detail he said and then review it later before the test. No surprises here. He makes a study guide too and practice problems. Do the work : You'll get an A.
Go to office hours and do the problems in the book. He always puts 1 or 2 problems from the book into the exams.

Michael was definitely a great professor with a lot of insight in his research. As a warning to anyone in his class, if his midterms seem easy as first...... do NOT hold that same standard going into the final as he will definitely make the difficulty of his test harder if he sees something not fit and be diligent with textbook detail.

This was a tough class but Stone's a fantastic professor to take it with. He's a really nice guy and very good at explaining these ideas in a way that makes sense and making all the pieces fit together, so to speak. Tests were tough but doable with solid preparation. Make sure you don't fall behind in lecture, it's really hard to get caught up.

Really enjoyable guy, kind and approachable. The material is hard, and though he webcasts his lectures still GO! It's important. Besides, a lot of his exam covers stuff he'll briefly mention in class. Stay on your school work and study hard, just like any other biology class
He is very approachable, caring, professional, and his exams are WAY fair. plus he's kind of cute in a nerdy way ;)

Really enjoyed having Michael as a professor. He webcasts his lectures, provides plenty of optional practice problems and posts detailed review material for exams. His exams are tough but attending his office hours, discussion section, and reading the book really helped. Michael is a great lecturer and is an approachable guy. Definitely recommend!

A nice guy, but G*d were the exams difficult. He didn't test on the main stuff, he tested on the minutiae. Stuff he would mention ONCE very briefly showed up ROUTINELY on exams, plus its never clear exactly what he's going to test on. He is perfectly happy with 70% averages on exams. Lectures confusingly organized. Studied my ass off, still no A.
Taught the first half of biochem, pretty straight forward and interesting stuff. Not too hard, I studied and got an A in the class.

Good lecturer! ...but tests are long multiple choice, and no HW.. Also, grading is a bit unreasonable. I got in the 85% range on every assignment, even though the averages should have merited a curve. Also did 2 extra credit assignments. Still got a B. Seems unfair to ask for students to do extra credit if you aren't going to give them any.

Great teacher, super clear and concise. Goes at a fast pace but once you get used it to it, the lectures are enjoyable. Tests are moderately hard, but if you study enough and maybe get a hold on a old exam, you'll do well. He is helpful in office hours and is down to help you out. Great teacher!
Great teacher, very clear and straight-forward. Keeps the mood light and is super fair and understandable!

Taught the 1st half of Biochemistry. He presented the material clearly and I learned a lot. The 1st midterm was a little hard but no surprises. His material on the 2nd midterm, which was half his stuff and half the other professor was exactly how the 1st midterm went. He was better then Sanford, who taught the 2nd half of the course. Very fair.

40% final, 20% each midterm, textbook is required for all homeworks and for studying. This class is hard but if you study enough, you'll understand what you are being asked on exam questions. The final this year was exceptionally difficult but it looks like the overall class grades were curved to account for low scores. TAs are a great help in 163b

The book is a must in order to do the hw. Hw every week, pop quizzes at the end of every chapter. Attendance is recorded in section, so attendance is a must. A real upgrade from 163B since there are PowerPoint slides posted however you must go to class to get the examples. Test are m.c. and free response. There is a big curve! Final is cumulative
Cares about students and the course. Brilliantly  organized course.

Shaowei is an excellent professor, and a very nice person! He used powerpoints, which was a huge improvement over 163A. Make sure he continues to use these as a tool; it just might make or break your understanding of a wonderful -but difficult- chunk of material. Does curve. I am going to go out of my way to take another class with Prof. Chen! :)

Shaowei is a very accommodating and friendly professor. However, he is extremely difficult to understand. Also, his lectures aren't very organized which exacerbates the problem. Perhaps if he used a powerpoint or gave an organized outline of each lecture this would help. His tests are hard and it's unclear what you are expected to know.

Why this class in only two units is a mystery. Several ridiculously demanding and tedious lab reports will leave you feeling frustrated at best and like crying at worst.Oh, and there is also a final exam. The topics are interesting but the work load absurd. The T.A. will make all the difference in the world to you. Good luck.

Nice enough. Difficult to understand. Simple quizes. 85% of grade based on one paper. No lab manual. No text. Lectures from power point. Since there are no other options for the course, pray you get an excellent T.A.
very helpful in office hours and after lectures;  could see his efforts to try to explain things clearly during lectures (he seemed quite conscientious about his accent).  overall, good teacher.

What did he say? Nobody knows. It's not just his accent (which is heavy); it's the fact that he is constantly mumbling. It sounds like he has a mouth full of marbles. 75% of the grade was based on a final project (which we were given about 2 weeks to do), and hardly anyone knew what was going on. Adafd asdfj aie, afj. Get that? No? I didn't either.

Loved this class! Highly recommend taking it with Yat Li. There are 4 papers and 4 quizzes in the class. All the information you need is in the lab manual for the corresponding lab assignment (for quizzes and the reports). The class was extremely organized and the information was readily available. Professor Li really cares for his students.

A great teacher. He is Chinese so he has a little accent, but he tries his best to answer any question you might have. He is also available out of class. Fast grader, it was a small class but we had our grades within two days of the exam. The class is definitely not easy, and I don't think a professor can change that. Work hard and you'll succeed.
He is awesome. Very nice guy

Overall a nice professor for a very intense course. You will learn a lot, but it will come only at the cost of putting in many hours of study. He is a ridiculously ruthless grader, where propagation of error doesn't exist in his vocabulary. There is a curve, but you should try to just learn as much as you can without worrying about your grade.

Read the ancient tome: principals of quantum chemistry and you'll do fine. If not tough luck. He uses ppt and skips steps (click click click) when showing examples. Curves hard, 50/100 is passing. No partial credit for anything.

Pro. Li follows the book and his notes are very organized. His quizzes are from lecture and the exams are hard but fair if you do the homework. He curves at the end and he is available to help when he is asked. He takes time out of class to explain concepts in class when asked. Very interesting class. Work hard and you will pass!

Teaches straight from the textbook, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. English is not his first language but he'll try to explain confusing concepts as best he can when asked. He's also very approachable after class and in his office hours. Assignments and exams were fair. Great instructor overall for an intense course.
Super sweet, funny, and engaging professor. I took Chinese 1 with her as a beginner, and she always made the class laugh!

This is one of the sweetest and funniest professors I've met by far. I'm currently taking CHIN 1, and she makes learning a new language very engaging and overall fun. She has a unique & fun way of teaching her students that makes me not only pay attention but also understand the material. I 100% recommend taking her course for beginners to Chinese!

Best teacher EVER. Sweetest and funniest professor ever and even a great teacher. Her teaching style is very collaborative and silly and you would never get bored in class. Took two of her classes and plan to take more.
I like wu laoshi, she'a  good teacher!! Everything is fun, but you have to go to class!! Miss class will lots so many points for grade. However, if you go to class and finish the work ontime, easy A!

She cares a lot about her students and hosts lots of fun events in place of class. Overall a very generous grader, flexible professor, and chill class environment. If you took AP Chinese in high school this class will be a breeze.  Worth taking for a gen ed. Though, lots of group projects mean you are in charge of keeping yourself accountable.

Wu Laoshi is one of the best language teachers I've ever had! She explains concepts very clearly and is extremely patient and understanding. As a grader, she's very fair and gives a lot of partial credit. Keep in mind, however, that Chinese is a difficult language to learn. Doing homework and preparing for daily quizzes is essential for doing well.

My name is ZhiBin Huang. I love Professor Wu's class is 100% amazing! For a student who wants to take Chinese! Just take her class! but it has a lot of quizzes and projects, but should be easy. I also make a lot of friends: Brother Fu, henry fu, and henry sun. She is friendly and helpful, You will enjoy her class. thank you professor Wu to teach me
Amazing teacher

She's an amazing professor, you should be prepared to do the work, but she genuinely cares about her students. She's really understanding and just wants to help students learn in a variety of ways, hence the amount of homework. There is a lot of group work, which can be unfortunate, but if you get a decent group you can all help each other.

i've taken chinese 3-6, and also 103 with wulaoshi! she's so sweet and caring-- the class can be a bit of work and somewhat fast-paced (but i think this is typical for language learning classes; if you don't have homework, you won't learn as much as you should), but she's so understanding and kind. she's very approachable and easy to reach!

I had to take this twice. When I came back from dropping out and retook her class I remember why I felt so overwhelmed: Some days I have had to submit as many as 4 or 5 individual graded assignments, all with different timing. Some of these are group work, not outlined on the syllabus, and are due after class the same day as assigned. Frustrating.
Solid professor, and really helpful.
Not much oral skill

Ting Ting is an absolutely phenomenal teacher.  If you've taken Keenan, you'll find her much more up-to-date, and the flow of the class feels much less dry.  She sends out daily emails, will probably recognize you by handwriting in the first few weeks, and is gorgeous.  If you're willing to put in the time and effort, the rewards are immense.
She is the most thoughtful teacher ever. Class is made interesting with stories, films and other activities. Definitely choose her if you are going to take Chinese.
Professor was extremely helpful and knew how to teach the language well. Daily quizzes off assigned vocab, so study them; tests were relatively fair. Overall, great class!

Katy was super passionate about coastal and marine policy that you got to learn so much by the lectures and readings. The group projects are the main part of the class and they are great introductions to a future in areas related to policy and coastal regions. The midterm was closed book and a fair challenge! Overall great class and would recommend

I was personally really interested in the class (Economics and the Environment) and Prof Seto went through some pretty good topics. The class had to be quickly moved online due to COVID and that took the interest/preparedness out of it. Overall enjoyed the class though.

Gary is really knowledgable and respected, and he knows it. He humble brags a lot. The work load was extremely light with only 2 short writing assignments the whole quarter, but his tests mainly consists of arbitrary facts and percentages rather than concepts from the class, making it hard to ace his tests.

Gary is amazing. He is so passionate about what he does. and he is so funny. I really enjoyed going to his class even though it was at 8 am. Highly recommend and he is a very good resource to have as an earth science or esci major.

Not easy A ge. Class kinda sucked,  it was interesting content but half the class he rants about Trump, the other half he reads of his slides. Then  he tests you on random stats in the lecture, like what percent of US energy comes from coal. If you are not passionate about this exact topic, or an Earth Science major, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS.

He's a super fun professor to watch in lecture, but the entire class is graded on 3, 50 mcq exams, so you can't afford to slack in this class. The questions are pretty conceptual, so keep that in mind. Super chill guy with lots of fun stories to tell.

Easy course to pass, I probably could've gotten a better grade tbh. However, this class is awesome. Professor Griggs is incredibly kind and knowledgeable, and I found his lectures to be fascinating. Oceanography is a great subject. Would 100% recommend this course for any student. Advice: STUDY YOUR NOTES! And take good notes; you will succeed.
He was a great professor and changed the course of my major

Lectures taught me a lot about Santa Cruz. Gary is such a knowledgable and caring professor. He's an expert in his field and I liked hearing about his own experiences in ocean sciences. Quizzes/tests were all multiple choice but a lot of the questions were about stuff never mentioned, which made it hard to get 100%. Would still recommend!
Nice enough guy, but so cynical around issues of climate change that it kind of ruins the whole class. Goes on tangents that are essentially to brag.

Grading is based off of 2 tests (each 1/3 of your grade) and lab work (other 1/3 of the grade). No extra credit. Lecture is essentially mandatory. Take notes, as some of the slides have no words on them (harder to study, imo). Good lecturer, hard to take notes for because half of lecture is about his studies abroad. Not the worst, but not the best.
The lecture was often led off-topic to irrelevant, and often racist, anecdotes. Attendance is not necessary, tests are easy, and assignments are made up on the spot. Easy class, just disappointing.

Gary has lots of good stories. A chill & easy class. There are 2 quick 30 min tests, and 3 papers of about 1-page each, a very manageable workload for an upper div. He wants his students to succeed, very approachable. He is very passionate about climate change and inspiring. He is basically famous in the science world. GARY FOR THE WIN!

Gary is an awesome professor! He's witty, interesting, and has engaging lectures filled with personal anecdotes in relation to the study material. You can tell he is really passionate about what he teaches. His optional book that goes along with this class, Coasts in Crisis, is super interesting. Attend every lecture and you'll do great!

Gary is amazing,hilarious, a legend. The class is super easy aside from only being grade on the midterms and labs. You HAVE TO show up to class (he's old school) to know what's on the exams (all multiple choice) but if you show up to class you'll definitely get an A. Lecture slides online don't help much & he doesn't use zoom or record.

Gary is very passionate about what he teaches. The class is test heavy, with your grade being based off three tests. Some of the test questions are easy and some are straight forward. There is a lot of true/false questions which I found to be difficult. If you're good at studying only lectures, take the class. If not,I would find a different class.

Gary Griggs, the man the myth the legend. Gary is such an awesome professor. His lectures are usually pretty interesting with cool stories. This class is graded on only 3 midterms which makes it hard and easy at the same time. There's no homework which is great but it makes it hard to get a good grade if you do bad on one midterm. Gary is the GOAT.

This class is easy if you're good at memorizing lots of information and trying to deeply understand it, but otherwise, pretty difficult if you're not good at that. There's only 3 midterms that make up your class grade. I went to every class meeting and studied the material, but I didn't do great. Make sure you review material over and over again.

He was a super kind professor who is clearly passionate about what he teaches. The lectures themselves were actually very interesting, as he includes a lot of personal stories and a few funny aspects. There are very few exams that make up the entirety of your grade, but you will do well if you study the lectures AND lecture notes posted on canvas.

The entire course is based off of three midterms. I went to every lecture, completed the study guides and even had a study group yet I finished with a 77. The lectures make it seem like the test will be easy but the test is on very abstract and random things he might have gone over once. He is a super funny and cool guy, but needs to revise tests

He has so much experience and his lectures were filled with so many fascinating stories from his career. Lectures went over everything that was in the tests thoroughly. If you go to all the lectures and pay attention you will do well.

Gary Griggs is a legend. If you like marine science and ocean geography, you will most likely enjoy his class. If you watch the lectures, you will do well on the tests, they are very straightforward. Quick to respond to emails. Eager to help his students. Very knowledgeable and passionate about his subject. Highly recommend.

Although obviously smart and respected within her field, Professor Hale consistently shows an inability to connect with students and actually lecture in a digestible way. Her lectures are often chaotic and hard to follow, and the entire pacing of the class is patternless. She is a great economist but a horrible teacher.

Galina is an incredibly smart and respected economics professor, but her course is overwhelmingly challenging. The amount of readings per week is fairly inconsistent - sometimes 2 articles, sometimes 12 - and are very difficult to digest. Her lectures are similar and require strong econ knowledge to even grasp the concepts. Pop quizzes every week.

Amazing professor. Genuinely cares for students and is very flexible regarding them. She tries to make the course the most enjoyable for students and constantly asks for feedback regarding what works and what doesn't. Course is well thought out and she puts in a lot of effort.

honestly such a sweet and incredible professor that genuinely wants the best for you!! you can do the bare minimum in the class and probably be fine but id really encourage participating a bit and actually engaging w the course, both for your own sake and for her (she puts a lot of work into the class and it shows, especially compared w the others)

Such an amazing professor. She is suuuuper caring and truly wants the best for her students. Had to take this class as it was a requirement but I ended up learning a lot more than I thought I would. You gain so much knowledge from the way she teaches the class. The homework is light and honestly enjoyable. Definitely recommend her class!!!

Professor Laurence is genuinely the sweetest professor. She is very accomodating and understanding. Her class is quite engaging and she lectures in a thought provoking way. Take her class!! It is an easy A but you'll learn a lot :)

She's such a sweet and engaging professor. Very helpful feedback and not a lot of work. Easy grader & very clear guidelines. One assignment per week and some readings but lwk you can still do really well in the class without doing them. PICK HER CLASS!!

she's very sweet! class is mandatory, so just go and dont be late. she deducted a few points because I was late twice (+30min). Easy A and very interesting class! I think it should be mandatory during your 1st year in college. Expect to do a lot of actives outside the class (go to events, join clubs, career success, etc).
Really sweet and caring, helped me with things not related to class, like reviewing a job application.

Mandatory if you're in C9. Keep up with the readings & try somewhat and you will do well. You don't learn many new things per se, but there is an opportunity to engage in discourse and learn more about things going on in the world. Some people might find the class boring, but I think everybody should take at least one class like this.

This course is rigorous from the perspective of Frosh, but prepares students for success. I don't agree with the discernment that he pushes his "beliefs" onto students, rather encourages students rethink their own understandings of socio-economic . If you're a scholar & you're willing to put in the work, you'll enjoy the class and get good grade.

Worst professor ever. Avoid any class he teaches at all costs. He takes forever to grade, and when he finally does he'll criticize all your work until you adhere to every opinion and guideline he has. The seminars were awful as they would get very specific and require you to participate every class. DO NOT TAKE

I would rather be ran over twice by an 18-wheeler and then be dragged against the concrete than retake this class. Sooo much reading just to not go over some. Grading takes forever and prof is stingy. Don't do it to yourself.

This class is called “C9 Core,” but I learned nothing from it except how frustrating it is to deal with a professor who waits till Week 10 to grade and then accuses students without evidence. If you value your time, sanity, or GPA, avoid this class.

On top of that, the professor kept implying students were using AI even when we clearly weren't. I didn't use AI for a single assignment, and somehow I still got flagged? Instead of actually reading our work or giving real guidance, they just assumed everything was AI-generated. It felt insulting and honestly just lazy.

He didn't grade anything until literally the last week of the quarter. Before that, all we got were vague, useless “feedback” comments that didn't actually help us improve. So you spend the whole quarter writing assignments with no idea what you're doing right or wrong, and then suddenly, boom, grades drop all at once at the end. Worst course ever.

Took for C9 Core: horrible workload, forced to read 20+ pages of economic theory written exclusively in dense, flowery language twice a week. Assumes students know much more about economics than the avg. frosh and takes points away when not actively participating in class. For a required course, asks way too much from students in terms of effort.
DONT TAKE HIS CORE CLASS HE TANKS YOUR GRADE AND MAKES YOU READ EVERYDAY, DOESNT GIVE YOU GOOD FEEDBACK

He doesn't know how to use Canvas; there are no assignment dates, and some are mistyped. He assigns 4+ heavy readings every week and grades very slowly; in week 8, he has only graded week 3. His slow grading hides mistakes and drags down grades for the quarter. No phones or laptops unless he says so. The course is repetitive and uncreative.

If I had a dollar for every time Gampel gave the worst form of constructive criticism on my assignments, I wouldn't have to go to this university. Besides this, his grading is bottom tier considering how it is is based on how much your views align with his. Never take any of his classes.

I took Jared for my C9 Core Class. I thought he was a harsh grader at first but throughout the quarter I met with him (I couldn't go to office hours but he was always willing to find time for me), and he helped me through my work. This class was definitely hard but I genuinely think it improved my writing. He's really funny and nice too.

C9 core professor-was unsupportive and graded based on formatting and style,not content. He approved the first draft of my final draft after I read it aloud in class, then tanked my grade right after SETs without explanation. It felt retaliatory and unprofessional,and it hurt my GPA. I was disappointed and wished I had chosen a different professor.

Took course for college core course. Terrible. Assigns so many readings and grades based on participation. Tough grader and his feedback on assignments isn't great. Will not appreciate you as a student if you don't share the same views as him. He easily picks favorites.

Worst professor ever. The class is about capitalism, yet he grades purely on writing. Graded fairly until the SETs survey, then tanked my grades.  Didn't take Pass/No Pass, thinking I'd be fine-big mistake. Hurt my GPA, transfer chances, and job prospects. Forces students to buy an expensive textbook(other classes allow free PDF).Very condescending

(Took for Core) He takes a long time to grade assignments. He didn't grade midterms and the majority of our assignments until the end of the quarter. Only gives feedback on a few. This isn't a writing class, yet all of his critiques are on how you write the post, not the content within them. Pick a different core professor if your schedule allows.

*Coreclass
Gives vague instructions for assignments but grades them strictly. Regularly advocates for socialism and critiques capitalism, turning the class into an echo chamber for his views. Unlike other courses that permit online textbooks, he insists on costly physical copies. Students with differing opinions rarely feel comfortable speaking up.

I had him for the C9 core class. He is the toughest grader out of all the C9 class professors, and he forces all the students to participate. He doesn't like when students have opinions that do not agree with his, and he is very strict about the curriculum. Makes you buy a physical copy of the book instead of a PDF like all the other profs.

(I took him for my core class) 
I do not understand the hate he gets on this page! YES, you will be assigned readings, and YES, you will be expected to participate in class. But that's the entire point of the class; to challenge what you know, grow as a writer, and Gampel is an excellent mentor. 
This is college! It's not supposed to be easy.

Rating for C9 Core class. This was my first class coming into UC Santa Cruz and it made me want to drop of immediately. He forces you to speak everyday or you will simply fail the class. He is very entitled to his opinion and has a lot of judgment to him. Do not take this class unless you want to cry everyday.

*rating for the College Nine Core class*
Jared is very closed minded when it comes to the topics in the C9 Core class. It is very much his way or no way in the discussions. The readings are mandatory and he requires participation in every class. My roommate had a different professor who did not force students to speak if they did not want to.

Alison is an engaging professor who cares about her students and their individual interests. Her class became a place of open and safe discussion on housing, racial capitalism, and the current political moment.
One assignment a week that takes like an hour and a few 5 page essays.
class was chill, the grading is ridiculously easy
Really easy class if you just show up and put in a modicum of effort, easy assignments and easy grading, they basically give you 100% if you try in good faith.

I really enjoyed the lectures that Isbister did, she really does try to make them interesting and also asks students to give their feedback to things which is entertaining. Virtually no solo assignments, mainly just group work in section each week. If you have a good group you'll do well. Also, super friendly!
It's mainly group work which makes up the grade, and lecture / section attendance. The workload is pretty light but Isbister's lectures are usually pretty interactive which makes them better.
I really like her lecture style. Sometimes they can be long, but the content in it genuinely is pretty good. Most work is happening in sections but it's all group work mainly. Not hard to keep an A.

Isbister really uses this class to advertise her lab mostly. If you want to do research with her, this is an easy way to get to know her. You do learn a lot about computational media like conferences and the main concepts within the field if you want to go into it for your career. Very low bar class and easy to ace, open note exams.

Most lectures are very conversational and collaborative. The content was interesting and light. Don't really mind that she incorporates her research in what we're learning since I think it just helps reaffirm concepts and ideas? Written assignments are mostly just giving your opinion on stuff. She's super sweet. Easy A just do the work!

Super easy class! Besides mandatory lecture/section attendance, super chill class. One assignment a week (mostly with groups in section) and few 600 word reading responses. Midterm/Final are both take-home & open-note! She encourages you to join research opportunities (not required tho!). I recommend this class!!
I wouldn't take her class if you have a choice, she isn't good at teaching and she constantly tries to advertise and relate her lectures to her research and lab. However, the class isn't that hard.

bruh I didn't have a choice. The vibe felt controlling at times, like walking up to people and yelling at them to stop using their phone. The whole place felt like high school. The workload is also insane, somehow heavier than my engineering course.

I did everything “right” (attended every lecture + submitted everything on time + full points on both web projects + solid midterm + lots of effort on the final zine) and still got an A-. The grading criteria never felt clear, so the final grade was confusing. Will never take any course with this prof. If you wanna keep ur 4.0, trust me, avoid him.

Dr. Altice's lectures were very engaging for me, despite being generally apathetic towards the topics covered by this course. If you've taken English courses prior to this one, the readings he assigns are comparatively easy as well. Overall, I learnt a lot and enjoyed doing so while in this course.
Man. This class hit me with tough time but his teaching impact me more than he knows. The 'medium' literally change how i think and create. Great professor with a real impact.

In the coolest way possible, classes feel like watching a really good, interactive video essay. Super cool personality, professor and the course itself keeps up with modern gaming. 3 weeks in and I'm so surprised by what I've learned. LOT of reading you MUST do so I give a 4 difficulty. Read, bring a warm drink to class, take notes, and relax.

He has one of the best-structured classes at UCSC. You can see that he puts a lot of effort into the class. If you genuinely want to learn, he is the professor for you; you will score an A+ as long as you pay attention and follow the rubric while working on the assignment.

Nathan puts a lot of effort into every detail of his lectures, and you can tell that he cares about what he's teaching. This was very much a media studies course with a focus on games. Most of it is reading, with a few projects to apply what you learn. If you read, take notes, and go to class, it's a breeze and you'll learn a lot.

This class has a lot of busywork such as reading/annotating papers and the content of the class is questionable. Unfortunately it's required from CS: Game Design majors. It's more of a literary analysis class than a Computational Media class.

Very well structured class with engaging task to participate in. Loved the in-person coding and practice that I was able to get in class. Would suggest to take his class if you have any motivation to LEARN.

Cool guy, weird grading policies like attendance being mandatory for sections that are just mini OHs or random in class assignments. The class was more coding and yap about game history than I expected so it felt like lectures were a waste of time. Assignments were fun and as hard as you made it to be. Grades assignments weeks late.

A lot of reading required outside of class, and the “optional” attendance is also convoluted. He does make content interesting to an extent but the class just feels more like a waste of time and space, he may be better in some other classes.
Content is fine but he's pretty condescending when he talks to you sometimes

The course content is rather dense and just feels like a continuation of Film 80V. Nathan isn't a super has Prof I'd say but his attitude can be pretty demeaning and I feel like when you talk to him sometimes he acts kinda rude about things.

The assignments were great, but the curriculum/lectures are not. If you know the basics of game development, you won't learn much. Lectures are more about teaching a JS framework than about teaching good design/development practice that's applicable to future projects. Attendance isn't “mandatory” but has weekly graded in class “coding exercises”.
cool lecture slides

Nathan is a super cool dude, he keeps lectures interesting and fun. I came into this class with no JS experience but did fine! Expect to dedicate a good amount of time to assignments, despite them being easy. You could work with someone on the final project and the whole course was fun overall. Attendance isnt mandatory but can add participat. cred

I was really impressed with Professor Altice's teaching style. He's dynamic and I found his lectures to be very engaging and his slides to be well made. If you struggle with group projects this may be a tough class, but (even though I usually find group projects rough) I felt the way he went about grading for groups was helpful 10/10!!!!!!

Nathan is knowledgeable in his field, but he definitely plays favorites. He ridicules and is cruel to students he clearly doesn't like. If you're not going to be one of his guys, don't bother trying. He's smart and nice to some people, but everyone can see who he is mean to.

I found the lectures really dry and disengaging. Its easy to get a B but difficult to get an A. Also, his group projects are confusing and he grades really hard on them even if you follow the guidelines. Find a good group if you can since a big portion of the grade is based on group projects. Likable person but really bad class structure.

Nathan is a really good professor. This class is first taught fully online, but he handles the class really well, also adjusts the assignment pretty well. This class is based on quizzes and group projects. The project is fun and I have an amazing time with my teammates.

start ur final proj EARLY, write good essays, and you'll be fine gradewise. i basically did the final proj alone and got a lot of extra credit. but you're not going to learn anything here and thats why im giving a 1. i really couldnt tell you much about game design after this class which really disappoints me because its otherwise such a cool topic

Overall, the class provides a lot of busy work and supplementary material in section can be more worthwhile than lecture. Kate is pretty laid back though and if you just keep up with the small assignments you'll be fine, its not that hard to do. The group final project is a pain though and they don't really offer help on GDevelop.

So much busywork due every week for no reason, the professor and TAs were barely any help, especially when figuring out the apps you need to complete the assignments. If you're looking for an easy class, DO NOT TAKE. also made attendance mandatory randomly in the middle of the quarter

As someone said, they apparently changed the attendance policy which is definitely bs. useless lectures and them keeping you there is honestly a huge waste of time. you're on your own really, ta's arent responsive either

Told us at the first lecture, attendance wouldn't be mandatory. At the end, they input a lecture attendance grade anyways. totally pathetic and dumb. class lectures and ta sections are most definitely useless too though, you don't learn anything useful from it. classwork isn't hard though hand ai is allowed for everything.
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS, the teacher really isn't very interested in this topic and it seems like she wants to end every class early. She didn't even show up half the time

Really hard to reach outside of class. Explains concepts quite poorly, lecture quality is quite poor too. If you're interested in the subject, the first textbook is quite an interesting read. Final is required to be done in GDev which is nightmarish to work with and learn to use, something the tutor agrees with. Prof tutorials on GDev won't help.

Provided book is way more educational than lecture, which tend to be shallow and unhelpful. Hard to access outside of class. DO THE GDEVELOP TUTORIALS; her explanations on using it aren't very good. Don't take if you lack gaming experience, you need to draw on prior knowledge a lot for the WEEKLY writings. Not too difficult, but LOTS of busywork!
no need to go to lectures. just do homework and its an easy class. final project is annoying but not bad

Horrible lectures, lots of examples from random games that nobody has played in the last decade. Talks a lot about her job and suboptimal research she did, and cancels class almost every week for no reason. TA's are amazing

Honestly one of the worst professors and the most useless class I've ever taken. Lectures are completely useless and mainly definitions and examples of very basic gaming terms. Lots of homework given that just take a lot of time. Don't take this class if you are trying to complete a GE requirerment.
ngl if u put in the work its pretty easy to get an A
Difficult class if you don't have prior video game knowledge, homework takes a long time, don't take it if you're looking for an easy A.

Attendance isn't mandatory, everything is taught by TAs during required discussions. The class is described as beginner but if you don't have prior video game knowledge you will have a miserable time completing the weekly writing assignments. Might be an interesting class if you like video games but don't suggest if you're looking for an easy GE.

Do not bother sending any emails to this professor, you will not get a response. My grandma was hospitalized during this class and I failed this class because I never got a response to a single email asking for extensions.
Lectures were completely useless, and she didn't explain how to use the design platforms well. Lots of reading and writings were graded pretty hard.

The class has a lot of work but it's all very easy and straightforward. Lectures won't help your grade in the class, just do the assignments and you'll be fine. If you don't know anything about video games you might have some trouble.

Lecture attendance was not mandatory and it was recorded. Be prepared for a lot of work because the class offers a lot. Read the rubrics! I had an amazing TA who gave extensions for homework. Good luck!
The workload for this class is quite heavy. I always found myself lagging behind on my assignments, and I was swamped with work. Do not take this class if you have a schedule that is already busy.
The structure of this class makes no sense. My specific TA is not helpful at all but I heard the other TA is better.

Before this class, I'd never taken a feminist class, and I was really nervous. Professor Kelly assigned us really great and informative readings, she is very very understanding regarding late/missing homework and offers extra credit each week. We only had two essays, and the HW was just reading, which was easy.

Professor Kelly could not be more boring and uninspiring. This was her first time teaching a class and it shows. Her lectures were completely pointless and by the end of the quarter there were only about 30 people who were showing up. It was a really easy class in terms of assignments/grades but you have to be a decently strong writer to do well.
Professor was very kind and considerate of students. Assignments were fairly easy and professor was pretty lenient. Overall good class.

This class taught me a lot about research, and I really enjoyed being able to research a topic of my choosing. I didn't enjoy the format of this class, however. We would complete readings before class and the lecture would just be quoting and talking about the readings, which tended to be dry. The professor is very understanding and kind, though.

Professor was really nice + understanding. However, a lot of your grade ends up being based on like 3-4 essays, and there's a lot of assigned reading too. Lectures were kinda boring and didn't help much (in my opinion at least).

Her power points are boring. Be ready to only be graded on a few essays. There is a lot of reading and annotating that you have to do. However, she is very understating when it comes to unexpected changes in life. Like getting sick and family issues along with mental ones. She will give you an extension. TA are also very helpful.

My favorite professor so far. Genuinely interested in what she's teaching and very invested in your engagement. MOSTLY DISCUSSION BASED, with pretty few assignments that are graded very generously. 

The readings were awesome (mostly political commentary and speculative science fiction), and genuinely changed the way I see the world.

If you think there's too much reading in this course, you've got another thing coming to you in your other courses. I've taken dual enrollment before and this class did feel like another English 103, but I feel like it prepares people for the amount of reading/homework is needed. She's very nice, but I've heard email responses aren't the best.

This class was bad for a number of reasons. So much reading, expected to watch whole movies and give your opinion on it before class. Doesn't respond to emails much. Group projects are awful. Whole class just felt like high school English all over again. Behind on discussions all the time. Be prepared to remember stuff from 2+ weeks ago.

NEVER responds to emails. A classmate got a condescending reply when informing her of a missed email. Mine were unanswered too.

She's unsympathetic to personal situations. I struggled to make it to class and was told I "don't have a choice."

She says CRWN1 is the most important class you will take (it's not) and gives a heavy workload as a result

Carolina was a great Professor! For Crown 1 she loved when kids participated so be ready to talk in class about the reading for each week. She does a lot of group projects so find some people in class you are willing to work with 1 on 1 for the whole quarter. If you don't mind participating in class and doing group work I recommend Carolina a lot!

Expects you to care about a required core class. If you're interested in the topic and want to talk a lot, very good I reccomend. If you just want to get by while doing the work, good luck. Mandatory attendance and requires papers to be hand written.  Speaks fast with a heavy accent so it may be hard to understand what she's saying sometimes

She's amazing. I had her in the Fall Quarter for the core class and she is so passionate about having us learn it's contagious. There were lots of group assignments and discussions, but she made them engaging.

When taking this course, be prepared to perform even if inexperienced. You must have time outside of class to meet with her in preparation for the show, but she is a wonderful professor who cares about her students. You cannot miss class though, especially near the end, but only a final reflection. Take if willing to use up free time.

this is a theater class, there WILL be a performance you will put on. HOWEVER, don't let this scare you, she is very sweet and will prepare you and the rest of the class to put on the small play. There will be rehearsals and some outside time will need to me committed, but it's fun! No one in my class had previous acting/theater experience.

Riano was a wonderful and very kind teacher to learn from! Although there was occasionally lots of reading hw, she doesn't check for annotations and just wants you to give a general gist of the work. Group projects make up a lot of your grade, as well as individual essays, but it's nearly impossible to fail as long as you do your work.

Your grade is heavily based on group projects and essays, but she doesn't grade very difficult so is very hard to fail this class. She was a great teach and always super friendly, would recommend anybody take her

Although she's passionate/has good intentions, these classes are unstructured, unpredictable, & exhausting. There is no way to predict what any day of class will be like. Takes forever to answer emails, never provided expectations for assignments & dropped them all on week 5/halloweekend w/ no warning. Also constantly interrupts students in class.

interesting class if you want to look at your life. this class helped with managing stress and learning to see other people's perspectives. sometimes it was intense--things we don't like to talk about--shame, guilt, fear--were explored without judgement. professor was cool.

This class got intense sometimes, but was good. I learned a lot about myself & made good friends. but this is def. not a usual class. be prepared to deal with feelings & the challenges of life. Class is better if you have the guts to share difficult things in your life, its between trauma bonding & love bonding... ;-) you learn you are not alone.

Participation in this class totally matters. If you want to learn abt urself and what makes you "you"--this is a great class. Be willing to talk and sometimes be uncomfortable. Some discussion topics make you rethink everything you know... Professor Berkley will meet you almost anytime and really cares. This class is worth it!

The class was good and Dr. Berkley was also a good professor. It is a lecture heavy class with some reading but all the material is pretty easy and makes you think about life. Had a few nice talks with the professor after the lecture and went to her zoom meetings.

Lisa was a good professor when I had her. She lectured with passion and always made herself available outside of class with flexible office hours. The course required a bit of reading which connected with discussions and participation.

Dr. Berkley believes & inspires her students so they can be their best. Course work is pretty minimal--reading, watching TEDTalks, listening to podcasts--the hard work is looking at yourself, the good & bad. Dr. Berkley cares & is always available to meet for office hours, even late at night. I got a lot out of this class.

The Professor was awesome! She kept the lectures entertaining while delving into deep topics and offering differing perspectives of looking at life. She always respected everyone's boundaries and made sure that people were comfortable to further conversate. Overall a great professor for an easy class that helped improve my outlook to life.

I took Lisa's class for credit. Politics aside, the class is very good. It helps students learn how to manage themselves and their lives. It's a fairly easy course. Show up, do the homework. Sometimes she has the class meditate. Sometimes she cries. Sometimes she's boring. But she cares immensely for her students.

Dr. Berkley is the best professor I've had by a mile and a half. She will challenge you, believe me, and all your prior notions about yourself. However she excels at walking the tight light between holding space and getting your comfortable with the uncomfortable. Where we could delve into the unspoken. Highly influential teacher.

I ended class with 95% on Canvas and was given a C! Professor said this was due to my low attendance, but never specified a weight for attendance on the syllabus AND she weighted it on canvas extremely low, so the entire quarter I was under the impression I had an A but apparently she likes to weigh attendance at over 40% and not let you know :)

Extremely unprofessional, she will yell at students for expressing their opinion and constantly interrupts. She may have good intentions but they are not executed well. Ruined my 4.0 GPA. Participation matters but it's hard to do that when the professor yells and interrupts, makes it hard to feel welcome. Sometimes political too, it's not good

This class doesn't allow technology, so you'll have to be engaged for the entire hour that you are there. Berkley is extremely passionate about what she speaks about, but often interrupts students when hands are raised. There are also sections which seems a bit pointless, and they are randomly dropped in the middle of the quarter.

Great class if you want to think more deeply about your life. Berkley's lectures can be intense, but she cares tremendously about her students and wants them to lead happier lives. As long as you turn in your assignments, you'll ace the class. Assignments typically consist of watching videos and responding to a prompt in a couple of paragraphs.
Terrible instructor, talks about her life all the time. Doesn't teach anything good at all.

She is one of the nicest and most understanding professors on campus. The class is super easy- not a lot of structure going on and no clear syllabus, but it is easy nonetheless. You start off with an A, do a decent job on all assignments and you'll keep it. She is very kind and understanding and you can submit assignments late if you put why.

Jason is a great professor and a really nice guy. He's always accessible and willing to help. I took ECE 171 and 173 with him, and both were great. In 171, there are multiple exams, homework, and 4 labs, which can be tricky depending on the TAs. In 173, there are just 3 labs and a final PCB project—no homework or exams. Overall, a solid experience!
Excellent Instructor! Gaining knowledge from a core contributor in this field truly enhances the learning experience.
Great professor with well-managed materials. He knows everything.

Compared material with my high school buddy on a similar course taught at another UC campus. Found that we covered much less with simple examples in class. Can see it from the "difficulty" rating. Not sure if I will survive Ken's 172 when I take it next quarter though. Most ppl are happy cuz it's an easy A but it ain't helping long term...who cares

The most amazing instructor I have ever met. He makes sure that you understand everything during the lecture. Homeworks are easy (if you follow along with the lectures). Aways available inside and outside the class. Very friendly and casual. I've witnessed students discuss concepts with him during the lectures, which is rare at universities!

Lectures were very engaging, with plenty of examples and easy-to-absorb information. Jason also speaks very casually during lectures which helps with engagement, prevents us from getting bored with the material. Midterm and final were very fair, very similar to the study guides with no surprises. Actually cares about us learning, big recommend.

This class was great! Material is pretty straightforward if you've ever coded in JavaScript, but the game projects are fun and give lots of room for creativity. Scope of the class is reasonable and due dates are flexible. Lots of little assignments that add up, with extra credit. Jim & TAs were super kind and helpful with all kinds of questions!

You can tell Professor Whitehead loves games. He is very knowledgeable, wants his class to have fun and be challenged with a solid introduction to game design. Would recommend for anybody even with the smallest interest in designing games, as Prof. Whitehead is a very experienced and well-respected individual.

I came to the class to learn about procedural content generation, and I was able to do procedural content generation when I come out. Very effective an instructor! But I do hope that sometimes Jim can go further than demo-ing in Unity, and give more insights about why he does certain things, and how things work behind the scene.

Jim was great and was usually always prepared for lectures. He oftentimes went over indie games and how well designed some of them are. This helped contribute to our game's design decisions. He met up with each team each week and gave critical, brutal advice. Not all of it was gold, but he definitely helped us (especially with art direction)

He is a nice guy, but should not be teaching game design classes. He gives horrible advice that drove our project into the ground. He doesn't understand games at all.  If you take any of the senior capstone classes with him, it would probably be in your favor to ignore what he advises you change about your game, which is to say everything.

Good teacher for Intro To CMPS if you need it for a GE or major. His class was very easy; notes were all online with everything you needed to know. In-class pop quizzes. Fell asleep many times, failed the second midterm, and managed to get a B in the class. Though keep in mind this is more about the history  of CMPS rather than programming stuff.

Jim is a really nice and helpful, teacher. If you need help on the homework or an extension for a week or so, he will definitely let have your time with the assignments. Really enjoyed being in his class. Highly recommended.
Best Class EVER! Got to play video games for homework, the midterms were pretty easy and Professor Whitehead was a very nice and approachable guy. A++++
Pointless class, dull lectures, don't use book, but an easy A.

THIS CLASS ROCKED! Jim is a great teacher. He knows what he's talking about. Game demos in/during class completely relevant to lecture, and they are all great games. Jim is obsessed with Shmups, but it makes a good inside joke. I had a great time in this class, and I am trying to be a TA next year.
GYM is AWESOM!! He let us play games in class and let us joke about his white head! We played on a console pretty much everyday!
SO MUCH FUN!  Not an easy class, but definitely worthwhile.  Lectures were entertaining and relevant to today's gamers.  Highly recommended.

Nice guy, very cool. obsessed with SHMUPS. the work is easy, the assignments aren't too bad. You can study for the tests for 1 or 2 hours and get an A. Making the video game is awesome, and the top 4 video game creation groups get prizes (Like an X-Box 360 for example). If you ever wanted to make a video game, take his class, especially w/ friends.

This guy wants to make the game design course easy for you, though he doesn't necessarily know all the answers. You can ignore what you get on the tests as long as it's anywhere near passing, the only thing that matters is the final project. You must take that project seriously - it's not "fake" like in other blow-off classes.

Jim is extremely nice and understanding. He's a great guy who really wants to make his class interesting. Those who took 80k and feel he was unclear or stubborn are wrong!  His notes spell out what will be on the test, he published study guides online, and encourages discussion on the various topics in class. He even let me make up a midterm!

Creating video games sounds cool. NOT with this guy. Very disorganized. Very stuborn. His test dont test knowledge. cool guy, but sucks as a teacher. he came 30 minutes late to our exam. had another exam a week before our project was due, and wouldnt push it back becuase he wanted to demo the projects(create video game) for the last few classes.

Whitehead is a very clear, concise teacher who really makes an effort to make the material somewhat interesting.  He doesn't try to trick you and the class is very laid back and, for an engineering class, really decent.

Really a good teacher. He's able to make sense of the many concepts taught in the course and doesn't ask tedious/picky questions on his tests. He requires many readings but that's a very positive thing. He's very effective from a truly educational perspective. Great teacher and person to talk to.
One of the better teachers in the CS department
No Comments
She is a great professor and is very funny. She is hardworking and very nice to everyone in the class. I would one hundred precent recommend her.

Although she is polite with words, her teaching was awful! Technically incompetent. I wish she'd also value technical reasoning over verbal reasoning. Don't be fooled by educational track; Learning and teaching are two different skills. Wish there was an alternative to this class.
Very difficult to work with. Please consider other courses and save your time.

The professor's class is great, and you can learn a lot from it. The assignments and exams are a bit challenging, but with some effort, they can be completed and you'll get good grades. The professor is very patient and kind, and she is the type of professor who chats with students as soon as she enters the classroom.
awesome

Very caring and understanding professor. Quizzes and tests are open notes. The only somewhat difficult thing about the class is the projects, but these are manageable with the help of all the tutors. She is easily the best professor I have had in UCSC so far.
Very cool professor

Professor Gilpin is an excellent lecturer. That said, the lecture material  felt a bit disconnected from the programming assignments. This class is designed around making different artificially intelligent Pacman agents. The programming assignments were very challenging and support was limited.

Took CMPM 120 with him. Awesome professor. Lectures are extremely engaging with frequent fun in-class activities. The homework is not too overwhelming. Grading is almost entirely project-based. Textbook not mandatory.

Pretty tricky assignments but covered a lot of material with a good amount of depth. Assignments were done as teams that can ideally cover your weaknesses as programmers, as frameworks switched week to week (some in Unity, PDDL, Python). Overall, excellent assignments with the right amount of difficulty.

Very high quality and well considered assignments. A lot of room for self-expression and problem-solving. All assignments were group based, but were set up to mitigate some of the usual pitfalls of group programming. Assignments can take a long time, but are lenient on grading criteria & plenty of support.
Class is mainly working in groups to create a game, but Markus is awesome. He has a super chill personality and his grading personally is also super light.
senin gibi hocanın anasını sikeyim orospu evladı ananın amına bacağımı sokayim
This class was a mess. The labs suck and the instructions barely help. Idk if she made the labs but they actually make no sense. Needlessly complicated at times.

I recommend going to lab section as much as possible, the tas are extremely helpful. Plenty of extra credit opportunities and even mini free points in most labs too. Labs are hard, can easily spend over 20 hours for the second half of class. Lectures are optional and almost no one goes, but was helpful to actually learn c.

Overall the professor put effort into engaging students with the lectures, however I cannot say much since she was injured for much of this quarter. 

overall this class felt like an online/asynch class. Quizzes and labs were online and I felt they didn't challenge critical thinking. They were very long, verbose, and often needlessly annoying.

She has a difficult class to teach, and she does a decent job. If you take this class, make sure to have: git.ignore, git pipeline, and your README.pdf files named correctly. If you don't know what any of that means, make sure to ask a TA and never, EVER edit a .h file or you are done for.

There is no midterm or final but there are 8 tedious labs and 9 quizzes

Grading is often up to the TA, "deductions at the TA's discretion" are the main reason for a loss of points. Requesting explanations for deductions is occasionally ignored. Luckily, there is enough opportunity for extra credit to make up for it.

Lectures not relevant to quiz
For the ECE 13 format, the class was okay. Just be aware of the labs and what needs to be done. Grading is very tough yet fair, with room to improve.

Un-empathetic and strict grading policy screws over students.

She will screw you over if you make a tiny mistake or submit an assignment an *HOUR* late.

In 167 it's mostly graded by the labs, so be make sure to allocate time for that and collaborate with others/TAs if you can! Love this prof, she's willing to make jokes about the material and is very understanding. Loves sensors and their design from the bottom of her heart. Nerd.

Overall: great teacher and nice/patient person to learn from
Professor Josephson's lectures are very engaging. However, this is a very project-heavy class - expect to spend a lot of time in the lab.

Probably the GOAT CSE16 professor at UCSC. You should probably plan your schedule to take this guy for discrete math since he only teaches it winter quarter. If you struggle in his class, remember it's 10x worse for other professors.

Professor Arden is a kind, easy, and helpful professor. The class is super easy, great grading criteria to get an A.  Discrete math was very easy to understand and practice with Professor Arden. 3 percent extra credit at the end.

First 60% of the class was a breeze, the Zybook is well done and pretty much all you need to get by in the class. Lectures varied in quality a lot and sometimes felt more confusing than helpful. Still, the very generous grading scheme makes this class mostly stress-free.

Prof Arden is the best CSE16 instructor at UCSC. The class usually gets considered hard, but his grading is extremely generous. Lectures are not mandatory, all slides online (and recordings). Zybooks readings are helpful. Most are graded by median of categories, so some bad grades don't kill you. And the lowest grade that qualifies as a C is a 69%

Owen Arden is a great professor to take for Discrete Math considering it is considered one of the harder CS classes. Everything is graded by the median (except for the readings which were graded by average) I did well on the midterms and didn't have to take the final. The zyBooks were very helpful and provided great explanations of the concepts.

There's a lot of homework but it's not too difficult to complete and is mainly busy work/reading the online textbook. The material can be a bit challenging, but Arden is probably one of the best CS professors I've had so far at UCSC. You can tell he cares, and I thought his lectures were well thought out and relevant to the course.

The material itself is dreadfully boring, to be honest, but Arden is definitely a good professor. He takes the median from each assignment group, so you can bomb a test or homework with little consequence. Exams are similar to material on the quizzes and Zybooks. If you get less than a B in the class, a lot went wrong.
Arden is lenient on grading, this class is very doable. Lectures can be dense and hard to follow though.

I didn't attend class, but the few lectures I went to were pretty good. The grading was very generous with the test category being determined by the median of the 2 midterms and the final. The weekly quizzes were very fair and the zyBooks were really helpful in learning all the necessary material for all testing. Overall great class.

One of my favorite professors I've had so far. Really reasonable, wants everyone to succeed but also learn. Used ZyBooks which was helpful, but also balances it with written homework for harder concepts so we get a better understanding. Lectures engaging and interactive. Enjoyed math for a quarter. I look forward to taking another class w/Arden.

Professor Arden was a great professor, his lectures were good and the amount of work assigned was very doable. We used zybooks to read the topics we're covering and also to do HW. There were weekly quizzes, 2 midterms, and a final. Doing the HW will help prepare for the exams. He does curve a bit at the end, which was great.

He was a caring professor that made the content easy to understand and was very open to questions. Homework is on zybooks/ a few written homeworks and has 2 midterms + 1 final. Lectures were a little long and boring at times, but overall great professor.

Owen really cares about his students' success in the class. He is really nice. The homework just consisted of Zybooks and a couple written homeworks. We also had a quiz every week and 2 exams + the final. The exam material was never too difficult and was straightforward if you did the zybook readings. Great professor and great class!

Mainly worked on this class asynchronously. Class is manageable if time is used efficiently. There are textbook readings that are extremely helpful in understanding key concepts for the class; Zybooks is very beginner friendly. Readings tend to stack and pile on each other; make sure to complete these readings throughout the week to learn material.

Pretty Good professor. His lectures are sometimes boring, but are still informational. The assignments were structured so that the median is your final grade. The assignments were easy to get a good grade on while we still learned everything we were supposed to.

The lectures are pretty dense but are recorded and posted online in PDFs. Programming assignments are tough but tutoring sessions are extremely helpful (Attend these). Midterm/final are pretty difficult and grading is tough on them. Owen teaches the class very well; you will learn, but you might get a lower grade than you expect due to the tests.

Professor Arden taught this class from lecture slides and assignments designed by a UCSD professor. He went way too fast through lectures and they did not prepare us well for homework assignments. Professor Arden created a hostile environment toward class participants. He would humiliate people who provided incorrect answers.
Amazing lectures, really cares about group learning / interactive lectures.
10/10 Proff
Arden engages with students and cares aboout students learning the material. Office hours are weird 15 minute blocks, but understandable because he is busy. Great teacher.

I needed to take an upper division elective class and stumbled upon Professor Sporka's graduate class. Professor Sporka introduced us to the fundamentals and foundations of game audio design using examples from recent works like Kingdom Come: Deliverance I & II. He uses zoom for those that couldn't commute to campus. Overall, engaging, & gr8 10/10
Tons of group assignments and grades a little harsh but overall the class was good

He is passionate about his class and teaching. But even if you attend all classes and do all the work he asks you to do, you are still unlikely to get an A or above. He is the toughest grader at UCSC that I have come across. All the best if you have him, don't get me wrong, you may still get an A!!

Daniel is a nice guy, but this class is awful. Multiple assignments were released that had issues with either the given code or the directions were lacking information. The two person groups for half the class results in you needing to do the work of two people when your partner does nothing. Midterm mean was a 66. This class feels AI generated.

Class is mostly group project based and covers a wide variety of topics, some more interesting than others. My favorite project was where we used A* for path finding. We also learned about MCTS and Genetic Algorithms. He gives extra credit for multiple projects. Definitely one of the most interesting CMPM courses with a passionate professor.

Tyler is a new professor at UCSC at the time of this review. He's a chill teacher that really cares about his students and gives very helpful feedback when playtesting your games. He's also nice enough to give real world examples of the games industry using his experiences from his own indie game company.
made me lose my love for making video games. i wish i had the time back.

Class is clearly very new, and poorly structured. Readings were interesting but assignments were unclear and unfocused, and broken up into lots of small parts. Final group project where they released new requirements in waves that made us have to rewrite the entire codebase. Glad to be done with this class and to never take it again

Enjoyed his policy on how code was allowed to be shared with classmates. Had a grace period for assignments and was very considerate with students. He likes sharing about his life in class. For the final project, it did seem like he rushed it all at once and made us do a ton of work in a short period of time. Course was easy, just time-consuming.

Bleh.  More homework for the sake of more homework.  Did you finish your final game when it was assigned?  Too bad, you need to take that finished game because I added a new intermediate assignment, split it into 3 separate pieces and then turn that in instead.  Mandatory section attendance even though you learn nothing in them.

This was a rare instance that I had fun learning how to program. Each assignment wasn't too difficult, but challenging enough to let you learn AND express yourself creatively. Assignments had very flexible due dates, and midterms and finals were low-pressure. Overall a great experience, and I feel prepared going into CMPM 120

Adam did talk about Twitter a lot, I learned more about the field rather than coding, which some people like, however it did not prepare me for CMPS 11 at all, but he is a very cool guy, I just don't think I retained anything from his lectures. He uses CodeHS for the homework which is cute but doesn't prepare us very well.

Everyone hates on Adam becasue he makes you actually learn. People we're upset that he didn't teach people exactly what to type into CodeHS, becasue instead he taught us how to program; the ways to think about solving problems and what computers can do for us. Made my next programming classes so much easier. Learned a lot form him. Great Professor.

There are two readings per week that does not relate to java and lectures does not teach you how to code. everything is based on CODEHS that requires you to make a whole battleship game within a week during the last week of instructional week. it's basically self teaching on CODEHS rather than him teaching. waste of time. could of learned itmyself.
I will literally dispose of every computer-type object I own and lead the most primitive lifestyle possible all because of how mad this class has mad me.

Adam is such a nice guy. His class is chilling. He uses codeHS to teach most of the coding. So it becomes your choice whether to spend time and pay effort to learn real stuff. Exams are not hard if you are willing to spend the time to actually think and search for the answer. The way he teaches makes coding friendly to new learners.

Adam is knowledgeable about his subject, but doesn't do a good job with actually teaching it. Nearly every concept was taught via the homework, while lectures felt irrelevant and like a waste of time. His live-coding is interesting, but for an intro class he goes to fast with too little explanation. At least the class was easy.
