Adam shows his passion for CS. While it was mostly online and the class seemed like a test for future CS classes, the class was worthwhile. This was my first ever computer science class, learning about how to program, what coding is, etc., and I feel what I've learned helped me how to program. He gives out lots of HW but it's worth it at the end.

Doesn't teach. He literally just showed us tweets and videos about programming during every lecture. He expected us to learn solely from an online program that gets difficult for those with no coding experience (like me!). Homework heavy. Pointless labs. I've learned nothing except that I hate coding. Somehow I still got an A but it wasn't worth it
Amazing professor!

Unclear on every assignment and grading criteria. Group projects didnt exactly correlate with what was being taught in class. Grader was tough but that can change depending on the quarter. Professor didnt even attend class for like 2 weeks - she had guest lecturers. I would warn people against taking this class.

This class was very unorganized. Sri's lectures were well prepared and she's obviously an expert in her own field, however, some of the lectures were not related to the requirements of the project. No final or midterms. The whole class is based on projects and group presentations. The assignment requirements are not clear at all.
I loved taking Sri's course. Super easy A, but also very interesting. You can tell that she cares about people with disabilities and her research proves that

This class has no midterms or finals. Instead, the class is graded 20% random quizzes for attendance. The quizzes are easy and based off of 3 short 5-20min that she assigns for every class. 80% are 8 projects that are worth 10% each and are due every Friday. They are very easy to do. This class is an easy A. Just show up and do your homework.

She only lectured for 6 hours the entire quarter, and barely understood the material she taught.  Worst professor ever! She seemed like she was forced to teach and that she hated every moment she had to be in class.

Most of the class was alright, but the last week was a nightmare. She gave this massive statistical analysis of a data set that was completely broken, and it took 3 of us 11 hours to make it open. The software we were supposed to use crashed 2 of our computers and didn't work on the 3rd.  Her rating would have been higher if this wasn't so broken.

Sri was nice and her lectures could be entertaining, but she didn't provide any incentive to come to class. Lectures were online, no real tests, just a couple homework assignments and a group project that we worked on outside of class. Left all the assignments and grading up to the TA which was frustrating as the TA never came to class.

this class was a complete waste of time. 60% of your grade is a group project that requires you to have CompSci and Psych students to fully complete. lectures were mostly her rambling, by 3 weeks in there were only ~10 of our 40 person class attending regularly, no textbook, and the midterm was just an excuse for the TA to get research data.

Sri is a really cool professor. She is really passionate about her subject and really knows a lot about it. Her class is pretty easy overall, but the project attached to it is not, super time consuming. Really nice person and cares a lot about her students. She's also not a typical engineering professor and she's very easy to relate to.
Homework was easy if you do the work, but a lot of busywork

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS IF IT'S NOT A PASSION. The content is not hard to comprehend, it's certainly fun, but the busy work due every 3 days is INCREDIBLY inconvenient if you have high volume classes/have a job. You barely have time to breathe. TAs and the Professor have been a delight, but I wouldn't exactly recommend.

I had more work for this class compared to my stem major friends and I'm not even a game design major. Don't take this class if you want a life or a will to live. Gives you a few days to do assignments and all the assignments are busy work and repeat the same info that the other assignments "taught" you. Over 14 assignments a week is crazy..

I find that I don't remember a lot of what I was taught in this course and that most of the homework was busywork. Dr. Wardrip-Fruin (or, at least, his graders) grades easy, however, so I do appreciate the compensation for the terrible format. He won't be the worst professor you encounter, but try to find another course if you hate online ones.

dont take class, too much hw, + teaches from recliner w his cat like why r u reclining and yet expect us to spend 45 hrs a week on this class, wants you to read his books and cite them, makes video games some academic and grueling english class. seems like hes just farming an easy paycheck to me by teaching an online class and having TAs do grading

This is possibly one of the worst classes I've ever taken in college. Way too much busy work, it's ridiculous. I didn't even know it was possible to make a class this terrible about video games.
Expect to be writing upwards of 6-7 discussions/annotations/papers per week. Please only take it if you need it for your major

This class was very easy, but has a heavy workload. Just do all of your work and you will succeed in the class. Coding can be difficult despite using beginner friendly programs, but the tutor was helpful.
Unwatchable lectures. Vast workload that takes 0 brain engagement. You pretty much get 100% on every assignment just for doing it. Required in person sections where pretty much nothing happens.
bro records his lecture vids while half asleep

As an AGPM major, I really enjoyed the class. Lots of readings and lectures but they're very interesting/insightful to learn about game design. We were given a lot of freedom with our final group projects and students could design their own games. Professor and TAs were helpful and easy to reach over the class discord. Recommend to other AGPM ppl.
Wish the CMPM 80K class were in person and not an online class.

As others have said, it's a lot of busy work. The (many) readings are interesting enough. The class is mostly led by the TA, though they and Noah are very accessible through Discord. Most things are graded on completion (annotations, writing responses, writing assignments). Overall easy class, just a little stressful over the 5 week summer session.

Took the class over summer. As far as I can tell, a lot of the negative reviews here are from non-game design majors. If you're a game design major, Wardrip-Fruin's fine. The video-lectures he provided were comprehensive for the material, and the class provided a good foundation for future classes. Be prepared for a large final project though.
atrocious amount of busy work, kind of condescending at times.

Easy content but just be ready to do a million assignments with no educational value. Deadlines are given for these million assignments so manage your time well. All lectures were long recordings, you don't really need to pay too much attention to it. Just a ton of bs busy work but an easy A
humiliatingly boring. This class gives me doubts as to what the university actually understands as "Game Design". Not worth putting too much effort in.

Never take his class if you don't HAVE to. Tons of work every week + weekly essays. Work due on Wednesdays AND Saturdays. He speaks incredibly slow. Hour-long lectures with an up-the-nose view the whole time. Lots of group work with tight deadlines to meet with your group; good luck if your schedule is busy. Should NOT be on the Best Bets list.

This guy must be one of the laziest teachers I have ever witnessed.The whole class is online and his only way of "teaching" video games are in 30-45 min long lecture videos where he talks so !@#*ing slow that you can genuinely understand him at 3.5x speed. If you have ever played a video game before everything this guy says is of little value.EZ AF
There is a good amount of work but if you start it early, you should be chilling. Don't wait until last minute :D. It should be an easy A+ if you put in maybe 5 hours a week.

Ridiculous workload for a low-level course. This class makes up roughly 80% of my workload each week, and my other two courses are upper divisions. The work is not difficult, it's just extremely time-consuming to the point that it cuts into the time I allocate for my other courses. If you're taking this thinking it'll be a normal GE, think again.

Lectures mostly follow slides. while you can miss lectures without much consequence if you study the slides well, if too many people start skipping lecture he may start giving extra credit/pop quizzes. Exams are straightforward, similar to slides and HW, and very similar to practice exams. Be careful to not lose points on HW, they're worth a lot.

Extremely straightforward grading system, 30% homework, 35% midterm, 35% final, with opportunities to earn extra credit on both exams. Lectures are based almost entirely on his notes that he provides on canvas, and we're allowed to bring these notes into exams. Material is explained clearly, and exam questions are never a surprise.

I am halfway through this class and all excitement for the topic has been drained out of me. If you ask a question in class, he will interrupt you and snap at you. Good luck if you don't understand something he didn't explain - he says it's intuitive, so it must be even though he skipped explaining it! Lecture is graded though so you have to go.

Clear organzation of the lecture, slides cover almost everything. Get ready for the hard exam compared to his homeworks. Even if attendance is not mandatory, he gives several extra credits for students who attend his in-class activities, so get ready to take his lecture, do homeworks, and get a good grade.
Teaching his first class ever, the lectures improved as the quarter went on, so kudos to Professor Wei. The class was difficult at times so make sure you meet with him or the TA.

Dong is a very smart guy and this was his first quarter teaching so I cut him some slack. Unfortunately, he cannot teach yet. That's not to say he won't be able to soon but this quarter was brutal. Our TA taught us everything and lectures were focused on theory but tests were all application. He made up for low student grades by giving extra credit

An excellent professor who explained some details of a math-heavy course clearly. Dr. Zhang regularly checked students' digestion by adjusting the lecture pace. Paying close attention during lectures is important, as his explanations often hint at concepts and problem types that appeared on exams.

Great instructor who provides clear, step-by-step derivations on the chalkboard and genuinely cares about students' understanding. Exams are fair with no surprise questions. He does spend a bit more time on linear algebra basics, which could instead be used to explore observability and controllability in greater depth.

This elective class is relatively easy compared with many other EE courses. Attendance is not mandatory (often low rate), and many non-EE concepts are introduced. Prof is flexible and easy to catch after the class.

Great professor! Posted all slides upfront, recorded lectures, fair exams based on examples/HW with no surprises. Clear project instructions, no mandatory attendance. Heads up: the course is a bit on physics/chemistry/material science rather than pure EE, so brush up on those topics.
Professor Yu is really good at explaining this subject's key concepts, which is his research area. He used a lot of concrete examples and geometric illustrating figures. Highly recommended!

Optimization part was superb, with many examples from boyd's book, and did in both analytical and geometrical ways to explain key concepts. It took the most time of the class, while the control part was rushed out in the last session.

This course should not be hard for those familiar with convex optimization. Professor showed lots of good examples to help students understand convexity. He often brought up geometric interpretations which are quite useful. The control part is not that much, he talked about PID control, swing equations, etc for power generation control.

Dr. Zhang is an excellent instructor. The course is well-structured, with the first half focused on convex optimization and the second on power systems. Though the power systems section could use more time, the material is relevant, and Dr. Zhang explains complex topics clearly. Highly recommended!

Professor Yu delivered clear and well-structured lectures, emphasizing fundamental principles with real-world applications. His detailed explanations of key topics (like LTI systems) and blackboard derivations were helpful. The second half of the course moved at a faster pace, a slight adjustment could further enhance the learning experience.

Words can't describe how cute Yu is. The cutest of them all. My fault for taking this class in college instead of middle school (such a rookie mistake). Very inflexible (why should he?). Often left confused after lectures (i should've just unconfused myself). Wondered if he even cares about this class (he's too good for this class). Overall, cutie

I'm taking this course whose subject sounds intimidating. Prof Zhang has been giving informative and helpful lectures. He explained hard concepts in layman's terms with lots of examples. Those explanations and insights definitely helped me overcome some difficulties by only reading Cover's book. Solid knowledge of probability is needed.

Overall an informative, challenging, and rewarding class. I highly recommend this course. He used relevant examples and applications when teaching theorems and coding techniques. This helped the material stick better than just presenting equations. An excellent professor worthy of top scores.

The lectures were captivating, filled with abundant examples and easily understandable information. Professor's speaking style was conducive to keeping us engaged and preventing any boredom with the material. It is evident that he genuinely cares about our learning, and I highly recommend his course. He also implemented a class curve at the end.
Prof Zhang provided insights and alternative proofs of certain difficult concepts, which are very helpful. He linked information theory with machine learning, good for CS students.

* Hardcore topic with unclear lecture (I would recommend slides from NYU or elsewhere)
* Many HWs, 10-15 questions per week. 
* HW+Project paper+Presentation. 
* No TA, no office hour recording.
* Unclear grading rubric, not listed on the syllabus.
Suggest: This course is abstract, please show visualization to help students understand the jargon

The homework is not very difficult, but the tests are 70% of the grade.
 I was able to do decent on the midterm and good on the final. He is a good lecturer and most of the content is straightforward. I learned a lot. Plus, the class is actually practical material.

Professor Tziavelis is a great professor. He teaches concept in a very clear way and provides many examples. Assignments are easy if you follow along with the lectures. HW is also very easy. Midterm and Final had some challenging questions but managable. Overall, learned a lot in this class.

Great professor! Lectures were very clear and organized, and the in-class examples helped a lot with understanding the material. Labs were pretty easy and the exams were fair and straightforward. Overall, a very supportive instructor who makes a challenging subject feel manageable.

Professor Tziavelis is an amazing professor and does a good job teaching CSE 180. I would recommend taking the class with him if possible. Grades are test-heavy (40% final and 30% midterm) but as long as you go to lecture and understand the hw you will have a good time. The tests are fair, definitely not easy but he provides past exams for prep
Amazing at lecturing! Class content is extremely clear
Most the content isn't hard, midterm is alright, final's challenging but his curve is amazing. Nikos is also very nice and his demos of SQL code are helpful to learning. Study the practice tests!

Nikos is an awesome lecturer. He uses several examples in class to make sure everyone actually understands the content. Really active on piazza and helping students with questions. Midterm wasn't bad (30%), final was tougher (40%) but the curve was a blessing. As long as you study, and do the practice tests he give, you should be fine.

Nice Professor, brand new too. I think this was his first class. Slides and stuff come from the last guy, but he's genuinely really good at teaching. Midterm and final can be doable if you study the past ones. Labs aren't too challenging.
Passionate professor, very easy curriculum. Reuse slides and homework assignments. exams are large portion of grade but straightforward and almost identical to practices
Listens to students needs well and clear communication. Lecture heavy and few things graded but exams are VERY similar to practice tests
Really liked this class and professor. TAs were also super great. Make sure you do your own work since the midterm and final are in person and worth most of your grade.
Curves very well

Nikos did a great job teaching 182 for the first time. He's super knowledgeable but just a tad boring - he just needs to make the class more his own. Your entire grade is basically your midterm and final. His midterm was very easy but the final was brutal. He did curve both exams. Homework was pretty chill and TAs are helpful. Just study!

I was apart of his first class at UCSC which was CSE182, very solid Professor, understood what he was talking about, always asked students in lecture for help on problems which solidified understanding. Taught material at a very manageable pace. The labs were not difficult, Final took all 3 hours, was difficult test but overall good class.

Great professor. Exams were a big percentage of our grade but very similar to practice exams. Labs were easy and enjoyable for introducing SQL. Theory focused class so not much SQL coding. He had amazing TAs who were dedicated to helping students succeed.

Nikos is a really good professor. Gave plenty of resources for practically the entire course (especially previous midterms, answer sheets, etc) Labs and homework assignments are clearly explained and due every two weeks. He is a great lecturer and you will benefit from attending in person, as he walks the class together through problems.
Good teacher, enjoyed what he does. He makes it seem like you won't need to work as hard as you actually have to to do well. Don't get behind.

Scott is awesome, his class was downright enjoyable. He can be a bit disorganized at times, but I found it endearing. He is a very nice guy and has a real love for the subject he teaches. I recommend the class to anybody looking to take computer science.

Scott's a good teacher and a good guy. Don't listen to whoever said he's a unfair grader; he was super reasonable (if not generous) with grades. He was fairly disorganized, so I imagine taking upper division classes with him could be frustrating, but he was fine for CMPS 12A. The class isn't super hard, but you'll get out of it what you put into it
Not terrible but pretty bad.  He's a really nice guy but a boring teacher and isn't great at explaining things.  Just reads old slides and lab projects are super hard

I really enjoyed Scott's class. It was a topics class and covered a variety of topics, all of which were applicable and appropriate for out general "theme" for the class. I will definitely take more classes from Scott in the future.
His teaching style was alright, and he grades pretty fair. I had a pretty easy time in this class.

Avoid him if you can, unless he's got a good TA that can make up for his incompetence. If you have to take this class from him, prepare to be doing ALOT of studying by yourself because he won't be teaching

I think he was a great teacher, he moved through the material at a good pace and spent a lot of time on each new subject so it wouldn't be confusing.  I'm not sure if what he teaches is too easy or if 12b is too hard, just watch out if you get 12b with Mackey after this class, you won't be prepared.

Scott is one of the worst teachers you'll ever have. cs 12A was a very easy class, once you understand the material. however, with his teachering everything is very confusing. He has no dedication, and no cooperation with students.
not good at teaching. reads off from slides during class. His final consists of problems that were never went over in class. Unfair grader.

Scott's ill, end of story. His uncanny clarity makes it very difficult for a student to not grasp the material. I never went to his office hours, but I asked him questions after class regarding programming assignments and he was extremely helpful. Great professor, ignore the two poor reviews above.

I didn't know my computer going into the class, and I barely know any more coming out.  He expected that we would know everything he was going to teach us.  Lectures were basically slides copies out of the text book, so very little point in attending.  The MSI instructor knew a lot more than him.
challenging without being impossible. Provided lots of practical guidelines and examples.

He's a great teacher. I've taken 2 classes with him and enjoyed both thoroughly. CMPS can be very dry but he is very personable and is not afraid to try interesting things in class. Also, regarding the cheating thing- he is upfront about his concern, but I honestly don't think he's any more "paranoid" about it than any other CS professor.
Yang Liu is a young professor. He is not focusing on teaching but on his lab. I have a friend in his lab and it is good. Take his class if you need it. It is a good experience.
Awesome courses, Professors and TAs. Extra credits help me a lot.

Lock your enrollment in before reading this page or you'll end up on the waitlist even with DRC priority. Yes, he is *that* good. He might give you a heartattack cuz how difficult some of the homework questions can be, but you

She's a nice person and seems to genuinely care about each student, but her grading is insanely strict considering this is just a core class. She inserts herself into everything we read, there's reading journals and logs where she grades extremely strict, quizzes were open book. All the other professors are SIGNIFICANTLY easier so I'd avoid her.

She was a very hard grader, especially when in comparison to other teachers. The lectures are very informative, and she is a very nice and compassionate person. You should expect to get a lot of work each week because she is very strict when it comes to the quality of your work.

Sometimes instructions are vague. She's a great lecturer and provides really in depth comments,

I really enjoyed her class because she wasn't strict on grading but she still hold a good expectation on what she sees as A+ work. My advice: put extra work on the topics you care about in the journals and less on the ones you don't really want to do.

Professor Carlstroem was great! She cares for her students and is very easy to communicate with. As long as you stay on top of things you will do well. The grading system is a little confusing, but she will explain.

The professor is really kind and accommodating. I found the lectures and the material to be really engaging. Participation is crucial. With a lot of reading and writing, the work easily stacks up if you don't start early. Great professor, but unfortunately is seemingly one of the most challenging core classes you could encounter.

Catherine was very nice, but the Core Course felt like an English class on crack. While some of the content was interesting, too much of it was hyperfocused on specific details only the professor was interested in.
one of the best professors ive had to date, super engaging and caring. doesn't put up will BS but put in the most basic amount of effort and you will get an A.

caring professor but has a very odd and confusing grading criteria. Cried a few times tbh. Participation MATTERS! she will call you out if you don't talk. really nice, but as someone who is shy, not for me. Lots of reading that is required for the next class talking seminar, kinda forces the conversation. Surprised I got an A.

I loved professor Carlstroem, you can definitely tell that she genuinely cares for her students, but you have to reach out if you need help. The grading criteria was vague and confusing sometimes but if you try your best you can def succeed. You have to read and write a LOT overall, but only a bit weekly so stay on top of it and it'll be manageable

She's sweet, but such a hard grader. You can participate in every class yet still get a B for that part. Also has a weird grading policy with checks and exes, so you don't know where you stand until the end. Instructions are not super clear for assignments. There are only a couple assignments and quizzes that determine your final grade.

She treats you like you're in elementary & is a VERY tough grader. The one thing I really liked about her though was that she made it very clear that she was always there for us if we needed someone to talk to. It kind of gave me a sense of comfort knowing that I had someone if I really needed it. She's a sweet person, just not the best professor.

Smart, interesting person that genuinely wants you to succeed. If you are disengaged the whole class, or do not talk a lot, she will mark you worse than the active students (as that's obviously one of the things she's looking for). Overall useful class, with the readings and analysis being interesting and useful, but get ready to read.

Catherine's a fascinating person, go to her office hours if you want to succeed! Participating too really matters, because she relishes in long discussions. However, discussions quickly go offtopic, and can drag the pace of the class down. Readings are intense and she expects HQ papers but gives insightful and clear feedback, offering rewrites.

I found that the reading and essay writing took an incredible amount of time and the feedback on the papers wasn't always clear. I felt like class time could have been managed more effectively; the class would get off topic and stay there for the rest of the time. Overall, the class was really high stress environment which I wasn't ready for.

Carlstroem is the smartest teacher I have ever had. She is incredibly knowledgable about almost every subject I could think to discuss with her. She is a hard grader but always allows for revisions. I became a better writer from 1 quarter with her than I did in 4 years of high school. She expects you to put in work, and the rewards are worth it.

Catherine was a really nice person. However, it seemed as though she was very disorganized at times. She was an incredibly hard grader  genuinely wants you to become a better writer. It was a lot of reading and homework. I would try and get another teacher for this class if possible.

Professor Carlstroem selects a wonderful choice of literature for the Cowell Core Course. She is extremely enthusiastic, smart & dedicated to her students' success. One caution: she assigns a large amount of work, so you need to read carefully and quickly for class discussions. Her comments improve your writing, so I highly recommend her class!
Her Core class for Cowell College is very good. She assigns a lot of work, but she also gives good feedback and lets you revise papers for a grade boost. The discussions are fun and interesting.

Great teacher, she runs each class as a discussion about the readings (which by the way there are a LOT of). Essays are a tad bit hard, but her comments are thoughtful and the revision process makes it easy to churn out a good paper. Only complaints are that she does tend to ramble and she refuses to give out actual letter grades.

Shes is very enthusiastic about the class and makes you think during class discussions.  The comments on our papers are very through, which is a useful tool in paper revisions. She's a bit of a hard grader, but gives you the opportunity to revise it so you can actually develop your writing and get a descent grade.

Literally one of my favorite instructors ever. Addi is a great lecturer and cool ass guy. This class really helps you take a moment to breath, think about your life, and gives you multiple avenues of coping with what life might throw at you. Class was always entertaining and easy to earn an A! def recommend if you r a thought daughter/son/child

Addi's lectures truly helped me to rewire my brain and improve the quality of my life drastically. He described this class as being a toolkit for your life, and I agree 100%. His lectures are as meaningful and helpful as they are hilarious. Papers for this class promoted so much thought and introspection and he always gave great, caring feedback.
great professional but more than that addi is a great guy! if you're sensitive and sheltered he might not be your type but otherwise you'll learn a lot from him TAKE A CLASS HES GREAT and easy A

The absolute best professor, maybe best teacher, I've ever had. Addi was genetically engineered in a lab to be funny and interesting. He is so grounded and so refreshingly blunt and honest, and hes also definitely a little crazy. Easy GE. Easy A. You're an idiot if you don't take his classes if given an opportunity. Legend.

I started this quarter feeling burnt out and disconnected, and this class became a safe haven for me. It gave me a grounding routine and something I genuinely looked forward to each week. It came at a time when I really needed community, and it inspired me to show up as a better, more intentional student. Thank you so much, Professor Addi.

Prof Addi is genuinely one of the most impactful professors I've had. Our class was split up into speech types/topics, with assigned groups. His setup was flexible, but I always left with great feedback on where I could improve. Overall, don't miss out on taking his class; you'll definitely walk away with real-world knowledge.

Addi has been one of the best professors / teachers I've had in all my years of schooling. He is beyond interesting, relatable, kind, funny, and intelligent. He genuinely cares about his students and their success. The topics we studied in this class are topics I implement in my everyday life. I 100% recommend taking a course with him.

Addi is the most interesting prof. I've had in my past 4 quarters at UCSC. Not one lecture left me bored and the readings/assignments were just as engaging! Addi is very easy to talk to which is very important considering the course content. He also makes time for students to ask questions and contribute to class conversations. Amazing class.

Prof. Somekh is kind, funny, genuine, and caring. He is able to connect with students on a 1-1 basis by sharing real life and personal anecdotes. In class, Prof. Somekh delves into difficult to discuss topics with ease, allowing students to participate, while also allowing space for them to step out of their comfort zones as needed.

Among all the classes I've taken as a third-year, COWL 65 has been my favorite so far. His teachings are very influential and allow you to look within yourself as a person. Addi is an awesome professor and really encourages students to reflect on themselves and grow as individuals. I highly recommend this class, and you will leave feeling renewed.

Addi is one of those rare professors that genuinely cares about his students. He has such a well-rounded outlook on life, and it shows in the way he teaches and interacts with his students. He's the type of professor who makes you a better student, communicator, and person. His classes are transformative & stay with you long after the quarter ends!

Addi was the absolute best professor ive ever had the opportunity and privilege to have experienced. His lectures are insanely engaging, inspirational and the teachings are lessons that'll you'll carry throughout your life. He has a strict no device policy but hes so cool you wont even feel the need. I would recommend this class to everyone I know!

If you are going through it in college, or just want to learn more about yourself, I'd 1000% recommend this class! There are weekly one page assignments where you get to literally write about yourself, and it's fun! All the concepts are interesting, and Addi is so dope and a great balloon artist. Please take it if possible, trust me :)

This professor is the best teacher I've ever had. This class will change your life. Take it now! I never wanted to skip becuse I was always laughing and engaged. Super easy grader and the papers are not difficult and he allows you to be very honest and creative. I would reccomend this to everybody!
Addi is so funny and awesome. You have to take a class with him. Twists balloons in class.

Great class! Lectures are engaging and feel like you're listening to a funny podcast instead of a lecture. He doesn't say anything too revolutionary, it's all stuff you already know if you're a human being walking on Earth, but he's there to remind you of these topics. Get ready to reflect on how you've been living, and ponder how you want to live.

COWL 66. Great professor. I wish he could teach ever class I need to take. No device policy seemed annoying at first but I didn't feel the need to check my phone once while he is lecturing. He deserves his job 100 percent. Genuinely interesting content and even more interesting personal stories and character. Great MF GE if you hate math.

Maybe the best prof I've had. Addi is hilarious, passionate, genuine. Made balloon animals/figures for fun during class breaks. No device policy, making class more real and engaging. Tons of guest speakers, all super interesting, I never wanted to skip class. Addi bases the class on student feedback, fixes what doesn't work & embraces questions

I loved this class, but more than that I loved prof. Somekh. He was genuine, sweet, funny. He did balloon breaks where he twisted balloons to entertain us. No phones and mandatory attendance, but I wanted to be there and pay attention. Weekly hw but adjustable if you just talk to him. light reading. Easy math credit, fun class, google him.

COWL 65 - Paradox, Meaning, Love was an awesome class to take. The objective of this class is to provide a set of tools for you to navigate the turbulent nature of life itself. Professor Addi Somekh does an amazing job in guiding you along his lectures and has student become introspective of the life they have lived so far.

I knew Gary since high school and was curious to take one of his classes. One on hand he is very real with critique, which I appreciate, but on the other hand he is way too close minded and has too literal a perception of poetry. He needs to broaden his mind.

He buys the books for you I had lit 90 as a ge. Hes the greatest hes funny and understanding. u cant fail his class. the most participation u have to do is read ur work aloud to the class, so speak like1x/class but is prob less than that.

Gary Young is a great professor and a great person. He unfortunately has to deal with a lot of arrogant young writers in his classes (which is probably normal in college creative writing classes), but he deals with any difficult students with grace and humility. I've always felt that Gary works hard to serve and be available for his students.

Gary Young is an incredibly rude and unprofessional teacher. He believes that all poetry should be literal (he loves to write about hay and apples), and doesn't believe in using personification, extended metaphors, etc, etc. He is surprisingly rude and crass, and often makes intensely uncomfortable comments to students of different experiences. BAD

Professor Young is one of the best professors I've ever had. He singlehandedly saved my writing from the mediocrity of academia three years of university had turned it into. A really great professor who understands students actually get sick and need a break sometimes (and will give you excused absences). Taught me a a lot about poetry.  :) :)
The most caring and helpful teacher I have ever had. An amazing editor and an amazing person. An incredible understanding of the human heart.

Gary was awesome! Helped my writing in a big way. Intermediate Poetry with him was amazing and my writing has improved more in one quarter than it ever has in my life. Go see him at office hours too, he's exceptionally helpful with work and will chat with you about your work and writing. Honestly, one of the gems of the UCSC Lit Department.

FOR ONLY THE SERIOUS POETS. I have taken 4 courses with Gary. He is by far one of my favorite professors. One of the most amazing professors and people I have ever known. He is kind, inspirational, and a pivoting figure in your work as a writer. He is encouraging and understanding. Take his class any chance you get.
Take Gary's class.  He's the kind of professor you go to college hoping you get.  An inspirational, kind, and witty man.  Also, a fabulous and touching poet.  Hell yeah Gary!
Gary is amazing. He will really help you improve the nuts and bults of your craft and technique, cut down on bad habits, explore new things.  He's totally supportive and a great editor.

Gary is knowledgeable, and quite an accomplished poet. Has a specific, literal take on poetry, and teaches from that bias. A very nice guy, and very helpful in allowing one to develop and individual style

Good if you don't know about grammar rules. Not good if you want develop individual style. He drops names like crazy, doesn't show any interest in students' poetry, and writing assignments are uninspiring. His interpretation of poetry is very literal.

great for those who want to learn more about the craft of writing, not great for those who think they can just turn in a creative story and get and A. This is an intro class for an actual major. You don't take a Intro Economics class lightly, you shouldn't take this class lightly either. Gary Young is very knowledgeable and helpful! Wonderful class
Too pretentious for words.  And his poetry is not that great, either.

Very knowledgeable and engaging, knows his craft, wonderful teacher. Structure of the class not wel suited for creative writing, but I understand this will change next quarter. Highly recommended for Lit and Writing students, but do not take if you think you can just turn in stories and get an A
funny british guy

Daniel is british and hilarious. i learned lots of neat facts and about cool experiments. tests were kinda hard (detailed) but everything else was fine. mandatory section. fun class, i tried to get my friends to come just because it was almost always entertaining.

Daniel is AMAZING. His lectures are amazing; I actually made my family wait a day for me at Thanksgiving so I wouldn't skip his Wednesday lecture. He's British and entertaining, and you tend not o forget his lectures. His tests are hard, but not the entire grade. I loved this class.
My favorite professor so far.  His tests were incredibly hard though.  The other assignments were easy and his lectures were always thoroughly entertaining.

I loved this class! Daniel is amazing. He is incredibly insightful and lectures were always organized and very interesting. There was very little work but you do need to go to lecture and read the textbook to do well on the tests. Even if you hate cognitive psychology, take this class for just for Daniel...i guarantee you'll end up loving it!!!
Can't say enough about the man. Very funny and very engaging. I actually looked forward to going to his class! He has been my favorite teacher thus far at Santa Cruz!
Richardson was an awesome professor. he made classes interesting and funny. I never knew Cognitive Psych could be so much fun! The tests were hard but assigments were quick and easy.
good

Richardson is one of the best teachers in the Psych. Dept.  The fact that I had little love for Cognitive Psych. but ended up finding his class on Embodied Cognition to be rewarding and enjoyable shows what a natural he is at teaching.  He will challenge you intellecutally, and you will find his lectures a pleasure to attend.
Excellent professor. Great slides, great presentation. Intro to Cognitive Psyc was one of those classes that I didn't want to miss, because each lecture covered so much interesting material.

Daniel plain and simple ROCKS!  His class is fun and his comments are sarcastic and crack everyone up.  We had ZERO interest in this class prior to the first day and ended up LOVING it!  Think Harry Potter in 20yrs and you'll have a good idea of Daniel.  His class was a blast and we learned a lot as well.  Highly recommended!

his intro to cog psych class brushed over a lot of material and rarely went into depth, but at the same time, he presented a lot of interesting information and experiments. lectures were always interesting and informative. i didn't mind the tests, but a lot of people thought the questions were too random.

AMAZING professor! Interesing topics. Uses slides for lectures and posts all of them on webct. 60% of grade come from 2 midterms(15% each) and 1 final (30%), the rest comes from section and homework assignments. Read only 1 chapter per week. Adorable british accent. Highly Recommended!!

For a Grad Student Teacher Andrew seemed to know his surgery next better than any professors I've had in the past. The class grade hinged largely on just 2 papers, and be ready to read some dense philosophy text. Took the class just to fill 2 units, If I had taken Andrews class as a frosh I might've ended up being a PoliSci major instead.
My favorite teacher ever. Period.

Andrew was an amazing professor who made the three hour slog well worth it.  He was attentive to his students needs, including emailing me when I was sick to make sure I was okay, and his office hours were very informative. I wish he was a full professor so I could take more classes with him as the professor, not just the TA.

Andrew is awesome! He always helps with any and all questions you have.  He does an excellent job of explaining course materials in depth, and helps you to apply it to real world situations.  He is by far the best TA at UCSC.  You can go to him for anything.  Super nice and never makes you feel inadequate in a given subject area.
graded me unfairly. Had a unpleasant time going through him.

She is literally so uninvolved. I submitted good papers to her and she still finds the most mundane things to criticize. I took wayyyy harder classes than this bs and got good grades she is not a great professor at all!

Took winter quarter 2025. Class format is 1x per week podcast/reading and short responses due Fridays. There were a few weeks where we had no assignments due at all. Grading is somewhat critical, read assignment prompts carefully. Overall not a difficult class if you set aside a short period of time every week (1-2 hrs ish) to complete work
Don't expect them to be nice because they won't be. The TAs are rude, if you turn in things late it's an automatic 0.
I took this class for a couple of extra units. Easy enough to follow along, but not heavy. Nice professor. I would take her again
Great professor. Be careful about which organization you pick in the beginning weeks but it's graded by like 8 things. FOLLOW THE RUBRICS.

One of the easiest classes I've taken at UCSC so far. Very clear criteria = hard to lose points. Important to choose a nonprofit you like or want to learn about!!! Modules have ~2 readings/podcasts that you have to briefly mention in the weekly assignment. TONS of extra credit opportunities in case you lost points on any of the weekly assignments.

This class in completely online and asynchronous. It was pretty easy to manage the work, but the TA's were insanely tough graders and didn't give feedback on what to fix. You listen to a lot of podcasts and do some readings. Your grade is dependent on weekly assignments about a non profit organization. Pretty doable class, but TA's grade tough.

She's a super super nice person/Professor, but the TAs do mainly all the work. It's not hard to do well as 50% is just showing up to the Model UN Zoom sessions. Sometimes TA grading is not the best as they expect a lot, but they really are helpful and super friendly. Also, lots of chances to raise your grade.

For being a PR GE, this class is easy. When I had an issue with my grading, it was accessible to attend the student leader's office hours and get feedback on what I could've improved on. I got C's and B's on my assignments and still managed to pass this class with an A. I loved Caitlin and my student leaders so I would recommend this class.

Cowell168 was an easy A+ for me since this class is only 2 credits the workload is very minimal and there are no exams/quizzes. It is also an online async and there are a total of only 7 assignments. You pick an organization that promotes social change, listen to some podcasts, and write a paragraph or 2 for the 7 assignments. Light work.

Way too much work load for the number of units that the course is worth. Entirely student led and graded! Imagine going into debt and sacrificing so much for school just to get an assignment graded by some 19 year old sophomore. Prof. aways complains about how much debt she's in because of her husband's art degree. She not a real professor imo.

Please whatever you do, don't take this class. I swear. I didn't take the reviews seriously and now that I am in this class I wish I never took it. Its IMPOSSIBLE to get a perfect on a homework assignment. The graders ALWAYS seem to find something wrong with it, even when doing the assignment with them. There are no makeups, or excused absences.
Never ever ever worth the interactions you will have to have with this professor.

She barely teaches any of her courses. Her classes are either entirely student run or asynchronous courses that she has never adjusted. The grading is unnecessarily difficult. I cannot comprehend how she is still employed by UCSC with the amount of complaints I have heard.

This professor is by far the most inhumane person on the UCSC staff. I have witnessed her drop students from her class multiple weeks into the quarter.She has absolutely no regard for how this affects your transcripts OR YOUR FINANCIAL AID. If you are on any kind of financial aid I cannot insist enough that you DO NOT take any of her courses.

This asynch class was a very easy A for me, we had like 8 assignments in which we had to write 2 paragraphs based on the prompts/our organization. The professor was very nice and gave good feedback, she didn't really do much but I think it wasn't really needed for this 2 credit class.

The professor herself barely runs this class, but it's been by far the most unnecessarily difficult class I've ever taken (especially for two credits). The class is horribly disorganized and run entirely by students. I've heard this class used to be an easy A, it is NOT anymore. Don't bother with this class if you don't have to, it's ridiculous.
Taking the mock trial class for 2 credits and it is absolutely too much work. It is entirely student lead (terrible) and has way too much work for only 2 credits. Don't waste your time.
The class was pointless, so I don't really blame her for anything. It was really easy and it fulfilled a GE which was great!

I had a really good time in terms of classwork, but other students in the class found they had a difficult time. Make sure that you pick an organization that revolves around social justice and activism otherwise assignments will be tricky to do. The podcasts we listened too weren't bad, sometimes just time consuming. Overall a decent class for me.

Class is very work heavy, lots of work, teacher is kind, just the amount of work is crazy, Todd cares a lot about this class. You dont really need to speak, but he may randomly call on you if no one else is answering his questions. Class is very easy to pass, work is easy, just very time consuming. No tests, quizzes, just tons of reading.

Super kind professor!! He really cares about you, though there is a LOT of reading for this class. The main assignments are journals based on the reading which aren't too hard but do take a bit of time to complete. His kindhearted nature makes up for the work though

This was a new class! It was awesome, Tues lectures we usually engaging to some degree, though he did make you think sometimes. Thurs you cooked in small groups then ate together to build community, that was really fun! There were exit tickets but they weren't hard! Most textbooks were provided. Todd is very accommodating, just communicate with him
Really nice and thoughtful teacher. My only dislike about his teaching is how he assigns A LOT of busy work, however he is extremely generous with deadlines and a pretty easy grader.

he's nice, but he yaps way too much. he cares a lot about participation. he has favorites (usually the ones that participate a lot). he assigns HELLA homework too so be prepared to stress yourself out. he does have two deadlines, a soft deadline and a hard deadline, but it takes me a long time to do the homework for this class (usually 10-15 hours)

Basically guaranteed A as long as you do your work. He takes late work up to a week without docking and is very understanding if you need more time. Grades on participation in class but you don't need to participate much to get a good grade. Attendance is mandatory and lectures can be a bit slow but overall a good teacher for a useless course.

Todd is a very understanding and compassionate teacher. I appreciated the effort he put into grading my assignments, he was always grading my assignments within hours of my submission. Be prepared for a lot of reading journals but if you keep up you'll be fine as Todd picks interesting and engaging topics.
IMO best professor here

Very clear and thought-provoking lectures and is very good at getting the class involved in discussions. Even as a stem major who doesn't particularly enjoy humanities subjects, I enjoyed his class a lot and found it very interesting and engaging.

Professor Thrope was great throughout the term. There is a lot of reading, but that's the nature of Core Course regardless of professor. He readily gave extra credit on the weekly reading assignments, and was very flexible with due dates. He definitely appreciates participation in the lecture component of class.

Although Thorpe assigns a lot of work, he genuinely cares about his students and is very accommodating. His class requires a lot of participation to encourage students to get involved in discussions. Make sure you stay on top of your assignments and readings. I would HIGHLY recommend Thorpe for anyone planning to take COWL1 :).

Todd cares about his class and approaches it from a humanistic standpoint. He's there to help you develop into a university student. Todd will give you individual feedback on almost all your work. Great professor to a lame mandatory course.

He is a great professor and you will do great in his class as long as you read the texts. There is a lot of reading, so manage your time well to get them completed. He offers plenty of extra credit, which helped me a lot. I didn't ever participate and I did fine in his class.
Todd is a friendly and knowledgable professor. He teaches quite well, but his lectures can sometimes drag on. Furthermore, he is pretty disorganized. Generally I had a great time in his course.

If you want to do well, you HAVE TO participate in class. He is all about participation in discussions. But overall a super cool person to talk to, and really understanding. Did have a few times when we had to read a book in a day or two, but besides that homework wasn't bad.

Todd was such a fantastic professor. His class is easy if you really put in the effort and show it. He is super easygoing and helpful; if you have any issues, he will do anything to help. Lots of reading, but assignments were straightforward, and discussions were interesting and engaging.

Had Todd for COWL 1 in in Fall 2020. Super nice professor, very caring, and very understanding. Lots of reading and regular reading journals, but none of the material was difficult to digest. Participation is huge, so be sure to speak up in class. Attend his office hours if you can. He's fun to talk to, and it shows your interest in the class.

He's super nice and understanding. He gave weekly reading journals but gave you extra time if you needed it to turn it in. The lectures were great, at times repetitive, but he gave everyone a safe space to voice their opinions and feel heard. If you were struggling he always made sure to reach out and give you a hand.
Very understanding professor who is willing to work with you as long as you try! Office hours are very useful and he is not a tough grader!

Do the reading even if it is optional. Listen to all lectures. Enjoy the culture through the course material. The professor does a good job separating Punjabi from Sikh culture. If you really want to learn about Sikh culture take this class. The music in the lectures was the most enjoyable part for me.

This professor did almost nothing to keep this class alive. There was barely any communication on their part. We didn't even learn of the final until the beginning of finals week! It was insanely unorganized. Professor Nirvikar Singh in the lecture videos is who really taught this class.
I think this was an essential course and it was obvious that the professor cared deeply about the subject. I wouldn't say it was difficult, but you did need to put a lot of work into the course.

super easy and interesting 2 unit course. it was async so it was stress-free. for the whole year we had 3 discussion posts (only 2 required to complete), 2 super short 5 question quizzes, 1 final paper. 2-3 Lectures posted a week, 20-40 min long. depending on what grade you're aiming for you could probably get away with not watching them all.

Took winter quarter 2025. Class format is lecture/associated readings with short responses or quizzes due 2x per week Tuesday and Thursdays. Professor is very kind and provides good feedback on assignments. Lecture videos are short and well planned out to summarize and contextualize topics of the week. Final is 3-5 pg paper and short project

Short lectures, weekly readings, 200-300 word prompts, and bi-weekly quizzes. The professor is very understanding and cares about your learning, always makes herself available and willing to walk you through assignments.

Professor Gallagher is a really inspirational and understanding professor. She understands that life happens she will provide as much support as she can. I would highly recommend taking this course or any course with Tricia,  if you want to explore more of Ethnic Studies and how it correlates to the K-12 education system.

Loved her. She gives a solid amount of reading but overall great teacher and lectures as well. Discussions are what we mostly do but they do require an amount of effort, she is caring and wants to hear Dif peoples opinions which is nice, be prepared to have ur mind expanded after lectures for dis class.
dedicated, impassioned, incredibly caring professor who elevates the discussion in her facilitation-- thank you, Christine!

Christine is AMAZING. She is my favorite professor at UCSC. The class was reading heavy which was to be expected but Christine helps students actively engage with the text and understand what's being read. Her tests were pretty easy as long as you do the reading but can be tricky if you just skim through. She helps get books if you need also.

Professor Hong was on a tight schedule and did not waste any time. Some found it difficult to understand the material during lectures. Only three writing assignments. There were pop quizzes usually once a week for readings from the prior week which was difficult at times. Intense amounts of readings for an intro class.

She gives SO much reading!! there are frequent pop quizzes. lectures are very VERY heavy, and hard to understand. You have to come in and sign up as attendance and she doesn't let you leave early. sections are helpful, no midterm, open for office hours.

Lecture heavy, sometimes unorganized and does not post slides on canvas. So, I would recommend going to class to understand the concepts. Also, be prepared to read. Grading consists of three discussion board postings/responses, weekly pop quizzes, participation, and a final. The final is not clear, but she had a review session (no study guide).
She talks forever and puts me to sleep. Very easy on grading though. Caring, understanding, wants to see students perspective. Tons of reading, youll never finish it all.

She hosts an interesting class which engages the students constantly in discussion based lectures. You have to attend class to learn material because she doesn't post it on canvas plus she talks a lot so you'll miss information if you don't go. She's easy to talk with, has great insight and grading feedback, and loves to hear your point of view.

Interesting lectures. Provides a lot of insight into what she is teaching. Will randomly call on students though to give feedback so be prepared. Attendance is mandatory but the class overall isn't difficult. Be prepared to read and write about what you're reading about.

Christine really deserves a higher rating. Shes amazing. Shes very caring and kind in and out of the classroom, shes very knowledgeable as well. She scanned the entire reader for me  when I told her I had not yet purchased it. Shes friendly and easy to approach, I loved her. Not much work was assigned, and if it was, it was easy. Take her class

Christine & the TAs introduced interesting discussions not just about LA during the 1992 riots but a overview of race relations in the US over the past. I found this class to be very intriguing & very boring at times. Lectures really depend on class participation.1 mini & 1 big essay,3 short blogs & final makes up grade. All fairly graded. Easy GE.

Christine Hong is a brilliant thinker and a compassionate educator. I learned so much from her lectures. Be ready to think critically and deeply. Definitely talk to her in her office hour: she'll give you the best quality feedback.
Professor Hong did an excellent job. Would highly recommend.

Christine provides an open, interactive atmosphere to learn about racial topics in literature. She provides tons of helpful feedback and is a fair grader. She definitely has mad respect for her students and is just a genuine, kind human being. She's also hilarious and relatable. Would definitely recommend taking a class from her!

Christine is an AMAZING professor, she has opened my mind to so many new concepts and has taught me to think critically about the world. I really don't understand these other negative reviews because she is probably the best professor I've ever encountered. She is incredibly knowledgeable and really reaches out to her students. I highly recommend!
Christine's class was really exciting. I feel like she has to go kind of slow at the beginning to allow students less familiar with critical theory, but she is knowledgeable and funny.

Huh. I'm seeing a lot of negative reviews for Hong, and...  I don't really understand why. Honestly, she's one of the easiest profs I've ever had, and this was my SEMINAR. She gives really good feedback, and goes out of her way to help you do well. Seriously, ignore all the losers who say otherwise. She's great.

Christine is one of the few professors on this campus that genuinely cares about her students; she has provided me with more academic feedback than I have received in all four years  at UCSC. This class was cohesively productive, and I would recommend that everyone take a class with Christine. I think she's an absolute gem on this campus.
Extremely knowledgeable and excited about the subject she teaches.  Also possesses an admirable dedication to social justice, particularly issues pertaining to racial inequality.

I'm not quite sure why all these poor comments are posted.Christine is a wonderful lecturer and had her students incredibly engaged in class. She has wonderful perspectives on history's connection to literature and really wants her students to succeed. Perhaps my experience differs because I was in a smaller classroom environment, but she was great

Andy is by far the best professor that I've had at UCSC! This class was so time consuming but I learned so so much from him. Andy just cares so much about what he is teaching. He is engaging and passionate. This class was hard just because of how much work it is but the topics make sense if you show up for lecture and put the work in!

Very sweet guy, loves his student but there's a lot of homework. You have homework sets once a week but they take about 2-3 hours as well as a lab that takes about 1.5-2 hours and you will still have homework/ labs on midterms and before finals as well as a large tech report. But if you're up for the work he is a really cool guy.

Andy is one of the best professors I've ever had. This class was incredibly time consuming and difficult but I learned a ridiculous amount. This class and Andy's teaching are absolutely amazing. Take this class if you can!

I seriously respect Andy so much, he really has a passion for Earth Science and Geology. He definitely knows what he is teaching about and really wants what's best for students! Would 1000000% take another course with him.

He's a wonderful teacher and an even better person. If you have to take a geology class, try to take one with Andy. I've never really liked earth sciences, but he def made me consider switching my major lol. He is clearly passionate about the subject, and that is reflected in his lectures and materials. Funny guy too !
Best professor Ive ever had

Andy is a fantastic professor who is as passionate about teaching as he is about his research. You get exactly the grade that you work for in his class. He's very funny and also communicates topics perfectly. The class field trip was so much fun and one of my best memories from this school. I owe a lot to him as he helped me plan out my ES minor.

Seriously my favorite professor. Yes, I think I'm switching into Earth Science just so I can have him for more classes. Thank you for being such an inspiring, passionate, wonderful teacher Andy! What a great guy!
Andy is the real gem of a department that's already full of gems. Take any of his classes, and you won't regret it. A real kind of "makes me wanna switch my major" class and professor.

Andy is an amazing teacher! He's passionate and geeks out a lot which is funny but also educational! You learn SO much, and he teaches it effectively that concepts become second nature.  Yes, his class is hard. With the lab, homework takes 2/3 hours per assignment, but it's helpful and interesting. I took this as a GE and greatly enjoyed it.

Be prepared to work for your grade. Make flashcards and ask questions... that being said- Andy is such an amazing professor. He's approachable and really has a passion for teaching and explaining concepts. I'm really happy I took this course as an undergraduate.

Andy is so enthusiastic, you can't help being interested. He just really loves rocks! Lectures are clear, all slides and lecture notes are uploaded online. He makes it very clear what information you need to be responsible for. I would sign up for any other class he teaches.

Andy is awesome. He's very passionate, peppy, and practical. The class is well organized, although the problem sets/labs can be very wordy +  confusing. Intimidating course, but try to keep up because he's very fair. Demanding course work, the oncoming assignments are relentless. Cute proff, wish I met someone like him during college /3

Andy is hands down my favorite professor I've interacted with so far at UCSC. As an EPS major, I took Eart10 for major credit. Andy is willing to go above and beyond to help any of his students. If you ask for help, he will be there for you. Nicest guy. 1010.

Andy is probably one of the best teachers I have had at UCSC. He is very knowledgeable of the subject and presents the material in a way that isn't boring. The midterm and final aren't too hard as long as you pay attention in class and do all the assigned hw assignments. I highly recommend taking a class with Andy Fisher!

A GREAT professor who is always willing to help and answer questions. He makes the material very engaging and fun with his stories and the "celebrity daycare centers." The tests and assignments are easy if you attend class and section regularly. I would definitely recommend his class.

Andy is amazing. His lectures are engaging and interesting, and extremely well organized. He added fun anecdotes (why streets crack, celebrity daycare centers, etc.) and really sets the course up to be accessible to anyone. Would definitely take another class from him.

Andy is an incredible teacher. he's funny and incredibly knowledgeable. His thoughts about celebrity daycare's are hilarious. If you try i guarantee Andy will ensure that you do well; if not, good luck. Deff take this class if you are willing to put in the work.

Andy was a great teacher, but dont take this class if you think it will be an easy A. You have to work and the material does not come easy. There is a lot of material and jargon you need to know. Really great teacher but only take if your interested in the material

Andy is a great guy. He is super helpful and nice, and very funny. His Geology class is great. Like everyone said, there's a decent amount of work and you have to go to section, but it's reasonable, interesting and relevant. He's totally got the hot nerd thing going on. Makes lectures more interesting for sure. Take this class! :)

He is very well respected, well known, and he loves to play his guitar and teach. However, if you have a learning disability/adhd/autism and you ask for your DRC accommodations, be prepared to either be called a literal idiot by him or having to FIGHT FOR YOUR DESERVED ACCOMMODATIONS.
Great professor, lectures move quickly but you'll adjust to it. Do practice questions and you'll do fine on the quizzes. Definitely recommend.

Professor Weiss is AMAZING! I would take him for the rest of my chemistry courses if I could. He is super chill and understanding, and the class is very much structured for you to learn the material rather than just go in and get a grade :)
Chill guy, always good vibes in class and high quality lectures. Quizzes were very reasonable difficulty and lowest gets dropped. Aleks is mad annoying though but definitely a good professor

He was amazing. He explains every topic clearly and provided many examples during lectures. He gave many practice quizzes and worksheets. Also there are no midterms, just quizzes that happen every two units. He provides a formula sheet and you get an index card as a cheat sheet. For the final you get two index cards.
Very Chill Dude

He is a great professor who cares about the subject he teaches. Try to sit in the front and be attentive.  He tends to get tunnel vision and not call on people to ask questions in lecture so have some patience when you raise your hand. He is more than happy to talk to students after class and work with people to improve.

TAKE HIM IF YOU CAN!!! he's an amazing professor and he's really understanding. His exams are exactly what he says: easy and straightforward. The practice exams are harder than the actual exam and students walk out literally telling him it was easy and he's glad. Everything is straightforward and his grading is always in a timely manner!

Professor Weiss is a great professor and teaches you everything you need to know for exams. Aleks can be very dumb sometimes, but personally I felt like quizzes are easy and barely needed to study. The class gives you all the tools in order to succeed, but the lectures can feel boring and could be more engaging. Otherwise, you're in good hands.

Works on problems w/ you when goes through his slides. First day of class did experiment in class + one a week since. All lectures posted on Canvas. Easily accessible in office hours or after class and willing to help. Small quiz every 2 weeks w/ final. ALEKS is 1000x more difficult than any quiz/in class and sucks. Overall, cool guy.

Ok so I took this class over summer (5 week session) and it was not super fun. Tests were difficult. Most of the topics I would study wouldn't be on the test and I would end up being pretty stumped. Id say take the class if you just want to pass (if you want to not really try or studying a little bit) (which is what I did). 
Aleks did not help .

He's honestly super great, practice tests and lecture example problems were exactly like actual midterms and final which is amazing. He's very clear in what he's teaching and he's easy to understand. Also super chill guy

He is AMAZING! The grading is pretty light, with weekly discussion posts, vocab, and quizzes. In the summer, optional Zoom attendance even counted for extra credit. Overall super easy course, if you are looking for an easy, low-stress GE, this is it!

this class made me crash out so bad. i don't know who lied and said chem 3c is the easiest in the gen chem series. it is definitely not. tests are weighted the most. do not take this class over the summer. final was two days after the second midterm with barely enough time to study. aleks and lectures unhelpful for preparing for exams.
Tests were terrible: two midterms, one final. The class average for the midterms was below 70%. The test material does not match what we practice on ALEKS. Do not recommend.

Very clear grading system, 4 quizzes (lowest gets dropped) and 1 final. ALEKS also takes up a good chunk of your grade so if you stay on top of it and study enough there's no way you don't pass. Notecards available for all quizzes/the final. Great and kind professor, probably my favorite from the 3 series.

This class was easy; there were no midterms. Only four quizzes and a Final, he provided a lot of practice problems for the quizzes, so as long as you studied, it was easy to pass them with A's. He also let us use an index card for the quizzes. Attendance for discussion sections was mandatory, and there was also ALEKS hw, but it was manageable.

Peter is an amazing professor. He explains concepts very well, and never tries to trick you on his exams. No midterm, just four quizzes throughout the quarter, and he drops the lowest score. Class is really straightforward, and very easy to understand.

Easy A, asynchronous. Has some interesting topics, but the lectures are from a previous professor (boring). About one discussion post a week, open note midterm and final. There were also "Mandatory discussion section Zoom meetings" for extra credit.

If you are looking to focus on major courses and just need an easy class, take this.
Good lectures that prepares you for the tests

The late policy was too strict. If you were late and missed the attendance quiz, she would tell you thats too bad, its for people that come on time, I look forward to seeing you on time next class. She had complete disregard for those that lived off campus with difficulty getting to campus sometimes with the inconsistent bus schedules.

No python experience and/or plan on skipping the lectures? Don't take this class. Seriously. Grading criteria for the HW, project, presentation wasn't clear. However, 5% extra credit for discussion attendance, extra credit on HW 1, and parts of HW Q's are lifted from the lecture notes. Hard class, but doable if you put in effort.

This class was one of the most difficult classes I've ever taken. The lectures are so dense that you don't have time to understand what you're writing down. Her classes are so boring and it's just her talking to you for the entirety of the lecture. They cover very little for tests and quizzes. Midterm and final preparation is little to none.

The lectures were not helpful at all to do the homework. The homework didn't have any structure. There weren't any good examples or explanations for what is going on. She did not answer questions in class well, she would just repeat your question back to you. Overall she looked confused half the time. Also, this class should require prereqs.

Homework is weekly and 50% of your grade but has almost nothing to do with the actual material discussed in lecture (the homework is stats). Lecture notes will only be useful on weekly quizzes and midterms. Lectures are dense but interesting. Definitely attend Section and try to get one early in the week, or else you will be lost on the homework.

Lectures are dense and are hard to relate to homework. Due dates were stressful because office hours were only long enough to cover 1 or 2 questions about the homework. It felt like I was not able to do the homework without attending office hours with the professor and TA, because it was impossible to complete with only lecture notes.

Lectures were difficult to follow and hard to apply to problem sets. About 10 people dropped the class by the second week of the quarter. Even if you attended office hours, problem sets were difficult to complete by the due date.
while shes very nice, this isnt an easy GE at all. Tough midterm and final that arent curved, as well as somewhat challenging homework assignments that build off each other

very dense lectures and makes it very difficult to understand. The homework doesn't reflect what is learned in class since it is mostly stats. Weekly quizzes have questions that ask stuff we didn't learn and it asks theoretical situations which are not fun. she's super into her studies but for an intro class its hard if you don't know anything.

She's nice but this was the most boring class I've ever taken. Don't take if you want an easy GE. The homework builds onto each other so if you miss one, your whole flow is screwed. Lots of math and physics talk, you definitely need to know the knowledge beforehand. Dedicated my entire life for this class, it was walking on egg shells,Save yourself

This is a good class for anyone who is genuinely interested in pursuing a career in meteorology. I took this year as a first year student for a GE requirement. The expectations for math and science background were unrealistic for the average student taking this as a GE. Our final average was around 50% and it was not curved.

Feldl is really nice and obviously cares a lot about what she teaches. I found her lectures hard to follow and it seemed like she expected you to have so sort of knowledge on the topic before even entering the class. The midterm and final were brutal with no curve. I struggled a bit, but that wasn't her fault obviously.

Professor Feldl is so sweet and knowledgeable about weather and climate, however, I found her lectures difficult to follow if you don't have a decent amount of knowledge about earth sciences going into the class. Homework was pretty easy with the help of the TA, but tests are pretty intense. She is really good at answering any and all questions.

Nicole is beautiful inside and out. She is clearly passionate about climate, and is fantastic at teaching the concepts of atmospheric science. She is very accessible outside of class and the hw is the perfect difficulty. My one complaint is that a lot of the code used in the class is very difficult to understand, and not explained the best.

I took this class for a GE and ended up loving it so much I almost switched to earth studies! Professor Feldl is incredibly passionate about the subject, and her excitement totally shows, in a positive way. Not too hard if you go to lecture and section. Also, she's obsessed with clouds and it's pretty funny.

Prof. Feldl is really nice and lectures aren't boring. I took this class for a GE requirement and it was good. It is physics/math/statistics based so be ready for that. Lecture is pretty important. Homework counted for 35% of the final grade as well! She also curved the entire grade scale as well so if you got a 70% in the class, you got a B!

I don't take him unless you want a bad grade. I had been trying to email this guy for weeks, and he won't respond or explain how I went from an A+ to a B-. Thanks for giving me a bad grade with no explanation. Super happy about that!

Each year it switches between Phoebe and Patrick. Avoid taking it with Patrick if at all possible. It's not necessarily the material (which is very difficult) but Patrick just didn't teach the class well. Midterm has an avg of 40, 60 being the highest. Final prolly had similar results given that so many ppl failed he's holding it again in August.

One of the few professors at the university that still truly care about his students and their future. It is a touch class, but if you rise to the challenge you will certainly grow intellectually and acquire lifelong skills. Office hours were great and I could usually knock out the problem set during them.

ESCI100B is a tough class and Patrick's strict, by the book teaching style made it even harder. His lectures were mostly him talking and writing on the chalk board instead of lecture slides and concepts were difficult to follow. He is NOT flexible at all (you get one extension only for the whole quarter) and the homework is extremely difficult.
Y'all know the scene from mean girls where Regina George writes in the burn book? That's all I have to say about this professor. If you're not religious, pick one and pray.

I do not recommend this class. This class hardly qualifies as a CC GE, and the content doesn't discuss any other cultures. Participation is mandatory, unless you want to lose 1% of your final grade for each time you don't go. Final was confusing and don't expect to be able to see how you did on it as prof removes access to you grades afterwards.

take this class if: you have ebt/want to spend 50+ dollars on groceries every week and already have a foundation in science. This is the first class in my entire college career that felt like the closest thing to a highschool classroom.  he makes students feel stupid for asking clarifying questions and doesn't even publish quizzes on time.

Please take another GE if you are looking to fulfill CC. Nothing about culture was talked about in lecture the entire quarter. He was very rude at times when students asked simple questions as if he were annoyed. Regarding grading, he completely terminated the canvas course so we weren't able to see our final grades. And he is ghosting students.

Tech-challenged prof makes us pay. Pre-lecture quizzes appear late, Gives incorrect info, jumps between random topics. Zero respect for students. Removed course from Canvas, nobody can see graded finals. Literally ghosts students afterward. Actually said "I hate this class" during recorded lecture! Claims to be CC but it is not. Do NOT take!!!!!!!!

For this being a CC GE, he never talked about anything cross cultural during lecture. If you missed a class at all, you lost 1 percent of your overall grade. After we took the final, he didn't submit grades until THE DAY BEFORE the next quarter started, almost a week after grades were due, and has been ducking students asking about their grade.

Do not take any class with this professor. He was super disrespectful to students asking questions, a very tough grader and didn't have any empathy for students. If you have to go to the hospital he will not excuse your absence and each attendance is worth 1 percent of your grade. UCSC should reconsider his position at the school.
