Do not take EART32 with Chuang! This class will ruin any desire you have to cook through the very specific guidelines, it is very pricey (50+ on ingredients a week), and the in class quiz is worth 10 percent of your grade, each is 1%, if you go to class and chose the wrong answer accidentally- he will mark you absent and will not fix your grade.

He was honestly very rude. He would force people to participate, but then ridicule their answers if he didn't like them. There is very little relation to cooking, and it is very chemistry heavy. He also only goes over things once then expects you to memorize everything he says. Not once did he ever talk about cultures even though it's a CC.

Cross cultural GE but never once talked about culture in class. Not much about cooking either till the end of the quarter. My main complaint is the professor's reaction to the students who participate in class, making some students seem crazy for their answers and calling them out. Not an enjoyable lecture.

Tedious, vague but also very specific criteria of the assignments. Professor seems annoyed and is mean to people who ask questions that he doesn't like. Don't expect the lectures to be about cooking until the end of the quarter, its mostly chem, but do expect to spend money on ingredients that you might not use again. The cooking was fun tho.

He teaches well but the material is so rudimentary a panda could teach it. He is mean to his students if they ask a question he doesn't like, he has taken the fun out by making specific guidelines for the cooking assignments, it seems like he doesn't want to be there, and he forces people to answer questions in lecture then ridicules their answers

Patrick is a great professor and teaches an amazingly interesting class, beware that 121 is calc heavy so be sure to have a strong grasp in calc to be able to complete the problem sets (which are extensive). The mid-term and final were among the most fair and "no surprises" exams I have come across.

Patrick is a great professor and teaches an incredibly interesting class, beware 121 is very Calc heavy so be sure to have a strong grasp of it to be able to complete the problem sets (which are extensive). The mid-term and final were among the most fair and "no surprises" exams that I have come across.

Although problem sets are challenging, lectures break down very clearly each part of the formulas and background info you need to solve problems. TAs/prof are available in office hours and attendance/collaboration with peers is a must. This class changed my mind about grad school - take this if you want to challenge yourself and grow

Very enthusiastic about his work. Attendance was mandatory but was never actually checked. Material, especially the problem sets were difficult and lectures were not always optimal for understanding them. Strict exam grades. Can sound a little mean, but truly does want his students to succeed

Very kind and actually cares about teaching. Was not super interested in the subject going into the course, but got really excited about learning Marine Geology by the end of the quarter. Dr. Polisar is very approachable and passionate about teaching! Highly recommend.

Lectures are easy to follow and prof. really cares about students' individual success. Gave study guides and hosted review sessions prior to each exam which I really appreciated. Would for sure take a class with him again.
He wants you to succeed. Really great prof

Professor Polissar is super nice and caring. He is beyond accommodating and definitely wants to make students feel welcome in class. The lectures are easy to digest but there's a lot of content. The course feels pretty easy but the tests are still tricky if you don't go to class. If you go to every lecture, the tests should be no problem though!

Pratigya is great! Grading was clear and pretty lenient and overall the class had a great teaching staff. Pratigya is very caring and accommodating and classes are very interesting and funny. He also goes live over zoom and records in case you can't make it which is super nice

All lectures were broadcasted on zoom and recorded. Few but challenging homework assignments throughout the quarter. The lectures are very well structured imo and the professor is clearly very passionate about the subject and embraces students' questions. Provides a thorough study guide for midterm and final, no surprises on the exams.

I've retained the most information from this class than any other course. Prof was super understanding and listened to student recommendations! Never had him IRL, but his online courses were educational and well-adjusted for online learning (which I think is very telling). IT IS science, but study to understand the concept and you'll be ok!

Quentin is a great teacher! He's funny, very knowledgeable and in general his lectures are very to the point and clear. Lectures are not recorded so I HIGHLY suggest just going to class, powerpoints are just pictures so unless you go in person you will not understand the material.

Quentin in spirit is a wonderful teacher who cares about the subject he is teaching and I really respect him for that, but like many of the other teacher in the department you will likely have some difficulty working with him if you have accessibility needs because of how he conducts tests. Additionally his tests on ambigious details
Professor Williams is very funny and makes the class fun and interesting. It's just the material is pretty hard, you need to work really hard for a good grade.
Pretty tough class but it's very interesting. Tough exams but there is usually a curve. Take notes on as much as you can :)

Class taught with Zachos, they're hilarious. If you can keep up you'll realize he doesn't take tangents it's all related and important, though not necessarily to the question you're solving at that moment. Quant qns are HARD until you cut the fat & they're simple. He's the head of the dept, I dare you to figure out who's his spouse without asking.
Great lectures, not an easy to understand subject! Tests are fair, but be prepared to work. Memorize stuff, be prepared for a little math, and keep taking notes!
Quentin is an entertaining and witty intellectual. Although he can be intimidating, his exams are fair as is his grading. Great UCSC professor.
Scary 'cuz he knows a lot. But if you pay attention in lecture, exams aren't bad.
Lots and lots of info, Incredibly detailed knowledge of subject
hard to understand, he seemed to leave things out of his lectures, or he had trouble completing his explainations clearly, i still dont know what greenstone belts are.  squirelly guy.
His quarrels with Paul Koch were hilarious.  A super bright guy who knows a heck of a lot about Earth Sciences.  A little intimidating at times,  but really nice once you get to know him.

Quentins knowledge of the material was remarkable.  He was also quite funny in a professor sort of way.  He unfortunately did not display his knowledge in a coherent way almost ever.  He should stick to research.  He also didn't show up for his office hours many times and was always disorganized.
nerdy but very informative.  loved his 110a class!
No Comments

Async class with all of the modules self-paced, but don't get behind. I had to really grind the last couple weeks to get a good grade, and it wasn't pretty. Would've saved myself frustration if I was doing a little bit each week. Easy to reach professor. You get infinite tries on quizzes, but must pass 100% on all module quizzes to move on.

Professor Clapham grading system made the class easy and gave a lot of freedom that allowed you to stay interested. There is a lot of different assignments, but you can pick what you want to do. You just need to reach a certain number of points to get an A. Clapham seems to really enjoy what he is teaching and he keeps lectures interesting.

Prof. Clapham is seriously passionate about what he teaches, and you can tell he is deeply knowledgeable about his skill of expertise in paleontology. The class is a points system, so you get the grade you desire. Lectures sometimes were dull, but assignments were unique and creative, and he was easily reachable via email for communication.

Clapham cares for his students and is really passionate in his work. Class was graded through points starting from 0 (1400 gets you an A). Each assignment is worth points and going to class is worth points. Sometimes his reasonings for not giving points on an assignment are confusing. Just pay attention and do assignments and you're good.

Strangest class I've attended. 70% of the grade came from online tests and the midterm and final, which were graded automatically, always got 100% or nearly on those. The other 30% were graded by him and I never cracked 80% on those. It seemed super weird that I was getting A+s on the quizzes and midterms/final, but Cs on the stuff he graded.

Prof Clapham is incredibly nice and understanding and is very passionate in his work. The homework was clear and not too hard; he definitely wants you to succeed in the class- I took it for GE, and it was good.

Matthew is great! A very kind person and super knowledgeable, we spent the quarter doing a phylogeny of ammonites from the Triassic-Jurassic boundary which was fascinating. Saw some awesome fossils in lab. He seems to change curriculum a lot from year to year so take some of the older reviews here with a grain of salt.

Matthew is such a wonderful professor. This class was technically asynchronous but he had set meeting times in case we needed help. The grading was clear, and the assignments were very useful. Overall, he is a really caring guy and wants you to succeed.

I loved his class, teaching style, and grading scale. He has a cool point system where you only have to complete a certain amount of assignments to get an A, and you can plan it all out beforehand. Also the class is just really interesting.

Back in the fall quarter I really enjoyed his class. His lectures are clear and the homework is very manageable. I love his syllabus it is fun and full of different (creative) assignments you can decide what you want your grade to be composed of. I never had to be worried about tough-grading and it allowed me to understand the material.

Your grade depends on how much work you do, starts at 0 and you do work to get up to 1400 for an A. I didn't find the work difficult, you just have to at least try and you'll get the full points on most assignments. Loved his class, would totally recommend it to anyone, you get to learn about dinosaurs.

Grades starting at 0 (goes to 1400) and you must earn points. I LOVE this because everything is "optional" Do the work if you want an A. Material is interesting and he has a good sense of humor. 10 points for posting a meme about the content each week? Sounds good to me. By far one of my favorite professors and classes. A lot of work but worth it.

Matthew is a great professor. I really enjoyed the class and Matthew was very helpful in explaining topics and help on papers. He helps you in every step of the way with the papers. His grading is great, giving feedback and criticism in helpful ways. There are things to be improved in the class structure, but overall a good class.

As others have stated, if you do the readings(there is no textbook, they're scattered all over the internet, sometimes paytoaccess websites), you'll be fine for quizzes/the multiple choice tests, but on the papers(there are SO MANY PAPERS)makes no sense. He'll penalise you for something one paper, the penalise you for its absence on the next

If you do the readings, you'll get easy As in the labs&quizzes, and the multiple choice parts of tests. But I never figured out how you get a good grade on papers(and there are SO MANY mini papers), I got consistent C-/D grades on written materials, and if you go to office hours, he'll tell you need one thing one paper, and the opposite the next

If you're going to take a class from Clapham, make sure the grading is based off of quizzes, because they are reasonable if you do the reading, but he is a ludicrously harsh grader of written material, he wants something very specific (never figured out what that was though) and if you don't give it, he'll fail you. A in the quizzes, D- on papers.

Hard class for me but didn't think it was because of his teaching ability. He always answers questions well, but it seems like he has trouble remembering not everyone has a PhD in dead ocean stuff. Still enjoyed the class though, the lab s great.
Matthew is one of the greatest persons in the Earth Science department at UCSC. I will be infinitively thankful for his help and dedication. He is also very, very funny!

Worst class I've taken. Nothing was explained well or written down anywhere. No textbook. Went into office hours to get better understanding, but still ended up with a poor grade. Waste of time. Lectures were long and boring, but interesting subject if anything. Terrible lab ta too. Rude as hell

Terrible!  This class had no prerequisites, so I took it hoping to be able to keep up.  He treated us like we had all already taken the Summer Field Course and gave us little to no instruction on how to get decent grades on our projects.  I spent 12 hours on the first project and got a 54/100.

I took hydrology with Noah not thinking that I would enjoy the class but I ended up loving it because of his great lectures. He is super passionate about the subject and knowledgeable. I decided to take geomorphology because he was teaching it and loved that class as well. The classes are hard, but if you put in the work, you'll get a lot out of it

Topics are unorganized. Speaking style is confusing. He's very condescending and rude, laughing off questions. I consider myself to be an above average student but for all the hard work I put into his class, he kept coming back with the most ridiculous grades. My transcript is so messed up now...so no he really doesn't care about his students.

Very clear and succinct with his material, in fact, so succinct blink and you'll miss it. No quizzes or midterms but there are extensive papers. Writing abounds. Approachable for stupid questions and speaks clearly. His language can be fluffy or eloquent, but he can break it down simply if you ask. Powerpoints are mostly pics so take good notes.
Great guy, his lectures are fun and interesting. He's really good at going  through the material in a way that makes you pay attention. One probably is he is a little unorganized

He is overall a decent professor. Although, the manner in which he set up this course was a bit outdated. The course consisted of in class participation and three in person exams. There was a lot of material to cover in the course but he did his best to keep the students entertained.

No homework only three midterms and a final which are quite difficult and actually pertain more to the textbook than lecture. I atended each class and still had a hard time. Additionally, the professor would sometimes go on tangents about current political issues which caused discomfort and even students walking out at times.

Dude was rude. Doesn't interact well with students, makes people feel bad for asking questions. Class was almost entirely graded on tests and he doesn't provide any study guides. I attended every lecture and did every reading and still struggled. The best thing was that he curved the tests. Don't take his class if you don't need it.

Slawek has three midterms that are all multiple choice but even if you reread every lecture and the textbook chapters it will still feel like you are guessing. He also changed our midterm with no notice to multiple answers multiple choice because he miss heard a girl choking and thought she was laughing. He only read lecture slides.

Slawek is a really cool, funny guy and was super fun to have for engineering geology with particularly the lab. Coming away from it, I honestly didn't learn that much just because the lectures were a little all over the place and confusing. The tests are impossible but do have a heavy curve. I would definitely do it again!

Professor Slawek is the best lecturer I've had at UCSC so far. He was very funny and engaging and made some of the more boring topics still interesting. Part of grade was attendance to lecture and discussion. The tests which are the main part of your grade are extremely hard, but he applies a huge curve to each one.

Slawek is one of my favorite professors I have interacted with at ucsc. You can tell her cares about what he is teaching, and if students are learning. Grading is based off of 3 midterms 1 final exam, participation, and attendance. Highly recommend this course.

This is a tough class, I would not recommend taking it just for the GE, especially if you aren't extremely interested in Geology. Slawek does not interact with students very well, and gets upset easily. He is a good lecturer but overall not very interesting

He is a tough professor teaching a tough course, but he cares immensely and it shows. He goes out of his way to make sure everyone passes and understands the material to the best of their ability, and he is forgiving when mistakes are made. I highly recommend this course with him if you enjoy the subject, or you just want a fun challenge.

Slawek is great in Lecture, knows his stuff, and really covers a large amount of material throughout the course. He has constructed the whole course from his own experience. I was interested and entertained in class. With that said, the exams are unreasonably tough and a bit out there- despite them being MC and open note. Still would recommend.
He's a nice guy! Takes you on a field trip and is funny in lectures. I learned a lot in his class. Read the book if you want a good grade and keep up! It takes work but it's not too hard to get an A.

He's funny and knows how to keep class entertaining. Lectures and discussions are required, and reading is necessary for a good grade, but it's worth it if you're interested in the subject. He keeps it interesting and makes you learn. The 100 minute class went by faster than my others that were only an hour long.
Lectures are really boring, but he is a funny guy. The field trip is fun, but long.
great teacher.  He sparked my interest in the world of geology, funny, super nice.  Now i love geology and i owe it all to slawek.

Funny guy! The lecture were always insightful and field trips were usually fun. Labs were good also. You may sometimes have to pry info out of him, but he's otherwise cool! His specialties are soils and glaciers; he's always willing to give good info on both subjects. Would definitely take more classes offered by him.

He's been my favorite professor so far!  He's a clear lecturer, and made class interesting by brining in pop songs relevant to the course material, and even SNL clips.  He kept the class laughing, and showed societal relevancy in geology.  I'd have to give him an A+.

Like said below, he does tend to come late.  His lecture is all powerpoint.  I had the unfortunate experience of having a TA who wasn't that good, so I didn't get much out of it.  There also is a field trip which is okay.  Work load isnt bad, and the final was good.  Get a good TA.

Slawek is a very knowledgeable professor, and a really nice guy.  Field trips during glaciology were super informative, and super fun.  Highly reccommended.  Just be prepared to use your quantitative talents.
This teacher is sometimes late to class.  His sections are unguided and unhelpful.  He seems like a nice enough teacher but the class is not inspiring at all.

Great teacher, really made a lot of students interested in environmental geology.  Does things like plays songs about natural hazards and SNL clips.  Lectures are clear, he knew the subject well. Field trip was great, tests weren't thorough but curved.
Great at slamming Smirnoff Ice in the playa. Don't ice the map board though, you will get in trouble. Even if it is the perfect size to fit an ice.

Okay, as nice as he is and as smart as he is, this is the most scattered professor I've ever had. By the time the final rolled around, he still hadn't graded the midterm, and I'm going into spring quarter still waiting on my final grade for his class. Not a fun time, but I'm almost positive I passed.

Jeremy is a decent lecturer and the funniest professor you'll have. He cares about your success and was very understanding and helpful during the pandemic. However, he is disorganized and terrible at communication. He skipped office hours without a canvas announcement multiple times. Also, for the avg student his hw is hard. Take 191C first.

This is the class where you only get out what you put in. It differs from most earth sci classes here in that he does not care whether you care or not; that's up to you. He is remarkably good at what he does and is highly respected in research. You will get a lot out of this class if it's your thing. He's at his best in the field.

Okay so Jeremy is extremely passionate about what he does. He is brilliant. His lectures were a bit hard to follow because they lack structure (no pun intended). But overall if you go to office hours he is the coolest guy ever and very easy to talk to if you have questions.
A very down to earth passionate professor. Teaching style has little structure, but the class was still awesome!
Very good at what he does.  An extremely intelligent professor capable of truly teaching you something new.  He also has some of the best campfire stories.
Very interesting class. You must be serious to get a lot out of his teaching style.
Doesn't return graded papers until the end of the quarter.  Not very helpful, unclear about expectations, very disorganized.  Great class as a learning experience, but he made it hard to get through.

going to lectures was really important to stay engaged, xi is also just a fabulous prof and is really into the stuff he teaches. definitely keep up on studying and homework. midterm was a wake up call, hardly studied and failed it, grinded for the final and got a B+. tests are majority of grade. class is sm fun tho and i loved what we learned

Lectures mandatory but uses a site called learning analytics for attendance quizzes, but usually taken around the same time so not hard to miss class. Graded mostly off of attendance, hw, and midterm/final. Final is not cumulative.

Xi is generally a good professor. The class is very lecture-heavy, so if you don't learn like that this isn't the class for you. He prides himself on the fact that kids do badly on the midterm, so be warned. You'll be fine if you go to class and study, even if you aren't sciency. If you want an easier version of this class, take ASTR 2 in winter.

Not a difficult class but you really have to know your stuff for a good grade. The majority of your grade is dependent on the midterm and final. These are both multiple choice and the answers for each question are  nearly identical. Surface level studying doesn't prep you for a good grade. Engaging lectures though.

Xi is a great professor! Everything on the test is in the lectures so do not skip those! The textbook package is like $80 though. There's weekly homework online which takes like 45 minutes. Midterm was easy. His lectures are very easy to understand and he always open to any questions. Pretty fun course, would recommend.

Xi was great! As long as you go to the lectures, you should be fine as far as exams go. Tests are in person, though, so if you don't have an affinity for spacial concepts, study. Homeworks were easy, but you do have to buy the online module to be able to complete them.

The homework for this class is pretty easy but the midterm and final are pretty tough! I failed the midterm got an 80% on the final but I still got an A because of participation and extra credit. The study guide doesnt reflect whats going to be on the exams well so I recommend reading the textbook. Overall Professor Xi is good just tough exams.

Homework is simple and it's nice to talk to him. Definitely attend his office hours if you have questions. He is a great teacher, but one of the things that was bothersome was that only some of the questions from the study guide ended up being on the exams.

Professor Xi is passionate about his class topics, so attending lectures is always made interesting. Weekly homework was easy and took under half an hour each week. Midterm and final make up 50% of the grade and were pretty tough, class averages ranged from usually 60-70%. Participation grade is from an easy one-question quiz at the end of class.
The class is fun, just be ready to buy the text book. Other than that it was a solid class.

Attendance was graded by a one question quiz in lecture and ta section, homework was optional but it was helpful. Need to buy online access to textbook and homework. I got an average of 60% on both midterm and final but passed because homework and attendance helped. Interesting lectures on planet systems, Mars, etc.

Professor Xi is an amazing guy, who is an active researcher in his field. He knows his stuff, and is passionate about it which helps make lectures more engaging. Just by showing up and doing your work you can easily pass, but an A would require some more reading in the textbook (not too much by any means). It is up to you how the class will go

Lecture wasn't well organized and lack of slides/reference material made reviewing content difficult. Prof is knowledgable but her no partial credit policy is frustrating. A problem with a rounding error would be graded as if it's 100% wrong. Made learning discouraging and your grade is very much dependent on how many equations you can memorize.

While I find her teaching style entertaining I find her class lay out really antiquated. She offers no partial credit for grading, she does not record any lectures, gives no equation sheet for the tests, and graphing calculators are not allowed. Overall its a very challenging class, if your math skills are behind definitely beware.

Problem sets every week, a lot of tough questions. Expect to spend hours on them. Office hours are a must for this class, either with TA's or Emily. You need to put in the extra time. That being said, the exams were fair and mostly tested the fundamentals of the material. Incredibly smart professor and she is very approachable and reasonable.

She is smart and knowledgeable but her homework and tests are so hard that she makes passing this course near impossible. Her grading is unfair. It make the learning experience discouraging and depressing.

She is obviously passionate about geophysics but the way the class is set up is awful. The homework is way harder than anything in class and usually takes an insane amount of time to complete. The tests are basically just a test of whether you can memorize all the formulas, and there are a lot of them to memorize.

Covid quarter and she took the time to set up her I-Pad screen so that we could follow easily. There were some technical difficulties, but that's life. I definitely suggest going to office hours because she makes example questions very close to what will be on exams. Very hard though

Emily is one of the best professors Ive ever had. She is very good at reading the emotions of her students, and is very helpful in office hours. She is fantastic at walking through problems and concepts on the board at a perfect pace. My one complaint of course is with her grading, which while not as bad as most say, is still harsh.

She's a legend in her field of research but expects 100percent or nothing from you. Seriously, that's the grading scheme. It serves no purpose to grade exams like that. She half derives equations on the board and doesn't follow the text which is illegible unless you're a math major. I only finished it to put matlab on my resume.

Emily is a fantastic teacher and a researcher at the top of her field, and she really wants her students to succeed. However, if you are not comfortable with math and physics, this class will be difficult for you. But don't despair! There are plenty of opportunities for help (go to office hours!) and Emily is all about second chances on exams.

Poor lecturer. Spends most of class reviewing what was taught last class (aka nothing) so its drawn out, tedious, and useless. Used a program for homework that was not compatible with many computers. Really irritating class - I ended up dropping because I couldn't tolerate the poor quality of the class.

If it wasn't for the T.A I wouldn't have passed the class. Definitely go to the T.A's office hours for help on the problem sets. Lectures didn't go so well either aka kinda boring. In the end the math really wasn't that hard I just wish I would have learned it before I did poorly on both midterms rather then the end of the quarter =/.

Many assignments rely too heavily on the derivations of equations.  She gives no partial credit on incorrect problems for tests and HW, which can be a pretty ruthless approach.  Her lectures often just consist of long drawn-out derivations.  Lots of time at her office hours is essential, but she offers only a few per week.  Definitely a tough one.
She held a fun class, but don't come in late or leave early. She'll remember you.
This class is SO boring, Brodsky is arrogant, and rude.  The labs were boring and used programs for experts in the field.  The field trip was pointless, way to long and COLD.

I thought she was a fun teacher because she was so excited about earthquakes and teaching everyone about them. She made examples fun in class with the use of over dramatic analogies. Some days were definitely better than others, but overall it was a really fun class

I'd suggest taking this class just because you never have to go to class. She posts the lectures online and even updates them for any changes she makes during class. She's funny and really loves what she's doing, it's just a very boring class. The field trip is also pretty awful, but if you show up you're good.

Prof Brodsky was an interesting teach, it was very easy to stay awake in the class.  Class participation will help you understand the materials better, though not terribly required.  Overall, a pretty good class

Easy class. Labs are pointless/boring but easy. 1 midterm which is really easy if you pay attention. She gets really annoying in that she spends a lot of time trying to get you to talk, which ends up wasting a lot of time. Doesn't treat you like college students, instead like elementary school age. Its not a bad class, she just gets annoying.
Fun and easy class, despite some difficulty on labs and rather vague answers to questions. I'd recommend Brodsky, just because of her upbeat and fun teaching style.
A good lecturer, but was not fair in grading.

He is a good professor. His classes are completely lecture based and your grade is determined by a few tests and a singular project. He teaches to the midterms and gives the questions ahead of time. He goes off topic alot but works to keep the content relevant to today.

KC is a very sweet guy very down to earth, also very decorated with plenty of experience class was superrrr easy, didn't have to go to class, but a good teacher if you pay attention to what he teacher would recommend.
Easy A. But probably you should do some studying outside of class. TAs are also phenomenal.

Light. So light. It was too easy to the point where I felt bad because I wasn't learning bc I didn't need to pass the class. The final and midterm were both online, and the class wasn't mandatory. Sweet man with a thick accent, but if you pay attention, you will learn. And if you don't, you'll still pass lol.

He's very knowledgable about international economics and is very funny (a bit goofy even). His exam questions are pre-given to you, and lectures are basically dedicated to answering them. Section reveals those answers again. Difficulty of grading depends on the TA, my TA (Ayush) was quite a tough grader. Also KC is my asian representation.
I really liked this course. Make sure you go to your section and actually take notes!
He's a great guy. He's super nice and everything but his lectures are almost impossible to pay attention to. Just be prepared to teach yourself most of the content.

Entire class was graded based on 2 midterms, 1 paper (could choose to take all but only 2/3 were required), a final, and weekly quizzes. All of which were taken on canvas and on own time making it a pretty stress free class. Lectures were occasionally difficult to follow but always very helpful and directly related to the tests.

Had him for ECON149 and it was one of the best classes i've taken. Really nice professor, put all of the course materials onto canvas so was easily accessible. Grades were based on 2 midterms, 1 3-page paper, and a final. He also shares the questions for all the exams beforehand so you can plan your answers.

This is a very easy professor, I had him at an 8am time slot but he made coming in at that time okay. He is a very easy grader for Econ 1, and his exams are very similar to homework. Study that and I promise you that you will be okay. Fully honest, I stopped going to majority of classes halfway through and still passed with a good score

Class graded on 2 midterms, final, & 2 page final paper. Class boring but gives all answers for midterms & final. Final paper short but incredibly vague with no prior writing assignments to get a sense of how he grades written work.
big chiller, love how he tries to keep content relevant / trendy. very accommodating and explains things well. econ 1 with him was 3/10 difficulty

Loved kc!! Class was graded on 5 hw assignments, 3 midterms (1 is optional tho) and a final. All test were multiple choice. He offered an extra credit assignment after the 1st midterm. I did really enjoy his class. Lectures were always enjoyable and easy to follow. Go to class, take notes and you'll be fine!

Very chill professor, had good experience with him. Lectures were a little boring but he posts all the slides online.  Study the practice exams since they are super similar to the actual exams. Class was 2 midterms and a paper (can choose 2 out of the 3), and a final. Go to TA sections b/c they are helpful.Would recommend as a professor for econ 1!

3 midterms (1 is a paper), but only 2 count for grade. Final is cumulative. Very easy HW every 2 weeks. Lectures are semi-boring but he reminds me of my grandpa so I'm chillin. Slides are always posted but could be formatted better. Always uses examples in lecture to get the point across. Overall very easy class.
Easy class, but his lectures are really boring sometimes. All of his slides are on Canvas, and he posts practice exams that are so similar to the midterms and finals.

Overall, had a really good experience with him. His lectures can get a bit bland but he tries to find humor in them when applicable. The midterms are pretty similar like the practice ones he gives you but having two midterms both being 20% of your grade can help or hurt you. Would recommend though.

If you aren't a good test taker don't take his class for Econ 1. Easy and chill professor to pass with but hard to get an A. 2 Midterms and 1 final add up to 70 percent of your grade. Essay thats worth 20% and homework is the rest. Overall chill if you just wanna get through it without too much effort.
Pretty easy and useful class. Make sure to review practice tests!

Professor KC is such a laid back professor, attendance is not mandatory for lecture or section. I never went to either and did perfectly fine. Consists of 6 homework assignments (guaranteed full credit), two midterms and a final. His practice exams are almost exactly like the actual exams, so it's seriously all you need to study.

I think he was okay. I mean I feel like his lectures were just him yapping about things that were not related to econ and him saying am i making myself clear 100 times. Idk not super difficult class tho. (this is my first review ever guys).

I took microecon with him, he is a very caring laid back professor and he even though his lectures may be hard to follow they're always recorded and slides are always posted on canvas. I wish I took attendance more seriously so I would've done better on the midterms, but if you study the homework before each test I promise you will be just fine.

Lecture's were good but sometimes he was hard to follow. homework consists of 3 problem sets sprinkled thought the quarter. Midterms were based very heavily on problem sets, sometimes even identical (with different numbers). 2 midterms and final, but if you study the problem sets you will do great. midterms are not cumulative an neither was final.

he might be one of the greatest teachers of all time. he really cares about his students, he fought to curve one of our midterms when the average was low, he clearly states what he is going to test us on well before the exams, deadlines are very lenient and well-communicated. all lectures recorded, if you just watch them and do psets you'll be fine

I really admire Saha for the care he shows his students. The resources to help me succeed in this class were definitely there, but I did not use them to their full potential, which is why this course was challenging. I greatly appreciate the time he puts into his students. I usually do not leave reviews, but he deserves a good one.
Tests are very similar to whats taught in class
Tests are very similar to what he teaches in class
Such an amazing class, loved his lectures, though they can be slow at times
He really took the time to make sure I understand the content 1:1. Pleaseeeeeee take him for your Econ 1 and 2 classes as well as your Stats 17!!!!!!

Dr. Saha is genuinely such a laidback and caring Professor. The class is easy as it's 2 units, and attendance isn't mandatory as he records them. You learn a lot about the basics of STATA (prob take Econ113 after so you don't need to pay again), and also only have 4 assignments which if you just follow what he says, seriously isn't an issue.
literally just if you do what he shows in lecture or follow the slides he posts, it's impossible to not get an A. Super chill super easy

I had no Econ experience and I was fine. Problem sets, online homework quizzes (multiple attempts), and discussion attendance were easy points. I recommend going to his office hours at least once to get to know him. He is very funny and considerate. My only warning, be timely with the midterm and final. Expect ratios of 80 questions for 90 minutes.
It's a 2 credit class and he treats it as such. Impossible to not get 100% unless you either don't listen in class or use the resources he gives. He's nice and answers questions respectfully.

He's so cool. 4 homeworks/25 points. he goes over some questions of the hw and kinda teach you what you should do it. two deadlines (soft-sunday, hard-thursday). you need to buy STATA but buy it for six months and take econ 113 right after as you also need. Don't use headphones or any distraction as he will call you out in front of everyone.

The class is honestly not as bad as people think. Yes Macro is easier than micro, but the homework for the class isn't too heavy. The tests are more word-heavy but all questions are multiple choice. Professor Saha is a chill teacher and doesn't expect a lot from his students but he does like it when people participate and show up to lectures,
Quizzes are online and attendance was not mandatory. If you decided to go to class anyways, his lectures adequately over materials (even if he is a little boring). I'm taking him again next quarter.
If you stay on top of the homework you will do fine. He does talk about some stories in class but most are pretty interesting. All the tests and homework are online and open note.
All that you need for doing the homework is in the do-files he gives you. It's all very straightforward, just make sure you do everything on time and you will be fine.

If you're thinking about taking a class with Saha, just do it. I took Econ 1, Econ 2, and Stat 17 Lab with him and barely showed up to 90% of lectures but still got A's in all of them. His assignments and tests are super easy and there are plenty of "online" help. Whether you want to learn or just pass you can do both. 5/5 professor.

Took this class spring 2024, both midterm and final were online. Relatively easy. He provides resources outside of class for students to go farther in economics. Cares for his students. Two problems sets, both were easy as long as you follow the instructions exactly. Connect homework quizzes every week. Extra credit TA sections. Overall good.

Horrible experience with this professor. The final was unlike any of the learning modules/homework assignments. I can confidently say this introductory macro class' final was harder than my multivariable calculus final. High expectations for such low standard of teaching.

This class is something you should take as a last resort or if you are already well-versed with the material. It consumes so much time to study for the final (40%) of the grade. And a lot of the pre-recorded lectures don't fully explain anything

I loved how he structured the class with a whole storyline and all. He's really funny when making the videos, really organized, explains concepts very well. All the hw and lessons are easy to pass. just kinda crazy that final is worth 40% but given everyone can pretty much earn 100% on all other assignments, the 40% is ok.

His homework is easy, educational, and you can easily get a good score, it takes many HOURS to understand the content.  I suggest you don't take this course, you can do all the work but the final test determines your overall grade and it is a difficult test, the time is not enough for a beginner. Written answers NO MULTIPLE CHOICE. Hard to succeed.

Needed a filler class and this was online async. Rather than lectures, class was split into modules that followed a story that was lowkey entertaining at times. Grading was fine and the teaching was easy to communicate with. Class is a teach yourself and wasn't difficult to complete. I wasn't expecting the class to be a lot more math heavy though.
Lectures were simple and straightforward. If you took AP Macro and Micro Econ, Econ 1 and 2 are pretty much similar in content.
A bit of a tough grader but definitely a good teacher. I enjoyed the way his course was set up a lot and want to take more classes with him

Insane sense of entitlement. He runs an introductory economics course where you have to teach yourself almost everything and considers passing his class to be an achievement. My fault for expecting more from UCSC honestly.

You have to teach yourself to do well. Instead of midterms, has a mini exam each week (no partial credit). Go to section for problems identical to the weekly exams. Very short lectures so I would make a study guide for each chapter.  Final is very similar to the practice exams he provides, do all! Curves a lot (went from 85 on the final to 110%).

The class is difficult if you don't have time to teach yourself. It's hard to understand why he does certain stuff, and he isn't helpful in explaining. The quizzes tend to be harder than the modules he uses to teach. The final was a bit brutal, considering how he didn't know how to teach. I wouldn't recommend it if you can't self-teach.

Personally I liked this course, but its definitely not good for those who have never taken an econ course before. Lectures are kinda engaging but long, its a lot of work, weekly hw assignments (~2 per week). Final is a VERY big part of ur grade (40%, no midterm in this class). Definitely need to spend time going over lectures a few times on ur own

Shenoy is an okay lecturer, I recommend that you take micro before to have a better understanding of what hes teaching. His TA's are very helpful and help you walk through the modules. You have two quizzes every week and sometimes his quizzes have nothing to do with what we learned. His class is easy, but his teaching style is not the best.

Worst professor i have had at UCSC. Gives no feedback, you have to basically teach yourself everything and takes forever to reply If he does at all. Overall he just doesnt seem to care about his students learning or passing, take someone else if possible

This has been a thouroughly unenjoyable experience. You essentially have to teach everything to yourself, videos are confusing, quizzes twice a week, entirely too stressful. I took another econ 2 class with a different professor and it was much much better paced. Have been trying to teach myself 1 module for a combination of 10 hours now. Dont take

I do not recommend. He has homework assignments and expects us to know everything with 5 minute videos given. Lots of google sheets which don't teach us how to do the math. Quizzes are harder than the material taught and the numbers are very specific. If you are off by 0.2, you'll still be marked down. He does not teach

The missions he gives are much more complicated than the modules. Most of your grade is quizzes and the final. He doesn't teach well so if you don't understand something you have to figure it out. There are a lot of google sheets involved which I personally am not a fan of, it messes me up on assignments I know how to do.

I feel as if when I have to take out loans to afford tens of thousands of $$ worth of tuition the least the professor could do is structure the class with well thought out lectures or at least not be hanging with his family halfway across the world

Doesn't teach in person and has pre-recorded lectures that are mostly useless. Weekly modules can take hours to finish and the quiz at the end of each one is harder than the material that was covered. For the final exam I found it best to go over every single module quiz and write down and solve the examples given. Some light thinking, not too much

He has a very soothing voice. Watch the videos they help a lot. Eo modules and missions on time. Modules get two attempts so its easy to run thru first attempt and put right answers on second but u might not do too well on missions(quizzes) if you only rely on this. Missions make up a big portion of grade so make sure to do really well on those.

I had a really difficult time in ECON 2. I actually never spoke to the Prof or saw his face, even over zoom (no zooms). We would work with numbers like 50 or 800 while learning the material, but during quizzes we'd literally be making computations with numbers like 1/1,002,357.85262, and this felt unnecessarily difficult for an introductory course.

Professor Anderson is great! Definitely go to every lecture that you can, because he teaches and explains things very well, and he also gives a lot of extra credit opportunities. His exams are a little hard, so study well before and take advantage of review sessions and resources. Big curve at the end of the class, so don't stress too much.

This course is good if you want to study a lot. A lot of material and three exams. Long and difficult final exam and the second midterm is difficult compared to the first. Nice guy though over all, just not a course I would take again

I took Econ 10A with Scott. He is such a great teacher who is very knowledgeable as he works as a CPA. He challenged me to think about and understand the material. I was very scared to take the class but it ended up being one of my favorite classes I ever took here! 2 midterms, 1 final, homework heavy, a few projects.

Anderson is a good professor and a caring person. His tests are challenging for sure, but he does curve. There are a few pop quizzes so make sure to show up to lecture. Lots of homework assignments that can be difficult, but good practice for exams. Overall, good professor and cares about his students.

The class is difficult but if you study hard and make an effort to understand the concepts you will be fine. He gives out quizzes in class at random so attendance is important. He's friendly and easy to approach with questions. He's a good professor, but the final was honestly the hardest exam I've taken in my life so far and I cried after.

Expects you to throughly understand financial accounting which will benefit you when you take the FAR Section of the cpa exam. I enjoyed his teaching style and the difficult midterms get you out of your comfort zone. You will learn a lot. Dont  be discouraged by a low test score because he will curve

Hes pretty difficult like he expects you to really understand all the concepts and be able to apply them. He gives pop quizzes in class so you have to be there. His exams are tough but he curves and gives practice midterms. He's a pretty good teacher tho he explains the problems and material well. u gotta get on that grind boi

Mr. Anderson is an awesome guy. Enjoyed his class, opportunity for extra credit, However, he doesn't give study guides which is a bummer because there is so much material to learn. He takes about 1 or 2 classes to review for midterms, but they don't really reflect what is on the test. That's the only thing that I would change. STUDY GUIDES PLEASE!

A solid choice for accounting. Definitely knows his stuff and is resonable when it comes to tests. There is a lot of homework and some of the assignments can be pretty difficult, but overall still manageable. Hes a nice guy and hes understanding of his students.

She reads from slides made by others, so honestly, I never went to the lecture. The homework software is AWFUL, and it takes me hours to do; it's not even hard, it's just annoying and repetitive. Tests are always online—very easy A+. If you miss homework she has a bunch of makeup ones that you can do. You really have to try to fail, to fail.
Bullen is super sweet and old but her lectures are kinda pointless I feel bad. A bunch of busy work but its all really easy. Easy A.

Her class was super straightforward, and she gives you everything that you need to succeed in the class. The course is kind of homework heavy and she does not under any circumstances take late work, but if you stay on top of your deadlines you should be fine. She also provides PLENTY of extra credit work.

Maria Bullen is sweet and the class is structured well. Attendance is not mandatory and she essentially reviews the chapters that you were supposed to read for homework in class. Pretty easy class and a lot of busywork but the expectations are very clear, a decent amount of homework every week. If you miss a homework you can make up points later.

The tests and homework directly correlate to example problems, making them easy. The test is proctored online though. There is a lot of homework (12 chapters with a smart book and homework set for each). Definitely much easier than some other Econ10A courses.
Learn mostly from doing the homework, she is very nice but there is so much homework that it makes it difficult to go to class.

This professor is awesome. The class itself can *very* easily get hard if you don't keep up. Skip a day or two and you're working overtime. However, the class is completely on you to succeed, and the professor is very forgiving and is there to help you. The effort you put in here is exactly what you will receive back. Would take again.
Amazing professor who wants all her students to succeed!

She is literally the goat. super kind and really just wants all her students to succeed. the midterms and final are open book, open note, and have the exact same problems as the homework. lectures were slow but not mandatory.

I love her! Go to her lectures, its not mandatory but only a few shows up and it will show your appreciation for the professor. She is caring, tries to make the class easy for you by going through the problems and help you prepare for the final. Expensive though, had to pay $110 for McGraw Hill, but is the foundation of the class so won't complain.

She was an amazing teacher. The class itself is not hard when she adds things such as open notes on tests and the study guides really help. I strongly suggest you take this teacher if its just 10A you need. If you need 10B as well, keep yourself accountable. Great Professor.
this is a financial accounting class. Don't be fooled. If you transferred and chose this class see if you can get the credits to bump you up. Otherwise teacher is nice, no issues

Lots and lots of online hw and "sb", but midterm and final are almost EXACTLY like the hw, so make sure to do the hw before the exams and you'll pass with an easy A. Hardest part is the amount of homework, either do them every week or leave a few days (48+ hours) to do the hw at end of quarter

The material this class covers is boring and tedious, but the way that prof Bullen structures the class makes it very doable. Lots of online homework but if you do the work you're pretty much guaranteed an A.

She was the best professor I ever had! I love her so much and wish she had more other econ classes that I could take, but no. The class is not that hard and you get 2 hw each week basiclly. The midterm and final are all similar to the hw problems, If you know how to do hw, you got it. It's open note for both. Easy and kinda chill, she was so great!

Class was super easy due to Prof. Bullens study guides for each assignment. Don't let HW and readings stack up, get them done on the due date, trust me. Exams are just like HW and are also on study guides. Although, if you are taking ECON 10B, seriously make sure you understand the material and don't just take the easy A. You will regret it in 10B.

Although assignments are easy, you will get swarmed with the E-Book and HW. The E-Book is genuinely terrible and frustrating so do not let those stack up till the end of the quarter. The midterm and final are ripped straight from your HW with different numbers. (ProctorU and lots of Q's on exam.) She's still a great prof though.

The class is very easy to follow; all the homework is due at the end of the quarter, and you have unlimited attempts. The final and midterm are open notes, and the study guides are super helpful for the exams. The professor responds to emails fast and is understanding. I found the class to be amazing. Favorite professor!

She practically showed us how to do the hw material with her detailed guides and samples. Was always the kindest and most caring person in her emails and offered to help us every step of the way. I got lucky to have her as my 10A prof.

One of the best accounting professors at UCSC; she cares for students' success and has a clear grading criteria. She gives quite a lot of work, but provides good study material (i.e., detailed study guide, thorough lectures). Both the midterms and final exam are straight out of the homework, except with different numbers. Would highly recommend!

Honestly not sure what Prof Jones even does. All exams and homework are automatically graded through McGraw Hill and all he does is send out an email once a week. There are recorded lectures/videos you can watch but I did not find those helpful at all because they were not engaging in the slightest. Also he uses ProctorU, which is very stressful.
He is very strict and if you want your grade rounded at the end of the course he will not. Lots of reading and time management required.

116 is way easier than all of the other courses Jones teaches. It seems like he enjoys the class too, as he shows way more of a personality in this one. Easy class, especially if you take the time to read the book. Two group presentations/paper. Very organized guy. He may not
be the best prof for the accounting series, but  he's good for this one

he was very rude, not good to communicate with. Basically does none of the teaching, you have to read textbook and do quizzes if you want to do well. 2 mid terms and 1 final. He has homework every week, lecture quiz every week etc. Just don't interact with him, even on email, very negative.

Kevin is extremely condescending to students, and doesn't communicate well at all - even if he responds to emails quickly. The first 5 weeks of this course are horrible, which is why I have the difficulty at a 4, the last 5 weeks aren't as tough as the content gets easier to understand, but you must teach yourself, lectures are useless.
Horrible professor, does not care about students, lots of reading, proctored exams

He makes you pay for McGraw Hills access for one year, and there is no option to purchase it for just one quarter. I asked him about this, but he didn't do anything to decrease the costs. Prepare to rely on McGraw Hills for everything.

He makes you pay for McGraw Hills, pretty expensive arounf $150. Prepare to rely on McGraw Hills for everything because his lectures are not helpful and boring. if you study just the homeworks and quizzes (for calculations), its a easy pass. he gives extra credit and randomly takes attendance but its extra credit points.

I avoided taking this class until Senior year because of all the bad reviews & wow are they misleading. Jones is MORE than fair. Simply, put in the time & effort! He consistently gives clear instructions. The only reason why people dislike him is due to pure laziness & immaturity. He's organized, clear, gives great examples, & very knowledgeable.
Absolutely the WORST prof at this school.
please just take this class at another school

He lectures with slides straight from McGraw, it's near impossible to read what he's writing even while sitting in the front row because he writes in chalk while the projector is on (he also has bad handwriting and abbreviates a LOT), and he assigns loads of busy work. Not a hard class but it's painful and you won't learn anything.

Kevin Jones is a genuinely amazing professor with an informative and entertaining teaching style. His straightforward and clear lectures along with his flexible grading style made this class very enjoyable.

I've never attended his office hours or held a conversation with him, so take with a grain of salt. He's an average professor who assigns tons of busywork and is a pain in the ass grader that gets you over little things. He writes like a highschooler and his sentences don't always make sense. He has zero flexibility in any way. 10A was proctored.

Lectures for 111A and 117B are useless, he just reads the publisher's slides without elaborating. Homework is a problem set, a smartbook, and a quiz all from the textbook. The mandatory discussion forum every week also felt useless. Every time I have had Kevin Jones for a class it is consistently the worst learning experience I have been part of.

Absolutely awful professor. If you want a class where you don't get a lick of information by showing up to the lectures and you are essentially required to read a 700 page textbook top to bottom, then you'll love this guy! I've had the displeasure of taking 4 classes with Professor Jones and it has not got any better in any one of them.

Unreasonable amount of weekly homework (like 7-8 assignments per week) and lectures are kinda boring and useless. Kevin is definitely polarizing, he is definitely helpful to talk to and supportive if you want to have a career in accounting, but if not he does almost nothing for the course but police it. Truly I was miserable.

I see why people dislike him because the class is very learn on your own, but for me that worked fine and I did like his lecture to follow along with the homework. IT make it easy to understand. His discussion posts are annoying and his grading on them was very hard, but he make its clear from the start what you need to pass. Overall I would take

Terrible, asynchronous class. Workload was a lot, taught myself, all McGraw Hill. I don't know what he was doing, cuz he wasn't teaching this class, had to 3 chapter per week, with a mid term and 6 assignments due the  same week, along with the time taken to essentially teach myself. Take a class at cc if you can, might learn better.

boring just reads off the slides which kinda makes it pointless to even show up to lecture but i did anyway, all exams are 50% computation and 50% conceptual so if u dont read the chapters youll definitely fail the class, he does explain concepts well but its sometimes boring that no one is paying attention, hw weekly, 4 quizzes, 2 midterms

Lectures were easy to follow and he gave time in class to do hw problems. He and the TAs were always there to answer questions. No midterm, final allowed a cheat sheet. Since I'm not that good at coding and don't have any experience the material was sometimes hard for me but prof definitely structured the class in a way for you to succeed.

Brand new class in the Econ department, but it was taught well! Prof. made clear the effort needed to succeed in the course, and live-coded examples for us during the lecture. Lectures are broken down into lecture, class exercise, and homework, where TAs walk around during the exercise and homework to provide help if you're struggling.

The first two weeks were a review of Econ 104/113/114. The class then covers intro machine learning methods (Lasso/Ridge/Post-Lasso/Random Forests) and you practice using them on provided datasets. Homework ties nicely into the lectures and section notes, and the class concludes with a final group/individual paper. No exams, clear grading criteria!
He makes excellent lecture slides and seamlessly teaches the code and theory behind machine learning in R.

Gerelt isnt the best but he can be kinda funny. Hes pretty boring and takes much longer than needed to teach the topics. Final 40% midterm 30% Homework 20% and the rest is attendance. Overall the topics were pretty easy in this class just study the reviews cause they are just like the tests. did give a curveball on final though

Content taught was easy but he taught it in a confusing way. Lectures were insanely slow-paced and monotonous. He's nice but I just don't like his teaching style. TA + LSS tutoring did most of the actual teaching work, his lectures didn't help me much. Midterm & final are very similar to review problems. Make a study group and you'll be fine

Lectures were extremely monotonous and hard to follow, with overly complex examples that made concepts more confusing. I ended up withdrawing and switching to a different professor, where I'm finally understanding the material. Would not recommend.
Lectures are very boring but the tests are very easily and similar to his practice exams. Realistically, i learned the most from my TA (Shout out Sajad)
Professors lectures are painfully boring and classwork felt less than challenging. Calc 2 was required for the course but nothing remotely challenging was used in the class.

This guy is the worst professor I've ever had. He pretends like his exams will be easy then makes them hard. Lecture attendance was mandatory and useless. I didn't go to the last like 3 weeks of class and still got an A-. Also, pretty sure I could've taught this class better. If 0 stars was an option I would put that.

Take the class if Ayden (I'm in love with him) is the TA. Hikaru's lectures are very boring. 2/3 midterms were canceled my quarter, so only graded off a few homework assignments and 1 midterm and 1 final. Doesn't post lecture materials so you have to attend lecture. I did good in the class, but it was not enjoyable. Ayden was my favorite part.

Class was relatively straightforward. He provides sample papers before tests and usually just pulls the questions from the sample papers/problem sets and tweaks the problems a little. He also does make class (semi)mandatory since he doesn't post completed slides online but most information can be found in the textbook.
Probably the laziest prof I have ever had

Overall this was a good experiance. Yes lectures are long, but if you attend lectures and go to section you'll be aboslutely fine. The math is simple arithmatic, very simple so no calculator allowed on test. Exams are very similair to problem sets, just be sure to know some derivations of the material and how to manipulate the equations.

You must attend lectures (very long and not recorded, but clear examples) and rework examples to succeed. Exams are a combination of homework and lecture examples with different numbers. He gives 3 midterms, but the lowest one is dropped. Definitely go to section for help and find an online pdf of the textbook (has problems + formulas derivations).

Lectures really long and poorly explained, very little worked example problems so come test time there isn't a lot to study from. He provides practice exams before hand but the last two only had two problems on there and they weren't much help. I've heard his TAs are great but I had classes during section times so I was unable to benefit.

Really boring material and the concepts are hard to understand. I would not recommend to take it with Saijo. His TAs are very helpful but they grade without much partial credit and exam averages were low. Makes his exams really hard but drops the lowest of 3 midterms and gave a a curve at the end of the quarter to help the class.

Professor Saijo's midterm layout includes anywhere from 3 to 5 in-depth questions that are to be completed and electronically submitted within 60 seconds. A large portion of the class was not able to finish the test to the best of their ability in this time frame, when met with that feedback no changes were made. Lectures are also extremely boring.
Professor Saijo is great. Macroeconomics can be challenging, but he is able to teach it at a level that's digestible. His TAs are also very good and proved to be a huge help throughout the quarter.
Hikaru Saijo wasn't a very difficult teacher. His lectures were boring, sure, but he still sufficiently taught what was needed to succeed. As long as you go to lecture you're guaranteed a high grade.

He goes over every exam problem beforehand in lecture. Sometimes hes unclear and messy with graphs, so its good to glance at the textbook for a better understanding. Lectures are really long and enthusiastic. But his grading is incredibly lenient. Go to TAs office hours or discussions! Theyre all very good.

Saijo was very unenthusiastic about the material. He basically just reads off of his slides during most of the class. He seemed uninterested in being there and did not know the answer to many questions asked by students in class. We also had a midterm on the 2nd week of class which is pretty early for a test.
Go to lecture, he basically goes over what's gonna be on the test. Write everything he writes on the board. He gives 3 midterms but drops the lowest score. He's funny
He's one of the better lecturers in the economics department, to be sure. Much powerpoint reading? Sure, but his clear grading criteria make up for it, if you ask me.
He just read off of his powerpoint slides. A generous grader, if you ask me.

He literally just reads his slides. He posts them on ecommons, so class is really not mandatory unless you want to see him go through the examples at a painstakingly slow pace. Also the power point is just a summary of the book. If you want to go over the ideas in detail, then you should get the book.

At first this class went great. He was VERY generous when grading the first midterm, but was much more strict on the last 2 midterms. Make sure to be very detailed on your exams, as it messed up my grade for not doing so. Overall, he was alright. Just practice the homework, practice midterm, and the slides and you should get a good grade.

Pretty straight-forward required course. Prof uses slides rather than writing it on the squeaky blackboards. Makes it easy to follow. The slides are online too so if you follow that, the tests are totally what you would expect.
He's energetic but sometimes disorganized and confusing. Tests are fair.
had him for 216, one of my favorite lecturers I've had

I struggled so much in econometrics until I took this professor. I finally understood the work and his lectures helped for the two 10 page papers. The 5 article assignments were easy and fairly graded but the STATA assignments were very time consuming and a bit hard since it was only learned in section. 20% is just attending so don't miss a class!

Lots of writing for this class. 4 main assignments throughout the quarter and 2 papers each for Midterm/Final (Draft and Final papers had separate grades). Really nice professor and makes class fun but definitely have to commit lots of outside class time to the assignments. Graded exercises at the end of each lecture.

This class gives me the feeling that you will never be able to do "perfect", which means you never get a full grade for your tons of assignment, they just keep deducting your points. You still have to go to class to do the exercises even the school already notified severe weather condition.

This professor was absolutely excellent. His class was probably one of if not my most favorite college classes. His instruction was clear, funny, and effective. Plus, he is highly academic and intelligent as a PhD from Standford and a top member in his field. I would take his classes over and over if I could. Highly recommed.
Professor Bulman is a top of the line professor who genuinely cares about teaching and has mastered it.

Bulman has been my favorite professor at UCSC, took both ECON113 and ECON104, you can tell he is extremely passionate about teaching and the material that he teaches. His classes are definitely not easy. The only thing I do not like is that he uses STATA instead of R. However, it is for sure worth taking his class
Tough grader.
So much homework for STATA and always a heavy grader. Won't take it again.

George Bulman has been my favorite teacher so far in the economics department at UCSC. Really got me interested in the subject of econometrics as a discipline. His class isn't a cake walk but if you put in the work he will help you succeed. Something about him makes you want to try hard and try to impress him. Study the practice exams!!

Bulman is a great choice for this class! His tests are very fair and reasonable. He gives old tests for practice. The test curves were generous and most people did well. The material can be challenging at times, but he explains it in a way where it's not so difficult. Highly recommend!

Bulman is the best professor I have ever had. I took his class in F18. He gives the best lectures. His slides are accessible, and will give you a good understanding of the course content. If you pay attention to his lectures and study, you will do well in the class. He is extremely helpful and will do his best to see you succeed in his class.

Had him F17, 2 midterms & 1 final. He gives out pop quizzes and his homework is graded on correctness and completion. Everyone loves Bulman but I'm not sure why. He presents himself as a "chill funny prof who cares and is accommodating" but he's actually stubborn, rude, and not accommodating. He teaches off his slides, so his style isn't the best.

Class had excellent structure with completely accessible supplemental materials. The five homework assignments definitely prepared you for both midterms and the final. Course material built upon itself, be careful to not fall behind. Bulman is funny and knows how to keep your attention. Not an easy class but all the resources are there to succeed

Bulman is pretty awesome! The class itself is hard (it's an upper div) but he really does his best to make it easy. Instead of just saying the proofs and moving on HE ACTUALLY GIVES US REAL EXAMPLES (something a lot of other econ professors should do). Extra info: 5 pop quizzes, do not procrastinate on homework, pay attention if you want to pass

He is is kind of narcissistic but that's part of his charm. This class is more difficult than Meinger but I promise you this class prepares you for upper divs much better. Spent 5 hours a week on homework and more for finals prep. Expect weekly homework. Go to MSI for state and test help. He gave 4 or 5 pop quizzes in my quarter but drops one.

Honestly one of my best college classes. Each test utilizes the elements that you learned in class. His lectures help you understand the material and is a fun guy to listen to. He may seem intimidating at first, but if you put in some effort to understand then it's easy.

George is definitely one of the best professors I have ever had. His lecture is interesting and extremely well structured. He was always well prepared and teaches with passion and wit. He leaves out the unrelevant and knows when to go in depth or give real-life examples and applications. The homework he assignes is very helpful. Grading very fair.

One of the greatest professors I have ever had. He has great passion for teaching economics and it shows through his preparation & presentation of his lectures. His level of expertise made the material much easier to comprehend and more enjoyable. I would recommend taking any and all classes with him. He is tough but fair and thats all one can ask.

This guy rocks. I completely knew nothing about econometrics and after taking his course I fell in love with it. This guy has so much passion, talent, and organize class structure that can help you succeed. Assignment are tough, but if you do it you will learn, there are tons of resource available (smart TAs, great slides).  It is really do-able!
His auditing class was moderately difficult, but all relevant and necessary material was made available, and he was willing and able to answer questions.

One of the best professors at UCSC for Accounting courses. She cares about her students and allows makeup exams for those who were not able to/ not ready for the exam. Her exams are tough, but if you go to lectures and pay attention, she does a lot of practice problems in class. She is extremely generous with partial points and curves really well.

She is a newer professor but is very kind and works to make sure you have the opportunity to do well in her class. Lecture heavy but her lectures are based directly on the books so if you miss, easy reference point there. Multiple exams but gives chances to retake exams and they're based on class problems. Can be a lot of work but so is accounting.

She made a LOT of mistakes that made me stopped going to class bc lectures soon became a waste of my time. She would spend half the class time working on a single problem and have to ask for help. As for the 2 midterms and final, just study the in class problems. Material-wise I had no problem. No late exceptions though.
Very good professor with clear instructions and explanations

Professor Aaron is honestly one of the best at UCSC. I took Econ 125 and 197 with him and learned so much. There's a lot of writing, but it actually helps you grow. Attendance isn't required, but active-learning days are super helpful. Plus, he's genuinely one of the funniest people I've ever met.

He's a decent enough lecturer (if you like his style) but that's really the only positive thing about the class. The amount of busywork assigned is colossal. Three papers, weekly short responses, more short responses or essays if you miss the dull activities. Scope of essays are both narrow and vague. Grading is opaque, syllabus inconsistent.
Extremely rude condescending to students as well as a rather large amount of irrelevant busywork. Would take 104 instead.

He pretty much lets us use any sources we want to write our essays (I can't say it because I don't want the light beam to get in trouble, but it rhymes with 'cat buy my teas'). It was honestly an easy class for me, and I didn't pay attention to the class material, but I got everything I needed while he was talking. He's hilarious to me.

I don't understand why people say he's rude. This is completely untrue. Those students are way too sensitive. Not only have I seen him going out of his way to help other students, but throughout the quarter, I have gone to him for help, and he was lenient and extremely kind. He's a fair grader and his lectures are some of the best I've encountered.
Easy, but he's rude to students who seek help.

Professor Meininger was a good lecturer with entertaining classes. Textbook and HW are online with everything being due at the end of the quarter. Midterm was an in-class essay. Final was a minimum 8-page paper connecting the major economic periods studied and the future. Random in-class learning assignments used as attendance.

Lecture Attendance is optional, but helpful due to in-class assignments with alternative assignments if you miss class. Lots of essays to write based off of theory and concepts learned throughout Lower-Div Economics course material. Great lecturer and does a good job connecting concepts to real-world events and examples.

Didn't think I would learn a lot from this class but was pleasantly surprised. Lectures are really informative and ties into real world examples. Papers can be tough but is to be expected since it is a capstone class.

This is a capstone class that ends in a spoken presentation. You are not required to show up to class but you absolutely should if you care about your return on time. The professor makes it very down to earth and wants you to participate. Love bringing his lectures to more real world or recent events. Keep in mind its an econ class not poli sci.
The other reviews that are here are all wrong.

really condescending and makes many disrespectful comments, I asked him for help for  an essay and to schedule a meeting because I was struggling w personal stuff and he sent me a 2 sentence message that told me to just P/NP the class without trying to help (this was v early on in the class) while my other prof acc met w me, lectures are useless

Too much busy work! Lectures are useless but you have to come to class once a week for the active learning assignment. 4 papers and 4 reading assignments (minimum-10 100-word annotations) throughout the quarter. Final is a 20 minute presentation on a policy and accompanying paper. He does not like when students disagree with him.Rude to students :(

I can see why he wouldn't be everyone's favorite, but I'm a fan of his lecturing style. I will say it's too much busy work: a reading assignment and in-class assignment each week, 4 1000 word essays, a huge essay at the end of the class (but you can synthesize all your 4 previous essays into one big one), and a 10-20 minute presentation as well

The most insane professor I have ever had. Insanely disrespectful/condescending to his students. Don't even bother asking clarifying question because you will be grilled for not knowing the answer. HE THREATENED TO FAIL A STUDENT IN FRONT OF THE CLASS BC HE WAS "DISRESPECTFUL". Take this class if you have the patience to not square up with him.

Lectures are very convoluted & longwinded, no end point in sight. makes a lot of offensive/weird statements. Doesn't know how to speak to students, extremely condescending, & honestly insane. I've never met an adult who respects his students less but demands respect back. If you take him kiss up. threatened to fail a student in front of the class.

Worst prof I've encountered at ucsc. I asked him for help on the essay bc i was confused and struggling and he just sent a copy and paste respond from chat gdp. Used inappropriate language and made offensive comments during class. Honestly could not stand him and I felt that it wasn't a good learning environment for me so I had to drop it.
