If you prefer writing essays than taking tests take this ECON elective! The class is lecture-based and weekly active learning assignments are group/interactive based. The prof is entertaining, very flexible with due dates, and likes connecting the ECON U.S. history to current-day situations.

Rude. Typical high school jock that thinks his jokes are funny and continue to bullies student. Multiple students had reported him for his disrespectfulness. This class is easy, however it's completely unbearable. You don't learn and it is just a bunch of busy work.

Professor Hu is great! She lectures very clearly and her tests match the material to a T! Although she doesn't keep track of attendance go to every lecture, she posts guides ahead of time but you will miss a lot of information if you aren't present. Ask questions, she is very willing to explain. The hardest thing were the currency reports.

Each week we will have a quiz about last quiz's context. For midterm is about a currency report and for final you can work with other people to write an investment report. The professor is really nice and gives feedback immediately. Last few quizzes are little bit hard but can drop the lowest grade.

Dr Hu plays no games. She expects you to show up prepared and ready to go. The fact that she treats you like a junior economist / financial analyst is both wearing and incredibly helpful for professional development. I would recommend.

I enjoyed taking her class. She has tremendous knowledge about international finance and knows what she is talking about. She provided concise and clear explanation in class. She was also extremely helpful and caring during office hours. The exams were difficult and long though.

She's a very challenging professor. Her lectures are incredibly difficult to understand and when asking for help or clarification she often gets frustrated and directs you to your notes. Take this class if you want to be unnecessarily stressed for the duration of the quarter. The curve is huge but once again there's no point if you don't learn.

She's a great,but challenging professor. Her lecture notes are very in depth and she expects you to know everything. Her homework is more tedious than difficult. Her tests are difficult, but she gives a generous curve at the end of the class. She's also very caring and would gladly help on any questions you have. She's very pretty also.

He will take joy in failing you over a rounding error. Half the course boils down to long multi-step financial calculation problems where at the end, if you give an answer like 2.014 instead of 2.015 , he will give you a zero. So he can tell you know the content but will still give you a zero, I don't know any other teacher that does this.

Would-be good lectures held back by fast pace and poorly formatted slides. Interesting projects and short response essays held back by oddly strict formatting rules and tough inflexible grading. Good homework system but a bit too much busywork. Far from the funnest class but you'll learn.
Worst grader, everyone is confused
He wants to see you fail

Far too many course topics with two busy-work style online homeworks due every week (through his own paid homework software). Lecture slides are messy and throw poorly formatted equations at you. Will contradict himself in office hours to the point where the TA cannot interpret what is expected of students, rendering mandatory sections useless.

Homework is on a paid online service, not super hard. Professor isn't very responsive to circumstances and grades rather harshly for things which don't make sense. Final exam on ProctorU and mandatory discussion section. He isn't the best person to be teaching a class on topics which otherwise would be interesting.,
genuine waste of time of a class. not much effort from the instructor to make it engaging or fair for students.

Class has potential to be really interesting, instead it's the same sort of busywork also combined with tough grading over small nitpicks. It might be the easier elective to choose for finance, but I'd take it with a different professor if I could.

not too many assignments but long and time consuming on a website you have to pay for, essay assignments which otherwise seem straightforward are graded extremely harshly. quite a condescending attitude towards students and speaks rather critically on everything. video recordings taken from someone else, class isn't worth any time at all.

Very knowledgeable professor who has a high expectation of thier students. Willing to field any questions, related to the class or personal, in office hours. Very specific grading criteria, as he wants to ensure you understand the material, and will grade toughly, but as long as you engage with material and study, the class is not unfair.

Worst professor I've ever had at this school. He grades as if teaches rocket science when the concepts of this class would be comprehensible to a 5 year old. He provides horrible feedback and doesn't respect his students.

Worst teacher I have had at UCSC and there have been some really bad ones.  His grading on assignments is an enigma as his slides look worse than most students.  Has never had a successful startup so not sure why he teaches a startup class.  Very condescending.  Avoid this teacher like the plague.

He is super rude, and condescending. Its truly a shame that he is teacher for such great classes (133, and 135). I had issues with canvas for FINAL exam, and he did not allow me to reopen the assignment, nor did he even offer any advice.

Kai is a great professor. He has a fair and structured grading model. His TA (Roberto) was really helpful/patient and explained everything very well. There are several problem sets and weekly essays. Attendance is mandatory because he has in class polls worth a lot of points. Final project worth 30% (done on excel) He will help if you ask for it!

Asynchronous lectures available every Saturday. Every other week a 2-person group short essay is due. On off weeks, a discussion that relates to real life events is due. Weekly problem sets and Excel sets, works great for studying since each answer gives feedback. Gives a study guide at the beginning of the quarter for the final. No midterm.

Graded by a weekly homework set, weekly essay questions (with a partner), piazza contributions, kahoot questions, a minute long presentation, and a group project as the final. Class structure overall is easy to follow, and very fair. Kai can be a little rude at times, perhaps unknowingly, but he's very knowledgeable and willing to help.

Don't waste your tuition and time on this terrible class and professor. You can't learn anything from this class if you don't study by yourself. Although this is an online class, he didn't even record any video lectures. You also need to pay to do your homework on a trash website, what a joke! THIS IS THE WORST CLASS I HAVE EVER TOOK IN UCSC.

This course doesnt have any real lecture recorded by the professor. He just give you some poor PDF notes, and it didnt help your at all. You also need to spend money on a website, in order to do the homework and one of the online final. You also need to take another proctored final. In conclusion if you didnt learn by yourselves, you cant pass.

Amazing professor. Kai puts in a lot of effort to make the topics very engaging by providing anecdotes from real-time events to make key topics interesting. I learned a lot from taking several of his undergraduate courses and would highly recommend him. You will have to work for your grade but the learning experience is worth it and very rewarding.

Kai is a solid professor. He knows how to push his students with participation and can encourage the class to study and stay on top of studying. He has good knowledge of the topics and shares some sarcasm here and there.

the professor is awesome, most engaging lectures ive had so far at ucsc. course content is interesting, but there's a mandatory $90 etext + smartbooks :(( attendance not graded but he gives quizzes in class, section attendance is graded tho. midterms online open note and final in person with cheat sheet. i loved this class!

The class is very straightforward, as long as you watch the lecture videos and make sure to do all the work on time you should pass. The group project takes some time but is not difficult if your group is good.
Great class, and structured well! Lectures are extremely worthwhile to watch for content. Group project is chill if you have a good group!

Such an amazing Professor!!! His lectures are actually recorded by him and worthwhile to watch. I feel like it's really engaging overall, and alongside class work which isn't overly challenging, it's really a chill experience. Professor Owen obviously cares a lot about this class and his enthusiasm is seen.

The absolute goattt! Professor Owen is a great professor and this class in particular was useful and I found myself excited to go to class. The group project takes up about 80% of the class so make sure you're with people you like/can work well with. There's a few chapter readings and quizzes but nothing unbearable. Take this class!!

its online and lecture videos are amazing. we have quizzes (20Q+, 20min), a midterm and a final. Group project is kinda easy but make sure you have GREAT people!! only thing you dont get feedbacks is on the group project.

Professor Owen is someone who cares about his students and wants them to succeed. His teaching style is easy to follow and he is always ready to help. I've taken a few of his classes and always had a great learning experience -139B has been my favorite!

class itself is an easy topic, you can get by through learning via textbook. Owen is a  good professor, but i find him better in his marketing and ecommerce classes. 2 midterms (online), 1 final (in person), will give extra credit if you answer questions in class. overall a decent professor and it is an easy class with lots of value

I have taken 3 classes with Professor Owen and I also had the pleasure of working with him as a grader. He truly wants his students to succeed and he is very understanding. 

ECON 139B was by far my favorite class that I have taken with him as the learning experience was very hands on and interactive.

Have taken many good classes with him, 139B was the best. Super useful and unique real-life experience with Google Ad development & real businesses. This professor is wonderful & cares about your future. He will help you succeed if you put in the work in the class. It's not an overwhelming amount of work, but definitely something to put time into.

The class is textbook material heavy with lots of timed quizzes and two midterms. There is one final group project that is a large component of your grade, but is manageable if you divide up the work. Owen is great professor with very well-produced lectures! This class was taken asynchronously.

Very charismatic and engaging prof. If you share in class, he often provides extra credit, but if you want to do the whole class based on the textbook you could. He also is active in the field of consulting, and occasionally brings alumni to talk about thier experience after college, so there is a big focus on real world skills too.

This course was async and online for me. It was a lot of reading of online textbook and homework and quizzes but very clear guidelines and not too difficult. The end there is a group project which can be fun and practical if you get a good group. I would take this class with friends so you can work on project together.

This was one of my favorite courses at UCSC. It was about e-commerce but a large portion of the class was a group project. It had a lot of practicality and looks great on a resume. Professor is awesome and cares about his students. As long as you go to class, participate and read any course materials given you will be fine.

Professor Steve is an outstanding professor with vast experience in business and marketing. His 139B class was incredibly valuable, likely the best upper-division economics elective I have taken at UCSC. The course is packed with practical information on e-commerce. I would honestly recommend this course for a hands-on fun learning experience.

This class has one major group project where you work together to create a google ad for a NPO. As long as you work on your project outside of class and make your client happy, this is an essay A. Homework is very light with quizzes every 2 weeks & textbook check for understanding. Would recommend taking with your friends due to lots of group work!

He is passionate about teaching and does it for fun, which shows. Sometimes he plays games in class. The amount of work given is reasonable, but it is assigned on Monday and due Friday which can be difficult to complete. Textbook is mandatory, but his exams are mostly from the textbook so as long as you do the homework you can easily pass the exam.
easy class

Steve is a great professor, he has a lot of business and marketing experience. I thought his 139B class was really great. Probably the best UD econ elective I have taken at UCSC. So much useful information in the world of e-commerce! We worked in groups with a non profit to run ads, final exam and quizzes were sort of difficult but manageable.
Easy class, only thing that sucks is the tight deadlines, assignments created Monday but they're due Friday.

Came into first few lectures w some tuff ass fits. lectures are kinda boring and there is mandatory attendance. you're highkey better off just reading the textbook though. Material is kind of confusing especially if u have no economics experience, The final was WAY easier than the midterm. Go to class and do the reading, you'll be fine.

I'm taught remotely, so I don't see the professor except during office hours. You need to buy your own textbooks, and the weekly assignments and quizzes are the same. There are occasional unexpected Zoom meetings; I missed an exam for some reason and didn't receive a reply to my emails for three days.  you need to pay for your own proctors.

for someone who didn't know anything about econ, julie made it very understandable. I took this class for GE credit, and while it was a hard GE, it was very interesting and I feel that I spent my tuition money well taking this course. her lectures are easy to follow, make sure u stay on top of everything and ur chill. she allows cheat sheet on test

I took her micro course online. Literally zero communication at any point throughout the quarter. The canvas due dates were off by months, showing that she hadn't updated her due dates since last quarter.
chillest teacher ever 10/10

Julie was an amazing professor and this was one of my favorite classes I have taken at UCSC. She is incredibly smart and is one of the few professors who gives personal feedback on your essays! Julie also has impeccable comedic timing which adds a ton of enjoyment to class. You can tell she wants you to learn and do well in the course!

i liked this class. classw as mandatory, and she does little practice problems at the end of class. the lectures were boring but straightforward and attending lectures were really helpful. hw was the same every week ( you have to pay like 80 bucks for the textbook/ hw). the midterm nad the final was pretty easy if you understand the material.

I took Julie for Econ 2 and I actually enjoyed her. Her lectures are monotone but if you can sit through them, she explain the material very well. Her homework are not hard, my only issue was the midterm was infinitely harder than the final. That being said, she gave extra credit at the end and have a nice curve that pushed me from a B- -> B+

tbh dont take this class online - not the easiest and not orginized online class, this is meant to be an in person class, midterm and final worth large percentage of grade, the homework is through pearson, personally not for me

Professor Gonzalez's class can be challenging, but with the right approach it's manageable. The lectures can be hit-or-miss, so supplementing with the textbook and tools like Unstuckstudy are key. Stay on top of assignments and you'll do well.

I took this class online over the summer. Julie was a very kind and caring professor. Her lectures were interesting and well structured; homework and quizzes were kind of hard. Her tests are quite difficult, but she gives lots of hints if you go to review sessions. Tests were online and proctored. She also offers lots of extra credit opportunities.

Professor Julie Gonzalez was super interesting when she lectured, does do tricky midterms though, (on purpose). Would NOT recommend during winter in person (took fall quarter ), unless she records. It is a better vibe for in person class. Lots of homework but cool tangent stories,(college stories go wild). Makes Micro-Econ personal and practical!!!
Video notes and the assignments teach themselves.

This was an asynchronous course. Lectures were pre-recorded. Weekly mandatory sections with TA. Weekly homework and quizzes given through McGraw Hill. Quizzes are proctored online. Overall decent class, definitely have to hold yourself accountable and watch all the lectures. Professor is nice. Light work load.

I feel like what she teach in class is related but hard for me to understand the hw, quiz. Quiz are similar to homework and you need to spend a lot of time on the hw & quiz. I don't know do I understand the concept the wrong way or is hard for me to understand what she said sometimes. She got 1 index card for you on the 3 exams, which is helpful.

I took macro first and the first test is basically just macro and I got a 75 raw score. The average was in the 50s. This class IS NOT FREE. I spent more time studying for this than ECON10A just take a different professor if you are not coming in with prior econ knowledge. She's funny though, but doesn't cover everything you need to know for tests.

TAKE IN PERSON! Overall I understand why she is disliked, and goes on these tangent stories somewhat related to her point. The tests were tricky but she curved and I successfully petitioned TAs for a better score, the class was easy to follow. She uses Pearson (76$), EMail TA, Scantrons provided. Go to every lecture if possible &you will pass!

Her midterms and finals were quite difficult but she curved all of them. I'd recommend going over the textbook chapters every week instead and just skim through the videos. She has a lot of extra credit lectures as well that increases your grade by 1% so make sure you attend them if you can.

The lectures are boring, long, and hard to get through but I often didn't watch the lectures and taught myself concepts using the homework and textbook - that's how easy it is. I find it hard to believe that anyone taking this online couldn't pass this class. You need to purchase access to homework/textbook which was like $70-80.

She either went too fast or too slow during lectures and was always behind in the homework and quizzes that were assigned. She honestly is not good at explaining anything, so I basically read every page in the textbook and taught myself everything. The exams were only 18-20 (72 points tho) questions long, so if you even got 1 wrong you had a B.

Jessie Li is a genius among geniuses. Her lectures are sometimes monotonous given that she rarely interacts with students in lecture. Her exams are difficult. However, she is incredibly bright, helpful, and accessible outside of class. She cares about the success of her students and wants to ensure they have a strong command of the material.

Professor Li is so far the best econometrics professor I have ever taken. Her depth of knowledge is truly amazing and seems to find always find another explanation to concepts taught. However, I would only recommend her if she teaches along with recorded lectures as it is hard understand the concepts and review.

Professor Li teaches great and being her student, you can think of you as a top university student. MSI teaching style. I love her teaching because only hard working people will understand the deep knowledge here, others who disagree are not that respectful to the top level. Her class is hard but is really workable, if you want growintellectually

i have to say everyone who takes her class is a true hero. her lectures are extremely hard and her pace is super fast. You have to admit how smart she is. just too smart to teach you know. Our class is around 70 people but only 20 people will go to class since going to class wont help you understand either.

I studied for one day before the final on addy and got an A in the class since everyone failed, the final average was around 50%. The class itself wasn't that hard and I would definitely take it again just because the curve makes it really easy to pass. Just go to sections and understand the properties of every statistical function.

Jessie is very hard to learn from. She throws up a bunch of variables and confusing formulas on non-interactive PPs. She grades very hard on the homework as HW is meant to be harder than problems on the tests???. The class even asked her to add a bit more examples on the lectures and show us more problems like would be on the test-she refused.

This Professor is extremely smart but does not know how to teach. Fall 2017 was her first year teaching at UCSC. She provided homework and tests that could not be completed in a timely manner and the average for each assignment was D's or C's. I would advice taking this class with a professor with much more teaching experience.

Professor Jessie Li is by far the hardest professor i've ever had in terms of learning experience. I attended every lecture, took notes, and read the textbook. Even with a nearly perfect score for every assignment and attending every MSI section, I still did horrendously on the exams. I would strongly discourage taking ECON113 with Professor Li.

She's really nice but the way the class, homework, and tests are structured is pretty rough. First time teaching so maybe it will improve. The homework always seemed really tough compared to in class work. Not a natural teacher but she definitely cared which is more than some prof.

The class consist of 70% Exams with a 30% hw grade. The midterm was impossible to be completed within the timeframe given (No one in my class finished within the given timeframe). Just pray for the curve to be fat

Professor doesn't care whether or not students are actually understanding the material. She speeds through lectures and examples without clarification. It was her first time teaching this class so she will hopefully make improvements. Final average was 50%, ended up with a 55% in the class with and a B+ in MyUCSC. Extremely ungratifying.

I like to think you don't need to be a genius to get good grades, just a good work ethic. 3rd yr with a 3.93 GPA and I've dealt with my fair share of bad professors. Jessie Li is by far the worst professor I've ever had. She went twice the speed as other classes, covered twice as much information, and gave ridiculously difficult homework and exams
Do not take this class. You will regret it. She is a nice person, but absolutely wrecks her students with homework we can not do and provides zero resources for midterm and final.

Teaches subjects too fast without caring if students understand. She wouldn't tell us any specifics about the exams. Homework is due about every other week and includes a program she won't teach you how to use and the other non program questions are so difficult you usually can't even start. Completely depended on MSI tutoring for this class.
Not bad. Teaching style was good, but easy to get distracted.

One of the best econ professors at UCSC. Class may seem daunting but there's only 5 writing assignments for the quarter. Chill lectures and he is also as a person, just really friendly and obviously wants you to do well. Allowed to use AI in the class on papers and analysis.

He's probably the worst lecturer I have ever experienced. The exams are extremely easy and the homework is too, but the final project is almost impossible because of how disorganized he and the TA are. I don't know if Im doing anything right and much of this stuff is not really taught in the class.

lectures are boring and often prof. would skip slides in class, only for them to be useful to learn how to do calculations. 2 midterms identical to practice midterms, so it is easy to get by without lectures. group final project- did not seem well organized and both professor and TA were difficult to speak with on how the project worked.

Would give him a 4.5 but that's not an option. Sections are mandatory, overall class is quite easy because of very very simple assignments and easy quizzes and exams. His lectures may be a bit boring but overall Prof Singh cares about students and is a nice person to talk to outside of class. He's occasionally witty.

I'm a UCD student who took this class through UC Online. It's an interesting class and I learned so much about my heritage. Dr Singh (in lecture vids) is easy to understand and explains things well. All lectures are recordings. There are 3 discussion posts but you only need to do 2.

Amazing professor. Lectures are a bit boring but he tries to be engaging. Graded on 5 hw assignments and a 10 page final paper, professor is easily accessible for feedback. Extremely caring, wants students to succeed, accepts homework assignments even weeks late with minimal point loss because he just wants students to do the work and do well.
So passionate and understanding

Great professor. Lectures are very boring, but he does make an effort to keep things interesting. Content is pretty straight forward and tests aren't too bad. Bi-weekly problem sets (very easy) and mandatory weekly sections. Final paper is 10 pages, no final exam.

My favorite professor so far in college. Super sweet, caring & understanding. Grading is pretty straightforward. You'll know the criteria on which you're being graded. Definitely attend lectures since he goes over all the answers for the assignment during class. Easy A.

Professor Singh was one of the best professors I have taken in my life, his lecture videos are very helpful and are full of knowledge. To a beginner learning about Sikhi the lectures are very helpful and even those that know alot they can end up learning a lot as he uses lots of factual sources. Overall light assignment load and kind human being.
Professor Singh is really good. It is obvious he cares about the content. The class isn't too bad, just don't fall asleep in lectures. You can pass just by paying attention.

Very passionate about the subject (introduction to the Sikhs), he clearly loved teaching the class & watching students engage with the culture. Easy and accommodating to any of the students needs. Super fun and easy two unit class

Very nice man. The class could have been more effective (he told us attendance was not mandatory so just about literally no on came on a regular basis) unfortunate because he wasn't a bad teacher, there was just a lot of information, and it could all be found in the book. He curves the grades at the end so everyone passes. Tests were a tedious joke

H's a great professor who knows his stuff! This class is a lot of abstraction and common knowledge, but it's broad enough that you will find things you don't already know, and it may connect things you did already know in ways you hadn't seen before. This class requires your focus, but if you care about the material and try, you'll do just fine.

This teacher is very good. He is a very sweet man who teaches well. He is passionate about his subject he teaches and does a good job preparing you for tests which are not too challenging. He is fair grader. Would recommend for an econ elective.
Nirvkar is a boss. If you want to take econ 139, take it with him
Easy to follow along in class

great class. a little on the easy side, but its interesting material for those new to the subject. singh is a very fair grader. you will also enjoy free candy and make up quizes. all in all this is the easiest econ classs ive taken at SC.
E-commerce was by far the easiest class... but I've heard the other class he teaches is tough.

Professor is very chill. No homework outside of class usually. 80% of the grade is made up of the midterm and final. Rest of the grade is a group project that is worked on the entire quarter. Overall good class but really study for the exams otherwise you're cooked.

There's very little work in the class (basically one main project) but the tests are graded so harshly. He'll take off half the points if you don't give the exact answer he wants even though most are opinion based questions. Its basically a big guessing game.
the course is very difficult

He obviously loves what he's doing. Biggest drawback is the content, some of it can be unexciting but most is interesting to learn about. Alonso uses current events and applications too. Midterm is a little tough but final project is pretty easy. Great low work elective to take overall, if you go to TA sections, HW answers are given to you.

Chillest teacher ever, very laid back and down to earth. Explains things very well and passionately, though he has a moderate accent. He makes the TAs work through the homework in section so they basically give you the answers. Tests can be hard but the grading scheme is very reasonable. Very knowledgeable

I took his 5 week online summer class and it was pretty good. Final and midterm combine for 45%, generous curves, and drops a lot of different assignments which help boost your grade. Homework answers are just given to you if you show up to TA sections. If you kinda just keep up and put in decent effort, he lectures well!

As long as you go to lecture and TA sections you'll pass the class. All the information for assignments is sort of given to you if you show up. Content is pretty complicated though so you kind of need to do extra practice on your own to do well on the midterm and final.

Took his class online on zoom and it was one of my favorite classes! He makes an effort to provide organized and clear lecture material and breaks down concepts well enough. Lectures are recorded, which helps for writing down notes and reviewing. Tests are online, but very similar to homework and he provides material to prepare ahead of time.

He is kind and enjoys teaching. He does not have too much homework, mostly quizzes after each lecture. They are not too bad. He even drops the lowest quiz and homework grades. The only downside is that the final and midterm are very difficult.

he is a nice person, not a good professor. lectures are hard to understand, they're dense with information you may never need, it is hard to understand what's going on and what to remember. gave many supplemental assignments that help & the TAs help with problem sets, but I did not feel prepared for any exam. don't recommend!

His lectures are a waste of time and it's difficult to extract what you really need to learn. The only reason I made it through the class was because of the textbook. Also, he is terrible at responding to students and is the worst at providing studying material. Only five homework, of which one is dropped. Good luck.

As long as you attend lectures, do the problem sets, and study his past exams(provided) you'll do well. I did really well in his class despite not reading the textbook. His lectures are all that's needed. Take his class!

There are professors and there are professors. Decent lectures, but honestly don't expect to learn much in this class. There's a decent curve for the midterm and final, and your TAs can be very helpful in this class.

I dont understand why he has so many positive reviews, hes not even a decent professor. Heavy accent, hard to understand, boring material. His midterm is worth 35% and final worth 50%. Spent so much time for his class and still didnt pass. His final and midterm were really difficult and the grading scale is too test heavy. Dont take his class!!

Alonso is 10/10 the GOAT. His lectures are very informative, and he is always happy to answer any question you might have. There are 5 homework assignments and a few extra credit ones a mid term and a final. Highly recommend taking his class.

Alonso is the GOAT, he is very thorrough in his lectures and gets the points across very clearly. The homework assignments can be tedious but they are graded on effort so as long as you show that you actually tried all will be fine. His tests are also a bit tricky but they are very similar to homework and practice tests, so just study them. A+

He might have an accent but is still very clear with the topics and how to solve for certain things. Honestly a super chill dude his tests are hard but he curves them and the class and he seemed to be generous with partial credit. All in all a respectable professor and I hope i can do some internships under him in the future.

Really passionate lecturer, goes over concepts well and reviews the previous lecture as a refresher. He's straight-forward and provides the exams of previous quarters so you can review and see how his exams are like. Midterm was 35% and final was 50% of your grade but he curves the exams and gave a generous overall curve at the end of the quarter.
Great dude. I didn't talk to him once, but he seemed to really care about us. The final and midterm are easier than the problem sets, so the A is pretty straightforward.

hard to access -- pretty much disappeared after classes got moved online. emailed him about the final and he opened my email (i have bananatag) and just ignored me. didn't give us any info on the new format of the test until a couple days before. we can't go back to finished problems on the final!!????!? pretty clear he doesn't care about teaching

Great teacher-lectures are a bit dry, but he goes over concepts very well and often reviews them lecture after lecture. Problem sets are a little tricky, but his midterm and final are relatively easy and very similar to the problem sets. Overall, good class and straightforward grading wise.

Villactora is a very good econ professor here. I honestly learned so much from this dude in 100B. He's very straight forward and as long as you do the work then this should be a very easy A. I got a 92 on my midterm and got curved to 107 so he's really generous with his curve. Nothing can go wrong with this guy. Just put in the work to do hw.

He is an amazing professor def the best I've taken here at Santa Cruz. He cares a lot about student's success in class. I 100% would recommend taking his courses. This was my first upper div here at santa cruz and honestly, it felt way easier than Econ 2 with Shenoy. For all my BME/Econ people who want to learn and get an easy A, this is the man!!!

Paulo was amazing professor who listened to student feed back throughout the quarter and adjust class according to feedback right as soon as possible (usually the next class). He cares about our thoughts on the subject and is really open to making class accessible to all students regardless of disability status. I had him for Ed 10 too.

Paulo is not at all a bad professor and certainly has good intentions for his students. He is a kind and cheerful guy. That said, he is rather disorganized and not particularly lenient about attendance. His class was easy to pass but attendance is a large part of it. I do not think I learned much from his lectures but he chose interesting readings.

Prof Tan has an amazing attitude and is super dedicated to the class. Readings were interesting and discussed majority of class, along with short lectures. He created a great classroom vibe and is very lenient and understanding of his students. Midterm and final had entirely creative freedom, and you could work with others too. 100% recommend him!

Prof. Higdon was easily my favorite professor for fall quarter. There is a fair amount of reading to prepare for class, which is mainly discussion based in the first half of the quarter and group project time in the second half. He gave good feedback, let us leave early once our work was complete, and seemed to genuinely care about his students.

Nolan is an awesome professor who has really interesting insights into a lot of things, especially if politics and the state of the world are interesting to you. Any problems that I had come from the fact that Merrill 1 spends most of its time being pointless, and not from him. He actually managed to make the course more interesting with his views.

This was the best class I have ever taken. However, it started way too early (8AM). The discussions were fun, and I liked how Nolan gave us all of his publications for free. He knows a lot and will talk about anything students want to discuss.

While there are a lot of readings and writings, as long as you complete the assignments you will get a good grade. He is a lenient grader and easy to reach out to. All the course content is easily accessible through the canvas and you can find a lot of the assigned videos on youtube.
Fun class. Nolan is great. He cares about his students. He told us to find and download a free pdf of his book to save money. The class is really interesting. I highly recommend

Taking this class over the summer and it's an INSANE amount of work. Be ready to read and write every day of the week. Also I find it kind of hypocritical that we had to buy his book when the main focus of the class is advocating for free press. If you are taking this for the TA requirement Id suggest finding something else...

Took this class during summer, there was an insane amount of work even for a summer class. 1,000 word essays due every week, plus 2 250 word responses. Requires an ungodly amount of citations and will assign multiple documentaries each week. Not difficult just a lot of busy work. 

Half of the content is stuff he wrote. Boring class, nice guy.

I took 60 over Summer so it was intense, but Nolan makes it easy. All the readings are free and accessible, as are the videos. He assigns a ton of content but he is lenient grader. Nolan assigns cool stuff and answers emails quickly. I highly recommend

Professor Higdon is a very kind professor. This class is the easiest class I have taken so far. There is only one weekly reflection due every week around 500 words. There are readings in the class but it is fairly doable. He also responds to emails pretty quick.

Loves to give out reading assignments. Make sure you actually do the readings and come to class prepared because there WILL be a discussion and you will look like a donkey if you didn't read at all. Required weekly reflections are open-ended and very easy to complete if you can just put thoughts onto paper.

He is super approachable and clearly cares about all of his students. In terms of the class, there was a 250 word reflection due once a week which he grades very generously as long as you follow the prompt. Also he responds to emails fast. I strongly recommend!

I loved him, one of my favorite instructors in my life. Fun and nice guy but gave good feedback on work if you asked for it. Introvert friendly, never called on me in the class discussions but he made the class interesting. Assigned just the right amount of work for the course.

No final or midterm, lectures are just a bunch of discussions about environmental racism and your grade is dependent on the group projects (which are pretty easy) and field journals (where you pick 5 articles abt your topic and write about it). Professor Higdon is also hilarious and brightens the mood in the class.

Professor Nolan held a very interesting and engaging class! He really pushed you to participate and engage in a elevated class discussions. He's a smart and funny guy and isn't afraid to voice his opinions. The assignments are pretty easy, so you can get away with not reading super thoroughly but he sometimes does ask the class about the readings.

Nolan's a great guy, and while the course seemed interesting on paper, I just don't think this course was for me. There was lots of reading and we were assigned several articles/documentaries to engage with each week and it got a little tedious. He's super funny and cool though! Beware his use of canvas and his lack of due dates!

Nolan is a great prof despite having to deal with pretty bad materials for the Merrill core class. Through no fault of Nolan, the merrill class was pretty boring and assignment heavy, but he did a great job making the class somewhat fun. In comparison to my floormates who are also taking Merrill 1, it seems like Nolan is one of the better teachers

Nolan is a very nice and flexible professor. The only thing I would say is you need to participate in class discussions as much as possible, he really enjoys that! He is very passionate about the stuff he is teaching, amazing teacher!
One of the best professors I had at UCSC, I also took his Educ 160 course which was incredibly interesting and important. Highly recommend!

Dr. Nolan is a pretty cool teacher. The syllabus makes him sound rigid, but he is chill. He had clear directions and graded things quickly. I think the guy doesnt sleep because when I emailed him at night he responded right away. I wish it was in person because he seems like a funny guy.
This class was awsome. Nolan is very involved and gives tons of feedback. Its a great class.

only 2-3 section meetings are mandatory. Lots of group annotating and general assignments, and groups are randomized. Assignments are due Wednesday and Friday, but aren't unlocked until Monday and Thursday respectfully. Auto extensions but only for individual work. Ok-ish at communicating with students.

Her class sucks, the content and readings are interesting but her lectures are repetitive and slow, the way she organizes her canvas is fine except every actually important assignment has at least three different canvas pages dedicated to it all with different information, sometimes conflicting, for the same assignment. micromanages you.

I have never had a teacher be so unsure/unaware of what they were teaching. Don't trust any of her grading criteria, as she doesn't even know what tf she's grading. She is so unbelievably unsupportive it's infuriating. Don't take her class if you have ANY say at all in the matter. She is quite literally THE WORST!

I do not think that I have felt so unsupported by a professor in this way. Her outlines and class expectations are not clear. She makes extensive requirements for her papers that even she cannot comprehend. The requirements of some of her papers contradicted themselves. Her lectures were also unhelpful. It was like looking at a picture book.

Knows how to lecture really well and organize class time. She values communication and attendance over anything else but is really hard to reach outside of class. I was attentive, turned work in on time, and actively participated but she STILL told me to "consider withdrawing" bc I missed 2 classes after emailing her about a major emergency I had.

Professor Lashaw is a wonderful lecturer and deconstructs the course content so you get it in bite-sized pieces that come together nicely by the end of the quarter. I will say that she is very much "no funny business" so be prepared to attend every lecture and section and do all of the readings (usually 70ish+ pages a week).

I adored Educ 160 with Professor LaShaw! She's so incredibly intelligent, a true expert in her field. The structure of this class was phenomenal: each component clearly built off of the first and flowed into the next, and assignments were very clear in their intentions. This class is a life-changer not only for teachers, but for everyone really.
G.O.A.T talk!! This woman is and absolute homie, everything an educator should be and more. I will miss her dearly.

I took her for Advanced Educational Studies and absolutely loved it. She's one of the only UCSC teachers who teaches multiple perspectives/sides to an issue and really pushes you to be able to explain why your opinion is correct. You need to come prepared to class to participate in discussions, but they were really engaging and helpful, love her!!

I've taken two classes with Amanda. She is a great professor and really pushes her class to discuss critical theories her passion is evident. Reading the texts is mandatory for discussions and essays (which are long). Attendance is absolutely mandatory, she has one of the stricter policies. But she is very caring!

Amanda engages her students in critical thinking and self exploration. She is a sweet and absolutely brilliant professor who actively strives to get to know each and every single one of her students. I adore her. My academic career at UCSC would not be complete had it not been for Amanda's lectures.

I took her class for educ 180 and it was amazing! It's your responsibility to stay on top of things in class and I did well! I didn't think the 30 observation hours were difficult because you have to spread them out and of course not try to do all of it in the end. Definitely plan early and make sure you have a flexible schedule.

Lashaw does not outline what is expected of her students until it is too late in the quarter. The syllabus seems to be thorough with information, but she changes her expectations as the class progresses. The 30 hours of observations a week requirement is super stressful, especially since you have to figure out/pay for transportation yourself.

Not over;y good or bad. She planned to take attendance every class, sometimes forgot. Only one reading per week. Tuesdays were lecture review of reading, thursdays was more class activity/group conversation/work day. She loved student participation and being group discussions. All readings are pdfs posted to canvas

There are few assignments so it's hard to pass if you miss literally anything. I explained my mental health struggles and overall situation to her and she was unreasonable and still failed me because of 2 points when I was supposed to graduate this quarter. She also just reads from slides and the rest is boring group work. Thanks a lot Michelle.

Mosqueda is a bit all over the place. This quarter's TA was a tough grader, and it seemed like they were not on the same page/ lacked communication throughout the entire course. He's passionate about education but the lectures are unclear and a bit hard to follow. Also, reluctant to share lecture slides for 177, but shared them for 128. Confusing.

Very unorganized. No grades until week 9, no clear instructions for the midterm/final, canvas was even more unorganized with unclear deadlines (due dates set to 2023/2024). Lots of shouting, and unorganized "yap" learned little/no new info, this class was a major let down and the TA was VERY unhelpful and aggressive even sharing microaggressions.

Very unorganized! I didn't know my grade until week 9 and your grade is dependent on the midterm and the final. He rambles a lot and would often go an entire class without covering the readings. His lectures lack structure & when these concerns were shared with him he got defensive lol. There was also no rubric for either the midterm or final!!!

Professor Mosqueda was awesome! He is very personable and relatable and understanding. He clearly has a passion for his work and I truly enjoyed going to class every day. I have never rated a professor before him, but I had to give him a great review! There are a lot of readings but he discusses them in class so you aren't lost if you miss a couple

My only complaint w this Prof is just how completely unorganized he is. I don't think he prepares for his lectures very much at all, like he just shows up and reads the slides for most of the class period. It can be difficult to follow along. The syllabus didn't accurately reflect assignments, and assignment prompts were frequently wrong/outdated.

Professor Mosqueda was very interesting, however his class was very lecture heavy. I took this class online, and with so little to engage in, I found myself dozing off at times. There were slides and such but it was just hard to focus. There were a LOT of readings too!
A FANTASTIC PROF. His lectures are so informative and full of practical stats for educators. He is clearly very passionate about his work and the work that his students could possibly create.

Was super helpful, cares about your education. Throughout my education courses, classes I've taken with him are more directly applicable to the field and focused on strategies. He's also extremely educated but still down-to-earth.

He is the best Stats professor I have ever had. Period. He is an educator and has a method to teach Stats. His lessons are carefully designed using scaffolding to ease in students to the class material. He is also very humble, approachable, funny, and offers positive constructive feedback. Also, he got his PhD from Harvard!

Had the opportunity to take one of his upper division education classes. I really enjoyed his perspective and take on things. He really challenged myself and other classmates to think critically about the subjects. I would love to take another one of his classes if I could.

Professor Mosqueda is very passionate about what he teaches, however he tends to reuse class materials including readings, videos, discussion topics, etc. I would not recommend taking his class because the material is incredibly repetitive, and the Professor was constantly unorganized and under-prepared. Take another class if you can.
Syllabus was a joke. Dates constantly changed and readings flipped around often. Professor is very helpful and will clarify material. He is understanding and entertaining to listen to. Passionate.

Bit of a heavy reading load, and of course there's a 10 page research paper, but he has you do outlines and drafts along the way so you only have a few pages left at the end. Its not my first choice, but its a decent alternative for an ED class.
One of UCSC's best professors. The material was quite repetitive, but his passion for the subject totally made the class worth the time. If you have a chance to take one of his classes, DO IT!

Seemed like a sweet professor @ the beginning of the quarter. We did asynchronous/synchronous classes which got a little confusing. We were told our midterm was going to be graded a certain grade and to not worry about it too much -- ended up with harsh grades. We were told she could have graded harder. As well, never got our final exams graded.

She isn't familiar w/ Canvas & often didn't upload asynchronous lectures. After weeks of inconsistency, midterms were harshly graded despite saying it would be graded easily. She said grades don't matter & that she views us as grad students. Unresponsive to emails. Also threatened us saying she reviews grad school apps & to watch what we email her.

Nora is a decent professor out of the ones I have experienced in the EDUC department. Her attitude can be a bit aggressive and not the most kind to students, even if she thinks she is a super forgiving professor. The final paper is 10-12 pages which is daunting, weekly discussion posts, and a midterm short answer exam that wasn't too bad.

Nora is the best professor Ive taken! I took her for Span 1 and was sad I couldnt take her for 2. But best believe, Ill be back for Span 3! She is passionate about what she does, and she will definitely challenge you. There a decent amount of homework, not too much not too little. I really appreciate how she only speaks in Spanish. Shes amazing

Nora is so awesome. This class is a lot of work, especially homework, and the tests and essays are graded strictly, but Nora walks you through each step and is very reasonable if there is something the class is having trouble with. I particularly appreciated her inclusion of all genders and sexualities in a reasonably gendered language.

For a kid who's very nearly fluent, this was a hard class. Nora is a spectacular teacher and makes it easy to care about the material, the tests are just really hard. You can prepare well for them by studying directly from the textbook, but there's only so much a person can do.

Nora makes her lectures exciting, and praises even the little improvements you make in your Spanish. Her feedback is directed to the individual, and she care a lot about her students. Participation is super important, and making the effort to ask questions and clarify things in the language is good for your grade and language development.

Nora is a sweetheart who really cares about her students. The first day would be intimidating for people who has never taken spanish before because she only speaks in spanish the whole time. She gives a lot of homework (wiley plus online access code) but they are generally pretty easy. Attendance and participation matters. Her tests are pretty easy

Nora is an amazing teacher! She is funny and amazing at how she teaches the content material. She makes sure you understand everything a provides great examples. She had three chapter tests and a final and they are all do-able with a little studying!

Seora Lang is without a doubt the best language professor, if not outright best professor I have ever had. She is progressive, intelligent, kind, and the perfect teacher. Expect her to challenge you, but give you plenty of hope along the way. Its clear through class time that she has put thought into everything. Easy to get along with and pretty.

Happy to have taken this class. Professor was approachable and supportive. Homework was not difficult compared to other sections. Using other professors slides and regrading is very common in all courses. The professor truly enjoyed teaching, and he was open to feedback. He is new, and so I think he followed the grading criteria from other profess

I will say that I agree with a lot of the comments about him being a tough grader. If you want an A you will have to commit a lot of time and make sure you grasp the material. This quarter was his first time teaching this class, so it was a bit messy. As a lecturer he does his job by explaining the slides. Quizzes were stressful with short time.

Showing up to lectures is a waste of time because most of the slides don't relate to the quizzes. Homework is graded harshly for such minor details missing, it doesn't matter if you show proficiency in the topic. This could've been a fun class, but Martin ruined my experience. I strongly urge you to take this class with someone else.

Prof. Martin claims to have worked on Siri at Apple. He is a very lazy professor. All the slides are copied from Princeton's website. The homeworks are ancient relics from decades ago that have been copied. You will likely waste your time going to lectures. You got docked heavily on HW and quizzes which are weighted way too high. Worst professor I'
Uses old professor slides and reads off of them. The quizzes and homework are super harshly graded. I do not recommend him as a professor. Take someone else.
Doesn't respond to email. I got completely ghosted after sending him 5 different email asking him for assistance.
Bit of a language barrier but funny, entertaining professor who actually cares about his students.
he is a nice guy, but not sure if its the language barrier, he is really bad at explaining and teaching. His lecture slides are filled with mistakes.
He has no clear grading rule. He don't really teach or know how to teach. If you are not a self-learner, good luck.

He doesn't care about teaching, more about his research. He is a spokesman for Mc Hill book company basically, and you must learn everything online, which you purchase for $100. He is funny, but this class was a waste of time. Final was take home, thank god saved me, because honestly there is a massive language barrier and no one understands him.
L E G E N D A R Y

Class was a little disorganized but I think it was his first time teaching it. Otherwise I enjoyed his lectures and also got to learn about his research that he was doing in his lab! Very interesting professor. Would love to work in his lab!
Amazing professor!

Great professor, he has a lot of knowledge about little topics here and there. And its really fun to watch him tie lecture material into real life experiences he's had. Takes his time on the subjects he lectures.
The course book was horrible. Mircea is an amazing person, but not the best lecturer.

Mircea isn't a typical prof that spends entire lectures going through intricate details of a concept but rather gives a broad sense of the topic and relates it to common knowledge all engineers should have but likely don't as first year college students. To do well you'll definitely need to commit time before class to read through the textbook etc

The class material was very easy (the whole course is essentially very simple coding and solving algebra 1 level equations) but Mircea explains everything in the most complicated way possible. He often goes off on tangents talking about his research and upper-div subject matters (complicated stuff). Additionally, the "textbook" is horrible.
Avoid him if you can. A truly awful teacher who manages to make simple material very complicated.

Getting in 'A' is as simple as putting in the work, not procrastinating, and forcing yourself to ask questions when you don't understand something.  This is no easy class. Mircea isn't the best teacher, however he will strongly prepare you for the future. Beware of the friends you make, this class truly roots out the strong and the weak.

Super vague in lectures and is not helpful when asking questions. Usually goes off on tangents during lectures which become completely irrelevant to the class and the homework given is not the easiest.
Didn't learn anything tbh
Funny guy, tough work.  He isn't clear and the class is very unorganized.
Mircea is a terrible professor, could barely understand him. Didn't explain how to do the homework or the labs. Was not helpful. He was the reason I switched my major.

He's a nice guy, but unless you are extraordinarily passionate about analog circuits/IC design, please do not take this class. If you don't already have 50+ years of experience in this field, prepare to struggle. Lectures are him reading off slides and giving very surface level ideas. Homework and exams are super tough.
Nope I'm good

Prof. Pedrotti is pretty dope. ECE80T is deceptive though. It's tough if you don't have any background in electronics. A GE? LMAO. There were some rough stretches for me, as an EE major! Do what that one guy said - take after 5C and with 101.

Pedrotti is dope and super knowledgeable about stuff. Another reason to take this class l8er: ask abt stuf

Much delayed review, but I still reminisce about how difficult this class was. I took this class in Spring 2018. Lectures are extremely dense and hard to follow. He mostly reads off of the slides, and those aren't very helpful either. Don't skip class as there are pop quizzes, 1-2 probs directly from the homework. He curved the class at the end.

Taken this class for GE, but it ends up being a terrible choice. There's so much reading. Lecture and reading don't cover what's in the homework. Don't take this class unless you absolutely wanna devote yourself to physics. Yikes.
Never again.

This course goes very deeply, it is not recommened to take it unless you have taken the professor's undergraduate course. In lecture he just give some brife explanation but in homework and project you need to do a lot. Besides, he ALWAYS give some questions which are not covered by the lecture and textbook, how it make sense???

This class is really hard. The homework is never ending. The only good thing is that the quizzes have problems straight from the hw assignments. Look for the smaller hw problems for potential quiz problems. The midterm was absolutely brutal! The class average for the midterm was 40%.He curves the hell out of this class BUT he waits till the end!!

All I can say is take this class after taking 5C and in conjunction with EE 101 if you can. That's what I did and the class was less than an hour a week of work and a breeze. The final paper is cool but a little time consuming so plan accordingly. Tests are mostly HW problems which you need to learn on your own (or with background from 5C/EE101).

This class is tough. There's a lot of Homework, Pop quizzes, and the final and midterm are very difficult. It is very important you spend the time outside of class studying the material. Just going to class will not prepare you for any of the assignments. Pop quizzes are exact Homework problems and are predictable. Good Luck.

Avoid as much as possible. Boring lectures and has pop quizzes. I did not really learn much from his powerpoint presentations. He mostly read off of the slides. His exams were hard. No one ever got the maximum score on the tests and average was below 50% for both midterm and final. The course was also homework heavy with little time to do them.
not good

The lectures are long and sometimes boring, but he lightens the mood with jokes. There's an overwhelming amount of reading in this course; be prepared for it. If you haven't had Electricity and Magnetism physics already, then be prepared to work hard.

Mr. Pedrotti has been teaching for a long time and clearly understands Electrical Engineering very well. However, the assigned workload is an overwhelming amount of readings and videos. The textbook and readings are not helpful for the homework, the section however teaches how to do the homework. People fall asleep in his lectures & don't show up.
Good class if you have taken physics 5C already, otherwise the homework is a pain. Nice guy and gives fun lectures about history of electricity. The research paper helped me a lot.

Has pop quizzes which are similar to the hw, so its highly recommended that you go to class. Concept of this class is pretty difficult to comprehend, but he does a good job of providing the foundation. Read the book! It helps more than anything! Definitely a tough course but passable. No curve according to him, but I'm pretty sure he did in the end

Thought I was going to fail, but ended up with a B+. He makes you work hard by self studying. Can't just rely on lecture, MUST READ BOOK!! If you pay attention in class and read beforehand, you will do fine. Very chill and nice professor, never seen him mad. Straight Flexin'.
I recommend not taking this class your first year. If I took this last on in my EE career, it would definitely be easier. Easy only for people with experience!!!

I've done the readings as well as attended lecture. Yet, the homework was nearly undo-able. I had to use Google most of the time. The midterm grades were completely random. Pedrotti himself mentioned that the results followed no pattern. nice guy though.
NOT A CHILL CLASS. TEACHER IS NICE BUT DOES NOT NOTIFY STUDENTS WHEN MIDTERM IS NOR DOES HE GO OVER HOMEWORK OR EVEN TEACH WHAT WILL BE ON THE HOMEWORK...NOT CHILL

Professor Bose cares a lot about ensuring that his students are able to follow his teaching although he struggled with this aspect since it is his first time teaching. You will end up spending lots of time reading the textbook, that is key. He truly cares about his students and wants everyone to succeed, so you can expect extra credit opportunities

This is his first time teaching so there's gonna be issues no matter what. Midterms and Final was somewhat like HW. Lectures are confusing sometimes which made it hard to take good notes. I'm certain that he'll improve in the future. He's knowledgeable on the subject and I think he would be great at teaching more advanced courses too(171,172 etc)

He's a chill guy but he has no idea what he's doing. Get ready to be put to sleep in his lectures because he will say a lot of information and you will walk out knowing you just spent 2 hours of your life listening to absolutely nothing. YouTube will be your professor. He's new to teaching so hopefully he is better when you take him.

Professor Vroomen essentially reads off of slides ripped from the textbook and does not lecture properly.  You should depend on the textbook for true understanding of the material. He is very hesitant about posting homework and exam solutions thus making it hard to succeed in his class. He does respond to student feedback in some ways and may curve

TIM50 itself is a pretty interesting class, but lectures are super bland and boring. Some grading is harsh, and weekly online quizzes often have questions which are focused on very irrelevant parts of the readings. Midterm and final are take home. Overall not the hardest class. Super nice TA's who do genuinely help you out. Prof is a nice guy too.

He is very knowledgeable but does not explain relevant concepts to exams or homework during class. Exams always differ from the actual content of the homework. A few of the questions on the (very fast paced) midterm were problems he had never explained how to solve! I broke out because of this class. Do not recommend.

When I took this class and saw the ratings, I was really scared. However, this class isn't that bad. Many students don't bother coming to class, the quizzes are open note. For the database assignments, I had no idea what I was doing and just receive help from TA. The case studies assignments are okay, just do your research.

Basically need to know the content before taking the class. Dry lectures, and the homework he gives isn't supplemented by them. He also doesn't provide feedback, so if you did a problem wrong, you will not know why. He also quizzes you on really small details from lectures and includes problems we've never seen on exams. Take elsewhere if possible.

This class shouldn't even exist as it tries to teach a year's worth of physics. The professor is chill but does not know how to teach. Conceptual lectures with messy handwriting that don't prepare you for homework or online quizzes. OH's give hw answers. Midterm and final aren't too bad but don't come with an equation sheet which is diabolical.

The hardest class I have taken in college, Lectures are completely conceptual while homework and exams are 100% application. Did almost no practice problems in class. Would personally wait to take class with another prof

Agree with the other's it's not a hard class just alot of busywork. Quizzes are kinda bs and cover things not discussed in lecture so read for that as well. Everything is group work that is randomly assigned. I ended up basically doing all the work for my team but honestly it's not hard just refer to the slides. Midterm and final cover same topics.

During practice final review, the professor went over the same problems we went over on the practice midterm review... went over 1 new problem out of 4, you could argue it wasn't even new. New is just what we learned after the midterm.

Avoid him like your life depends on it. I would rather fight two bears with an amputated arm, bleeding out, than ever seeing this man as my professor again. Handwriting is ineligible and the actual material taught is useless in exams. Exam Review sheets are as useful as his teaching. If you need an idea of who he is, lookup Professor Calamitious.

Seriously any review above a 3 is fake news save your time stop reading these and pick a different prof or class. He just doesn't know how to teach and expects everybody to be an expert and picks ridiculously hard problems for people who have never seen the topics before.

Don't do this class with this guy do it with somebody else. He expects you to have a background in this stuff and there is just way too much going on at once. And he just ramps things up more and the HW has very little to do what he actually talks about during lecture. Seriously this class is not worth it save it for another quarter it's that bad.

Guy is incredibly boring but the HW isn't that hard. The quizzes are BS as they test on random topics from the reading that were discussed for 4 seconds so don't bank on the lectures helping you for quizzes. Spends way too much time on mundane topics rather than the ones that actually help you on the case studies. Overall not good not terrible.

Words can't describe the pure evil in this mans heart. Not only does he have the hand writing of a preschool kid but he also mumbles. I've never had a professor more inconsistent with the content on exams vs the content taught. Don't bank on the exam reviews helping you either. Rather, start praying and counting your luck. Do not take this class!!!

confusing lectures with messy handwriting and homework that will NOT reflect what is in the lecture as well as it being graded weeks late without any real feedback. immense stress and time wasted due to an incompetent professor

Class material might've been interesting if the lectures weren't so unbearably dry. HW instructions/quizzes are often unclear and you're assigned a ridiculous amount of reading. Don't bother attending his office hours either, he is super condescending and very dismissive of students' questions and concerns

Vroomen is completely unreachable outside of class. He isn't understanding of outside circumstances whatsoever. Very strict late policy. TAs grade all the work and often dock points without clarifying why they are doing so.

Material is semi-difficult to understand if you have no prior experience, so read the textbook. Lectures are boring but helpful if you don't read. Case studies due almost every week, but they help prepare for midterm and final. 2 database assignments that don't take long. 1 in-class quiz every week, open-note.

Paul is a pretty boring lecturer, and you need to dig deep into his lectures to understand what he is actually trying to teach. There are two weekly readings (which can range from 30-60 pages each), a weekly quiz, two midterms, and the final. Attendance isn't required, but much of the lecture information is in quizzes, so it would be helpful to go.

This guy is such a bad professor it's funny. Lectures were dry and explanations were not given thoroughly. He loved putting the most insane-looking equation on the board with no context and telling the whole class this was "easy", then rambling about unrelated stuff for the next 20 minutes. Anyways, don't take this class with him.

Took ECE129a with him, his 2nd year teaching the class. Really difficult to communicate with (seems to treat every conversation as a chance to deploy one-liners) and isn't clear about grading—some assignments are graded on points, some assignments are graded by completion, lectures are  "mandatory" on the syllabus but doesn't he doesn't ever check.

For perspective, I'm a CE major and needed this class for the ECE173 elective. He is unnecessarily harsh and snarky in my opinion. It is almost impossible to communicate with him outside of the lab. I'm glad it was just a tutorial class because a real EE class with him must be brutal. Avoid at all costs. Van Gelder-level professor, maybe worse.

Peterson might be the worst professor on campus, full stop. His lecture are boring to the point of passing out and they really don't teach you almost anything that you couldnt learn in a 10 minute youtube video at 2x speed. His homeworks/labs/test are long and arduous for no good reason, if you want to waste youre time, go with Mr. Peterson

Complicated professor. He's good at introducing students to interesting EE/CE topics and challenging them to dive deeply into the class material. However, he's obscure about his grading criteria and expectations. Known to gloss over important material, so you're left to learn a lot of it on your own (good skill for Engs). Can be rude or nice.

I had Professor Petersen for multiple classes: analog design, digital embedded design, and a custom RF class.  Since graduating I have worked as a design engineer for 25 years.  I can say that without a doubt that Professor Petersen was the best teacher I ever had at a university and I owe my success to him.  He is an engineer's engineer and IYKYK.

Petersen is a straight up engineer. Take him if you wanna become a better engineer. He's tough asf, rude, and stubborn -- but you'll learn a lot. If you don't really care about EE/CE/RE then avoid him because you won't get anything out of the class.

Literally an amazing professor. He goes to the lab section in person and helps everyone out. Even during the weekend, he spent his personal time with us! He's funny too especially when he talks about CS students lol! Take him!
I'm going to miss this guy whenever I finish taking his class.

This is the most well structured class I've ever been a part of. He structures it in a way where everything builds off of what he's mentioned in class. This gives such a good intuitive understanding to other imperative topics to RF design that it honestly annoys me that other teachers don't copy his style. He cares so much and is all around amazing

Petersen doesn't lecture, just reads off his old notes to the class. The notes are very conceptual and do not prepare you for exams. Gave no feedback on homeworks until the last week, when you wouldn't even be able to utilize his suggestions. He expects you to already know concepts. Prepare to teach yourself. The labs were worthwhile though.

This man doesn't care about students. He is the head of the department which gives him an inflated sense of authority on how he should treat people with less power than him. He actively tries to fail people and gives exams where the average is 30% because he thinks that's normal. He's not interested in teaching, just cashing his paycheck. Avoid him

really bad. would criticize me for asking "philosophical questions" (really just conceptual questions). Likes to feel superior to his students. Makes you write WAY more than necessary on homeworks. Tests are way longer than it would normally take someone to finish.

Petersen is an extraordinarily difficult grader with opaque grading criteria. So far out of 6 homeworks and 5 labs, I have received back 1 graded homework and 1 graded lab. Neither had any meaningful remarks. Homeworks and labs are long and hard. I have no idea how well I am doing in this class and it's very stressful. Avoid if possible.

Great professor. I learned a lot. It is true he will make you REALLY work for it. The tests are really hard, but he grades accordingly (curve). The homework was really really long, but if you spent the time on it you mastered the subjects. If you want to be a great engineer, take Petersen, he will break you down and you'll be better for it!

He wasn't fair with students about the content of the midterm. His huge assignments were focused on the course's theories, and not practical problems. However, the midterm was 90% composed of solving circuits and, since he asks to explain EVERYTHING you are doing, no one could finish the 12 questions. Useless lecture notes. I studied the book.
Such a horrible professor. I don't think you can get much of a worse professor than him. Coming from a person who got an A in his class. I would avoid this guy at all costs.

Petersen was a terrible intro professor. While he was very knowledgeable on the subject, he had no idea how to teach it. His lectures were useless, covering only the conceptual forms of circuitry (which is good for fundamental understanding but doesnt help you at all with homework or tests). His exams were completely unfair and took months to grade

I definitely do not recommend not taking an introductory EE course with this professor. He is very knowledgeable however his teaching methods are not the best, to say the very least  No correlation between instructional material and exams whatsoever. He claims that the questions on the exams will be a certain way but completely throws people off.

Claimed every topic was easy and was "trivial". I think he was accustomed to teaching higher division courses and thought that EE101 topics are very simple even to someone seeing them for the first time.
He doesn't have a clear grading criteria, so that he can give subjective grades to his favorite students

This is my second time with Prof. Chen. I had him for ECE101. He covered many topics in the class but overall is fair. The industry experience he shared intrigued me about this field. He made analog interesting and prepared us for workplace which is useful IMO. Extra bonus questions on the final were very helpful.

lectures aren't recorded. know the material from your prereqs like ODEs and complex analysis. he covered these complex topics in the last two weeks and a significant portion of the final had it. way more time should've been dedicated to these topics in my opinion. the recitations from the TAs are a great help. labs aren't too bad, again, the TAs.
horrible

Knowledgable about the subject but abysmal at teaching. Lectures are fast paced as he mostly reads off of illegible handwritten notes. Grading requirements for the exams were not always clear. He also rushed the last two topics of the final during the last week but made those topics over half of the final. Will avoid in the future if I can.

Does not record lectures, which is a huge hindrance because he can go through material kind of fast. I recommend having an iPad to take notes on top of his posted lecture notes, it was impossible to keep up using a notebook. He is clearly very knowledgable and passionate, and he is a very patient and helpful person but the class structure was poor.

Poor lectures. When doing circuit equations, sometimes refused to show work because 

"ECE 101 is not a math class." 

Quizzes often covered material not relevant to the class and material that had not been taught yet. Homework assignments were difficult to understand, asking for quantities we had not been taught. Combative in-person and via email.
This guy takes down any negative posts, be wary, this class is crazy tough

lectures were clear on material and explained well, grade for the lecture was based solely on midterm and final. With the prof's lectures, TA's recitations (office hours) when needed and working entirely through homework, the tests felt manageable. Gave plenty of partial credit. Lab is no worry if you can follow directions on lab handouts.

A short 5 week summer course which seemed well paced. His teaching style and presentation made it refreshing and easy to follow. The professor replied emails very quickly and gave reasonable bonus points on the exams to catch up our grade, enough for me to get an A at least :) Positive eexperience overall. Hope to get him again in 171.

I believe he curved (to some extent) at the end otherwise I would have no chance of passing, which I am glad he did. The class is not easy even though it's "101". He is very good at his emails and he answered my relentless questions late night and weekends very promptly. Probably he is always on his phone, lol!

Many of my classmates took his 101 in the summer. Once you're used to his teaching style, it becomes easy to follow. But by no means 171 is easy. I feel it's 2x harder than 101 as there is so much more to learn. Also learned something about RF since he is an expert in the industry. Visited a few office hours, very helpful and approachable.

Definitely a challenging course with sound background required. That said, he did a decent job explaining given tight schedule and enormous amount of materials to learn. Notes are clear and aligned with reading. Maybe slow down a bit but understandable cuz of schedule. Office hours are very helpful, recommend go chat with him after class.
