OMG, I passed the course despite didnt do as well on the exams. Anywayz, I attempted the PSPICE extra credit problems which were not eaasy but worth my time and effort. Should've visited his office hours more. He always made sure I left without questions. One of the better professors who cares about students learning in ECE. So happpy now!

Took Chen's 101 last time and just finished the follow-up 171 course with another prof. Glad to have taken 101 with him who spent a lot of time going over examples & focusing on the fundamental which helped me struggle less with 171. He knows how to teach with simple language! Can be strict at times for our benefits. Not for lazy students for sure!

I took 101 with Chen. It's one of the gating classes in the dept. His notes are filled with many good examples. If you understand the notes, you can spend much less time reading the book. Since the class is online due to the pandemic, he is very assessible via emails. He gave almost instant reply/feedback to my questions which has helped me a lot.

"Fine" as far as professors go. Has amazing lecture notes that he makes available, but lecture is not good and is also mandatory. Worst part of this class is that the midterm and final are the only exams and make up almost your entire grade. Simple examples in class but very complicated and impossible hw (its not graded tho)

Poor lecturer. Whenever he's behind the homeworks (which is often,) he'll skip steps while working on problems (or hold lectures on holidays) to "catch up." Apparently, the midterm average of 45-50% is typical. Heavy curving saves most people from failing. That said, TAs and tutors were passionate and indispensable—Gabe knows how to pick them.

Exams are very unreasonable. The practice midterm and midterm review were useless. Lectures don't help with completing the homework, the textbook was only marginally more helpful. Youtube taught me more than Elkaim. He doesn't answer questions asked in class very clearly, and there are a lot of questions because his explanations are so convoluted.

Take 141 with someone else. Elkaim does few examples, and skips many steps. Draws graph and the only explanations are 'I've been doing this 30 years so I know that it looks like this'. Exams worth 80% of grade but the averages are low. Homework doesn't help prepare for exams and is very time consuming for the amount of credit you receive for it.

Elkaim is well-known on campus for teaching Intro to Mechatronics. As a prof, he's not without faults—lectures and lab docs can be difficult to follow if you've got ANY holes in the prerequisite material, for example—but the energy and care he brings to material makes up for them tenfold. I can't recommend taking the class with him highly enough.

ECE 242- applied feedback control. Probably the hardest class I've ever taken in my life. The homework takes an insane amount of time, the exams feel near impossible. Not really the professors fault, the material is just unimaginably hard

Manages to keep the lectures interesting no matter the topic and always has funny stories to tell. Projects, while extremely time consuming, are very fun and will teach you a lot. Be prepared to spend 40+ hours a week working.

The material is useful and interesting, and Dr. Elkaim is nice and approachable, but the workload is completely unreasonable. Homeworks range from 5-10 problems per week, and the difficulty level is very high - a moderate difficulty class would assign like 2 or 3 of these per week and it would be plenty. Not nearly enough examples in class.
He is a phenomenal professor and very passionate but he definitely makes you work hard. He will teach you life skills.
Class wasnt bad at all. I would recommend taking a programming course before.

He loves the subject he teaches, but cant keep up with his own curriculum .TA's taught the whole class, and even they were occasionally kept in the dark. Do NOT take for large lecture classes unless you are okay learning stuff entirely on your own!
Great teacher, best Ive had so far, unfortunately class was very difficult and relied on extensions and grace period heavily. Make sure to start early!
Gabriel Elkaim is awesome, he explains everything so well, and you can just tell he loves computers and technology. Even when explaining something as simple as binary he has the energetic vibe going.

Elkaim is an amazing lecturer and you will walk out of the class fully understanding whatever topic hes trying to teach you. His handwriting is a little messy, but just raise your hand and he will explain it. However, he is tough, don't be surprised when you spend all week in labs. To sum up, Elkaim reminded me why I want to be a computer engineer.
Gabe is a great professor. He made the hell that is Mechatronics bearable. Incredibly knowledgeable.
Phenomenal. He knows what industry is like, and prepares you for it. Most fun I've ever had in a class. Be ready to work 70 hours a week, and learn more than you ever have before.
Crystal clear lectures always touching upon real world applications which serves as a great motivation to dive deeper into the subject. Making linear algebra interesting is not easy!

Gabe recorded his classes and office hours, live AV included. One of the best classes I'd taken at that point due to that. I struggled with the algebra and background math, but the class and prof were so outstanding, that I ended up learning a lot! The hard work really paid off. Gabe was very patient with emails and office hours for all students.

This class was absolutely fantastic. The TA's were incredibly helpful, and If you showed up to office hours or re-watched a lecture, you would have a solid understanding of what to do. But the class requires a lot of trial and error. Mostly Error. Good luck!

LOVE Gabe, it is truly an honor to know him and have been his student. The class is often claimed to be the most difficult and time consuming at UCSC, but every minute is worth it and you will miss it when it's gone. Gabe is a fantastically smart and compassionate man who will get to know you very well. He genuinely  cares about his students.
This is a very hard class.

102 is kind of a miserable class. Nobby is a nice professor who'll have unexpected moments of humor in the middle of gnarly semiconductor physics. 102 could be SOOO MUCH HARDER, whether or not it should be depends on your goals. You can make this class rigorous by reading the textbook, or you can scrape by & only memorize what's needed to pass.

Nobby is an excellent teacher - the conceptual understanding is the most important basis to have and the tests revolve around that which can make them difficult. Make sure to go to lecture & pay attention, read the textbook, and take GOOD notes. His research/lab is also super cool, so go check it out!

He is actually making one of the hardest topics in the world as easy as possible. He knows solid-state physics is tough. If you think this is too easy go youtube and search Mr. Razavi's online lectures, they would be a great "complementary" material, instead of giving Nobby a bad comment. He's so nice.

A really great professor that cares about your understanding of the material. Nobby likes to test on concepts and theories in this class, so be prepared in knowing what each equation means and how it can be interpreted. Tests are very long and theory-based. I think if you have a solid physics background, this class shouldn't be too difficult.

He's not a bad guy, in fact I love Nobby. He's a cool guy and he makes his class very easy. Problem being, he makes it stupidly easy. A class that teaches the fundamentals for semiconductor physics is really just a memorizing facts class. If you want to deeply understand semiconductor physics avoid like the plague. If you just want an A, he's good.

My grade consisted of 4 quizzes (straight out of the lectures) a midterm and final. We were allowed to use cheat sheets for both exams. Nothing out of blue, he is straight forward with the expectations. Learned everything I needed to know without feeling overwhelmed. Nobby is great! Would take another class with him.

There was no homework assigned, so our grade consisted of 4 Quizzes, 1 Midterm, and the Final Exam. What he tells you to study for the quiz will be EXACTLY the content of the quiz. The material is pretty dry, but he tries his best to make lecture not boring. Overall, he's a great professor that cares about you and I'm glad to have him for EE 145.

Lectures are recorded so if you miss class, you won't miss anything. He posts his powerpoint slides online. The material is very tough, so study hard. He doesn't assign any homework, so you will have to keep up with the material yourself.

Lectures were basically him reading off the slides so it was hard to get clarity on any specific subject. Only a few assignments that you're graded on which are scattered across the course. I was not super interested in the material which made the class much more difficult.

Really chill professor, but his teaching style isn't the best for 2 hour classes of him just reading off the slides. He doesn't give lots of homework, but he grades based on a few things. Overall just a chill guy that wants to inspire people, but doesn't know how to engage a class all too well.
Assignments are easy but he is a boring professor who cannot teach well. As long as you can teach yourself you will be fine.

A very understanding professor who is flexible and often allows students to retake missed quizzes or assignments. He doesn't try to make the class too hard, so assignments are sparse and pretty easy. Only problem is his lectures can be hard to follow, which makes it hard to know what to study for midterms, etc.

Professor Chen would never follow whats on the syllabus and calendar. He would change up the due days of assignments within a couple of hours before its due. And the most hilarious is that he changed the final from take home to an actual final just a week before that final day. Had no planning for teaching the course and change up all he wants.

The lectures are essentially sparknotes of the textbook, I wish he put a more unique twist on his lectures. There's extra credit in attending lectures, in homeworks, exams, and a whole bonus homework assignment so if you put in the effort there is no shortage of points to be had. Overall a pretty good professor

Very nice Professor. The homework problems got pretty difficult sometimes, but most of the grade is from the midterm and final. He offers a lot of extra credit instead of a curve, but his exams are open textbook and are very doable with it available. I found his lectures well-paced and entertaining.

Clear lectures and follows textbook. Lots of extra credit like attendance (10%). No curve at all. Open book/notes really required because need to look for specific tables in the book such as Sellmeier coefficient and non-trivial derivation problem. Final and comprehensive much easier. Hard to reach outside of class. Very nice okay to ask questions.

Lectures are very engaging and is willing to slow the pace of the lesson/course to ensure students learn. He's somewhat reserved, so you do have to make sure you seek him than vice versa. Downsides: very hard class and Jesus Christ the labs are awful in terms of difficulty, spent 30 hours on a lab that wasn't graded. Really interesting though!

This class is honestly one of the worst experiences you can have in your college career at UCSC. As was said, do NOT take it unless you absolutely have a reason to. I would only take maybe another light GE with this and that's it. Tae isn't quite helpful at all. Groups aren't the greatest, and the work takes you around 40 hours a week to do.

The class is 10 units and covers Mechatronics so I don't think anyone expects it to really be easy, but Tae doesn't seem to care about presenting concepts in a way that people can understand. The grading is ridiculously harsh and the class is pretty miserable. Unless you are absolutely required to take it, for your own sanity avoid it.
I can't believe they let Tae teach another class after ECE 13 drama. He's super condescending and doesn't really care about his students. Class content isn't easy and not for beginners at all
worst class ive taken at this school so far. dont know how Tae is teaching.

I don't know who thought letting a person teach a class for freshman as an intro who somehow teaches concepts like we're well versed in the subject matter was a good idea. It's like you're on your own, Tae is no help with anything. He's also a bit rude at times if you ask him too many questions.

Imagine taking a class with no textbook, no homework, no foundation of the subject. For our midterm, we asked if we have any practice tests or anything to use to study and he just said to use the lecture slides which wasn't organized. We had no idea what we were looking at. Don't take this class unless you already know the subject beforehand.

This class is supposed to be for freshman with NO knowledge, yet you are expected to be more than proficient at physics, robotics, and programming. He is unwilling to help, provide background knowledge, or explain concepts. The labs are technical and complicated. Lectures do not make sense, so prepare to teach yourself everything.

I think the Tae Myung Huh is a decent person, but a bad professor. His explanations in this class are very poor. You are expected to code very high level projects with no prior knowledge. This class is advertised to assume you have NO knowledge of code or ODEs, but the ramp up incredibly quick and are poorly structured, and his TA doesn't grade.

Tae seems nice, but his attitude can be condescending and his communication with students is bad. As some have also said, the plagiarism/anti-cheat detector is bad and even if one doesn't cheat, they get flagged for it and he often doesn't want to elaborate or fix this. He doesn't want you to ask him questions and instead redirects to TAs.

Don't take this class with him. Unless you cannot physically submit your lab, no extension. Automatic 0 if you are one second late for lab submission. He acts like he is forced to teach and constantly gets annoyed when asked questions. He says you can work with others but don't because you will be flagged for cheating by a program. This guy sucks.

Labs are tough and the instructions are usually a little unclear. ECE13 is supposed to be challenging regardless, but this professor makes nothing easy for students. Lectures are completely useless and no one really goes. The plagiarism checker catches "cheaters" who don't cheat and ruin people's grades, he doesn't wanna talk about it either.

Avoid if possible. He didn't accept one of my labs because I accidently forgot a 0 in the title and refused to accept it after I went to his office hours. His lectures are useless for the labs, nobody showed up by end of the year. He refuses to help with anything other than grading questions in his office hours and leaves everything to TAs.

Very strict and inflexible. Gives you an automatic 0 for late lab assignments even if you have a good reason for it. Says everything is graded by humans but uses an autograder for everything and if you accidentally misspell your lab assignments, it won't be recognized by it and you get 0. Use plagirism checker and gives you 0 but i didn't cheat.

Everything is basically graded based on the labs(70%), which are extremely hard for the last few. He doesn't offer much assistance with the labs, making it very challenging to succeed in this class. If you struggle with the material, you are mostly on your own. In general not really a very understanding instructor.

The grading is very strict, and I got a lot of zeros on my assignments. When I ask him questions, he sometimes loses patience and rolls his eyes. Even though I spend a lot of time studying, my grades are still poor. I believe that the grading standard in class should be about ensuring students have learned the material, not about tricking them.

Lectures are not helpful to what the labs are. Oh, and labs make up 70% of the grade and 30% from online quizzes. The labs also get re-used and TAs aren't always the most helpful people to help finish them. Labs 1-5 are okay, 6-9 speed up in difficulty extremely fast, probably too fast for the lectures he gives us. Take with McGuire.

Lectures tended to be vague with little to no coverage of lab material which we were expected to complete weekly totaling to 9 labs for the quarter. the professor had office hours but refused to use them as a way to assist students on points of confusion or for lab concepts which are required to complete them in a timely manner. TA's and labs help

He has office hours but doesn't use these hours to help with Lab Assignments. There are many Lab Assignments and these take many hours. These lab assignments tend to have vague instructions and you are expected to learn most of the material on your own. Lab Sessions and TA's are helpful but packed, get there early. Very strict on grading.

Although I really struggled in this class, I really appreciated Dr Schmidt's help and way of teaching. He's obviously a brilliant person, and incredibly knowledgeable, he could answer every question I asked. I think that I learned a lot, and found him exceptional. He's a harder grader, but I do admit the grades were fair when I asked.
Covers a lot of material in a short time, lots of HW. However, great professor and course to learn from.

Holger Schmidt really knows the course content, and will answer any questions you have without reference.  For a class like 145, that's pretty essential.  You're going to spend a lot of time studying on your own, but read the assigned reading, do the homework, and you'll master the material by the end.

I would say below average for the UC level professor. He knows his material but doesnt have the patience or the passion to inspire students. He is short tempered and will snap on students for asking some questions. I've seen him blow up on a student before and it wasnt pretty.
adequate professor. knows the material well enough to lecture about it but really boring and lectures straight from the textbook

Holger is an amazing teacher and also an amazing engineer. This is a VERY rare combination. You can go to him for almost anything engineering related. Extremely helpful and a very cool guy! I'll say it, I LOVE HOLGER SCHMIDT! WOO!

I took this class last Fall quarter and believe me the only other professor after Dr.Ali Shakouri who can teach in this mad house called engr department is him. His tests are challenging and thought provoking. His homeworks are aslo very interesting.Very helpful with the project and also with lectures.Easy A if you study regularly and do the hw.

An excellent professor. He is extremely good at giving intuitive explanations on complicated concepts (think about the chairs in a stadium analogy for density of states). I have had multiple classes with him and although they have been challenging I have learned a great deal and mastered the concepts. He is also very helpful when you ahve questions
This professor is availabe for his students to ask questions and do interview to help me with my other classes.
No Comments
As if EE70 is not hard enough, EE145 kicks up a notch.  I highly recommend taking EE145 with Ali Shakari instead, unless you really want to FAIL.
No Comments

very strict, tough teacher for ee70, and ee70 is already a killer. very strict on grading, does not shift the grading scale at all like other professors might, even if a large part of the class is going to fail
No Comments
No Comments

This is a high effort class with straightforward (not easy) exams. His lectures were OK, but he's a mildly unpleasant guy. Regardless, I learned the topics pretty well, and he correctly emphasized conceptual understanding over drilling practice problems. IMO the topics are special enough to warrant waiting for a good professor to teach them instead

Bluntly, the mean score on the final exam was a 31%. He eventually regraded the exams, but I think it was a failure of teaching not an unreasonable exam. His lectures are mandatory but not very good. I studied a lot, but still feel like I have a shaky grasp of some important concepts. The course would have really benefitted from available tutoring.

The absolute worst lecturer I've had. He explains poorly, rarely answers questions clearly, and acts very  condescending toward students. His exams are brutal, grading is unforgiving, and tons of people fail. Final average was 30% with no curve. If you can avoid this class with Hamid, do it, you'll be saving your GPA and sanity.

Prof Hamid is harsh and unsupportive. Partial credit is non-existent, even with the right concepts, small math errors = zero. Class average was ~65% with minimal curve, final average 36%. He blames students instead of reflecting on poor instruction or assessment. No real feedback. Avoid at all costs.

Lectures were required, and long, but not very informative. The textbook is good, but very dry, and in my opinion hard to rely on as a main source of learning. 
The 3 exams made up 90% of the grade and were all over the place in terms of difficulty. The mean score on the final exam was a 31%. 
The professor is nice enough, but not a great teacher.

Do not take this class over 5 weeks, the 3.5 hour lectures are hard to pay attention to. There are few practice problems but the exams (multiple, so your grade is diluted) are like the HW - except a hint was wrong and we were not given enough time to do the problems & submit. He is understanding but a tough grader - get ready to read the textbook.

95% of the grade is 2 exams. This professor teaches this course as a math course. Exams are heavy on mathematical proofs while the homework is not. Everyone feels like they are going to fail but they curve exams pretty hard.  

Professor does not release practice exams and does not publish exams or answers after the exams have been graded.

95% of your grade is based on two exams. 5% on really long homework that's significantly harder than what's covered in lecture, and often isn't even covered in lecture. Hamid's a very entertaining and friendly guy but he's not a good professor. His lectures are awful, and his exams don't relate to his lectures and review all that well.
Only passed because of the curve. The Final was hard!

Exams worth too much and were difficult. The class was asynchronous and TA's who actually taught were not the greatest. Professor insisted on Proctored exams and was not accomodating at all. Maybe a good professor in person, but not a great option for a remote class. It was a source of a lot of stress for me personally.
Midterm was difficult and the average was about 57 percent. The final is impossible. Average was below 50 percent before the curve. Do not take ece103 with this professor if you care about your GPA.

Really doesnt care about teaching. Just uses UW slides every class. Easy midterm, impossible final. Big curve. Answers questions but is annoyed to do so. Kinda amazing how much he doesnt care about teaching. Know the homework for the midterm and youll do fine. Good luck with the final - it was nearly all proofs based on the second half of class.

He literally uses the university of Washington slides to lecture. It's impressive how awful of a professor he is. Like he just openly doesn't care about teaching this class, hence why he makes it so easy. If you like learning don't take him, if you just want to pass, Sadjad's about the best teacher you can have, because you'll pass with 0 effort.

He goes over problems in class which is really helpful. There are no quizzes. The homework is long but make sure you do it because the midterm and final is similar to the homework. The midterm wasn't too bad. This class is basically a math class and it is boring. He is a nice guy and he curves the class so just do the hw and you will pass the class

We were supposed to have quizzes but never did. Overall the class came down to knowing and understanding all the homework problems, as the tests were very similar to them. The homework itself was very long but only counted for 10% of our grade.

I think this class is probably the worst class I have taken at UCSC. Professor Sadjadpour is so bad. He is not an engineer, he is a mathematician. To whoever, think's he is the best professor at UCSC, wait until you take a Petersen class. His exams are the same as the year before. He needs to change them so that "lucky" students won't Ace his exam.

He is the litmus test for electrical/computer engineering majors who think they are good at mathematics. This guy is helpful, clear, and his tests are pretty much homework problems (which are difficult). Do the homeworks again and again and you will ace the class.

Best EE professor I've had. Super clear and funny. Ask questions! He will happily answer them (even though he might make some fun of you on the way-but joke back with him and you'll be on his good side). Write down all of the "Golden Rules". Exam problems are straight from HW (mostly). Know all the proofs (even if they don't seem important to you).

Very funny, not afraid to speak his mind to the students. The material in the course can be pretty boring, and he's not kidding when he says the second half of the class is significantly more challenging. Make sure to know your integrals and trig identities. In spite of the class itself, he's a likable guy.

Very intelligent professor and also a pretty funny guy. The material covered was usually pretty dry but he kept his lectures fairly interesting. First midterm was easy but the final was a nightmare.  GOLDEN RULE: Go to class and TAKE NOTES and you should be fine.

All my criticisms of this class are not at him directly, but at the material (which he did help work on, so putting it here is fair game). The first and last lab was so poorly structured. You would get lost working on them, not because they are hard, but because the way the manual is written is confusing. The rest of this class is fine though.

he would do this annoying thing in class where he would make a pop culture reference, pause to see if anyone got it, and 9 time out of 10 when no one gets it he'll go "come on, we're all nerds here!" no bro we are all just taking this class because we are trying get through major requirements

lectures are useful to attend, do labs long before due

Class had a HUGE amount of work, and while it is doable, it was quite difficult. Patches were released to our assigned code almost every single day which was rather annoying. Overall I probably wouldn't take this class, again, but you will definitely learn quite a bit from it.

Lectures are kinda engaging, the bulk of the class was labs. Prof wasn't as helpful for labs. Labs scale in difficulty, but last lab is crazy difficulty spike. That one just throws you into the deep end. If you want high partial credit, write quality READMEs highlighting key issues/quickfixes. TAs & graders are generous and actually want to help.

Steve is a cool professor, although he doesn't have mandatory attendance his lectures and in-class activities are super helpful for your labs. The last labs are pretty difficult if you fall behind but overall as long as you go to the TA sections as well as the online tutoring sections, you can easily get an A in the class.

My favorite professor out in the ECE department! Attendance is not mandatory, but if you want to hear him yap about some cool stuff I recommend going to them. Also his lectures help with some of the labs as he explains them pretty well. His labs are a pain, so GO TO LAB HOURS!!! He's sometimes hard to reach so your TA's & tutors are your best bet.

Steve is a really good teacher and the class is very enjoyable. Many of the issues in the class labs were because there was a new micro-controller we used. As such, the labs were experimental and should be fixed in later quarters. Anyways, GO TO LAB SECTIONS if you need help with labs

Very time consuming class, especially week 6 and on. Labs may work perfectly fine on your end but there always seems to be an issue with the grader. Class was CARRIED by tutors who took the class already and only one out of the three TA's. Steve is a great lecturer and always kept the class engaged which was fun, but he's not super lenient.

Prof McGuire is a good teacher. He has an lecture style which is interesting, though attendance is not mandator-would recommend going, as there are complex subjects that come up that will not be covered in the lab manuals that you need. He will take all forms of questions and is INCREDIBLY knowledgeable about C based off of his prior work.

Professor is decent, but it does get annoying sometimes with the amount of patch notes/releases during/after the start of labs. Labs are not easy, but are good at teaching new topics and helping one familiarize themselves with new topics. Labs are not easy so it's always good to start asap. TA's and tutors are very helpful with the Labs.
Angry grumpy guy not useful for anything actually homework related only talks about random stuff

Steve is hands down one of the coolest people you will meet. Attendance was optional so you can have him all to yourself :) TA's are great and labs are pretty difficult if you are not quick to pick up on embedded programming paradigms(and C), lots of extra credit+curve, and lab hours every day. Make use of labs and you will pass with flying colors!

One of the best professors I've had so far. Labs were due every week with lots of opportunities for extra credit. This was my first time getting experience with C but his class made the learning curve bearable. He genuinely cares for his students and his lectures were very enjoyable. If you need help with labs, meeting with TAs will help a lot.

He's a super fun professor to have for a class, and he teaches the material super well. One of the few professors whose lecture I made special effort to attend. The material can be challenging, but he clarifies things well, and doesn't mind sitting down with students and helping. Projects are fun and actually have real life basis

Coolest professor I've ever had, knows CSE and ECE extremely well, and teaches even better. Made learning C and low level concepts enjoyable even though it can be a tough experience overall when starting. The assignments are very interesting and teach you a ton. Lab sections are super useful as well. Highly recommend taking any class with him.

Very nice professor and very good at lecturing information without being boring. The labs ramp up in difficulty pretty quickly but the TAs are very helpful at the lab sections. This is a very hard class in my opinion but the professor and the TAs do as much as they can to help you succeed.

1st half of assignments was an advanced cse20 class but in C. TAs & tutors r extremely helpful in debugging code or helping u understand assignments. 2nd half of assignments had a learning curve since it was about embedded systems,9 labs total.Great lecturer, flexible w/ extensions. B ready to spend a lot of hours in lab. Offered ec @ end quarter

Steve's lectures are very informative as he uses personal anecdotes to explain the relevance of the concepts he teaches. The labs in the class can be time consuming but if you need help, there are many lab sections to get assistance from tutors. If you only have python experience, the beginning of the class might be hard as C is a bit different.

His assignments start off really easy but ramp up quickly. The TA during lab times will help you ALOT with code. They will literally fix/debug or give you code. There were no midterms or finals, its all code, and online quizzes.

The labs are very easy, and frankly are the type of experiments you'd do in middle school. In lectures he has us derive formulas through intuition, which I really like. Honestly, I kinda wish the class was a bit more rigorous, because you don't end up actually learning anything. Hell, you can pass the class without showing up to a single lecture.

great professional passionate about teaching and clearly cares about students. class is extremely easy, graded out of 5 report assignments dropped lowest one, no quiz or exams. attendance is not required and most of the report could be done without the lectures.
Didn't attend a single lecture and got an A. No midterm or final, graded on 5 hw and lowest dropped.

Rolandi is a good and engaging professor. Had to retake this class after taking it with Vroomen. The same topics are discussed but as someone with no physics background, this class actually made difficult concepts fun and easy to learn.

Super inspiring professor. Lots of flexibility with which assignments you choose to complete. Makes difficult topics easy to understand. Fun lecture. I actually took ECE 104 with him. Highly recommend.

ECE 30 with Rolandi is one of the easiest classes I've taken at UCSC. The class consists of five projects(best 4/5 taken for grade). The professor is super nice and accommodating. Some TA's grade more strictly than others on assignments as well. Very light workload with other CS classes.

Many physics topics taught very broadly (mainly conceptual). Grade is made up of 5 labs worth 25 points, but 1 is optional (lowest grade dropped). Very manageable to take with other CS courses. Nice dude, would recommend :D
its free
No midterm or final. Graded on 5 hws, lowest one is dropped. Hes very accomodating and extends assignments. Homework is graded on effort and completion instead of correctness

Clearly loves robotics control and vector mathematics, very kind person so take his classes if you get down on yourself easily in heavy STEMS/ find words of support helpful while fighting the good fight.

I showed up late most of the time and he still reexplained concepts to me afterwards for the love of the game, definitely super approachable.
Extremely Unprofessional

Extremely pretentious. He did not care that more than half of his class was taking ECE118 simultaneously and could not focus on his class. He will grade you harder if you don't come to class which I don't know how that isn't allowed. It would not be a hard class if not taken with 118. Just go to class and you'll be ok.

If you want to take this class, you better know every thing about matlab(3D molding, plot figures...), eventhough this class's pior requirements has nothing to do with matlab. His PPT is terrible, A LOT of functions and he talks like everybody is smart enough to just look at the equations and understand in a glence. Took a lot of time to get used
Great professor if you can understand him. He takes a bit of getting used to.
Dejan is a horrible professor
Best application of Kinematics I have had so far.

He is a great lecturer; he gives many good, real-world applications to the material in his lectures. I suggest knowing MATlab before taking this class, because he uses MATlab a lot in the lecture and in his homework. He could explain some of the later concepts more clearly. The tests are easier versions of homework.
Great lecturer.  Not necessarily friendly to people who get behind.  Gives good applications of material.
Great guy, he really cares if his students understand. Very clear covering the material, and very reasonable tests/homework.

Was intimidated by him to start with, but grew to like him over time. Homework is from the book and quite difficult, but he drops the lowest 3 homework scores. Tests and finals are relatively easy, they're from either homeworks or TA sections (which he posts online). Would recommend.

HW's aren't that bad, you need to use matlab, His test review problems were too broad. He had problems only his tests that he only went over in class, but would not post on his website. His slides were directly from the book. He is pedantic, so he does not curve. Overall, a horrible professor, gets mad if you are focusing on other classes.

Dejan is a really good professor. He's not always clear on his first go-through of the material, but if he's not, just ask him about it and he'll try to explain it in a different way until you get it. He's also a really friendly guy who'll try to learn names. One warning, he has a pretty heavy Serbian accent.

I can tell Dejan wanted to help his students but I never took advantage of his help. There is only one midterm and a final, so try to do well on both tests! Go to office hours, section, and msi if you don't understand the material. His writing is difficult to read and I regret taking this class with him but I'm glad I got this prereq out of the way
Dejan is a wonderful professor. He genuinely wants his students to succeed. Material is difficult but he takes questions directly from the book. Just do practice problems & go to lecture. Good luck!

horrible teacher. heard he had a 40% fail rate. understood the material. even tutored others but test sometimes consists of problems never seen before. don't get any of the multiple choice wrong because one multiple choice problem is worth 10% of your test grade. homework is pretty hard. does not curve .

Milutinovic is pretty much the worst professor I have ever had. His lectures are unclear, he doesn't stick to the material he has to cover (goes off on tangents), and the notes he provides are horrendous. I learned nothing from him.

Dejan Milutinovic is a well-intentioned yet ineffective professor. His handwriting is incomprehensible, lectures are very unclear, and is unaccessible: he did not allow us to send him any emails leading up to the final because "he was too busy and had too much to do." Grade breakdown was skewed. Avoid this professor at all costs.

I can confidently say that this is the worst math teacher I've ever had. Aside from his   condescending demeanor, he can't even speak english understandably. He's extremely confusing, his grading system is flawed, and consistently tries to trick students with his questions rather than testing them on the concept. Do not take this teacher, ever.
I would not advise taking any class with this teacher. He is not clear at all.
Great lecturer, very fair exams, and passionate about the subject. Fast paced, but definitely take this course with Prof. Ellis if you have the chance!

This was only his second year of teaching, but he absolutely knocked it out of the park. If you liked Dhar you will definitely like him, since his lectures are structured similarly. 
What he does differently though would be his grading. He lets you retry both midterms and you do not even need to do every problem on them, just the ones you'd like.
absolutely goated professor

Good lectures, and has partial credit for homeworks. Exams are tough, but the final has the option to retake previous exams to raise your grade. All lectures are recorded, he is accommodating, and answers questions while giving an actual answer that is digestible. Highly recommend.
One of the greatest professors for ECE101. It's sad he only taught during Fall 2024. People are struggling right now with the current professors for ECE101, we need him back 🙏

Ellis is one of the best profs I've had at UCSC. His lectures are so engaging and he explains difficult concepts in a way that everyone can understand. Exams were pretty difficult but we were given the chance to retake midterms during the final. Labs are very doable and gives ample time to do them. No calculators or cheatsheets for exams.

Professor Ellis is a wonderful lecturer, well paced and clear in his explanations. I thought all exams were very fair, though not overly easy. He also allowed both of the midterms to be optionally "retaken" during the final for a better grade, which gives you lots of extra time if you don't need to up your grade. He is also very open to feedback.

Take this prof especially if you are a DRC student. Engaging lectures minus the last section (he had a baby). Labs were very doable but of course time consuming. I didn't like that the exams were harder than the hw, felt unprepared there. Textbook choice was solid. Prof Ellis please let your next class make cheatsheets there is so much to memorize!

Professor Ellis was great. He consistently made the class feel engaged, was very clear about grading, his lectures were extremely engaging and was very generous with partial credit. He was probably one of the nicest professors I've ever had at UCSC. If you can take ECE101 with someone, do it with him.

Mathis is super accommodating and understanding. However, his hw is really difficulty and takes a lot of time & energy to complete but you're given at least a week to do each one. You still get hw on midterm week and due at the start of finals week so that's draining but other that he's a great teacher.

I came into the class with no coding experience, and Claudie gave me all the resources I needed to learn. I felt very confident by the end, and I liked how she organized the midterms. Overall great teacher and lecturer. The way she organized her office hours and discussion sections were great. You can tell she cares a lot about students.

One r coding assignment a week and the midterm/finals are the same but longer. She provides a model script  and examples in class. If you go to section the coding part is fairly simple even with no coding experience. Claudie is sweet and willing to help. Lectures were a bit confusing esp as the quarter went on. Go to section and its very doable.

She is so well organized and makes learning R accessible even to students with no prior coding knowledge. She respects her students. She's fair while still caring for students. She does her best to clarify material that may not be clear or is difficult to grasp. She makes the connection between assignments and real-world applications seamless.
Amazing class. She is so nice and discussion sections were very helpful. You can tell she cares about students.
She clearly does not care about teaching, and is super emotionally manipulative to students.

Her class was interesting. I enjoyed lectures and she was easy to follow. Class moved fast sometimes, but a few minutes of reviewing slide shows after each lecture made it easy to fill in any gaps. If you go to class, take notes, and show up to take the test you will do well, everything on the test is 100% on the slides. No hw!

Long, content heavy lectures, with basically no homework besides optional readings. The tests were all multiple choice, but they were completely open note. As long as you take good notes and show up to lecture its not that difficult. All in all the class was a bit boring but I would take it again.

She didn't go over anything. Every lecture,100 slides (+ paragraphs on the screen). She also would mess up a lot on the tests and in my opinion, did not give enough time for them. She never gave her classes homework, so it was hard to bring up grades. She is nice and all, she just needs to incorporate different teaching styles in her classroom.

The professor was unkind, which made the class stressful. Lectures were overloaded with info-heavy slides, making it hard to follow or prioritize key points. The teaching style felt unorganized and unhelpful. I wouldn't recommend this professor unless you're ready to teach yourself most of the material and even then it is hard to succeed.

Overall, the worst professor I have had since I have began coming to school here. The grading rubric is strict, and doesn't allow for mistakes, the class revolves around taking notes for an hour 30 mins and engagement in the class is lackluster. would not recommend for anyone, and would never take again.

Too many slides per lecture. The quizzes were about all the slides and there were so many that you couldn't study properly. She doesn't seem to care about her students as she never took time to even go over anything for the test. I don't even know what I got wrong! If you like sitting around for 100+ slides, take this class!

All the quizzes and finals are based on the slides presented in class. However, this includes even the tiniest details instead of testing upon the concept as a whole and the shortest slides per lecture were 65 and the max going to 120. Per class. Bonus Q's on quiz help make up for lost points. No answers or discussion of exams.

Extremely boring lectures, grade is 80% tests and there is very little guideline for how to study, professor didn't seem to care too much at all about the class in general. If you like 80 slide info dumps twice a week take Earth 1 with Adina Paytan
The absolute GOAT of being the worst professor of ALL TIME.

Professor is honestly just lazy. Makes you buy a an app called TopHat that you will not use in any other class. Reads word for word off of slides that look like they were made in 2003. Doesn't assign homework. Only remotely interesting parts of the class was when she wasn't there and a guest lecturer was teaching.

I understand she was a substitute for Oceanography but she should never teach this class again. Take this class if you want to get an F and zero understanding of the topic. Adina Paytan is one of the worst professors I've ever had. Lectures are extremely boring and test material covers information on slide 5 out of her daily 200 slide lecture.

The Prof. is very passionate about the class and you can learn so much. But her way of teaching is unfair for students who have a different learning style. While she can divide up tests into smaller chunks she does not and you will never know what to actually study for. You also have to pay for Top Hat. There are way better GEs out there.

EART 1: There is practically no feedback on midterms and since that is the only graded portion of the class you have no idea why you are getting questions wrong, or how to improve. The only answer sheet for the midterms have incorrect answers on it. Class is a total mess.
Lectures are long and not that helpful. Gives no feedback after tests or exams.

Took EARTH1. Lectures covered so much material in such little time that it was difficult to pick out what needed review for the tests compared to what didn't. The class was only graded on three tests + participation, which wasn't good since I'm not good at taking tests. The professor herself was also super unapproachable. Take a different GE class.

Absolutely AWFUL PROFESSOR. Makes students cry in front of the entire class and humiliates them. Lectures will bore you to death and every lecture is around 200 slides long. Your entire grade depends on short quizzes that you aren't given enough time to properly complete. I would not recommend this professor to anyone.

Frankly rude to her students. Is not personable or approachable. Lectures are very boring, she just reads off a slideshow of 80 slides word for word. Asks very specific niche questions on tests. Would 100% not take again.

The class was not terribly difficult, although textbook use was minimal so paying attention in class and following Powerpoints is helpful. I take some issue with Dr. Paytan's attitude - she does not have much respect for students. This was my experience. She was not easily approachable and the least friendly of the professors I've had.

She's a great resource if you're looking to pursue a graduate school path or researcheducation career path. She is very understanding and supportive through personal emergencies and really wants her students to learn, succeed, and leave the class with something useful (like a grantresearch proposal).

This class was pretty disappointing for a UC class. I know it's a lower-division, but the assignments were so easy it felt like a high-school class. The lectures are a few years old and could be updated. I was really excited because I'm an envs major, but I hope the other envs classes are more rigorous and engaging.

She's a very interesting person and the course is very cool. She's basically a glorified YouTuber, as good luck ever talking to her in person, or really talking to her at all. For such a cool member of our department it's a little disappointing. That being said, if you like this class, you'll love the Environmental Studies major.
Easiest online class I've ever took, one discussion, a few quizzes and required zoom meeting each week. I didn't even get to meet Professor Jinnah, but you'd honestly only see your TA's on zoom.

I took this as an asynchronous class. There were a few hours of lectures spread out over the week, and lots of readings and additional material. There are short, easy quizzes after each lecture, and 1 writing assignment and 1 paper due every week. I learned a lot from this class, and Professor Jinnah was really helpful and a moderately easy grader.

Professor Campbell was one of the first professors I had at UCSC. He was incredibly inspiring and encouraging of all career paths in the field of environmentalism. He is passionate about what he teaches, which is evident in his lectures. Extremely kind and helpful, always willing to help students better understand concepts. One of UCSC's finest!

One of my favorite ENVS courses thus far. Covered topics on energy generation, sustainability and energy efficiency. The course is equation heavy, but nothing crazy. Elliot worked through the material slowly and offered many opportunities to get extra help. He is a likable and funny professor, and I would take courses with him again.

Professor Campbell single-handedly created my interest and passion for climate science. This course is introductory to anyone unfamiliar with climate science, no math or science pre req needed. Professor is active with students in designing course curriculum and in office hours. Have good time management and a willingness to study! Would take again

Unexpectedly math heavy, but mostly stand alone formulas that are easy to learn. Professor Campbell can be confusing at times--asking questions and making a study group definitely helps. Grades are determined by weekly homework, 2 exams, 1 paper, and a short quiz before and after every lecture. Read the free textbook and take good notes.

Elliott is great! A very nice guy who cares a lot about your success. This course involved more math than I had anticipated, but none of it was horribly difficult. He can move a little fast or be confusing at times, but going to office hours/asking questions helps with this greatly. Attendance is for your own benefit, try not to miss class.

The class was overall not too difficult. The lecture material was mostly just learning formulas about chemistry and climate and applying them in word problems. He's extremely nice and always respectful if you have a question about the material. Don't skip class though, attendance is graded through notes and exit quizzes.

He's a really nice guy who cares about the subject and wants his students to succeed but the lectures are very messy and can be very confusing. Cannot miss this class you will fail, he's not great at explaining kind of just writes equations and solves them without explaining. Would not recommend thus class to someone who isn't good at math.

He's super nice and clearly cares about the subject but his lectures are so disorganized. He just puts formulas on the board with little explanation. Also, the class is a lot different from how it's described. Very math, chemistry, and econ heavy and the homework is nothing like the lectures or readings.

10/10!! Elliott is great! gives the textbook for free and exams are exactly like the home works with no surprises. Lectures are easy to follow and have examples that help with the home works and exams.

Professor Elliot is one of the kindest professors at UCSC. While the material he covers can be a bit dense, he breaks it down in very understandable and structured ways. His lectures are well structured and easy to follow, and this same statement holds true with the rest of his class. 10/10 recommend!

Professor Campbell is a great teacher and makes lecture engaging and understandable. HOWEVER, if you are taking the Renewable Energy course be aware that it is basically a math course, which the course description fails to capture.
Super interested in what he teaches. I loved this class so much and I wish I could take it again. Easy to reach out to if needed and considerate.

One of my favorite professors at UCSC so far. His course is formatted extremely well and it is clear that he has spent time formating his course to be very efficient despite the amount of material covered in this class. The daily quizzes, notes, and weekly homework force you to stay on top of it in the class and prepare you for the open note exams.

Elliot is passionate with what he does and also passionate about teaching the class. He uses the textbook a lot with readings and lecture material. The way he's structured the class is really good (spread out between homeworks, attendance, paper, exams) Just a cool guy in general too, enjoyable to listen to in lecture.

Elliott is extremely passionate about renewable energy. Although the class covers a lot of material, you learn a lot. As long as you go to lecture , do the homework, and can solve any problem on the study guide, you will do great.

She seems very nice but the lectures were disorganized and often a waste of time. The labs are where work actually happened.. lecture was honestly unnecessary.  Seems like she means well but I didn't learn much at all.

Lectures are poorly structured and Monsen frequently rambles off topic. Students had to frequently ask for basic assignment information (due dates, format, length, etc) during class bc the Canvas was frequently empty or incorrect. The self-help "getting a job" book she used was tonedeaf. Incredibly dissapointed in this capstone.

Ignore everything anyone else says if you take her for ENVS 100. She is super caring about her students and wants them to learn. The accompanying lab with the class is where the real work is done, but Katie tries to introduce you to the new information simply and easily, as well as giving vital information to excel in internships and upper divs.

Katie is a very sweet lady and the class content is pretty interesting. You'll definitely learn a lot about tending the land so if you wanna be a farmer, this class if for you. HOWEVER, she doesn't grade anything during the quarter. It's been 3 days since grades were due, like bffr if I can turn it in on time YOU can grade on time smh!

We meet in Carson garden for Fall24, half of class was discussing the reading with Katie and each other. Second half was hands on work taught by Garden stewards for 1.5 hours. We did a mini-field trip to the Katie planned part way through the quarter. There's typically 1 chapter to read a week before class and then writing a reflection after class

Katie is one of my favorite professors! She really cares about her students and wants us to really understand the material and do well in the class. The lectures were never boring, and we took lots of field trips to learn material hands-on. She really inspired me to get into the freshwater ecology field once I graduate.

Katie is an absolute gem! Not only does she care about her students success in the class, but she cares about their wellbeing overall. She makes herself super accessible and shes so easy to talk to. You can tell she has a passion for what she does, and that makes learning from her interesting and easy. Weekly journals, 4 assignments, final paper.

Katie is an absolute angel. She is a real gem of the ENVS department. If you have an opportunity to take a class with her, DO! She cares about her students so much, and takes time to check in on us. She has been incredible with remote learning, she really appreciates the insight everyone provides, and is very forgiving with technology.

If you like never receiving your grades back, receiving no direction for studying, and feeling like going to lecture is a waste of time, take a class with Katie. She belongs in an elementary school classroom.

This class was easy but she CANT TEACH! Nothing is explained well, she just laughs over her mistakes, and you feel like youre in a third grade class. Education is not a priority for her. I will never take a class with her again.

Don't be fooled by how nice she is. Katie is not suited to teach a college course. You will hardly learn anything from her and you will be assigned material that hasn't been covered. There will be several days out of the quarter where you are wondering why you are paying for this level of education. Biggest regret is taking this class.

Katie is a great person but a terrible professor. If you are interested in actually learning the material, receiving clear instructions, and effective use of class time you should avoid Katie. Office hours are useless. Books are necessary although you will be told they are not. Tests are much more detailed than any of the class instruction. So bad

MY FAVORITE PERSON EVER! Katie is the best, hands down. She takes time to get to know her students and is always available to help. She is hilarious and her lectures and REALLY engaging. You don't just sit there and listen to her talk for an hour and a half, she really makes you think but it's not a hard class. I still look back at my notes

Katie is an amazing lecturer and her assignments are always engaging. However, she will likely grade 90-100% of your assignments after the quarter is over and won't be very accessible to talk about your grade during or after the quarter ends unless you pester her, which isn't fun for anyone. She is very helpful for all other questions though.

Have a quiz and homework assignment due every week. Homework takes on average about 20 minutes. No midterm, just the final. Attendance checked via Top Hat. Extremely caring and passionate. Somewhat disorganized but nothing too bad. There is a lot of reading but you can honestly get by without reading anything except 1 or 2 articles.

Dr. Katie is an amazing person! The class itself was a little wild just because she had to cover so much, but I enjoyed listening to her lectures. She assigned an absolutely INSANE amount of reading, most of which I simply couldn't get to, which is too bad because what I did read was mostly very worthwhile. The actual assignments were reasonable.

Dr. Katie is so kind. The course is quite laid back and covers a wide variety of sustainability-related topics. Grading criteria includes participation, weekly take-home assignments, weekly online quizzes, and several group assignments. Participation is counted through Tophat. Overall, she is a very nice professor and the course is not challenging.

Dr. Katie is really nice and obviously very passionate about the subject. Her lectures are interesting and engaging, if a bit disorganized. Attendance is mandatory though tophat, which you have to pay for. No textbook, and she gives opportunities for extra credit which are genuinely interesting.

Dr. Katie is such a sweetheart. Her lectures are not very organized but they are incredibly interesting. She is definitely passionate about the subject matter, and the final is exactly like the study guide. If you're interested in sustainability at all, definitely try and take a class with her.

A really interesting professor and takes a genuine interest in her students. If you read the articles and answer the questions she asks about them, it should be an incredibly easy class to pass. Her final was also 100% based on the study guide provided beforehand, simple matching and short answer type questions.

She was very kind and accommodating, just communicate with them. We had weekly discussion posts and a final paper that made up our grades, but easy with effort and passion into your work. They're communicative, and open to student feedback for improvement. Connected to current event like Gaza, Environment Justice, Trans rights & Intersectionality.
Livia is a solid instructor, but the class itself was not very interesting or enjoyable. Really easy class though
She lives in Brazil and was hired for this class after it already started so the class was asynchronous. Given the unique circumstances she did what she could and was very flexible!
She lives in Brazil so she is consistently asynchronous. She is caring and though I didn't want the online class, I have no complaints about her, she was really great.

This professor thinks that her class and assignments should be the only thing you should focus on even though you have workload from other classes. She doesn't even teach her lab sections, and if you mess up on an assignment, she acts like you insulted her. Thank god I won't have to take this class again.
If you're a good writer, dedicated 100% to just school and nothing else then this is the class for you.

I found this professor to be extremely unprofessional and unaccommodating. The feedbacks I would receive on my papers was  negative even though the other person grading them would give a proper thorough feedback. She would make this class feel like it was the only purpose of students lives and she was very unethical on her emails do not recommend.

Emily is a great teacher and you can tell that she really has a passion for teaching and getting to know her students. The class itself is pretty reading heavy, but for a required course it isnt too bad. Participation is the main basis of the class and coming from a quiet person, get ready to talk.

I had a really great experience and I really enjoyed this class. It's pretty reading heavy with maybe 2 hours per class, but the assignments aren't that bad. Murai is a really good teacher who clearly values what her students have to say, and discussions usually went well in class. Overall, a really good experience.

Professor Murai was very unaccommodating. She encouraged students to reduce hours at their jobs just to keep up with her class. I did learn some useful things in this class like proper APA, but there was so much work. 3 major papers each with smaller assignments leading up to them on top of long lecture videos and quizzes.

I took this as a zoom class, so it may be different for you! But for me, it was hard to keep up with, as every week there's a new paper or assignment that's due. You'll learn how to write a proper APA paper, though. As someone who normally puts in minimal effort to school, you'll have to pick up the pace for this class. Murai's a tough grader too

This was an asynchronous class, so I didnt interact with Emily a lot, but she left great feedback on all of my papers! There was a lot of work and reading, as well as group work, and lab attendance was mandatory.

I took her class for CLNI 1 the Fall quarter in 2020 and she was an amazing professor. The assignments do contain a lot of reading, but its not difficult to understand. There is a lot of discussion since its remote learning now. Shes available outside of class and is easy to talk to. Definitely recommend taking her class.
There is just so much busy work, most of it is just a huge waste of time. The reading is totally manageable but the homework is not useful, it is busy work that just wastes time.
just dont take her writing class

Some heavy reading but worth it. Emily is great and wants to see a reflection of genuine learning. Be sure to participate in class conversation/ make your own remarks about the content. Easy final and lots of opportunity for extra credit.

Murai has too many high expectations from her students and believes that her class is more important than all other classes on campus. She assigns massive loads of busy work and grades extremely hard. Also she isn't very understanding and can be passive-aggressive. Expect to spend all your time wasted on this class. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!!!

The class isn't tough if you try to complete assignments on time and visit her office hours if you need more help. She gives you time to work on assignments after peer-review sessions. She's totally accessible and lets you revise assignments after returning feedback on them.
She gives a ridiculous amount of work. You will have multiple assignments due for the same class period, sometimes even 24 hours before your actual class period.
Prepare to do upper-div coursework
Emily is a nice and patient teacher. If you have any question on your grade or class, you are welcome to talk to her.
I learned so many writing skills and passed the ELWR. She is also a very great writing teacher. Highly Recommended

Emily is very nice and at times she can be annoying. But she gives really good feedback. What I didn't like about her class was that she would make us print everything. My printing bill was almost $50 that quarter. The topics and discussions are interesting and are always fun to debate about. Lots of reading and lots of homework. Don't skip class!

This is by far the best professor I had ever seen. She is a very nice lady and she can explain everything really well. She helped me passed the ELWR this quarter and so did my other friends. She always have clear instruction of what we should do, and she helped me improved my writing skill significantly. Best writing teacher!

Course was pretty easy, and the weekly reading hw's were not too difficult. There is 1 video essay group project, and the final would have been multiple choice were it not cancelled due to the events occurring at the time. The material can be dry at times but I gained a greater sense of appreciation for animation and the history behind it.

Ruiz is one of the most caring and open teachers I've had so far. Her class about the history of animation is extremely interesting even if you're not going into that field. Her final isn't a research paper anymore. It was a tricky multiple choice test since most of the questions were asking for very specific details within her lectures.

I loved Professor Ruiz's class and her lectures. She doesn't rely on powerpoints to expand on the readings and she adds context and expands on the assigned readings.  No tests, just a midterm paper/powerpoint and a final project or paper. Ruiz is passionate about what she is teaching which makes all the difference.

A very easy and fun film class to take. Not many assignments and no tests. She's really nice and easy to talk to. It's a class about animation but she doesn't grade you on artistic ability, she grades on effort.

Professor Ruiz taught the History of Animation and it was by far one of the best and easiest classes I've ever taken. She's really kind and flexible on assignments. The course was not difficult, as her lectures were interesting and aided with visuals. There are no tests - a final research paper, a presentation, a flipbook, and some weekly posts.

Natalia is a wonderful teacher and I loved this course! The amount of research/reading could be overwhelming at times, but overall rewarding and you'll definitely improve as a writer. Everyone in the teaching team is super supportive and welcoming so make sure to go to office hours if you need extra help. You got this just be prepared to WERKKKK :P

ENVS 100 is one of the most difficult classes that all ENVS students must take, but Natalia's lectures and support helped me a lot. Natalia is the sweetest professor and gives great insight into assignments in the lab. She wants everyone to be engaged with the class and it worked. Information given was easy to follow and understand. Great person!

Natalia is a friendly professor with an amazing and super interesting background in ornithology. I would recommend her as a professor or advisor to anyone I know, as she gives clear and thoughtful feedback with useful instruction.
He is awesome.

Professor Haddad is a kind person, willing to make time for you, and enjoys his classes. This class is an absolute waste of time. 100% busy work, up to 2000 word article summaries due a week along with assignments that came directly off the slide, I've never been less inspired in my life. Boring lectures, definitely better classes to pick from.
SO much homework, do not take with other hard courses, or other courses with lots of homework
I am a high school student and took this class to get college experience.  Prof. Haddad was so helpful and encouraging. There was a lot of reading and homework but it was doable.

Took this online class as a non-major; caring and accessible professor but grade consists of a lot of small assignments that rack up a lot and lots of reading. Wouldn't recommend for a non-major because of the difficulty  of the course but professor has good lectures.

Super nice guy and super knowledgeable about water policy! Had a ton of great guest speakers, and although I did fall asleep once or twice, it was for the most part very interesting. He's a slow speaker though, so would recommend listening to recorded material at 2x speed. Was super understanding about the whole COVID-19 situation & cared about us.

He assigns a lot of work but most of it is super easy and doesn't take very long. He's also very understanding of the whole COVID situation and how it can affect his students so he's allowing late work with no penalty. He obviously cares about his students and it's refreshing. The course is an easy A and I'd recommend it as a G.E requirement.

while i agree there's a lot of work, i've turned in a few assignments late during the 'rona and our ta gave me full credit. that being said, i really enjoy dj haddad and he seems like a really kind guy who cares about water. i'm just taking this for ge's but its pretty interesting, he's very fun, and has cool and interesting guest speakers :-)

would like to make it known that during a global pandemic this professor is assigning at least 6 assignments per week as if 1)students don't need time to adjust to online school 2)students have no other classes to do work for and last but certainly not least PEOPLE ARE NOT DYING. PEOPLE ARE LITERALLY DYING AND HE'S GIVING BOATLOADS OF BUSY WORK

Quite possibly the most boring lecturer I've ever had. Tons of text on each slide, which he simply reads off of, and does not post online. Tests were insanely specific, i.e. having to memorize the authors and titles of a handful of readings, quoting his lectures, etc. Lots of homework each week.
Great guy and the class is interesting if you go to class. Made up of HW and a take home final.  Made water and energy interesting and brought up things I didn't know

Bland material to begin with (TIM major here), lectures weren't especially interesting but Haddad tried. Had weekly HW assignments & a group project. Pretty easy midterm & ok final (Haddad basically told us during class what he was going to put on the exams). Honestly, if you put in the effort to do the busy work then this class is a cake walk.

He is a nice guy and but the lectures can get boring. If you read the book and do the homework it'll prepare you for the midterm and final. For the final he gives you a cheat sheet so thats a plus. Also theres is a pretty good curve in the class. Barely went to class, read the book, and got an A
He's a nice guy but is boring in class. Not a hard class but not interesting.

There is one midterm, one final, and one group project. Professor Haddad is a great professor for this class. His exams are fair, and he practically tells you beforehand what to expect. He assigns weekly homework, and if you take the time to read the book, you'll be fine. This class is an easy A if you just go to class and read the book.

Avoid ENVS25 with Haddad. It was all about the essays when I took it. 36 hours to write them and the prompts made no sense. Everyone was on WebCT late into the night, interpreting them. The online discussions with classmates were an interesting and valuable experience, but not worth it. I've never taken such a difficult course before or since.

well, it could be a pretty interesting class, but it was boring as hell. hes a really smart guy, knows what hes talking about, but he talks out of the book, which he wrote, and is what he uses for lectures. he changes the way he grades year to year, this last year was only 2 tests, but there have been essays in the past. fair class, decent prof.

This class was horrible. Professor Haddad made no effort to make the material engaging, and the tests were ridiculous. I failed both, and STILL got a solid C in the class. Didn't learn anything that made it worth while, nearly impossible to make it through lectures without sleeping, and if you aren't out, you're neighbor is.
He's nice, but the lectures are dull. There are only two tests: a midterm and final. Take it only if you need to.

Brent is a nice guy and he presents the material well. The actually lecture is boring but I think it is the subject matter more than the professor. Grades were based on 40% midterm 60% final but he offers extra credit. If you don't have to take this class don't but it is bearable if you have to. Biao is adorable!! and Tim passes notes during class.

This class looks intimidating because it's law heavy and late at night (7:10 to 8:45) but everyone should take it if they can. I had no law knowledge previously but the lectures made so much sense and I felt like I could understand envs and law together. He's a great lecturer and I wish he taught other classes cause I'd wanna take that so fast.

Professor Bushey was so nice and approachable and his lectures were very engaging. There as readings due every class and students are called on randomly but once you were called he didn't call on you the rest of the quarter. If you didn't do the readings and were called on he just skips you and comes back. Also had some awesome guest lecturers.

The class seems intimidating, but as long as you show up to class, keep up with the readings, and participate you should have no issues. Professor Bushey is extremely fair and his passion for environmental law is reflected in his teaching.

Prof Bushey is super passionate about Environmental Law and Policy and that shows in the class. If you are equally passionate this class will be great. Lectures cover the tests very well so it is pretty fair. Attending class is easy as long as you are good with the timing.

Professor Bushey is a very knowledgeable professor and it shows, given his work in the EPA. There's a lot of reading but if you're passionate about the environment, law, regulations, etc. you shouldn't have any problem completing the assigned reading. Just be prepared for each class and you should get an A. I had him Spring 2020, so he was lenient.

Doug is a great guy. He worked for the environmental protection agency so he is well equipped for the course. There is a textbook and the class is mostly looking at real life cases and the environmental laws that surround them. Tests are short essays. 100% would take again. Doug is great and his in-field experiences really add to the course.

Midterm and final are tough and really make or break your grade. I found that I learned most from my sections and not the lectures because so much info is thrown at you at one time. I would not take this class for a GE requirement, which is what I did. I think she is a sweet person but not the best lecturer.

Professor Flora Lu is incredible and had very interesting lectures. I think this is an important class for every ENVS student to take. A lot of the concepts were difficult to understand though. Make sure to go to section (attendance is mandatory) and go to office hours so you can better understand the concepts. Beware of the midterm and final.

The midterm is NOT spawn of satan like someone said. Dr. Lu is an amazing lecturer & person. All the lectures are super interesting and relevant, make sure to take notes tho. TA sections are incredibly helpful and encourage participation. Course material can be a bit dense but with adequate studying it all comes together and overall isn't too hard

She is the kindest woman and is so understanding of all situations. The lectures are important and some things she talks about aren't on the slides but appear on the test, so listen and take good notes. She hands out snacks for participators and every lectures is so engaging. The guest speakers were really well chosen too. Overall great prof!

Had the longest, most boring, lectures, and then makes her entire test based off of them. The discussions are really helpful if you participate and they can help you prepare for the tests. She did have some interesting guest lecturers come a couple times. The midterm is a spawn from satan, PREPARE.

Amazing professor, passionate and kind. Very understanding and in the job for the right reasons. She wants you to succeed and is always open for questions and conversations. Great for a GE or major requirement.
For ENVS26 - Great professor! She is super caring and makes the lectures interesting.

One of the best educators at UCSC. Engages students to become more invigorated in getting what they want from college and will open your mind! Today she had 20-30 students attend her office hours and sincerely cares about the success and growth of her students. She's also well networked with the Ecuadorian Amazon and helps get you in the field :)

Amazing! Most influential people in my life: 1. Ghandi 2. Michael Bechwith 3. Flora Lu-----she cares so much about her students and the material and has spent SO MANY YEARS involved with indigenous studies in the Amazon- If you're reading this considering her winter 2013 LALS 100 course, TAKE IT. She is is sadly switching to ENVS next year

Amazonian societes was one of my favorite classes at UCSC. Flora is so sweet! She brings snacks all the time and it your even remotely interested in South America or the Amazon take this class. The reading is easy and interesting. Plus she has GREAT legs!

Dr. Lu is very helpful and engaging. She is brilliant but humble. Her lectures are always interesting and she selects good readings. She has done really interesting and important research. If you have a chance to take a class with her or get to know her in any capacity, take it.
Class is entertaining, enlightening, engaging, and thought provoking.

Dr. LU is amazing passionate profe. Her classes are challenging but her lectures, readings and assignments are incredibly engaging. She is always willing to help students as well and is very approachable. I encourage everyone to take one of her classes! She is by far my favorite teacher in the LALS department!!

Flora Lu is really awesome, she is really passionate about what she is teaching, and makes you motivated to do something worthy in life. The midterm and final was to do an essay, which was really straight forward and easy if you did the weekly reaction papers. I really enjoyed writing the advocacy letter to chevron.

I loved this class! Professor Cheng is super kind and genuinely cares about teaching, and he is also a super knowledgable and professional researcher in the field of soil science. I learned so much and would love to take another one of his classes.

Weixin is a really really good professor and has an incredible background. He provides amazing stories and information, and he is really eager to teach. Was only graded on 3 things in this class (Midterm, Essay, Final)

Listen, this guy is a really nice human being. However, his accent is thick as mollasess and on top of that he wears a mask during lectures making it impossible to decipher more than two words per sentence out of his mouth. Expect to use the textbook/internet for 99.99% of what you learn.

This professor is incredibly kind but his lectures are very dry. He has a heavy accent and also reads off of his slides in a monotone voice. Even though it's his field of study, he doesn't find a way to engage the class and make this topic fun. His exams are easy if you go to class.
