Take the class if you want an A but not if you want to be inspired

An excellent professor, he reminds me why I do what I do and why I love the major I chose. Just because he speaks with an accent doesn't mean he thinks with one, his passion and dedication to the subject are obvious, and I learned more than just scientific background, but also life skills. His office hours are so helpful, he wants you to succeed!

He has a fairly heavy accent, which makes lectures hard to process at first. You get used to it after a few lectures though. He is very knowledgeable and cares about the subject. Every lecture he has you write a short summary that is worth a decent amount of your grade. It's very simple; pretty much free points if you show up. Easy class mostly.

He doesn't speak very clear English, making it hard to follow along. Further more, his lectures were pretty dry and hard to stay awake in. There was a fair amount of reading but it felt like the book was doing all the teaching for him. This class made me want to switch out of the ENVS major. He is very sweet though

If you like documentaries that are science based and are at least slightly aware of what is going on in the world - this class is easy. I showed up on Tues/Thurs and took his participation summaries and easy weekly quizzes and passed with an A. There's some chem to learn but nothing too complex. Cheerful professor and loves his students/class.

The lectures are pretty dry and boring but if you pay attention and attend lectures and follow along his notes (which are really unorganized  organized strangely) you should do fine. The textbook isn't really needed unless you really want to go above and beyond, his lecture notes should be good enough. He's really nice and loves doing what he does
Seems like a nice guy but he was very difficult to understand and not that interesting. Would probably be a little better in a smaller environment but definitely not for a large lecture class.

Weixin was extremely difficult to understand, which made the class dull and uninteresting. The subject itself is not exactly thrilling, so having a professor add to that made it nearly unbearable. He gives pop class summaries once a week. I thoroughly disliked his class. Tests focused on seemingly unimportant information

The class was alright, during lecture he would usually dwell on complicated graphs that we don't actually need to understand for the midterm or final. The material was more Earth Science based than Chemistry based. He gives weekly online quizzes and random weekly short summaries during lecture. He helps you a lot during office hours.

His accent is very strong and hard to understand. Classes are not too necessary since his lectures aren't that helpful and he posts them online. only reason to go to class is for the quizzes. His tests are a bit tough but he curves them. Not one of the most significant classes that i've taken.

I really enjoyed this class. Yes, it was pretty basic knowledge but nonetheless a great prereq for the major. Cheng is very passionate about teaching. The online quizzes are helpful & boost your grade quite a bit if you do them well. Tests were fair. I really loved him as a teacher. He is kind, open to questions, & passionate about what he does.

I am an ENVS major and am pretty passionate about the environment. That said, this class was a waste of my time. It felt similar to beginner level high school earth science. Weixan was unorganized and his english (speaking and writing) was terrible. It seemed like he just quoted Al Gore in his lectures the whole time. Take chem instead please.

To be honest, he seems like a really nice guy, but this just didn't work. His lectures and notes were horribly organized, and very confusing, even with simple ideas. Additionally, he's not a very good speaker- all monotone, reads the notes practically verbatim (even the charts and stats). I'm an ENVS major and I LOVE ENVS, but this was torturous.

Completely incompressible. He is a scientist to a teacher. His english is horrific, his test are near impossible to study for and he has no format what so ever. Unless you research it, the significance of the class is hard to grasp in relation to environmental studies. Take this at a CC, dont waste  your money on this class. Worst UC Class.
if you like envs 23 take this class. cheng is as usual a great professor, the class isn't too hard and its very interesting!
awesome class if you are into the environment. cheng is a really great professor and extremely passionate! expect to have to study a lot for the midterm and final

I want my money back! Weixin is capable of a good / passionate lecture- I saw him do it ONCE (when discussing his own research) This makes the rest of his uninspired, formulaic lectures all the more unforgiveable. He didn't even bother to provide study material for the final. UC- this man is a researcher, not a teacher.

Greg is one of the most considerate and passionate professors in the ENVS department. He always takes student feedback into consideration, making our field class the best possible version. Greg was a tough grader, but his feedback is detailed and pushes you to improve. Even with the strong academic history, he was laid back, fun, and caring.

Really great lecturer and cares a lot about his students. He encourages questions and feedback. Also doesn't have a late policy, which helps a lot in this class given the significant workload. Exams are probably the easiest part of the class, it is definitely more project/assignment oriented.

This class was a unique and interesting experience. Greg is very knowledgeable so he is a great professor for this class. He is a tough grader so be sure to triple-check all group reports. His expectations can be a little high, especially for beginners to fieldwork. Overall this class is doable and a fun experience!

Greg Gilbert is passionate about what he does and is also a super sweet person in general. He is very approachable, understanding, super smart and gives good advice. He usually likes to do a lot of data work, I took him as an intro upper division class and he was awesome but might be a bit more work if he's the only one teaching the class!

Gregs class was a lot of work, but he is really motivating. I didn't even really care about plants before this class, and now I look at them with a new found respect. I would recommend this class to anybody as long as they're ok with group work and doing a lot of it.

Prof. Gilbert was my faculty advisor for my internship. He has been extremely helpful and approachable. I've talked to him several time during office hours and he always has great suggestions for my project and some wonderful stories. He has done a lot of work in the tropics of the Americas and his SCWIBLES work is very inspiring!!!!

Greg was my most inspiring professor ever when I was in his Tropical Ecology class in 2003. He cares so much about his subject matter and his students, and it shows. He was choked up on the last day of class because he was going to miss us all. Really learned a lot, and loved the class. He invited me to take a grad seminar with him the next year.

Like Greg said in the beginning of the quarter, "this class isn't about pictures of furry animals" (though there were some pretty cool pictures!). Weekly online quizzes and group essays were designed to make you do the reading and engage with the text. A pretty good work load though this class is definitely worth it.
good class, interesting subject matter. Greg is very enthusiastic about the tropics. Enjoyed the class.

Professor Gilbert gives a lot of work to do in the class with weekly readings and group essays. However, his grading system is pretty fair and fairly easy to achieve a good grade. Much of this class was based on how much work you put into the class. Midterm & Finals were 15% each. Interesting lectures and guest speakers. I had fun

greg was not there for over half the quarter due to illness. this did not stop him from giving a really hard midterm (mean was about 45%) and assigning a lengthy paper (about 15-18 pages). the class was interesting, but there was also lots of busy work. greg knows his stuff about fungus.
Greg is great, really nice and helpful if you come to his office hours. however, he won't be teaching 100 anymore. Bury and Zavaleta are great teachers too.

Gerg didn't do all the lectures. We actually had quite a few guest lectures which I thought were really the best part of the class along with the assoc. writing lab.  Greg's a really nice guy and made me laugh with the way he bounces as he walks. He cried on the last day of class, which was really sweet.  The class was co-taught with Sarah Rabkin.

This class was pretty straightforward, very similar to introduction bio/chem courses at community college but we went in depth in a couple of areas so some of it felt fresh. He is very chill and you can tell he really cares about his area of work. He and the TA's were very understanding and helpful to ensure all the students had a chance to pass.

He is a really cool professor and is engaging in class but he also has the worst slides you have ever seen. Taking notes is a little difficult unless you are good at listening to what he is saying and getting the notes from that. Most of his slides are unhelpful pictures but his class was overall super easy if you just listen to lecture.

He's an absolute king. He makes lectures fun and engaging. The class itself is a very manageable workload and you get opportunities to make up for lost points. Scott is super funny and it's clear that he really cares about his students! He is also very knowledgeable and experienced so don't be scared to reach out to him. Totally recommend!!!
He's a sweet funny guy. He's not your traditional professor, he's very cool posting creative learning content and playing cool jams in lecture!

I believe this was his first time teaching this course so some of the material and the general course structure didn't feel very polished. Overall, this class is pretty easy to succeed in if you attend and pay attention to lectures. There are many opportunities to make up lost points and collaborate with your peers.

Scott is hands down one of the best and most hilarious plus engaging professors to work with for students who are environmental science majors needing to fulfill one of their lower division requirements or students who need to satisfy the scientific inquiry general education requirement. Overall, the class was pretty straightforward without hassle.

Scott is an amazing professor! I highly recommend taking ENVS 23 with him. His grading criteria is super clear, and he is so accommodating. His lectures are always structured and organized super well and he is also super funny.

I LOVE PROFESSOR SMITH!!!! I had them for 136C, and they are the most down-to-earth professor I've every had. I looked forward to lecture every time. The homework is not terrible, and all the readings are available via PDF on Canvas, so no textbooks! Would highly recommend!!

I took Film80S and looked forward to each lecture. Professor Smith is very down to earth and teachers lectures in a way that feels like a conversation rather than a lecture. The assignments and tests are pretty easy and open note. Also, her choices of films are wonderful. She's great with communication outside of class as well.

Took FILM80S. Very easy and interesting class and she was always very cooperative and accommodating. Midterm & final were online in class but were all 100% open note and open Canvas. Very easy GE if you need and I'd def recommend this prof

I took Professor Smith for Film 80S: Sound and Cinema. She is an amazing professor. Smith is nice, kind, and is always available to help students with homework/discussions/etc. I took this class for a GE Requirement and was one of my favorite classes of the 2025 Spring Quarter. This class is doable. Every week, we watch movies and analyze them.

Professor Smith was AMAZING! They are super caring, knowledgeable, qualified, great at explaining, use class time well and I can't say enough good things. If you are thinking about taking them, YOU SHOULD!

Assignment expectations were confusing and often seemed hard to follow. TAs were harsh graders and expected us to fully understand the material and the terms used in the film world. Would remove points for the littlest things with no feedback. Took for a GE and did not like the class which is a shame since it's such an interesting topic.

It wasn't even a class I needed I just wanted an easy gpa booster but it did the complete opposite. When the wifi went out during a midterm it automatically closed and gave me a low score. The professor didn't care and said to try hard on other assignments. Most people in my class thought this was unfair but she didn't give me a chance to retake.

Lectures/readings were straightforward if not common sense, weekly discussion responses + longer responses every other week, never more than 600 words. Tests were easy, but highly specific to the readings, so keep up with them somewhat. Writing grades kinda depend on your TA. Overall, easy course, not very interesting but not bad either!

Video Games as Culture (Film 80V): 3-4 articles of reading per week. Two 30+ minute long lecture videos per week. She covers most of the key points in the articles in her lecture videos. Murray encourages you to read the articles, but it's only really necessary when you need to find quotes for the bi-weekly "essay" assignments. Overall a chill prof

I'd rate Soraya a 3.5 if I knew how to give half ratings. She's well organized. Her lectures are based on slides but don't add much of substance to them. The class has a heavy workload that isn't unmanageable but I wouldn't take it with a busy schedule. Films and discussions can be interesting. You can get by without doing some readings.

A little tougher than your average asynch course, but if you're organized enough it should be a breeze (i definitely wasn't tho lmao). Attending lectures is the only thing you need to pass midterm/final, which aren't too hard or long. Bi-weekly 800 word papers and 2 movies a week tho, this prof is definitely not for the unorganized. Y'all be warned

Professor Murray is a very knowledgeable and kind professor. She is clearly passionate about the topics and likes to hear input from students. However, her class is not an "easy" A the amount of readings (you can get away with not reading some) is pretty intense and there is quite a lot of writing. The TA's are pretty harsh and expect a lot.

Expects us to do the impossible. She wanted me to respond to their prompt, use evidence from the readings, elaborate them, use visual representation from the movie, and expect us to do this all in 150 words. (which is impossible) The TA expect you to do all that and tell us that we are not detailed enough. They remove points over every little thing

This class was so organized and fun! I always knew what was expected. Final and midterm were online and open note, fairly easy if you go to lectures. They were true/false and mult choice. 1-2 assingments due weekly that were very reasonable. 10/10!

More assignments than both of my upper division major classes combined. Weekly discussions, two films, multiple 15+ page readings, and an 800-word paper every two weeks. Excessively specific questions on midterm; final not taken yet. The readings consistently presented overly speculative analyses of the films. Will probably end with a B+ or A-

I'm sure this would be a great class for those who wanted to take it, but the fact that it is mandatory for AGPM majors has partially ruined my time here at UCSC. I came here to make video games, and this ain't it chief. While I wish I could tell future students to be cautious about taking this class, unfortunately they'll have no choice.

Had interesting material but basically a repeat of pretty much everything else taught in AGPM foundational courses. Lots and lots of reading. 500 word biweekly writing assignments + multiple choice midterm/final directly from reading and lecture.

All the grading and comments were handled by TAs, Professor Murray wasn't present except for her Canvas announcements. I didn't mind that though. I thought some topics were interesting to read and formulate opinions on. Gave us two tries on the midterm & final and made both open-book. Just an easy class where you have to do discussion posts.

The class instead of being about media and what makes it good, the class is entirely comprised of reading long papers by snooty 'academics' that very evidently don't play video games and responding to them. Incredibly boring. Also a lot of the course material is about race and lgbt stuff for no reason. Just wanna make video games man.

Easy GE, every other week there would be a 1,000 word paper due. Every Thursday, a discussion post was due. The midterm and final exams had 25 multiple choice questions, open note. We had one hour and two opportunities. Lectures were very interesting. Would recommend.

There is no direct lecture. So far it seems to boil down to how much your TA likes your work or how harsh they are with grading. For reference you are graded on following a prompt but the TA can and will grade you on things that contradict/ were not included in the prompt/rubric. No partial credit for items on rubric, its either 5/5 or 0/5 so far

Class was completely asynchronous during the pandemic. Essays were long (1000 word essays four times over the quarter and 150-word discussions every week) but they were graded extremely easily. Make sure you answer all parts of the question and use needed sources on papers and discussion posts. Very interesting class and easy A!

Murray is a great professor, the class was very PC, but it was nice to learn about a lot of subjects that I usually wouldn't research on my own. I learned a lot and this was a really easy class if you keep up with the deadlines. Lots of responses that are 1000 words each, so that's a lot of work. The tests were open note and she gave 2 attempts! :)

Technothrillers was a great course to take, despite it shifting to online for the pandemic. If you like sci-fi movies, take this course!! Professor Murray is a gem and one of my favorite professors on campus. I highly recommend this course if you're looking for an easy-going class or need to fulfill the PE GE.

This is my favorite class at UCSC! There were a few writing assignments but they were great to do if you love video games. I can't recommend this course enough. It was really easy, I loved attending lectures, and Professor Murray was super accommodating when the pandemic hit. If you're looking to fulfull the PE GE req, take this course!

Warren is a cool dude. But when it comes to his class setup I wanna lose my mind. Took 120 with him and his assignments were extremely confusing. The descriptions were overly detailed and made no sense. Thank God for the TAs because they helped so much. Attendance was mandatory and there weren't any excused absences. for an 8am kinda crazy

Warren is a sweet dude. This class was SUPER easy. The lectures are super interesting, but definitely make sure to attend discussion sections because attendance there is part of your grade. Don't bother buying the textbook because you can access it online on the UCSC library.

He is not a terrible professor, but he deviates so much from the class content! The class is super simple, almost no homework. You will not learn a lot from the lectures, but definitely attend your discussion. Textbook reading is not useful so don't bother buying it, it's available on the UC Library online.

Coming from a CS background this class was very easy. Basic knowledge in HTML and Java would help. He gives code that you can use for your own projects so from editing a couple of lines of code you can get your project done in a day. On discord he wasn't super active but when he was online he could help solve whatever problem you might be facing.

this is a coding class, I do not know where I was when I enrolled in the class. I ended up understanding the course, but the first two weeks were so hard. I had to meet with the professor many times. It is doable, and will make you feel accomplished, but do not be afraid to ask for help. There is only 2 assignments/week. I enjoyed it a lot!

Film 20C with Warren was probably the easiest class I have ever taken. He changes the class focus every quarter and this one was on social media. Attendance was mandatory even though you could not show up to a single class and still pass. All assignments were online and had about 1-2 per week. Never touched the textbook at all.

Yeah the other ratings on here are intense but he seems to have restructured the course to be more manageable these days. He's really nice but not very tech savvy. Attend all lectures and sections for easy points. Easy A+ if you attend. Easy assignments as long as you watch the movies. Exam was worth the same as a regular assignment so that's cool.
I think Sack gets a bad rap. He's a pretty funny guy and doesn't assign too much work. Lectures can seem to drag on but are worth going.

This class was terrible. All Warren did was assign readings and have us annotate the book online. Then he would give us papers with unclear directions and tests that had absurdly useless questions. At least he gave us a good study guide with all of the questions that he could potentially ask. The TAs did all of the teaching and were amazing.

Warren Sack is by far the worst professor I have ever had. I cannot express how insufferable he made the material. The text is 20 years outdated, he has no rapport with students, and cannot lecture at all. Really comes across as though he hates is job, which is really unfortunate considering FDM majors are required to take this class. Good luck!

How do I begin here... This class I find the least engaging out of all. I only took this class to understand the "Digital Media" of the FDM program of UCSC. Lowkey a but underwhelmed by it. The papers are very unclear as well. It is a blessing that the TA is at least able to help us out. If u r proposing the FDM major, don't take this class.

Man this class sucked. I try to keep an open mind about classes like these but the professor just made me absolutely hate everything about it. He's boring and quite pretentious, and I get the feeling that he has no idea what he's talking about. His instructions on papers were not only confusing but they were stupid in design. Disappointing.

The absolute WORST class Ive ever taken. Avoid it if you can. The instructions for big projects like essays are UNCLEAR. Some of the instructions of our midterm were changed like 6 hours before they were due. Thats how bad this class is. The work is easy, you just annotate a book throughout the year, but man this class is infuriating!

This man is so respected in his field which is pretty cool. I will say if you are a film major with little to no interest in the Digital Media branch be wary of this class. If you do the work you will pass with an A but do not expect to take anything away with you from his lectures. Go to the first class and show up to section and you're good.

I think he saw the reviews on this site because when I took this class he completely changed the criteria. He made class mandatory with a writing assignment each class, and he had so many papers with ambiguous and unclear prompts. Lectures were long and boring. I'd recommend working closely with your TA.

Prof. Sack somewhat read off his slides, although he told us he was making an attempt not to. I pretty much never took notes but we were given study guides for both the midterm and final and it made the class pretty easy, but only because it was rote memorization. Sack is a caring and kind person; I just feel like I didn't learn a ton.

He is one of the worst professors in UCSC. He literally just reads off of his notes the entire class. I went to his class for 2 weeks and then never went again but I still got an A. Just show up to the sections, post homework online, and study for midterm, finals and you will get an A. He also posts all the questions for finals and midterm.

I went to all of his lectures and I'm telling you that you don't need to attend class. I don't understand all the hate he's getting  I guess, in terms of learning, he did fail on that part, but the class is incredibly easy. There are weekly posts, a midterm, a final, and a final project. (He gives you all the QA's beforehand, so easy A!)

This man is basically the worst teacher I've ever had the unfortunate luck to come across. Film 20C is the worst class, easy as dust, and useless. I learned not a thing and got an A after never going to class.
sack grades the class too hard for non film majors trying to get ge's.  ta's didnt seem to care about helping as much as they were trying to get their own work done.

Jennifer Horne taught FILM 20 A well, although it was an intro course and the content was pretty simple, she kept things engaging. She is not very tech savvy. The in-class quizzes were pretty easy if you pay attention in lectures and take notes.

took film 20a. lectures are organized, participation is encouraged, and she brought in some rolls of film for us to look at in class which was fun. she is not very tech savvy so be aware of that. she is very receptive to student's opinions and input and encourages discussions at every turn.

If you participate in section and give yourself time to do the papers, you should do fine. It is a lot of reading, but not all of it is necessary to read, so you can skip a few if need be. Just don't miss class and don't avoid her. Talk to her, she's helpful and clearly loves what she does.

I had a great time in this class. It is clear she is passionate about what she teaches and I admire that. She does offer extra credit, so do not be fooled. If you are unhappy with your grade, it is in your hands to fix it and try harder. It's college.

Very unclear about what she wants from her students. She changed the rubrics AFTER we submitted our assignments and it is unclear what her expectations are, as she doesn't make an effort to share them. Haven't been able to check our overall grade this entire quarter either. Overall horrible experience, wouldn't take her class again.

Worst class I have ever taken in my entire academic career. Lectures do not provide you with any significant information. Wants you to engage with her about coursework, but is in no way approachable. Class objective seemed to change every few weeks, assignments were poorly explained. Students were unable to view their grade the entire quarter.

Horne is extremely unclear about what she wants from your essays. There is only three things that get graded, and two of them are honestly the same essay that have very undefinitive prompts/directions. After the first essay, I was told to just "do better", and with 60% of the class failing the first essay, that is a crazy way for students to learn.

I love Jenny! She is so passionate and knowledgeable about what she teaches, and her lectures are interactive and lovely. She teaches a boring class to most, silent cinema, but makes it very exciting and interesting which is hard! I really respect her and love her teaching style. She is also very calming which I enjoyed. Mellow about papers & hw.

Professor Horne, is always well prepared! She know what she's talking about. Her American Social Problem Film class was mind blowing! She showed films from the silent film era to Chi-Raq! Such a fun class, just do the readings, come prepare and you'll earn an A plus tons of new knowledge! I will definitely miss Professor Horne when I graduate.

Professor Horne is excellent! I took Silent Cinema because I didn't like it and wanted a challenge; now I'm considering a career in archiving and restoration.  We met twice a week, we watched a film every class and there were mind blowing!  Midterm & final are research proposal, the first one is with a partner and the second one solo. I loved it!

Professor Horne is extremely knowledgable and passionate about her subject matter. I really enjoyed this class. Horne is really nice and approachable, and always goes out of her way to respond with personalized and insightful emails or set up appointments. She clearly cares about her students, something I really appreciate at a school this big.

Took this 2 years ago and still reference the concepts learned in her class. Very knowledgeable professor- if something is unclear she explains it in office hours. Material prepares you well for upper divs both cs and prod; heavy on representation theory. Students complaining about her classes are those who don't read the material. Need a smart TA
Inarticulate and rambling lectures.  My least favorite class experience at the University.

The concepts in the readings were genuinely really interesting; the way Horne describes them, not so much. Poor preparation for lectures, little feedback on papers, and don't even think about asking a questions in class, because all you'll get back is a vague answer that some how completely avoids the question. The final was an absolute train wreck

Professor Horne does not know how to structure a class. This was her first time using an online grading method and it turned out to be a complete disaster. I don't think anyone in the class actually read the material besides a small content that was required to complete the online submissions.

This class was a disaster, but it didn't have to be. Film Theory is an important and interesting aspect of the FDM major. Thanks to Professor Horne, Film 120 was worst class I have taken at UCSC. She does not know how to run a lecture, articulate concepts, answer questions, properly address race issues, or grade assignments. She needs to be fired.

Great professor! Jennifer is an incredibly skilled professor who knows her stuff! I enjoyed her class a lot but in order to be successful: spend a LOT of time on your essays (like a day), go to class, EVERY CLASS, take notes what she says is important IS, do most of the reading ESPECIALLY the passages she highlights in class, study for the midterm

Horne was a GREAT teacher. I took this class as a GE requirement outside of my field of major and it was really enriching. She made class very interesting and there was very little work required. To succeed you need to read the "key" passages she mentions in class and write something of actual substance for the papers. Easy A

If you want the A, then be prepared to read for hours on end. The textbook assigned is actually extensively studied and there are multiple websites to clarify some difficult concepts. Overall, you can do well on the test if you read the pages of the quotes in her slides and re-re-re-re read all the assigned texts and pages. Don't skip movie days!

Do not take this class.. complete waste of time. She is not only very unclear, her lectures were based off useless power points with extensive quotes. She is very confusing and lacks originality with her teaching. Entire class failed the midterm.. says something about her. AVOID!

Took the class as a GE, was very easy to understand and follow along during lecture, very cheerful and approachable guy. Not too many assignments, and they were all pretty easy, some of them were even pretty fun. Midterm was technically a small group project, final was multiple choice online. Enjoyed the class without much stress.
He was an amazing professor! The lectures aren't technically mandatory but were very helpful. He is very understanding and helps if he can if anything comes up.

Super fun GE, great guy, really cares. Not really more to say. He clearly loves what he teaches, very accommodating with extensions. I had a total of six graded assignments the entire quarter and only 3 or 4 were ~300 word papers. Super clear about what he wants, and doesn't ask for too much. Highly recommend for a GE prof.

Amazing lecturer and funny guy. Class was always engaging and clear. Homework assignments were well explained and the TA's were totally on top of everything, clearly in good communication with Logan. Super understanding guy if you have any issues that come up during the course. One of the best film professors at UCSC, in my opinion.
He's a great guy and is super easy to understand, loved his class and made the subject fun!
Super easy class, lectures were super cool to learn with. Only a few assignments for the class

Took 134A with Logan. Super cool dude and there were only like 4 assignments. Two papers, one lecture project, and a final quiz. All super easy if you pay attention. Lectures were a bit boring and he kinda just read off the slides so it got repetitive. TA's were great and they help so much, shoutout to Alex. Discussion is mandatory, lecture is not.
Really great professor and easy class. As long as you clearly follow the grading criteria, you will do well.

Loved this class! There were like 4 assignments, 2 of which required lots of writing/analysis so be ready for that. You do get tons of help at discussion sections which are mandatory. Although lectures aren't mandatory I found them really enjoyable. Logan's slides were very helpful and straight to the point. Weekly screening were fun too!

Not as fun course content as some of his other classes, but he has the same class format that I like. As long as you put some effort into the essays and show up to discussions for participation points, you're golden. Final is really just a review of course content, don't need to worry about it at all.
The TA graded harshly but Logan was great! The lectures were good but the class wasn't as interesting as I thought. It is really about the history of television tools but we do watch TV clips!

Pretty chill, most of the grade is on two essays and discussion sections. Final is incredibly easy, open book no time limit. Lectures are recorded unless there was a tech issue. Great lectures on film history overall. Lectures not mandatory, but attend discussion sections since missing out on too many will dock your grade a decent amount.
TAKE LOGAN'S CLASSES! He is one of the best. If you attend the lectures you have all the information you need.

Fairly easy class, 2 essays, 1 final, and attendance made up your entire grade basically. Attendance isn't mandatory but you get points for going to discussion which impacts grade greatly. Essays are very important so if anything try on those. The final wasn't really a final, just some easy overview questions. Other than that great class/professor.
He gives great and helpful feedback.

Logan Walker seems to be a nice person however, he only graded my assignments closer to the end of the quarter leaving me no time to improve my grade and work on the suggested techniques for further assignments. I would not take this class again as it didn't leave much room for improvement.
Overall a pretty chill professor. Really easy to understand during lecture, and super easy to reach through email.  I'd definitely take another film class with him.

I've taken both 20B and 136D with Logan and both experiences were great! Minimal work, intriguing & well-explained lectures, and really interesting screenings/readings. Logan is understanding and great at adapting to individual student needs. Overall, any of his classes are a great experience. In person, 20B had a screening at every lecture (fun!)

Chill dude. Easy class, and makes the presentations in lecture fun to look at. Basically no work and the quizzes are super easy and most of the grade comes from 2 big projects that are pretty easy too as long as you listen to how he says to do them. Final exam was easy multiple choice. Attend your sections! I got A- as I didn't attend half of them.
Extremely nice guy. Will give you extensions if you ask for them. Had him twice and I am taking him again next quarter definitely recommend

Took her class two years ago and I still think about it occasionally. She is truly such a great instructor and wants you to succeed. Tough grader but her notes are very helpful. As long as you come in with an openness to learn and engage she will make it very easy for you. The syllabus is very well structured and she cares about her students.

I would always recommend a Kim class because of her insight and wealth of knowledge. Lectures were always interesting with fun content! For 194S, there was lots of writing and homework, and it was graded kinda harshly, so make sure you can commit to the topic fully and be engaged. Would recommend, prepare to think quite deeply for good grades.

Professor Kim was amazing. Class was stimulating and there tended to be good discussion. She's very warm and has a wide range of references which makes sense since she comes from an interdisciplinary background.i fell into a nasty (suicidal) depression and without saying anything, Prof Kim emailed me and I'll never forget that.

Lots of EGO! Very technically insufficient. Didn't give grades or post until after finals week on over 3 assignments, this is due to being a subjective grader. Had to ask. Condescending. Always messing with her hair and blouse on Zoom. Thought I would really enjoy class- very disappointed in class and the professor. Will never take again.

Easily the most I've learned in a Film & Digital Media Critical studies course (non-production). If you want to get woke take this! She is the one of the smartest and articulate professors at this University. Lot's of reading but it's truly optional, only need to read for quotes for the three essays (2 midterm, one final). The readings are dope tho

Kim is a probably one of the best film professors I've had the chance of having during my time at UCSC. Not only is she intelligent, articulate and is enthusiastic about the material she teaches, but she is very caring and understanding about student's needs. I would definitely take another course with her.

The cost for books + reader was nearly $200. The tests were really hard, I think the person with the highest score in my class got a C in his midterm. Unrealistic amounts of reading to only have one hour to discuss it in section. Piece of advice: study from your notes rather than from the texts. Everything you will be tested on is in the lectures.

DO NOT TAKE if you want an easy class! Be forewarned that Kim is very disrespectful and will drive you insane with her terribly ridiculous, hard, and specific exams questions. Also, a lot of reading in which the exams are solely based.

Professor Kim is extremely intelligent, articulate, organized and knows a ton about the subject and makes the class really interesting. However, the class is frickn' hard, she assigned 3 textbooks along with online reading, and honestly it wasn't too bad because there are no tests! But to really get it and succeed you need to be ready to work hard.

Assigns a lot of reading. The tests are incredibly difficult, asks very minute details from readings. Requires a lot of work, don't take if you have other classes that have a large workload. Go to all the lectures and sections and read the readings multiple times.

Kim was very personable and had a good level of enthusiasm for the class. Yes, there is a ton of reading, you basically have to do it all, but if you read everything, attend class, and have an overall understanding of it all conceptually, (with the exception of really random book facts) you can pass. It's a lot, but I didn't find it impossible.
She makes you read a lot. Even if you do the readings and go to class and section theres still a pretty good chance you won't pass. It underdivision but it sure didn't feel like it.

Proff. Kim knows her stuff and she expects you to do so also. The class requires a lot of reading. However, with the effort, its possible to get an A. Exams are very specific;requires a lot of memorizing & writing. My hand literally hurt after the final. Overall, it was a fun class but you need to be into the subject & whilling to learn to pass

She is very prepared, her lectures are script like, she knows what she needs to say each lecture and she gets it done. It might be an intense class, but I LOVED the class and I am a legal studies major. If you make the effort to seek help you will be fine, go to section it helps ALOT. her slides are big hints for tests.

Horrible class.  She was unorganized, constantly messing around trying to get her technology to work.  Teaches her opinion like its fact, and pays way to much attention to small, insignificant details.  In the end, your tested more on useless facts than the overall themes of the class.  Would not reccomend it.  Not to mention she repeats herself.

Very hard class.  Exams were very precise and required a lot of studying.  Questions were mostly written, short answer and fill in the blank meaning you had to have done all the reading and take pretty good  notes in class to even have a chance.  The sections were very helpful.  More of a cultural studies class than a film class in my opinion.

Definitely not a class you can easily pass, let alone get a good grade in. Kim really knows her stuff, but she makes her classes unnecessarily difficult via a tremendous amount of reading, nit-picky TAs, and difficult exams. She's fun to listen to and watch, but it's not worth the effort.

If you put the effort in, this class can be great.  But it does require a lot of effort.  Read the readings, come to class, you know the drill.  Tests are difficult, but fair, and Kim really does have a passion for the topic, so take advantage of office hours.
She's hella unorganized! I can't stand her! She reads from the book all class long and makes going to class a painful experience!

Professor Kim is the worst professor ever. She doesn't care about her students and only wants to show off. She's very intelligent and hot, but she can't teach to save her life. Take her class pass/no pass if you can. It seems as though she never wants to be there and that she doesn't have enough time for her students. What a waste of time & money.

Took 165B online and honestly was worried. Ended up being a great class. Not a ton of assignments, only a short written quiz every week, a rough draft, final presentation, and final essay. My TA was great as well so honestly made the experience a lot better bc she provided good feedback. Easy A as long as you understand and read the material

She is so awesome! Very engaging classes and I loved listening to what she had to say about certain films. She's very liberal/left leaning and it shows which is awesome. She's funny and kind and cares!

Film Majors be aware!! This professor gives out 5 Pop Quizzes to COLLEGE STUDENTS. There is a paper proposal that is 5 pages long, a midterm that requires students to answer 2/3 questions in 800 words or more within the class time we had, and there is a final paper 10 pages long with at least 6 scholarly sources.

This is the second class I've taken with Prof Wang. She tends to go off on tangents during lectures which can be distracting. Her assignments are graded harshly which would be fine if the syllabus explained what was expected instead of being vague. If you don't have a TA who tells you what to expect from assignments good luck.

Yiman Wang is a great professor who gives helpful and interesting lectures that easy to understand. I feel really comfortable and less stressful learning this class for the whole quarter. She and her TAs are very kind and willing to answer your questions when you need help.

Professor Wang is extremely intelligent and cares about her students/what she is teaching us. In Film 120, students were extremely rude and disrespectful to her simply because they could tell she had an accent/was not the best with electronics--absolutely appalling to me. She could improve her lectures by shortening slides and getting to the point.
I like all the material presented. But her lectures were super hard to keep up with. Super dense slides that would just have quotes from the readings.
she is awesome and very polished. Just like glass.

Prof. Wang is awesome. I'm always amazed by the wealth of knowledge and analysis she incorporates into the lectures post-screenings. I can tell she herself is very invested and excited about the topics and readings (both of which are extremely interesting) we discuss; however, her lecture slides are really verbose, and she tends to go on tangents.

Do not expect her classes to be film classes. They're much more concerned with sociohistorical and cultural discourses, using film as a window into these topics. I'm in class right now and I'll literally quote her next sentence: "western colonial discourse is a discourse that manufactures and depends upon stereotyping the Other". That sums it up

She has a very thick accent and is somewhat difficult to understand. She holds the microphone up to her face and moves her head around a lot so her voice cuts in and out. She doesn't know how to operate electronics and wastes a lot of time. Gives too much info on slides.

The films and readings were interesting but OH GOD those lectures. Two hours of rambling, hard to understand nonsense. Her accent and penchant for big words make it hard to understand her, and the fact that there is near-zero discussion means you'll never have a chance to ask questions and try to grasp the concepts. Also: TERRIBLE essay prompts.

I came into the Gender and Global Cinema class with excitement and interest and left the class with utter disappointment. Wang's lectures can span for 3 hours straight of her talking without taking a breath, making it difficult for even the most attentive of students to pay attention. She doesn't give room for discussion in the class either.

She knows her Chinese cinema, that's for sure. Film selections were great, reading material was always fairly interesting, and her lectures were often informative, though sometimes they could run on a little long. Still, not a class you can slack off in; you need to work for your grade.

Their teaching is very straightforward & lectures were entertaining/insightful. The assignment work load is not too bad either. The concepts are abstract & not entirely explained, but you don't need a perfect understanding to get an A. ~60 pages a week in reading & it's good to keep up cause otherwise the class will make 0 sense. Good for 170b too!

Irene was a very thoughtful, caring professor when I took her for Film Theory. She sometimes feels a bit detached and impersonal but I think this is just her personality and way of teaching. She really does engage with the material and often would break down the difficult concepts in concise ways. Would definitely recommend her as a prof

This class is not an easy A at all. Your grade is determined by 3 multiple choice exams & one paper. The exams are pretty tricky bc she puts random stuff that isn't on her study guide. The paper was graded pretty harshly but if you do well it'll bring your grade up considerably since its 40%. Overall do NOT recommend. Lectures are extremely boring.

I took Film80A with her in the fall for my IM GE and it was a breeze. She screened movies on Monday and analyzed them on Wednesday, and the class before every test, she went over all of the items on the test. Low and behold, after spending about an hour going over those items, I got over a 90% on every exam. Very easy GE, 10/10 would recommend.

I'm not sure if it's the TA that actually grade but grading was tough on pretty easy material which was annoying. Films are fun, but she tends to throw in more things on the test that aren't on the study guide so its like she's asking for you to mess up and not get an A.

Monday are usually the screening days where you'll just watch films, and Wednesday is where Irene will discuss each film and analyze them. Often time, she just reads off her Prezi slides (which can be found online). The class wasn't informational IMO, its just analyzing film (w regards to the most minor details).
Best professor I've had at UC Santa Cruz!

Irene is an amazing professor! I've had the gift of taking two of her classes so far and I hope to take more. She loves what she teaches and is extremely knowledgeable when it comes to documentaryexperimental cinema. Also, the fact that she is super hot doesn't hurt, haha.
This class was interesting and non-demanding. If you pay attention and try, you will be good. Solid teacher and engaging material.
Don't take this class as a GE unless you really enjoy films and analyzing them.
Professor Gustafson is an amazing professor! So intelligent that it's kind of sexy ;P. haha this class was interesting and informative. If you have Gustafson for any class, you're lucky! :).

She's super passionate about the subject and pretty funny during lectures. The tests are really easy & based on readings and film screenings. Irene always told us exactly what was going to be on the exams (none of them, including the "final" took more than 20 minutes to finish). Overall a great class and an amazing professor.

Irene was seriously one of the best professors Ive had  When professors are passionate about the subject they teach its noticeable and believe me she is extremely passionate really easy to talk to really helpful answers emails quickly Go to lectures and watch the movies ull be fine she tells you exactly what will be on the exams take this course!

I came into this class far from a film major, just to try it, and left wanting to declare. The assignments were fun, and I found them to be pretty easy, time consuming, but easily graded in the end. The lectures were interesting, and I still apply what I learned to my everyday life. Heads up - all the assignments are photo/writing based. Take it.

Irene was fantastic. I attended every lecture because they were all super interesting. She really put a new spin on production technique, and made me view the visual world in a whole different light. The assignments were fun, though graded hard, and the final project is making your own little movie! It is a great class, I highly recommend it.

So Irene at first put me off as a littly artsy fartsy, but she explains everything clearly and ultimately helps students understand that why and the how of cinema in a way that is accessible and encouraging to our own endeavors. Also did not put up with BS, which is an issue with some college sutdents.

Irene is awesome, helpful, and inspiring. She lead the class well, demanded everyone's attention with ease, and really did a great job. She is friendly and helpful. Everything she showed in class was valuable. The projects were challenging and interesting.

Irene is "cool."  Her class is entertaining and informative, but she hired terrible TA's.  If you get Luke, drop the class ASAP.  He's the worst TA in history.  Irene is amazing though and makes up for the horrid weekly sections.

She is very knowledgable and geniunely loves what she teaches. Don't take this class and expect an easy grade. The lectures are boring as are some of the films but she is overall a good, knowledgable teacher.  She is a stickler if you don't come to class all the time.
UPSIDE:  prepared, organized, and concise.  She doesn't meander off-topic and her lectures fit clearly into an overall structure.  DOWNSIDE:  acts culturally superior, can be rude/condescening

This class was not attendance mandatory and was easy to do from any location. I would recommend this class as an easy GE and I would definitely take again. This class does require you to fully watch films to understand and complete the assignments so be prepared for that.
Very passionate about film

Class is formatted weird and a lot of the material is subject to opinion. Was really looking forward to the final analysis paper only to find out that I had to pick from a film we watched in class. Which is fine, but the film industry is so broad and there's so much more out there.
she didn't make anything clear and has a difficult time navigating technology, her class structure is really weird and overall i really didn't like this class. wouldn't recommend.

If you have the option to take Landberg's film class do it! She puts tons of effort into the lectures and choosing the films. Lots of things to be graded on so your grade is padded but the essays are graded relatively harshly. She cares a lot tho so worth it!
Now and then, you get an assignment where you have to write a small essay, but classes are fun if you decide to go. It was a good experience. Probably one of the best GE classes out there.

Very nice and definitely an "easy A" kind of professor. If you do your work and take any kind of notes in lectures, you'll be fine. One downside is that she's not very tech savvy, which is not great in a film class. Also grading criteria was never made clear, and anyone questions about grading would get a "you'll be fine" answer.
Easy A and a pretty fun intro to film class.

Very engaging teacher, The class was very straightforward and understandable, and Professor Landberg did a great job at breaking down each film so it was easy to understand the underlying themes and culture that influenced each film. However, expect lectures to be extremely note-heavy. Bring a computer. 4.7/5
She is hilarious.

This class was at 8am and very boring. The professor is monotone and talks at you. I would start to fall asleep sometimes. When you ask him questions he's not good at explaining things. He didn't show up to the 2nd midterm. Aside from that the grading is fair. If you do the work you will pass but it's not an enjoyable class or an easy A.

A little unfortunate, his class was at 8 AM in Fall 2025. Lectures sound like you're getting talked at, but can be helpful for quizzes/tests. The TAs were more useful in preparing you for tests, though. Not very difficult to pass, as the tests accurately reflect topics covered in HW & lectures, but the class is not engaging in the classroom at all.
I think Chris should quit his job as a a professor
It is a tough course but there are many opportunities for points (hw and labs). The quizzes are a bit challenging though

I dont know who thought it was a good idea to have this man teach an 8 am with his boring lectures and monotone voice. The TAs were more helpful than him in teaching the material. He is very passionate about his work with pumas but he could not care less about his students. For our second midterm bro didnt show up and our TA managed everything.

Geniunely not a nice guy, gives off this pretentious energy screaming I'm better than you, doesn't have an actual meeting time for office hours, leaves his door open while other students wait making it a very awkward experience, doesn't want to help his students and quite frankly couldn't care less, cool research uncool guy!! Not typical for UCSC

He could be boring sometimes but honestly he isnt as bad as everyone says. I was able to understand the material pretty well without reading the textbook and relying on lectures (he only tests on lecture material textbook is just recommended). Pretty nice guy and if you study a little bit you should be fine
you can pass the class and fail both midterms and final fyi. but professor is pretty mid and lecture is boring, bro is for sure paid by the hour.
good professor, test questions are sometimes very confusing

Prof Wilmers is chill. Lectures were mostly clear and the assignments in sections were helpful. He gave 10 point quizzes every Thursday which were hard and stressful though. But his grading scale and tests aren't too hard if you study. A 93+ was an A+, and an 87+ was an A-, and 78+ a B minus, so I appreciated that.

Professor Wilmers was a tough professor to have. While he clearly has a passion for his field, he teaches like we all have graduate level understanding of the material. On the first test he stated we would have all the equations and proceeded to put none of them on there and then argued about it with students. Destroyed my interest in Ecology.

I don't get all these bad reviews, Professor Wilmers was wonderful. He would frequently stop in lecture to answer questions the class may had, and he would provide us with practice problems for the midterms. During office hours Chris was caring and understanding when it came to any questions or confusion. A great professor overall.

The labs for this course were amazing and the topics covered in lecture were interesting, however, the midterms and final were terrible representations of the class content. Wilmers provided no study guide and only gave a list of concepts, half of which never made it to any of the exams. Was very dissapointing to see that bc I loved this class :/

He is a very boring lecturer. He did not give a study guide to his students for the midterm or final. He held zoom office hours instead. He gave a list of topics but that was all. He would rather talk about mountain lions than ecology.

I really appreciated Chris's teaching style. Lectures focused heavily on the math and included some interesting case studies; the book provided context for what was covered in lecture. To do well on HW do it early, use the book, and go to OH with any questions. If you enjoy the math behind conservation bio and put in the effort, the class is great!

Also, Environmental studies is an interdisciplinary field, but this straight, white, privileged man does not have a CLUE about the policy or sociological side of ENVS. Do not take unless you are science based, he will ruin your last quarter at UCSC. He probably cares more about Pumas than POC. Actually, he definitely does.

It  seems like people didn't like his ENVS 120 class because it was math based. It isn't Chris' fault, the course should be considered/changed to a different department, and not considered an ENVS class. Had him for Capstone 190 and he is very kind, understanding and willing to help.

1. he reminded me of Toby from The Office 2 Generally fair class 3 homework kind of hard but do-able 4 lectures and notes can be confusing but posted online 4 Wasn't terrible though 5 called students out for talking ( kinda give props) 6 somehow funny at times ... somehow 7 not bad of a class
His lectures are not clear at all. I did not learn anything. Were are the inspiring professors at?

His lectures are not clear at all. I really wanted to understand the information, but it's really difficult if you don't have the right math background and think a certain way. He definitely teaches to one type of learner, so be ready for some hard core confusing quantitative analysis. Did not enjoy and it it turned me off to a subject I like.

The class mainly consisted of disucssion posts, readings and annotations, and 'reflections' of when you experienced any form of inequality, which were just essays. I did well on most things except for the reflections because there wasn't enough analysis in them, according to the graders. I can't say much about lecture since i didn't pay attention.

Great lectures. i did it for summer session and she keeps u captivated for all 3 hours. very light coursework, and it's quite easy to get by without much effort. however, if you do put in the effort to read and listen you'll gain a lot of really valuable knowledge

Nick is an amazing lecturer! This course includes a lot of challenging reading but her lectures make them engaging and easier to understand. Highly recommend taking a class with Nick as she is an excellent speaker, a caring person, and a Feminist Theories genius.  
The class was graded on going to discussion, annotating readings, and 3 essays.

Nick is one of the best lecturers on this campus. She could talk about material with no slides and keep me interested. Class was a little unstructured, but material was cool. One issue isthe frequency of papers and the lack of a rubric. There was a paper due two weeks before the final paper was due. A midterm and final would've been sufficient.

I have never rated a professor until now The difficulty & effort required for a course I have been studying years for is just WOW Attendance HW & reading required for lecture & section Professor is not lenient at all Professor is not easy to speak out to & can be patronizing although this is a FEMINIST course. ExtraC options available
Loved this class !! Really interesting and eye-opening lectures.
Great professor and a great class. Lots of reading but it is not all required. Do the reading if you wanna learn more. No exams, just papers to write.

I really enjoyed this class with her and thought that it was both very interesting and very easy. It's not hard to do the work for this class, you don't need to do every assignment, and there's plenty of extra credit opportunities. Whether or not attendance is mandatory depends on your TA, but for me it wasn't. 10/10 recommend!

i dont usually mind reading theory, but maybe give us more than 3 days to process a books worth.. other than the unessecary amount of reading the class is a easy A. just listen to lecture and you'll be fine tbh . i took it in the summer fyi

This teacher clearly cares a lot about the subject, but I found that this course was difficult as an academic introduction to feminism. The readings were often very dense and hard to make sense of, and there were many throughout the week (~30-50 textbook-sized pages a week). I'm not sure if the lectures were confusing or just easy to zone out to.

Professor Mitchell is my favorite professor at UCSC. I am a politics major but I took every class from FMST to CRES to learn from them. They can regurgitate articulate historical dates and answer complex questions on the spot. Professor Mitchell never had us spend a penny and provided hard to find sources. Take their class and experience greatness.

annotations due before class everyday, but you only have to complete 10 days for full credit and the rest are extra cred. nick is a great lecturer and explores the complexities of race very well. this is a great ge to take with him. sections are mandatory but they're engaging and involve the readings from class.
lectures are intense but enjoyable!
I really enjoyed the class. It gave a lot of in depth analyses and I learned things that I wouldn't have learned anywhere else.
Lovely professor, will definitely be taking more classes from Nick!

Prof Mitchell knows so much about feminist studies! Despite the class being intro-level other students asked really sophisticated questions and I struggled to keep up with lectures. Not for someone who hasn't been learning about feminist movements for years.

I really enjoyed this class. Nick is a great professor and made it clear what the assignments would be. The class is graded on a few essays, annotations of lotsss of readings, and participation in discussion groups, which I felt was fair. Just be ready to read. Lots of communism, which I loved, so be prepared. Great class!

TAKE CRES10 or any class with this man for that matter! Prof is a real one. strictly there to engage you in difficult topics and see to it that you learn and grow from the material. also so funny and a true character, not just a professor. so much love!!!
YOU MUST TAKE CRES10 WITH NICK. He will change your life, anyone would benefit from this class, one of my favorites from my college experience.

I took Feminist Theories with Mitchell, but regardless of what class you take with him it'll be a life changing experience. One of the best Professors I've ever had, it was an honor to be taught by him. He lectures in a Ted Talk kind of manner.... his mind wow. If you try, you will pass easily. You must take him.!

Literally horrible. Has yet to grade literally anything and is so disorganised.  Mumbles during his “lectures” and they are so hard to follow I honestly learned nothing. Does not know how to teach and seems like he won't ever care to learn. Literally never even posted the syllabus.

If you want an easy course that in NO WAY challenges you to grow or learn, Quentin is your guy. If you care about learning and getting your money's worth, avoid him at all costs. Worst prof I've had at UCSC. He's a nice guy but a useless professor. You can learn more from YouTube videos than 10 weeks' worth of "instruction" from Quentin.

DEEPLY uninspiring. He talks to us through eye rolls and sighs. He tells the class that we won't succeed and he teaches like he's being held hostage. He spends half the class just staring at us waiting for someone to raise their hand and say something. Cancels minutes before class/One time he didn't show up and we waited an hour before leaving. 0/5

The class was a disorganized mess. had literally no structure ever. He was always late. You will pass with flying colors if you show up to section; hardly any work but hella disappointing lectures. Sucks, because this is allegedly one of the only hands-on production classes here, but don't expect to be filming anything other than iphone projects.

one of the worst teachers I've ever had. I basically stopped showing up to any lectures after week 2. the lectures were absolutely pointless, I learned nothing and it's so upsetting because I was looking forward to this class because I love production. EXTREMELY disappointing and huge waste of money!!!!! bro DOES NOT know how to teach. horrible.

Wow. joke of a class. This man has a reputation ... I would ask around about it. I love production and went into the class very enthusiastic and it left me immediatly. I would just say pray for a good TA, mine was my saving grace. But I honestly can't say I learned anything from Quentin this quarter, easy A tho.

Quentin's class is really disorganized and felt like a waste of time and money. I literally never left the class feeling like I learned something, especially because Quentin really struggles to give a proper lecture. It's an easy class, but honestly you could get better info from a youtube video. He is also not great with technology.

bro cannot lecture to save his life. he says everything while also saying absolutely nothing. easiest class known to man. says attendance is mandatory but never took attendance. just sections. he was late literally everyday. he's completely disorganized and honestly had no respect for anyone's time, then got butt hurt when we stopped showing up.
He doesn't grade anything and he never posted the syllabus. He cares but there is no organization in the class at all!!!

Flashed my class first day of college. Otherwise every easy class. This was during the strikes and he changed the class to pass/no pass which obvi made everyone mad. Swapped it back and messed up everyones grade and wouldn't respond to emails until you emailed his boss. Otherwise incredibly easy class.

Film 172 is one of the most intensive production classes this school offers, you're thrown into it on the first day and just have to do it. It was seriously such a stressful time because I was putting everything into it. Quentin was always there to help out even at odd hours. His teaching style for this class is amazing compared to 20p.

Can confirm that in 2023, Lareau projected a graphic picture of his genitals sent through private messages on his computer at 8am. For many other freshmen, it was our first college class ever. We later got an email announcing there would be a Title IX investigation regarding the situation, but as far as I know, he still works at UCSC. -100/10

I was in his film 80A class where he flashed his genitals on MY first day of college EVER. What a traumatizing day...and of course, the school gave him no consequences. However, in order to meet a perquisite for the production classes at UCSC, I had to take his film 20A. Believe me, the course and his genitals were awful experience.

He's alright, but he's not very respectable due to the way he talks back to students sometimes. He puts on that facade of a genuinely caring and benevolent nice guy, but you can tell after knowing him for 10 weeks that it really is just a mask. Bro is a demon, not in any outright bad way, but just in a "this guy is kinda annoying" one. Decent class

It feels like he doesn't want to teach this class. His lectures are incredibly soporific. You can learn all of this stuff for free on youtube in a more engaging way. I will say though, Quentin is nice, but his teaching style is awful. You would think that a production class would make you do production-- not in this one apparently.

Professor Lareau flashed my class, and similar stuff has happened previously with him. It's an issue with him, otherwise, the class was easy just watch some movies, and write a couple of essays, no tests. It's an easy GE. But I'll never see him the same.

This man showed us his nudes on the screen.His lectures are pointless to attend and look like they were made by a fifth grader.I hated this class,it was the bane of my existence. He received no consequences for showing us his nudes.Yes the class is easy but he wants you to write 1000 word papers based on his useless lectures. 0/10 do not recommend

I didn't enjoy the structure of this class, lectures were just repeating what the reading said with giving some context behind the week's film. Films that were picked were great, though. Assignments were very simple to complete, and graded easily, but his guidelines could be confusing at times because he tended to create very broad assignments.

An easy class, not a lot of work. There are three papers and theyre all graded relatively easily. There are a lot of readings to do, but I never did them and was able to follow along the class fairly well.

Jon is AMAZING. He is caring, accessible, has many small yet doable assignments and gives phenomenal feedback that makes you a better filmmaker. He has taught me so much and I'm taking him next quarter too. Hands-down he is the best film production professor here so take. his. class.

Ayon-Alonso feels like youre being taught by an uncle in your family which can be good or bad depending in how you see it. He focuses on class being more intimate but doesnt actually teach anything and has the readings cover what he's actually supposed to teach. Also feedback for projects weren't the most consistent

Ayon-Alonso is one of my favorite professors. He is extremely kind & connects with everyone, he wants you to succeed not just in this class, but in your future! As long as you show up & invest yourself, you will do great in this course. He is a great professor, resource for industry/career info, and just genuinely cares about you as an individual.

Easily the best film professor I've had. It was so nice having a production class and Alonso couldn't have been a better fit. Super funny guy, tons of industry knowledge, and you can tell he wants you to succeed. First few weeks are spent doing hands on projects, last few are spent filming. 100% take the guy if you can.

Highly organized lectures but few assignments. Scoring well on the two quizzes will set you up for success, I suggest taking notes on everything even if you don't think you'll need it since some niche content is references in exams. Stamp is very supportive and easy to approach after class if you have any questions.

simple, clear cut class. lectures are absolutely necessary even if attendance isn't checked. you can find the movies online if you want to watch them on your own time, and the textbook isn't at all necessary to succeed in the class.

Shelley is an amazing teacher! Her lectures are exceptionally organized and engaging. Through 3 classes I've taken of hers, the tests can be very specific and stressful, but she's always there to support you and makes her material very interesting to learn. Take notes of everything! Because you may be tested on very specific specifics. Great choice
Shelley is a very clear teacher. Her voice helped me learn and it is easy to follow. She is a class act- kind, respectful, knowledgable, and enthusiastic.

I have Prof. Stamp this quarter and last quarter while having online classes. I really like how she is clear with her grading, rubric, and lecture. The materials are not too hard to understand but still interesting at the same time. I would definitely take her class again and I really recommend anyone who is searching for a good film professor.

I took this class asynchronously, but we had a couple of weekly lectures and a weekly screening, and I definitely enjoyed the lectures and the material! All of the test material is directly from the lectures, so you don't need to read, but take notes during lectures because sometimes she'll reference really specific, insignificant details in tests.

I was worried about this class because the only grades are a midterm test and paper and final test and paper and as someone who gets testing anxiety I was rly worried. I really enjoyed the subject material and structure of the class, even the papers and tests were very manageable. Id 100% recommend this course.
It wasnt bad but it also wasnt great. You can pass this class by just watching the lectures and taking notes so you can pass the 2 essays and 2 quizzes. Didnt really need the textbook.

Class: FILM160 Film Genres- Film Noir. My second class that Ive taken from prof. stamp and enjoyed it even more. She gives great historical context, demonstrating the importance of the films to the time period. Her interest in film noir was obvious and made the class even more interesting. Required to watch x2 movies/week.

Shelley is a relatable, easily accessible professor who really wants to help you understand the course content. The movies we watched for This intro class were interesting, and always related well to the topic of any given week. Final exam was a little tough, but if you pay attention/take good notes during lecture + WATCH THE MOVEIS, youll be fine

The structure of the class is weird so discussions and launchpad activities are due back to back, which made the class super stressful. The textbook was useless. The films were pretty boring. The midterm & final were difficult. I did learn quite a lot about cinematography though but just the basic stuff. Not the best class but also not the worst.

Professor Stamp is nice but the course was just really boring. There is readings, lectures, and a movie assigned every week. There was also this LaunchPad thing students had to buy for the class but the activities in it are not helpful and are also not graded so it's useless. The final was ok but the midterm had questions that were weird.
Not good at communicating, even though I enjoy this class She makes it less enjoyable.

Shelley is a true gem and def one of the best professors in the film dept. Lectures are so interesting and are done with passion, while still being organized. Screenings are all so perfectly curated and discussions are fun and engaging. Looking forward to having her as a professor again.

The tests are really hard. She asks questions about the most obscure things that she quickly glosses over during lecture. The readings aren't very useful as only a small portion of questions come from them. The movies dont even make up the majority of test questions. The majority was random facts that she briefly mentions during her lectures.

This class was horrible. Entire grade is based on a midterm and final, each worth 50% of your grade, with extremely specific questions on topics/movies mentioned once in lecture. Lectures are really fast, and slides aren't posted anywhere. Study guide for the tests aren't helpful at all. Do not recommend.

There were only two tests weighted 50% each. She gave 1 hour 30 mins for 50 super random and specific multiple choice and an essay question. She doesn't post lecture notes and speaks really fast. There are absurdly long readings that are randomly mentioned on the test. She is not helpful for help for studying.

Shelley Stamp is by the best professor in the Film & Digital Media department. Her lectures are extremely organized, although sometimes can be too fast-paced. She wants you to like and understand the material. She is overall an awesome person and a phenomenal professor. Class is mostly essay-based, so get ready to write!

Absolutely loved Professor Stamp, she is really well versed in her field and is a fantastic lecturer. I attended every lecture because I actually enjoyed the curriculum and presentations. She began every lecture with a class-wide discussion which was super helpful and engaging

Truly an amazing professor. Super knowledgeable and her lectures were really interesting. Definitely go to her office hours, if you can't make her appointment time she will go out of her way to make a time that works for both of you. Very easy to talk to and inspired me to be a film major.
On the lowks, kinda goated? 🔥

Such an amazing lecturer! Really nice, very informative and easy to follow. A lot of homework but really easy and about half was online. Cold calls but doesn't make you feel bad if you don't know the answer. Pay attention and do the work and it's an easy A. Also brought us all crepes at the end of the quarter she made herself as a treat!

Incredibly nice and helpful. Makes sure to recap on old material if it's relevant to the new topic. Constantly writes translations on board for vocab otherwise not learned. Easy to catch up if fallen behind. Very lively and makes you want to learn the material. Does cold call so be sure to pay attention. My favorite prof by far.
Amazing professor, made me motivated to learn and was very supportive of all students.

She is a very understanding and caring professor. I struggled a lot with attendance due to my avoidant personality and general anxiety, but through talking she was able to accommodate and understand my circumstances. This is a language class, so be sure to practice whenever you get the chance to do so. One of the best classes and best professors.

Like many others have said said she is a brilliant prof she assigns homework every class but it only takes about 15 minutes. The exams are easy enough if you do the work and listen in class overall a great class.

Mme. was great. She is a great teacher. You will have to do A LOT of practice, and she will mark you down if your work reflects poorly, but that is because this is a language class; it is impossible to do everything in lecture. Make sure you memorize your vocab and your tex grammar, and you'll do great. She is understanding, so go to her for ?s. GL

Madame Rohmer was the best! She explains the material clearly, the class structure is organized, and you always know what to expect daily. She's passionate about the language, cracks jokes sometimes, AND she learned everyone's names, a lovely comfort you don't often find in university courses. I'm excited to learn more from her in French 2!

Professor Rohmer, is possibly the best French teacher I've had, her lectures are very fun and engaging. Her homework is constant but it is easy to finish. She is such a wonderful teacher, very easy to contact and encourages you to do better all the time.

Loved her!! She was so great and kind. She was also very accommodating and made her classes interesting. Learning French was pretty easy because she went over the material. As long as you do the work and actually practice the material learned in class you should be fine .

I've had three other french teachers and none of them even compare to prof. Rohmer! She is French native and has a linguistics background that really makes her an excellent teacher. She is also very kind and understanding, especially so with everything going on in the world right now. I'm looking forward to continuing my french classes with her!
