Madame Rohmer is the best! She is very kind and understanding and is a really good French teacher. She can help a lot of you are confused and explains concepts very well. Also has a good balance of readings, lectures, and grammar in her lessons. I would say that she gave a lot of homework and graded kinda harsh, so make sure you know your stuff!

Madame Carine is an amazing professor with an obvious passion for the language and teaching. She came to every class with a prepared power point that was easy to follow and interact with. The small class size also allowed for the professor to have one on one time with each student to help with whatever they might need from pronunciation to grammar

I've taken French in the past, and she is one of the better French teachers I've had. You can tell she wants her students to do well. She's also super caring and funny! Like all language classes, it moves fast and there's lots of memorizing. But she makes crepes for you at the end of the quarter. Makes it all worth it.

Carine is so great! She cares a lot about her students, is extremely accessible outside of class and is quick to respond to emails. She also bring crepes to class sometimes :) There are workbook pages due every class but they're easy - as long as you go to class consistently and do the reading and assignments, you'll be fine.

She's a overall a great professor and certainly the best french professor I've had here. She's patient and helpful, especially when it comes to pronunciation. She does a great job clarifying topics in the textbook and her tests are super easy if you do the homework and attend class. You do have to put in the effort but it's nothing too overbearing.

Participation is a must, but she's really patient and sweet so you don't have to feel embarrassed if you mispronounce something. There's a handful of homework, but they're incredibly easy.  Her exams are just as easy, as long as you've done your share of work. She is a real gem, though, and she has a great sense of humor. 10/10 would take again.
She is very organized, the homeworks are important, and the final projects will be challenging. You will learn a lot. She's very good

French 2 isn't an option on RMP for some reason but that's what I took, not 3. The professor is an angel, she's witty, extremely helpful, and really wants the best for you. Very generous grading policy for late assignments + extremely useful lectures. I took a lot away from this class and would take it again in a heartbeat. Don't let work pile up.

The course has a good amount of work and you always have to stay on top of it, but as long as you put in the work, you will get so much out of it. Her lectures are packed with information and she is prepared 100% of the time. She really cares about her students and is very understanding, she is one of the best professors at this entire school!!!

If your looking for an easy class, this isn't what you're looking for. This class is a bit tough and requires you to stay on top of it, but teaches immaculately with the intensity you need when you are learning a language. She's kind and helpful and learns each student's name. Easily one of my favorite professors of all time.

If you want to learn French, take her classes.  You'll have to put in an effort but she is the best French teacher I've ever had.  I still refer back to her classes and notes and check out her videos to help as I have moved on to French 5.  She gave me the French test to qualify for classes since I came from a community college. She is the best!

Professor Cailloux is an incredibly kind and thoughtful person, however I did struggle a bit with the actual class lessons. It seemed like the class was taught as if the new material was review for us, which made me feel like I was never quite grasping the material fully, but rather just trying to memorize without understanding it.

Mme. Cailloux is incredible; she is brilliant, understanding, and kind, but she doesn't let uninterested students waste class time. She is very helpful inside and outside of class, and her study guides are straight forward and comprehensive. Language classes in college are not easy As, so don't sign up thinking you can skate through.

Madame Cailloux is excellent! She's tough and not very lenient in terms of absences but she was so important in my growth as a French learner. She speaks French as much as possible in class and is also very available if you find yourself needing help. Participation is super important -- be there on time and show her you care, and you'll do well.

She's definitely a great professor and cares a lot about the students. You'll learn a lot about the French language and Francophone culture in taking this class. However, the class is really rigorous and takes a lot of dedication to do well. Also, you're only allowed 2 absences. I would only recommend taking this if you REALLY want to learn French.

She gives a lot of work, but as long as you do what is asked she is awesome. Make sure do all homework and study a bit for the quizzes. If you do what is asked, pay attention and participate you are set! She's a wonderful teacher and cares about how you learn and understand French.

Cailloux gives a lot of work and expects everyone to participate fully. Slacking off is pretty much impossible. She's a very helpful woman so do not hesitate to ask questions or go to her office hours. I've taken both 3 and 4 with her now. Like many language classes, hers are demanding and linear. Make sure you're really interested in French.

Madame Cailloux is easily the best teacher I have ever had. Sure, there is a lot of reading and work that has to go into the class. But its to learn a whole new language, so it comes with the territory. But Cailloux makes learning about French and the French culture really fun! She does randomly call on EVERYONE in class so make sure to do the hw

Jesus Christ! If this was the only class you were taking, it'd be okay. The assignments are simple, but they are piled one on top of another. She teaches way too fast for any beginning French student. I wouldn't take this class unless you were pursuing French past the first class.

Overall an easy grader, received average marks through out class but still got an A in the course. Her accent was hard to understand sometimes and she thinks that we know more than we've been taught, but otherwise the class is survivable. Workload is average for a language course.

M. Cailloux was not very helpful at all. She would often get angry at our class if we did made a mistake. As the quarter progressed, the more angry she got, and the more work she assigned each day. I was very enthused about taking this class after taking French 2 and 3 but now, I don't even want to continue. She's not a very helpful lady.

She is a good professor, make sure you come to class cos she grades all the class participation and gives extra credit too. She is very strict with submissions and stuff. Make sure u do your homework and dont miss any test or quizzes.
Mme Cailloux is amazing! So nice and loves to help you. Tests are hard and she gives a ton of hw but it's a great class! :) love her!

Madame is hilarious and brilliant and made my freshman year in French incredibly enjoyable. The homework load is perfectly manageable, however the book is very expensive, so don't enroll if you don't have $130 available to spend. She gives detailed study guides for tests, and follows through. She expects effort and participation.

Madame Cailloux is a doll! She's the sweetest woman I know, always willing to help and explain things over and over. Her tests are pretty time-consuming and at times a little difficult if you haven't completely mastered the material, but overall her teaching is superb! I took French 3-5 with her and loved every minute of it :)

Madam Cailloux is an excellent French professor. Her exams can be tough and at times there is a lot of homework. Be prepared to put in time for any language class. She really did help make my french 10x better. I learned more in one quarter with her than 4 years in High School. Highly recommend taking french with her.

Bryan cares about us so much!  He knows when to help and when to step back. You always know when you make a mistake but he doesn't always tell you directly, letting you figure it out on your own (really builds your confidence in your ability to independently use  good French). Very professional and encouraging. I'm critical, but he gets an A+.

Bryan is an amazing professor who really goes out of his way to make sure everyone is getting the material. I've had some problem with class due to work and my other major classes but he was totally helpful and understanding. And he can be really funny in class!

Bryan is fantastic. He is funny, knowledgable, enthusiastic, and friendly. He is very willing to help and answer questions and truly wants to teach his students to speak and pronounce French well. Attendance and participation are both very important, and pronunciation/speaking skills are emphasized. I'd take him again in a heartbeat

Not as easy as Paik, but easier than Elsey. Surprisingly young and humorous. Ability to pop his eyes out like no-one else. Great teacher who actually cares to teach you exactly how to achieve good pronunciation and French skills.
Bryan is so awesome! If you get the chance to take a class with him, do it!
Bryan was great! He was helpful and funny. Also a fair grader. You need to put in the effort and you'll do well. Show up to class and if you need help he has regular office hours. Great class!

I loved having this professor and this class as well. Prof Sparke is such an inspiration to anybody interested in GCH. He has done so much for Global Health, like working with Paul Farmer. 100% would take him again.
Professor Sparks does a great job of keeping students engaged during lectures. No heavy homework assignments. Test are very fair. This is a great course for those interested in the medical field.

Took spark for Global and Community Health, he was a great professor and always willing to speak to students and listen to their ideas. Not much homework but there were 1-2 quizzes per week and open book midterms and a final. Would definitely take his class again!
The class was easy to understand and you can tell Sparke cared a lot about what he was teaching. There are a lot of weekly assignments but they are easy enough to do.

Professor Sparke is an amazing professor! You can immediately tell how passionate he is about what he is teaching, not just out of personal academic fascination, but out of a deep and honest conviction that it can have a real, profound impact and change the world! He also is more than willing to go out of his own way to help his students!

Professor Sparke is simply spectacular! He made lectures so engaging and enjoyable! Please take a class with him it will be the best decision you make! I look forward to taking classes with him in the future. He truly cares about his students and loves talking with us.
Amazing professor!
Matt Sparke has been my favorite Politics instrustor at UC Santa Cruz and has engaing lectures. There was quite a bit of writing to do but the grading was pretty easy.

Professor Sparke has a vested interest in expanding general knowledge and widespread understandings of Global Health. The class has a fairly unique structure as you spend about half the quarter working on a funding proposal which ends up being the most difficult work of the class, but its not too difficult.

He's seriously one of the best professors I've ever had. You can tell he's passionate and he brings so much energy into the room. Honestly, if I wasn't lacking sm at the end of the quarter I would have gotten an A in his class. 100% would recommend !!! He's super nice and understanding.

Great Professor, He is passionate about what he teaches and cares for his students. His lectures are sometimes dense but if you are interested in the topic they are interesting. And he makes an effort to make sure the atmosphere is lighthearted. Plus he ie flexible and understanding and allowed extra time for my assignment which helped me a lot.

Never once punished me for late work, wouldve failed the class if he had. He really wants his students to succeed. His lectures are dense and theres a lot of work, but hes passionate about the subject and does a really great job doing low stakes scaffolded assignments and his exams are reasonable/low pressure. Gem in the politics department.

I took two courses with Sparke and he is truly one of my favorites. I have a pretty debilitating disability and I can't stress enough how kind, patient, and accommodating he was with me. More broadly, lectures are a delight and when discussing global politics and economics he is brave enough to be critical of the powers that be! Take his class!!!!
Great teaching style! His lectures were well-organized and his slides were very helpful.
SUPER cool prof and he really does care and will be lenient on late stuff. Don't miss a class from him his lectures are fun.

He's probably the nicest professor here, really understanding and is really open to criticisms/suggestions. You only have 1 midterm, a final (both online) and a paper. The paper is really all your weekly writing assignments just compiled and edited. Try and stay on top of readings and you'll get an A (for both writing assignments/weekly quizzes).

Sparke is so funny and I love his British accent! His lectures are informing and interesting. Midterm and final are not too hard. Sparke truly cares about his students and is very accessible during office hours. He is willing to accommodate you if you have an issues with the readings or need extra time doing the assignments. BEST PROFESSOR
read instructions and do assignments or you wont pass
He's great and helpful 10/10

Prof Sparke is a passionate professor whose lectures are informative, entertaining, and easy to follow. His lectures are planned well. He is incredibly caring... I wish I had more space so that I could elaborate on this! His class makes me feel informed, empowered, and IMPORTANT. He is the best professor I have had at UCSC so far! Take his classes!

Chill dude but only reason I came to class willingly was because 1. Attendance is mandatory and 2. Because it was two steps away from the dorms. If u dont read u will die in this class so make sure u make friends with someone who reads bc even sparknotes won't save u. I dreamt that I would wake up with a broken leg so I'd be able to skip class.

SO MUCH READING, I fear I am not a reader so this was especially awful. You can just skim them so you get the idea of the story and then be ready to really talk about one paragraph that you read in depth. Just agree or disagree with someone in class like once a week and you will be totally fine.

Jeremy Gauger is a phenomenal professor. I took kresge 85S with him and kresge 10, and these classes opened my mind. I feel smarter in terms of critical thinking, perspective-taking, introspection, etc. He chooses intentional topics to read and discuss, and class discussion is engaging. If you get a chance to take a class with him, you should.

Jeremy is a philosophy professor and a lot of classes sounded like a philosophy lecture. We did a lot of group work. Some of his grading was harsh but the rubrics were clear. For the first 4 weeks we did weekly written reading reflections. Other professors had their class film a few minute video reflection which would have been much easier.

Was a pretty good professor, but sometimes his lectures drag on and can make you sleepy. Assigns a lot of readings and homework, but I know some people in my class who got by without doing any of it. Aside from that, he really cares about his students and always gives good feedback on assignments. Just do the work and you're good.

He will grade tough so be prepared to write a bunch. He goes off on random tangents in class, its so hard to listen to this guy for 5 minutes straight, if you don't meet his writing criteria he literally grades off his mood istg.

In my second quarter of Sophomore year, I was severly depressed and could barely make it to classes due to mental health and addiction issues. Jeremy was very respectful and flexible with my absences. After explaining my situation, he was incredibly supportive and understanding. I cannot stress how much this professor has helped me.

The class consisted of Professor Gauger talking most of the time with short group discussions. The discussions and lectures were about readings that were assigned for outside of class, which there were a lot of. Classes could be a bit boring at times with all the talking but were sometimes interesting. Just do the work and you'll get an A.

he is quite nice and helpful. However, his lectures mostly consist of him yapping or having students participate in discussions about the reading that most of us never did. As for the readings sometimes they were entertaining and engaging but oftentimes they were LONG and most of us did not do them. You must participate a little to get full credit.
Jeremy is such a caring and thoughtful guy. I believe he did the absolute best he could with the overall pretty boring course work. Super relaxed and was by far the easiest class.

Great guy. Cares about his students and understands what he's teaching. For a mandatory course, he's the best you can get. I'd definitely take another class with him. If you do the readings, you're set, but you can get by on not doing a handful of the readings. Super cool, chill, and intelligent instructor.

Very good professor. A lot of class discussion and participation is important. He appreciates when you add to the conversations. He is very kind and holds lots of office hours that you can sign up for or drop by if you need to talk to him about anything. Very helpful. Prepare to read.
As long as you do the work, passing is easy

One of the greatest professors for college core classes. Professor Gauger cares about what his students think. If you are going to major in liberal arts in the future, he might be your best beginning mentor. Be ready to read, he will discuss the take-home reading material during the class.

Gauger is a really passionate guy and I think students who are eager to discuss course material bring out the best in him. He talks a LOT sometimes though, so idk, be prepared for the occasional tangent. I honestly think he's one of the better professors to get for CLN1 and I can tell he cares a lot more ab his students than a typical prof does.
Amazing professor. Cares for students and is fair about grades. There is a lot of readings for this class, and in class participation really matters. Overall, an amazing experience. Would take again.
Jeremy is a great professor who really cares for his students and wants the best for them.
Readings were always explained in class, extensions were given when needed, and class was interactive.
Lenient grading and no tests.

I appreciated how kind and understanding Professor Wong was. It made me feel like what I had to say mattered. She was flexible with deadlines when it made sense. I wish more students had taken the class seriously—there was a lot of value in it. I think everyone could have taken something meaningful away if they were more engaged.

Professor Wong taught us valuable teamwork skills that not only relate to the current situation in the topic but also will apply in our future endeavors. She was always thoughtful and understanding, making sure everyone understood everything. Between the materials, guest talks, and feedback, I felt fully equipped and hit all the course goals.

Bad organization, It was a disaster. Over half of our class time was wasted every day to over explain that we were "meeting in groups" and what that meant. Every time we had a question, she would say "I don't know". GCH is an amazing program, but Wong was disappointing. My classmates agreed. Take the course with someone else.

Professor Wong is a sweet and caring professor. I took her Merr 41 class for GE credit, but it ended up sparking my interest in public health. Her class was interesting and engaging, and I felt I got more out of it than any other classes I've had. There is a lot of busy work, but it's manageable and interesting to work on.

The professor always made me feel included and engaged with the course material. I learned a lot, and Professor Wong was super kind. Even though it was a general education course, it's definitely impacted my future career path in a positive way!

The readings were interesting and easy, which was a solid way to kick off college. Group projects can be a headache, especially when not everyone is pulling their weight. As long as you turn things in on time, you should do fine. Honestly, the class isn't rocket science. The professor is really straightforward and makes an effort to be available.

Overall decent experience in her class, but her teaching style is rather boring and I found myself very disinterested in the course content. Very kind teacher, just kind of a boring class you need to take.

The class is pretty straightforward. The professor is nice and will explain what you missed in class at office hours. She gives clear instructions on the assignments, but some things are she'll only go over in class and if you miss the class you won't know. Learn how to use Canvas to read the comments and feedback she leaves in the grading portal.
Easy class but very group project dependent, was willing to let us resubmit assignments if we weren't happy with our grade.

I took Prof Wong for Merrill 1 and it was a very mediocre class at best. She isn't great at providing feedback, simply commenting "this can use more work." There are a lot of writing assignments and the projects never have clear instructions and tend to be confusing. I wouldn't take her again but she isn't the worst.

I enjoyed this class! The professor is passionate and caring about the topic. There were documentaries that we watched about health in different areas of the world and discussed them with the readings. It felt like a community at the end and I made good connections.
This was a decent class that everyone has to take. The assignments were simple. It's not hard to get a good grade if you go to class and hand everything in on time.
This is an interesting class. There was a midterm and a final paper where you work on a case study. The workload was manageable. I would definitely take it again!

The class itself was relatively easy, mostly group projects and busywork. It was also by far the most boring class I've ever had to endure. Entering that class was comparable to entering an event horizon. You could feel time slow down to a crawl, every lecture or assignment reeling you closer to the epicenter of the black hole that was that class.

What was supposed to be a very easy introduction to college was an incredibly boring, lengthy, mandatory lecture where the professor often docked off points on projects for things not even in the rubric. She's very specific so be careful to cover your bases and also class participation is graded.

This was one of the most interesting classes that I have taken in SC. Prof Wong is truly the sweetest, she really cares about her students is extremely understanding. Overall, the workload for this class was manageable, you don't have to do all the readings and I would absolutely take it again!
This was my favorite class!

I took this course and it changed my life. I found out that my passion is to go into public health field from Prof. Wong's class.  We watched documentaries on global health issues like the one on Paul Farmer and worked on real world projects and presentations that inspired me. It gave me a direction for the future that I didn't have before!
Great class and I learned a ton from the readings and discussions.

She's genuinely one of the best. She is super understanding and helpful if you hit a rough patch. She has a very welcoming and approachable personality, making the few classes there were more engaging. Totally recommend her if you're looking for a prof who genuinely cares about your learning joruney and well-being over uneccesary tests and hw!
Helpful and teaches well, Latin 1 is easy if you study really hard at first and get the basic Latin sentence structuring.

I just finished taking LIT 61P online. Professor Chew responded to my questions quickly and whenever I struggled to complete assignments she was understanding as well. Furthermore, I think her lectures are very detailed and I most definitely wouldn't have gotten the grade I received if I hadn't attended the office hours of both her and her TA.

I took latin I, II, and latin lit. Language classes have always been immensely difficult for me, but Ms Chew is the nicest, most caring professor I ever had. The material is hard, but do work in her class, and you will pass. She is the kindest (and fastest) grader I've ever met, and she is very accessible outside of class. Best prof!

Professor Chew is very nice and clearly cares a lot about the subject and students but I wouldn't recommend her for learning Latin or Greek unless you're good at self-motivation and self-studying. Lectures are interesting, not much homework, weekly quizzes where you can submit corrections, and not too hard tests/translations.

Great professor! The class I took was a senior seminar (not the one I had to choose on the dropdown menu). Hybrid online + offline class, with prerecorded lectures and 1 mandatory meeting time every week. Very accessible, helpful with understanding course material, and passionate about it all. Engaging + great at facilitating discussion.

Kristina was absolutely wonderful. You could tell how much she cares about her students (she even tried her best to remember each of our names). She made learning a new language very manageable and fun!

Professor Chew is one of the most amazing, caring people I have ever met. She is also an amazing teacher, both in lecture and in office hours and small groups. I highly recommend any class taught by her.
The class itself can be confusing at times but Professor Chew was really caring during virtual education. When the average quiz scores were very low, she regraded EVERYBODY'S quizzes herself.

I've taken 4 classes from professor chew and will be taking a 5th this fall. I've taken greek 1, greek 2, literature 184a, literature 186a, so far. Let me tell you she is one of the best teachers I've ever had. She gets to know all of her students and makes sure they succeed in her class. She is so sweet, an amazing teacher, and just a great person

This class was great! It's very helpful to have the physical books as she references them a lot and it's much easier to work out of rather than the online version. If you already know a little bit of Hebrew, even the tiniest bit like the alphabet, this class will be the easiest class you will ever take

THE most patient woman I've ever met. Took her for Hebrew 1A and 1B at San Jose State, and I've never had a more understanding and caring professor. The perfect teacher for a different language, and the assignments are great practice, not overbearing at all.
Lectures a bit fast but extremely kind person. She would let you retake quizzes if you fail and basically just makes sure you get an A.

Super easy & enjoyable GE, barely any homework, but you come out with a basic knowledge of Hebrew, which is cool! Gali is super kind and accommodating, and easy to reach outside class. She's very enthusiastic and wants you to learn. Definitely gonna be taking more of her Hebrew classes!

Super nice and caring teacher. Also the easiest GE course for ER. Homework was like translating 3 sentences from Hebrew to English. She doesn't say it in class but anything she does the day before a quiz or exam will literally word for word be on the exam, just memorize the answers to the questions she goes over and easy A.
Super nice teacher, she wants you to do well. Material can be hard but if you pay attention and go to class you'll do well.

Gali is AMAZING! This is a new class (Hebrew: Travel Abroad) and the curriculum goes very fast, so if this is your first experience of Hebrew it might be tough. She is empathetic, funny, caring and a great teacher!!

Gali is my favorite professor I've had in my college experience. She makes sure we learn Hebrew but also understands that we have things going on outside of class, so she doesn't give much homework. The workload is manageable and the class itself is actually FUN. It seems like all the students in the class enjoy their time there because of Gali.

Galia is the best. She managed to make learning Hebrew into one of the nicest language experiences I have ever had. By the end of the class you will have completely memorized and understood all the material and have a good grasp of the language. She tests fairly and really well prepares the students ahead of time. Overall incredible teacher.

Galia is super easygoing! She definitely has the pedal to the metal as far as class speed goes. So be ready to jump from one topic to the next. She is very understanding though so it makes up for it. But seriously, hang on to your hats! She talks very quickly so for me it is sometimes challenging because of my processing disorder. She's rad though!
fun class
Galia is super nice and her class is fun, I took it for a ge and definitely recommend. She makes learning Hebrew easy and her assignments are not hard at all. She truly wants everyone to pass.

Galia is one of the best professor at UCSC. She really cares for her students and will even bring candy and games for Jewish holidays. By taking a class with her, you'll find learning a foreign language is easier than you thought. She's also extremely encouraging and uplifting even if you get an answer wrong.

Galia's literally the best. Take every class you can with her. There's a lot of quizzes, but for some reason it wasn't that hard learning a foreign language with her. She is very approachable and is one of the best professors I've had at UCSC.

Ooh, Hebrew? Must be hard! Well, not really. The homework load is super manageable: give yourself even a half hour before class and you can get it done. The spelling and unit tests are graded very leniently.
I love Galia! She is so nice and loves teaching. Her exams are clear and easy. The class is an easy A. Take it, you will not be disappointed.
Best professor i took so far.
Love her style! Coolest professor at UC.
Ms. Stein-Rosen is awesome. Hard to imagine more fun than this in a language class.

He acted like teaching wasn't a priority. He showed up late, went off topic, canceled class, took weeks to grade stuff, and forgot about assignments. This is all fine if you're looking for a chill class; he was very funny and well-versed in random topics, but don't take that to mean the final essay wasn't a lengthy and seriously graded thing.

Overall, it's a great class with some areas of improvement; his lectures are engaging, but, are not necessary to do well in the class. Although the textbook was "mandatory", it was not used in the class. It teaches you how to be a historian with several essays being the main part of the grade. TAs grade the papers, so go to the discussion sections.

He's a nice guy and passionate about what he does, but his lectures aren't all that important. You're only graded by 3 essays and it's kinda hard to get an A on them. This class is great for people interested in medieval history, but if you're just taking it for a GE, I'd suggest another class.

Benjamin Breen is a very smart professor, who knows a lot about history... that being said HIS65B is titled: Medieval Europe 1000-1500 (Plagues, Pirates, and Peasants). This course had little to nothing to do with Europe during the medieval period, lectures mainly were about the middle east during this time. I don't recommend this course at all.

He is very passionate about the subject and actually provides thoughtful feedback on the papers that he looks over which show that he paid attention to your work. His lectures have little to do with the assignments in the class but they are interesting and entertaining if you like learning about medieval history. Light workload.

Breen is a really cool professor and has a lot of passion for the subjects he teaches. He wants his students to succeed and is always available if you need extra help. He has a ton of interesting anecdotes and is really informed about history. Also, he has so much love and respect for his wife and it's really cute whenever he talks about her.

His lectures are not at all important in the long run, so unless you're interested in medieval history, no reason to go besides for his inconsistent quizzes. Long as hell readings which are very tedious. Graded on 5 things total, but he is very lenient with the grading of papers, and TAs give helpful feedback. Wouldn't take again but an ok teacher

Breen is very passionate about history and makes for an amazing lecturer, as well as an amazing professor overall. Funny and uses interesting examples as in-class activities. Will be able to fine tune your research skills with him, but his assignments are very thorough and can be slightly tedious. Overall, awesome guy and a super valuable class!

Prof Breen clearly really cares about the subject. His lectures (even though they were prerecorded and posted online) were well prepared and were honestly pretty interesting. Grading is based off of 4 essays, the last of which was 10+ pages and was worth something like 40% of your grade but you get a lot of time and help from the TAs.

Great professor. Take your GEs with him if you're a strong writer. If you're not, just take it P/NP with him and you'll be fine. He gives a lot of reading (but which history professor doesn't.) Grade was dependent on 2 papers. Responds to emails very quick.
Absolutely love Ben. He gets really excited about the material and it's contagious.

Professor Breen is amazing! He is such a great professor who genuinely cares about history and students. He's very accommodating and understanding. He's a fair grader; you will get the grade you deserve. It's easy to get an A if you genuinely try.

Ben is a funny and caring guy, he wants his students to succeed and approaches history in an engaging way. He is willing to have open dialogues with his students and go off on tangents which makes for very interesting lectures that really share his understanding and appreciation of history.

Breen appeared nice and knowledgeable but he gave me questionable grades and when I raised concerns about it he bent over backwards to justify the grade. The comments he made were historically inaccurate and he showed no willingness to revisit the paper. I would not recommend him.

Professor Breen is a really good professor, he focuses on the less famous stories in history that rarely get talked about, which makes for a far more interesting class. The class was graded by three essays and a class participation grade (30,30,30,10 respictively). If your good at writing essays, this is the class for you.

Admittedly, you don't need to go to the lectures in order to do the work. However, Benjamin Breen made me want to go to class anyway. Very insightful, always interesting topics, and it's clear he's super passionate about what he's teaching. Made me want to switch to a History major.

Even though I learned absolutely nothing in this class and the essays could be done without taking the course, Breen is interesting. He is very knowledgeable in his field, yet the history he teaches is not rememberable. Easy A, if the TAs are easy. Class mainly focuses on research and writing academically.
Genuinely wants his students to succeed.

His lectures are super fun and hilarious. He talks about the most random stuff that sometimes don't relate to the content of the class but it's fun. His assignments for homework though don't really relate to what he teaches in class though so be prepared to do a lot of independent research.

Prof. Kreps is the coolest. This is my 2nd class with her, lectures are so interesting and enjoyable. Extremely intelligent, she's traditional in teaching style and values attendance. Required reading and a film to watch each week. You make 2 short films in groups, and an in-class essay for the midterm and final. TAKE THE COURSE!

Amazing teacher with a funny attitude. Very informative lectures and a great teaching method, however it is important to attend every class not just because of attendance, but the material is important. one group project worth a major piece of grade but fairly easy and simple, overall great class but difficult.

Relies heavily on TA if she has one. Did not interact with students much outside of lecture. Lectures are information heavy, but no quizzes just a midterm and final. Very chic style and demeanor, and entertaining at times. One of my favorite professors.

Kreps is by far the BEST professor I have had at UCSC. She is incredibly knowledgeable, funny, and engaging. You have to keep up with the readings to be successful, but it is worth it simply because of how interesting she makes the class.

Took my fall freshman quarter. Lectures are a must, most information is taught then and there's lots of class activities to help you understand. Kreps is great, both extremely knowledgeable and very understanding, in my opinion a must take. Tests were alright, don't let them put you off taking the class. I plan to take another class with her.

I took this class in the spring quarter last year and to date it's still one of my favorites. Dr Kreps is incredibly knowledgeable and does a phenomenal job at encouraging her students to question and engage. Only fallback was the difficulty of the tests. Yet, I'm still searching her name to take a class with her again. 100% worth it.

Lectures were super informational and engaging. Lots of in-class activities during lectures made the information easier to absorb and understand. Tests were pretty difficult and focused a lot on dates which I wasn't too fond of but she made up for it by teaching the material super well and giving us re-test opportunities. Best teacher I've ever had
History 10B with Delgado was the best class I had ever taken at UCSC. She inspired me to double major in History.

Very informative class, would recommend as a GE, but a little broad for history majors. Wasn't a fan of the textbook but I appreciated that she had us read two other books as well and each of the TAs gave a lecture. Attendance was a nightmare but manageable. Easy A if you know what you're doing.

Prof Delgado is a very passionate professor who care about what she is teaching. I took this class for a GE and it wasn't too bad. Engaging lectures, hands out money for answering questions. There are 2 papers(4.5 - 5 pages), 1 midterm (online un-proctored canvas quiz), and 1 final paper(7 pages). Attendance is mandatory and important.

Prof. Delgado is very passionate about what she teaches, and her lectures are engaging, but it is often an overwhelming amount of content. She values feedback and participation and gives TONS of extra credit opportunities. 2 papers, 1 midterm exam, 1 final paper, and weekly chapters. Definitely not too much. BEWARE, ATTENDANCE IS A NIGHTMARE!

This professor was extremely difficult and not accommodating. Work is intense and long and the professors presentation lacked information meaning you have to really pay attention to what she talks about. Unfortunately she talks very fast and doesn't clarify what information is important. Too many readings and assignments had very unclear prompts.

I had a slight schedule conflict and she was not accommodating at all even though there was nothing I could do. I asked for her help to clear things up and stay caught up with class many times and every time she would give me half ass answers that weren't helpful or tell me the same exact thing again which was I just couldn't miss lectures.

This course is not for the weak. I took it as a GE in my first quarter, and let me tell you, DO NOT REPEAT MY MISTAKE. There was an insane amount of reading every week, long papers every other week, and the final was criminal (two separate 5-page papers due in one week). Dr. Delgado is a good person but a strict professor who often goes off-topic.

If you are looking for a GE class to B.S. your way through, you probably won't pass HIST128. Her heart shines through in lectures, and as difficult as it is to stay awake in morning classes, there was rarely a moment I didn't find myself fully engaged in her words. Dr. Delgado is so passionate and wants you to succeed, so don't be shy to reach out.

Dr. Delgado is hands down the best professor I have had at UCSC. Her class is reading and writing heavy so be prepared to put in the work. If you are willing to do so, this class and Dr. D will empower you. Go to office hours, she is so easy to talk to about anything history-related. She believes in her students and I cannot recommend her enough.

Dr. D was the best professor I've had at UCSC so far. She was really passionate about the things she lectured about and she prioritized in class discussions a lot, so there were no discussion sections outside of the lectures. There were a lot of readings, but as long as you skimmed most of them, you were alright when it came to the essays.

Grace is very nice and great lecturer, but very stuck in her ways. The lectures are very content heavy and can become boring. If she runs out of stuff to say, she will still make up stuff to do to hold you in till the very end. Attendance is a nightmare, especially in big classes where she forces you to stay after in a big line to sign in.

Super knowledgeable and a very nice professor. She didn't have discussion sections meet, but TAs and herself were very easy to contact with questions. Attend the lecture and take notes because she thoroughly covers the topics you will be writing about. I enjoyed her class and thought the assignments were well-thought-out and insightful.

Easily the best gen-ed professor I've ever had. While I wish the lectures were available online, they are just so incredible and passionate that they're really worth coming to. You can tell that she's proud of her TAs, her students, and her work. She also helped get me out of a tough spot in a way that most professors wouldn't.

Dr.Delgado is a really good professor because you can tell she enjoys/cares what she is teaching. Her lectures are engaging and informative. There's no test or quizzes only 3 response papers where she cancels class and gives you that time to write them. The prompts she gives are pretty self explanatory and as long as you pay attention & read.

Delgado is just your average university professor. I'd say take her, there are no surprises. If you show up to class and do the work you'll get a good grade. She can be intense but I think she just cares about what she teaches. The grading is really lenient, no tests, and you get 100% on the homework just for completing it.

Professor Delgado is amazing! Her lectures are so rewarding and engaging, probably some of the best in the History department. You can tell how much she cares about what she is teaching and her students. She is respected for a reason, and you will learn so much from this class. Its a lot of reading and papers but its manageable. 10//10 recommend!

Professor Delgado does give you a lot of readings to do, but if you fall behind, not reading every single article won't affect you on your essays. In total you have to write 5 essays with thorough and clear prompts which is very helpful. The TA's are amazing, and definitely participate because it is a big part of your grade.

This class is one of the most difficult GE requirements I have ever taken. For an introductory course you are reading hundreds of pages a week and then given a prompt that makes little to no sense. If you are taking zero other classes you might have enough time to complete everything this class. DON'T TAKE AS A GE TAKE SOMETHING ELSE.

Do not take Prof. Delgado's class. She assigns more work than my two upperdivs combined. If you are not already a latinx history expert, you will suffer. She'll fail you if you skip class 5 different textbooks with hundreds of pages assigned for reading every week. For those you have to write multiple 4 page response papers in the 2 hours classes.

You have to do a Response Paper every other week which is a big part of your grade, but during discussion sections you get to go over the readings with students and the TA which helps. At first, it was a little difficult for me to get adjusted to since it was a lot of readings per week but I was able to manage in the end. Great prof and amazing TA!
He was a great relaxed professor. Reading heavy class but little assignments besides short paragraphs and annotating text.
power trip prof 101

I felt like Professor Silver helps you get so much out of what you're reading in STEV1 and he is a very nice and cool teacher! That being said, you will have to read and reflect a lot, and it is extremely annotation-heavy. If you already have a heavy course load, it will get heavier-overall would definitely take again.

Kiva is a great guy, but the class itself is not for everyone. Extremely reading-heavy and required more work than my other classes. Weekly reading quizzes, but classes are mainly discussion-related. Being that this is a mandatory class, I'd recommend taking it with Kiva as he's at least a good professor.

Silver is definitely not an easy teacher, but he's super passionate and caring. Lectures were very engaging and helpful although very info packed. Highly recommend buying the books as you can bring them to the exam!
Very empathic and teaches the class well and has a strong passion for history

Prof. Silver is delightful! He is a super quirky and goofy professor who really loves teaching and cares for his students. Lectures are mandatory, but he makes them entertaining and interesting with plenty of humor and stories. Tests were a bit challenging, but they are open-note and open-book. Genuinely one of the coolest professors at UCSC.

I absolutely loved taking a class with Kiva this year and will make sure to do so again. His lectures were extremely captivating and so good that I would often forget to take notes because I just wanted to listen to the story. Do not hesitate to take History 70A or any of his other classes.

I took Kiva my first quarter and he was one of my favorite professors! Very passionate and willing to help out. I even took the hiking class which allowed me to understand the material we learned better. Overall an amazing professor!!

Very kind and passionate for a core class. Attendance is mandatory, but mostly conversations like the oral midterm option. Many office hours and easily reachable through email. Very empathetic and willing to extend or excuse assignments and give extra help whenever asked.

Kiva is a very engaging and compassionate professor, you can tell he cares about students and is passionate about the material. It is a challenging class, you do have to grind a bit because there is a lot of reading and writing due and three large research papers that come up quickly. Also attendance/participation is super important to him.

Kiva was very energetic during lecture, which always helped me pay attention even when I was bored. His tests are a little difficult, but if you actually do the reading you'll be fine. Overall a great professor, he's a really nice and approachable person. I'd love to take more classes with him.
Nice guy, and an engaging professor. Lots of notes and readings, some are very interesting some are boring. Attendance policy is a little strict so just make sure you go to almost every class.

Gives amazing lectures that are easy to understand, but it is a lot of information so be prepared to take a lot of notes. Attendance isn't mandatory but if you miss class often you won't do well. Accessible for office hours and answers emails quickly. A LOT OF READING. 1 midterm, 1 paper, 1 final, = 55% of grade. Cares for students.

Kiva is a very kind professor and goes the extra mile, but this class was intense. Created a good environment for students and attendance was mandatory with one excused absence. There were a lot of readings and assignments weekly with three major papers. He's very understanding, but you definitely have to work for the A.

there is weekly quizzes and a lot of reading. Professor Silver is really nice and is passionate about his material but the lecture slides are not useful at all, you have to listen to him talk and take notes on that or read the long chapter readings very carefully. It's do-able but it is a drag but he's really nice, just dont like history.

Dr. Silver's class is the best class I have taken. He is caring and the topics he chooses are fascinating. If you don't like reading literature, this may not be the best class for you, as one novel is assigned every week, but if you have an interest in the history of ideas, how they have impacted history, and like to read/write, take this class.

Professor Silver's class was really good if you enjoy France history. As a non history major taking this class for credit, you better be prepared to read. The midterms and finals are all based on readings, and the professor does not upload slides at all, so class was mandatory.

Professor Silver's lectures were interesting and engaging if you are interested in France. He doesn't upload lecture slides so you have attendance is mandatory. There were a LOT of reading, and they are important because the midterm, paper, and finals are consists of them.

I struggled my first quarter, and this class is the one that suffered the most, however, I would retake Prof. Silver, his lectures were long, but his energy was always high. There's one take-home midterm (written), one paper, and the in-class final. He was extremely helpful with my situation and super understanding.

(Taken for STEV 1) Prof is obviously knowledgeable about religion, but he's not a great fit for STEV 1. The course was more like a lecture than a discussion, with no room for student input. We had more tests/essays than other sections, and more than half the class never spoke. I learned a lot, but I wouldn't recommend him for this course.

Professor Deutsch was truly an amazing professor who clearly was passionate about the subject matter. I would definitely recommend taking this class if you want to learn more about the holocaust. Your grade consists of a take home midterm, paper, and a final exam very similar to the midterm. Everything is graded by your TA.
Most knowledgeable professor I have ever had! Very good at answering tough questions during class

This guy is incredibly, INCREDIBLY smart. I felt like I was in the presence of a sage of ancient historical knowledge. Genesis is a unique and utterly fascinating class, I loved it. The workload is fairly light and the exams were not unnecessarily difficult. I would highly recommend this class!

Probably the best professor I've ever had, honestly. If you are able to pay attention in lecture you will learn a lot, and he does a good job keeping it interesting. It was a good class and I left with a good understanding/newfound interest in the subject matter
i liked his class. really good lectures. course work seemed pretty straight forward. got a D in the class, i'm still not sure why
pay attention

He is an amazing, insightful professor. He invites a lot of student comments (which is good and bad). He's super nice and I think approached religious texts with respect and openness. We read bible pieces, merchant of venice, even The Road. Great variety and fascinating class.

Professor Deutsch is a brilliant lecturer, and I thoroughly enjoyed each class. He is infinitely knowledgeable on the subject matter and beyond, providing for a well rounded presentation of the texts. He makes himself very available, and is open to students' concerns. I highly recommend this class, for it has been a superb quarter.

He is brilliant and knows so much across many disciplines. He's also super nice and approachable and enjoys talking to his students. The only downside is that he often lets certain students ramble on too much. Overall, a great class with a wonderful smart and kind professor.

At every lecture I feel as though I'm being preached the wonders of Judaism. He can't seem to keep a coherent line of thought going and spends the majority of lectures asking questions that nobody can/will answer. He needs to go back to teaching American Studies and get out of classes in my major.

Extremely knowledgeable about the literature, and context in which it was written. The mini history lessons my be a little boring, but his charisma and  intelligence make me respect him. Also, he's kinda funny sometimes.

The best professor I've had at UCSC. She genuinely loves her field of work and teaching it to her students. It felt like we were being treated like her colleagues almost, she would joke around with us, make an effort to involve all of us in conversation, plus other awesome things like that. If you have a class with Kat, it's gonna be a banger.

Dr. Gutierrez is one of the best teachers I have had. She can have fun with discussions but keep an appropriate tone when the subject matter demands it, her lectures are informative and interactive, she actively responds to student feedback and tries to help you as best she can. Truly amazing.

Very caring professor who is super understanding and explains things very well. Her class was super interesting but the grades were very reliant on how you did on a multiple-part project with a partner. Picking your partner carefully is important and pay attention to the grading rubric.

Professor Gutierrez is by far my favourite professor that I've had so far. She creates engaging lectures for the class and, she's very passionate about the course material. The grading is pretty tough but fair and there are quite a few readings. All in all, I enjoyed the class and I would take it again.
khyifvlugblhik.

I loved Prof. Gutierrez! Her class was definitely more difficult than I had expected it to be, but if you do the assigned reading, you should be fine. She was super friendly and approachable, had a great classroom environment. Very open to feedback too! Overall she's been a fav professor of mine.

Dr. G is a great professor. She's clear about grading expectations, great lectures, and encourged class participation, but attendance is mandatory. There's 3 mini papers that were hard, but the written sourcebook for the final and a group project weren't bad. Probably not a class a non-history major'd want to take just to fulfill a requirement.

This class is very participation heavy, so be ready to share and present a lot. Overall she's been amazing and this class is a perfect union between the history of plants in SEA and regional Southeast Asian History. Classes were hybrid, so you only had to attend live lecture once a week. Readings were mostly short and definitely digestible.

One of the worst classes I've taken at ucsc. Thompson's lecture are fractured and unorganised and mostly consist of anecdotes and huge block quotes that he reads directly off the slides. Nearly every lecture he plays lengthy, history channel grade documentary clips. Why as a professor are you relying on cable tv documentaries to teach a course.
amazing professor, caring and kind
Goated history professor. He is super sweet and funny, has spent decades as a historian and has lots of great stories and cool information.

Favorite professor here at UCSC! Inspired me to become a history major. I attended office hours frequently, which really helped me get a better understanding of the material and helped with my essays. I recommend him if you want a history class that is actually interesting, even if your not a humanities major.
super nice and does a good job connecting with students, grade only based on 3 essays, relatively straight forward prompts, lecture heavy with information, lots of weekly readings

Prof Bruce is simply the best. He is hilarious and genuinely a BRILLIANT professor. He has so much knowledge and decades of experience in his field. He has lots of cool stories and interesting perspectives. I only wish lectures were longer than an hour. He has so much to say that class often felt rushed, and I only wanted to hear more from him.

Bruce is a very funny professor with little assigned work outside of 3 papers. Linda was also a great TA. Sometimes the lectures got boring and he focused more on the intellectual history of the war a bit too much, but otherwise he is a great professor for both upper and lower divs.

Very cool teacher, watched interesting holocaust films that taught me new perspectives. He's a very educated film critique but doesn't act entitled or posh. Your grade is based off 3 papers you write but as long as you watch all the movies and do at least 30% of the reading you'll be set. Overall really enjoyed the class and definitely recommend.

Professor Thompson is an extremely caring professor. He takes pride in what he is teaching and lectures very clearly concerning the films we watch in class. The class is graded off on three papers; however, the TAs in discussion break down how to write the papers effectively. All in all, a great professor!

Bruce was a great professor. Very engaging and he cares deeply about the material he is teaching. Easily one of the best professors I have had since coming to UCSC. I took his class LIT164D for a GE requirement, absolutely would try to find another class taught by him to fill my other requirements.

I'm nowhere near a history major, but I want to take all of his classes! He makes every aspect of class topics to be incredibly interesting! There was never a full day and class participation was incredibly high! Everyone I know who's taken one of his classes raves about his style of teaching and so do I. Papers were sometimes rough but manageable.

Professor Thompson is truly one of the best. His lectures are engaging and he makes even dry topics interesting. With the help of resources like unstuck AI, I aced the essays. Definitely take this class if you can!
Please don't take his classes.
He was the most depressing professor ever.

Bruce Thompson is my favorite professor I've had so far! He's so so funny and such a delight, he made a class about historical failures not depressing and actually super engaging! Put simply, he rocks.

I cannot begin to explain how much I adore Bruce Thompson! Not only is he an exceptional and intelligent professor, but he also makes his lectures so interesting and funny. My course wasn't difficult at all -- barely any homework and our assignments were all papers. Take one of his classes and please appreciate him for the little goofball he is!

Phenomenal professor. Kind caring and inspirational. You always hope to get a professor like this in college one that opens your eyes to new history and literature, and makes you passionate about exploring new things!
Professor Thompson was extremely nice throughout the quarter. There was not too much homework other than an essay. The course was only based on attendance, a midterm, an essay, and lastly the final.

He seems like he has a level of knowledge about the Renaissance and European exploration that is slightly higher than that of a high school student. Read a Wikipedia page and save yourself some time. Overall, Professor Thompson doesn't seem to be interested by the content of the course. Just read a book or listen to a Hardcore History.

Bruce Thompson is one of the best professors I've had so far at UCSC. He is a funny and engaging lecturer who clearly cares deeply about what he's teaching and enjoys it. He creates lively class discussions and assigns interesting readings for his class. His teaching will make you want to come to class every day.

Great professor and human. Love this guy. Was super lenient with me during a hard time in my life and talked about interesting topics that he was super passionate about. I wasn't the best student when I took him and I wish I had focused a bit more out of respect. Also, had (optional) field trips!!!

LOVE this man, I took HIS 82 and it was one of the easiest courses I've taken at UCSC. His lectures were super intriguing and the assignments were more than doable. Plenty of opportunities for extra credit and everything has an automatic one day extension. He was super understanding and caring towards his students. LOVE HIM!!

Aims is a sweetheart who is super passionate about the things he teaches. This was his first quarter at UCSC and on Zoom, and struggled a bit with that. But he was great in office hours, the grading was super lax. The final was a choice between a paper and an art project, and most of the grade was participation.

She's very passionate about what's she teaching and the class is pretty interesting, but as a non history major felt like a lot of work for what to me was a lower div GE. She's also really nice and the TA is a generous grader once you get past the first few weeks. The midterm and final aren't hard if you do the readings and attend lectures.

I was really excited to take a class with Dr. Sullivan because I've heard great things about her but this lower division class was impossibly hard. Dr. Sullivan seemed so focused on her students not using Chat GPT that I feel like she lost focus on the class learning. The exams were closed-note essays with less than an hour to complete :((

I will be blunt and say this class has killed any joy I had for the subject. What was supposed to be a fun GE class open to all majors has quickly become my most time-consuming class. This takes more time than both of my engineering classes combined, and the graders will go out of their way (their own admission) to dock points wherever they can.

This class has fascinating material but it's a lot of reading. It was maybe 100 pages of papers and old fiction per week. A lot of the material also isn't gone over in class. Lecture slides are more visual and supplementary to what she's saying out loud. Notes are posted but get ready to write quick. Again it is interesting but it's a lot of work.

Worse experience ever, don't take her for a GE, it's way more work than it's worth. Thought it was a cool class about Brendan Fraiser and the mummy but it was and I'm putting bluntly really boring for 60% of the time and borderline sexist for the other 40%. Also if you miss just a few lectures good luck cuz you already failed

I took the Curse of The Mummy Class the first time it was held. It was an upper-div. History/Literature hybrid course, but not a lot of students understood how much reading we had until later. The lectures were pretty interesting, but the assignments were very vague and you had to be creative. My TA was a gracious grader, so that helped.

class was really boring and non-engaging. Ended up ignoring/tuning her out for almost all lectures, just to get attendance credit. But of the 2 (this class was co-taught), Elaine was a lot nicer and more caring (helped me navigate CANVAS and make-up work for the time that I missed due to entering the course late).

Sullivan is a great teacher but this combo class doesn't really focus on her. When all the assignments are based on readings the actual history is more background. Her solo classes are better, especially her Cleo to Constantine class for actual Egyptian Ptolemaic history. Class itself isn't very interesting but I love Sullivan as a professor.

HIS 159M: I liked Sullivan's lectures. She's respected and highly knowledgeable. This class was combined with a literature class. The communication was disorganized, assignment expectations were unclear, and TAs would make up new assignments with nothing but a confusing and vague email to alert us. A class with only her as lecturer would be better.

Sullivan is professional, intelligent, and a truthfully fantastic lecturer. She truly cares about the student's improvement. She is kind but can come off as intimidating and slightly unapproachable. Will not round grades tho, I was .04 away from the A, she did not respond to my email. Regardless possibly one of UCSC's best professors.

Sullivan is an amazing professor and is one of the reasons I now want to focus in egyptology. her lectures are captivating, she is easily accessible through canvas or email, and the work wasn't too hard even though it covered a lot of subject material. She made the class actually fun :)

Professor Sullivan is such a kind and thoughtful professor. Her lectures are VERY interesting and really attentive to detail. She's very funny, too. As for the class, you won't really interact as much with her for grading (you will with your TA). There is a ton of reading but it was enjoyable reading. One of my favorite electives so far!

Sullivan is the best! Her classes are really interesting and well-structured. The grading criteria is very clear, so there's really no excuse not to do well. For a non-history major, this class might seem a little tough, but its definitely doable for anyone. 2 10pg papers and 2 tests, but again expectations are very clear.

Fantastic professor and very passionate about the subject. That being said, if you dont like egyptology, dont take an egyptology class. Very modern approach, gave us a VR tomb tour and had we the option to 3D reconstruct a temple for the final besides a typical paper. Im a ling major but kept up and will absolutely be taking another of her classes.

Professor is a great lecturer, very charismatic and friendly. Class has alot of obscure, difficult Egyptology reading. I got tired of wading through it about 6 weeks into the quarter. Found the class difficult due to my lack of enthusiasm about the topic and the archaeological approaches. Has a mid-term, plus a long 10 page research paper.

Absolutely amazing professor! I took her class as a GE, but I learned so much and became very passionate on what she was teaching. There was lots of reading, but it was all very engaging. She's able to explain things very clearly and doesn't overcomplicate ideas and concepts. It was a work intensive class, but completely worth it!
Professor Sullivan is a great teacher - a lot of reading but worth it if you are into history and take the subject seriously. Very helpful and always available outside of class for extra help.

Elaine is a great professor and super helpful. It's refreshing to have someone younger in the ancient history department who helps introduce new approaches to archaeology and history. Highly recommend.

I was really excited for this class, but it has been the most boring class I have ever taken at UCSC. She read from a script the whole time and it was really hard to even understand what it was that we were supposed to even be learning.
Horrible experience with this class. It was just busy work and boring lectures.

I love prof. Aso! She's super welcoming and approachable, easy to ask for help or clarification. 3 essays and mandatory section, plus a lot of reading, yet it's still manageable for an UD history class. Super interesting lectures. Would def take one of her classes again!
I wasn't a fan of the lectures, they could be difficult to follow at times. Overall, though, the content was decently interesting, and the assignments were simple.

The lectures were fun and interesting. Sections were mandatory, and you were only graded on 3 quizzes, 3 essays, and a few source analysis sheets. Very easy class as long as you pay attention to the readings each week.

Professor Aso is a super sweet professor and she's really accommodating! During the storms she made sure to rearrange deadlines and assignments as well as canceling class and recording the lecture instead. She is super nice to talk to and really encouraging. Her lectures and powerpoints were really well organized and made it easy to take notes.

Noriko Aso is a very sweet lady, but her lectures are very boring. She doesn't make the lectures engaging and just reads off of the slides and her outline. Not to mention, the lectures are unorganized and lack any structure. Class consists of 4 essays and weekly annotations, which are pretty easy. Its not a difficult class, just very boring.

Prof Noriko was great! The only thing is that sometimes lectures weren't posted on time or were very long, so plan ahead. The only part of this class I didn't like was my TA, Wilson. He was a harsh grader and expected you to have a background on historical things that didn't relate directly to Asia. Make sure to go to office hours if you have him.
this woman is so sweet i love her so much be nice to her

Great professor, very knowledegeable and happy to help students. Assignments were never too much for one week and especially on zoom I felt it was very manageable. Grade consisted of a few 3 page papers and a 6 page final essay.

Noriko is the best! Im doing womens studies in East Asian history and she has been such a helpful mentor. Caring, kind and intelligent. The class was simple to follow and not difficult. However you learn so much. Noriko really proves that you dont need a lot of work to learn. Definitely take her!

Professor Aso is such a sweetheart. The readings were often just out of my comfort zone in theory/tone but lectures and online discussions helped clarify my understanding quite a bit. This class is incredibly interesting, I learned a lot from it. Grading is clear, 1 small paper, 1 big paper, weekly posts, and a group project. Totally doable!

Professor Aso is a sweetheart and it is easy to see why she gets a high level of respect from students. The class consisted of 3 main essays and 5 1-page outlines. The readings are not the worst if you just read the main points but if you are not a big reader, I highly recommend attending all of the lectures because for better guidance on the essay

Noriko is one of the nicest professors I have had at UCSC! She genuinely cares for her students and the homework is not that bad. She also gives second chances. When I bombed my essay, she gave me some advice and let me retake it!
7 out 10  not enough assignments

Professor Aso is a very sweet, understanding and helpful woman when you get a chance to actually talk to her. Lecture can be boring if you're not completely into Japanese history but if you are then it shouldn't be a problem. She's extremely knowledgable and can be unintentionally funny at times. You can easily get an A if you put in the effort.

She is nice but I believe she's not a  good lecturer. I have trouble paying attention to a person who says uh, oh, um.. Alot! And she takes forever to get her point across! She takes random attendance!
SO BORING. she may be cute and nice but she's not a good teacher. not worth the easy A, take something else.
Very knowledgable professor. Very helpful. Very fair. Very cute.
Noriko Aso is kind of soft-spoken, but knows her stuff and is also quite friendly and adorable.

If you need help she is willing to help. Nice and keeps the lectures interesting. There was a ton of reading set for this class and we only had 2 essays. Your grade in this class will depend on the effort you put into it. Its not hard but there will always be READING. She says ummm alot which kept me awake in class.
This was a great class and she was one of my favorite professors at UC Santa Cruz

If you're trying to get you AH&I GE out of the way, I would fs recommend HIS10A. The class is easy peasy-she gives you the possible midterm/final questions (all of which are essays/short-answer responses) and they do actually appear on the test, & homework minimal. The lectures are pretty boring and attendance is mandatory, but otherwise it's chill

I am a computer science major. Chose this class for GE. 
During finals week I tried to looked up more history classes from Professor Jones to take. She makes the mundane subjects interesting and story-like. My heart always feels warm during class, her passion in history and teaching is infectious.
This class is easily my fav of all time.

She is super stingy about attendance and being late to class despite her lectures being quite boring. The Sections are online making it really hard to engage in any meaningful way also asked her to round my grade that was less than 1 percent away and she refused would not reccomend.

Basically lectures for the entire class every class which can get stale. She is also quite stingy about attendance as she knows if it wasn't mandatory nobody would come (she will not mark you present if you are quite late). A few short papers, the exam and the weekly quizzes are the only things that are graded.

Really good lectures, and the class is graded pretty leniently. There's only two essays, a few question/response papers, and a weekly quiz on lecture material and readings. If you actually do the readings (I did!), it shouldn't take more than 3 hours a week. The class is very broad, not deep, so its hard to get bored unless you hate history.

Professor Jones is an amazing lecturer who is clearly very passionate about history! Lecture is mandatory but you can email her if you can't attend; she is understanding. This class is a lot of work, but generally the assignments don't take too long and extensions are easy to get. Very engaging lectures and readings and a forgiving grading policy.

This class is a waste of time. She makes attendance mandatory knowing that if she didn't she would be lecturing to an empty class. She says she wants everyone to be engaged and get the most out of our time together, but all she does is lecture. She bombards you with writing assignments since there is nothing better to do, making it time consuming.

Professor Jones is a great, she cares about the material that teaches is understanding. The assignments are fair and help you learn. There are essays that you have to write but if you pay attention to the reading and engage with the class you should do fine.

Prof. Jones is extremely knowledgeable and does a fantastic job making rather dense readings/material understandable. Their lectures can be rather daunting and can feel rushed towards the end, buts its definitely in your self interest to attend every class and engage every reading. 10/10 would take a class with her again. Shes also very organized.

I've heard she's beyond amazing for her other classes, but this one sucked. There was a ton of homework and busy work and in the end, I don't really understood the purpose of the class. Almost everyone I talked to had no idea what was going on throughout the course and it was so miserable to go to. But she's really nice and always accessible.
There was a lot of reading and busy work for the class. But if you don't mind reading it was very manageable and Professor Jones is super approachable.

Jones is one of my favorite history lecturers! She is makes the class really interested, is very knowledgable about what she is teaching, and always highlights the importance of what she's teaching and why it matters to the class. Overall a great professor and person, expects student to turn in work on time and to try doing well in her class.

Professor Jones is the best lecturer I've had so far in college. Her history 10A class isn't just names and dates, she covers broader themes and questions about why things happened and their impacts today. Don't miss out on an opportunity to learn from her!

Great professor, great lectures, reading isn't so bad (4 books, 5 essays) Show up to lectures and you'll pass. I took AP US History in high school, but decided to take this class for the maj. requirement. Great class as not only a review, but definitely to understand US history more in depth. Never regretted taking this class. TAKE THE CLASS.

Dr. Jones is a class act. Im a Chemistry Major, so History isn't really my forte. Class was still interesting, she tried her hardest to compensate with the shortened class times. PROS: Cares; a lot Not hard to pass if you at least try to do everything Interesting topics Cons: Lots of assigned reading Generalized essay grading
Mandatory attendance, assigns a 5 page paper that we only had a weekend to do. If you're working a side job and have other homework intensive classes, good luck.

Professor Jones is hands down one of the best teachers at UCSC. She is SO smart, funny and man, she pushes you more than any teacher! A LOT of work, not easy class, but her teaching, helpfulness and passion for what she does makes this class WORTH your money. She's the best, and will challenge you to do your best. Great teacher.
Jones is a great professor but is a tough grader. The TA was not much help for the final take home exam. Rather than having helpful discussions, we just sat there in silence.

She is such a lovely professor. The books were all interesting, but some of the articles were a little dense or dry. She is super understanding and very easy to talk to. She organized lectures in a pretty effective way. Overall, she's an awesome prof that hist people should take at some point. You do a lot better than you think if you participate.

I have had her twice and hope to have her as much as possible during my time at ucsc.  she is the most inspirational teacher/professor/lecturer I have ever met.  She wants all her students to do well and has a never ending supply of knowledge to offer them.  I cannot emphasize how much I love her!!!

I've taken HAVC 44, 143E, and 143G with professor Narath, he's my favorite professor that I've had at UCSC. You won't regret taking any of his classes, he has the most passion I've ever seen in a teacher, he's quite silly, and he really dives deep into any topic he's discussing, if you're at all interested in architecture or design- take his class!

So good and so enjoyable. Prof Narath is super lovely and understanding. The class comprises of three homework assignments, three tests, and a good amount of sentence-long reading responses. all very easy if you come to class and take notes.
Incredible professor, grading relies heavily on your TA but the guidelines are loose and creative if you're into that. No section, essays make up 100% of the grade.

I took this course remotely. He used recorded lectures from a past quarter, but they were completely sufficient to each us everything we needed for the assignments and tests. The midterm and final were all writing but not very difficult as long as you took good notes during lectures. Definitely a passionate teacher and an interesting course.
No complaints, Albert is the best. If you get into one of his classes count yourself lucky cuz they fill up fast. He made me switch majors to HAVC!

Professor Narath is just amazing with his lectures, they are heavy in content but very interesting if you enjoy architecture. I recommend taking notes since his exams are based on the lectures as well as readings (though readings aren't required but will help you with exams). I loved his lectures and I could definitely say he's a great professor!

Albert Narath is my all time favorite professor. This is the 2nd class I've taken with him. If you're thinking of taking a class with him, do it! Also the readings are not strictly necessary, tho they are interesting. You can skim them or just find the relevant readings for the take home midterm and final when you get the prompt (I barely read) <3

Professor Narath is one of the best professors I have ever had at UCSC. He is funny, kind, and makes such interesting presentations.
