The lectures are 100% pictures with very few words so attending lectures is necessary for context. He is very accommodating so if you need help just talk to him. Overall an amazing class I highly recommend.

Professor Narath is a very funny and kind professor who really just likes presenting information to students through his lectures. No textbook, just readings he provides to help enforce the lessons from each lecture. Notes during lecture are necessary, and he provides lectures online after the class with power points and recordings.

Professor Narath loves to lecture. Be aware of taking notes during lecture as you will have to refer back to them for discussions, midterm and final. His lecture style he continues with little pause so it can get confusing when he is talking about something important. Assignments are weekly discussions, midterm and final with three SAQ

One of my favorite classes I've taken so far. He single handedly made me question my major, such an incredible teacher and lecturer! His lectures flow in such an incredible way and I always describe this class as "what learning is meant to feel like". Seriously take this class if you can, its not very difficult but so engaging and enriching.

I've taken multiple classes with Professor Narath and they are the BEST. He lectures on really niche stuff, and everything he talks about is interesting and unique. Classes are pretty easy with a few short assignments throughout the quarter and a take-home final. 11/10!

Albert is my all-time favorite teacher. I would literally listen to him talk about paint drying bc he would make it fascinating. He's incredibly passionate about architecture and design, and his enthusiasm makes everything he covers interesting and engaging. His lectures always have a well-crafted narrative and cover cool topics. He's the best.
Definitely would take again. Prof. Narath is really interested and excited about his subject matter, which made me excited about it too. He gives fun assignments, and is all around a good professor.

Albert is really a king, tbh. He inspired me to study architecture and look at my built environment in a new, exciting way. He goes fast in lecture but you can always take away the major points. Assignments are easy and not boring, just be sure to cross-reference often. Readings are mandatory for section but very interesting and enlightening.

Great professor! Lectures are great and he is obviously passionate about the subject matter. I always regretted even being 10 minutes late, you'd miss out on valuable information or even a short video. Grades are based 4 short writing assignments + midterm + final that are all solely based on topics discussed in lecture as well as in the discussion

He made me want to give up my major and become an architectural historian. Truly made my every day life a little bit more interesting with a better understanding of architecture. Fantastic class that told a fascinating narrative. Assignments are fun and easy. This is what a college class should be like!
Albert Narath is the best.

Professor Narath is without a doubt the best professor I've hard in college. Not only are his lectures incredibly interesting but he has a deep connection with the material that shows in how he speaks. I've taken three classes with him and will continue to take as many as I can. Could not speak highly enough about Prof. Narath.

Narath: easily the best teacher I've ever had. Dido his class Designing California. Dude's ideas are so unique and his passion is infectious. Furthermore, the way in which he presents the material is just wow... The class has a narrative arc and feels more like a David Lean epic than a class. No doubt he'll be on the nyt bestseller list by 2030.

Professor Reiterman has become one of my favorite professors at UCSC. She truly has a passion for the classes she teaches and actually cares about the success of the students. The classes are not overly difficult either, there is a decent amount of reading and work but most of it is fairly easy and enjoyable. 100% recommend any class taught by her.
Great lectures. Sets clear expectations and is an organized class. Just go to lectures and do the readings and you'll be fine. Feedback was helpful and I could tell they wanted me to succeed :)

Probably the best professor I've had at UCSC. She gives really interesting lectures, sets clear expectations, and clearly cares about the success of her students. I really enjoyed this class, it was challenging but not stressful, and she creates a very welcoming lecture environment.

You will do well as long as you go to class and do the readings!
Really nice and passionate about what she teaches

Kailani had really interesting asynchronous lectures, but they tended to be a bit long and rambling. I didn't go to a lot of the optional discussions but the ones I did were super helpful with the essays, quizzes and finals. There were 4 quizzes (timed, short answer), 2 essays, and the final was to revise and expand one of the essays. Good class
I learned a lot even tho I was not familiar with the topic at all before taking this class. Prof is really kind and gave me an extension when I really need it. Glad I took this class

prof furtado had amazing lectures every week! the lecture were dense and sometimes hard to follow BUT I feel like I learned so much about oceanic art. There was a lot of reading for the class but she's willing to break down the articles and films if you ask her during office hours. Participating is important so you can't miss class

A really kind person, but a terrible professor. Her class was interesting however, her instructions are usually very vague and missing even 1 assignment can bring your grade down a lot. Don't think you will be able to learn from mistakes in this class as you won't get grades back until the next assignment is already due. DON'T TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!!
She is super open to office hours and showing the class new concepts. She also provides really good structure to the essays, it helps me feel prepared to write them. She also gives great feedback!

I liked this class. There was a lot of reading for a class that I took for GE but it's honestly not that bad. There's not a lot of assignments so make sure you turn everything in because if you just miss one thing (like me) it will bring your grade down by a lot. There are sometimes in-class activities that are on paper so be sure to come to class.

I don't know if it was because of my TA or the professor herself, but grading is very sloppy. Nothing is submitted into the grade book except two papers and if you didn't do well on those, you're screwed. Very harsh grader and there were no opportunities for feedback on papers before submission.

Encouraged students to do the readings every week, asked students for their opinions about readings. Lecture heavy and attendance is mandatory, but the lectures were very interesting to hear as an art major. Would take again.

Personally I would not take this class or professor again. Every assignment was complete/incomplete except I think the midterm, final, and maybe one other assignment which made your grade entirely essay based. Her lectures were always disorganized and the students were never engaged. Homework was easy and I didn't do any of the assigned reading.

Incredibly boring lecture/professor, which is unfortunate since the content is pretty interesting. Grading was never clear since assignments are complete/not complete but tests are graded by points. My TA was completely unreachable which was annoying. You can find a better class for GE credit.

Professor Wasserman is very passionate about what she is teaching, but her lectures were disorganized and didn't make much sense. There is a lot of required reading, and some of them are very long (anywhere from 30 to 100 pages), and it seemed like not many people did the reading because of this. I did, however, enjoy the material we learned about.

Prof. Wasserman has a monotone attitude but her heart is in the right place. Lectures are not rehearsed, they seem to cover whatever is on her mind #adlib. The content is not substantial nor dissimilar to middle school history class (students are not engaged, she clapped at us today lol). Weekly async assignments are easy but boring.

HAVC 48 is the same as the climate justice class, idk why they're separate on here. He is so sweet and genuinely cares about what he lectures on. Only four quizzes and two papers. Befriending your TA will get you far. Explains everything well, and provides you lots of material to get you thinking about the climate and climate justice.

Professor Demos is one of the smartest professors I have come across. He really knows whats he's doing! All he cares about is teaching us important topics and expanding our knowledge on the world around us. You are expected to complete four online quizzes and two essays. I am a humanities major and I loved this class! The TA's were amazing
Great professor, class was very manageable four quizzes that were online and two essays. Very nice guy

Professor Demos' passion for his field absolutely translates into his lectures, and I found the content very fascinating. If you take this class, go to lecture! Lecture was crucial for comprehending readings and I never regretted attending. Four short quizzes and two essays, my TA was very kind and a gentle grader. I recommend Professor Demos :)!
Awesome. Really inspirational professor. Calming lectures with a very inclusive and family like-minded spirit. I felt welcomed and my opinions were encouraged.
Amazing!

I took his asynch climate justice class fall quarter 2020, remote. His lectures were droning at times, but they were still interesting, especially if you enjoy learning about environmental justice and human rights. My TA was really nice and clear in what she wanted from our essays (2). Overall I recommend the class. I bet its better in person.

His lectures were really interesting, and you could tell how passionate he is about what he teaches about. The TAs grade kinda tough on the papers, but the extra credit should be able to balance it out.
I never actually got to talk to him, it was an asynchronous class. He seems very passionate and knowledgeable about climate justice, which made the class enjoyable

His lectures are very boring and there are two 1.5-hour lectures every week. You have to go to section but otherwise it was four 5-question quizzes and two papers. Easy A but it doesn't count for anything and was not as interesting as I hoped.

He's really passionate about climate justice, lectures are very entertaining but he is very soft-spoken so you might want to fall asleep. He does have quizzes but you can retake them at the end of the quarter. As long as you pay attention to lectures and skim the readings, the essays and quizzes shouldn't be hard.

The professor gives interesting lectures and you can really see that he is passionate about what he is teaching. Discussions were facilitated well and opposing opinions were always welcome, making the space feel really inclusive. Work load was not bad at all either so I felt confident in getting a good grade and just enjoying the class

Only got the courage to say this a year after, but I have to speak my truth. He has been telling his classes twisted and baseless propaganda on the Middle East conflict that demonizes Israel. He put me down when I tried to speak from my own experience and stand up for my heritage. He and his TA made me feel unsafe, uncomfortable, and unheard.

Not respected by anyone in the CARE office or Title IX. An ego the size of the moon got in the way of most of his lectures, which feel like Vox or Vice articles without any jokes -- and twice as many redundant adjectives. Only 4 essays but you have to sign in daily. Good luck sitting through this man blowing hot air over a bored crowd for 2+ hours.

Umm what happened to the hot chili letting students know if their professor is hot or not?! This guy is a silver fox. He is very smart and it's sometimes hard to take notes on his dense run-on sentences but all-in-all very interesting class and lecture. We are lucky to have him at UCSC!

Overall this was an interesting class that wasn't difficult. We covered different forms of art activism across the globe. Sometimes TJ's lectures were hard to follow or too complex, and he lacked clarification on assignments. But there were only two papers and four pop quizzes. As long as you take notes and talk to your TA if needed you will pass.

I really like this guy. I think he's new to UCSC. This class had only 2 papers and the majority of your grade comes from pop quizzes on the readings. But it's pretty clear when those quizzes are going to be (roughly every 2 weeks). He is really passionate about the subject (Climate Justice) and I enjoyed his lectures. Also offers extra credit.
If you want to learn political theory, this is the place!
She's very passionate and knowledgeable on course material. DO NOT take if you need a GE fulfilled. Fun class if you're into philosophy.

I took HISC 20 for ge. Not as bad as many people say, I didn't do most of the readings. It was easy and not tricky if you went to the mandatory lectures and took notes; lectures were recorded.The books she required were all online. There were 4 "weekly" assignments, a midterm essay, and a final that just asked questions talked about in lecture.

Dr Bargu is passionate in her subject, but it is really hard to follow her when you're taking this class for a GE credit. It's a very expensive class, frequently bought books instead of food, but thats not the case for all, I just had a tough quarter. If you love history and philosophy, I highly recommend. Not for those looking to fulfill a GE.

I took HISC 20 as a GE requirement, this class was AWFUL. She did NOT follow the syllabus at all; we were supposed to have 7 writing assignments, a midterm, and a final exam and we only had two writing assignments and our midterm in the grade book by WEEK 7. She rambles for the entire lecture time and there is 0 structure to the course. Stay away.
She talks a lot.
Lots of reading!! However I love the content and although difficult at times, the instruction is made for you to struggle with the text first. Love Prof Bargu

If you are planning on taking this class for a GE, do not do it. The professor is nice but unsympathetic to student issues and didn't provide access to lecture slides or recordings which was very frustrating because of the awkward lecture time. They were also not communicative about expectations for the final or midterm which were 80% of grades.

Prof. Bargu's class was very interesting and thought provoking, however, tons of reading. Get ready to read and write, but if you do it properly you will walk out of her class much more equipped to read and write about theory.

This class is a lot of reading. It's not easy, but he knows that. The lectures are engaging and often profound. I can understand why someone wouldn't like this class, but I think it's the best that I've ever taken. Once a week there is a 2 page reading reflection due and a 10 page paper at the end. For me, it was worth it to stick out the challenge
Politics of recognition is so dope.

I took Politics of Rel & 105D. His lectures are almost impossible to understand! It seems like he can't bring his thinking down to a level that students can comprehend. I did the reading, but he made it hard to differentiate between his thoughts & what the reading was actually putting forward. Genius, maybe, but needs to simplify/clarify lectures

I am taking Karen's Science and Feminism class as a Feminist Studies major and it's not great. I would maybe recommend this class if you're a STEM major but man is it unfulfilling if you were coming to it expecting a Feminist Studies class. It is basically a science class which is not why I came to college personally.

Karen Barad is one of my favorite professors so far. She's funny, smart, and she's honest. Her lectures were amazing to listen to, and she's just so upfront about who she is and what she thinks. Her readings were really heavy, but to be fair her FMST 30 class is her baby. She's the reason it exists. Take her class if you can!

Karen is very passionate about her subject. She has done a lot of work in the field of feminism and science, and she seems to be respected. However, there is a lot of reading, a lot of which is hard to get through. There's a lot of tedious required writing. Section and lecture are both mandatory

This course left out real world connections while attempting to teach complex, dense theory which left me confused. I'm not really sure what I learned in this class other than the names of different theories and theorists. I wouldn't recommend taking this class unless it's a requirement for your major. This class had so much potential.

This could have been a great class. Instructions and grading criteria for midtermfinalpapers were not clear at all. First two months of class we had no assignments but then had a paper, a midterm assigned the day we submitted that paper, a paper assigned the day we returned the midterm, and final assigned the day we turned in that paper. Why.

While registering for the course there are no prerequisites listed but the first day of class Barad said that it would be hard to pass without a strong background in feminist studies, wish I had known prior. Reading was overwhelming and there were no written assignments until the last 6 weeks of the quarter and everything piled up.

This class was not easy to understand, the concepts Barad uses are difficult and to my point of view, pointless. She is VERY knowledgeable about her work, very nice, and approachable. I took this class for the GE requirement, I ended up passing it with an A-. We did two papers, THAT'S IT. It was about your techno scientific object (POINTLESS)!

Professor Barad is very knowledgable and passionate about feminist science studies. Don't expect it to be easy; the concepts are very difficult but Karen is very patient and happy to re-explain things multiple times.  You do learn some quantum physics, but I had never taken physics and it was fine! The TA Alexis is wonderful as well.

I still don't even know what this class was about and I went to every lecture. All we did in every lecture was re read the reading that was already supposed to have been read. She is funny occasionally but tried to take on to much within the class.

All I can say is that what I learned from the class seems like a total waste of time. The prof. wasn't even the one who graded the papers. I put a considerable amount of effort into the class but the topic itself still seemed confusing, especially if you have to write a paper about it. The prof. isn't even an efficient person in returning papers.

This was an interesting class, but I think too much material was covered in a short time span. I definitely felt rushed writing the final paper, considering the fact that I understood the gist of everything towards the last week of class. I wished I knew more about "how" to write the paper (that "A-ha" moment) earlier.

Interesting class. Karen made things really interesting the first 5 weeks but the second half of the class focused a lot on Bohr's quantum physics (which she tries really hard to simplify but it's still very philosophical). Overall very interesting class, not many assignments (and ones given were interesting). I would recommend taking this class.

This class was surprisingly more interesting than I thought it would be. Karen makes lecture really interesting and worth the time. She is very generous with her time, and is exceedingly patient. I struggled through some things during the course, but in the end, I totally loved it! I wish I had time to take more courses from her.

Not the best professor. Her class was supposed to be topical but it was incomprehensible unless you knew Copenhagen  physics. She is knowledgeable about her subject, but not very good at communicating it, unless you know a lot of background information about science.. Project was really lame and I didn't learn anything. Wouldn't recommend her class

I really liked this class AFTER I had taken it. While in it I didn't think much of it and just thought it was incredibly hard. Thinking back I am sure that this was the most aspiring class I have taken at UCSC and it made me change the way I think.

Karen is definitely the best teacher I have had at UCSC.  She is clear, kind and brilliant.  She will challenge you in every way possible, and change the way you see the world.  Take her 80class 1st if possible--it is a helpful foundation.  Her seminars are incredible, but go in with an open mind and expect to work hard. Can't speak highly enough!

fmst 133-tries to do to much work in a quarter system. if u take her class she is going to work u over ur limit. this could b a good thing not when u have 2 other upper divs. but it depends on what u like. she is approachable. def needs to teach in semester system

Karen is really truly awesome, one of the best professors I've had.  She's clear, engaging, and will demand that you question every comfortable convention you fall back on.  She will make you think and work damn hard (the quarter-long research project is demanding) but the material she covers and the results are worth every bit of the challenge.
Karen is an amazing professor -- intelligent yet accessible. Her syllabus was fast-paced and interesting. I only wish more students had taken advantage of her knowledge.

Professor Winther may be my favorite professor I have had at UCSC. Even though his writing assignments are in short form, he leaves a TON of feedback which really helped me improve as a writer. I hate online classes, but I found his lectures engaging and insightful. Overall, he is a quirky guy who is incredibly passionate about what he teaches.

Professor Winther is very passionate about the classes he teaches and it shows. He wants his students to learn and understand but continuously lectures on very difficult topics. There are very few assignment (all of which are writing) and he is a hard grader. It almost seems like nothing is ever good enough for him which was frustrating.

I think he had a fun time teaching this class, which made it fun for us. He's a cool guy that really cares about what he is teaching. Lots of reading and our only assignments were writing. He seems like a tough grader, but once you figure out what he is looking for it gets easier. I really had a good time in this class!

Maybe the worst professor I've ever had. The class was supposedly about a philosophical understanding of the ocean. There was never any philosophy, and it was all about him preaching about the end of the world due to environmental collapse. No critique of anything whatsoever. I felt I was in a cult or in a middle school class.

Loved Rasmus, he was genuinely a great and passionate lecturer. Super energetic and provides some of the best feedback on papers ever. He does require a lot of readings and you are expected to understand them thoroughly, however, he lets you rework on assignments until you are satisfied with your grade which can definitely help!

Probably the worst professor I've ever had. He is rude, disrespectful, and conceded. He treats his students like they're ignorant and accuses them of not caring about school. He's extremely unorganized and not great at lecturing. Avoid him if you can! He has extremely high expectations but does not do the work himself.

Great professor. Extremely involved in class and students and rereads the readings when the class does. Cares about his students and does his best to get everyone interested and involved during class. Great group of TA's as well. Overall an intellectually fun class.

In his class you will realize that readings don't matter. In class, students are expected to teach the class instead of him. He frankly said that he has never done the readings and the most sad part is that the students that never done the readings but understand the concept superficially end up dominating discussions. The class is not punctual.

He is very clearly into philosophy in a way that makes all his lectures engaging.  His choice of books and class structure may be atypical but definitely preferable.  The textbook for the course is useful as the tools provide an outline for thinking logically while the other books show philosophy in unlikely places and apply tools. Would recommend.

Took for TA. Very enthusiastic about philosophy. Tends to go down rabbit holes. Rarely stays on topic. Loves talking. Sometimes late to class.  4 books to read throughout the quarter one of which is 100pgs long. 2 midterms, 1 group project, no final. As long as you can think and have decent writing skills, you should be fine.

Possibly the worst teacher I've ever had. His lectures are all irrelevant to the course he's teaching and he assigns reading without ever going over it. Out of the 4 books assigned, only two of them had to do with Philosophy.  If you're looking for a class on Maps, Environmentalism, and geology, look no further. Skip it if you want philosophy.

A good professor who really cares about what he is teaching. He is always  willing to answer questions. He was never late or unprepared. Loves to have class discussions, and may call on random students. He assigns a lot of reading, and you need to do it to get a good grade. Go to lecture and section and you will learn a lot. Tests aren't bad.

Rasmus really knows what he is talking about and clearly has a strong passion for the subject. He really wants students to learn the material and teaches the class with a very modern perspective. He is extremely helpful during office hours. There is a lot of assigned reading but its worth it. The midterm is easy and there isn't a final. Great class

Great professor, super interesting class. He assigns a lot of reading and a lot of it is pretty important if you want to do well. Attendance is mandatory and he doesn't allow any electronics in class but it's because he genuinely cares and wants people to be there and learn.

Took for TA GE. Class was for the most part easy. Thought material would be on famous philosopher's  ideas (Plato, Aristotle, etc.) but it wasn't. A couple of short essays and take home midterm (no final) which were easy. Only part I disliked was that attendance was mandatory and he picked on people randomly to talk in lecture.
If you take Professor Winther's classes and do the reading and put in effort, you will be rewarded in many ways.

Great professor. Took his intro class to complete a GE, and now I want to take every class he teaches. He's a lot of fun and works hard to make sure all students get engaged in lecture. Little to no homework besides the extensive reading (which I never did). Midterm is take home and final is a group project. Easy & fun class with a great professor!
One of my favorite professors at UCSC, very devoted and engaged with his students, he's neither pedantic nor patronizing, and he makes such an effort to get the class to understand  his points.
Attendance is mandatory ( don't miss 3 classes), but it's totally worth it. Definitely my favorite and most intellectually stimulating class this quarter.

Rasmus is a good teacher. He is very enthusiastic about the subject matter and gets excited when someone brings up a good point or idea. His lectures are interactive and he lets others participate instead of just him talking. I didn't do any of the readings for the sake of time and disinterest, but did well on the midterm and hopefully in the class

Yamamoto-sensei is one of the best professors/teachers I've ever had period. It's very obvious she loves teaching Japanese to us. Yes, there is a lot of bookwork and assignments, but it's a given since we only have 10 weeks to learn. I would, without a doubt, take a class of hers again. She doesn't ever make you feel stupid or judged.

Yamamoto is a very kind and effective professor. The subject material is tough, but lecture activities are very helpful and the homework is not busywork.  She gives very good, personalized feedback on assignments, quizzes, and tests.  The textbook is required but it is cheap, and is used for JAPN 1,2, and 3.  I highly recommend Japanese with her.

She's one of the kindest professors I've had at UCSC. Grading is very generous and straightforward. Class is fun and she makes it easy to make friends. I had so much fun learning Japanese. She gives good feedback for improving speaking and writing. I would highly recommend anyone to take her class if they can. It was such a great experience.

Professor Yamamoto is great! I always try to get in her classes for japanese. The class is structured well which I love because it's always the same homework and quiz routine. She's not too tough of a grader and the homework is easy and enjoyable. The quizzes in JAPN2 are a bit tougher than JAPN1 but still manageable. She's a super fun teacher.
Good teacher and fun class with interesting material there is a lot of quizzes but they are 6 questions and worth 6 points plus they aren't very hard.

Take her class! Homework and quizzes/exams are easy if you pay attention in class. Very nice grader! She won't minus the whole point when you got a Japanese letter wrong in a sentence. And if someone misses the class, she will make an extra office hour for those guys. Nice person! I will ABSOLUTELY take her class again!!!

Yamamoto-sensei is a great teacher, but she makes you work for your grade. The language is inherently difficult and the assignments take a while to do, but if you're interested in Japanese, you'll love the class.

I love Sensei Yamamoto!! I'm taking this intro to Japanese class with her for my final quarter here at UCSC, and it's every thing I'd hoped for. Yamamoto is super caring about her students, and actually hopes for our success. She's super passionate, and makes learning Japanese a fun and laidback experience! 10/10 would recommend

Kind, caring, funny, and always willing to help students. Great for students who are fans of Japanese history, art, or pop culture, as well as wanting to learn a beautiful language. Easy homework, easy midterms, class participation matters. Speak up!
Yamamoto-Sensei is an amazing teacher! She's very charismatic and funny, and she makes it very easy to learn through her repetition of important concepts. Take her class, you will not regret it.

It's been some years since my last class with Yamamoto. I'm coming up on my 3rd year of living in Japan, and I'm spoiled with awe and praise for my fluency. Thanks to her. I'm now a language teacher too, and knowing the discipline intimately from both sides, I can say she knows damn well what she's doing. If you want to learn Japanese, take her.

Oh my god TAKE HER CLASSES! Yamamoto sensei is the best there is! She is very clear, concise, and fun in her teaching style. She's very approachable and goes out of her way to make sure you understand the material. I took her class after a year's break from japanese, and she made the transition as easy as possible. Absolutely wonderful lady!

This is one awesome professor. Sensei was so helpful for my first two quarters of Japanese. She is funny when she needs to be, but still cracks down. Because of her I want to pursue a language studies major in Japanese. Definitely recommend her!

The absolute best!  She is like the revered mother of language instruction. So helpful in simplifying a tough language. She stresses correct pronunciation in addition to cultural and social tact when addressing native Japanese.  The class is extremely difficult, because the language innately harbors that obstacle to new speakers; Sensee succeeds

Very good teacher....reminds me a bit of a toned down, older Fujita-sensei. She can be a little unclear on some things, but she makes herself readily available to her students in case they need help. Really kind-hearted and sweet lady...it's a shame she's not a full-time teacher.

I really, really enjoyed Yamamoto-sensei's class. It was the first Japanese class I took at UCSC, and she was very helpful and clear. I learned a lot by paying attention and following her instructions, so don't take Japanese (or any language!) if you don't plan to work hard. Very rewarding class with an amazing professor.
easy!! knows how to teach!! and know her material

Yamamoto-sensei was an absolutely awesome teacher.  She's quirky in a fun, exciting sort of way. She's been known to stand on desks, bring strange props to class, and give out awesome stickers. I always found myself laughing in her class. Although the class is a little rigorous, if you're serious about taking Japanese, her class is the one to take.
mean and vengenful

Takeuchi Sensei is a caring and passionate teacher who really cares about your success. There is a good amount of homework, and if you haven't had any previous experience with Japanese like me, you will need to work hard. The attendance is mandatory for a good reason because there is a lot of material to cover, but she does a great job teaching it!
I don't need to say much, she's great!

All the Japanese classes offered at UCSC will have nearly the exact same outline and structure regardless of who teaches. It is a heavy workload, fast paced class. That aside-Yukawa sensei is an amazing teacher who really brings out the fun in each class. She is super caring, energetic, and makes this class feel bearable. She will help you succeed!

I'm actually taking J2 currently, and Yukawa Sensee is such a fun teacher. She is very involved in the classroom so get ready to participate a lot. The Japanese courses in UCSC have the same structure- which means tons of HW + quizzes. I am grateful to her for being lenient on HW grading though, and her awesome energy in the classroom. Recommend!

I had Yukawa sensei for jpn1 but she is super caring towards her students and explains concepts and lessons super well. She's a super lenient grader and doesn't take points off of small mistakes, and she also gives good feedback on assignments. There was a lot of extra credit assignments to help balance grades out. I definitely recommend her.

She was very nice and went out of her way to help me and make sure she did everything she could to help me pass. She was very caring and easy to understand I am happy to have been one of her students. The class material was very difficult the tests are worth alot which makes it difficult for bad testers like me even though got good scores on others

Yukawa Sensei is a very nice teacher. She is very generous on grading. Even if you made a mistake on something which you haven't learned yet, she won't take point from it. Her class is really interesting and her feedback on essays is pretty helpful. If you want to learn Japanese, definitely take her class.

For someone who struggled the first two quarters of Japanese this class should be a pain right? Not with Yukawa sensei. Her grading was clear, she's generous with points on her exams, and was very supportive for the progress of her students. I took the Japanese series for fun and found it a chore until I had Yukawa sensei. Definitely take!

Daryl is a fine professor. He does assign more work than other core teachers but the workload is fine. Attendance is mandatory and he is big on participation but you get 2 free absences. IMO he doesn't provide clear feedback on reading reflections, but for other assignments the grading criteria is pretty clear. He does show his own films in class.
He is a great teacher but the class is significantly more involved than similar core teachers, you learn more but you have noticeably more work.

Daryl is the worst introduction to the University you could get. He will give you at least twice as much work as other Kresge Core professors do. He'll force you to act A.I. skits in class, yes, A.I. skits. Daryl also forces you to present your final projects to the entirety of Kresge College. Other classes you simply are asked if you want to,

I understand we're required to take a core class, but when I say don't take, DON'T TAKE HIM FOR CORE! He did have us participate in class which wasn't too bad but he would call people out very badly. His grading overall I didn't find too bad compared to other core teachers, but he was very stingy with grading and took his time. Bad intro to college

Daryl is so insufferable, does not work with you at all. Doesn't know how to lecture, has anger issues, yells at his students, and isn't a very kind person. He is very strict on deadlines and has no wiggle room at all. He often times tries to incorporate his own films and photography(which are very bad) into lessons with no correlation at all.

While he tried his best to get students to participate in class, he was very easily irritated when students were shy. Was quick to raise his voice at students for trivial things like miscounting in class. TOUGH grader and will give you a 0 on big assignments if you turn it in even 1 minute late. Beware of taking him.

I took his CORE class at Kresge, overall very rude and very opinionated even though the class is supposed to be based off of all the students individual opinions and feeling comfortable enough to share our opinions.

(for FILM2 not FILM80s) this guy deserves to be fired. has some serious anger management issues. there was an altercation with a student that got aggressive and then the next week he screamed at the entire class because we called him out on his lack of respect claiming that he doesn't need to baby us because we're adults. extremely unprofessional
Professor was funny and chose a mix of good/disturbing movies. Attendance is a big part of your grade and so is the final group project. Fun class with a fun professor.

Daryl was one of the coolest professors I've had. If you're taking film 80s with him, be prepared for DISTURBING class movies. Attendance is mandatory he is VERY strict about it, and it will bring your grade down significantly. There are 2 short writing assignments and you work on your final movie with 10 other people throughout the quarter.

Attendance is mandatory, but why would it not be mandatory lol? You're paying for the class. Oftentimes I would come up to him after class to get clarification about an assignment and he would always answer my questions with a smile. People really need to just toughen up because life after college won't have optional attendance.

I took this class because I love film. Prof. Jones has an extremely strict attendance policy, and only allows you 2 excused absences and after that, your grade goes down even if you are sick or have a good excuse. He doesn't really lecture at all, and the films he shows are interesting, but very intense. I think films should be take-home.
Another professor who thinks essays are the answer to understanding material.

Daryl is very unorganized, and he doesn't lecture the class on the topics that were outlined in the syllabus. He relies on student discourse. Class meetings are unstructured. Daryl is unqualified to teach Film and lacks credibility given that he does not know how to properly structure a course. I cannot tolerate wannabe professors like Daryl.
Daryl is a very unproductive film professor. His critiques are so opinionated that they are outside of reality. It is almost impossible to take his ass seriously.

the material for the class is interesting, we discussed more about trans issues/representation than films themselves. he was an ok professor, still very cis though, and didn't handle disputes in class very well. had to deal with a lot of transphobic comments from other students which sucked. overall tho i liked the class.

This class is the most unorganized class I've ever had. There was no structure. Students' discourse carried the class periods with minimal to no content provided by the prof. Class felt more like a gender studies class. Films watched looked like it's been picked out last minute. Not qualified to teach trans topics, bad at handling disputes.

His heart is in the right place, but he completely lacks the credibility to teach a class on the topic of transgender people. He shows videos that feel like they were picked out last minute, and just shows them to the class asking what people gathered rather than teaching. Barely lectured, doesn't seem to know enough about trans identity. Very Cis
Very good professor. I learned a lot and he did great at encouraging thoughtful discussions. Papers are very important in grading but overall not too much work

i was in jones' seminar on ethics of documentary film. there were no synchronous meetings, which i favor. all of the assignments were very clear and straightforward. the final at the end took me literally 4 whole hours but it was very comprehensive and somehow felt appropriate. really good sweet-hearted human being.
I loved this class, made me have a different view on writing.
don't get on her bad side because if you do shell watch you constantly. for the most part the majority of her prompts are uninteresting.

Farnaz is an amazing teacher. She helped me DRASTICALLY improve my writing. She is a bit of a hard ass, so if you aren't prepared to work and are sensitive to criticism, then too bad. She doesn't tolerate BS so leave it at the door. If you come to class ready and try your hardest, Farnaz will grade you against YOU and not the rest of the class.

I had Professor Fatemi for two courses.  Before entering her course, I was a really horrible writer.  I did not write with an open mind or heart which is really crucial in writing a good paper. She saw ambition in me and believed in me.

I took the comic book class back in Winter 05. Farnaz was very nice. There was a lot of reading and writing, but it is a writing course after all. I did notice that certain students rubbed her the wrong way. I suggest that anyone taking a class with her leave their attitude at the door. All in all, this was in my top 3 favorite classes at UCSC.

Farnaz was a great core professor! She likes to build relationships with her students and cares about them. She is clear about assignments and down to earth. She will totally give you an easy A if you pay attention in class, turn in all assignments, and get on her good side!

I believe I would've gotten a n A if I didn't choose to do pass/fail. I only choose to do so because the workload was unimaginable and Farnaz took a disliking to me the moment the class started. Also, mandatory grading on others work is pointless and she didn't grade anything on her own. horrible teacher, fun subject.

Really good teacher if you're interested in comics. However there's so much work involved that it effected my other classes. wastes paper. she let's you get off on a lot (turning papers in late) if you're on her good side. make sure you like comics. mandatory group session.

Franaz is the worst teacher ever. She makes you do plenty of useless work. If you want a easy class, this is not it. If you want to maintain a high gpa, do not take this class. If you like comics, i suggest you think carefully before taking this class. Don't get on her bad side. Go to office hours frequently and find out your grade.

Definitely not a great teacher. Once you catch her attention in a bad way, she watches you like a hawk. Just a warning, a ton of homework is assigned in this class. If you're very interested in the topic of her class, then take it; if not, AVOID AT ALL COSTS. If you want to keep a good GPA, don't take this class.

Frustratingly nit-picky on essays, frustratingly boring prompts, style textbook teaches shortening of sentences while essay requirements are long, meticulous about attendance/tardiness, kinda creepy up-close, lots and lots of work, DON'T TAKE THIS CLASS. (writing 2)

Farnaz really cared and was committed to helping in any way she could.  The final project was fun and made me feel accomplished. The material was really fascinating and I've kept most of the graphic novels we studied even though I took the course last winter.
terrible teacher and unfair grader

Thought comic books would be fun, but no. Unbearably boring and pointless, and lots of work, Farnaz was also unusually tough on less-than-willing students. Once she didn't like you, expectations for participation and attitude skyrocketed and it mercilessly became do-or-die. Couldn't breathe. One of the worst experiences ever, dropped it after 4 wks

good lecture, class is student run. gets extremely upset if the the students aren't discussing/talking in class. Doesnt really help out on essay (you're better off getting a writing tutor) but care a lot about the student-teacher relationship. Value you as a person more than a student.
not too good, not too bad.  not the worst teacher, not the best.
I had Farnaz for two different classes and they were both wonderful. I learned a lot and really felt like she gave me room to do my own thing and expand my learning experience

Great teacher,REALLY respects students + learning.Classes are student directed, which was a little frusterating at first, because I felt that I would have learned more from a lecture, but she does because she values students say and I did learn a lot.  Very good at boasting writing confidence.
Very pointless class. There was lots of essays and meetings for this class too.  The class basically is liberal propaganda and brainwashing.  Not very fun at all.

The class, while somewhat boring, was helpful with tutoring, especially the readings. Farnaz worked really hard at finding answers to questions and helping them out with tutoring. The discussions were interesting and well-facilitated. Perhaps it would be better if we only met once a week.

CRSN 55 with Susan felt intimate which gave an enhanced experience in learning about service learning. Having the opportunity to get involved within the Santa Cruz/UCSC community was awesome! She can seem unapproachable, but she genuinely wants you to find your passion and work with expanding it. Susan was easy to email and discuss questions too!

Susan is an amazing teacher & mentor. It's clear that she's very knowledgeable & passionate about journalism. And though she can be intimidating at times, I respect her tremendously as a person. She expects a lot from you, but it just motivates you to work harder to meet those expectations. Though harsh at times, she gives lots of useful feedback.

If I could give Susan more stars, I would. I absolutely adore her and love her teaching style. She doesn't like to use letter grades, but uses evaluations. If you get evaluated well, easy A. She is very passionate about what she teaches and it shows. Susan is also very approachable outside of class, and in class, she cares about her students.
She is amazing!! Very approachable, very caring and an incredibly nurturing professor! Encourages students to do their best and offers very helpful feedback.
Absolutely loved this class! I can't wait to take it again. Susan is a great instructor - so kind, caring, and easy to talk to. I definitely would recommend this class!
A true asset to student media at UCSC! Knowing Susan is a privilege. She is tough and expects the best of the students she advises but she's incredible and a great friend to her students.
No one has been more instrumental to my success as a student and my growth as a human.

Danny p is my goat. He goes over rly interesting readings and topics in class. The class is photography themed which was super cool. You're mainly graded on completion but he expects good faith efforts. Very cooperative and accommodating as well. Lots of class discussions but his class periods are well structured so it's fine. Workload is okay too
Most of the class was graded on completion. The assignments were mildly time consuming, but not super difficult. He's really nice though!

Overall, he is a great teacher! I love writing but this class gave me good feedback and I was able to write fan fiction for this class. Super easy weekly writing prompts and then there are always extra credit chances. It is an easy A if you like creative writing.

Daniel is truly the best professor I have had at UCSC, he cares about his students and wants them to succeed.He is very passionate about his work and inspires his students to be creative on their writing journeys.I took Daniel's class for Writing 1/2, and both times the endless support has truly helped me become a better writer. Def take his class!

Daniel is the greatest writing professor. I had him for WRIT 1&2 & 65W, his teaching is truly out of this world. WRIT 2 has 3 essay projects and 1 light presentation. What you put in is what you get out; bad effort will yield bad feedback and lessen Pearce's ability to make you a stronger writer. Take this class! I cannot recommend him enough
Pearce is a teacher who you can tell very much cares about his students. He has interesting lectures and gives good feedback on essays. His teaching makes me want to take more of his classes.

Loved this class! We had 3 papers and 1 presentation. You get to work in groups and also do peer reviews. The presentation is individual tho. Super chill and laid back. Super helpful with grading and accommodations. Very grateful to have this professor especially for a core class!
Daniel is extremely insightful and smart. He is clearly passionate about creative writing and it shows in his considerate teaching. Highly recommend this class to all writers.
Professor Daniel made me feel supported in this course, I feel my writing has gotten significantly better and I hope to take more classes with him in the future. :)

Out of all the Writ 1 professors, Mr. Pearce is probably the best. While the class is mostly based on small readings and 4 projects, He gives very good feedback and is all around a very nice person. I genuinely felt like I became a better writer afterwards.
Brilliant and kind professor. Super personable, and a warm lecturer.

He was super kind and genuinely cared about his students. The class is structured around the readings but all of them are short, easy to read and interesting. I would definitely recommend him for this class and I felt like I actually improved as a writer throughout it.

Other reviews for Pearce are really good, so I decided to take his class. I regret it. The work isn't toodifficult, just tedious. He never grades, he just labels your assignments as complete and you don't know your grade even in Canvas bc he doesn't put it there. Lectures are mandatory and boring. Unclear prompts, BAD feedback, overall unhelpful.

Only a few writing projects per quarter, and an amazing guy. Truly cares about his students and is always open to working with them. Hands down one of the best professors to have, especially in a smaller class setting such as the Writing courses
He really cares about his students and appreciates participation.
Prof Pearce is awesome. You can always get the help you need, whether it is through him or the writing tutor. He is not strict on word and page count and really cares about what you write.

Professor Pearce is the best professor I've had so far at UCSC. He is super kind, funny, and obviously cares about his students. The assignments in his class weren't difficult and were spaced out well, and the readings were short and easy to understand.  Highly recommend signing up for any writing class that he teaches, you won't regret it! :D

Professor Pearce is amazing, I highly recommend taking his Writing 2 Human Rights class if you can. Not only were the classes, content and readings engaging, Professor Pearce is incredibly understanding and kind. I enjoyed all of the essays that I wrote and did research for in his class and as someone interested in human rights it was eye opening.

Professor Pearce is wonderful! He gives very thorough and constructive feedback. He is caring, sweet, and super supportive. The course's workload is manageable, and the topic is so interesting. Truly feel like I have learned and grown a lot as a writer after taking this class. PLEASE TAKE HIS CLASS AND YOU WON'T REGRET!!!

professor daniel was by far one of my favorite professors of the quarter ! he is very understanding and is willing to accommodate so you can feel like ur actually learning something ! as long as ur reading the passages assigned every week you should be passing the class ! :)

I probably hate core as much as the next guy but Prof Leslie was reallly chill. At some point I skipped straight up 2 weeks of her class and she asked me if I was doing alright instead of yelling at me. Not too much work just make sure you put a little bit of effort into your writing.

Her classes are pretty easy. Follow the rubric and you'll likely get 100. Be aware she's a very specific grader. Readings are super interesting and thought-provoking, but discussions are facilitated poorly and assignments are so boring and feel pretty useless. Class is about learning how you learn, but the class doesn't actually encourage this.

First of all, KRSG 1 isn't a class, you can not talk or read for the whole course and get an A. Just show up. Leslie is a great instructor though, she steers the class discussions (which is the majority of the course) quite well and is quite caring and nice. If your can talk and write a lot, your golden. If you're quite, you'll be fine.
This was an easy class, and a good intro to UCSC.

Great professor. She gives a very clear rubric for every assignment and gives clear feedback. If you apply her feedback for the next assignment, your grade will reflect it. You don't have to be good at writing, just conveying ideas and she says this multiple times. Open to listen to students ideas even if she might not agree with it.

The professor is very kind and soft spoken. Get prepared to read a lot. Majority of the time in class is you discussing about the readings in small groups. I would suggest to look ahead in the modules to get a better Idea of what you need to complete to get a higher and better grades. As well as get a head start on the major project.

I loved Leslie. It was not a traditional classroom where she lectured. You had to discuss with your peers about certain subjects but it was relatively easy. Lots of reading outside of class and critical thinking, but overall enjoyable!

It was a relatively easy class, but there is lots of readings and the module projects are fair, she grades like a high school teacher, just follow the paper outlines she gives you for the module projects and you should be fine

Despite the teacher being caring, she grades very late. I only received one grade back halfway through the semester. I never knew how I was doing due to very few assignments. No final or midterm! Very open to regrading perhaps the best thing. The worst part was how the instructions were extremely unclear and seemed to change every 5 seconds.

Professor Leslie is sweet and amazing. She is very kind, gives great feedback on work, is accommodating, and understanding. I 100% recommend taking Kresge Core with her. I had the best experience in her class. There is weekly reading that you need to stay on top of, a fair amount of work, and attendance is required. Also participate in convo.
She is great, you do have to read a lot and write a lot but not that hard

Professor Lesie is a terrible teacher. She failed to update her course with respect to the shift to online learning. She hasn't given me any feedback on ANYTHING I have submitted since the beginning of the class. Her lectures contain little to no important information on how to complete the coursework. NEVER TAKE ANY OF HER CLASSES!!!!!!!
She is an awesome, kind, and caring professor. The material is not hard and anyone can easily pass this class.
Juliana was an amazing professor. She was really sweet and open to help us no matter what. We had module projects, which 2 were in groups and 2 were individual. It is an easy class.
Juliana gave us interesting things to think about in Kresge 1.

Juliana is a very nice professor and gives great feedback on essays. She tries to make the classroom feel like an inviting environment for everyone to voice their opinion during discussion. Overall very organized and not too difficult.
She is such an awesome person! She is so sweet, nice, and smart. She answers questions really effectively and I'm thankful for that. She was a great core teacher!

She was a very sweet professor. I warn you in general that this class was at times very heated, and led to some awkward and at times offensive discussion; in this way I felt bad because Leslie had a difficult time trying to bring students back to her attention. On essay feedback she is amazing. Attendance is needed and be ready to talk.

Such a sweet, understanding and happy professor. If you have an issue with anything at all, she is willing to help you during office hours. She gives really good commentary on essays and has definitely made me a stronger writer.

I took this for a GE and have no interest in creative writing, even as a lit major. Juliana is great, very sweet, and kept class interesting. Living Writers is mandatory and impacts your grade so GO! Even though I thought I'd suck at this, she was very nice and not judgmental.

This is probably the best LALS class I've taken. Arredondo is really passionate about what she does. I honestly looked forward to going to her class all the time. The lectures were pretty clear. Mid-term and final were two essays each, which were a bit time consuming but not difficult.

She is a great professor! Lectures go by very quickly and are interesting. I have learned a lot in this class that will help me to understand the real world. This class is worth your time and effort. Plus, there are only two take home midterms and a final making it a low stress class.

She was an okay teacher. She grades too hard and she expected us to read 6 books, but she was always enthusiastic about the subject. It's a good GE class to take if you are interested in LALS and like to write.

Don't take this class! She intentionally tries to confuse people and is technologically inept. I needed to start a project for her class and she never replied to my emails! Overall, it was a frustrating experience for me.
She was a really enthusiastic teacher. Loved her energy and class is good. I was not really interested in the topic, but she made class interesting. Great teacher and willing to help.

Amazing professor who knows how to teach and engage with the class. Material isn't too difficult to comprehend if you attend lectures. The Midterms and final are made up of 2 take home essays. UCSC needs more professors like Arredondo!
Professor Arredondo is AWESOME. Definitely wants to help her students and make sure we understand the material well. Engaging lecturer and very entertaining.
I love Prof Arredondo! She's funny, well caffeinated and makes the class fly. She knows her stuff and will expect students to as well. She respects students as learners and CARES about us.

Interesting class, there is a lot of essay writing involved. Her tests are composed of 2 take-home essay midterms and a take-home essay final. Pretty easy class, I only read the two or three articles related to each essay topic that she handed out and I got A's on all my papers. She's a super cool professor, I enjoyed the class!

There are two midterms and one final in this class. Each is composed of 2 take-home essays related to the readings/lectures. If you're a strong writer this class is an easy A. Lectures are interesting and easy to pay attention to with her.

Enthusiastic about the subject, knowledgeable and easy to understand, I really enjoyed having Arredondo as a professor. Its a pretty easy class as long as you attend lectures and work hard on midterms and finals. It wasn't impossible to get a good grade though and I really liked that.

Guiding light in a world of darkness. If you need ER GE then take this class immediately!!! All the homework is super easy. Readings are the most important to follow. Never went to office hours except one time and prof was super kind and nice to work with. Occasionally has discussion posts for students to get to know each other more, really cool.
best class to take for ER GE! workload is so light, I am so glad I took this class this quarter!

100% recommend taking this class for a GE, especially if you're a STEM major. Everything is open book/note, and the work is also very easy. I think I spent a max of 30 minutes on the workload for this class each week. It made me feel like I was only taking 2 classes instead of 3.

Really great professor she is very passionate about teaching. She is very understanding and flexible even with final projects and exams. The class consisted of one paper, one final project, and worksheets throughout the quarter that she went over the answers for before it was due. Definitely recommend.
It's a very simple class that talks a lot about gender and race. Every week, you just need to read and complete the worksheet and quiz, all of which are in openbook.

This is my second course with Patel (this one was asynchronous online). We have weekly discussions, quizzes, readings, and worksheets-- sounds like a lot, but the workload is pretty light as long as you don't let your work build up. Clear and reasonable expectations and grading; midterm and quizzes are open-note, and the final is a paper.
was super easy, i was out for a few weeks because of a surgery but the work was all online so it was easy to finish
Easy class for a ge
easy class
Loved her easy A especially if you're queer or passionate about the LQBTQ+ community.

It's a pretty easy class - Two midterms and one final, one being a paper and the other two being an open book exam. The coursework was very light, and the teacher was super nice making the class enjoyable!

Professor Patel is very understanding and teaches very clearly. Grades are based on open note quizzes you can retake to get 100%, a paper, open book midterm and final. There's a project but she allows you to do it in a group that you pick or individually!

LOVEEEEEE her, so so so caring and understanding. only 1 paper as the final and a quiz as the midterm which is similar to other quizzes. quizzes are unlimited attempts and super easy. very easy ge to fulfill. honestly only showed up the first 2-3 weeks and still have a 100% in the class. def recommend her

One lecture a week was dedicated to doing group worksheets that took maybe 30 mins. Very interesting and important coursework, but the information from lectures is rarely seen in worksheets or quizzes; they are based on readings. Very easy course and great professor

She is a nice professor. The lectures are a bit boring and attendance was mandatory. If you did not go to class, you'd be penalized for it but she is lenient if you communicate with her. She was caring and passionate professor. hw is easy too.

Usually, I am okay with taking a class with Prof Patel but this quarter attendance became mandatory which made me realize just how boring the class itself is. Nothing was ever graded too harshly and even if you missed class as long as you emailed her beforehand she would not penalize you.

Patel is a very caring professor who will always prioritize her students above all else. She is very understanding about attendance despite it being required. There is 3 exams, 1 paper, 10 quizzes and worksheets so it can get packed if you leave it all of the end. They weren't harshly graded it is a very great class to take for a GE requirement.
The class was super straightforward. The material was not difficult whatsoever, definitely recommend taking this class if you need an easy GE!

Super easy class, a very understanding professor. Attendance is mandatory and she uses a sign-in sheet but she cancels class half the time anyways. Its based on a bunch of worksheets and quizzes + three exams and a final paper.

Good professor, it does get a tiny bit overwhelming with the amount of text on her slides but most important parts that will be included in the quiz is highlighted. Weekly quiz (unlimited tries and on canvas), 2-3 exams (on canvas, unlimited time) and one final paper. Attendance was mandatory, sign-in sheet at the beginning of class.

Professor Rivera is a sweet lecturer at heart. She is very understanding of students' voices. She gives us a space and a place to discuss our thoughts and opinions about topics that we analyzed in Global Latinidades. Lots of reading. However, as long as you go to class most of the time, you will be fine.

Cecilia is very knowledgeable about Latin America, however her lectures can be boring and unfortunately are mandatory. There tends to be one assignment per week if not, every other week but they're not difficult and she is not a harsh grader. Easy class just boring.

If you take this class for a GE just be prepared for group work and possibly being bored in class.Much of the material was all over the place and unclear Doesn't really know how to answer certain question when your confused As well, she is a harsh grader even though the class is small it's hard to talk to her one on one. One big project at the end.

Easy but boring class. There are a lot of long readings but skimming is fine for this class. There are quite a few assignments but they're not hard to get out of the way. Overall this class is an easy A if you just want the GE credit.
this is a great class, if you want a gpa booster, her lectures are a bit boring but its an easy A.

She literally has no idea how to manage a class. We spent more time learning about El Salvador than we did mentioning media or nationalism (our class subject), and she literally could not manage to assign half of the assignment's she mentioned until last minute, giving us little to no time to get any of it done. Awful experience

Her lectures are incredibly boring and she jumps around topics when talking. She doesn't use powerpoint at all so its just her talking for an hour straight with no sense of direction. If you have her for a Tuesday/Thursday class, good luck staying awake. I was miserable during this class, and I don't recommend taking her at all.

Subject matter is interesting, but she is boring, awkward and unapproachable. Went in to talk to her during office hours right before she was leaving and she was terribly mean and intimidating. Could never recommend her

Class was very very easy. Tests are all essays or short response questions and are super easy if you pay attention to her lectures and go to section. She gets flustered often and is kind of awkward but is very passionate about Central America and the issues the people there face. Just do the readings (or at least skim them)

She started off the class with a bad attitude, that "since this is an 80 series class" we are all unmotivated and uninterested in the class. To be honest, this was in fact true for me and most of the class. However, I feel that this was a horrible way to approach the situation. Boring lectures, boring readings, she drones on and on

I rated her clarity a 1 because I have no idea why she is on a college campus teaching. The class is dry and uninteresting. There is a lot of reading which is directly referenced in the exams but study groups help out with that. Bring headphones or earplugs, shes BORING!

She would frequently post the readings after she said she would, but would expect you to still have them done by the time class started. She gave us our final prompt late and switched it from 3 essays to 4 without saying anything. She also goes off on tangents a lot when lecturing.

Horrible Professor. As an LALS student I am ashamed to have her associated with the department. This class was painfully boring. The majority of the class would spend their time on their phones and computers either surfing the web or playing games. During lecture she just talked and did not make the material accessible or make the connections clear

This class is super interesting and really easy. It is a lower division class, yet I still learned a lot and really enjoyed going. Her lectures are pretty dry and boring, but if you go to section and do the readings you will get an A. There are two response papers, and tests are blue book essays. Not too much reading and none of it is challenging.

Interesting class that focuses on El Salvador, that is her field of research. She is knowledgeable of her field, but seems to have some difficulty answering questions. Great class for a GE, not hard at all, readings are really interesting.

She's a fun teacher. She's very knowledgable, and provides much work and interest. She's a great professor. There is a reading, but not much as other teachers. Her tests aren't difficult, if you do the reading. Great Class!

She's generally nice enough and respectful to her students, and you can tell she's spent a lot of time in this field. But she's very lecture-heavy, it was really hard to pay attention most of the time (not that you needed to most of the time). She also focused too much on El Salvador; I learned little about anywhere else. Not too terrible, though.

Didn't learn anything.  She was really boring to listen to, and her tests were so easy that nobody studied for them.  She lectures the whole time, doesn't ask the class questions, and then gets mad when we don't do the reading.  She gave us fifth-grade homework as a buffer for our grades.  Overall, bad experience, especially for a college course.

Classroom was really boring professor lacked motivation. Attendance was mandatory although it was not necessary because I didn't learn anything the whole back side of the class was sleeping. Although she seems like a nice person it seems like she was always P-M-Sing all she spoke about was el salvador because shes from there. Overall waste of time!

Cecilia Rivas is a good instructor although she can get a little stressed out. SHE IS ALWAYS THERE WILLING TO HELP JUST DO NOT APPROACH HER TOO MUCH SHE DOES NOT LIKE THAT. tHE CLASS IS VERY INTERSETING, BUT HER ENTHUSIAM TO TECH THE CLASS IS SOMEWAY NEUTRAL. SHE HAS DIFICULTIES ANSWERING QUESTIONS.

Professor Leiva was amazing! He clearly loves the topic and does lecture the entire class. Very few assignments and and two projects (easy) Downside though, be careful about the annotations. The syllabus says to complete at least 5, and I did, but he kept the zeros for them even after saying he'd fix it. So make sure to double check! (i didnt-ugh)

Professor Leiva is an excellent professor. I took his LALS94X class and it was a really interesting class. He does lecture a lot and it can be a bit depressing at times given the topic, there are reading assignments, and two projects due. I got an A and I found the class relatively easy, especially if you do the work.

Professor Leiva is honestly a chill professor. Our only hw was just annotating readings and 2 digital projects. The class is relatively easy but he does side track a bit. He doesn't really respond to emails but if you speak to him in person/office hours he is willing to help. A couple of my classmates needed a extension for the essay and he did it.

This class was chaotic. Every meeting was just the professor lecturing despite there not being a section and he only answered one of the five emails I sent throughout the quarter. None of the assignments have descriptions, so you have to go digging through the syllabus to know what to do, which doesn't specify what readings are due for what days.

Leiva is cool and passionate about the subject, however, I think your experience on the class really depends on your TA. I had a very kind TA who graded easily so the class was a breeze for me! Tests are open book and you have weekly discussion assignments. Lots of reading, however if you just skim the book and lectures you should be set. :)

Super interesting topics and good choice of books. At first I was a bit overwhelmed as the class is asynchronous and he talked a bit slow. I always speeded the videos which helped. Most of the interaction is done with your TA as they grade everything and hold section (mandatory attendance) once a week. Make sure you get a good TA!

professor leivas class was very nice! although the didnt teach the class in person instead his TA , he did post some great lectures on canvas. as long as you do the weekly discussions and read the books assigned , you should be able to get an easy A !

The class is asynchronous, so lectures are published weekly and should be reviewed at your own pace. Reading is a little heavy but manageable. Comprised of 10 discussion posts, a midterm, and a final. Both should be easy if you study according to the study guides provided. TA's grade, so a good TA will get you far! Overall loved the course!

TA's did the grading for this class, one discussion post a week worth 10 points, one midterm, final was multiple choice and two essay questions. Lectures were long. Section with a TA once a week was mandatory. Okay and interesting class overall.

Took this class for a general requirement but ended up really enjoying the subject. The lectures can be quite slow sometimes but all the material is very interesting. Reading could sometimes be overwhelming but always applied to what we were learning about in class. As long as you do your reading, you should pass with no problems!

One of the best professors Ive had! I took this class online and asynchronous, so watching the recorded lectures were a must. The lectures were very interesting, but slow. Hes very approachable in office hours and helps explain questions extremely thoroughly. You can tell hes passionate about the subject and really cares about your learning.

Easy and enjoyable intro class! He is very passionate about the subject and I got a lot out of the class. The books we read are super interesting, and lectures can get a little dull but it isn't necessary to go to them all the time which is nice. Tests were easy if you do the reading, and I learned a lot!

Professor Leiva speaks makes complex concepts seem easy. Great run through of Latin American history in just 10 weeks. Highly recommend this intro class. :0) As long as you read the powerpoint presentation and do some reading you should be fine. Easy A.
All lecture slides are online, but the lecture material isn't even on tests. Difficult class and hard tests. Sections are mandatory. There are section quizzes.
Fernando was a fun professor who seemed to be really passionate about the material he was teaching. The class required a lot of reading and there aren't many things you can do to raise your grade.

Leiva is a nice guy. He really cares about what he's teaching. His lectures are clear and while they help on quizzes, not so much on the exams, but those can easily be passed by going to the website he mentions. Super easy and hardly ever showed up to lectures.

The tests are v. hard: "What percentage of Mexicans owned land before the revoluation?" The lectures are v. boring and not relevant to the exams 90% of the time. tests aren't on concepts, but on minutiae from books. Didn't even show up to the final, and of course there was a huge error. Section attendance mandatory. Too hard for intro class. Avoid!

Professor Leiva is an amazing lecturer. Haven't talk to him in Office Hours but he is more than approachable and welcoming! Midterm 1 was not difficult whatsoever but did require reading Chasteen and Gonzalez thoroughly. He is truly a passionate person and doesn't ask much of students besides wanting to learn more! Highly recommend him.
He seems like a cool dude, it is just that lecture is super long and it gets boring. The reading are interesting and the tests given are pretty straight forward. In order to do well you must read.

Gives detailed explanation for intro to LALS. Lectures are definitely boring, but feels more appealing to listen to if you have read the assigned chapters. For sure, the book is very helpful. Grading from Syllabus (subject to change) -2 Quizzes (15% each) in Section -1 Midterm (30%) -Final (30%) -Participation from Section (10%) Mandatory
One discussion every week, midterm and final paper. She's not bad overall but grading is tough and strict.
Love this professor he's my G fr! take his classes!!!

A great passionate professor! His handwriting is a little hard to read sometimes however he is aware of that and is incredibly open to rewriting/clarifying anything so as long as you communicate that with him, I don't see that as a reason to not take his classes! Super nice and very engaging the whole quarter 10/10 would recommend him to anyone!

This professor has the worst handwriting I've ever seen. You'll have to pay really close attention to what he says because his handwritten notes in class are unreadable. His class requires three books, so be ready to spend some money.

An amazing lecturer and one of the most passionate I've ever had. At first, I wasn't looking forward to the lectures, especially since they were in the evening. However, the readings and content we learned in the class were so interesting that they didn't feel heavy at all. Attendance isn't required, but gives random EC points for being in class.

Prof Perez is great. He's super understanding if you talk to him about anything and his class was super easy. Tests are open note and pertain entirely to the lectures and readings which makes them super easy if you pay attention. Lectures can be a little boring but if you're interested in the subject you'll love it. He also gives sm extra credit

Super interesting and thoughtful class. Took this class for a GE and ended up absolutely loving it. Lectures can get a little long sometimes, but honestly, I think that was because they were held in the evening. Professor Perez is considerate and does a spectacular job linking events and history over the timeline of the AIDS epidemic.

Very easy GE. No attendance mandatory, clear criteria + open book for quizzes. Some of the readings are kind of long, but honestly easy enough to skim and still get a good grade in it. Lectures are posted online + slides are available that you can honestly skip the lectures.

Great professor very passionate and excited to teach and inform others. He takes notes while he speaks and then posts them for everyone to see. The midterm and final are short papers and short multiple choice exams. Very interesting class and definitely recommend!
Professor Perez is extremely knowledgeable and passionate about what he teaches! Amazing teacher and super fun class, would highly recommend!

Had Professor Perez for LALS56. basic breakdown of class: no late work; class work consisted of 10 reading notes, 5 group works (which can be done in class), at home midterm, & at home final; Lecture was him reading off of a slide presentation; everything is open notes and open book; and homework was just a LOT of reading.

I don't know how me managed it, but I actually wasn't bored to death during lectures but that could just be because I was interested in the topics. There's a lot of reading and reading responses but you don't really have to read everything he assigns, just the ones where a reading response is needed

This professor was pretty straightforward. I took him for LALS56 and it was a pretty easy GE. I didn't attend the lectures often, but the lectures were pretty much him reading off a presentation. The hw is also pretty straightforward just reading and taking notes on them or answering questions. The exams were also open note and on canvas.
Readings were EXTREMELY repetitive. He is not accessible at all and gives very unclear information. Do not recommend.
