He posts two lectures a week with weekly readings, and the reading is pretty heavy. There is an essay midterm, and multiple choice final. His quizzes are open note and he goes biweekly for the quizzes and reading responses. If you mess up a reading response, then your grade will plummet, BUT the TA's are very helpful and honestly is hard to fail.

Professor Justin is great! He is incredibly knowledgable and caring. He explains the concepts very clearly and is very responsive to questions. It was a great class and the assignments were really easy.

I found this class to be pretty straightforward. Grades consist of the weekly reading responses based on lectures and readings, essay midterm, and multiple choice final. Most of these reviews are upset by the grading on the reading responses, but I think it's very easy to do well if you don't just regurgitate the reading material. Highly recommend!

Justin is really smart and takes a very holistic approach to history. He cares a lot about his students and sets clear standards. If you reach out he's more than happy to work with you. It's an average amount of work but if you stay on top of it it's not too bad.

it took me a while to understand what she wanted from readings and i was too scared to go in and ask what i needed to do (my problem entirely) but she was very good in lectures and also prefers and enjoys in class participation.

Amazing and caring professor. Professor Taft preferred class participation rather than lectures. Midterm and Final were both papers along with a final project poster. HW was weekly readings that push you to think critically. Attendance is graded.

I had Professor Taft for LALS60 (Latin American Childhoods) and she was a caring professor with insightful lectures. She's very understanding and flexible with situations that come up. I was only graded off of two essays, two exams, and participation/attendance. There are weekly assigned readings that may take a couple hours to complete.
she was pretty cool, learned lots of things that made me open my eyes about my culture

Professor Taft is insanely knowledgable about research methods. Her lectures are engaging, and extremely clear about what you need to know. The class moves weekly (one topic/assignment/section), so although you don't have time to slack off, your weekly responsibilities aren't too difficult or exerting. This class will make you want to do research!

She is the best professor in the LALS department. A trained sociologist and a youth social movement/collective action scholar, Professor Taft really cares about her students and puts a lot of time into her teaching and mentoring, and it shows! She is also an organizer, showing with actions her scholar-activist identity.

Jessica was by far one of the best professors I've had at UCSC and I really enjoyed the opportunity to take her class. Her lectures are informative and her readings were very accessible. I highly recommend taking her class!

Erbig is a great professor very passionate about the subject and knows so much more. It is a lot of history and the lectures are quiet dense but if you're interested in the subject they're interesting. Definitely recommend taking this class the workload is manageable and there's no midterm and the final paper is a group paper.

Awesome class even as someone who hasn't taken very many history classes. Assignments are helpful in understanding the readings and you get to talk to your classmates a lot. The readings can be long though. The professor is kind and passionate about the subject,

Prof Erbig's lectures are genuinely intriguing. He is able to simplify complex topics so that someone with no prior knowledge of the topic can understand them quickly. Readings can get long at times, but most of them are pretty fascinating to read through. Lectures are mandatory and important to attend to discuss readings with classmates.

Professor Erbig is super understanding and his lectures are engaging.Theres a couple of readings every week followed by a worksheet, but there honestly all interesting things to read about so its not dreading.Tbh this class helps you enjoy reading. Would recommend anyone to take. Honestly no complaints about the class tbh

The course itself revolved around the lab component, while the class felt like a lot of busy work. The assignments were not relevant to our research proposal which made up the bulk of the course, which made the work seem not relevant. The work was not hard, however, and the professor + tas were lenient about late work and were understanding.

Do the assigned reading before lecture, and you'll be set. They can be dense sometimes but are helpful in understanding lecture and having discussions with groups you might be put into. Erbig genuinely wants everyone to do well, always asking if things are clear, accessible outside of lecture, and a great professor overall.

Absolutely love Prof. Coben. I make a point to take his classes whenever he's teaching. He's definitely not everyone's perfect prof, but he's so passionate and so knowledgeble. Any of his anthro or lit classes are a must-take for Legal majors. So easy to do exceptionally well in the class if you just do the readings. Very no-nonsense course.
He is my favorite professor at ucsc i go out of my way to take his classes.
He can be snarky at times, but he truly means well. I loved taking this class; every single lecture was new and different and just so captivating!

Coben is incredible!! His lectures make you think analytically about legal concepts and truly shape the way you go about law. Definitely recommend meeting with him during office hours and engaging with him after class if you can, he loves to yap and always has great insight! Do the readings, engage in class and attend lectures to do well!!
Nate is a great professor! There's no midterm in the class which made the final kinda overwhelming. I really enjoyed the content of lectures and course materials, would def take again.

Great professor, incredibly interesting class and content. Clearly incredibly intelligent and passionate. My only note is that his lecture format is centered around him giving monologues with usually zero visual aide or writing. Lecture is very much like a podcast with occasional student comments.

Goes on a lot of tangents during lecture, but they tie back to the subject matter. He is very passionate about anthropology and is very knowledgable as well. He does reading quizzes, The quizzes are curved and he curves based on participation at the end. If you participate and read you will come out with an A.

Coben is an amazing professor. Don't believe the 1.0 quality ratings, because his teaching is EXTREMELY knowledgable and you always walk out of class with something new to think about. However, he's extremely difficult in the sense that he'll make you work for your grade. Regardless, loved this professor for giving me a quality education!

This professor is extremely knowledgeable but very very rigid and it takes away from the overall experience of the courses he teaches.   if you don't have a TA for the courses you take with him, just follow the syllabus exactly as it reads, and pray you don't need help outside of what he's willing to offer. again, very rigid so follow the syllabus.

He does not use slides as a method to get people to go to class, which makes some get frustrated. The class is structured around reading and then a discussion about the reading in class. He is very cunning and interesting and brings lots of insight. He is a great professor and had a blast in his class.

Is a fine lecturer, but super full of himself. In a large lecture hall he would pause to rant about people being late or something trivial and just draw more attention. students don't care and it was annoying to listen to his crashouts for those already there. He has good ideas but his tangents are too unorganized for note-taking purposes.

I dont understand the glaze in the other reviews. Nate is fine as a lecturer but definitely not great. He assigns a lot of reading and just goes over the readings in lecture. He does not add anything new and rarely uses lecture slides or the chalkboard, so its just him talking and talking, which makes it hard to solidify any knowledge. Hes just meh

Coben is a very passionate teacher and that is what tops him over lots of professors. He is extremely good at providing useful information in regards to upcoming exams and quizzes. The lectures aren't mandatory but the sections are but I basically assume the lectures are mandatory because you need to attend to understand the material fully.

I loved this class, my favorite professor at Santa Cruz so far. If you can take this class with him please do. The readings are so interesting. They are important for lectures so read them beforehand (two a week 20-40 pages each usually). Writing assignments were not hard and were explained clearly. Midterm was based on lecture directly.

He's really passionate and I learned a lot but his lectures kind of just ramble on nonstop. I went to almost every class and they were really helpful in studying for the midterm & final. Readings were optional but tested on. We also had a paper about a legal process that was kinda hard but my TA was really nice and helpful.

Amazing professor and is really passionate about what he teaches in terms of law. Weekly quizzes and two exams both based on the readings, so it is very important to read before class as he explains concepts deeper in class. Readings are manageable, but the exams aren't straightforward, and require in-depth thinking. Class does make you truly learn

Weekly quizzes but if you do the weekly readings easy. Very passionate but lectures can be drawn out but there is usually a reason. does not use slides mostly discussion of readings, not mandatory in lecture but attendance is required in section. Projects are reasonable. He picks really good readings but can be long
he is really cool, take his class

I loved all the classes I took with Nate. He is laid-back, intelligent, and funny. His lectures are entertaining and enjoyable and you'll want to attend them even if it's not required. I wish I could take more classes with him.

I really like this professor and the readings he chose! This definitely is an obtainable A IF you do all the readings/attend lecture. His lectures can at times be all over the place but always entertaining

Dean did a fantastic job facilitating small group discussions, where we got to know each other and had a chance to talk through our discussion questions, which made me feel engaged. I loved ALL the texts we read (a first in any course!) and hearing what other students and Dean had to say; I learned to see race and America in a whole new way.

This class was the highlight of my academic career at UCSC. I always went to class excited to hear what he would say about them. I was often left touched and transformed by his comments, which were exploding with insights and would drive me right back into the next day's readings. Great class.

Dean is nice but the final was so unrealistic that the highest score in the class was a B (which was an outlier). The course is insanely reading-heavy and you can't get away with reading the bare minimum. If you're a full time student and employed don't take this class. His lectures were hard to follow. He has a fanbase but I don't recommend.

This was the best class I have taken in my entire life. It's a bit of reading, but participating in section is useful in understanding the material and prepares you for the papers, which are the most vital to your grade. Working a job up to 30 hours a week is doable if you are a fast reader and attend every lecture. I loved this class so much.

Mathiowetz was amazing! His lectures were the most engaging I've witnessed when it came to Ancient Greece, however, you absolutely cannot miss a lecture. They aren't mandatory, but they help you pass the exam as well as help you understand the content way more. The class is also based off of 4 things, midterm, two finals, and participation.

Mathiowetz brings ancient philosophy to life with his captivating lectures. The workload is heavy, but engaging with the material is incredibly rewarding. I found unstuckstudy to be a helpful study tool alongside the course textbook.

Fantastic Lectures, class was always a treat as Prof Mathiowetz took us through ancient times in a very engaging way. BUT I have to say, I just took the final and it was incredibly difficult. As someone who took detailed notes and went to lecture it was still too hard. I studied for 2 days and maybe got half the questions correct.

Prof is amazing. But If you have to work while in school, do NOT take this class. I took the final, and the amount of reading and engagement with the material required is completely unrealistic unless you are deeply passionate about ancient political thought. Be ready to sit down and focus for upwards of 20 hours a week to engage sufficiently. Hard

This course is not for everyone. The readings are absolutely ridiculous; they are dense, complex, and time-consuming. However, if you have any interest in classics, ancient Athens, or political theory, then this class will be one of the most rewarding things you have ever done. It's not for everyone, but truly a beautiful course. Thank you Prof. M.

I absolutely loved taking this class. The professor explained these ancient thinkers so well and left me thinking many times about the texts, he invited us to challenge and think these thinkers. He as also really accessible outside of class. This class is only graded by a two papers, but you'll do fine if you attend lectures.

3.6/5. He gives great lectures, but this class has too much reading. It's not manageable if you have a job outside of school. He bans laptops and tablets. He also makes you buy physical copies of all the books even though you never use them in class. Don't buy the books. There are only two papers the entire quarter and they are 60% of your grade.

Dean is a great professor, but this class was so hard. There were only two assignments (a midterm paper and a final paper) and they were TOUGH. The prompts are extremely difficult and don't make much sense and the papers are VERY LONG. The readings are also extremely difficult and are super hard to comprehend.

Brace yourselves for Professor Mathiowetz, he possesses a unique ability to transform even the driest philosophical concepts into uproarious tales. The way he recounts Socrates' witty comebacks or Cicero's political escapades will have you rolling in the aisles with laughter. Who knew political theory could be this entertaining?

TOOK POLI 100! Professor Mathiowetz is one of the best professors I have had at UCSC, he is kind and understanding and is incredibly passionate about his work. His office hours were very helpful and he made an effort to understand my point of view. The Republic was difficult but he made it way easier to understand the material.

I think Mathiowetz may be my favorite politics professor at UCSC. You can tell just how passionate he is about teaching and how much he loves learning from his students. It's essential to participate regularly for a good grade, but it's worth it. I don't think I've taken as much as I've learned here to different classrooms ever before

Mathiowetz is easily my favorite professor at UCSC. He is brilliant, passionate, and truly hilarious. If you complete the majority of the readings and pay attention during lecture, you'll do fine and you'll learn a lot. I highly recommend Mathiowetz to anyone interested in politics or theory. I don't usually care for theory but I love his classes.

Do yourself a favor, do your health a favor, do your soul a favor. Take a class taught by Dean. By far the most engaging lecturer I have ever had in my entire life. 105A had me considering my entire existence. I'll be honest, the class is a lot of work. You have to do a ton of reading and even more internal contemplating. But it's so worth it.
Good class, really interesting but can be a bit bland because of how dry the subject is. A lot of reading, can get through without doing it but will be much harder to write his essays.

InCREDible professor! This class pushes me every day but I leave each class just so full of insight. Mathiowetz's lectures are clear and interesting and dynamic. Good sense of humor and ultra handsome (for real) and nice guy who cares about students.
Very funny and and tries to explain to the best of his abilities. Some of the reading are hard but he explains them so its easier to understand. Good-looking guy as well:)

The best Professor at UC Santa Cruz by far

Is my hero 

Would die for him

I have never written a review about a professor before in my tenure at UCSC. Mark is an amazing lecturer outside of the occasional misinterpreting of his British accent. He is awesome. Cannot overstate how much I love Mark. Take this class please.

My fav professor ever! he cares about his students and fosters an academic environment. Very gracious on grading as long as you show effort and understanding. Great at answering questions and very understanding. Class was a lot of fun and I felt immersed even when the topic was serious

Professor Coonerty was the best teacher I have ever had in my entire life. I have never learned so much in a class before. He helped us get so engaged with his courses and even get excited to come to class and learn from him. He is so easy to talk to if you need help and was so accommodating, accepting and supportive of all of his students.

The most insightful class and experience I have had. Ryan has provided me more insight into the legal field. There is a decent amount of reading, but it is within reason. Reasonable quizzes, a group project, and a very reasonable final assignment. Ryan is an amazing and fun professor here. Take his class.
Great teacher

One of the best professors I've had, really cares about his students. Ryan has a lot of experience in the legal and political atmosphere, which makes for great anecdotes. There isn't much structure to the lecture, but he is very engaging, just be ready to take notes. Keep up with readings and the Times, although quizzes aren't graded super hard.

Ryan is literally my favorite professor in LGST department. He doesn't lecture at us the whole time which is really nice, instead he encourages class participation which is very engaging. There are daily quizzes (that are super easy, just do the readings and you'll be fine). His office hours are always super helpful too.

The class is kinda disorganized since he's just talking and there's no powerpoint/lectures but he is REALLY easygoing and lenient and that definitely makes up for it. I hated the daily quizzes but they force you to have at least some idea of what's going on in the readings and in the world (he tests on current events in the New York Times).

My advice: Coonerty does not lecture off of slides, so be prepared to take good notes based off of in-class discussions. Grading on quizzes is lenient(mostly to account for attendance). Be able to argue and provide evidence to differing opinions on exams (the more clear and concise you are the better). Participate in class.
The TA seemed to be very generous with grading. The professor is easy going too. It sounds like some people are just salty about their grades. Exams and essay prompts were straightforward.

My fav class at UCSC! Little structure to lectures, but he utilizes discussions to guide us in formulating our own conclusions by providing materials+overarching questions. His style made me engaged and want to work hard. Passed everyone on papers but few got straight A's. I think daily quizzes only count for participation, so do well on papers.

Professor Coonerty is a good guy and offers an interesting perspective as an educator. While none of the three courses I took with him were highly structured, they still touched on important events happening in the status quo and how these events relate back to themes of American political history. All of his courses also had great guest lectures.

Great lecturer. There are 2-3 question quizzes on the assigned reading at the beginning of every class but he lets you miss two (he won't tell you this) and he'll be lenient on grading those quizzes if you participate in class. The reader is usually mostly New York Times and case briefs so if you can't afford it just google the article/case.

I really recommend that if you have a chance to take one of his classes you do. Its worth the work, which really isn't that much. There are quizzes on the reading at the start of the class, but it really isn't that bad. You actually end up learning something unlike other classes.  As well as the quality of his teaching is remarkable. MUST TAKE.

Such an awesome professor! Two time mayor of Santa Cruz and now on the Board of Supervisors, he has a ton of connections and is uniquely qualified to teach politics here in Santa Cruz. If you participate in class and attend lectures, the class isn't too hard. Lectures are actually interesting, and you'll find yourself wanting to come to class!

Amazing professor! Very detailed and thoughtful lectures. He can really get a discussion going for the whole class, it's important to participate! If you have the chance to take him, totally do! The short quizzes at the beginning of class are col because they keep the pressure to keep up with readings and count towards attendance!

I really enjoyed his interactive approach to teaching. Instead of lecturing for an hour and 45 minutes, he allowed students to give their own insight into the relevant course topics, which really enlivened the classroom. If you want to be an active participant and learn to engage with material as it applies to the real world, take him!
Easy. Got to class, read cases. Ryan is really fun to listen to.

One of the best professors I've had. Really changes the way you think, I recommend taking any class by him. He makes you read the NY Times which seems difficult at first but is so valuable, still read it to this day

My very first Upper Division class.  Although challenging, he really brings out the best in students, challenges us - makes us think outside the box.  Perhaps cliche, its the truth.  He doesn't want students to believe what professors tells us, he wants them to find out for themselves.  Amazing, BEST PROFESSOR I've had at UCSC. Thanks Ryan.
Ryan is AMAZING! Best professor ever. Is there anything he can't do or doesn't know!? He give practical and real advice. He's smart and genuinely cares about his students. And such a cutie!

The lectures were disorganized and the material each lecture was incohesive, there were no strong arguments made about the material as well in the class overall and the professor does not lecture but rather reads directly off of typed-up pages, she does not take questions during lecture either and does not take accommodations as well.

Melanie has a nice personality (as long as you don't do anything to distract her in class). With that being said, I felt uninterested in attending lecture as much of it felt moreso like an elaboration of U.S. history that I already had an idea of. But, she does try to do a good job in presenting the content in a nice way; super friendly to talk to!
Talk to her individually! She seems intimidating but is actually very sweet. Quizzes every week. Hardest part in my opinion are the papers.

She was knowledgable and her lectures were well-organized, honestly think the reading is average for a politics class, but if you're not a social science major it might be overwhelming. Need to put in effort to get an A, but not impossible. She could be mean, calling people out for small things (getting up for the bathroom/texting).

I took this class to fulfill a GE requirement which I would not recommend. Lots and lots of reading is assigned weekly. Professor Springer was a decent lecturer, but she is incredibly anal about disruptions in class. I found her reactions to small disruptions to be much more distracting than the disruptions themselves.

The best lectures I've experienced at UCSC. Her course was very fascinating. She does expect a lot from students, though. Make sure you participate, keep up with readings, and don't procrastinate on papers.

Prof Springer offered a clear grading scale and the class is easy if you took a government class in high school. Her final essay was open-ended but she assigned it to us 4 days earlier so we had a lot more time to do it then we should've so I don't understand the other reviewer. Really nice and lectures are all recorded so you go at your own pace.
one of worst teachers ive ever had. annoying and cares way too much about some things

Easy class, think High School AP Government. You cover literally all the same topics. The only two marks against the prof is that she convinced me to buy a book you 100% don't need and refused make the final optional during a full blown race war instead offered a two day extension on the final paper and a snarky email.
Great professor, she is awesome. Assigns way too much unnecessary reading though.
I love Dr. Springer! She is so kind, and amazing.

I took 120B in spring and 128 this Fall. She is super enthusiastic and loves when her students care too. Shes a really fair grader so I dont think she would change anyones grade or bump anyone but study a little, ask for help from TAs in 120, review your notes and actually pay attention in class and both classes are an easy A.

Dr. Springer is amazing.  She explains the material very well.  As long as you pay attention to the lectures and read, her tests are a breeze.  What she says in lectures is more important, than what is on the slides.  She is very engaging and likes to get to know her students.  I 100% recommend taking a class of hers.

An excellent lecturer.  Attend class and take amazing notes and you will get a great grade.  Everything you need to know is straight from the readings and lectures. She's passionate about the material and it shows during class.  She does not post slides lectures so class attendance is a must.  Great smile too.

Lectures are dry and rarely correlate with the required readings. Readings are boring! Uses slideshows during lectures  but what she says is more important than what is on the slides. The class felt more like a history class than anything else. Also, her paper prompts are so vague,not a fan of her style and will avoid taking another class with her.

Ive take poli 128 and 120, elections and her democracy class. Election was amazing, very cool material, easy midterm and papers if you actually payed attention in class. ALL YOU NEED TO DO IS WRITE DOWN EVERYTHING SHE SAYS IN CLASS! You can easy do both papers based on her lectures. 120 was disappointing, boring material. Felt like a history class.

It was clear that it was her first quarter teaching.  The class was supposed to be about American Political Development with regard to race, class & gender, but we rarely talked about those issues which was disappointing.  Seemed a lot like a high school AP US History class the way she taught it.  Not a fan of her teaching style.

She was my favorite professor so far! I heard she is a hard grader, but I got my essay revised a few times (for free, on campus and by peers) and received a high A. In my opinion, your grade reflects how much effort you apply. WARNING: She doesn't put her slides up online and she talks quite fast. Don't hesitate to tell her to repeat something.

Tough Class. She's a super tough grader and not very helpful. She's looking for very specific things in your writing and you HAVE to buy into it. The TA grades everything except the final paper. Class itself is just 1 paper a midterm and. Like I said, tough class, know what you're getting in to.

Professor Springer just started teaching at UCSC this quarter and she is amazing! This class is fairly designed for anyone who is interested in learning about elections and voting in the U.S. There was 1 in class midterm, 1 take home midterm essay and 1 final take home essay, attendance and participation is required-she takes attendance randomly!

Hiroshi is super invested in his subject matter, his lectures are well thought out and he is always happy to answer questions. This would be great if the two papers and presentation the entire class is based on were actually based on class material. Your entire grade is based on three group projects on the same topic of your choosing.

If you don't NEED this class, do NOT take it. Incredibly smart and well qualified professor but very hard to hear (soft spoken), very boring lectures with no engagement at 8 am. Talks at you for an hour and a half, it is ALL group work, everything except the midterm and final test. TA makes class really easy.

His lectures were SO BORING. dude needs to retire asap. He is pretty dense lecturer, only talking at you but this is the easiest upperdiv ever. The TA is an easy grader and the two exams were all based on the practice kahoot. Do not take this class unless necessary bc you will fall asleep during lecture lol. You will def get an A tho.

Professor Fukurai is extremely intelligent and respected. He has to be one of the most caring professors I have had. He is understanding of our situations and is lenient if you have to miss lectures. The only component of our grade was our group project which consisted of a group essay and presentation that ended up becoming optional.

Super caring professor, that will help you outside of class. All work in this class was group work, including the 8% of extra credit offered. 2 multiple choice tests that were fairly straightforward. Lectures are a bit dense cuz he doesn't make it a discussion. But, overall, good experience that you can def get an A in if you attend and do E.C.

He likes group projects, which bring their own issues, but I loved this class. We had two exams and two papers for the class, and they were all very doable. He's pretty lenient on his grading and very supportive of his students. He loves class engagement. He is a bit tangential, but I think that added to the charm of his class.

The professor and the content of this course are amazing! However, I hated the amount of group work. Also, my TA was essentially inaccessible outside of class or the discussion section. Do all the extra credit it will save your grade.

Professor Fukurai was overall a great professor. He assigns a lot of readings weekly but if you can manage them okay you'll be fine on exams. My biggest frustration was the group paper & accompanying project, but if you have a solid group you should be fine. Didn't use Canvas which sucked. Lectures were good and he was very responsive to emails.

I loved his class! His lectures were so interesting and I loved when he talked about his life and research. There was a lot of reading, but it was some of my favorite stuff I read in college that I still think about. The exams were fairly hard and didn't feel like a great measurement of learning, but everything else about the class was fantastic.

hiroshi makes us do everything in groups and since everything is online, it made the class awful. A group paper, group presentation, and exam. pick one!! & his exams are so unnecessarily tricky. ta was useless. hiroshi is smart but lectures are really boring, and i could not for the life of me stay awake. first sociology class i did not enjoy.

Fukurai is an incredibly knowledgable professor. His lectures are straight-forward and somewhat boring, though he has his moments of hilarity. Go to class, do the work, and you'll get an A. Study guides are long and tedious, but useful. Readings are somewhat optional, you'll get the most of the class if you read though.

He's a very interesting guy. His lectures are interesting; however, his teaching style isn't interactive so you may get bored. Makes you do all your work in groups, which can either be good or bad. Midterm and final are super tricky. Study, read, look over notes, and link up with class mates. Tests are hard!!

One of the best at UCSC, he really cares about the students and is very passionate in what he teaches. He assigns a decent amount of readings but goes over them in his lectures. Put in the effort and you will earn an A.  I wish ucsc had more faculty like him. The best !
Do your extra credits and you will get an A!

Highly recommended, tons of extra credit and interesting material. Awesome lecturer! 1 midterm, 1 final, 1 concept paper and 1 final paper (15 pages) only thing I didn't like about the class was the required team work ( you have to partner up for all class work).
Great personality, excellent lecturer!

Professor Fukurai is  a very  knowledgeable person. He is  nice and willing to help all the students. He likes that all students participate during his lectures.  Do the Reading, tricky questions midterms and final.  He gives a lot of extra credit during the course, use them all. One midterm 25 questions and one final 25 questions. 10 P final paper

By far the best teacher I've ever had. He is an amazing mentor and the students of UCSC are lucky to have him. I couldn't have wished for a more amazing Professor to teach and mentor me during my time at UCSC!
Hiroshi comes off as a hard teacher, but he gives SO much opportunity for extra credit, this class is an easy A if you put the work in.

Professor Fukurai is passionate about what he teaches, it's hard not to become inspired by his lectures. I took Race and Law, he wrote one of our text books and I found it really interesting. Two tests, not cumulative, two papers, one is 3 pages MAX. I read and did all assignments, but really enjoyed the course and its material.

It's easy to get an A in his class if you attend (he posts the slides for each lecture; however, they don't make sense without his explanation of the content, as the slides are mainly pictures and short bullet points). DON'T FALL BEHIND! (Honestly, it's so hard to catch up if you fall behind because there is so much content.)

Professor Landis was a great lecturer who made use of class time in a very efficient way. He had all lectures recorded and utilized his TAs effectively. I would recommend this class to anyone who wants exposure to American politics in a well-structured way. The tests are engaging if you do the reading and attend the sections.

super engaging professor! his lectures are really easily digestible and a lot of your grade comes from participation during class. only a couple of short papers that were mostly argumentative or opinion pieces and graded accordingly. really cool guy!

Prof. Landis is super funny and makes complicated topics much easier to understand. He does not show political bias and views politics rationally and through a historical lens. Tests were challenging but pay attention, rewatch lectures, and take notes.
Nice but can be bias when lecturing on his views

Landis makes American political concepts super easy to understand for someone with no background in politics. Incorporates humor into lectures which makes topics less boring. Grade is heavily based off section attendance and exams so make sure you go to lecture, study the material well, and don't slack. 10/10 TA, prof, and class.
lectures aren't bad and his grading is decent, seems like a nice guy

This prof is outstanding. There's a lot of reading, but she breaks it down in class and the topics are all relevant to things happening in the world. It's also really obvious she cares about her students' success.
Best professor I've had at UCSC! Take her and you'll learn A LOT

I have Prof Nichols for my senior capstone and I've surprisingly loved the class. I wasn't that interested in property rights at first, but this class has changed that. The readings are dense, but she breaks them down & is very knowledgeable. I'm actually enjoying writing my paper.
Amazing prof who will make you work but keep you interested. Really really smart woman. I'm impressed!

professor nichols is clearly extremely knowledgeable and passionate about all of her subject matter. if a class she is teaching is something you are very interested in, you will learn so much. if you're not super into it, it can be pretty overwhelming as she is a bit intense. lots of reading, lots of lecturing, required attendance.

She was nice and understanding, her lectures were often boring, and she usually read directly off the slides really fast, had to have lecture slides pulled up to follow on. Good class that sometimes got confusing with concepts that seemed outside the scope of the class (economics stuff).

Nichols is an incredibly engaging lecturer. She never reads from notes like so many others and just knows the topic. She always makes it relevant to what's going on in the world, which makes it easier to understand abstract concepts.

Overall, Nichols didn't explain course concepts to the understanding of the students - she kinda bulldozed. We had one essay, one midterm, one final, some random extra assignments, but lecture and section attendance mandatory. she explained better during the midterm review than any other class, and she focused too much on econ w/out explaining it.

It felt like she was just there to supervise us teaching each other course concepts, which was cool ig. Very reading heavy with reading responses due every class. Nichols was behind on grading and didn't provide much guidance on writing our capstone papers. 2-3 classes were actually dedicated to our capstones. She's a good prof, just disorganized.
She is a brilliant woman who understands politics inside and out. This was one of my favorite classes at UCSC. I highly recommend taking her if you want to learn. Expect to put in work though.

Painfully obvious about her political biases. Never provides a sense of open-endedness to her course concepts, instead just always steering you towards accepting an alternative leftist view of the world. I'm totally pro educating people about leftist views, but it can't be the ONLY perspective presented for a topic as complex as international law.
Very knowledgeable and passionate about her work. This class was very interesting as well. The only downside is that her essay prompts are incredibly vague.

Dr. Nichols is incredibly knowledgeable and passionate about international politics. Unfortunately, we had insane essay prompts that were nearly three paragraphs long. No clear rubric for the essays, so the TAs made up their own, which was not shared with us. Grades weren't posted until almost end of quarter, so you're honestly guessing your grade.
Best professor I've had at UC or community college hands down!
She's an amazing educator. Interesting lectures & very knowledgeable. Take her and you won't regret it!

Dr. Nichols was super caring and understanding throughout the class. The grade is balanced so not one thing has too much weight, but the assignments are very doable and are pretty interesting. She herself also knows her stuff and it helps when working on assignments. Overall, super caring and chill. Open to offering extensions on a few things.

Excellent professor who is compassionate, extremely knowledgeable, and works with students who ask for support. If you are struggling, ask for help and she will give it to you! Has a lot of interesting to say during lecture, but you have to listen and take good notes since the slides are pretty much an outline of what she says. I highly recommend!
Great lecturer and has no problem helping you outside of class. Reading is a lot though.

Nichols can be a bit intimidating, but she is really passionate about international politics and the legal sector. I have taken two classes with her, and if you follow her feedback and instructions, you will do well. She is also really helpful if you schedule office hours. Class is mandatory and there were weekly assignments.

Wow, Professor Shawn gives me hope. One of the only professors I have encountered who will speak openly about the most controversial issues. They're extremely smart, and I feel inspired after listening to them lecture. The textbook assigned is crap and too expensive. But the class (human rights) has been excellent.

This professor is really chill very accommodating it is easy to do well I would just rec studying for midterms and finals but hes super chill super accessible and a good prof in general. dont believe the hate. he does have kind of a boring voice but hes still super good

Honestly, this man has been so sweet. You can tell he really wants his students to succeed, even adding vocational minutes to his lectures to help students with things that do not involve his class at all (such as how to write a professional email, and opportunities at UCSC). He is the type of teacher to blame himself if the students don't do well.

Respectfully, I would never take this class again or recommend it to anyone. The man stands there, talks to us for an hour and then expects us to understand. I'm not even sure if he understand either. He stands there reading a script and whenever someone asks a question he says he will have to research it. Further more he is a harsh grader.

The class was alright but one of the biggest cons was the fact that I could not see my grade the entire quarter, so I had no idea what I got until the end. It was really annoying to deal with and made me super anxious. He's very monotone and kind of boring so I stopped attending lectures after a while, which really did not affect my grade at all.
He does not like teaching this class, and it is very apparent in his lectures. The papers did not really help with anything, they were just tedious.

I really wouldn't take this class with him if you can avoid it. Lectures are excruciating to sit through, and he is not passionate about the subject at all. The writing assignments don't help you understand the material. He also seems a bit conservative and never took a side or expressed any opinion or really emotion at all.

Its clear that this professor and its TA's are taking over a class that was built and designed by someone else. He seems almost just as lost as the students when it comes to preparing and explaining the weekly assignments and how they meet up into the final essay. The course would be easy if he took more time to make sure the directions were clear

I am not sure if I caught him in the wrong quarter.  But he wasn't that accessible and not responsive. And the poor guy is mono-toned, so it was very hard to stay engaged during the lectures. I will say that many people, including me, reached out to him after the final grades were posted with questions and concerns and the man never responded lol

This class felt like a great foundation for the rest of my learning at UCSC. It's well organized with clear grading. I really liked the final project which is a long essay that you do a paragraph of each week. There is a lot of necessary reading but you can partially skim. Fairly easy weekly quizzes, midterm, and final if you do the work.

What a great prof! Very clear and makes sure students have plenty of opportunities to ask questions. Gives great study guides too! Graded by 2 exams, 1 essay (1000 -1250 words), and participation. Everything is pretty easy and he is very helpful if anyone is struggling. Definitely recommend!

Newsome is a solid professor. He is straightforward and knowledgable. There's not much else I can say because I didn't interact with him directly very much. But his class was great and interesting! Be prepared to do a lot of reading and writingit's not bad at all as long as you don't procrastinate.

Professor Newsome is a great teacher. He is incredibly reasonable and makes sure to account for outside events going on and change his assignments accordingly. You can tell he really cares and wants you to succeed. All tests ,quizzes and writing assignments are very straight forward.
well so far is not a good instructor, don't have what it need to be one, also don't have a class plan everything is random I wont take any class with him...

super nice teacher. tests were generally easy especially if you already have learned or have a background in spanish. provides interactive exercises with classmates to help you with speaking in spanish. very fair and straightforward tests too!! if u put in some effort, you will definitely do well! :D

Loved this class. It was pretty easy. If you actually do the homework and study the vocabs then you shouldn't have trouble passing this class with an A. The online hw could be time consuming but it helped a lot. Oh, I had to spend $160 on the hw code of the "book". Overall, this class was fun. It was his first time teaching Spanish. Not bad at all.
boring and confusing
Class was super manageable and fairly easy; about 5 assignments due per week but they do not take very long to complete. Professor gave great feedback and clear instructions on course material
This class was awful please do not take it.
So much homework, unclear and unhelpful feedback from both TAs and the professor. Video assignments almost every week and super boring.

This class was honestly not that bad. A lot of people are being dramatic in these responses lol. Yes it is homework heavy and i do believe the homework should be reduced, but the teacher is very funny and the course is generally interesting. The grading is tough and strict for such an easy concept but as long as you follow the rules you should beok

This is the worst class. Extremely long assignments that are confusing, stupid, and boring. This class could be a lot more simple, but it feels like they are trying to make it hard for no reason. The work is so specific that I have to read each assignment for an hour just to figure out what to do. Grading is super tough. NEVER take this class.
So many assignments lol. Not very interesting. Useless languages. Unknown languages. Learning to speak also gibberish. Be ready to spend more time on this class than on your STEM classes. good luck

Took asynchronous and didn't watch a single lecture, everything was doable with his instructions + his sources, and the internet. I still got a little bit out of the course since basic linguistics is pretty interesting, but he taught nothing. Lectures were way too long and unengaging.

Took his online Ling 50 class, while lecture was just recordings, sections were mandatory to attend via Zoom/in person. He was very nice and reasonable when it came to his assignments/content load. Lots of lecture watching/readings, while you could very well get by with just going one or the other.

Watch the lecture videos and read the textbook and you'll do fine. I will say there's a lot of work but it's not hard just make sure you check the to-do list often. I thought the lectures were interesting and he explained things well, he and his TAs were very easy to contact.
I took this class because I thought it would be exciting. It wasn't. The professor relied heavily on aides for grading, he wasn't really accessible. Boring professor.

Not a bad class to take on its own but if you already have a hard course load, would probably recommend not taking this class. Lots of pre recorded videos and quizzes with 2 attempts. What you learn depends on how much effort you put in. Multiple group projects but the work is easy and staff is accommodating for any related challenges.

This class consisted of mainly busy work, the weekly tests were the only consistent assignments most weeks. This is just a class taught by someone who doesn't care about students if you do the work your grade will be good, but don't take this class if you actually want to learn about language. I have taken several online classes and this the worst.
Lots of videos but learned a lot
very fast response time

Might be the most frustrating classes I've taken. Mostly busywork for the homework and quizes but having to create and understand a made up language that will just poof out of existence at the end of the quarter is not exactly motivating. I wouldn't recommend this class to anyone unless you care about languages nobody actually speaks.

I don't recommend taking this class unless linguistics is your major. It is a lot of busy work and you have to make a fake language with your class and final project is to translate it (very confusing). Strict guidelines and one online meeting is mandatory. I suggest taking easier GE classes rather than this one.

Do not take his class unless you need it for your major. The lectures were not helpful, and we spent most of the quarter learning IPA, which is useless. The way he organized the Canvas modules was also extremely confusing, and it made it hard to figure out what assignments I needed to finish.

don't like conlangs? stay away. you're going to have more homework because there are no lectures (duh). Most of the time you can use the transcript for the lengthy videos. AI and discord help a ton. ur given a whole week to do short but tedious quizzes. I highly recommend taking this. recommend ling50 beforehand if ur new to linguistics -a freshman

There's so much homework for creating a made-up language that no one is going to use in the future, and the videos he assigns to help with the homework do not even correlate whatsoever. The class as a whole is a joke. Don't even take it because all the quizzes you can take once and it won't even help you at all.

This class is new but interesting. There is simple coding involved, but easy enough to understand. The course is easy and interesting as long as these are topics you find interesting. Pranav is a great prof and is very helpful.

One of the best classes I've taken, teaches you semantics without being overwhelming with workload. Pranav and TAs were understanding and happy to answer questions, and assignments directly reflected class content. Discussions are mandatory, and "exams" are basically longer homework assignments. Awesome class, I learned a lot!!

Pranav is fricking amazing. He's a great prof and a great person who actually cares about his students. I enjoyed this class so, so much, not just because of the material but also because Pranav is genuinely such an amazing prof to have. I took this as a GE and class to fulfill major requirements, and I highly recommend it!

i love this class due to the prof, he is so passionate about semantics and really wants you to understand. if you pay attention, go to section and office hours, and ask questions you'll do great in this class.

Lots of busy work and things to learn, so don't expect an easy course, but he still made the work very interesting. If you like puzzles and logical reasoning, you might like this. Feels like you need to know some linguistics before taking, but I scratched by without. Lectures were clear and engaging! Expect group work too!

Pranav Anand's invented languages class is one of the coolest I have taken. In Spring '22 my class invented a space whale language, and it was lots of fun. There are lots of little assignments to keep up with, but totally worth it if you are interested in linguistics. Very cool and informative lecture videos (that are not super long either).

Anand is a fantastic professor and really shows that he cares about his students and the course material! However, the class shouldn't really be considered a "lower-division" course because you have to learn almost the entirety of linguistics just to understand the class (ie. TONS of hw). Get ready to work if you plan on taking this class...

Pranav is extremely accessible/helpful online, and he clearly has a lot of passion & knowledge in what he teaches. This class in particular had a lot of work each week that was very laborious yet straightforward and sometimes fun. His grading was meticulous but very fair. You'll have to learn all linguistics basics to pass, so keep that in mind.

If you're looking for an easy A for GE's this is not for you. You can succeed if you actually put in the work. Pranav definitely moves very quickly but if you genuinely pay attention it'll be fine. Each of the 3-6 weekly quizzes you take will MAKE OR BREAK your grade. Plenty of opportunities for extra credit, professor is very helpful. Loved it!

Pranav is a really caring professor! He is very accessible via office hours etc. but this class should definitely not be taken if you want to take an easy GE. Lots of lectures, lots of homework and is pretty complex.

The class is pretty easy and only took about 2-3 hours per week for most of the class. I have no experience with linguistics but that wasn't a problem. There is group work but they are pretty simple assignments. Our class had an official discord where the professor was very active and helpful. Due dates and instructions on canvas were very clear.

Took it as an asynchronous course expecting it to be fairly easy as it fulfills the textual analysis GE requirement. However, the grading criteria from the multiple quiz assignments each week was not worth it. He answers questions that do not even provide an answer, and he expects you to already know certain terminology for linguistics already.

This class was fine, but as a non-linguistics major it was a little difficult at times but not impossible. The work was manageable but could feel like a lot at times. If you have no interest in linguistics I wouldn't necessarily take the course. The prof was pretty nice and accessible when you need him.

This class should not be an introduction GE that non-linguistics majors can take. It has so much homework and you basically have to learn all of the linguistics basics to pass. The professor was cool, I had no real problem with him. He's very passionate and clear when he lectures. I do think he can cut back a little on the assignments, however.

This professor doesnt accept any late work and give an insane amount of homework each week. One thing I appreciate though is that we can work together with classmates. Nice professor but really tough for an intro class. Kind of unbelievable.

Professor Anand is great, but the class itself is extremely difficult for a GE. If you have no experience with Linguistics, DON'T take this class. Anand is really nice and super into the content of the class, but the material and work is def geared towards people with a linguistic background. This class should be an upper division course, not a GE!

Pranav is amazing. This class is a lot of work but it's not that hard and if you find it interesting then it's a really fun class. Beware the group work but otherwise he's a great lecturer, answers questions well, and really knows what he's talking about. He makes linguistics interesting and understandable.

I took this class as GE thinking "oh cool invented languages". But this stuff feels way over my head as I am an ENVS major who has never taken a linguistics class before. Yes, it is a very interesting a fascinating subject, however not an easy GE and should honestly be an upper-division course.

My class was made so much better by Pranav's attitude towards the subject. He truly cares and is enthusiastic about linguistics. If you like a well-structured class that allows you to nerd-out I highly suggest taking one of his courses.

The class itself is a lot of work, especially for an online course, but Prof. Anand is a great professor. Lectures are easy to understand and aren't always full of complicated terminology. Definitely a good option for the TA GE and I learned a lot!

Fun, engaging lectures. Assignments are rare with VERY lenient deadlines and online quizzes have 2 attempts. You have a week for the open note take-home final. Be careful with the phonology unit, it's the most confusing. Free textbook. Spent 2h/week MAX and expect to finish with A or A+. Take this for your GE reqs. Professor is interesting/kind. :)

I've had Grant for a few courses, and also worked with him as a research assistant. Absolutely amazing professor. Not usually a ton of homework, and none of them are too difficult, but you do need to put in real effort to do well. Quizzes aren't too tough either. Lectures are super interesting, and he always try's to make them fun.  10/10.

Grant was very accommodating throughout the quarter when classes are held online because of the coronavirus. He dropped a homework grade and made the final more lenient. The online course style was manageable, the homework assignments were straightforward and he prepared us for it. If you don't get the homework, office hours were really helpful.

This class is a great choice for a GE. You can skip a few lectures and be OK, but his lectures are sometimes fun when you do go. There is a lot of heavy reading assigned, but the questions on them are pretty straight forward. Graded on a few quizzes, 2 papers, and reading responses. He's a nice dude with a chill class.

There are short reading quizzes that you do for homework for every reading and they are about 3 questions. Then you have quizzes for each section, I think there was around 5-6 total. There are two essays that are out of 15 points, and there's a good variety to choose from. Lecture is a little boring, but review the slides and you will be fine.

I didn't think he went deep enough into the subject matter of Language, Society, and Culture. I was expecting more tough conversations about current events/issues and I was consistently let down and bored. It was an easy A, though, so I can't be upset. I stopped going to class after I turned in the second of 2 required essays.

This class was super easy. There are reading responses so you have to somewhat read but all the readings are on canvas, no textbook! There are canvas quizzes after each section and 2 papers total (6-8 pages). The subject is also super interesting and Professor McGuire is a good instructor so it makes the class even better.
He was an awesome professor!

Loved Grant! This was a pretty easy class. 8 online quizzes with your lowest score dropped, and a take-home final. Theres a moderate amount of textbook reading, but if you go to lecture and sections, you don't really need to stress about it. I usually skimmed the chapters by the end of the course. Final is take home. A good class to take care of GE

Grant is by far the best professor to take for this course! He's nice and is willing to teach and help you if you ask. He sometimes brings his dog to class, which is another plus! Homework: turn in 4 out of the 7 Online quizzes: 6/7 quizzes Section and lecture: mandatory Experiment: easy 3% Exams: 2 in class and final was take home

Grant is everything you wish for in a professor, he is enthusiastic, very knowledgeable about the subject, and encourages new ideas and conversation (yes, in lecture). He is a very fair grader and very helpful and understanding. Really interesting lectures and concepts I never would have guessed could be studied. Far from a dull professor.

not the best professor.. if you're looking for an interesting ling course he is not your guy. he has a strange interest in caddying and reggae that he uses in all his lectures which make entirely no sense. worst class of all time.... if your looking to pass, do not take!
Awesome professor. Fairly easy class. Lots of memorization but pretty easy. The lectures were pretty interesting and you can tell he really enjoys Linguistics.
class basically set up for you to fail

Grant's lectures were interesting especially the random youtube videos and other fun things.  His slides were sometimes over filled with words, making them hard to read but otherwise his lectures were informative and entertaining.

McGuire is an awesome professor and makes learning about linguistics extremely interesting. Definitely take this course if you get him as a professor! There are weekly quizzes that are super easy as long as you attend the lectures regularly. Everything that is on the quiz is discussed and explained clearly in class. The T.A's are also very helpful.

Grant definitely keeps the class entertaining with his youtube examples and randomly ultrasounding his own tongue. His lectures were online but going to class was definitely worth the extra effort. Section is mandatory, and the book is ridiculously expensive for minimal use. I enjoyed this class, & it's mandatory for my Language Studies major.

Grant's an okay dude. His slides and examples can be fun/funny, but he basically reiterates everything the reading says in his lectures. i.e. If you did the reading and took notes you will fall asleep! I used to be worried about missing class in case he said something that wasn't in the book but now I know better.

Grant is an excellent professor.  The class will be very interesting if you are interested in learning more about phonetics.  The homeworks are fairly easy but the midterm and final will be more challenging than the homeworks, though not impossible.  Pay attention in class, especially to the acoustics unit as that can be the most confusing.

This was by far the best ling class I've taken. It was very interactive with lots of noise production (trying to make ejectives, implosives, clicks, and sounds not made in english)My favorite part was that he would show many relevent videos clips and play around with praat.Not a class to miss if you are interested in speech production and phonetics
ryan creates a super comfortable classroom environment and lectures are engaging and easy to follow. phonology was always one of the highlights of my week.
I learned a lot and he was a fun professor. Every week there is an assignment (an essay) and a dense reading.

The homework questions can seem hard, but if you use the lecture slides and the readings, they aren't very hard. However, some of them he does require you to find your own outside source if you want full credit. But there isn't a midterm and no quizzes throughout the quarter. Your grade is mostly just the homework, and there is only 1 per week.

Ryan made what could have easily been a terribly boring class really enjoyable. Everything was well paced in that homework and tests really built on each other. He was very approachable and highly responsive to emails. Great sense of humor and made tons of jokes throughout lectures. If I have the chance, I'd take any of his classes again.

Lectures are info heavy but very engaging/easy to follow & he posts the slides for you to look at on your own. The majority of your grade is from take-home quizzes that are open-note and aren't too difficult, and most of the rest is from the final, which is essentially just a longer cumulative version of the quizzes. Highly recommend, learned a lot

I can't begin to state how much I appreciated his teaching style. Very clear with what is expected of you, lectures are very passion-driven and engaging, and quizzes are overly fair, allowing you to take advantage of your notes and resources. I will be taking up a minor in linguistics because of this class, and I can't reccomend it enough!

The online quizzes make up most of the grade and they're not that hard at all if you pay attention to his lectures or look at the slides before or during the quiz (which he allows). His lecture videos are a bit on the longer side but if you just power through them you'll be in a good position in the class. Would highly recommend taking his classes!

95% of the grade comes from online quizzes (80%) and an online final (15%). Going to classes would help you understand concepts. Review lecture slides before taking the quizzes/final, and you will likely earn good grades. Good luck!

He does lecture fast, but he posts the lecture slides on canvas so it's not a big deal. The material that's covered is honestly pretty dry but he does a great job of making lecture a lot more entertaining. An interesting thing is that 80% of the grade consists of take-home/open-note quizzes, and they're surprisingly not that easy.

Nice guy, but teaching style (i.e. lecture slides ) is repetitive, dull, and disengaging. Quizzes are 80% of your grade, and become harder and harder as the quarter progresses. Class notes and textbook readings don't prepare you enough to successfully complete the quizzes.

Hes just a good teacher! I really appreciated how thorough he was in lectures, but it can be kinda hard to keep up because he goes really fast. That said, he posts the notes, which is super helpful, and he and the TAs were always really good with office hours and stuff. You can tell he really wants people to learn.

Ryan is really smart. He kept lectures engaging, but also really fast paced. The lecture slides are posted online, but I would recommend going to class for clarification. You have online quizzes each week and a take home final. If you go to his office hours, go with questions. Overall, he's a great guy and an awesome professor; I learned so much!

I loved Prof Walker. She is super sweet and has a lot of knowledge. She is very caring and wants the best for her students. Lectures were pretty entertaining. The midterm and final were administered on canvas. She was very flexible and very easy to talk to. There is extra credit opportunities through SONA and through assignments the TA's assign.

Professor Walker is an amazing teacher! Her lectures are well structured and slides are easy to follow. Weekly quizzes are based on the readings and lecture, and midterm and final were open book. Course was interesting and the professor was very open to answering questions.

He is such a genuine person. As long as you watch the lectures and ask questions in section you should be good. The class consisted of 8 quizzes, one final exam, a research project, and participation in section. He only counts 7 of the 8 quizzes so your lowest score doesn't count.

DO NOT TAKE LING50 (with brasoveanu) IF YOU DON'T HAVE TO. I just took this for the GE credit. There's no homework but there is mandatory section and weekly quizzes. And towards the end, it won't be on quizlet. I regret taking this class. Requires too much work and you'll be in a class with 95% linguistics majors. Not worth it just for the GE.

Dr. Brasoveanu is fine at teaching, but if you have DRC accommodations, be prepared for a fight. Getting reasonable accommodations for a DRC-recognized disability should never be a struggle, but for whatever reason, Dr. Brasoveanu has repeatedly refused my requests, even after getting the DRC involved.
An interesting class taught by a great professor. One of the only classes I have taken that I dont want to end. The professor is inspiring, organized, methodical and wants students to learn.

I took this for summer session and since it was a 5 week course the material was condensed. There are a total of three assignments. He does VERY similar examples to the homework in class. You have to keep going to class because the material he teaches is complicated otherwise. I would recommend making study groups to work on the assignments.

It's important that you go to lecture because the material is confusing without his help. Also, If you have any questions he is extremely helpful. Adrian is one of the nicest teacher I've ever had. There's no final- Just five homework assignments and the last week of class you just mess around. Awesome teacher and great man!

Adrian is adorable!! You can tell how much he likes teaching Ling because of how much he giggles during lecture. He's also just a really nice guy and cares about his students. There's no midterm or final, just homework, so if you check your homework with a TA or someone who knows the subject well, there's no reason to not get an easy A.

There's no textbook and he doesn't post lecture notes online (everything is on a chalkboard) so if you don't go to class, you're basically screwed. Adrian moves really fast in lecture sometimes but he's totally fine with students taking pictures of his notes with their phones, and if you ask questions he'll give more thorough explanations.
He explains the steps when solving a problem well. There was no textbook, so lectures are the only way to learn.

This class is not like learning a language! His accent is hard to understand and goes to fast to take good notes. Though i was gonna major in linguistics but the lectures were boring and I fell asleep in class multiple times. i hated how the 10 tests and quizzes were online and on your own time instead of during class. Not flexible about  deadlines

Adrian is an amazing professor. He's funny and engaging, as well as really informative about what he's talking about. You can tell he enjoys what he's teaching, which made going to class all the better! He also really cared about what the students needed and would take the time to clarify anything we asked.  100% recommend him to anyone!

Adrian is the cutest man!! His giggles are infectious. When he has a good time, you have a good time (and he always has a good time!). Very helpful and spends extra time for clarification. Accommodates due dates to fit the class' understanding of the  material, but Semantics 1 is a pretty basic level. Great prof, easy A. Take this class :)!

Adrian is an all right professor.  He can be unclear at times, but the material is ridiculously easy.  Adrian spends too much time explaining simple concepts, but this may be due to the nature of Semantics 1 as it is meant to be geared toward new Ling. students.  The class is very easy and Adrian's teaching style excels in more complicated classes.

I took Semantics 1 with Adrian and I absolutely LOVE him. He has the cutest accent and when he gets excited he does this little giggle that is amazing. Super interesting class. If you go to class and take notes, you should be able to get an A no problem!
Great professor making clear what is so opaque in the readings. Very enthousiastic. Complex concepts are explained in a way that makes sense. Don't take this class if you didn't LOVE semantics I.

hrmm..  well he was pretty enthusiastic but he seemed to kind of wing class as he went along. his grading was no good. no tests, but everything depended on hw and attendance which could easily screw someone over for a few honest mistakes.

Adrian is so cute! He'll make the dorkiest linguistics jokes that no non-ling majors understand. Cool guy. Easy class (at least compared to other upper divs in the major). Manageable workload. Just try to be engaged and you'll enjoy it.

Wow, if you're not majoring in Language or Linguistics, don't attempt this class. He may as well be speaking Greek. Everything seems to come from the readings but these are highly technical and confusing if you do not have some background.
From the accent to the vigorous hair pulling and chalk board action, he is all together rad. His humor and boundless enthusiasm will make you smile.

He is the sweetest, funniest, most adorable professor i've had! Possibly my favorite professor so far in my college career. The class isn't impossible, but not too easy either. Adrian is really passionate about linguistics, and his exams are open note! He is not one to budge about grades though. I loved this class! oh, and he had a cute accent.

Good lecturer. Have to show up to sections to retain a lot of what you learn. Getting a good TA can make or break this class. Ivy is clearly very knowledgeable. Had someone in my lecture who just asked nonstop questions every single lecture. Ivy took the time to answer all of them as genuinely as they could. Clearly cares about course/students.

You cannot do well in this class without going to lecture and section, everything is taught there. Assignments require a lot from you, but they grade on your effort & explanations rather than correctness. I really struggled with deadlines/falling behind and Ivy was super gracious and let me catch up.

Ivy is extremely knowledgeable and wants students to understand linguistics, but you need to take initiative to engage with the course material as it comes and reach out during office hours if you slip behind.

She's just so bland and boring. Her lectures always made me sleepy, and she never really taught the material or explained or expanded it; she just goes off her slides. We have weekly quizzes on Thursdays, and she only releases the slides then, so it's super annoying. She doesn't give the impression that she cares about her students either.

The lectures were long, and most information was in the slides. Slides and section handouts were necessary for the quizzes. It was very quiz-heavy. Ask your TAs for help and go to the section. The only reason I learned was through my TA. Ivy was very confrontational and not apologetic when proven to be at fault. Best of luck if you still choose her

Took this for a GE and would not take Ivy again. Lectures were scattered all over the place and were very hard to follow. I usually am an active participant in my lectures, but the way these lectures were structured was not at all engaging. Students were falling asleep in class. Slides would always turn off midway through lecture.

Please don't do what I did and ignore the reviews written about her here, if this is a class you wanna take for a GE, don't do it.  Quizzes are so confusing and that's all your grade relies on. She also accuses people of cheating and using Chat GPT . Overall rude and not helpful professor.
Long lectures, good person tho

I made the mistake and took this course to fulfill my MF GE, and I regret it. Ivy was in my opinion not very good at describing the basic understanding of the course, luckily my TA was helpful, made it easier for me to understand what this course was even about. AND they put new material in the HW before you even learn it. It is a backward course.

Instructions on homework are really difficult to understand and unnecessarily over complicated. Lectures are really fast-paced and sections don't help. The course is really backwards and they introduce new material in the homework yet don't review it until after it's due. Barely passed the class and everyone was so lost during the whole course.

Great class to take for a gen ed IMO. Her class is extremely straightforward, all assignments are outlined in the syllabus, ~2 readings and a quiz per week that is directly covered in the material. Papers, midterm, & final also take directly from lectures and readings. All multiple choice. Just go to lectures and discussions and you'll be fine.

Took this class as a GE and it was more work than I thought it would be. The class is passable and the material wasn't hard. The professor seems nice but would just make it hard to grasp since she would go to fast in lecture and not record it. I disliked her teaching style more than Garfield disliking Mondays. Section is important to attend.

Unless you're a linguistics you'll probably do fine in this class but if you're taking it for a GE, just don't. If you're trying to avoid math make sure you don't get Ivy because she is a tough grader, only lets you take the weekly quizzes once, as well as the midterms, and she is very unapproachable. There is no room for error in this class.

I've never cried so much from a college course. She made so many assumptions about student's knowledge of non-prereq courses, which left many in the dust. She is highly confrontational and defensive if you ask her almost any question. She embarrasses students in class for questions they ask. Homework was unbelievably difficult. Don't do it.

I wouldn't take a class with Ivy if you value your mental health. No joke, broke down multiple times because of this class. Readings long but necessary to understand ANYTHING, lectures have no content, handouts USELESS, and she says there's no stupid questions but then will make you look stupid in front of everyone when you ask for clarification.

Professor Ivy missed more classes than I did. If you do not read the difficult articles she assigns, then you cannot give a good discussion during class time - she can tell. She expects you to know about Morphology and Syntax so I advise to be proficient in those topics before taking a class with Ivy.
She has teachers pets that she treats nicely and others she is rude too. Ok teacher otherwise but disorganized.

I took Ling 50 with her, and it was 90% tests, 10% participation. First 7 weeks aren't bad, but then semantics and syntax really get you. I just takes more time to understand. My TA is the one that really taught me the material.
Easily one of the most interesting classes I have taken at UCSC. Prof is super smart and knowledgeable and willing to help if you ask. Lots of quizzes . Every word she says in class is fair game
Ivy is a great teacher that knows and loves linguistics. If this were my major I would love to take more classes with her.

very knowledgeable, caring, gave engaging lectures to try to "discover" the syntax of English. she and all the TAs were accessible and you can tell they all put effort into the class. definitely recommend taking this class!

Maziar Toosarvandani is a funny and kind professor; however, if you are taking Semantics because you think that it will be easy math GE, beware because it is not. Prepare to spend a lot of time on the weekly homework assignments and try to have friends in the class so you can work on assignments together. Lectures can be very confusing as well.

YOU WILL NOT PASS THIS CLASS UNLESS YOU MAKE FRIENDS. But that's a semantics thing, not a prof thing. My biggest critique was that he didn't teach some of the stuff that was on the final, which was stressful. TA based class. Be ready to lock in.

Maziar is fantastic, and I think it would've been very difficult to comprehend the class content without his high-energy teaching style. However, this class has been very confusing, as the students are expected to know some of the content before Maziar even teaches it. Be prepared to pay lots of attention and sign up for tutoring!

Maziar was always a delight in class! His lectures go fast but he usually answers everyone's question to make sure everyone's up to speed. An excellent first in-person linguistics class. Assignments every week, but as long as you're taking notes in class, they're not hard to keep up with.

He cares and is an amazing lecturer. He is truly a genius in his field. He can be a little awkward sometimes, but this does not take away from his teaching. Lectures have a tendency to go REALLY fast, so take as many notes as you can, and I might recommend snapping some pictures of important slides.

I took LING50 as a GE and found it to be very manageable! Lectures cover a majority of quiz content and he drops your lowest quiz (all mcq!). The three projects he has are very simple and you do not need a lot of linguistic experience to get good grades. Pay attention to definitions and the examples he mentions in class. Kind professor!

His lectures are very informative and he does his best to get people participating in class. No final or midterm, just small weekly quizzes that you can take twice and keep your best score. I took this for a GE and it was pretty easy, and I actually learned a lot of interesting stuff! I'd definitely recommend this teacher.

Maziar is great & is clearly very passionate about linguistics. Slideshows were always super organized. During lectures, he often gave students the opportunity to ask & answer questions. He also described concepts & illustrated them by providing real-world examples. These often included videos & in-class activities. Overall, would highly recommend!
One of the best teachers I've had. Super organized and lectures were very engaging. TAs were also very helpful in this class. I took into to ling w him
