Maziar is great, his teaching is fun, he always seems very passionate about teaching. he's great! he doesnt record his lectures, but provides slides, no midterm no final, weekly quzzes and a final project.. please take him if you get the chance :)

Maziar is the best!!!! I seriously couldn't say enough good things about this man. He is sharp as a diamond when lecturing and explains every concept very clearly and concisely. He also just has a nice voice and manner of speaking that makes class a breeze. I found predicate calculus pretty tolerable and sometimes even enjoyable as a result.

Literally the BEST professor you can take syntax with at UCSC! I am so grateful he taught LING112 this quarter, he actually made it easy to comprehend and dare I say a bit enjoyable! He was so understanding with my mental health issues I had going on too, I couldn't have asked for a better professor.

100% recommend getting a study group, it makes life so much easier. No finals or midterms, just one weekly assignment. His office hours are great, he explains any confusions that you may have. Sometimes lectures can be a bit confusing or can cause you to get zoned out very easily.

Maziar makes sure everyone gets a chance to speak during lecture - he starts off class with "Are there any questions?" There wasn't a textbook for Semantics 1, so we relied on Maziar's slideshows, which he was kind enough to post online, with notes. The weekly collaborative papers varied in difficulty, and section was mandatory (and helpful).

I feel like the words I'm about to use aren't as good as Maziar is as a professor, but here goes! Maziar is engaging and makes syntax interesting for his students. He's approachable, and if there is anything said in class that you do not understand he's always willingly available, present, and helpful during his office hours. He's open-minded, too.
Maziar was great. He was so excited about teaching all of us, it was awesome. It was a little frustrating that we couldn't figure out more on our own, but that's okay.

Maziar's a great professor. He knows what people are trying to say even when they are being less than clear. When we don't get something, he is able to approach the problem from another point. Maziar is one of the best professors I've had, and I'm not new to this school...Guess ling isn't so bad after all.

This is his first quarter at UCSC. Formerly taught at MIT and UCLA, but was unaware this class did not have prerequisites. Assumed students knew a lot of advanced linguistics material prior to this course. Challenging, but I don't think it's necessarily the professor's fault.

Amanda was so funny and entertaining during her lectures. She is obviously very passionate about her research and her students, and her class was ver manageable. I took ling 171 last spring and it was very chill! I hope everyone gets to take a class with her

Professor Rysling is one of my favorite professors ever. Although I'm not a Ling major, she reignited my interest in linguistics and made meaningful and helpful connections throughout. Her class was exceptionally easy and she made sure everyone understood. As long as you try, you'll pass. She welcomes all and makes sure you see her as an equal.

Amanda is by far one of my favorite professors, she always kept long lectures entertaining and she made sure students understood what she was teaching. She was very understanding and gave us short breaks mid-way through lecture. 3 short and easy homework assignments, easy quizzes every other week, and final was online.
I'm not generally a big fan of 3-hour summer zoom classes but Amanda was super chill and made the class I was only taking out of requirement very enjoyable

This was a fast moving class over 5 weeks in summer. Amanda has been an amazing professor and an inspiration; she is very helpful and understands where people get stuck even if they cant articulate it well. Anyone that wants to learn the material will get a lot of help but those that dont care wont get their hand held.

You have to read the required reading before coming to class or you'll not get the materials. Phonology was pretty difficult, and because of the TA that I got, I pretty much failed the first time around. This quarter I had a different TA and professor and learned more, honestly. But like others say, if your TA doesn't care, I would advice switching

Amanda isn't the best lecturer I've had at UCSC but she is awesome during office hours. She'll walk you through everything you need to know about the class and assignments but you have to ask the right questions. She is super intimidating but once you get over that she's super helpful. Also get a good TA, they can screw you over if they're bad.

Her teaching style is okay... but homework is usually graded extremely slow, to the point where you would have to turn in the next assignment without getting your papers back... Would help a lot if students actually get their feedback back so they can turn in the assignment with the necessary fixes.
Mostly based on reading, unless you get a good TA, you're not going to pass.

Phonology 1 was HARD, but I was so grateful to have Amanda walk me through it. Her office hours are so helpful and is willing to meet outside of class to help too. Do the homework assignments with a partner, and don't be afraid to ask Amanda questions. The class is tractable, but you have to put in the work. She's the best professor I've had here.

Sean Keilen singlehandedly restored my passion for studying Shakespeare and theatre in general with this class. All in-class discussions were very insightful and deep, but really depended on whether or not you'd read the texts. If you read, then you'll have the time of your life. But if you didn't, you'd be pretty lost. Loved being in class here!

Overall very thorough interpretation and depiction of Shakespeare, with very interesting in class analysis that got me to enjoy the plays and what is happening. The selection of the plays could have been slightly better, and I wish the class was a bit later in the day as the content is very involved. Well done though.

This professor is amazing. He gave me a love for Shakespeare that is so valuable to me now. His lectures are amazing. I cannot emphasize enough how great his Shakespeare class is, I would recommend this class to anyone. He does grade by only 4 assignments so make sure you spend a lot of time on them. Please take a class from him, he is great.

Don't graduate without taking at least one class with Sean. He's an incredible lecturer and presents the material in a clear way. He loves Shakespeare and appreciates slow, close reading. If you also want to have this same appreciation, give this class your all. Go to lectures, ask questions, and take time with the plays.

Keilen is very knowledgeable, however, as said by someone else, the course structure is terrible. There are three assignments, two of them are unclear and make-up 40% of your grade. As well, he changed the final exam from take-home, open book to in-person, closed book six weeks into the quarter. Good luck if you take this course!

He's very knowledgeable but the course structure is AWFUL. Third day of class you have a paper due that's worth 20% of your grade and it's due before class so he hasn't even discussed that part of the play yet. The same with the next paper that's also worth 20%. He grades on participation but it's a class of 84 people.

Hes an absolutely fantastic instructor. Very well-versed in the subject matter and he really helps deepen your interpretations of Shakespeare. Seminar meetings were wonderful and the papers were fairly substantial, but they really helped guide my thinking process for the final seminar paper. I cant recommend him or this seminar course enough.

Keilen is such a kind and eloquent human being. He guides you through Shakespeare and inspires you to love it as much as he does. This quarter he assigned two short papers that prepared you for one longer final one, but there was no outside research required. Attendance and participation are key, and you will need to buy the textbook.

Sean is a fantastic teacher. He makes the students truly think through what they have read (and you must read!). Book choices were great although at times a common theme between two books felt a bit forced. Overall great class would definitely recommend.

Loved all the texts Sean picked out for literary interpret except for The Aspern Papers by Henry James. Sean's essay prompts were challenging, but it made me push myself to critically think in different perspectives.
All around great. He does like to do more creative writing prompts instead of the traditional essays though, so just a heads up on that.

Prof Keilen is such a nice guy and a really engaging lecturer. His TAs are great too and this guy knows absolutely everything there is about Shakespeare. Make sure you keep up with the content of the texts, but you won't get called out or fall drastically behind if you can't finish the reading one day as long as you are on top of the papers.

Keilen's class material is dense and dull, and yet for the hour that he lectures, you can forget that you nearly died reading it. He's just that engaging. Very interested in student participation and growth and will go out of his way to appreciate students. That being said, two sections a week is hard, and there are a lot of assignments/quizzes.

Keilen actually cares about his students and really wants to see them grow as both individuals and critical thinkers. Lectures were engaging, but the course material was a bit dry. Section TAs were also fantastic. You have 4 essays due, so the workload is not terribly difficult. Would love to take a different class topic with this professor.

Professor Keilen is extremely thoughtful about the material he assigns and teaches. He clearly has a passion for Shakespeare and he genuinely cares about his student's opinions. That being said, he is a very tough grader and is not always clear as to how he wants students to write papers. Overall, he is a kind, passionate, and wonderful teacher.

Sean is a great lecturer, especially on the topic of Shakespeare! He's engaging and passionate. He teaches each section once and the section's TA lectures, so you will get to talk to him even if you don't attend office hours. Essays were based on form and reading. Lots of reading and annotation are required, so you do have to work hard to succeed.

Very strict, and a tough grader. Shakespeare Sem can get boring quick because it's all been read and questioned before. Also, he will not care about your reasons, he will fail you if you miss a certain amount of days, even though it's the last class you need to graduate.

If you have to take an English class at UCSC, take one from Professor Keilen. He's one of the smartest and most dedicated professors on campus. He can come across as almost snobbish with his teaching, but he really cares about his students and how they read. He'll push you hard to perform well because he really WANTS you to succeed. 10/10
Sean was a GREAT teacher! I dozed off in class sometimes, but mainly because I took it at 9am and was still drowsy. He really does care for his students and makes an effort to help if you want it.

He was a great professor. He is so intelligent and helpful. I learned so much in his course and got a good grade.  He's not down for more than two absences, so you have to go to class, but it is definitely worth it.  Great professor and great experience. I have talked to many other students who have taken his courses and they all agree.
every class is discussions about the books we read and then write in the book answering prompts

*stev 1* She is an incredible teacher especially in small groups, everybody participated and she would just let the conversation flow, every class was interesting! No pop quizzes, but you have in class writing at the end of the week. She definitely does not grade on completion but she has great feedback. She also thoroughly grades reading notes!!!

*STEV 45* I enjoyed the readings a lot and I thought it was an enriching class. I thought she could've been more supportive and less punitive to my friends who were struggling in the class. We read a lot about white dudes and she wasn't really open to suggestions for more diverse content. Learned a lot, even if it was limited.

I took stev45 with professor heald, it wouldn't let me select that as a class. She was genuinely one of the best professors I've had! She seems genuinely interested in what she is teaching, and always encouraged me to share my ideas.

I really enjoyed her classes, you can tell she's invigorated by what she teaches, and she really communicates that in her lectures. But she will push you. A bunch of students in my class didn't understand why we had to read so much and why she expected us to know Shakespeare...when it's an upper division Shakespeare class.

Professor Heald made Shakespeare enjoyable for me, someone who has never read Shakespeare. The lectures brought great discussion and I didn't feel pressured to add if I didn't want to. I got useful feedback from Professor Heald one on one, and ended up getting an A on all three papers.
Super smart, knows a lot, engaged, prepared, thoughtful, open-minded, modest, great sense of humor, relates well to students, caring, generous, articulate and lucid. Great teacher!

Professor Heald has ridiculously specific expectations for writing. It is not that they are "high". If you do not analyze and close read exactly as she does in lecture you will not receive good grades on papers. Attendance policy is strict. Lots of close reading. I would not recommend this class for students who are not literature majors .

I'm a literature major who, before this class, had a 4.0 and had never received lower than an A- on a paper. I went to every lecture, read every text twice, and participated in class and still only got B's on papers. Students were discouraged from thinking complexly about the texts, expectations were a horrific caricature of literary study.

Professor Heald is a good lecturer and the assignments are fair and straightforward. I did feel, however, that the attendance policy for lecture and section was unreasonable. I understand how important it is not to miss class or be late, but I felt the punishments to be a little extreme. 7 combined absences and you fail the class.

I took this class because my roommate recommended the professor and overall had a great experience! The movies were super cool and it was really fun to talk about them . I had a great TA who made my experience that much better. Attendance is mediatory and was super annoying but it was still fun. Don't get the book its a waste, I didn't use mine.
Enjoyed the class themes and reading Shakespeare wasn't so bad after all. Abigail is a tough grader though and has very high expectations.
Compared to other core classes, her essays were longer and we had a core book that was really thorough. Really heavy on reading, as are all core classes.
Loved taking Shakespeare with Abby! She was honestly a really caring professor and very knowledgeable! Be prepared to read though! Also take advantage of the time she allots for questions!

I came into this class not knowing shakspeare at all and it was really troubling. The stories are really interesting and discussion can get fun as well. Learn how to do analytical reading and writing before taking this course or else you will struggle with the tests.

Loved the class, GREAT lecturer. Totally changed how I viewed and read Shakespeare and his work. Pay attention in class; it'll help with the tests. Main point of the tests were to understand each play's big themes + comprehension.

At first I thought Abby was a little stuck up because she taped off the back four rows of classroom unit 2 so we wouldn't sit there, and we're still not allowed to use phones or laptops at all, but she's actually really nice. She actually engages the class in lecture, and cares about what we think. She's awesome 10/10. Don't skip this class!!

Abby is a really caring professor and very passionate about Shakespeare. If you aren't familiar with Shakespeare you will have to work for the A in her class. Make sure you read the entirety of the plays and take diligent notes both while reading and during lectures!
Heald is a great teacher and shes is totally adorbs

If you love Shakespeare, this is the class for you! Heald is a great lecturer and her TA's are great! You have to do the reading so you can participate. No essays, just 2 midterms analyzing passages. Final is an oral presentation. You definitely learn a lot behind the language of Shakespeare.

Renee is mostly awesome, she is very engaged and enthusiastic. She will however interrupt your presentation in the middle of it for no reason whats however, making you feel isolated and invisible. I think her analysis is ok, she seems very smart, but she doesn't seem to have a lot of knowledge about social context of monster studies.

Absolutely amazing teacher. She is so cool and approachable and honestly a fashion icon. I took a class of her's that was co-taught with another professor and one time she announced that she would be the only one teaching that day in the wake of her colleagues absence, and the 200+ student class genuinely all clapped and cheered.

This is an interesting class and the readings were fun there's just a lot of them. Lectures are not too helpful but they are mandatory. Not too hard of a class to pass it's just a shame that the readings bogs the students down where it's a scramble to finish everything instead of enjoying the reading.

I took the Curse of The Mummy Class the first time it was held. It was an upper-div. History/Literature hybrid course, but not a lot of students understood how much reading we had until later. The lectures were pretty interesting, but the assignments were very vague and you had to be creative. My TA was a gracious grader, so that helped.

Super boring class, took as a lit major and I hated how sexual it was. Really only went for attendance and zoned her out most of the time. WAY too much reading (even for the lit major), and honestly feel bad for people who took this as a GE. Go find another professor.
Class is not an easy GE as it may seem, tough reading, and unless you're interested in the material, may be a waste of your time.

Lectures are boring and you can kind of just fully ignore her. I took this class as a history student and was disappointed by how Literature focused it was. Assignments are supposed to be really creative and wide mummy-Victorian examinations but they were functionally just odd and unclear. Fox herself also just rambles and has full slides of quotes

For LIT 159/HIS 159: I attended almost all lectures and discussions, yet assignment expectations were unclear, the two professors AND the TAs sent out an overwhelming amount of announcements with contradicting information regarding huge parts of our grade. TAs would make up new assignments with nothing but a confusing and vague email to alert us.

The professor is not accessible, all done by TAs. Assignments are very confusing and aren't given clear instructions, many times instructions given by TAs differ from the professors. I loved Harry Potter but this class ruined it for me, it ignored many interesting topics. Assignments are also graded very harshly. Don't take if you cannot write.
terrible instructor

took to fulfill ta ge! class is async but includes difficult quizzes and 3-4 major writing assignments. don't need to read all Harry Potter books to succeed. 

be creative in your papers, do your research on harry potter, and you will get an a! Everyone's grades are curved at the end and Ta's grade kindly. everything is due by 8 pm on friday.

TAs are harsh graders, teacher makes you read the first four Harry Potter books but chooses to focus on topics that aren't relevant to the readers' interpretation of the plot. Attendance is taken during section and contributes to a significant chunk of your grade. Definitely not an easy class.

Professor injected unrelated political ideologies and beliefs. Assignments reinforced the need for conformity. Conversations w/ peers revealed shared discomfort as well as sadness from not taking anything positive from HP themes.The class deviated from the magical essence of Harry Potter, imposing a singular ideology for academic achievement.

Truly upset on the outcome of this course. I was excited to take a Harry Potter course but I never heard from the professor once besides a welcome email and prerecorded lecture videos from past years. All the work was given to TAs who were EXTREMELY difficult graders. Im a 4th year so I'm surprised ucsc lets such a lazy professor get away with this

If you are not into creative writing/literature, do not take this class. The pre-recorded lectures are fine, its the TAs who really run the show (grading, section, etc). The TAs are insufferable and overcomplicate the already confusing assignments. This is not an easy class by any means, the TAs grade harshly and attendance in section is crucial
Super easy class, professor isn't really involved other than the recorded lectures, but overall great class structure and grading

Professor Fox only creates the online lectures, while you typically email and meet with your TA. The lectures were easy to understand and engaging. However, there is a good amount of papers to write regarding the Harry Potter universe.

As a Harry Potter fan, Dr. Fox's class was a dream. The classwork is manageable if you give it the time and thought it needs. Despite being an online class, everything was due on Friday nights at 8 pm instead of 11:59, which I found a little cumbersome as our work usually ended up being graded super late. Very fun class, would take again!

The class is very interesting and even as a hardcore HP fan lectures went into things I hadn't ever considered. Assignments are fun although the instructions are a bit vague. I would take this class again.

Not really much interaction with the professor.The TA I had was horrible. She was not as interactive like other TAs but was very easy to give you her honest opinion of how well you did not do. There was no interaction with the professor of how the class would go when the TAs went on strike. Strike ruined the class.

Really interesting and utilizes slides and outside content really well. Overall really easy class, just not a lot of things to be graded on. Very understanding with attendance and students needing lighter work loads because of jobs

Very passionate professor! He cares so much about his students and the work of poetry. I loved literature and poetry outside of class but he made me fall in love with it even more. Attendance for lectures are NOT mandatory but attendance for discussions are! Other than that, absolutely amazing professor!!

Super nice guy, very caring about his students. He is very relaxed on attendance and late work, but do you best to come on time to show him respect because he deserves it. We are often let out early from class so that a bonus. Essay requirements are a bit long but he grades very generously.
Took Intro to Modern Poetry with Prof Chen. Amazing class and lectures, knows and is excited about lecturing. One of the best classes I've taken at UCSC.
His class is super chill. A lot of reading if you procrastinate, as long as you space things out it is not too much work at all.

He is a great professor and his lectures are actually really interesting. He connects it back to real world topics and events. Big thing is there isn't much you're graded on besides the midterm and final. There's a lot of reading, but you can get away with not reading it all or just quick skimming. Really understanding  and cares about students.

This class is graded off of four assignments, three of which are graded based on completion. Very easy choice to get the TA requirement. Overall, Professor Chen is fun and enthusiastic and while I personally don't enjoy poetry, the class was fine. sections are mandatory.

Professor Chen is so lit you can tell he's genuinely interested in what he is teaching and his lectures are very informative. Not all of the readings are necessary but if you can find the time they do aid your understanding the material. The grading is all done TAs but he made a lot of assignments complete or incomplete which was very manageable.

I love Professor Chen, he always seems to be energetic, happy, and loves cracking jokes during lecture. There are really only a couple assignments but they are pretty chill. Best part is Professor Chen loves his job and cares for his students!

Literally one of my favorite professors! Although his lectures can feel long, it's very educational. Your grade is based on 1 midterm and final (5-7 pages) on any of the readings given. He offers you prompts but you can honestly write about whatever you want. Your essays are graded by your TA. Professor Chen is very understanding and accommodating.

Your grade depends heavily on your TA, but in my experience, the TA's were wonderful. There are 2 close readings (they are easy), and 3 10 question quizzes (that are also easy). His lectures are dry, but he's a nice man. He posts all of his lecture slides. There's a lot of reading, but you don't need to complete it all. I enjoyed this class a lot.

I'm so happy that Chris was my first college professor; he's hilarious, super super kind and laid back. We were graded on only 3 quizzes based on the readings, and on 2 papers graded by the TA's. Overall a great experience. I highly recommend!

If you ever get the chance to take him for a GE, definitely take it. Your grades are 3 quizzes based on whatever poets he went over in class on the lecture slides, so the readings aren't "mandatory". (still read them if you want to though) The two papers you have to do are straightforward too. Your grade might depend more on your TA though.

Chen was easily one of my favorite professors at UCSC. I learned more than most of my LIT classes, and the primary and secondary material was top notch. Chen is easy-going, but this is not a bad thing at all! In fact, his teaching style is geared toward the students, making things a lot less stressful! I loved Chens class... take him if you can!

Professor Chen is super friendly and has a great reading lists. Don't be intimidated by the long reading list its super doable. Essays are pretty straightforward. Quizzes are easy as long as you go to class. Go to class, participate once in a while, read the books and you'll get an A.

Down-to-earth professor, really understands students needs and life outside of class. Loves class discussions. Shows interesting videos throughout course. 6 250-word weekly blog, 2 reading quizzes, 1 midterm paper, 1 final paper. Readings are manageable and interesting. Pretty straight forward class.

He was an incredibly nice professor. I did learn a lot in this class, I often felt bad because it seemed that students wanted to take advantage of his easy going natures. He posts all slideshows online, assigns 3 easy quizzes (if you study slides you'll be fine), and two analysis papers. Your grade sort of depends on your TA.
He's aight. It was a really easy seminar and I was a little disappointed. He's helpful and knowledgeable and totally approachable though.
Really down to earth and approachable guy, your grade really depends on who your TA is though because they're the ones grading your papers.

An extremely engaging, approachable and helpful professor.  He is very knowledgeable and provides fascinating insights. The workload is reasonable, and he  takes student needs into consideration.  I highly, highly recommend Professor Chen.
Superrrr understanding. Has mandatory attendance but she is cool about it. The readings she assigned were manageable and interesting. Learned a lot from this class. I like Prof Cole, take her class!
Love this professor. He's very passionate for his field of study, and it makes the class more interesting. Very good about answering questions and encourages engagement.

I took Lit185O (in Italian) and really enjoyed the course! Keep up with readings and you will do well. Frequent group work and weekly quizzes, but all the work was very manageable and Filippo is very compassionate and supportive of students for even just trying. Super interesting material and I definitely recommend taking a class with Filippo!

Filippo is personable, although he is slightly elitist. He has good insights about the material though. The problem for me too is that a lot of the material is really abstract and Western centric which was hard for me to deal with. However, he is open minded to all perspectives, and is mostly nice, and I have taken him more than once.

I took LIT81H! It was a very average workload with many engaging conversations relevant to our current climate. He is an equally exciting professor who is incredibly sweet and passionate about what he is willing to share with us. Attendance matters, as pop quizzes/discussions are considered attendance for the day. Overall great instructor!
Amazing professor, truly cares about his subject and students. Inspiring classes with the best discussions. You will have to work for your grade but it is well worth it.
Loved Professor Filippo Gianferrari. Loved his class. Inspiring. Put in the work/work hard and you'll get the A. He is passionate about teaching
One of the most inspiring professors I have ever had. A genuinely good person on top of that. A+

She was frustrating and difficult. Though I truly adored the topics of the course, the general structure of the course, the assignments, and grading were asinine. Average pages of readings per class is 60, which is fine, but you only end up discussing 1 reading out of the 4 you're assigned. Grading criteria was wildly unclear. It sucked.

Whole course is only graded out of 100 points. She expects you to read 100+ pages a week, which is typical for LIT upper div. She can be really interesting but she is hesitant with sharing lecture recordings if you miss and her lectures typically don't have any slides. Don't recommend the 1.5  hour classes with her, doesn't care about engagement

Grade is based solely on four essays. Largely depends on how tough your TA is when grading, but most TAs are rough since it's technically a lit course. Do NOT take as a GE. Prof got mad at the whole class when people weren't doing her extremely long readings. She's passionate but her lectures are super boring despite being about fashion.

She was really nice but it did get boring in lectures if you don't do the reading. It was a lot of reading for me but the discussion sections did help a lot for helping me understand it and use it in the papers. There are very few papers, 3-4 pages but they're not that hard if you have ideas flowing and know the readings well.

Really text heavy lecture slides that were hard to understand. Her lecture style is very messy and most of the things on her slides were quotes. Her class is alright for the most part but she doesn't make coming to class very enjoyable.

I took Vilashini's lit 200 grad seminar and it was interesting, in terms of getting to know the different faculty who come through and learning the styles of each. She enjoys her buzz words, so her lectures are very creative in that regard, she is nicer than you would expect, and she is slightly unreliable when scheduling meetings, not bad though.

I loved the topics for class and all the readings she chose were HARD but really made you think, which is the point for a senior seminar but just beware. But she was super helpful if you didn't understand the topics and office hours were really helpful! Her advice for my research paper was really helpful!
Great lectures.

A lot of the lecture topics were really cool, but often it seemed like we weren't learning what was relevant to the general idea of the course. You are expected to read a lot, but you can get along completely fine if you don't read at all and only look at the readings when you need sources for papers. The papers assigned have good prompts.

Cooppan is a pretty decent teacher, she is very unorganized though and the teacher assistants do everything. She only has three assignments and the final, so you graded on a few things. But you have a while to do it. All her content is posted on canvas and she is very patient. Overall it was a good class, with not too much hw.

Politics of fashion is really interesting! It did feel pretty repetitive at times but it wasn't too bad to sit through lecture. She genuinely cares about what her students have to say also. I never did the readings and just took notes on what she said in class about them. It made writing the essays a little harder but it was fine.

She's a very eloquent speaker--lectures are great. There were many options for prompts, and lots of freedom in regards to essay topics, with good feedback in regards to argument. Taking a class with her again for sure!

I took my senior seminar class (Postcolonial Literature) with Cooppan and I highly recommend her. She is an engaging lecturer and is good at facilitating class discussions. Though a bit disorganized at times, I learned a lot in her lectures. She is funny, warm, accommodating to student needs and a true scholar.

Most of the reading was dry, and I disagreed with a lot of her interpretations of the text, but I don't have anything against her. Just a bit boring. Her essay prompts were incredibly confusing and required a lot of parsing to just understand what she was asking.
The course was really interesting and Professor Cooppan is super friendly and understanding. The essay portion wasn't too difficult, do the readings and go to lecture to pass.

Prof. Cooppan is a great speaker, yet classes ceased to be stimulating, it seems like she writes no lesson plans, as class is not structured, and she can spend 1/5th of the class reading a rubric for an basic assignment, she constantly pushes lectures back, depleting rapidly the curriculum to be covered in the 10 week period. Difficulty: 0

She was amazing. Every reading was decent in length and always at least a bit interesting. Papers were a little tough but entirely fair. She is a great lecturer and was very engaging with the class. The subjects were very interesting. Overall a great professor.

Extremely knowledgeable and analyzes the reading down to the bone. Her assignments are clear and specific, but provides no template so you will have to think for yourself. Encourages and rewards discussion during lectures.

CRES10 was one of the most amazing classes I've ever taken. Keep in mind she's a literary scholar, so her lectures are mostly her analyzing the texts and going in depth. She's an extremely knowledgable person and I respect her a lot. She is real and always tries to get a discussion going. Great class, would recommend, always!

For global fiction, she assigned a large amount of reading that she could neither provide interesting lectures around nor successfully examine in depth with the short time provided during the quarter. Her voice is high pitched and very irking and she seems to think she is the goddess of theory, which she certainly isn't. Should take tips from Jody.

Professor Bell is extremely lecture-based. I often found it hard to focus, and the readings were sometimes difficult and often lengthy. That said the content was usually fairly interesting. Graded by 3 assignments (1 is attendance) but he did not grade our final paper or our attendance, (only 1 thing in gradebook) which feels wishy-washy to me.

I had Professor bell for Social Media and Society. He was a fine professor and lectures were fairly interesting, but he never graded our final papers or participation grade, so our final grades were based only on one paper we did at the beginning of the quarter.

Took Social Media and Society class. Readings were thought-provoking and felt really relevant. The reading is the homework (I guess that's a literature thing?) but was manageable. Tbh a few of readings were over my head, but Professor Bell always walked us through them to make sure they clicked. Would def take again

He talks in circles, difficult to pay attention. I took Lit-81E-01 (Social Media & Society Literature) and it felt like we talked about the same thing every class. Read a reading for homework, go to class and listen to him talk about it, then repeat it. Your grade depends on the midterm and final, no hw. Attendance "mandatory" but not in gradebook.

Not the type of class that should take place at 8 am. It is too heady for that and no one cares that early. I was never awake throughout any of the lectures, got the most from the discussion section. That being said, Dorian understands our generation more than a lot of teachers and he fosters some decent discussion. Reading the room would help.

I became a Film and Digital Media major because of Professor Bell's Film Noir class. The films were mostly French but still amazing. Professor Bell was good at walking us through some of the tougher theoretical readings. I also really liked how participatory he made lectures. Perfect class if you want to learn how to watch film.

This class was super interesting but you REALLY need to know your French (like be practically fluent). I consider myself almost bilingual and I had a hard time keeping up with all the reading. There is a lot of french discussion in class and you will have to give one half hour presentation as well as write two 8 page papers, obviously all in French

Fantastic professor. I've taken his classes many times and have enjoyed every one. Sometimes the seminar-style class can get a little slow but the readings are always interesting and engaging. Graded by a few papers but he is a fair grader and the prompts are very open.

Dorian is a great professor. I get that some of his explanations can take a while, but he is really good at breaking down the readings so that they make sense for the class. He was very nice and responded to emails quickly. Tests were a bit of a challenge, but he was incredibly willing to answer any questions you might have leading up to them.

Dorian said a lot in lecture, but a lot of it didn't really connect with many of the students. Not only did people find themselves writing down copious notes that didn't make much sense, but his exams and assignments were extremely broad and confusing. Sections and lecture attendance were mandatory, but I didn't get much out of either.
When he gave us test prompts they were extremely ambiguous and had nothing to do with lecture. He never really seemed to get to the point in his lectures and was very repetitive.

I loved Professor Thomas. They were so sweet all year and highly supportive. This class is reading-heavy and not an option. But grading is super easy, and if the assignment is late, they will work with you to make sure you get back on track. The workload is light, and I would definitely recommend this professor.

All you need to do is the readings before class. Other than that there's very few assignments since most of the course content is in class. Her class actually helped me with my participation in group discussions, something that I previously struggled with. She's very caring and clearly passionate about social issues. Attendance definitely matters!

The material itself was interesting, but I found the lectures to be a bit dry and not engaging. They are very knowledgeable in the subject though. Only graded on a few things, so participation/attendance really matters towards your grade. A bit of a slow grader, as well, but we didn't have a TA so it was slightly understandable.

Most of the conversations we have in class are surface level and driven by emotion rather than logic and facts. I feel as if I have to tiptoe over some topics, despite being a democrat myself and moderate left, the people in this class are so left leaning that it made it impossible to not feel ostracized during every conversation.

Dr. Thomas is an amazing professor. The workload is very light and they're understanding of their students. The in-class discussions are also really interesting and it actually relates to the homework we did.
Lots of discussion in lecture so if you participate you will have fun! Tons of assigned reading (mostly poetry) but we only ever talked about like half of it in class.

I was very confused by this class - unfortunately, they were thrown in last min, but class was disjointed and very unfocused. They allowed lots and lots of class participation, to the point that we ran out of time every class period.

Professor Thomas was very good at facilitating class discussions and delivered all lectures very clearly. Very down to Earth and chill, looked forward to class every day. Explained things very clearly for all assignments, answered any emails promptly. Grading was moderate levels of strictness.

Very understanding teacher. Attendance matters obviously, but unlike most writing teacher, if you have covid, or ,or an emergency of some sort, you won't lose attendance credit. Her canvas is a little confusing, but she explains what to do, if you attend her office hours.

Professor Thomas was one of the most caring and understanding professors I have had! They clearly listened to and cared about what every student had to say, and made sure all students had the chance to participate. Very helpful and easy to reach too.
An interesting class from a caring professor. I would love to take it again. (Taken Spring 2020).

Professor Thomas was super accommodating and passionate! I recommend this course if you love literature or are interested in monsters. The assignments aren't difficult and it's nice to do work in groups. I will say that I would have enjoyed this course more if it was in person and not online. Nonetheless, it was a good course to take!

My favorite online teacher! The class was asynchronous and the assignments were all clearly laid out and she was always available to chat or discuss assignments. My favorite part was how well the class was structured. I seriously recommend professor Thomas!

I learned so much in her class- you can tell she is passionate about the subject and she is flexible if you need an extension. Very understanding about online learning difficulties but a tough grader with great feedback on assignments.

Professor Thomas was a pretty solid professor overall. She gave pretty engaging lectures, but everyone is expected to participate or else you will lose a pretty big chunk of your grade. Her assigned papers were pretty good assignments with a clear grading criteria. Ultimately, she's a really down to earth prof, and she's pretty chill.

His lectures are very dense but he is super open to explaining the concepts/words w/o being rude. He assigned short 500 word weekly papers and I understand the confusion since his instructions are so vague but his feedback at the beginning of lectures are helpful. 60% of the grade is dependent on one midterm paper (Hobsbawm) and final 8-10pg paper

I took Sahota in the winter quarter of my freshman year and he was a great professor! He is extremely knowledgeable and willing to help you succeed. He is also a generous grader and passing the class is not difficult. To get the most out of the class watch the movies they are amazing and engage with the text. I definitely recommend the class!

One of my favorites in the lit dept. Grades will be mainly based on relatively open-ended papers, and he will be happy to give feedback throughout the process. His fascinating (often tangential) lectures demonstrate a deep, nuanced understanding of culture and history (esp of India) and drove me to make new connections. Hard texts, but worth it!!

My takeaway from a course with Sahota is that you're going to get out of the class whatever you put in.  He was helpful with understanding and refining the research process, and made time for students in seminars and office hours. His grading can be slow, but I utilized office hours for feedback on my standing in the course and how I could improve

One of the worst professors I've had during my time here at UCSC. This course is determined by your midterm and final, which are both 30% of your grade. However, he takes forever to grade and can't give clear instructions to save a life, even the final lacks clear instructions. I'm writing this during finals week, and my midterm isn't graded.

SAHOTA IS THE WORST. He rambles and is so disrespectful! I had to miss a couple of classes because I was extremely sick. I provided paperwork from my appointments and my positive Covid test as proof, and he basically told me I was going to fail because of my three absences. He called me out in front of the class for it too. 0/10 NEVER AGAIN.

He once asked for students to give him criticism about his teaching. I brought up how he tends to connect unknowns to unknowns, and speaks just as densely and roundaboutly as the reading we were doing. (He's very bad at defining key terms, seems irritated when you ask for definitions) He then told me that wasn't his problem. Never taking him again.
never responded to emails. didn't grade anything

I really liked Sahota, he extremely interesting to hear speak and seems super passionate about a lot of the content that he teaches. The way he would bring in and talk about reading that were just kind of tertiary to what we were learning was super interesting and I really enjoyed his class. The lectures were really eye-opening to me.

This was the most boring class of my entire life. He stood at the podium and talked for the whole hour and half and wrote on the chalkboard maybe once or twice. Huge projector and didnt use it the entire quarter, no slides, nothing. Went on so many tangents. literally pray you have a good ta cuz I learned more from her than I ever did him.
the most boring professor i've ever had
With no real knowledge and teaching skills , dont expect too much. Ask Dept of Asian Language and Literature department, univ of minnesota where it became tough to sell his ideas and thoughts.

The readings are long and useless. No agenda, no rubric for grading, no assignment guidelines. He wanted more class participation but he doesn't know when to shut up. Can't answer questions, doesn't stick to the material, and doesn't realize he's supposed to teach not just assume we know everything and go off talking about whatever he pleases.

It was a bit of a joke in our breakout rooms that the way he graded was silly. "Good work, 2/2". And then he'd add "edits" to what we wrote that completely changes the meaning to what HE got out of the material. He doesn't use canvas, either, so we can't see our progress or know when things are due. Wouldn't recommend if you want structure.

Most unorganized class I've ever taken and all he does is ramble and add fluff to things to try and make things sound more intelligent and deep than they are. Very inaccessible class if you require structure (doesn't use canvas, randomly changes due dates/recquirements during lecture, doesn't supply you with resources needed for course at all)

Sahota is a really nice guy. He rambles like a philosopher, says slightly problematic things, but ultimately is open to talking about and changing his mind on things. His lectures are useless because he rambles far too much, but if you know the material they are interesting. Just read, do the essays, and all will be good.

AVOID SAHOTA! Bad lecturer. Lectures are poorly structured, rambly. Assumes you know WAAAY more than you do, everyone was lost. And if you ask a question, even just a simple definition of a term, his answers are roundabout and complicated, like don't even bother asking. Assigned 1200 word final exam AND 8 page final essay due on same day. Just bad.

I don't know why he has such a low rating, he is a very knowledgeable professor. 4 essays make up your grade with clear guidelines, the rest is participation. Why is lit 101 only available at 8am though. Come on. The department really needs to change that.
Hands down the best professor I've ever had. Sure, if you have no interested in the subject taught or you want to get through by doing as little as possible, then don't take this class.

The most boring and incompetent professor at SC. He's passed off basic questions he says he didn't know to the TAs. He gives really vague lectures and mumbles so that even on a mic, people have trouble hearing him. You'll do well if you have a good ta. His class is so terrible people either sleep or do hw for other classes in his class.
Gave excellent feedback on projects leading up to final paper; helped me improve the depth of my analysis. Very engaging and interactive teaching style.

She is SOOO sweet. the class is easy but engaging as she effectively encourages students to engage with the course for their own growth. It kinda feels like a high school class, but more chill (Ex. first class she had us put our phones in a basket, then stopped for the rest of the quarter). She gives less homework than other core profs. 4ish essays

I'm not yet done with the quarter (and therefore this class), but it is unbelievable to me how kind and welcoming Melissa is. She really cares about YOU, not your grade or even necessarily the goals of the establishment. She is so mom-core. THIS IS HANDS DOWN THE BEST PORTER 1 PROF. PLEASE TAKE. All of my other friends had lots of complaints.

Easiest class I have ever taken. Melissa is incredibly caring and fosters a very positive environment in class. Readings due before every class, but most people didn't do them and discussions were still very insightful. Class was so chill and we did a lot of mindfulness. Always excited for her class as it felt like a very safe space. Amazing person

shes amazing 
trust every review 
100% you will not regret taking her class

I did not want to be in this class, but at Melissa understood that we were all forced to be there and did not give us a hard time. Workload and grading are very easy, everyone gets A+ unless you do absolutely nothing.
The best choice you can make for Kresge core, super invested in every student and is the most caring person ever. She was so sweet and made a class I thought I would hate enjoyable.

Frankly I hated Kresge 1 and think it's a scam for such a useless course to be required and force me to spend 1k for it, but the Professor was solid and she did give great feedback on all assignments. She said it herself: "the class is not meant to stress you out". Light work.

Very passionate and accommodating professor. Turned in some assignments late and she accepted for 100% credit. Provides very detailed feedback on all assignments and takes time to read everything. However KRSG1 as a class is flawed and very useless. Would take her again for another class.
Sweet and silly! I loved having her!
LOVE
She cares so much about the students, loved the class !

I love having Melissa as my Kresge 1 professor because she's so caring, funny, and overall inspirational. I love hearing her stories, lectures, etc. If you ever have the chance to have Melissa as your professor, you won't regret it at all!

She is sooo amazing! I tool her Kresge core class and also Intro to creative writing. She is kind, smart, funny, very understanding, and really knows her shit. I reccomend taking any class you can with her, she is by far the best teacher I've had at Santa Cruz.
Loved Melissa! She made Porter 1 very enjoyable. There is a good amount of reading, but it's doable. She adjusted some assignments to make the workload easier for us. Very caring and sweet

Professor Melissa is by far the greatest porter core professor. Even though there is a lot of reading for this class professor Melissa is very understanding and would ask us how we would prefer to approach an assignment. I found this class very enjoyable, but I bet if I had a different professor I would have hated this class.
Amazing professor-- you're gonna have to write, but she's very descriptive and always open for questions. Very kind person. I recommend to all!

OMG she's amazing. I took her in Porter CORE in my first quarter, and then I took her for LIT 179A and LIT 91A. This woman got me through some tough crap. She's down to Earth, honest, and funny af. She teaches from the heart about writing and publishing. Take her class. Trust me. It'll change your perspective and life for the better.

Coming into college, she made me feel so supported. I never dreaded going to her class because I knew she wanted to make us feel as comfortable as possible, and her method of teaching a class (and she honestly doesn't like the curriculum) is accessible and interesting. I would love to take more classes with her, the mother figure i needed

I loved her!!! I could not recommend her enough as a prof to anyone looking for an awesome teacher. She was super understanding and sympathetic to her class as we went through the class online, and she really helped bring us all together in a way I wasn't expecting before. I only wish that classes could have been in person, because she was amazing.

Professor Sanders-Self is the best!! A really great intro to college, and she made it really low stress. If you are taking an intro class definitely choose her. Only thing is that i haven't gotten any grades back but this semester is unique so I understand.

Professor Biehl was great. She pushes the limits that it requires for you to improve. Get ready to read and write over and over again and then 5 times more. I wouldn't recommend this course if you already have a heavy load, but if you want to see real change, start here.

Content was extremely interesting although the assigned readings were hefty. Weekly film screenings and long lectures which at time felt like discussion sections. Papers were graded toughly although the criteria was clear and helpful feedback was given. Final was rewarding since we could propose it, so I chose a short film. Overall, fun but tough.

Good prof; as a cs major, interesting but read material assigned before class since lectures depend on it. 6 papers but do get the chance to redo them for a better grade. No quizzes/tests but you show what you learn from topics on your papers; exit tickets after every lecture. Some lectures in the morning can be boring, but readings are interesting

This class was very heavy on readings as a CS major, but makes sense for a LIT class. Class is about the history of California through art. Still very interesting, but do not take this class just because it has 'Engineering' in the title if you're in STEM. Optional screenings are fun! Mandatory weekly discussions will hurt grade if not attended.

The class is definitely a decent amount of work for a GE and is tedious but manageable. A lot of reading and tedious assignments. I was not exactly sure what this class was going to entail when I signed up, and found out it covers the poetics of infrastructure. Grading was pretty fair, but it depends on the TA. It's not horrible, but not easy.
Lots of tedious work but its manageable.

Don't listen to these "awful" reviews. Zac is an amazing Literature professor! He's very approachable and always wants what's best for his students. It's these student's faults who think a GE should be extremely passable, its not his fault they couldn't pick themselves up in the class.

This class is homework-based, lectures aren't needed to watch for the class. Homework was pretty easy and the workload wasn't too much considering there were no lectures. Might be boring if your not interested in California Infrastructure. Easy A for the TA ge.

At the end of the course, the I felt the prof never clearly explained the "poetics of infrastructure", which is the course objective. Grading depends on TA. If you are looking for low-workload GE, find another class. 3/5 because at least we were not punished with bad grades for not understanding the material completely.

The enjoyability of this class is purely based on how much you like the books. Before enrolling, I would definitely watch his intro lecture (available online) and preread the books he mentions to see if you enjoy them. I didn't like the material, and the TAs are on strike so I probably won't get my grades back so all my effort was for naught.

Worst professor I have ever taken. "Lectures" are pre-recorded, assignments due randomly (Tue before 1:30pm). Tell me how this class had more work and assignment than my major upper-division classes??

NOT an easy GE. 

Worst off, final was explaining a book he should use for his next upper-div course...Shouldn't that be his job to figure out??

Terrible online class but professor is fine, but thinks this is the only class your taking. Heaps of reading every week with multiple discussion post with response and comprehension quiz. Makes everything due before section/lecture so get ready to read and stay up. Canvas is loaded with whole bunch of stuff and hard to find things. Not a easy TA GE

Ridiculous amount of work. Thinks this is ur only class (has assignments due before your section even if Tuesday or Wednesday). Readings are inaccessible (some are only available to be viewed by 9 students despite being a large class). And he throws his schedule out the window (sometimes double the amount per week despite what his syllabus says.
Kind, very knowledgeable, WANTS YOU TO ENGAGE. Treat his classes like a group discussion even though the lecture is dense!

Enjoyable class if you're willing to engage with the material, helpful recorded lectures dissect the readings further. One mandatory section per week, TAs are nice. Can become a grind with discussion posts and readings if you fall behind, make sure to get ahead in the beginning few weeks. Overall had interesting and well-structured content.

Went into this not expecting much, actually enjoyed the class. I recommend taking an in person discussion section if available, definitely the only reason why I stayed engaged. readings are long, but interesting. Not the worst class to take for a GE, fairly easy to pass as long as you understand the rubric provided to you.

Lit 81I with Dr. Zimmer is the best online course I've ever taken. The class is as easy or as involved as you want it to be. Truth be told, you could EASILY breeze through this class, but there's also limitless content to expand upon if you want to make the most of ur tuition money. There was one field trip and one movie screening(both optional).

LIT189A is a course offered in Spanish, and I definitely recommend it. There are weekly readings, discussion posts, and quizzes but they are pretty easy. There is a midterm which is a short essay and the final is 4 short essays. Professor Zimmer is also really easy to talk to and accessible outside of class. Take this class!

Genuinely one of the worst classes I have ever taken in my life. If you are trying to take 81 with zac DO NOT DO IT!!! He gives virtually no time to take tests, and even the TA's are not accommodating whatsoever. Mine specifically was very rude and takes days to respond to emails even within office hour times. I hope to drop this class ASAP

I took both of his speculative fiction courses and they were both amazing. This upper div one was my favorite class I've taken at UCSC. He's so widely read and the lectures were always interesting. He welcomes comments and questions at any time during which made the class really engaging. He made me want to go get a Ph.D. in literature.

Zac Zimmer really cares about his students learning. He gives good feedback on essays and gives exceptional lectures. He is very accessible after or before class. His classes are reading dense but totally doable. Zac is one of the smartest professors I have ever had- he made an 8 am lit class worth the early morning!

Straight-forward class. She's available after lectures for questions and is kind. Teaches well but conceptual parts could use some greater focus. Exams are easy, rarely will you have to think outside the box if you do the homework and lecture problems. You're able to review midterms. Overall good class with a great professor.

A very strong professor in the math department. Her lectures are a bit dry, and she goes at a swift pace, but rewatching them (she makes the videos available) makes the content super easy to understand. Her tests are very fair, and don't try to trick you in any way. 2 midterms, 1 final, with the final score replacing the lowest scoring midterm!

Took this course as one of my first classes ever here at UCSC, and loved it. Show up to lectures and do the homework and boom, those are your tests right there. STUDY FOR SAID TESTS!!! They count for at least half the grade. But if you do poorly on one midterm, if you do better on the final that grade also replaces your lowest midterm! Loved it!!!!

Probably one of the best professors in the math department. Her lectures are a bit dry, but they are thorough and will prepare you for the exams. She mostly uses free resources for her classes (no having to drop hundreds of bucks on awful online textbook nonsense) and clearly sets expectations about what is required of you to succeed.

She was great! Always ready to answer every question, and there are like a billion opportunities to get help with this class. She never tried to give us trick questions; she genuinely wanted us to learn. Homework takes some time - don't start the day of! Best way to study; go back through her completed notes to make the cheat sheet. Def recommend!

Suzana is one of the best professors I've had in a while. Her lectures go at a slow easy pace and she's a very understanding and caring professor. She offers office hours 3 days out of the week and It's easy to do well in her class if you do the homework and at least half of the quizzes since she has a forgiving grading scale.

the lectures were never mandatory and discussion sections were optional for extra credit. the lectures straight to the point and we did example problems that were exactly the same as the exams. 

Her grading policy is great and super forgiving. As long as u tried and put effort into studying and turning the homework in on time, u'll definitely pass

She teaches in a way that can be very confusing, going too much into detail about simple concepts and rushing through highly complex problems. We are always "running behind" schedule, causing her to speed up her lectures even more. She makes simple mistakes in every lecture, making taking notes confusing. Essentially, you will be teaching yourself.

I had her for math 3 and she explains things really well and her grading is super fair. her lectures are boring but it is obvious cares for our success if you talk to her after class or anything. Would definitely recommend taking her class although edfinity kinda sucks sometimes.

had her for math 3 (not 2), lectures could be on the boring side, but she explained things very well. grading is super fair and she drops your lowest midterm and your lowest quiz/homework scores. very caring and sweet. fairly easy class overall and would definitely recommend.
Her lectures are a bit boring but she does teach everything that comes up in the tests well. The tests are very similar to the practice ones.
She's a good teacher but her accent makes lecture a bit boring to go to, if you study the practice test before midterms and finals you will do fine in the class.

1 midterm and 1 fianl, the final can boots up you grade if the score is higher than what you got in the midterm. She have a good cruve grading system, but her leacture is not what i expect becauise she's reading from it. Most of the time you learn from the homework instead of her leacute.Last, she sent study guid very late, but go over it with you.

So Suzanna is a good professor, her lectures were boring, but I did manage to learn as the material was not too hard. I found the best part was her grading scale (that being a C is a 64%) so it made actually learning easier without the fear of failing. Overall, you cannot go wrong picking her.

Professor Serboi is quite good, only thing preventing me from giving her a higher rating is that the textbook for the class is awful and a number of the problems she assigned from it referenced problems that weren't assigned. She explained the concepts well enough that one could overcome the poor textbook.

Lectures were incredibly slow and boring. All she did was read off the slides and if there were questions, she might explain it well enough if you're lucky. Her class isn't all that difficult, and you can get pretty good grades as long as you make sure your answers on the homework match the ones in the back of the book.

Great professor. Lectures aren't mandatory, but there's a participation quiz due the following day so you should still try to watch the lecture. Homework isn't too difficult, usually 10 problems every week. Exams are mostly easy, though some harder problems may stump you. Cheat sheets are allowed, so you don't have to memorize all the formulas.

You learn more from the textbook than her. No one in this class knows what's going on; she doesn't know how to explain concepts other than reading off the slides. Lectures are recorded, 1 midterm 1 final, homework every week. Definitely go to section to understand the class.
Overall a great professor

She was fine, do all the homework and lectures were pretty straightforward. If you actually study you can probably pass. Dropped 1/2 midterm grades which was great. Not a fan of mandatory attendance but she'd give you some leniency if you needed to miss class.
I think if professor nandini and her 309 students weren't on a sinking ship and she had 309 life jackets she would talk one for herself and throw the rest in the water, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS.
this class convinced me to quit STEM

do not take this class with nandini, wait to take it a different quarter for a different professor. even while using all the resources available for outside help, the tests are brutal and do not match the practice tests she gives prior to the exams. her lectures also just reiterates the readings which are not helpful, rushes 8q lecture quizzes.

Overall, Nandini has the intentions of a great teacher however her execution falls flat when it comes to translating calculus to students in a comprehensive way. lecture includes an attendance quiz w/ difficult questions in it on material we barely learned & the time we receive to complete these quizzes is not enough. i felt unprepared for tests.
yeah v do NOT take this class. wait to take it w a different professor. ANYONE is better. im fighting my life not to crash out during every lecture! lectures are disorganized.
do not take this class trust me just don't do it

"Are you with me?" "No, queen". Nandini is a very nice and sweet professor, but the lectures are so poor that I leave the lecture every time knowing less than I walked in knowing. I think a digital format, such as projecting with an iPad, would be better than writing on paper with a pen on printed reading notes for organizational purposes.

I LOATHE this class. Learn from a textbook with mistakes by yourself. Go to lecture only to scramble for lecture attendance credit, which is some 6Q quiz that we have 10 mins to complete, or rip your grade. So vague about what we need to know for exams. Explains concepts by giving an explanation for how the formula came to be. Get anyone else.

Found this class pretty difficult. Her explanations of simple problems were hard to follow. Weekly homework that was super long (edfinity). Midterm and final were really challenging. Very much a teach yourself class. Sweet lady though, clearly cares.

I took calc in high school and I thought this was an easy class. I had friends who didn't and they thought it was a hard class. She's nice.. but she explains things way harder than they are, and she makes mistakes when answering problems on her slides. If you have the time to study on your own time take the class. The hw is harder than the tests.

If you take this course, you are teaching yourself. The course isn't impossible, but it takes a lot of studying and practice. Nandini does not help or lecture well, so your grade is in your own hands. 25% ended with an A, 25% with a B, 35% with a C, and 15% failed the course. Good luck. Do all the practice exams and use LSS and TAs for help!

Whoever says that we got our grades by "not trying hard enough" is lying. Nandini was an awful professor who blamed her class for getting poor grades for using ChatGPT? not her horrific teaching. She was vague and her TA's would out-teach her in their sections.

A lot of people are complaining about the course, but they aren't putting in enough effort. Make sure to do the homework and worksheets, they're free points. Attend office hours for extra credit and spend time understanding concepts. She doesn't teach well, but the course weighting is good. I think she's a great person, but a terrible teacher.

Nandini gives subpar lectures, overcomplicates concepts, and assigns far too much homework. She is also not a lenient grader and does not curve tests despite repeated low performance. She also doesn't take criticism well. Nandini is a genuinely lovely person, but that does NOT translate to her teaching style. Stay far, far away from this class!!

I dropped this class because I knew that, if I had stayed, I would've failed. I love math and was genuinely looking forward to taking this class, but I literally could not comprehend anything she taught. Like others have mentioned, she seems caring and passionate, but I need to emphasize that she CANNOT teach. PLEASE do not take this class with her

This is by far the worst teacher I have ever had. She makes simple concepts much more complicated than they need to be which confuses everyone. She speeds through her lectures and just assumes everyone is "with her" while we are all frantically trying to write down everything on her paper. She also often makes mistakes. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!

I just took the midterm. Everyone failed. She does not teach at all, and all she does during lectures is make many mistakes and say, "Are you with me?" No one is with her. She doesn't grade; the TAs do, so your grade really depends on who you have for TA. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS if you don't wanna crash out.

Professor Bhattacharya struggles with technology, but she's kind and passionate. The material is challenging, but using resources like unstuckstudy AI and study groups can help. Attend class and do the work to succeed.

she struggles a lot with technology so often a lot of class time is wasted but she's very kind and genuinely likes teaching students. Exams weren't hard but if you didn't try and learn you definitely wont pass. A lot of reviews talked about her accent, yall are just racist cause you can totally understand her
nice

Really funny guy! I didn't perform well in this class, though. He gives attendance quizzes, homeworks, 3 midterms and a final. The final is in the style of a midterm. You can also retake up to all 3 of the midterms too. Love Bob as a professor and person but I just couldn't keep up...if you struggle with math definitely go to office hours/tutoring.

First time this class was offered in years, but Bob was very understanding of this and went easy on us. He is the funniest professor I have ever had. He's also super smart.

The class was confusing to me, but I think with a TA for next time, it would be a very doable class. Definitely take Bob if you can.

Don't mistake his sarcasm for rudeness!

Bob is the goat, like others have stated, he's like if Peter Griffin had a phd in math. I went to like 5 lectures and got an A+, this class is so easy especially if you attend and he's so funny. 3 midterms, no final, and you can retake all 3 midterms during the final allocation if you need to. 10/10 would recommend, I wish I went to more lectures.

Bob was a really chill and funny guy. I enjoyed going to his lectures, however I would agree that he goes a bit fast when it comes to going over the material. He does help you a lot when it comes to preparing for the exams though, and he is also very chill when it comes to them as well.

Bob is a very funny guy and engages with the class (though sometimes too much). He is very accessible if you have questions, I went to his office hours weekly and was able to just do my homework and ask for help when needed. The class goes really fast and he's a bit intimidating in lecture, but outside of class he is calm, understanding, and great.

Bob is a really nice and funny guy but he lectures so fast it feels so hard to keep up. Taken 2 different math courses with him. Failed the 1st time I had a class with him, got an A with a different prof. Weekly quiz, midterm every 3 weeks, goes over topics so fast so you have to teach yourself. He's not a bad guy at all there's just something...
bob more like blob is bad at teaching and threatens us with test.

Bob actually sucks at teaching, I love him as a person, he is very funny. But I genuinely got nothing from the lectures. I had to rely on my sections to teach me and most of the course work I had to learn by myself. He also lectures wayyyyyy too fast and my classmates and I can never keep up.
Bob is the best, funny guy, best dressed, and an overall cool dude. Would take his class again, 10/10. Explains the subjects well and cares about his students.

While the class itself is not interesting, attending lectures with Bob at least makes it entertaining. He's a cool guy who knows his stuff, explains topics in simple terms, but the class does move fast.
He responds to emails his class is amazing and very relaxed. He is able to help you in his office hours and is an overall chill guy. Amazing with his lectures and very funny and quippy!!

Bob is awesome. He is one of the only professors I know to write separate lecture notes for the class which are extremely helpful. He appreciates genuine participation and questions, and provides useful feedback during office hours. Just a great guy in general, everyone should definitely take a course with this professor.
i love him
favorite professor i've had at ucsc so far. very accommodating and understanding and he's really funny. genuinely wants you to succeed.

bob is amazing. he made complex calc/linear algebra topics very digestible, and was a fun guy through it all. I found myself WANTING to go to lectures, not to get the material, just to listen to whatever funny stories bob had for us that day. he is a VERY kind grader, and allows cheat sheets for every test, so unless you hate yourself, you'll pass.

Bob is where it's at. 3 midterms. Midterms were literally the reviews but had different numbers. Weekly homeworks and section quizzes, but he drops a few of both. Final is optional, it's a chance to retake any/all of the midterms. Such a fun lecturer, loved going to class.
Bob is amazing they should pay him more

Reviews don't lie. Classic chill & tired prof archetype. Super communicative, tells you what's on the test and what isn't. Explores extra math concepts to expose math majors to concepts they might like. Difficulty depends on how good at math you are. Everything's on Canvas including recordings. Cares a lot and is dedicated. No complaints. Good prof
Love Bob, he's funny and he's good at teaching.

Bob is a great guy who can teach very well and is clearly very passionate about what he teaches. Allows cheat sheets and gives 1 very doable hw assignment a week sections were very easy aswell would only have to be there for around 20 mins awesome teacher!

super chill guy! super accesible outside of class, responds to emails immediately. the labs are mostly easy but can get difficult every now and then. if you don't have a firm understanding of pre-calculus then you might have trouble. the midterm and final are both multiple choice and mostly just basic mental math

Labs are very difficult, requires a lot of outside of lecture focus on the class, mainly graded on homework. Marty himself was very funny and a joy to have as a teacher, the course is suitable for people interested in science, otherwise I recommend taking 11A.
Marty and his small teaching team are very caring and go above and beyond to help students, I'm not much of a math person but I thoroughly enjoyed the class

Marty was a great professor! His lectures are really informative and interesting. The course material is nothing like traditional calculus because it's a class built from the ground up for biology majors. One critique I have is the discussion sections; my TA was not very helpful in discussion, which caused confusion so beware & attend office hours!

Marty is a great guy, and his lectures are incredibly informative. He clearly knows how to teach and I don't typically get lost when following his lectures. However, Tao Ma, the TA I had for our bi-weekly sections where we worked on the lab manual (the only graded thing in the class outside of the midterm and final) was completely incompetent.

Lecture day before thanksgiving. Ta's need to be humbled for how ridiculous it is to understand them. When you ask for her to repeat herself she hits you with attitude acting like she's the one paying $3,000 to get access to her incoherent ramblings.

chill guy but he lowkey just kinda makes things up. its fake math. these formulas and equations didn't actually exist until being manifested by the Great Martin. pretty easy class but super confusing because you dont use the traditional fundamentals of calculus. get ready to graph, and memorize the practice tests.

Such a great teacher! His lectures aren't mandatory, but he does often give out worksheets that will be due in the next discussion section so if you aren't there you have to print it out yourself. The class itself is fairly easy and there are a lot of different people you can go to if you need extra help. Overall, a fairly easy and fun class.

Concepts are a bit hard to grasp but the workbook is super easy to get through. There's no hw throughout the quarter as long as you're able to submit all the workbook pages that are due at the end. Tests are all multiple choice and very straightforward, and Marty prepares you well for them.

Marty has been one of the kindest professors I've had! After taking 16A and 16B, I can confidently say the class is doable and very applicable outside of math. 16B coincides directly with content from chem 3B. Lectures expand your understanding of concepts and section teaches the math. As a non-math savvy person, this has been my fav class.

Marty is amazing! Since this class was being taught for the first time this year, we were his guinea pigs, so lots of the questions on the lab were very misunderstood by us and the TA's themselves… Also we did labs instead of worksheets which is helpful for us STEM majors! Although discussions were mandatory (graded) which is both good and bad...

A great teacher for teaching the basics of calculus, especially with his biological connections. Cared about answering students' questions, kept lectures light with jokes, stuck to questions similar to the homework for exams.

he is such a sweetheart. he genuinely cares about his students and spends so much time making the slides/simulators trying to make it easy. very approachable (literally gave extra credit for giving feedback on the course and teaching style). course is a lot of work for the lab manuals but it's rewarding if you put in the effort to understand it.
