The lectures are somewhat hard to follow but as long as you ask questions you should be fine. He creates large projects so be prepared for that. Make sure to go to discussions as they do count for the grade.

An absolutely amazing professor. He made the class so entertaining that I was excited to go every week. Conveys the material well and includes many relations to the real world in his slides to contextualize everything. Make sure to go to section because that's where most of your lab work will get explained and completed.

I really enjoyed the integration of biology concepts and calculus.  You are required to attend all discussions, but he drops two scores at the end of the quarter if you miss. Good lecturer and is 
very passionate about the subject.  He makes it clear what will be on the midterm and final, and labs are graded very generously

All you have to do is attend two sections a week. The lab is worth most of ur grade and is pretty easy since you work in groups through the quarter and can always ask the TA for help with stuff you don't know, they don't grade it harshly as a lot of it is just completion. He also makes it extremely clear whats going to be on the midterm and final.

I really learned a lot from this professor and i laughed a lot during this class! I felt the information was perfect for biology majors and the tests were curved since it was the first course ucsc has provided in this. He also was very upfront about what you needed to study to do well in the course. Very concept based but i loved it!!!

Amazing clear lectures that are easy to listen to. Not too much homework and not too time consuming outside of class if you stay on top of work. Wish I could've had Weissman for 11B as well, would've made it way easier.

Marty was a great teacher for the most part. The quizzes and HW were a bit tricky, but not impossible. The only thing I would critique is the examples he gives in class-- they're not always relevant or helpful in my opinion.  Also, sometimes he would randomly spend like 10min showing us how to code when we don't need to know that. But he's chill.

It's clear that Boltje really cares about math and about teaching, and has really passionate lectures. But he goes off on tangents and I'm never sure if what I'm learning is going to be on a test. I would expect his upper division classes to be amazing, but for a lower division class he never felt like he was fully on track.

Your grade is divided into 3: 60% final, 30% midterm, and 10% homework but if you get over a 50 you pass. I always went to lectures but the content needs more time to be taught so I had to do a lot of self-study. Don't take with him if you are expecting an easy A or don't want to put in extra work. The midterm was ok but the final was hard.
I really enjoyed the professor but prepare for a hard final and for the final to be more than half your grade. You can really tell how much he enjoys the topics he teaches.

Avoid this professor. His grading is too harsh and you're better off with another teacher. I would watch youtube videos about the concepts instead of going to his lectures. He often rambles and is too fast at times.

Lectures are very content and notes heavy, discussion sections are very useful. I had 100% before the final, studied all week (already knowing the content from AP calc BC) and felt super prepared. I came out of the final worried I wouldn't pass the class. I did learn a lot and liked the structure up until the end.

Took his 19B class and around series is when I went on YouTube and took notes there instead. He's a nice enough guy but his lectures are pretty boring and he's not the best at making concepts clear. In fact, I'd argue to say he makes them more confusing than they actually are. Not the best, but not terrible in my opinion.

Your grade heavily depends only on a midterm and a final, worth 30% and 60% respectively. The final had some concepts never discussed in class and his lectures are not much help unless you are already familiar with the material. If you do take this class I would recommend some YouTube course like organic chemistry tutor, his lectures are not clear.

Spends a lot of time on theorems and proofs which overcomplicates the class. I attended every single lecture and the amount of times where I actually understood something can be counted on one hand. Overall I learned nothing and I had to self study every day. While he could be good for other higher div classes he's just bad at lower div stuff.
Only three things in the grade book, I had the correct answer on the midterm but he dint count it because I had two answers written down.

Lectures were terrible. Wrote a ton of theorems and didn't explain examples clearly. Rushed through material each class and spent time on topics that were easy, without spending time on topics that were difficult. Decided that if you attended the lectures, you wouldn't need the textbook. I attended the lectures. I needed the textbook.

His lecture is mainly showing you a bunch of theorems and definitions in class. He rushes a lot in his class and doesn't go over each topic specifically with examples. People who learn through examples, please consider not taking his class.

- spend too much time on topics that were easy and none on difficult ones. 
-never had time to finish his lesson plan and would rush a bunch of theorums at the end of class. 
-homework was difficult because he was bad at teaching, it wasn't actually that much, or that ridiculous to ask given the coursework. 
-Evades questions.

I believe this class will be difficult if you've never seen proofs. Professor Boltje is a good lecturer but nothing that special. I can't find anything specifically bad to say about him.

The grading scale is different, you can pass the class with a 50%. The homework and exams are a little difficult. It might be hard to get an A, but easy to pass.
Amazing lectures and provides pdf notes. It is a difficult course , but it is manageable.

This class was ridiculously difficult when it came to both the midterm and the final, even the hw's were quite strenuous at times. The average score of the final was a failing grade, I mean what a joke. As a lecturer he's not bad, but doesn't have enough helpful examples. I must note that I took this class online during COVID-19.
Great lecturer, explains complex concepts in extreme detail. One of the best math professors I've taken and genuinely cares about his students.

Had him Fall '19, where we had lectures cancelled due to power outages. Homework is easy. Aced the midterm because he purposely made it easy. Only problem was the final. He only grades on answers only, and if an answer is similar to his answer key, you'll get partial credit. Answers written another way might be marked wrong, like I had done.

This class was , with the limited number of days due to power outages, clear and direct in what was covered; that is, no material was reviewed across classes. It is also to note that a standard format would be the introduction of the theorums followed by a symbolic reprisentation and a couple numeric examples. Homework was minimal: Webwork:3,4 p/d
He is a solid teacher with fair grading. I highly recommend taking a look at his old test which will help a lot. Stick with definitions and you will be solid. (B-A)

had him for math 19b online spring 2016. it was his first time "teaching" this class so the midterm and finals were much harder than previous instructors'. approachable at office hours. the quizzes were hard not gonna lie. but if you do his practice exams well, you'll do well. fat curve, so do well on the final and you got urself an A.

first and only time in my academic career ive 'failed' a class, if you value your sanity DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. I ended the course with exactly a 72.95% and received a D. Didn't realize until the final that their grading scale counted ANYTHING under a 73% a D (literally who does that). No extra credit/rounding, this class was literally the worst.

as someone whose not the quickest with math and who struggles with online courses, 19B is miserable and the profs don't help. lecture videos are often a waste of time and homework is overly challenging/tedious. exam prep rarely looks like the actual exams, especially for the final where they love to throw curveballs.

One of the few profs to still use ProctorU, which is essentially malware

Homework annoyingly long and unhelpful

Lectures were just read out of the textbook

Textbook did not really prepare for the homework well

Forced us to pay $80 for the eBook (you have to buy it to take the exams)

Just take the class at community college. It's cheaper, too

I have always been very passionate about math and pretty good at it as well. Taking this class sucked all the love for math I ever had. The lecture videos are just read straight from the textbook and do not prepare you for the homework questions and tests whatsoever. No partial credit for any amount of work or understanding, final answer or nothing

Nothing against the professor, I just had to learn on my own, if his videos work for some, then thats good, but myself and many I know couldn't relate. As long as you study hard you'll be fine. Perhaps doing the homework early too if you can, you'll have a lot more time to review since the class does have a lot of content in 5 or 10 weeks.

I gained so much knowledge learning from 19A and 19B. The professors aren't as bad as I thought they were. To succeed, make sure to create study groups with your classmates and focus on studying for HW, quizzes and exams. I would like to encourage you all to attend discussion sections for extra support and review difficult math concepts. Good luck!

Expect to either do a lot of self study or actually go to the discussion sections. Honestly, the discussion sections are the most useful tool you have, so long as they are in person (there weren't any this quarter). It is just so much harder to actually learn the material in an online discussion. Can't really say much else. This class was just ok.

If you have an ok understanding of AP Calc AB, you'll do fine for the 1/2 of the course. The second half is entirely new material that the lecture videos do a poor job of explaining. Learned a lot more from the TAs and YT. Quizzes and midterms are unproctored. Final is proctored. Final wasn't too bad just make sure to study. It makes your grade.

He rarely appears in any communication and is not helpful at all; the book cost me 80, ridiculous. Avoid taking him because of how he tough things by explaining the reason instead of the formula first; I spend millions of hours on understanding the reasoning, and it isn't gonna be useful at all in the test since u just need to memorize the formula

Got a 89.92 in the class, A on midterm, HW, and quizzes. Final average was a 60 percent and i was 20 percent above the median. (81/100) and he didnt round it. Pathetic. I feel robbed. Such a waste. All he said was “there has to be a cut off somewhere”.

DONT take this class if you want to learn anything. I took 19A and 19B online bc I got unlucky with my enrollment time and this was the only option left. I have not learned anything from the textbook they have or from the assignments. They also don't provide any extra help and all their responses are basically just "look at the canvas".

DO NOT TAKE 19B ONLINE IF YOU ACTUALLY WANT TO LEARN THE MATERIAL! Trust me, just wait to take this class in person. The lecture videos are awful(less than an hour of them per week), and you will have to teach yourself everything out of the textbook. You will unironically learn more from Khan Academy and YouTube then you ever will from this course.

DO NOT TAKE 19B ONLINE IF YOU ACTUALLY WANT TO LEARN THE MATERIAL!  Trust me, just wait to take this class in person. The lecture videos are awful(less than an hour of them per week), and you will have to teach yourself everything out of the textbook. You will unironically learn more from khan academy and YouTube then you ever will from this course

Cool professor, go to office hours he is a very nice person and will help you. Online class, the midterm was ez, final was pretty difficult tho I studied a lot. Wish I could take an in person class with him, but i'm not sure if he teaches on campus anymore.

I took his online 19b class and it was horrible there were multiple professors but it was so hard to get into contact with almost any of them. The exams were so much harder than the homework. Would not take again

The online version of this class is a scam, the profs should be ashamed. It's 5 credit class with less than an hour of recorded lectures each week. The class is entirely through an awful customized online textbook (which they were paid to make) and a Q&A forum which they lazily respond. UCSC doesn't have enough discussion sections for it either.

Don't expect to interact with the professors at all. They have an online discussion platform where they lasily interact with the students. They make you buy a $80 online textbook, and have less than an hour of recorded lectures a week. Get ready to spend a lot of time doing homework and teaching yourself.

In all its a very basic online course and easy to follow, yet still a rough go. The use of the textbook in relation to the assignments were pretty rough (with the addition of a tight schedule). I've failed this course before and I am hoping to pass this time. Just take the in person, this is no easier.

I took 19A and I'm currently taking 19B online with Frank. The lectures provided aren't very helpful. At this rate I don't even watch the lectures provided, I just watch YouTube videos because they actually give me the information needed to do the homework. What makes the class doable is that its online and the late work policy is pretty lenient.

The lectures are informative, but self-study is key. Utilize resources like the textbook, forums, and unstuckstudy AI to supplement the course. Attendance is mandatory, so don't skip class. Overall, a manageable calculus course if you put in the work.

Suh's a nice guy, but his class structure is confusing. Lectures can be interesting, but don't meaningfully prepare for exams. No review or practice for exams, coupled with the above, makes class content feel irrelevant. Exams contain content not covered in class in any capacity, again making the lectures feel pointless. Imo, avoid if possible.

Professor Suh comes to each class incredibly prepared and knowledgeable. He is happy to answer questions and wants students to grasp the material. Section attendance is checked with weekly quizzes that are very manageable. He expects students to understand the topics beyond simple applications, so exams can be challenging, but he grades fairly.

This class was difficult because it was really hard to understand what the professor wanted from the students, especially for the exams based on the 1000 page textbook. The final exam had questions that were not on the HW, and there was no study guide or cheat sheets provided. However, the concepts themselves were not that difficult to grasp.

Wonderfully good at teaching concepts. Homework didn't require much of you, but you can easily find similar examples from the textbook. The biggest issue was that feedback was never given on HW. Luckily there are many calculators online that you can use to double check your work. You should use the textbook when you can, it's free and very useful.

Is a great Professor if you seek to understand math from a theoretical perspective. Don't expect to just be fed formulas and perform computations. Suh emphasizes understanding the relationship between mathematical concepts and WHY we do things. Enjoys answering questions in lecture and has great office hours. Expect to invest time into understandin

Very knowledgeable and animated lecturer! He takes time to make sure he understands the nature of your questions to answer them correctly and enjoys answering students' questions the most. He also has really good office hours. While lectures are not mandatory, they essentially are since test questions are centered on lectures.

Professor Suh is great. Very personable and engages deeply with student questions, lectures were very interesting. However, 30% of the grade was midterm, 45% final, and 15% homework. He gives no practice exams, no advice about what to study, and super hard tests, also nothing posted on canvas (even grades). Lectures optional but needed to succeed

I am utterly disgusted with the level of service I received from Suh. The communication was abysmal, and I was left feeling extremely dissatisfied with my entire experience. Assignments were rarely given back and no scores are posted on Canvas. Tests included topics that were not in the textbook which the class was supposedly focused on. Horrible.

Worst math class I have ever taken. The problem is the lack of information given. The HW expectations are already impractical given that only 5/10 of it is taught or in the book, it reaches the point of absurdity when no answers are posted or allowed to be shared by the TAs so you never learn how to do it correctly. Suh did not care abt my concerns

Suh is an amazing lecturer who goes above and beyond on his lectures by providing greater depth to the general skeleton of content we are expected to cover in class. Although he does not always cover all aspects of problem solving, he provides in-depth theoretical framework, so I highly recommend studying and practicing from the textbook for tests.

The lectures were clear and easy to learn from. Assignments aren't super difficult, midterm was straightforward. The final, at least for this quarter, had issues due to adjustments made to shorten the final because of the current strike. We didn't have enough time to finish and our final was, in short, a disaster.

I believe that he is one of the best math professors in UCSC.

His lecture format is different from most other professors. However, he sprinkled in really cool examples within the lecture (Fourier transform, least square, etc).

Additionally, he is passionate about mathematics and teaching the subject.
Almost no hw!
Tests were challenging.
Take him

He is one of the worst professors I have had. For most of the quarter, the entire class was lost but no one seemed to care. The final was an absolute wreck. He shortened the time from 3 hours to 1. I don't know if a single person finished. I still have a feeling he won't curve, though. His lectures also do not help, you might as well learn yourself
Can not teach. DO not have him as a prof. No one knows what's going on in the class.

Man is absolutely horrible with upper div courses. I'm not a bad student by any means, I graduated with honors, but my god this man is horrendous. He clearly has favorites, and if you aren't one then you better hope you have no issues or misunderstandings b/c he'll be no help. Take a class w/ someone else. No lecture notes, no book, nothing to help

I should take the MATH replacement test again. I got 89.5 the first time, and 90 to replace MATH19A. This professor is harsh, with lots of mandatory in-class quizzes. No curve, no extra credit. Nearly all your grades are depending on your quizzes and exams. I learned AP Calc, and in 19B and 23A I got an A in both. Can you believe I got a C+ in 19A?
Overall, an amazing prof. Weekly quizzes that are worth 50% of your grade but he drops 2 homework assignments and 1 quiz. Really sweet and understanding and really cares about his students.

His lectures are fantastic. It's clear how much he cares about his students' understanding and well-being, putting in way more time and effort into the class than any other math prof in my experience. The hwks are hard but very fulfilling, making us think about the concepts we learned in new ways. I hope to take more classes taught by him

The first few weeks with professor Junecue I was unsure. He uses a different note style than most teachers, and his homework seemed far-fetched and require lots of thinking on the setup. But as time goes by I came to appreciate the efficiency of his notes, and his homework became so engaging for me that I always put it first on my do-to list. Great

His lectures were the highlight of my week. Deeply knowledgeable and brilliant, with high expectations of his students. Any algebra-related class he teaches will leave you wishing for a longer quarter, so as to prolong the experience of learning from him. Caring and respectful towards all his students. One of the best professors at UCSC.

Lectures were a bit long but he is very enthusiastic and engaged with the material. Homework was definitely tedious but helped prepare for exams. Overall I would say that he is not easy and demanding of his students, but getting a good grade is not that hard with proper effort. Was a great teacher and very passionate.

He is one of the few professors who I can definitely say the way they behave was truely distinct from how I felt about their assignment. Despite what some think, these two can often correlate not just that people are angry at the homework; and he was very understanding in considering a schedule when multiple students discussed it

Taking 103A (complex analysis) with Tamanoi right now. I don't understand the hate! I actually loved his class, and he explains very thoroughly. Sometimes he gets a bit lost in tangents, but he gives good and insightful lectures. Whenever I get confused by the textbook's proofs, his lectures almost always clears it up!
Challenging course, but Unstuck study helped a lot with prep. Professor's handwriting can be tough, but the free textbook is solid. Attend lectures, do the homework, and you'll do well.

Lectures are difficult to understand between the heavy accent and cursive writing. Assignments are tedious and hard to get through while not helping learn the material at all. The exams were way harder than assignments and almost everyone was underprepared for them. Also, no study guides and no calculators.

tamanoi isn't as terrible as people make him seem. while yes, it's a very difficult class, he's very thorough and slow when teaching concepts + the homework he assigns helps a lot! the TA's are amazing too! but bc of the difficulty, class avg was about 52%, but he curves like crazy

Jesus Christ, do not, I repeat, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS under any circumstances. This professor has the worst tests possible and is more concerned about teaching the history of calculus than actual calculus. His tests are so hard, and the final had a class average of 40%. The curve was insane, though, and I barely made it out with a B+.

If there is anything you can do to not take this class, do it. I got a A in MATH 11A and I worked so hard just to be constantly slapped in the face by this course. If there is no other option, take advantage of webassign, the textbook, and your TA. Those were the only things that kept me from failing. Good luck :)

This professor is pretty tough. His lectures are hard to follow and he doesn't provide many examples. The class averages on his midterms were around 50% each time. Be prepared to watch a lot of the ochem tutors videos. If you do a little above average on any test you can still get a good grade. There is a lot of hw so stay on top of it. Good luck..

He is an extremely gifted and intelligent professor, unfortunately he teaches as though we are on the same level as him. The homework is INTENSE, there is about 2-3 assignments a week, each around 10-20 questions, of which have several parts in them. Go to section, attend the lecture and be ready to teach yourself a couple of things.
He assigns a few hours of homework every two days. Get ready to work hard. He also teaches really quickly and doesn't do a lot of examples.

Will need a few days to process today's midterm. Many of us didn't finish and I barely had enough time to check answers. Brain = fried. Have to respect his passion for math, though. He'll enthusiastically explain who invented some theorem but will only have time for 3 examples in class, max. Will also finish a long explanation with "simple, right?"

It's obvious that Professor Tamanoi knows the content but he's not good at explaining it. He can very easily confuse you which makes the homework and quizzes very hard. The textbook is a great resource and teaches the content much better than Professor Tamanoi. Also very hard to read handwriting.

Those monkeys who rated this professor badly have a skill issue. There's no reason for people to fail this class because he's an amazing professor that thoroughly explains things to his students and is very understanding of uncertain circumstances. Amazing professor I would 100% take another class with this GOD SEND of a professor. W handwriting

Tamanoi was a great professor--he would try to answer questions students had during lectures. Some things to mind: He uses a free textbook and bases his lectures on it, and he writes in pseudo cursive in his notes.
Excellent professor, though a bit stubborn. Clear, fantastic lectures.

I enjoyed Professor Tamanoi's MATH 21 class. Although it was quite challenging, his lecture notes, coupled with the homework problems ( which there were a lot of ) helped with my understanding of the course material. While the midterms and final were challenging, they are easy if you understand the material thoroughly, and attend lectures :)
I'm over a year sober and I almost relapsed by taking this class. Worst professor I could have possibly gotten. Avoid at all costs!
Probably one of the worst professors you will ever have in your lifetime
Good lectures and notes, TAs are great, just an absurd amount of work and midterms plus the 200 points final. Feels outdated.
I had to deal with a traumatic loss in my family but she could not care and her grading is confusing and brutal.

God-awful teaching aside, her grading system is baffling. Not a soul, including our TA (who graded half of our work), understood what was going on. Rubric is if your work is deemed ‘proficient' which was horrifying to see her try to explain what that even means. Expect most hw/exam work to be correct and then still have to be redone.

On top of the ridiculous grading system that no one understands, this class has yielded the most unfair grading I've ever seen. Discrepancies in grades between identical work were consistently prevalent, and almost every assignment had to be redone because it didn't contain enough pointless fluff. Horrible, horrible teacher. Do not take.

Grading scale was horrible to understand at first but still overall very strange and annoying. Lectures were hard to understand since she speaks very softly and goes off on random tangents sometimes. Going to TA sections were really helpful in my learning experience, and the material isn't as bad as it seems.

I never experienced such a wacky grading scale through any math curriculum as much as this. Her lectures aren't great and she goes on random tangents every minute. Her class is not that difficult but the scope of passing the class wasn't clear until week 9 when there was a grading shift.

I have never felt the need to write a review about a professor, but I have had the worst experience with Debra. She yaps about irrelevant things when you ask her a question. she is extremely passive-aggressive when it comes to asking questions. She doesn't communicate well and honestly needs to retire Im not sure why shes even a professor.
All I can say is that she is a certified yapper

There was not a syllabus or schedule for readings. Tests reflected little of what was assigned. Lectures made no sense. Review problems for midterms were posted day before. Nothing posted for final to review because of covid19 but still had us take it while all other professor made finals optional. Not hard to pass, but unnecessarily stressful.

Listen -- I understand the negative reviews about Professor Lewis. Her lectures aren't great. She mumbles a lot. However, that being said her class isn't hard. If you learn a few things on your own you'll be able to pass no problem. That being said, she is incredibly nice and comes across as extremely intelligent, just not the best lecturer.

Horrible professor. Oblivious to students' other responsibilities. Assigns homework along with projects in addition to midterm, all within the same period. Mumbles to herself and makes it mandatory to go to class. Like what? Avoid her if possible

Very approachable person, but an awful professor. She has this stubborn belief of a "flipped classroom" where you practically teach yourself the materials, and as a result, her lectures in class simply don't correlate to the homework or make any real sense. If you need to take her, your best bet is hope that you get a good study group or a TA.

I'm sure she knows the material she's teaching, but what she talks about in lectures most of the time doesn't seem to be about, or at least connect with the current lesson. Learned more by reading the book and going to TA's discussion sessions. If you miss class for any reason, she will not repeat anything important as in "your problem not mine"

Professor Lewis was by far one of the worst professors I have ever had the misfortune of having. She goes off of a "flipped classroom", which is okay, but not in the manner in which she executes it as. I learned more from the textbook than from her lectures. In fact, I didn't even bother going to class after week 6 because of how pointless it was.

Honestly speaking, she is a good mathematician, but the worst professor I have ever met. If you are going to take her class, be prepared for following things: 1. hard pre-class quiz which is due before the lecture 2. arcane lectures which you will never understand unless you learned by yourself 3. you can never hear unless you sit at front rows

She is the worse teacher I 've ever had. The lecture is disorderly, she jumps from one point to another in few minutes. Sometimes have a quiz on class, so you should not miss some class. The MIT lecture she provides before every class is very useful. Strongly recommend watching the MIT lecture before classes.

Her style is all about crowd sourcing everything. She started off very bad, where the lectures were essentially Q&A sessions with pop quizzes on material you were expected to teach yourself. Now in week 8, things have changed a bit and she is covering material with examples and a lower expectation of self study. Maybe better in the future.

Takes too long to get her point across, often goes on tangents, & disorganized. She's a nice person but bad prof. Gave unnecessary projects that did not help me learn math. Cared more about the social issues regarding math than us actually improving our math skills. Going to class is pointless but she makes it a requirement.
Lewis is definitely a really sweet teacher although she does take a while to get to the point.

Often takes so long to get to the point of what she's trying to say. Requires attention while speaking and will willingly go around and slam your laptop shut. Makes us do more writing for the amount of reading than my core class. Gets too caught up in issues that should be discussed in sociology. Disorganized.

She is very unorganized and her lectures do not go with the subject at all. Its an online class so were expected to do 7 hours online also while doing pointless group projects. She spent the whole quarter teaching us about math in the outside world and non math things but not actual math. Although its an easy A if you do the work.

Literally never heard from him at all. Wasn't really active in the message boards. Did not teach. Did not interact with students. Idk why his name is even attached to this class. I learned nothing from him.

Longzhi lin is a very nice guy and its clear he cares about his students. However his online class is structured poorly. There are multiple professors but its hard to get into contact with any of them for help.

The online version of this class is a scam, the profs should be ashamed. It's 5 credit class with less than an hour of recorded lectures each week. The class is entirely through an awful customized online textbook (which they were paid to make) and a Q&A forum to which they lazily respond. UCSC doesn't have enough discussion sections for it either.

Lectures are him writing proofs w/o explanations of how the proofs are constructed. HW is about 6 hrs/week. HW is graded on completion, no answers in the back of the text, so the exams are the only time you get feedback. Harsh grader. Exam scores were very low. The math dept should get involved as Lin put in no effort to teach the material.

math 23B with these 4 professors are so tough. Even though I received an A in the class, it was still really tough since the test questions are mostly conceptual and your homework problems are only computational. It is hard to understand these conceptual concept only by reading the textbook.

Many of these reviews come from students who failed 19B (but lets be real) if its not that bad if you just watch khan academy to supplement the material from lectures. IDK about upper division classes but at least for lower div math I wouldn't worry at all. PS If you are a math major who likes calc, save yourself. Study CS or CE :)

NO! Never take this class with this prof. They dont have a global time zone for student to select and they wont change anything to help students when there was Covid-19 and a wildfire and everyone had to evacuate. They still decided to use proctor u and the final is SOOOOOO TOUGH.

His teaching was not the problem, his tests were. The final was unreasonably long and contained 4-5 proofs (along with computation) which are hard to bust out in such a short amount of time. He is a tough grader and gives very tough partial credit. Also, he's just not a nice person.

The accent is hard to understand. His teaching methods (the way he teaches the math, the steps taken to solve a problem) are very tedious and obscure. In retrospect, not attending the lectures would not have mattered for me, since I took AP Calculus AB and BC in high school and used those notes to self study, and is the only reason why I got an A.

Taking this my first quarter here was extremely demotivating and made me feel as though I was not as good at math as I had previously thought. The lectures are hard to follow, a bit also because of his accent, and it was hard to figure what would be on exams. It helps if you were ahead in math in high school and have done this material already.

Dr. Lin seems caring and is willing to work with you outside of class. Unfortunately, during lectures it's the opposite. He was unhelpful when answering questions, didn't give practice finals or study guides, didn't webcast, and went so quickly through proofs and examples that I couldn't keep up. I ended up teaching myself a lot of the material.

Lectures could be kind of confusing, and he focused more on proofs than examples in lecture. He was a really nice guy, but I think his lecture style could be a lot better. Also, I was lucky my TA was good. Overall, not a bad class, just put in effort and do hw.

His class is really hard to understand and makes calculus a lot harder than it should be. He seems like a sweet and good guy, just not a great teacher. Work hard, do your best and the curve will save you.

Makes calculus a lot harder than it actually is. Would recommend going in with knowing at least 50% of integral calculus because it makes things a little less hellish. Lectures were painful to sit through and were filled with proofs rather than the actual material we need to know for the exams. Midterm was ok I think but final was out of this world

19B with Longzhi was a bad experience. He's very unforgiving (which isn't a crime, I know), meaning no practice materials, no option for your final to replace your midterm score, etc. He's also just a bad lecturer. If he's your only option, just wait and take the class online.

Lin made the material very difficult to understand. Lectures are boring and hard to follow. You will basically have to teach yourself or very heavily rely on the TA's and MSI. I'm sure Lin is a nice guy who wants his students to succeed but he is a terrible teacher. Will never take again. Stay Away!

Lz made calculus very difficult as he spent more time on proofs than actually going over examples. Does not stop to make sure students understand and has a thick accent that is difficult to comprehend. Many people did not go to lecture and used the textbook to learn. He's a chill guy though if you go in to talk to him.

I honestly think Dr. Lin gets too much hate. He may be hard to understand at times, but you can tell he enjoys math and really cares that his students understand the material. He is super helpful outside of class, and answers questions well. Super chill guy. Keep in mind, though, as with any class, you'll only succeed by putting in the effort.
Like any math class, final and midterm will be 75% of your grade. He basically regurgitates the textbook in his lectures. D Nichols will be your savior.

He is terrible at explaining the material and makes many mistakes throughout his own lecture. He is really difficult to understand due to his heavy accent and he makes the textbook seem more complicated than it actually is. Also, the TAs aren't that useful either.

Pretty much copied off textbook/notes. Defns & proofs with little intuition & mediocre examples. Grade was ONLY tests & 1 point = 1% of final grade (and quizzes are 3-4 points per MC problem, no partial credit!). Saved by curve, although he wasn't very clear about it and made me stress about losing a single point on the final. 50-55% test avgs.

I took Professor Ginzburg for Math20A, but it won't let me put that. I really enjoyed this class! The professor was very nice and helpful when questions were asked. Technically, attendance isn't mandatory, but if you don't attend all the lectures, you will be confused because the lectures are just him talking and writing on a chalkboard.

He's not a bad guy but his lectures are pretty much him copying the textbook onto the chalk board, and your questions will often be met with "this was from my notes so I'm pretty sure I'm right". Also, CHECK HIS ANSWERS FOR THE QUIZZES. On almost every quiz, his "correct" answer was wrong and he had to give everyone full points for that question.

He's alright. You'll get used to his accent eventually, it isn't the worst. His lecture style is pretty boring but he really does try to answer any questions you ask him. Whether he answers them well varies.

Ginzburg is a good professor in that he is accessible and approachable and does his best to explain questions during lecture. You must do the homework in the class even though it's for no credit, in order to do well on the tests. Test difficulty is around the same as his practice tests, go to LSS!

He does a fairly good job at explaining everything. He does tend to skip steps and it often makes a few students confused. He says that homework will be collected at discussions but they never were, but there are two quizzes that are conducted in the discussions. Other than that, he has a strong accent and it's sometimes hard to understand him.
Great overall teacher and a brilliant mind. Tests are not easy but very reasonable. He teaches with lots of helpful examples and lectures are almost never boring. He is a genuinely funny guy.

Get passed the accent and fast pace of the course and he is a very good teacher. He teaches you exactly what you need to know for the midterms and his lectures (combined with some light textbook reading) make the concepts easy to understand. If you participate make sure your questions are good ones because he will be blunt.

I'm VERY surprised he has such a high grade on here. He is the worst teacher I've ever had... Whole lecture was in poor English and no teaching, strictly examples, then switches examples on the test. Really challenging tests, especially since his lectures didnt teach anything. Not clear, heavy accent, and just terrible class
This professor is decent, he goes at a pretty fast pace and his accent makes it unclear sometimes. I think I made it through because I had taken this course in community college, good overall though.
Very approachable, and caring guy.
Excellent professor, very approachable.

Great teacher. The textbook "Vector Calculus" sucks, but that probably isn't his fault. I am a transfer student, so this material was pretty much all review for me...otherwise it would have been a good learning experience.
He is a good teacher. His accent gets in the way sometimes. His tests are hard but test on the material you expect. Cool dude super smart.

Homework worth about 20% of grade and midterm and final worth the rest. For both tests he gives practice tests and goes over these before the test. He does move quickly from example to example in class but since I had taken this previously it wasn't too bad.

This guy makes the material way harder than it needs to be. Very methodical but doesn't explain why these concepts are important or how they are actually used (to calculate mass, work, etc). If someone asks him a question he can't understand he either ignores them or talks about something totally different. On the plus side, very quirky and funny.

Even though the course itself is difficult, Prof. Ginzburg teaches with a lot of examples. He also teaches fast, so we ended early sometimes! Lectures are concise, and sometimes he would made a goofy comment! The homework is from the textbook. He welcomes questions, and having a great TA also helps. Highly recommended for Math 23B!

He super cool. If you think he was hard, it's not his fault because the material itself is pretty hard. Although his lecture notes are quite messy, you could somehow still understand what he's doing. His midterm wasn't so bad neither was his final. Even if you didn't do so well, there's a nice curve to it. I'd recommend taking this course with him.

He is a good professor and he teaches well with a sense of humor. His accent isn't a problem and it is easy to understand. He likes to teach very quickly, which gets right to the point, but make sure you understand everything to pass the class, meaning know everything in calculus.

Amazing teacher, the lectures are absolute gold! The book sucks, and he makes absolutely no reference to it during lecture. He just teaches you the material and trusts you to do the reading if you need to. He teaches concepts and then does a TON of examples, which themselves teach you a lot. Take good notes and don't miss a single lecture!

Lectures did not have mandatory attendance, but discussion sections were effectively mandatory due to discussion quizzes being part of your grade. Both are helpful to attend if you are struggling on a topic. The class was very chill — if you read the textbook and/or pay attention in lecture, you will do great. Roozbeh is a nice and helpful guy.

hes the goat, non mandatory attendance and he gives plenty of opportunity to exceed, lectures are generally just some short explanation of a topic then him doing an applicative proof, if you just read the textbook and apply yourself you can never show up to class and get a B easily

He's a nice person but not the most efficient lecturer—he copies out of the textbook, including every single proof, although he at least tries to provide his own explanations sometimes. Tests & HW are usually from textbook and some problems are really hard; the class does not prepare you well for those (he eventually had to drop some scores).

One of the best professors I've ever had. I would 100% take him if you're enrolling in Math 3. Attendance is mandatory and TA's are very kind and caring, helping students with HW. All Homework Assignments are operated through Edfinity. $20-$40 dollars is the cost. Beware of Quizzes as well. Also, go to office hours for extra support. Best of luck.

I am very unsure how James has such a high rating on here. The content of the class is easy and midterms are structured in a way that is very simple. What pisses me off is that no matter what you learn it's not going to prepare you for calculus. If you care about math stay clear of James Upton.

james was a really cool guy to learn from! always so helpful and intentionally made things pretty easy for students. just go to lecture no matter what, he often finished early anyway. two midterms, one final project and a final, all in person. midterms and final were always less than 10 questions. very helpful and overall just a good lecturer.

Upton made me want to pull out all my hair and never wake up. If I could give him a zero I would. Honestly, worst professor I have ever had. His exams don't really relate to what we learn in class and his review questions DO NOT prepare you for the exam. The homework is also unrelated to what we learn in class.

Amazing teacher! Class was a breeze and lectures were really helpful because he guided you through almost every concept in a way you would understand. He answered questions in class as well. Homework was through Edfinity, assignments/quizzes were easy to get full credit on. And Midterm/Final were similar to the practice ones. Take him if you can!!
I'm terrible at calculus, and don't remember much of this class, but Upton was a super chill guy, very forgiving grading, and I somehow managed to get a B+. Can't ask for more than that.
Very good professor

Exams aren't weighted that much. Great professor. Was able to clear up any misconceptions during office hours. Very helpful. Grading was very easy. Overall a great professor and very good at responding to emails in a timely manner.

If you need a refresher from Precalculus in high school, he does pretty good. Tries to be engaging, but  lectures and voice sometimes come off as monotone and boring. Nice prof, homework is through Edfinity. Quizzes are also through Edfinity and are unproctored so you can just do it anywhere. Cheat sheets allowed on midterm and final.
He is an okay Professor. You will get bored at times but just go to office hours and you should be fine. He will curve the midterms and finals for an average of 70%.

Pretty good professor but the lectures themselves were sometimes confusing, often skipped steps and expected us to know what he was doing but he did answer questions if needed. Study guide was very similar to the actual exams which made things easier, homework graded on completion and overall was generous with grading. Would recommend his class.

Math has never been my strong suit but Professor Upton made understanding math 10x easier. Professor Upton focused on providing examples and making lectures clear. He was swift to respond to emails outside of class. Past students tend to say his study guides are similar to the final and midterm but I find that to be untrue.

Very glad I took this class! I've always had difficulty with math and I think he's one of the best math teachers I've had. Tests were super easy and straightforward. I recommend reviewing his slides and practicing them for midterms/finals! Super glad he records his lectures and they are are easily accessible on canvas.

I loved having James as my precalc professor. His lectures were incredibly clear and easy to follow, and he uploads all of them to Canvas after. Homework is a very reasonable load and the problems are very helpful. As someone who struggles with math he slowed it down and helped it seem less scary.

I took Math-3-01 (Precalc) and he is a great teacher. Put his lectures online for students who missed class so it was easy to stay caught up. Homework was only around 15 problems a week that covered all the concepts, unlimited attempts, and a helpful system that explained the answers. He made learning math easy. Very clear about test expectations.
Great professor. Lectures were clear and helpful. Homework also extremely helpful for test prep. Clear expectations and guidelines. All lecture notes and videos on Canvas. Fair grader.

This professor was helpful, thorough and taught concepts well with examples in every lecture.  His grading was lenient, as he dropped the lowest homework/quiz scores, with most weight going to weekly homework assignments that were useful and let you retry questions. I felt like I learned a lot of calculus, and had a nice experience learning it.

Professor Upton was a great lecturer. His notes were straightforward and easy to understand. Attendance wasn't mandatory for both sections and lectures and he recorded his lectures too. He was fair with all his grading. For tests we were able to have a page of notes which was really helpful. There was 4 quizzes, 1 midterm and 1 final.

Prof Upton was an excellent professor. I was pretty scared going into this class as I've never really considered myself a "math person", but James made the class very straightforward and easy to understand. He lets you have a full-page notecard and he doesn't make you memorize useless information - just the important details. Highly recommend!

Super nice, definitely sit in the front, ask questions during lecture! The homework is basically his whole class so make sure you study the online weekly assignments for tests. Talking to him after/before class is also a good move and I would definitely introduce yourself at the beginning of the quarter.

I absolutely loved Professor Navarro. I only went up to precalc in high school and despised it, so I never took AP Calc. I was a bit iffy going into this calc class because it's calc, but I genuinely loved it. Navarro made lectures so understanding and is extremely willing to help you outside of class. I completely recommend 11A with him!

Professor Navarro is a nice professor and is very passionate about math. ALL his exams are just like the practice exams: same ideas, just different numbers. However, I did not take math for a year so my skills weren't top tier, so I would recommend reviewing and just constant practice. A con is that his handwriting is hard to read, but you can ask

A very good professor overall. Lectures can sometimes be a little boring and confusing, but he has tons of office hours, and is super helpful. Tests are easy and identical to the practice test so even if you dont understand all the material you can still do well

I took him this quarter and he was genuinely so nice, his lectures are a bit fast but you can always ask him for help after, plus if you do the readings you will be just fine. his finals and midterms are also exactly like the practice midterms/finals he gives out so just keep up with understanding concepts and you will do well

Extra credit on homework when you do it a day early, mandatory (easy) reading quizzes before class, and you have to submit lecture notes for attendance. Incredibly easy class, but he has a very thick French accent, and he unfortunately writes like he speaks. You'll know what I mean when you attend his lectures.

He's a kind and nice guy, but speeds through lecture material pretty fast and assumes knowledge from the readings almost always, meaning you will have to do quite a bit of review on your own. I think you can do well in his class as long as you're on top of the workload and consistently practice the material.

Overall a very genuine and kind professor. Lectures can be a bit confusing however if you do the assigned readings prior to class and get an overall idea you will be prepared for lectures. Offers midterm and final practice tests that are 99% similar to the actual test.Very accessible and understanding. Would take his class again!
very nice and understanding teacher. takes the time to clearly explain coursework and will tailor the lectures to the class needs.

Well planned lectures, lots of in class activities. He does an amazing job making lectures useful to both people who just want to pass the class and people who are really interested in the subject. Tests were a bit harder than the practice exams he gave us, but still reasonable. Homework was light and useful. Hard working and accessible prof!

Caters to both those interested in theory and those who just want a summary for tests. Very helpful in-class practice and walkthroughs that math classes rarely have, taught like a high school class. Really cares, provided extra office hours during a strike. I really enjoyed his class even though diff eqs aren't really my area of interest in math.

Dimitri cares about making sure no students are falling behind and that the class is interesting for all majors. He has well-planned lectures with lots of examples, and the provides additional typed notes as reference material on canvas. For math majors or people who wish to understand more of the theoretical side, he encourages them to come to OH.

Made the class hard. No cheat sheet, not really accessible during OA. OA's also suck too because its often filled due to his "great" teaching. Lecture is just the book. Homework was excessive and hard. Tests intentionally made to be hard as well. Coding part is literally all him, did not bother teaching. Does not care abt the students. DO NOT TAKE!
must have been bullied back in the day and is taking it out on us, must feel really good flexing your phd and brains amongst a bunch of calc 1 students

If you see the name "Eion Mackall" on Math 11a or any other math class, run away, don't look back, remove the class from your schedule and take any other professor, ONLY take this class if you want to lower your gpa and if you have multiple years of experience in advanced python, because he will NOT teach you a lick of code despite it being a requ.

I hated this professor so much. He "teaches" insanely fast in small handwriting, so sitting in the back was NOT optional, he barely answers questions, and he doesn't record his lectures, which was the worst thing for me because I had to take pictures of almost everything that I couldn't get written down. There'sa lotmoreiwanttosaybutthere'snospace!

Do not take this class. Lectures were incredibly difficult to follow and were overcomplicated. You need to know Python coding in order to do the homework, which is simply unfair. Test averages were very low (50-60%). Not an approachable person to ask for help.

I have never met a more inadequate and inhuman professor. He does NOT care about you. Not only does he just read off the textbook for lectures but 40% of your grade is based on coding assignments, which he ALSO doesn't teach. Tell me how python coding applies to a calc 1 class?? Take any other prof, spare yourself.
eoin mackall is evil why am i doing python that you didn't teach in a calculus class. gives much higher difficulty work than the class level

Eoin gets a bad rap on RMP. He's a smart guy, and an okay teacher. Sometimes lectures can be taught about in a very technical way, it can be very hard to follow. Python though? Wasn't a fan. :(

Edit: Final was very hard. Cancelled it mid-test to give everyone a 100% because too many people were cheating. #cheersbrotha #brothathrewinthetowel

He is a tier 1 villain. He wants nothing to do with teaching, and makes a very easy course impossible to succeed in. For my math 11B half the class failed the course and then he sent us a nasty email saying that we all were "pushed through they system," and stupid. If you want to learn anything or keep a good GPA stay away

DO NOT TAKE THIS PROFESSOR. Expected to know extremely advanced python, and is worth a big chunk of your grade. Class average was a 52%, and blamed us for "not trying". Lectures did not help AT ALL. He is rude and passive aggressive when you ask questions. Gave everyone 100% on the final bc everyone was cheating (just bc everyone would have failed)

Eoin has genuinely been the worst teacher I have ever had. He overcomplicates the basics of calculus. The textbook is your only hope in passing his class. He places no regard for the well-being of his students. He does not do his job as a teacher to prepare you. Whoever gave Eoin the ability to become a teacher should have their PHD revoked.

Not terrible at explaining concepts, but often delves too deep into overly specific details rather than getting through everything required to learn. Forces students to learn Python despite no mention of it in the course description. Textbook is more reliable to learn from than his lectures. EDIT: 60 pts on the final were Python. In a calc course??

hes not hilarious. his CLASS is hilarious. hes actual evil. wants nothing good for his students. he had some nice moments, overall hated him as a teacher. he makes you CODE PYTHON in calc?!! pls explain why that is helpful to my learning, its NOT. he doesn't even teach it to you! eoin mackall you are the reason that my freshman GPA is going to TANK
genuinely evil

He is just a horrible professor, just really bad at teaching. He overly complicated the material and assign Python without teaching it. His lectures are not helpful at all. Luckily my TA Du is very good at explaining the concepts, made us study guides and have 5 hours of review session before every exams. He is the only reason I am passing.

Brags about how he FAILS EVERY STUDENT for a CALC 1 CLASS. 52% midterm average. Been told by other prof that he's unnecessarily difficult. Without TAs there would be NO STUDY MATERIAL. Gets ANNOYED if you ask for help in anyway. Also expects us to code in PYTHON and that takes up most of the homework so don't bother learning any calc in this class.

this guy is the worst professor of all time. he does not care about his students at all. obviously a smart guy, but an awful teacher. dont bother going to lecture, just read the textbook and you'll be fine.

Professor Mackall is the very definition of a bad professor. The way he teaches the class and just gives excuses on why everyone is struggling in his class shows irresponsibility in teaching. I learned absolutely nothing, but the fact that he ruined my college experience. Do not take the class. It's not worth it - trust me.

HE IS EVIL I TELL YOU!! I had to physically get dragged by my ankles to attend his lectures which weren't that helpful, I fear. He assigns python without even teaching it and barely gives any resources. He's rude to students when they have questions and barely clarifies ANYTHING. Please don't take this class if he's the prof, he's just mean.

This professor is terrible. His lectures are not structured, and when they occasionally are, he copies from the textbook. He gives random coding assignments that have very little to do with the class, and he spends no time reviewing them at any point (don't worry, they are only worth 10% of your grade). DO NOT take his class.

Professor Monard's lectures are amazing and notes are very helpful. He gives a lot of HW and it's tough, but his exams are easy. He is easily approachable and cares for his students' success.

If you genuinely want to learn, I would highly recommend taking his class!

Professor Monard has amazing lectures and is well structured. He gives us an easy midterm and a hard final, but the materials and study guide are really helped. He is really good and his lectures are charming. Everyone should take his class.

Professor Monard has to be one of the hardest professors I have ever taken however his lectures are amazing and well structured. Professor is very approachable and considerate as he really wants you to pass, but honestly the quarter is a struggle. But if you get through it, you will be so much stronger in math than before and genuinely interested.

He's really cool, and extremely accommodating to everyone's needs and concerns. He even made extra office hours in the evening for international students. His homework was pretty tough, and the final was too, but he gives you many resources, and has very comfortable energy. Highly recommend.

A true gem in the UCSC math department. Available at all hours of the day to answer questions and give feedback. While math 148 was the most difficult class Ive ever taken, the class was very rewarding and Professor Monard was extremely accommodating in regards to grading.
He is a sooooo good professor. Though the material was so hard, he managed to explain them to us in a clear way. Also, he made the lecture amazing!

Gives helpful instructions during office hours. Homework a little bit too much but really worth it to think the questions on it thoroughly. Also encourages us on Math by giving some interesting topics in calculus.
Real Analysis gets a fat curve, was really generous with grades and overall a pretty good professor.

Monard is a great professor He shows his passion for math. Math 20A was only difficult because the material was difficult by itself. Monard walks with you to help you become very successful in his class. He is amazing at explaining very abstract concepts to an average person and knows when material is too difficult for us to understand on our own.

Francois is passionate both about the math he teaches and his students' success. The lectures are fast-paced and the homework is very difficult, but he is very helpful in office hours. Although I took 20A instead of 19A accidentally, the class was worth the time and effort it took. Be ready to work extremely hard but learn a lot.

Professor Monard is amazing. He has great lectures but goes a bit fast due to his deep-deep knowledge of Mathematics. In office Hours he is very helpful, therefore I highly recommend going. His homework requires a lot of work and thinking and his tests are fair if you study and understand the notes beyond memorization. I really enjoyed the class.

Monard has a minor French accent but it is still easy to understand him. He is helpful during office hours and his lectures are in-depth and full of examples. His tests aren't too hard. The practice tests he gives are very helpful.

I got an A in the class therefore I love him. I never thought I could do well in class. He has good lectures, although hard to pay attention so early in the morning. He gives reviews, study those hard and go to MSI and you should do well. Midterm easy, final SUPER hard. But everything is okay because he curves everybody final grade to a B.
Nice lectures. Very accessible in office hours. Nice when you ask for help and has a good humor. Pay attention to get the A.

Professor Monard was a very helpful professor who supplied resources and study materials for tests. We had quizzes every week and discussion is mandatory. Sometimes he went a little fast in lecture but just go into office hours with set questions for extra help. The tests were similar to homework and practice tests.

Take the online version instead!!! 

Your success in this class literally depends on how fast you can give up learning from him to turn to learning on your own online. The longer you wait to more behind you'll get. The midterm and finals are super hard and unforgiving too where the average was ~40%. No free points, barely any partial credit on them

he can't teach for the life of him, please do not waste your time. he doesn't wanna be there 10x more than you don't want to be there. often times he will get into self-proclaimed flow state and do the math without explaining it. IS VERY RUDE WHEN ASKED QUESTIONS “You shoudlve known this in your previous classes, moving on.” absolute CHUD

do not take this prof. he does not teach, he just expects you to already know the topics. spends time teaching things like proofs that are never tested. tests are unreasonably hard and does not give a lot of partial credit.

The way that he teaches through lectures is tough to understand. He does problems on an iPad and projects on the screen. It's almost like he assumes you know the stuff already before even being there, and you go in and out knowing the same amount as before.

Lectures are kind of hard to follow as it's proof-heavy, a lot of self learning required. I watched the organic chemistry tutor. We had 3 group projects; the rubrics were slightly unclear for them. The midterm was kind of hard; however, the final was pretty easy. Final grade gets curved, for reference, I ended with an 89 which translated to an A.

Calc2 is just really hard, but he kinda make it more hard. His curves are really high. After he graded the final my grade was at a C, but his curve brought my grade to a B-. Only take him, if you have no option. I recommend taking the online class if you can.

He posts notes from class after each lecture. Homework is about 15 questions per week and counts as much as the final. I thought tests reflected homework and example problems, but make sure to review. I took calculus in high school which may have helped. There were 3 group projects, but they weren't difficult and had office hours for questions.

It is almost unethical how bad this class was. So many of these reviews were reliant on The Organic Chemistry Tutor (myself included) which goes to show how unhelpful his lectures were. Not to mention the class was at 8 in the morning and his monotone voice and proof heavy lectures made it very hard to follow anything he was saying.
He is the worst. It's definitely his fault lectures are confusing and he never really explains concepts. do not take him.

Overall, your average math professor. He sometimes explains proofs and such that are unnecessary for those who aren't a math major/minor

BUT overall good professor and very available to help in any way.
He's kinda funny but don't expect to learn anything when you go to his lectures. I had to watch youtube videos to learn all the concepts. Shoutout organic chemistry tutor

Lectures were focused on proofs which I respect. I used YouTube if I needed more help and he was helpful in office hours. I put in an adequate amount of time studying for tests (8 hrs a week) and I did well. It IS Math19B so I didn't expect it to be super easy. Take the class if you are truly passionate about stem.

He is an okay guy, idk why ppl review bomb. You gotta realize that calc 2 is like a hard class and it's not really his fault. That being said he sucks at making review for exams. For almost every subject I had to use organic chem tutor to relearn topics, you're going have to review stuff multiple times regardless cause this course sucks in general.

DO NOT take 19B with Jiayin this class actually killed me. NTM it was also an 8am. He makes the class harder than it actually is and I never actually learn anything from him. I used youtube and quizlet and I'm still cooked. #shoutout to professor Leonard. only plus is that attendance isn't mandatory but encouraged.

(Nov8) Teaches like he expects you to already know the information and could explain a little bit better. Super chill as a person, but tough in the way he teaches.

(Dec 8)Update: DYING

Calculators are not allowed, class are fast, exams come with useless formulas, and you're expected to figure everything out on your own. The review materials are confusing, limited, and GATED with SETS rate for entire class LMAO.
I studied 20 hours a week and still failed the midterm, this teacher made me an alcoholic...
You are cooked

The class average for the midterm was 42%. His lectures were often very hard to follow and random at times and overall the class was not helpful. Additionally, the midterm problems practice (or study guide) was quite different from the questions on the actual midterm. If you do not study for a few hours a week outside of class, YOU ARE COOKED.
worse class i have ever taken in my life. Would rather live in delhi india than do it again

This professor is groovy. Knows the maths inside and out, explains it with mojo, and actually wants you to succeed. Lectures are sharp, exams are fair, and office hours?. Work hard, baby, and you'll be smooooth. 5/5.

He's really funny. 65% of your grade is free cause 50% is homework and discussion which are both really easy. And 15% is projects that is impossible not to get 100% on. That's the positives. He can't teach at all. The worst thing is his grading and curving of the tests are not clear at all. He basically just makes the curve up randomly.

Very kind and it's obvious he enjoys math. That does NOT mean he can teach. Attended every lecture, took notes, completed the homework, got private tutoring + help from students. Not once did we know what he was teaching or how to do it. UNBELIEVABLY unorganized. Got the B from homework on completion 40%, section 10%, random project, midterm, final

Take this class if you have the change. he literally explains EVERYTHING. tests are kind of hard but if you put in the effort  and go to lecture, you can do it. he also posts all grade info to Canvas which is helpful

don't take this class unless you have to. he literally does not explain anything at all. tests are kind of hard but if you put in a lot of effort to learn the content yourself, you can do it. he also doesn't tell you your actual grade which is very annoying
Calc was a grind, not gonna lie. Limits punched me in the mouth, derivatives hit harder—but the structure was clean, practice paid off, and by finals I felt dangerous. Show up, work hard, you win.
Literally does not explain EVERYTHING!!
Literally does not explain ANYTHING. Nice guy

Bro this class actually SUCKED. He can never give a straight answer to anything, because he doesn't know anything. Save your GPA, and your sanity, and take this class with ANYONE else. Every lecture was difficult to sit through, and the midterm made me cry before, during, and after. I genuinely regret not dropping the class when I had the chance.
Don't even TRY!!! Spare yourself NOW!! Please take my advice. If you see this and think you'll be fine and you'll figure it out?! YOU WON'T!! Take this class with ANY other professor! Seriously.

This class was super unorganized, and the lectures felt pointless. I had to teach myself everything on my own and sometimes in discussions. He also never really gave a straight answer when u asked him questions plus canvas was blank and says grade on canvas isnt ur actual grade so u have no way of knowing how ur doing in the class.

Would not recommend this class. Showed up late to midterm, very unorganized, lectures are pointless, canvas is completely blank, and doesn't answer questions straight up. I only learned from youtube videos and sometimes discussions.

Yo yo WHAT UP droppin' a review: Doc Calc class got crunch. Lectures crisp like fresh chips, quizzes spicy but snackable. Dude explains integrals so smooth it's basically math ASMR. Homework chewy but fair. Would 100% take again, homiez.

Professor Jesse Kass seems like a nice and caring professor.  However, his class felt super unorganized and his lectures could be confusing at times.  I wish he was more structured and we had some idea on what we were going to learn each lecture.  I felt like I learned more from the TA during discussion than from him.

Jesse Kass is possibly the worst math teacher I've ever had. If possible, take math with any other professor. His lectures are confusing and unhelpful, and the only time I learned anything was from the TA during discussion or from YouTube videos on the subjects. He cannot answer questions about what he is teaching or clarify on information.

Prof. Kass was willing to communicate but there isn't much to say about how well that communication is. On another note, lectures felt pointless, showing up everyday and yet, somehow, we were on one problem for multiple days with some lectures ending in a "cliffhanger." Furthermore, two days before the project was due, he made it a group project.

Jesse's class was not well structured. This was his first time teaching 11B and that was very apparent throughout the entirety of this quarter. He does not give straightforward answers and does not provide clarity when asked direct questions about exams. Our project also got turned into a group project two days before the due date. Don't take him.

Worst math teacher I've ever had. He somehow managed to confuse me on topics I had already learned. His lectures are utter nonsense, as he goes into excessive detail on concepts that are not even covered in the course. Overall, a very sweet and funny man, though he should retire immediately and never come back for the good of education as a whole.

He is the worst teacher I've ever had in my entire life. I took math 11A confident I knew what I was doing and got a great grade in that class. I come to math 11b and everything I thought I knew flew out of the window. Showed up late to the midterm and cut our time down towards the end of the test. DO NOT TAKE HIM. (he def wrote the good reviews)

"Jesse's class is an ADVENTURE. For the exam, he said 6 questions and delivered 6 EPIC SAGAS because superficial learning? Not in this house. No cheat sheet allowed because Jesse believes you should BECOME the formulas. It's calculus boot camp but you emerge a derivative demigod. LSS is clutch, sign up yesterday. 10/10 would integrate again."

Montgomery, cares about his students but I think it was hard for him to teach lower div math. He went off in tangents at times about proofs but yeah. He is also more "old school" because he assigned homework from the textbook and not on Web Assign or Web Work like other math professors. He's a chill guy though, just kind of scattered/unorganized.

He is such a kind person. Very respectful when asking questions or simply dont understand. Sections are also a key part of this class. You will learn basically 50/50 lecture and section. He most definitely wants us to learn the material and understand why its applied. Wish I could take another math class with him.

My recommendation to people needing to take his class is to wait for another quarter when another professor is teaching it. The only reason I even passed his class is because of COVID and he let us use our first midterm grade as our final grade. His lectures were awful and he doesn't explain anything. Get ready to teach yourself the entire course.

This is the worst math class I have ever taken. I have not taken calculus before this class and he was not beginner friendly at all. His lectures jumped all over the place and he extremely unorganized. He was the only professor available for 11A this quarter and if I had known that he was this bad, I would've just waited to take it in the spring.

I came in knowing nothing about calculus but he made the class an easy pass. The midterm was only 13 questions and the problems given were almost exactly like the practice midterm he gave us prior just with different numbers. He does only grade one problem on the homeworks ,but if you attend class he tends to do the problems if you just ask.

Probably the worst professor ive had at UCSC. Homework doesnt correlate to what is actually on the tests. Grades the homework off of one problem and is all or nothing. Doesnt teach with his own work, uses students work. No one shows up to his class not because its hard or early in the morning but because it is useless. 0/10 would not recommend.
the most useless lectures I have seen. never teaches, only shows examples made by students. it is a travesty that im paying money for professors like this. he sucks.
I enjoyed his class. I took it on online and failed but when I took it with Montgomery he helped the concepts become clearer.
He cares about students and will answer all math questions if you ask. I really like him.

Montgomery doesn't seem to realize that many of his students have never done calculus before, but would rather talk about Newtonian physics. Maybe an upper div math class would be better with him. Do not recommend.

Don't take him period. He briefly went over 19A material and eventually went beyond into 19B. You really need to self study, go to MSI, do more work than what he gives you to even scrape by. His midterm was fair, but the final was not. The study guide barely covered the final. The final grade was based on the final which half the class failed. RIP
I never taken calculus in high school, so taking this class was IMMENSELY difficult. He goes over material beyond 19A. Not an effective professor.

Montgomery mostly talks about proofs on class and assumes you already know everything about calculus. We skipped 4 chapters in the beginning of the class. I mostly had to self-study online. The final was completely different from the practice quizzes, no wonder more than half of the students got less than 50%... Avoid this professor!

Montgomery went over content that was further than 19A. His lectures aren't the best, but he does go over questions that will be on the test. The homework isn't very helpful and neither is sections. His TAs are average at best except Salvator. In the end the grade was based off of what you got on the final instead of whatvis in the syllabus.

Be careful with this course. His class is quite messy and not so well-structured. However, to get through this course DO follow his studying methods. They are insanely helpful. Have an actual study schedule and a study group. Practice problems and do your absolute best to understand concepts. Read the book and thoroughly understand the concepts.

Richard delved into material beyond 19A during lectures (all the way up until finals week) which I think confused most students. However he didn't really test on any of this material except Integrals and even then it was very basic knowledge. I felt his midterm was fair to the material and his final was pushing it a bit but still fair.

While he is obviously passionate about math he should never be allowed to teach an introductory calculus corse. He obviously finds the basic material boring as he more or less skipped all of it. The class he taught was far closer to a 19b class or beyond than an intro course. Stay away from his lower division courses.

Professor Montgomery's Classical Geometry class starts off enjoyable and easy, going over high school level stuff. After the midterm though, the class turns to non-Euclidean geometries, and everything flips. He isn't effective at teaching the content, and the homework becomes very difficult. He can also be very spacey and unorganized.

He's not great at teaching lower diversion math classes. Expects you to know a lot before going into the class as well as teaching material for next quarters class. I was learning stuff for 19A and 19B

While Richard is stellar at speaking and very good at engaging the class, I feel as if he hasn't really taught us much about calculus, but instead expects us to know a fair amount. Not only is he having us skip limits, the basis of calculus, but he spends most of the class just going over problems and expecting us to know how to solve them.

Amazing teacher. Made lecture super fun. Really went above and beyond. Was accessible before, during, and after class. Really cares about his students. Grading is weird. There are a few tedious writing assignments. Covered and tested on material outside the scope of the course. You have to learn from examples in class.

Definitely a top 5 professor I've had at UCSC. Lectures are formatted well and are very engaging. However, there are a ton of random and kind of easy-to-forget-about assignments that are due randomly throughout the class- so be on top of that.

Great guy, really made the class enjoyable and the math approachable. I really liked what we covered proofs and it's great foundation for higher math classes in the future! He is really reassuring and understanding too. The worksheets in class were great group practice as they basically guide you through proofs that would be pretty hard alone.
