Basically, it is the easiest class i have ever taken. Attendance is mandatory, because of the quizes. There are these four little paragraphs that you have to write in class, which gets annoying. He plays a lots of music in the class, which is a lot of fun.

Homework done in groups, lectures are broadcasted on Zoom and recorded so attendance was not mandatory. Feedback for assignments did take a long time to get back. Homework was a little challenging but done in groups so it was manageable. 1 MT and final - not too hard if you do the examples from lectures. Makes the materials easy to understand

Not the best at lecturing as it's very hand wavy and very abstract and he does on tangents so it's very easy to get lost so once you get to the HW assignments it is quite a shocker. But once you take the time to figure it out in ur team, at section, or at OH, it's challenging but doable. And the exams are very doable if you do in class examples.

"easy" and fun cs class. 3 projects, 1 midterm, 1 final. HIGHLY RECOMMEND TAKING THIS WITH A GROUP OF 4 FRIENDS. homework is doable alone but would be kinda challenging. Midterm and final weren't too difficult too if you did well on the projects. Prof was really nice and understanding. Not great at replying to messages fast or at all sometimes.

At first I was daunted by the premise of NLP but Flanigan was very reassuring, patient and helpful in teaching. Homework was a good mix of challenging but not too difficult and was graded based on effort. Quizzes felt easy and truly reflected the exams. Overall I felt that I learned many things of value while not being pressured too much. FlaniGOAT

He mostly teaches graduate classes, so the class felt a bit awkward. Overall, felt a little disorganized but not to the point that it was stressful. He promised 10 quizzes, be we only did 2. The final and midterm were online and very easy. Lectures were recorded, on zoom, and in-person. Grading was very lenient. You could pass with little effort.

Very accessible professor, exams were based on lecture concepts with no tricks thrown in. If you attend lectures, you should be able to get a really high score. Group projects were also pretty manageable and the professor was readily available for questions. As long as you put in effort into projects, there's no way you get lower than a B.

His first time teaching this class was extremely disorganized with lecture and assignments but he made that up with alot of help resources and extensions. He and the tas worked hard all quarter to come up with a new class design which was really well thought but resulted in directionless lectures. Group projects are fun you learn alot if you do em

She's great at teaching, super nice, and relatable. She's younger, so she's much more in tune with the times, and her humor is good. His teaching style is awesome because she's more focused on learning and getting familiar with the material rather than grading hard.(The final was super low stakes.) Overall great teacher.

Dr. Raja is great, she's always willing to listen and learn from her students, and I felt respected when I was in the class! Class was mostly discussing readings given for homework, but she has said that she's planning on changing some plans so make class more enjoyable and encourage participation. Lots of reading, but she grades very leniently.

The RCC core class is not difficult and there is not a crazy amount of work, and she does a really good job of keeping class discussions interesting and engaging. You can tell she is passionate about the topics covered and she's also really really nice and is always willing to talk about anything. I would recommend taking her class.

Always keeps classes engaging through different activities. Each reading you do 2-3 sentence answers for HW based on questions given to you. Very chill to talk to as well. There's a group project throughout the year where you do a paper and presentation about an issue in society you and a group of people choose. Very easy and fun teacher overall.

Don was a great professor. He made me really feel supported and he was the first professor I felt who really cared to know you on a more personal level. This class is a really fun way to study plays and playwrights who are BIPOC. Don brings such fun energy to his classroom and conducts it like a big family.

If Mr. Williams is good at anything, he can rally a group. While he's not the best professor or lecturer, if you can make a personal connection with Mr. Williams, it's worth it. He sticks his neck out for students and while he's old fashioned, he has a lot of wisdom to share. He'll make you work, but you will learn a lot of real, on the job theater
This was the worst class I have taken in college yet, by far. Disorganized, chaotic, random I dont know where to start. It sounded interesting and ended up being a complete waste of my time.

I recognize that a lot of students loved this class and really appreciated everything in it, but for me I was really disappointed because it really just felt like an ad for Rainbow Theatre. I also hated the lack of structure in the class and in Rainbow Theatre when I tried to be a part of it. I think he's a great guy but the class frustrated me.

With as short of an attention span as mine, Professors like Mr. Williams make it really enjoyable to be in class. I had to take this class as a GE to graduate, and while I understand the subject matter is very important, I wouldn't really take any other classes like this unless it was mandatory. That said, the class was an excellent experience

This class is easy. Show up, do the reading, and write your papers. He doesn't ask for much and most of the time he just likes to talk to the class. He cares about his students for sure. He is pretty easygoing just don't push it. The reader is $65 which is wack but whatever.

Don is a real nice guy who wants everyone to succeed in his class and in the future. He provides oppurtunities to get involved in theater at UCSC and connections for internships/careers if interested. His lectures are pretty interesting. Overall if you put in some effort his class isn't bad. Do the reading, it's good for you.

Easy class, grade is determined by attendance I would say. A few essays, but they are graded really easily. Do yourself a favor, get the E.R GE out of the way, and raise that GPA. Take this class. Easy A

Does not lecture about material as much as his own dogmatic life lessons. Williams does not hesitate to embarrass students if they do not complete assigned homework or if they come to class unprepared. Uses movies to teach about material.

Don is a very passionate person who does a great job of creating spaces for people of color in theater. However, it is important to think critically about the plays that you read and see because often they are not as socially conscious as you would expect and Don is not one to mention or even notice the subjugation of certain communities.
Easy teacher. Not alot of reading and he rarely checks whatever reading assignment he gives. Watch alot of movies but is pretty motivational when he talks about life.
AMAZINNNGGGG!. very fun and inspiratoinal. he doesnt just teach about theater., but it all ties into life.He allows us to find ourselves as a person. did i mention he sooo entertaining. lol

Don is an alright teacher. Although we don't really learn much about theatre - I guess its something you learn by doing rather than being taught. Lectures are more like inspirational speeches.Still, one of the most fun classes you'll ever take. Improv games are fun! Readings are plays that Rainbow does, and last (and first) essay is easy.
No Comments

Chris is a great professor and made the statistics part of ESCI160 really easy to understand. The actual coding using R is not taught in the class, but he does provide video tutorials with the homeworks and is helpful in office hours.
Stats was taught in class, coding you basically teach yourself online but he's clear about expectations.

he was very understanding to students situations by keeping a zoom lecture and in person at the same time. The only downside was trying to get the blackboard notes since I knew no one in the class. Homework was easy and engaged you to understand material more. pay attention to the lectures mostly since they show up on the test. easy and fun class!

Honestly the best prof. you could ask for. Chill, caring, nice, does funny demos in lectures. It is a test heavy class. There are four in-class tests (worth 40%) but final is only worth 15%. But he drops 1 lowest test grade out of 4 because he is an awesome person. If you literally pay attention to lecture slideshows, tests are easy. Def recommend.

Amazing professor and super engaging! As someone who has trouble paying attention during lecture, I was so incredibly engaged. He has a way of breaking down difficult subject matter and making it understandable for anyone. I HIGHLY Recommend to get him as a professor! Thank you for the amazing class Professor Edwards!
Love this professor! You can tell he loves teaching and is super respectful and fun to be in classes with

Edwards is an amazing professor, he is very understanding and is very passionate about what he teaches. The biweekly tests can be difficult but he outlines all of the points from the chapters that need to be studied. There is online homework assignments that can take up to two hours usually twice a week. YOU NEED TO GO TO CLASS IN ORDER TO PASS.

Chris is amazing at his job. I'm awful at math, but he made the math-ier bits as easy for us to learn as possible. His lectures are SUPER understandable (he says he isn't funny, but he's got this lovable professorial humor), he's accessible and friendly outside of class, his homework is doable and well-made. Cares about what he does. Thanks, Chris!

Prof. Edwards is a great professor and lecturer. The class was super lecture heavy, but slides are posted online too. Really makes you work for that A. Office hours and section are super helpful and I highly suggest attending those. He also came in the day before the midterm and final to help us review the material, which I thought was super nice.

I really enjoyed this class. There were hwk assignments every 2 weeks so it was manageable and as long as you do well on those, you'll be fine. Definitely attend the lectures, he does random checks for a grade and that's where you get all the information. He's really understanding and takes students opinions into consideration. Definitely recommend

Chris truly strives to get students engaged in the subject, and does an excellent job doing so. He changed his curriculum a little bit this quarter with the use of a virtual textbook, which had a few problems, but he was understanding whenever an issue arose. Very interactive lecture, and his hilarious+genuine personality are great. Fantastic class

He is a great professor. Go to lecture and you will do fine. He has power points that are confusing but he writes on the board the crucial info, and if you just write down everything he writes down, that's all you need to know. Tests aren't hard at all, just basic concepts. Don't panic when he tells you that there is coding for hw, it's very simple

Chris is extremely knowledgeable and passionate. His class reflects this and moves at a fast pace. The homework can be really tedious, but its worth a lot of your grade which is nice. The lectures are pretty engaging, but to get your desired grade your definitely going to have to attend section or tutoring regularly. Good class, a decent workload.

Chris is an amazing teacher and I feel like I really learned a lot in his class. His class is divided into 5 major homework assignments and a midterm and a final. The homework is worth 70% of your final grade so it is really important that you try and do good on those.. Go to section, the TA's are really helpful in explaining the homework better.
Hes a wonderful professor with a good sense of humor. He really wants you to understand what hes teaching and is very approachable.
It was a fun class, just go to lecture and do all the hw and it's not that hard to get an A. Going to section makes it a lot easier too. He's a nice guy and it's easy to get help on stuff.
Professor Edwards was so helpful whenever I was confused about anything but the homeworks were tedious and the class was slightly harder than I expected.

Chris is amazing! His lectures are very informative, and he explains everything super clearly and in all the detail, making sure that everyone understands the material well. There was quite a bit of homework, but if you attend and pay attention, then this class is really easy. Multiple choice exams. Gives lots of extra credit opportunity as well.

I think Chris is a kind teacher who cares about his students and gives many opportunities to succeed such as extra credit. He's passionate about the subject and you will feel supported in his class. He doesn't explain statistical concepts incredibly well but he's not a statistician so I can't really fairly expect this from him.

you can tell that he is passionate about his subject. However I felt that he over complicated some of the concepts making it harder then needed for students to understand, as well as feeling like his tests focused more on memorizing specific information rather then comprehension. Oh and his funny little dance to erase the chalk board lol.
Really caring professor. 10/10 would recommend.

His lectures were super interesting, and I learned a lot in this class. I definitely recommend taking a class with him. He cares about his students and is very passionate about what he is teaching. He doesn't assign work excessively allowing students to have time to really become interested in the material, without feeling pressured by grades.
Makes it very easy to understand content. Fun class and easy GE. Quizzes every week reflecting material helps for midterms and final. plus textbook not necessary so save yo lunch money!
I <3 Jerome

I took OCEA80B with Professor Fiechter Winter 2021. He is a very nice professor and the class is very interesting. It is also not challenging, it consists of activities once a week where participation is graded, quizzes, and the exams. If you watch the lectures and focus on the lecture slides you will be set.

Nice person, but bad teacher. Lectures cover many topics but none in depth. Tests are all memorization and also very confusing. She is very intelligent and has a vast grasp of the topics that she is teaching. Only take if her if you have a very good memory.

She's funny and super chill at 8am. Do your work and study up on the material. If you need clarification, grow up and go ask for answers. She will explain it in 20 different ways if you asked her to as long as you can understand the concept. Quizzes are open book, and you can find some of the questions in the midterms. Study guides are great too.

she's in her 20's, she doesn't seem to have much experience teaching, and seems like she likes hearing herself talk. she goes into lots of detail for an intro GE course and tests you on specific facts rather than conceptual knowledge. Personality is like a grown-up astrology girl, which can get annoying, but her enthusiasm is nice.
She was a wonderful lecturer, and the slides were very information heavy. There is a pretty heavy group project, but she is always open and gives feedback to help guide along the way.

Kendra's lectures were great. Very informative without being overwhelming and allows time for lots of questions. The group grant-proposal was a large part of our work for this class, but she provided a lot of extra office hours time for this project. She is great to talk to about career and internship ideas as well!
Course was straight forward; involving weekly assignments, a take home midterm, a take home final exam, and a group report due at the end of the quarter.
Tests online. Homework isn't long.

Why does this class have no prerequisites? Biochem component is very difficult and would benefit from prior coursework. Kendra is also unable to talk about biology without making complex unnecessary references to phytoplankton. Slides go by quick and are super dense. She is very smart but does not have a knack for making info digestible.

I really enjoyed his lectures. He genuinely wants people to care about marine life, and understands that his class may not be your top priority. Lectures tended to end early, but he would do in class assignments typically every week. They were super easy though, as he just wanted us to apply what we learned to things we cared about. We wrote poems…

He is pretty chill, just lectures and then weekly readings and quizzes but they're easy and open book so don't worry. The final is open note and book. He talks so fast in lecture I can't keep up actually a mile a minute. If you're bad at science like me maybe don't take but it's not that bad.

Dr F is one of the best teachers/ professors I have ever had. The class was engaging and interesting, and even though you could probably get away with 'cheating' on most assignments and quizzes (they are all take home) his passion for the course content was infectious and motivating.

I loved Ari's class he is super passionate about the ocean and his class was very interesting. There was a good amount of reading for homework each week but exams were non-cumulative and open note with extra credit so I did very well. I recommend this class for a GE if you don't mind a bit of reading and want to learn more about the ocean!

If any of you show anything less than complete and total engagement with Ari's class content, I will personally forcefully push you through the baleens of a blue whale (something you'd know if you decided to pay attention).

Took this class as a random GE and it turned out to be my favorite course that quarter! He's super chill, all the notes you need to take are provided on his slides during lecture so as long as you show up and take decent notes you'll be fine. Both the midterm and final were online and open note. Only about 2-3hrs of homework per week.

You could clearly tell he was very passionate about the subject, and really helped spark my own passion for marine bio. The class was easy, but I still learned a lot. Also, never miss a lab, it will really hurt your grade. I strongly recommend taking the class, its a good way to get your GEs done, and you'll learn a lot.

This professor is AMAZING when I signed up for this class, I didn't care about the ocean, but his lectures are so interesting that I ended up learning a lot. As for the quizzes, midterm, and final, they're open book you just need to pay attention during his lectures.

Grade was based off weekly quiz, homework, midterm +final (all online), participation, and labs. Great class, very funny dude and would certainly take again. He gives 100 bonus points at the end of the quarter if you write 2 pages about an experience you had with the ocean and connect it with what you learned in class. Also very cool lectures

If Friedlaender has a million fans, then I am one of them. If Friedlaender has ten fans, then I am one of them. If Friedlaender has only one fan then that is me. If Friedlaender has no fans, then that means I am no longer on earth. If the world is against Friedlaender, then I am against the world.
Ocean80- Lectures were pretty boring- mostly just him reading off slides. Sections are just labs and are done by TAs, which were done by really amazing TAs Megan and chloe

Professor Friedlaender was great! His TAs did most of the grading and the entire coursework was online including the midterm and the final. Workload was manageable and attending class was mandatory however he never took attendance but would do like little short assignments for in class credit. Easy A if you do the work.

Very good! You occasionally had group work but it was always fun and never harshly graded. Fun field trips and the work was never too difficult. I am not a STEM major, which I think goes to show how good he was at making a STEM class accessible. Sometimes lectures were boring, but he was very self aware about it.
was lit
Amazing professor! I highly recommend this class (I took it for a GE). Awesome field trips too!!!

Seems like a great guy, tests can be a little tricky just because of the way theyre worded but overall as long as you do the homework assignments it would be hard to fail. You also have 2 field trips in a quarter where you can put your knowledge to the real world test :) I enjoy the class and would definitely take one of his courses again.

Prof Lamborg is really nice above all else and his lectures are well put together and fairly interesting, but he's started using an online textbook that was really tedious. Each assignment 1-2hrs, each reading w/notes 2-3 hrs TWICE a week. Aside from this the class is fairly easy and interesting. In person lectures soo much better than online.

Struggled a bit because I had to learn some basic coding on google colab but Carl was very helpful in showing all of us how to use it. Problem sets are due and graded but you are given 2 days to revise and have it regraded :) Very generous with lots of partial credit Would definitely recommend this class as an elective it was great

Classes are not mandatory, except on Mondays since you have to do group work towards the end of class, but it's pretty easy. The class is really interesting and it's a great class for a GE. He also gives a study guide review session before each exam and it helps a lot! A great prof and the TA was amazing as well!

Really great class & Professor - accessible outside of class. Sometimes he gets distracted in his lectures & they run over, but it's just because he has so much knowledge! You get to learn more as a result! The TA was great & gave a couple of amazing lectures. Tests can be tricky, but you learn a lot from them. Make sure to understand the Concepts!

Only Monday's are mandatory for a super simple and easy group participation thing. Lectures are on GoogleDrive. Very easily accessible outside of class via email and responds very quickly. Grading was straight forward, about 15% each of the 4 midterm/final tests. 25% for online txtbook hwk, rest free participation. Quiz can be a difficult/tricky.

Very interesting material and overall great elective for Chem Majors. The problem sets are tedious, but not impossible. The study guide is extremely helpful for all problem sets, midterm and final. If you like problem-solving and learning about natural waters, this is the class.

Took his zoom oceans 1 class for a GE. Such a sweetheart, will help you in any way. Easy class, online textbook assignments were a bit much but they were only for completion. Tests were easy for the most part and there is a final project which was also a day's work. I would definitely take this class again.

Carl was great! He's super passionate and always willing to help. Try to go to his discussion if he has one (better than TAs). This was one of my favorite classes here. HW: simple, "field trip" is an assignment @ Natural Bridges. Tests: M.C+short answer (you do 2/3, moreextra credit) but if you study & go to class/section, you'll be alright!

Lamborg was one of the best professors that I've had so far! The classwork wasn't overwhelming, we only had 2 midterms, 6 homeworks, 1 field trip, and 1 final (which was basically another midterm). His tests and homeworks are very lecture-based, so you should probably show up if you want to do your best on them.

Carl is very passionate about the oceans so he really knows how to lecture on it. Attending class is the best way to learn since his slides have little information on them. Homework is light and not complicated at all. Exams are not difficult as long as you go to his optional section the day before them. A great GE class!

Carl was a great professor! The class is graded on 6 assignments, 1 "field trip" assignment, midterm and final. The tests are generally decent (20-30 multiple choice and 2-3 short answers). Go to the discussion section with Carl if you can, he was a huge help

You're only graded by 7 assignments the whole quarter so try not to miss anything. He posts the slides on canvas but I would suggest going to his lectures because he's such a dad and you want to be there to witness his analogies. The class isn't ridiculously hard but don't think its an easy A.

A good professor. He uses iclicker to record the attendance. The lecture slides that he uses are the very useful tool to study. 3 mid-term, final seems like a fourth mid-term. If you can go to the class every time and remember the terms in the slide, you would get an A.

I took this class because it was a GE I needed to fulfill. Attendance goes into your grade as well as 5 homeworks, 3 midterms, one final, and one field trip homework. I didn't expect this class to be as hard as it was. It seemed like I needed to memorize the whole textbook to get an A. There is a curve at the end which helps and Carl is a nice guy

He took attendance each class using the iclicker of reef app. You can tell he is super passionate about what he teaches and all his lectures are online if you miss anything. His tests are so hard, in my opinion, it was hard to know what to study for people there is just so much information on each slide. You really have to study for a good grade.

For the first half of Oceans, Lamborg taught the class. He's intelligent, his lectures are solid and he clearly loves what he is teaching. His section focuses more on ocean physics, but the class is an Easy A since so much extra credit is given. All the slides are online, good review sessions. I honestly missed him when they switched!

I absolutely loved this class! Raphael is probably my favorite professor at UCSC. His lecturing style is amazing because he always includes a fun little fact or story so it's never boring. You definitely need to study the lecture slides for the exams because the essay questions always got me. But all the exams and quizzes were fair.

Kudela is a gem. Was nervous to take this class but I ended up really enjoying it. He is exceptionally knowledgeable about what he teaches and is honestly just a sweet guy. We had two midterms, a term paper, almost-weekly homework and quizzes, a video project, & final, so not really a light course load. Review his slides, study, and you'll do well!

He was probably the best prof I've had at UCSC so far. His class was interesting and easy to understand. The quizzes and exams were very fair and the final project was really fun to do. Would definitely recommend!!

Very approachable and enthusiastic teacher. Definitely worth taking any class taught by Raph. ....be prepared for donuts and milky ways along w some bad jokes, but all in all he has a good sense of humor and set up a fun class.

If you want to know more about Oceans, this is your man!  He's a little bit more into phytoplankton and random details that you probably won't be super interested in, but he does a decent job going over a LOT of info and making manageable homework.  Work with TAs and do practice tests and this class is "smooth sailing"

Andy is a great professor and better person! I was gonna drop his class at first since I didn't understand a thing but after attending every single lecture, it wasn't so bad. Everything from lecture was on HW and exams so just show up and you'll be good! He has a pretty cool accent too.

I really enjoyed Andy and his lecturing! I was definitely one of the only students super engaged in this class though. You can get away with learning the bare minimum and pass the class with a good grade. Andy is super engaging and passionate about what he is teaching so if you show up, you will learn a lot!

Had two classes with Andy and he is a super solid teacher. His GE class takes a lot of work and time, but understand his study guide and you will pass. He is happy to explain any confusion in office hours and genuinely wants you to pass if you show initiative. For his OCEA111 class there are 5 assignments-1 is term paper (75%), and two tests (25%)

definitely expected this class to be much easier. rmp lied. It wasnt my favorite but the TAs were very helpful and if you needed further explanation theyd gladly help. The work isnt too hard to figure out, its whatever. Id maybe take the class if there was no use of the R program. Make sure to do your best on assignments, they count more.

His class is lecture heavy but it's informative. His homework is worth 75% of the grade so put a lot of effort towards it. There was a few extra credit through this course. Midterm and finals are fair. If you need an SR requirement, I recommend Andy for Ocean 90.

I don't know if it's just the pandemic, but I expected this course to be way easier than it was. Andy is a fine guy, but tends to overexplain concepts and doesn't make the main points super clear in lecture. However, he does post slides, recorded lectures, and even module notes that highlight the necessities. Just wish the class would keep my focus
Nice guy responds to emails quickly

Andrew Moore was an amazing professor. He was helpful and very easy to access via e-mail and office hours. However, the TA I had really sucked, which made me dislike the course. But Professor Moore had nothing to do with that. He made the course material easy to understand and always did his best to help.
Couldn't finish the class due to (on)-campus housing. The class can get competively confusing, however once you get the gist it becomes motivationally easy!

An individual homework assignment is worth more than an individual exam (midterm or final). So if you do really well on the homework there shouldn't be anything to worry about. The exams are pretty easy if you look over the study guides he provides you. Professor Moore is really nice and considerate. Plus his accent made lecture more interesting.

Andy's just a chill guy. His tests are fair, and if you do the homework, they are pretty easy. He posts all his lecture notes/power-points online. He's also very accommodating and flexible if you notify him about anything that comes up. He's clear, easy to understand, and Australian, so his accent alone makes the lecture a little more interesting.

Andy's easy to listen to (and not just because of his great accent). He's a good teacher with a fun sense of humor that makes occasional appearance in lecture. He made a lot of otherwise confusing topics both understandable and interesting. Only downturn was that I sometimes felt he was bored with what he was teaching us.

Lectures were not mandatory, neither is section. Homework is 60% of grade and is graded fairly strictly so work hard on those assignments. The final and midterm were short answer but they were fairly easy. Hmm what else...Andy is hot and Australian.
Amazing teacher really energetic and knows how to keep the pace of the class up even with a half asleep morning class, really funny and over all great guy, wish I could take all my classes with him.

this guy was great. homework assignments are worth a lot but are relatively painless and really easy to do well on. great teacher over all- i actually learned a lot in his class... and he's fun to listen to.

Good teacher, pretty entertaining with lots of humor.  Assignments are worth a lot, and exams weren't too hard.  Just stay on top of the homework and use that to study and you will do fine.  Very friendly too, its good to get to know him a little
He has a cool accent, he is really funny, and make sure he knows who you are. His assignments are worth more than the final and midterm so just do them and you're fine.

He did alright for a course he was taking over for another professor.  Overall it was not that interesting.  I learned a lot of information and the midterm/final are balanced out by HW assign. which are doable.  The TA was really helpful, but I didn't go to Andy's office hours, although he seemed very approachable.

So at the beggining his english accent is quite exciting. However, his class is so dull, there were very few classes that actually held my attention. He seems to talk above you, like he is so smart he can't stupid it down. The good thing is that he offers tons ofextra credit and the Hw is worth a large percentage of your grade so it isn't too hardt

Professor Moore was an awesome teacher. Very funny, knows that material well, and friendly to students. The class was extremely informative and worth it. Powerpoints can be a bit dull at times, but if all else fails his accent will keep you entertained. Great professor!

I really loved this class, despite only getting a B. I think he is one of the best teachers I have had at UCSC. The difficulty of this class lies not within the way the class it taught but within the subject itself. I agree that it was not easy to get an A but that is to be expected with this topic. Attend the class and take notes.
Attend sections and do the assignments decently well and you get a good grade. Never attended lecture and got an A.

Personally I wouldn't take this class again, as there is really no way to guarantee an A because of the vague grading criteria. With that said you can definitely pass the class without doing the readings or attending most of the classes, as he posts all lectures.

This class caused me so much unnecessary stress because of his ambiguous rubric that we had to follow. He graded on 3 short papers and your final paper. It was frustrating knowing what he wanted us to write even after asking him about the assignments. Class wasn't difficult at all but you'll want to pull your hair out trying to understand grading.

Awesome Professor! As long as you go to class/watch lectures online and take notes, you will be completely fine. Discussion posts on reading each week (lots of reading), a midterm, and a final are all that were graded for this class.

You cannot get away with not doing your lectures for this class, and you probably should show up to lectures in order to even understand the course material. Most days I showed up to lectures confused, and leave even more lost. Not his fault, the material is just not easy to understand. Not a terrible class, just do the homework and do the readings

Way better than taking a math course! Although it does get confusing toward the end. I didn't attend lectures and 
still got a good grade but I would recommend going to lecture when he starts covering chapters 6 & 7 just to make your own life easier. Lectures are recorded too.

Attendance is not mandatory, but from personal experience it is way easier if you just go. His lectures are engaging and he encourages open discussion with peers, and asking questions in between the steps of the problems. TAs grade SUPER EASY, like as long as you write something kinda close you'll get credit lol. Loved this "math" class.

Really good teacher and enjoyed going to his class since he would try to get people involved and answered a lot of questions. Class wasn't hard tbh just some tedious work make sure to pay attention extra attention after the second midterm because that's where the class gets somewhat hard the rest is pretty easy and straightforward.

Professor Robertson made my introduction to logic extremely interesting and fun. Attending lectures didn't feel like a chore at all, and he's extremely helpful and patient. Paying attention in this class definitely matters, and although attendance isn't mandatory, I highly recommend going in person, since it helps a lot with understanding concepts.

Prof. Robertson is very kind, and treats his students like adults. In this class, you're responsible for your own success, but he will absolutely help you if you're struggling. I recommend this class for the MF GE for people who don't like math. It's a little tricky, but if you just pay attention and do the homework you're totally fine. Easy grader

Super clear expectations, engaging lectures, lots of little low-stakes homework assignments that help you learn the material.  The homework is also graded on participation, not proficiency.  super easy

He's a great guy, rally cares about his students and making sure people pass. Watch the lecture videos, they're really insightful. He uses lecture time to go over problems rather than teach, if you want someone to guide your hand, may not be the guy for you. TAs grade your homework but all of them were really sweet and nice. Overall 10/10.
he says attendance is not mandatory but when you email him questions he only answers them in-person lecture.

He's really kind but I never found his feedback to be precise. He also often contradict himself when commenting on my work, which left me confused about his expectations. Definitely reach out to him if you are confused about anything!

Awesome professor really cares about his students and their success. Grade based on 3 one-page papers and final project. Grading criteria was highest score on the papers would be the grade for all 3 papers. Really interesting lectures, didn't think I'd be interested in IP law, but this professor made it so interesting!! 10/10 recommend TaKe ClaSs!
Literally the goat. Most interesting class Ive taken and hes a great lecturer. Participating is fun and he always challenges you to take your thinking a step further. Great great Professor.

I took this course in the Winter 2020 quarter. In terms of lectures, the professor did a fantastic job of breaking down introductory moral philosophy in an engaging and fun way. I would recommend this class to anyone and everyone. This is the third course I took with Robertson and once again he was an amazing educator.

I took his IP course in spring of 2021. The topic itself is absolutely fascinating and Robertson is a retired IP lawyer who is qualified and very capable of educating his students on the subject. My onlywould suggestion is to provide more detailed rubrics. Regardless, I loved this class just as much as the other two I have taken with Robertson.

Hes made countless improvements from the negative reviews he got from the last LGST146 quarter. I think thats pretty indicative of Professor Robertson's more general ability to improve and accomodate. He constantly takes feedback from students to improve his teaching and shows genuine understanding and care for his student's success.

The section was harder than the class. She assigns a lot of reading but doesn't actually test on any of it, making it not worth it to read especially when she spends all class summarizing it. Papers aren't anything crazy either.

She is so amazing! I am currently taking another one of her classes this quarter and she is so knowledgable on the topics she teaches and opens up lectures for comments on the readings which is super interesting. She assigns readings that are relevant and not too long which encourages me to actually read them.

Really great prof! Super engaging and passionate, no books recquired. I have taken multiple classes with her, her lower div has easier grading than the upper divs (which I think is reasonable). Gives good feedback and clearly wants everyone to not only do well but enjoy class. Looking forward to taking more classes with her.

Achs herself is really sweet and chill. Lectures are just group discussions of the reading-- so you didn't really need to do the readings to understand what was going on because she goes over it. Weekly tiny quizzes. The TA I had for her was TOUGH and graded papers heavily based on opinion- but I'm not sure that they regularly work for her.

Prof has great lectures and even without mandatory attendance people still showed up because she teaches well. Her assignments are clear and easy if you listen to the lecture. Great intro class and inspired me to take more phil classes.

This is a very interesting class! Professor Achs is a great lecturer who allows for a lot of class participation (in fact, it makes up about half of the lectures). Your grade is pretty much only based on 3 papers graded by the TAs. They are harsh graders but give very valuable feedback to improve your writing over the course.

Only graded on weekly quizzes (3 questions each), the lowest grade is dropped, and 3 papers but the first is just practice and doesn't count towards the final grade. Utilize office hours, that's how I received almost perfect scores on both papers. Lectures are engaging and thorough but I recommend at least skimming texts beforehand.

The professor makes the class very interesting, she engages with the students and doesn't make the class very stifling. However, if you don't do the readings beforehand, although you'll be able to follow the lecture with no problem, the class will become really boring. Papers instead of exams, and chill TAs. Pretty chill class overall.

Rachel Achs is very interested in engaging with students. She modified her lectures to support student discourse (not mandatory for participation grade). The class was easy with weekly quizzes and two papers (one for credit) and a final essay. TAs were useful and teacher was open to new ideas. Would recommend, very easy

Rachel is a great prof that explains things well. Her slides are good and she can go thru them a lil fast but they're posted after lecture. There are readings (some explained over 2 lectures), online weekly quizzes (3 ?s) based on lectures/slides, & 3 papers. Book for the course is ~$14. Paper grading is based on clear rubrics & done by TAs.

It is clear that Professor Achs is passionate about the subject. Lectures were engaging and clear. You are mostly graded through tiny quizzes (open note and online) and two papers. If you are not used to writing philosophical papers, the writing can be hard, but closely following the essay structure/rubric provided helped me write effectively.

I loved Dr. Ach's class so much. She really got me into philosophy. She teaches in a way that makes really complex ideas make a lot of sense and I really appreciate that. There is not much homework, it mainly consists of the readings, some tiny quizzes, and two to three papers.

My friends and I took this class to fulfill GE and major requirements. But we have all run into issues due to this professor and her TA incompetence when grading, handling work, and a number of other things. If you are POC I don't recommend this class due to the views of the readings and the TAs. Would be better if they were more open to critique.

Professor Achs is knowledgeable and passionate about what she teaches. She is a funny teacher and makes a heavy class enjoyable. The grades are split into a few elements, which are quizzes based on lecture material, participation/attendance in section, and 2 papers. The TAs are critical when grading the papers but will help you during office hours.
A great teacher! However if you struggle with math the class can be tough so don't underestimate it.

I have never been so lost and confused in a class not once did I walk in confident that I would catch up and pass an exam. The professor was cool though offered extra credit but you could only really complete it if you understood so... take at your own risk!

Professor Orlandi is incredibly funny and very sweet. However, taking Philosophy 9 alongside other heavy courses made me suffer so incredibly I became more religious than I was prior to taking the class.   Please be aware that the exams contain some questions you will be grossly underprepared for. Do the extra credit, attend the classes.

Really solid professor! Nico cares a lot about what she teaches and her grading is very fair and generous. Quizzes were super straightforward and so were the essay prompts on the midterm and final. Lectures were sometimes helpful, but not always super necessary. I recommend her for PHIL 23 though.

Professor Orlandi was a great logic instructor. She clearly understood the topic and how it could be misunderstood, provided good feedback, and the class was well set up. I'm new to logic but it was introduced slowly and sequentially so it could be understood well. Really easy to get a perfect grade if you stay on top of everything.

great professor who knows their stuff, would get off topic sometimes but very fun. lecture attendance wasn't mandatory but had exit tickets spread throughout that you don't know when they are. reading assignments every week. a midterm and final paper. section helped a lot to understand topics in class. paper grading wasn't communicated that clear.

Took Phil 7 (Intro to Philosphy) with Orlandi and she covers a good amount of content in a very digestible quarter. Engaging lectures, all the essay based tests were graded fairly, and interesting content that you will want to learn about. Orlandi is a great teacher and obviously cares about her students

This class was very tough for me. Nico was great and funny, but the actual content of the class was hard to understand. It made no sense. Your grade is also only dependent on 3 exams. I went to a lot of tutoring to help me. Prof Orlandi is cool though I'd definetley take her again.
does not teach, must rely on tutors especially jaxon, to succeed in the class other wise it is hard to pass

I didn't feel like we were having a serious conversation on the topic. The professor would stop the lecture several times throughout the day to comment on someone's clothes, hair, etc. When talking about the material the professor would look away from the class and read exactly what was on the projector. Overall boring class

This class is so hard, especially because almost your entire grade is based off of 3 exams. They are a really good and funny person though and class was enjoyable even though I don't understand anything :'-(
Nico and the TA's made what could be a dense class something incredibly interesting and enjoyable. Peanut butter isnt a food.

Although the class was structured differently than what I imagined, it was a fairly laid-back class with a lot of knowledge to glean from. There was no homework throughout the course; instead, there were five quizzes, one midterm, and one final paper. With a basic understanding of the readings assigned, students will do very well in the class.

Fantastic course that was held by a clearly very knowledgeable professor, which can often be challenging to tell in video recordings. Will take in person classes in the future if possible. Lectures manage to explain complicated topics very well.

Was a fairly laid back and easy class. Prof was an engaging lecturer and seemed knowledgeable about the topic. Very low workload with only a weekly quiz, a midterm, and a final paper. The content is interesting along with being very easy to understand and requires no prior knowledge about the topic.
Weekly quiz but its relatively easy, gives study questions that are directly used on quizzes and exams. Lectures review readings and their study questions
Her lectures suck and this class was so annoying. She makes the quiz due on Friday but only opens it on Friday, which is really inconvenient.

Worst lectures I have ever been to-- mind-numbingly boring. They just read the slides, try to be funny, and fool around 60% of class time. You only have to do one quiz a week, but if you mess up on any of them, your grade will drop significantly.

Attendance is not mandatory, you don't have to purchase a book. You will have 3 exams, and that's your whole grade (but they are very, very easy as long as you do the optional homework). Homework is not turned in. Nico is hilarious, very accessible, very kind/generous, and an overall great instructor. I can't recommend you take this class enough.

This class was awesome. I genuinely enjoyed learning the material. If you want to do well, you absolutely have to come to class. The homework is a great way to practice on material you may have trouble with. This class was structured beautifully!

He is incredibly knowledge and sweet! You will learn lots from him even if you don't intend or mean to. Unfortunately the grading criteria is very arbitrary and unattainable, and on very few things. And unless you like tangential lectures, you'll probably be lost. Overall, if you're passionate or deeply curious about the course, you'll like it!

Lectures are often long, disorganized, and boring. He's a nice guy and knows his stuff, but it's important you know all this going in. I took multiple classes with him b/c he's the only option for several required philosophy courses. If you're a philosophy major, you'll manage (as you have to), but if not, I strongly suggest choosing another class.

Prof Stone is very passionate about what he teaches. His lectures are very unorganized, which I didn't like. It would help if he created some lecture slides instead of just writing his thoughts on the chalk board. Lectures were often scattered. He gives you the option to join in person or through zoom, which I really liked.

I like the concepts covered, but the lectures overall felt very disorganized. I think it would help if he used lecture slides instead of talking bullet point by bullet point. I like that you could join class through Zoom or in-person. Although the material is difficult to understand, he is an understanding grader.

Professor Stone is such a thoughtful and genuine lecturer. You definitely get the sense that he has a passion for what he does and cares about making sure the material is communicated well. The actual subject matter and readings were confusing at times but he doesn't make you feel dumb and takes everyone's questions seriously.

We had two papers and a final paper. The papers were not graded at all. I personally didn't enjoy the papers, but that's probably just because I personally don't love metaphysics. (A general theme of PHIL100C). I think Abe Stone did great in teaching this class. He's very nice in grading. 3 Questions on every quiz and they are heavily curved.

I really liked this class even though I'm not a philosophy major. Prof Stone is really smart and his lectures were pretty interesting even though the material was boring. The essays are not that hard except for the final essay.

Abe is a smart man. He knows a lot. That being said, these were some of the most boring lectures I've ever endured. He rambles, gets sidetracked, and gets lost so much that you begin to check out. After a while, I stopped attending class and just went to section and was fine. Feel free to mess up the small tests he gives out, they're very curved.

Definitely a Philosophy Professor. Hard to understand but super interesting if you are able to keep up with him. He kind of goes off on seemingly unrelated topics, but they are in a way related. He glosses over all the thing which most people are barely understanding and dives into the the complex specific in any reading. one of my favorit teachers
Good class to take if you are really into philosophy, if you are not and you are only taking it for GE credit, I suggest take an alternative class.

Made Philosophy boring for me despite it being my major.  The multiple choice assignments were poorly planned and the intensive focus on literary comparison between different texts made it feel less like a philosophy class and more like an English class.

If you are a philosophaster who thinks they know all the answers, you won't like Abe's lectures. If you are a serious philosophy student, you will see in Abe the most authentic lecturer of philosophy: Confusing, often unsatisfying, and never afraid to raise the tough questions - much like philosophy itself. He's also a funny and very smart guy.

You will mostly have no idea what he is talking about unless you really love philosophy. Use your TA as much as you can. He is not the greatest lecture in the world, he seems to not enjoy public speaking to much but he loves philosophy.

Definitely the epitome of philosophy. Very smart, but rambling, unfocused, and not a very good public speaker. Has deeper understanding of philosophy and is unable to express it. Read texts, don't worry about lectures, make friends with your TA. Enjoy his cargo pants, crooked yarmulke, and Burger King watch collection.
As far as philosophy teachers go, he's pretty good. Extremely easy class. Only a hobbyist though
Without a doubt one of the best philosophers on campus. Displays the subject matter in all of its complexity, which may be off-putting to some. Great brain, underrated.
Great teacher

Stone is brilliant.  The problem with his lectures are that they are exclusive. He has such an advanced understanding of dense and complicated philosophical works, that the questions he is working through in his lectures make no sense to someone who is reading that text for the first time. he would like you to get it but won't simplify his thoughts
Abe Stone is the personification of philosophy; Brilliant, confused, and often difficult to understand.

Adorable man who wears a yarmulke to class everyday...despite his constant "um's", looks of distress, and nervous laughter, I felt that he explained things very well and creatively. I have to admit, I did tend to get distracted by his nervous ticks, but mostly because they were really cute.

This guy loves to lecture, so strap in. TA graded the papers for my class, but they're easy to do if you read the readings. Does take attendance and has a limit on how many classes you can skip. It actually affects your grade in the class.

DONT TAKE THIS CLASS! I read through the reviews myself and thought, How hard can it really be? Answer: The hardest thing you will ever do. His lectures make no sense and the whole class is literally premised on being academically inaccessible. I do well in school but could not do this class. DO NOT TAKE IT! Genuinely one of my biggest regrets.

Bowin's Logic class is extremely difficult, especially online. If you are not typically a math or science person I would not recommend this class, it is much more math oriented and I did not expect what this class was at all. If you know what youre getting into it might be okay but if you dont you will be on the struggle bus.

Do not take this unless you have to. I'm a LGST major and thought it would be best to take this to knock a GE + major class, but no, just take STATS 5. Get ready to use Chegg. If you do take it, he curves the midterm and extra credit really helps - do it in a group. Uses ProctorU. TA are kind of useless. He has book in PDF form. lots of reading.

If you're taking this class for a pre-req DO NOT. If you're taking it because you have to take it with a different prof, arbitrarily hard, online textbook had mistakes in it, online modules had hella mistakes with no corrections.

Hands down worst class I've taken at UCSC, Bowin's videos are unhelpful and the problem sets were ridiculous. The TA's were great and tried to help when they could but several of them said that the problems assigned where not for a beginning class. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS FOR MF CREDIT.

This was the hardest class I have ever taken and not in a good way. Was not rewarding and felt like I learned nothing. If you are taking it to knock off a GE, DONT. It is not worth all of the stress and pain, take a different class. When I asked professors and TAs for help they told me to figure it out and did not help me. Homework is VERY hard. :(

Ancient Greek Philosophy can be challenging but it is the groundwork for all later philosophy. I can think of no one more well informed to teach this subject matter than Professor Bowin. His lectures are well prepared, so be diligent in your note taking and complete all of the readings. I benefitted greatly from this course. Thank you Professor!

never EVER take Intro to Logic if youre not a philosophy major (or even if you are, honestly). Im a fourth year and this was by far the worst and hardest class Ive ever taken. The professor is boring and goes through things too fast. Attendance is MANDATORY (he scans ID cards.) Boring, hard, and pointless material.
John Bowin is super nice. The people that rated him badly are the ones who don't pay attention during class and don't skim the textbook. He's a great teacher and I'm happy to have had him.

100% DO NOT recommend taking this class for a GE-my mistake. This class is the definition of illogical. Teacher is very smart but horrible at teaching. MSI was very helpful and probably the only reason i passed this class. This class was a constant headache.

I'm not sure why this Prof. has such bad reviews. This class is pretty hard and he does go through the material a little fast which can make it confusing or hard to understand, but he is more than willing to answer any questions after class or during office hours. Also the sections are more for giving a clearer understanding as well as the MSIs.
Intro to Logic was just awful. Bowin is a brilliant man but a terrible teacher. Lectures were pretty pointless and can be equated to watching someone do their homework over a projector.

I found Professor Bowin to be an excellent instructor. He encourages participation and offers extra credit for it! As long as you make an effort to stay somewhat engagedask questions when you're confused this class will be a breeze. He does get a little wrapped up in the history sometimes, but is always willing to answer student questions
One of the rudest and disrespectful people I have ever met in my entire life, he does not deserve to be on this campus.

Presents himself as helpful and open to questions but politely scoffs at any attempts made to clarify his material. Only thinks in the language of the class, making his feedback convoluted. If you're taking this course graded, godspeed. Otherwise make sure you do well on the homework, come to lectures, and try to do the extra cred to pass. Or flee!

Lectures are mandatory but i never got much out of them. Sections were incredibly helpful, and going to MSI helped some too. This class takes a lot of time and effort but i found it rewarding. But it was really no cakewalk. Start yr own study group to get ahead.

You can see he knows what he is talking about but if you are not a philosophy major (or similar field) then you will be completely lost. If you are taking this instead of a math course to complete your MF requirement, do not take this class. Especially for those who have problems with math or learning disabilities, this  course is challenging.

This guy is the worst. He lectures on and on about random philosophical theories and philosophers and makes it very unclear. Good thing his class doesn't require you to take notes because if you do the readings (skim main ideas for most part) and go to section and sign in for lecture you will do at least a B. I did not enjoy his class

He really cares about the subject matter and wants his students to also. Yes attendance is mandatory and sometimes lecture can be a little dry but Bowin is passionate about teaching and if you're ACTUALLY interested in Philosophy you'll be rewarded and find him extremely helpful. Read everything. Write concisely and throughly. Engage lecture/sect

He rambles and rambles so an explanation of something that should take 10 minutes takes 40 minutes. Maybe that's ok in a timed lecture, but with an asynchronous class where he can post as much as he wants, we end up with hours of him talking and talking and talking
I had an asynchronous class with him, but his lectures were very engaging. Phil 8 is an easy A as long as you go to discussion groups (which I failed to do)

Great prof. His lectures were easy to understand and he explains well. Walks you through each topic thorogughly. Reading wasn't too bad. Homework assignments and quizzes arent hard. WATCH LECTURES. lectures r vital to the course.

He forgot to post assigned readings and a lot of the slides were not proofread (repeating/blank). The tests were hard to follow due to broad questions that could be answered w/ diff. readings. 2 Quizzes & final were ungraded 3 days past the grade deadline (cant contest), and our grades were submitted late. My first C at UCSC (graduating next qtr)

The class is generally pretty clear, but just be careful for the TAs. Some of them arent really reliable and their grading criteria makes no sense. Also, if you dont do the readings YOU WILL BE CONFUSED. There are no papers in the class, just a ton of quizzes and assignments but aside from that Ellis is fine.
Jon is fantastic! Check out CPP

Prof. Ellis is honestly a really great and understanding guy. As a philosophy major, I can say he is one of the most engaging Phil professors on campus, and he is extremely patient and flexible with his students. You can tell he is passionate about teaching. Nothing but good things to say about him!

Jon Ellis is a great professor. His lectures are engaging and he very much cares about student's learning. There is a good amount of reading, but nothing crazy. His lectures are filled with dad jokes, so take that as you will. I would love to take one of his classes again.
Ellis is an incredible professor. Gives detailed and great feedback. Fair on the grading and is understanding. Highly recommended.

Honestly, I didn't really like him as a professor. He often would get caught up in his own examples and get confused and subsequently confuse the students. His silence and staring at the class also was pretty awkward at times. Interrupts you when you're asking questions. He is pretty funny sometimes but I did not enjoy this class.

Topics are interesting, but the lectures are quite confusing as Ellis. If you don't attend class, none of the slides will make sense. Not a difficult class but nothing spectacular. There is some probability covered in this class which shouldn't be hard, but it was explained with so much jargon that  the majority of students got confused.

Jon is an effective teacher. He is intimidating at first, but after a few classes you will see he is a easy-going guy with an austere appearance. Read the material and attend lecture and discussion and you will be fine. Very interesting course!

Professor Ellis is by far one of the best philosophy professors at UCSC. His seminar was a brilliant example of how a small discussion can be "meaningful" to graduating philosophy students. He knows his material but focuses more on the students. Great guy.

Ellis is the best philosophy teacher I have had by FAR. He is way more organized than any other philosophy teacher. He is amazingly clear and makes the material very interesting. I actually learn a lot and understand what he is saying, unlike others.
Great professor, clearified everything to a T, sparked my interest in philosophy.
probably one of the best professors at ucsc. his lectures are very clear. the class is awesome if you are into philosophy. just try not to fall asleep in class. definitely take this class

Ellis is the BEST PROFESSOR!  He is such a wonderful man.  I had a few questions before the test and he not only volunteered to talk to me on the phone but invited me to his house! Such a lovely teacher. A very good overview of philosophy. Really gives you something to think about.

He's a good man and great teacher. Explains things very well and and helps as best he can. His examples are clear. Not too much work. There are 3 shorts assignments and 2 papers. A lot of reading but it's manageable. The most interesting class I've taken so far and it's pretty fun. He's also quite the looker! The TA's are awesome.

Ellis is a great teacher. The class is hard though. I got a D on the first test AND I studied. The papers are a good way to get points.  He has some cute jokes and he is a very charming man. On the downside, his voice is so soothing, that it put me to sleep every single class.

This class was very interesting, and it helped that the professor was easy to look at. I found some of the readings to be difficult to understand, but the professor helps make them understandable to the average person. Not too much work assigned. Fairly easy tests. I would suggest taking this class if you think you are interested in philosophy.
Best professor ever, would totally recommend taking this course for a GE. Overall wasn't too hard and lectures aren't mandatory.

Stopped going to lecture at some point, but the professor seems sweet. class is very discussion-based, so if you don't like talking to people, just skip lecture. There is in-class, closed-note response paper, that gave me so much ANXIETY cuz u will write an essay to a prompt under 5min. But thanks to my TA being generous with grading I did fine.

Even though it was a large class, she made it feel small and gave really great examples. Lots of readings but you can get away with not doing them since she explains them so well in class. Two response papers plus a final project of your choice but not really challenging and she gives you free range on pretty much everything. Very approachable.
Good class with long lectures! Some of it is a little dense to comprehend but slides are useful. My TA was a tough grader so beware what sections you pick!
Professor Dinishak is super friendly and learned/remembered the names of the majority of the class which probably consisted of 100-150 students. Very discussion heavy in class.

Clearly cares deeply about philosophy and passionate to teach. She has incredible stage presence and conveys complex material easily. Lecture are engaging so we could be involved, and she's always around for office hours. Plenty of opportunities to raise grade, none of the assignments are too hard, and readings are very manageable. Good ge to take.
Very nice, a bit of a tricky grader with only a few assignments. Class always had engaging discussions. Only one book required and prof gave 10 out for free! Will be taking this prof again.

Prof Dinishak was an engaging lecturer, but I feel as though she went a little overboard with the in-class discussions. I would've liked to have had more insight into the required readings during lectures to understand their meanings more deeply. Quizzes were really simple if you read and the 3 papers required in the class aren't too long.
great professor, lectures sometimes get a little boring, lots of reading but it's not super required

I swear 75% of the material was just on native americans. No idea why, just name the class native american philosophy instead of ethical philosophy. Also, its gonna depend on your TA if this class goes well for you but unfortunately, my TA was mid. Still took the win though.

I had Professor Dinishak for Ethical Theory and I think that she did an amazing job of covering complex topics in a comprehensible manner. I am currently a first year and this class was mainly filled with 3rd and 4th years, however I did not feel out of the loop at all. Her grading was fair and she was all around a great professor.

Professor Dinishak is incredibly kind and knowledgeable. Her lectures were interesting and she really guides you through the dense material. Her lectures relied heavily on voluntary participation. Lectures weren't mandatory but section was. Overall I definitely recommend Professor Dinishak, especially for Philosophy 22.

Great instructor. Solid class to take for a GE, easy A if you try at all. You can get by without doing a lot of readings. Topics in lecture are often interesting. Had no problem receiving an extension on an assignment. She's kind, knowledgable, and engages class in voluntary discussions. She really listens to her students which feels encouraging.

She's actually really funny at times and speaks clearly during her lectures. She's very kind and encourages participation from everyone but it isn't mandatory to participate during her lectures. She sounds very passionate about what she talks about and made me feel like I actually belonged in that class. I felt extremely engaged as well.

She is an amazing professor and everyone else I've talked to in the class agrees, it is a little stressful that our whole grade is only 9 assignments but I would totally recommend this class to anyone whos interested. The readings are dense but superrrrrrr interesting if you try to understand them.
Awesome class for learning about philosophy, especially if you're a non-major. Much of the grade consisted of writing essays, and they were graded pretty hard.

I think Dinishak herself is a great teacher; her lectures are really useful for navigating these difficult readings, and she clearly has passion for philosophy. However, personally, PHIL 11 is organized in such an awful way for people with anxiety. 80% of the grade is made up of 3 papers, and we only received feedback on 1 by week 9.

One of the best courses I have taken at UCSC. Prof Dinishak is absolutely amazing. The courses are organized, structured, and the content is so so so interesting. Prof Dinishak makes everyone feel extremely comfortable and validated, which led to some amazing class discussions. She gives amazing feedback. I feel that I really grew as a student.

A real gem for UCSC. Take it if you have a true passion for learning philosophy, but not like old white person philosophy. She knows her stuff, and will welcome you into the seminar-like discussion with open arms.
Hardest grading out of any philosophy class I've taken so far. I personally find the lectures extremely interesting and engaging. She encourages all students to talk and give their opinions in class.

She genuinely cares about teaching, and if you're actively engaged with the material, the class is very manageable. As long as you participate and keep up with the work, it's easy to earn the grade you're aiming for. Her critiques of the canon through a feminist lens are refreshing.

Dion obviously loves teaching and what she teaches. She is very passionate about hearing her students voices, so expect to talk during class: she lectures but wants to hear plenty of dialogue. Assigned readings can be long and dense, but the two papers are graded very generously if you focus on your own opinion/analysis.

Dion is truly my favorite professor here at this school because of her enormous heart and passion for teaching. Her entire teaching style is not lecture-heavy and does depend on students to lead the class, but you'll be ok as long as you talk in groups. 
Her grading is VERY generous, so as long as you read and know the material, you'll be fine.
Dion is my favorite professor I have ever had at UCSC. Could not recommend more.

this class is nothing like its course description and the profs teaching style is not for me. class is set up with prof lecturing for 5 minutes then we break off into small groups and talk about questions. often times the convos get off topic anyway. all in all, kind prof but class is so dull, don't waste your time. also prof interrupts u hella

Found her teaching style very pointless. The big and small groups always end up going completely off-topic, and her method of marking down everybody's participation results in many students saying things just for the sake of it. I found that the readings and discussion were completely unrelated or confusing.

Dion is very insightful and a kind person, but her style of teaching wasn't for me. There's a lot of in person discussions, both small groups and whole class discussions. You have a lot of time to get the essays done, but the reading can be a little challenging. Attendance is mandatory and worth 20% of your grade too.

Extremely kind and a great as a person. Truly cares for her students and the subjects she's teaching. Graded us on 3 essays and was quite fair; there's a lot of reading but that's expected and participation is vital for a good grade. The only negative aspect: I don't think anyone got a perfect score on any of the writing assignments (strange).

i loved this class for the TA GE. only 3 papers+1 brief (couple min) class presentation where u share ur thoughts on reading, no slides/research/planning needed. participation+attendance mandatory but rly easy. u spend each class j talking ab sci-fi books that she provides+discuss things like ur thoughts on robots, technology, sexuality/gender, etc

I liked her class. Participation and attendance is mandatory, but overall a chill summer class - only 2 1000 word essays and 1 informal presentation required. We ended up just debating topics about technology and art in groups, which was interesting. Readings aren't super sci-fi focused, more dystopian

I really enjoyed this class and the whole teaching team was amazing! My only con is that wouldn't provide accessibility to students like letting them keep cameras off+ providing lecture notes because of participation reasons. I understand that but there's gotta be another way around it. But ig it doesn't matter since we are coming out of COVID...

Dion is really an awesome professor! We had our lecture online and our discussions in person. She is caring and very eager to hear your thoughts on the texts you read. You can survive her class by not buying the required books but make sure to have the correct online pdf. P.S she knows when you use Sparknotes, she's not dumb. Overall 9.5/10

Enjoyed her class, even though it was a requirement. You'll be expected to read 2-3 different articles/media before each class and then talk about it. Participation in the form of talking is graded. Only had one pop quiz bc people would never talk/read the assigned stuff. Group project was fun, and no final, just a final paper. Overall, good prof

Dion was such a good professor! She was engaging in discussions with the students, had fun with the topics, and made online learning amazing! There are a total of four papers overall and she grades them fairly! I seriously loved how freeing the prompts were which gave you space to write about something that interested you from the readings!
Professor is really nice, would highly recommend
Dion is so amazing! she is a tough grader and requires attendance but she truly cares about her students. She really helped us stay connected during covid times. I would totally take her class again.

I loved Dion! You can tell how passionate she is about the works we talked about, and that made me more excited to read. Make sure to participate for a good grade. She talks a lot, and is left leaning politically and makes that known. Dion always gave me great feedback, but there are some people in my class that did not get the same treatment.

Dion is super nice and she truly makes you enjoy books. The class is pretty easy, read and do your papers on time and you'll be fine. She's understanding of situations so she did extended due dates at times.
Dion is amazing. I want every one of my classes to be taught by them. They are so respectful and caring and intelligent and I learned so much and enjoyed it
Dion was very good in encouraging students to share opinions in class. You can really tell she really likes to see students interacting and talking to each other. Section was required to attend.

He gives difficult and often lengthy homework, but the homeworks more than prepare for his tests, which are very fair. He does do graded iclicker, even at 8am, but if you earn more than 80% on the questions, you earn extra credit. He gives extensions on assignments if you ask, and offers extra credit after exams. He is funny and nice to students.

Lederman is not a nice person. He is rude and curt to students, and has different standards for himself and his students. Demanding students to be on time and mean when handing out extensions when he himself is often late releasing homework and test study material. I do not believe Lederman cares if students succeed or not. His class is at 8am.

Lederman was an okay teacher. I did not personally learn the way that he taught the material. Has a very generous grading scale. Homework three times a week, never super relevant to what we were learning. Tests were not too difficult. Attendance is semi-mandatory.

Graded homework every lecture, homework does not match the lectures, must pay for the homework and an iClicker subscription. You must go to every lecture because the iClicker points make up a lot of the final grade. The tests are very easy (compared to the homework) and they are very accurate to the study guides. Use chegg and get an A

He is the best physics professor I have ever had! He is so good at teaching and making sure all the content is digestible, especially for the exams. All the iClicker questions were helpful, and even when he asks if people had questions and no one says anything, he explains everything so carefully. Lederman is super sincere and awesome.

Literally my favorite professor I have had so far for upper division physics. Great lectures, relevant hw, fair exams, super friendly and approachable. Lectures had lots of examples that were very relevant to the rest of the course. All bad reviews that I see are from 6A where the students most likely didn't like physics and wanted an easy A. 12/10

Lectures and homeworks related exactly to the exams, there were never any surprises. The iClicker questions for participation were helpful in solidifying concepts. He was also really approachable and helpful in office hours, and held 2 hour review sessions on weekends before exams (above and beyond!).

He had graded (for accuracy) homework that you couldn't do ahead of time. The homework wasn't similar to the tests at all, and the final was incredibly difficult. He also never shows examples with numbers and has graded participation. It doesn't help that he can be intimidating to talk to. If you want to enjoy physics don't take this class.

Hw 3x weekly (associated with each lecture), in-person iClicker for participation, accuracy matters. Hw and disc. sections were unhelpful for tests, practice tests are better for studying. felt like the assigned hw was for a different class half the time, almost to the point where I wonder if he ever read the hw problems he was assigning.

Pretty tough guy but this course is just hard in general. Homework has nothing to do with lectures or midterms and was near impossible I thought practice exams were very close to real exams. But dude doesn't round up no matter what it sucks. I enjoyed the lectures but I would recommend taking this class elsewhere.

The material for the difficult homework and exams were not given in entirety via lectures. I felt like I was being dismissed whenever I spoke with Lederman and that my concerns or questions were not worth their time.

8 am lectures with iClicker participation were kinda annoying. Ended up going to half of them in total. Homework 3x/week also meh but it helps to do all of them if you want to be prepared for the exams. Practice exams were also pretty good. Spend time trying to understand the concepts instead of memorizing equations. Good luck.

Homework 3x/week, not related to lecture. Lectures are slides full of equations with no real explanation. You must go to class and do iclicker which gets graded based off of how well you understood the material he just covered two minutes prior. Will ignore your emails if he doesn't want to deal with it. Always in a rush, very impersonal.
Really really great teacher for me, concepts are of course very challenging but he's super helpful.

Professor Lederman was not great. In Final Exam review he was asked to show an example problem. He responded "I guarantee you I know how to solve this problem" and said to struggle until we understood it. Class sucks for visual learners who benefit from seeing the steps of a problem. Lectures not helpful. Lots of homework that I never understood.
Honestly, try your best to find a different professor if you can unless you REALLY enjoy physics. If you have no experience with the subject you will literally be drowning. avoid at all costs.
