Avoid. Through two exams, the average score is failing. The exams are not like the homework and the homework is not like the lectures. His lectures seem like they are meant more as a seminar for people who already understand the concepts, not for people who are seeing this material for the first time. He seems uninterested in helping confusion.

He seems like a really nice guy but he is a horrible teacher. I left class always confused because he basically reads off some slides. There is a lot of homework, but I believe that it is not TOO bad. Also, he does not care that his exam average is low. He would not curve it even though many students failed.

If you can avoid taking a class with Lederman, do it! Lectures given do not match the homework, and the homework doesn't match the exams. He doesn't seem to care that his exam averages are failing grades.

hes a confusing lecturer, I would recommend going straight to txtbook and slides. He also assigns long homework sets every 2 days, hard for students that have jobs most days of the week. Most students seem to feel ill-prepped for his exams. Doesn't seem to support the strikes either as hes encouraging students to still attend lecture. poor TAs.

Sriram's teaching lacks structure, focuses on proving equations over explaining concepts. Ineffective in answering questions, assigns ExpertTA homework that doesn't correlate to tests. Inconsistent grading, alters scores with a confusing curve. Grading scale was indeterminate. Kenny's demos were most helpful, offering practical understanding.
I took Physics 5C. He goes on many tangents during the lecture, which may not relate to the materials. Definitely read the textbook or watch YouTube videos, it will help more than the lecture.
The lectures are horrible. He goes on constant tangents about topics that do not relate to the material. Exams are extremely hard.

The professor during lectures does not teach very well and when a question is asked he asks back a question instead of answering the question. Most of the material covered in the lectures are only vaguely connected to the homework he assigns I RECCOMEND NOT going to lectures and just reading the textbook on your own because that is way more helpful
Classwork itself was fairly simple. Shastry is not great at answering student questions during lectures however.

Lectures were mindless ramblings with seemingly no connection within the given lecture material. Averages pre-curve on the midterms were 40 and 55. Opening the textbook often provided greater insight into the material. Made basic mechanics needlessly difficult.

I'm an astrophysics major and this was honestly the hardest and worst class I've ever taken in college. Prof doesn't know how to teach and its better to learn by literally reading the textbook. His homework and final exam were ridiculously difficult. He assigned one of the hardest homework over thanksgiving which ruined the 2 days we had off. Avoid

Shastry is a very lovely person, just a horrible professor. Your grade will improve drastically if you DON'T got to class. He is helpful in office hours, but he straight up couldn't cover all the necessary material in the class, and what he did cover he communicated very poorly. Tests are ok if you study for them from the book.

Shastry was my first physics teacher in College and it was much  different from high-school. He is EXTREMELY smart, but he's not so good at explaining concepts. The midterm was exactly like his review midterm, but the final was very tough. Insane curve, I pulled an A- as a freshman, so if you are upperclass men, then Shastry will be fine.
Great Professor, extremely helpful. Inspiring class

It's a very hard class, and this teacher... should really not be allowed to teach this level of physics. He forced his students to do math that they were not even supposed to be enrolled in. For example, he wanted to use a question on the final exam that involved multi-variable calculus, which is two/three quarters ahead. What saved us was the TAs.

Like the previous reviewer, Shastry is the not the kind of professor who should teach large lecture classes. He tries his best by providing practice exams and fair grading policies but he is slow and more suited to teaching upper division classes.
horrible, just horrible at teaching. he is a very intelligent man, but he fails to understand that physics 5a is not quantum mechanics

HORRIBLE! The worst teacher I've ever had! all over the place, you can't understand him he has no rhyme or reason to his lectures and overall progression of the class. Homeworks are tricky, you have to learn everything on your own, lectures are pointless he is absolutly no help and if you ask a question he just nods and says yes.

Lectures seemed loosely planned, lots of careless mistakes when going over examples, most examples are not helpful, poor communication of key physics concepts, required reading for the course doesn't cover lecture material, homework assignments require students to google trivial pieces that should be given in the problems, but he's a nice guy...

I personally loved his lectures as he's great at giving you intuitive understanding. If you don't do your reading before class and have some basic understanding of topics it can be hard to follow along. Homeworks are difficult but some of the best exam prep I've had for a class, as the exams are FAR easier than any assigned problems.

Very hard professor, but teaches math subjects in great detail that can later be applied to physics. Homework was difficult but was great preparation for exams, which were relatively easier. I reccomend attending office hours and asking questions as soon as they come up.

Really hard professor. On both midterms, he tried to give me 0 points for questions I made small mistakes on. One was a misuse of e to get rid of ln. He explains everything verbally and quickly, which helped no one in the class. You need to teach yourself everything from the book and understand every step of his homework solutions.

Very knowledgable about what he teaches, but very often skips over steps that are not obvious. One thing I noticed in office hours was that he verbally explains solutions instead of writing them out, which was hard to learn from. Would always take time to answer all questions, even if they seemed obvious. Very difficult but I feel I learned a lot.

He's a very talented person, greast reasearch but poor teaching quality. He spent too much time on basic calculus and rushed during the last two weeks by making content inorganized and unnecessary difficult. No practice tests or reviews. Homework can be confusing, especially the last two. If you have other choice, just don't take his course.

This is for PHYS 116A since there was no option for it, but he was the hardest professor I've had, his lectures were him spouting concepts and math problems and he was quite rude when I had emailed him about the grading criteria as it was never made clear. Class only had 9 HW weighed 20% and exams were 80% of total so it was a very hard class.
An absolutely incredible Professor, his were some of the most beautiful Physics lectures I have ever learnt from. Very receptive to questions and willing to help with homework!
He's smart and supportive, but difficult. His grading is fair. Lectures are really really good for depth of understanding.
Good professor in his teaching, extremely poor final exam for being worth 40% of the grade. For most students, quite difficult, for all students final was unreasonable.
Dont take his class.

Lectures and professor are very difficult to understand. I did not go to lecture at all and only studied with the book. I had a B in the class before the final, but the final was insanely difficult. I studied for three days and I also went to the review sessions and still got bodied. Worst class to have this prof in my last quarter.

I took this course last Winter. Looking back, Onuttom was the worst professor I've ever had. He was extremely rude in office hours, was extremely disorganized and rambling in lecture, and his tests were very hard. He does this thing where he just shouts math and concepts without writing any of it down. The book will be your teacher in his class.

this class was not that hard for me since I already knew physics, but I can understand why others would struggle. he gets mad if you ask about the curve for the test, and his only advice is "draw a free body diagram".

Took Computational Phys(S15) and now have taken almost all of the Physics series. I see it as one of the most challenging and practical courses in the major. Onuttom was extremely clear but concise in lectures(info-dense) and I found him to be great at answering most questions. He is tough and I put in A LOT of work(20h/week) but it was rewarding!
He is a great teacher, buy you need to put in the effort as well. He is beyond smart and knows physics better than other professors.

Lectures are tough, but interesting. Onuttom is a tough teacher, but he really really cares for his students. (Especially physics students) He wants to everyone to do well, so go to his office hours and really learn. He is shockingly precise, making very few mistakes, excluding grammatical. Concepts for this class were really tough for me.

Onuttom is one of a kind. He is very precise and hardly makes mistakes. Extremely intelligent, which makes it hard for him to simplify the concepts to the class. He is a tough grader and his tests are quite tough. He is quite open to his students but may be intimidating. Physics and math majors will love him, Engineers may not like his style.
Will expect something more than just average. He is pretty tough in terms of tests, but if you have a good handle by now then you will be fine.
Professor Narayan is an extremely intelligent man but he SHOULD NOT be teaching undergraduates! He sources other texts without telling his students.

I heard plenty of dreadful things about Onuttom before taking the class, but I liked him. He is an excellent lecturer and is very willing to help on conceptual problems, but less so on the homework. He gave hard homework, fair midterms and a difficult final. He expects work from his students, but is also very considerate.

Professor Hance is an amazing Physics professor. I have had him for four classes, and Phys 129 was the last one I will ever have with him. He cares a lot and is good at explaining topics. He is definitely better when he teaches an elective as he can be more liberal with how he teaches. Overall one of my favorite professors I have ever had.
Was a great lecturer and was very patient with questions on matieral.

Really nice guy, has a great sense of humor and clearly wants you to do well. Puts effort into helping during office hours. Lectures are the usual, tests are medium difficulty, and his class is curved, so even though subject matter is tough, doing well in the class is not

I took his classes for two times, 5B and 105, and I can say the only good thing of his class is the curve. His classes are just writing down whatever in the book. Tests are really hard. Homework questions are always long text and boring. If you really want to learn Physics with your interest, don't take his class just for curve

Good professor. Lectures are basically just derivations of equations, which you don't really need but is nice to know if you're a physics major. Some lectures are extremely dense and hard to follow. Super hard homework. Super hard tests, but Mike is a homie and curves really nicely. Do the practice tests and read the textbook!

Honestly one of the most genuinely enjoyable teachers I've had so far. He has a real passion to teach, as well as actively making sure everyone understands the topics. He spends a lot more time on the topics of physics which makes the class hard, but for my quarter he heavily curved. Overall, was an absolute treat to have.
So for me, avoid this class unless youre trying to get analogies that you dont understand thrown at you for an hour and a half.
so for me, he doesn't quite impose his style of teaching very well and tries to tackle too much adversity at once

Super awesome professor! But I'm not a physics major. His class got extremely difficult after a few weeks. I couldn't keep up and dropped. But he was great. His office hours were so fun and open. Great guy! Just hard if you're not already aware of basic physics

Such an amazing professor. I thought I hated physics before I took his class, and now I'm considering minoring in it. He does a great job of explaining concepts, making it engaging, developing learning, but not overworking you. There's a quick, easy quiz per week and a problem set. Super easy. Honestly, only class I looked forward to attending.
Lectures aren't too fast and it is easy to stay on top of things. He also does fun demonstrations sometimes.
Big chiller
Big chiller.

Prof. Ritz is awesome and caring. He does everything to alleviate your stress while also being fair, I felt there were no surprises on his exams, quizzes, or homework. This class is an easy A if you go to lectures and ask questions during office hours or section.

Prof. Ritz was super clear about how he grades and what you need to do to succeed. Also encourages classmate connections that helped me a lot. Quiz and hw due every week, and a midterm and final group project.

The best professor I've ever had. He's so caring and reached out to me to check if I needed help with anything because of a bad homework score. Very accessible for office hours, and liked to help and teach students understand physics. My grade was definitely on me since I didn't spend as much time as I should've in the class. Such a great professor

THIS IS THE BEST PROFESSOR I'VE HAD SO FAR AT UCSC. He is very caring and tries to be as accommodating as possible to people's situations. His lectures were very engaging and he teaches content very well. All exams come with an equation sheet which was very helpful for people like me who sucks at memorization. He deserves higher than a 5.3 on RMP.

An amazing professor, truly. He is probably the best teacher I have  had ever. He truly does care about his students and goes beyond to make sure you can understands physics. I have never took a physics course beofre, and now love learning about physics because of his class. I highly reccomend this class, he is amazing. literally worked at Nasa.

Gave really good lectures, and makes a lot of time for students if they seek to see him. He's a really good guy, who not only cares about physics, but actually teaching the material as well. I didn't do as great as I wanted to in this class, but that's completely on me. I don't know how he has a 5.3 on RMP, but it's well deserved.

Excellent teacher. Very straightforward lectures that tell you exactly what you need to know on the homework, quizzes, and exams. Homework was done on ExpertTA. Required discussions session have questions that show up again on midterms. You can ask him questions anytime on Slack or during office hrs. Do everything diligently and you will earn an A.

He was amazing and did everything so that every student understood the lectures. I asked for a code for experTa (the website used for homework) so that I didn't have to pay for it, and he gave me free access to it. If you need help go to office hours and he will do everything he can to help you understand. Very nice guy.

HW every week, couple of quizzes, 2 midterms, a final. Very easy to understand and a very nice professor. Discussions mandatory and worksheets were beneficial to understand exams. Exams were more testing on knowing how to do a problem rather than getting a number value answer. Lots of partial credit and class was curved. Def would take him again!

Professor Ritz was an amazing instructor in many ways. He is very understanding of the needs of his students, always answers questions thoroughly, and has frequent office hours for those who need more support. Overall, I would highly recommend choosing Ritz if you have the choice for any physics class.

11 hw problem sets total. Expert Ta deducts a certain percentage from questions u get wrong. Discussion worksheets r harder compared to hw and exams.Exams test how well u can set up equations vs solving for a numerical answer. Organic chemistry tutor n physics ninja carried me, lectures were broad n weren't much help for hw

He gives you so many resources that its impossible to not get a good grade if you put in the effort. Attend the Lectures, do the discussion section sheets and homework, go to office hours when you're confused and the A is very attainable.
Lectures were very clearly communicated and generally easy to understand. He was responsive to student feedback and was very accommodating. Very clear syllabus.

Teaches physics through deriving and explaining concepts. Lectures are optional but highly recommended. His office hours are really good, he will help you with anything. Some parts of the class could get tough but he will always support you if you ask for it. He has a cute dog too

Steven Ritz might be the professor I respect the most so far at my time at UCSC. His lectures are really engaging and makes sure that you understand the concepts he's discussing. He is always available outside of class (even on a sunday night before a homework assignment is due). His tests did throw me a bit of a curve ball but honestly a 5/5 prof.
Buddy really got a phd and everything jus to be a mid physics teacher and run his class like its the most important class (i.e kicking you off the curve if you miss a lecture).

Great professor. Classes were engaging, and exams were mainly lecture problems. He always emphasizes that you need to rework lecture problems, listen to him. If you can do lecture problems without needing much help, you're gonna do great. Make sure to ACTUALLY read the syllabus to see how you can qualify for the curve.

Dhar is the best professor/lecturer I have ever had. He is engaging and makes a otherwise possibly boring subject very interesting. As long as you study what he tells you and go to class you will do well. The class is difficult but it is a physics course so that should be expected. He does expect a lot from his students, but he is an amazing prof.

Did terrible in his 5A but good in 5C because I ignored all the homework problems and just ran the lecture problems only over and over. His online make up lectures suck and won't stick, but genuinely just rework the lecture problems and you'll be fine. His in person lectures are pretty good though, genuinely enjoyed them and it was a decent class

His problem sets are a waste of time because they don't appear on the exams, and there aren't many resources beyond his lectures, which are posted online days after they occur. If you miss more than 5 lectures, the highest grade you can get is a C.

Lots of people give bad ratings based on the difficulty of the class, which is unfair. The work you put in is the grade that comes out, Dhar's has a clear and strict structure that if followed will lead to success in the class which he speaks about alot. Lectures are clear and sometimes funny, homework heavy, would recommend.

Dhar is a professor many dream to have. Physics is my weakest subjects, but the support he provided made me so much more confident in myself and my abilities. He provides you with all the resources you need, and he is very kind with his grading. His lecture problems and office hours are grade-saving. Hope I have him again soon. :) Love ya, Barun!
became religious and prayed that someone would run me over on the way to class every MWF

VERY polarizing teacher. If he doesn't work for you, then theres nothing you can do. His teaching methods are conducive to learning, but they require a lot of CONSTANT time and effort. He assigns lectures to "make up" for breaks. His tests do not give reasonable time, they are speed tests. I will be avoiding this guy for the rest of my UCSC career.

I absolutely love Dhar the GOAT of physics. Great at lecturing and prepares you well for exams. Rework EVERY lecture problem and difficult ExpertTA problems and you'll do fine. Tests are difficult bc of time limit not material. Gives lots of opportunities to redeem yourself and make a comeback if you don't do so great on either midterm.

Dhar's honestly a solid professor. Heard he had a bad reputation before taking the class, yet after attending his lectures, he's super passionate about what he's teaching. His lectures are very informative and, in my opinion, best prepare you for the exams. One of the better teachers I've had overall, would take a course with him again.

Barun Dhar is genuinely a very good professor. The class average for any test is very low. This is due to the midterms containing more questions than time permits. On top of this, questions on tests receive partial credit, but you must do everything the way Dhar shows you, otherwise you won't receive partial credit. You will not have time to check.

He's a good lecturer but be prepared for essay length emails and him lying about the midterms. He'll say it's only 3 questions with parts, but the parts end up being entirely separate questions so 6-9 questions in an hour. It takes all of lecture for 1 question good luck.
Ngl twn Dhar my goat lectures very helpful wish he could teach all of my cs classes everyone who rated a 1 just couldn't handle the course rigor and just doesn't wanna put in effort.

As some others have mentioned, he is the GOAT of the physics department, at least... if not one of the top 3 professors at this school (for me, at least). He is the most passionate teacher I have encountered during my three years here. His class is very hard, but that is by nature of the topic. If you have the chance to take him, DO IT.

Professor Dhar knows how to bring fascination to the course and you will feel it! I wish all professor in this physics department were able to bring their topics up with the same energy as Dhar... 5C this quarter was much more difficult, which is to be expected. exams in 5C were much more difficult, but overall this guy is the GOAT.

Honestly think the rating is a bit unfair. Class is difficult don't get me wrong but is manageable if you don't troll (like i did). Just make sure to actually rework the lecture problems as the midterms are based off of those problems. Class is recoverable if you fall behind too i was 15 lectures behind at one point and still passed 5B.

He's very knowledgeable, and his lectures are clear and well paced. Reworking lecture problems and practicing Expert TA problem sets prepares you well. There are two midterms and a final, with the final replacing your lower midterm if you score higher on it. Stay engaged and don't fall behind.

99 students out of roughly 200 scored a 34% or lower on exam 2. Instead of re-evaluating his tests or teaching methods, he put all the blame on the students. He then sent out multiple lengthy emails saying we weren't going to succeed because we weren't trying hard enough. This should tell you everything you need to know about this professor.

There's definitely some self studying with his class but he puts you on the right path with his lectures. My only complaint is that he puts the homework ahead of the lectures sometimes. Some also say that his way of doing problems is the only way which I somewhat agree with but the core concepts and the general math behind them are explained well.

She is an AMAZING professor. She's funny and knows how to make the material as comprehensive as possible. Her exams are extremely reasonable, and you are given more than enough to succeed in this course. As long as you put in effort, you should be able to do well.

Amy is an amazing teacher, really engaging and cares about her students. Grading policies are strict, but she makes them very clear and I have not heard of anyone having issues with them. Though lecture attendance is extra credit, discussion attendance decides whether or not you can retake a midterm during the finals time slot. Take her class!

Amy was an amazing intro physics professor. She had an extremely well structured class, any info you needed was very accessible outside of class. Homework was manageable, challenging, and felt relevant to the course. being in lecture was always super fun, attendance was not mandatory but I wouldn't want to miss that experience.

This is the best professor I've ever had. She was so incredibly structured and answered every question I had during lectures. Definitely be prepared for some hard work but if you're putting in the effort, it will definitely pay off. She's super understanding too and allows mastery quizzes to be retaken if you state what you've learned since.

Many truly don't appreciate their physics professor until she goes on sabbatical in New Zealand. Amy is well-spoken and well-respected. Effectively teaches the material and cares about student success. Masterfully quells panicked physics students' nerves. Wish she was teaching 6B this quarter. Come back queen we promise to remember g is positive

Amy is an amazing professor. She is very clear with what she expects from us, her lectures are very engaging and often times have demos. The exams are pretty fair and she provides us with a lot of study material. She's hilarious and very kind. Whoever gives her a bad rating doesn't know how to study tbh.

This class is incredibly organized and her expectations are very clear. She is also so funny and her lectures are fun to attend! Attendance isn't mandatory but you can receive a little extra credit for going.

No other class I've taken has been this organized/structured. From day one you know EXACTLY what topics you'll learn and what will show up on quizzes and tests. Each module is complete with lecture notes before/after her annotations, readings, a mastery quiz, and HW. Ask questions. Go to office hours. She does her best to ensure student success.

Many of the lectures don't feel like they relate to any of the testing materials, and the fact that she will fail you even if you have a passing class grade just because you didn't get a 60% average on the exams is very unfair. I would maybe take her again, but only because the other professors don't seem any better.

Professor Furniss has been awesome. The class was definitely challenging at points but she herself is really good at lecturing and does try to help you succeed. Grading was generous and re-tests of exams were a lifesaver for sure.

This class was very difficult. The lectures were packed with material and the homework was sometimes difficult. Tests are hard, but she does tell you what to study for. Rewatch lectures for the best example problems. Furniss is a great professor, she is very intelligent and has engaging lectures, but physics is a very difficult topic.

Omg, this was the hardest class ever but Amy was so kind and funny. It didn't feel like an intro class a lot of the time because I felt like lectures were sometimes rushed through. She's so brilliant though, so I can't even leave criticism.

Such a kind and engaging professor. The exams are difficult and there are no clear practice exams that helped a lot but the class before exams is a super helpful review session. The testing format allowed you tot retake a midterm instead of taking a final if you attended all of the discussion sections which was helpful.

Amy is amazing. She understands how people learn, and structures her class around progress. It is very obvious that she cares for her students and wants them to understand the material rather than just pass. She is also hilarious. She made me excited for lecture, and she kept me paying attention the whole time. TAKE PHYSICS WITH AMY!

Amy is an incredibly organized, hilarious, and eloquent instructor. Every lecture was engaging and she made the class laugh out loud nearly every day. This class made me a better problem-solver and, for my first physics course, it was one that I thoroughly enjoyed. Canvas modules are well-structured and everything is set up for your success. Slay.

Very organized professor. Clear expectations and truly cares about student success. During lecture she is lighthearted and jokes around yet solidify her standards and expectations for students. One of the most respectable professors I have had. Understands the students are not well versed in physics and teaches based on what the students need

Amy clearly cares about her students succeeding in the class. She provides every possible material to be successful, and it's up to the student to use it. She is very clear about her expectations while being very reasonable. I wish I had more professors like Furniss.
She is such a sweet person. I had her for the entire physics 6 series. I strongly suggest going to office hours because getting to know her is so beneficially.

Amy Furniss is the best she should have a nobel prize in everything. She is HILARIOUS, never missed a physics class because it was so entertaining. She cares a lot about your learning and genuinly wants everyone to get an A. Go through learning objective spreadsheet to do well on test.
so so so great! she makes physics actually understandable and provides you with many opportunities to succeed. her exams are just like the problems in the notes and section worksheets.

The class was a kinda figure it out yourself from the lab manual, however the professor gave us his phone number to contact with any questions outside of classes and was available during class to explain any problems during the class. I would take notes on the advice he gives at the start of the Lab it's very helpful for writing the Lab report.

Didn't really answer our questions, just expected us to read the lab manual and magically understand everything on our own. Graded lab reports WAY too harshly and not fairly. There was a page limit and then I was deducted points for not writing enough (I already went over the maximum pg limit). Course was disorganized and expectations were unclear

WORST PROF EVER! He makes mistakes in class all the time and then confuses himself and then cannot complete the problems. Everything I learned was from the SI tutoring, his lectures made no sense. He told us the final was 40% of our grade in an announcement and then changed it to 45% of our grade w/o notice (diff between an A and B for me)

He's passionate about physics, but his teaching style is not for everyone. This class was tough, he does not simplify the material and exams are 90% of your grade. He sometimes speaks too fast, and his writing is difficult to understand. HW was difficult and not helpful. I appreciated the practice exams and that he curved! only reason some passed.

Honestly one of the worst profs I have ever had. During lectures he confuses himself and does not explain things clearly. His tests are worded weirdly as well and the practice tests aren't really helpful. Would not recommend.

His lectures were unclear and filled with mistakes. Not only were his lectures a mess, but tests AND homework were always graded wrong and it would take ages to get them fixed. His tests are somewhat fair so if you study a lot you should do fine, but for the most part his class was filled with uncertainty and had no structure.

I believe that I definitely could've learned way more if the lecture notes & the way he teached were better organized. He usually makes mistakes during calculations in class, which was so hard to follow & the homework was graded harshly (using gradescope). I passed, but definitely felt like I didn't really learn anything sadly

He makes mistakes during every problem that he goes over in lecture. The tests are HARD, the homework is graded harshly. No partial credit given during tests, and no study guide beforehand. He takes attendance and assigned 80 pages of reading before the quarter began, none of which was understandable. Do yourself a favor and avoid this professor.

I do NOT recommend this professor. He consistently made mistakes throughout lecture, making it very difficult to learn the material. The weekly homework is graded harshly. Both midterms were weighted heavily and were incredibly challenging. Attendance is a small part of the grade. To pass, supplementary help (MSI, ACE, etc.) is a necessity.

If youre going to take his class its best if you choose pass/no pass. Physics 6a was supposed to be an intro to physics, but it feels like the professor expects us to know half of the stuff from the get go. If you are going to take his class and end up struggling, go to sections and watch the Organic Chemistry Tutor on YouTube.

distracted and confused for 1st month (turned to students for help & often messed up on example problems) which made learning very hard. switched to doing the problems in class which was much better but have to be attentive he messes up sometimes. Posts lectures & hw answers (good for studying) lots of studying for test but focuses on key concepts

it's ridiculous how horrible this professor has been. he messes up almost every example problem he shows us in class so we have to teach ourselves, then grades the hw so it's so much pressure to try to get every point you can. I studied more that I've ever studied in college for the midterms we've had and I've never felt less prepared.
No direction to this class, guy has no idea what he is doing

Ramirez constantly confuses himself in class. He seems to have a hard time understanding basic algebra and trigonometry and in the third class he lectured, he asked for help from the class several times. Probably the worst lecturer Ive had in all of my schooling (including grades k-12). I learned more from a sub prof that we had for 2 days.

Literally got the ratio test wrong on the first day of class. His lectures were reading out of the textbook, but he actually got a lot of the formulas wrong and going to class just made us confused. By week 3 half the class had stopped showing up. Had to teach myself everything from the (awful) textbook, which is really hard in Complex Analysis.

Homework was very hard while the midterms and finals were comparatively easier. Lectures can be a little slow at times and difficult to understand but the textbook helps clarify things. Review the homework problems before the midterm and final because the questions on the exam are simpler versions of the ones on the homework.

Syzranov has been one of my favorite professors. His lecture pace may feel quite slow, but it's worth listening to. Even if you don't show up to class, his lectures are posted online and putting it on 2x speed has been a game changer. 
He curves your overall grade at the end of the quarter and is understanding. Awesome accent too.

He's a caring and nice professor with flawless enunciation and uses the document camera. He postponed exams multiple times due to storms. He gives you example exams from past quarters similar to the actual exam. Discussion worksheets are graded for effort, not correctness. Homework is due every Sunday at midnight, and no homework during exam weeks.

Easy to talk to during or after class and OHs, but was incredibly rude outside of class and through email. Lectures were pretty subpar and incredibly hard to follow along, so I pretty much stopped going and used the textbook and YouTube videos to carry me through this class.

2 midterms, 1 final, and homework sets every week. I think his lectures could be a little more engaging but overall he did a good job with what he had to teach us in the curriculum. Practice exams are fairly similar to what the exam will cover. The only downside that was difficult for me was that we had to memorize all the formulas for the exams.

He seems to be a very professional person. Lectures were informative and useful for understanding course content. He also provided examples of different class concepts, which made them easier to understand. He has high expectations, but if you follow along with his lectures then that shouldn't be a problem.

1 homework a week, usually sunday. Lectures are helpful if you pay attention. The textbook(free) is helpful. He provides multiple practice exams which are extremely helpful. Reasonable with deadlines. He's always happy to answer questions. the only thing difficult was Gauss law, everything else was pretty easy. exams have lot of partial points.

The subject material is difficult but he tries his best to explain the theory and provide examples. If you attend the lectures and read the online OpenStax textbook before doing the respective homework assignments, you will do well in the class. Study using the practice midterms and ask questions on Ed and you will do well on them too.
hot

Professor Syzranov was a decent professor, his lectures were a bit confusing but the book and watching youtube videos would help a lot. He curves a lot and the grading scale is lower than usual. There are many opportunities to earn extra credit in this class. He's accessible outside class by attending office hours or posting your question on ED

The way Sergey structured lectures was a bit confusing, I disliked how he made us memorize equations for midterms/finals rather than giving us the equations and ensuring we knew why we were using them. More than 1/2 of the class stopped showing up and read the textbook instead bc of the confusing lectures. 100% recommend taking Dhar over this prof.

Professor Syzranov did well to convey the concepts which was good bc I personally had some trouble wrapping my head around a lot of it. He left many options to earn extra credit and answered questions in Ed discussions frequently. He also frequently stopped lectures for anyone's questions which is always great to see.

It seems like Sergey cared about teaching, which is surprising because from what I've heard he's a research focused prof. He always asked if things made sense in class, responded with comprehensive answers on EdDiscussion, and clearly communicated grading/curves. if som1 didn't understand during lecture tho, somtimz he would just state it different
Super easy lab, only graded based off work done in lab and 2-3 pre-lab questions per lab.

Wow literally can't even express in words how great Mr. Brown is. He genuinely cares about every one of his students and he's an amazing teacher. One of a kind; if you have an opportunity to get to know him or take one of his classes, absolutely take it.
He is always there to help you understand the lesson. A very kind man that has a passion to teach physics to others.

Excellent teacher.  Very intelligent and cares deeply about students and lectures.  I emailed him about (minor) concerns regarding the class and received a detailed, thoughtful reply almost immediately.

This guy knows his stuff and knows how to teach it. He is VERY supportive and has GREAT concern for the students. He still wants you to keep in touch even after taking him. If you ever have a chance, definitely take him...otherwise you'll really regret it.

Probably the best physics professor I've ever had. Not only does he show concern for his students, but also has great determination in teaching the materials very well. Take this teacher if you get the chance because anyone else wouldnt be as great as him.

He seems truly concerned with the learning of his students, and is willing to do anything to make sure people understand course material, even if it means explaining an idea 3 times, which can drag on.  He's super supportive, especially in office hours, and explains ideas really clearly.  Class demos are great, and he has a wonderful sense of humor

The quality of the lectures in this class varied considerably. Some were dreadfully boring, whereas others were quite stimulating. Interestingly, there was a strong corelation between use of the  wave machine  and lectures that put one to sleep.

One of the best physics professors around, works hard to make sure that his students understand the material and do well. His exams are a bit on the complex side but he makes up for it with generous grading. My only complaint is that the homework was different than what you would see on the exams or iclicker questions. Read the textbook!

Jason was a king; I used to hate physics but he really made every class interesting. He's also really funny and cares about his students. His tests were slightly on the more complex side, but he prepares you with the homework and practice tests. Definitely take him, best physics professor I've had at UCSC

AWESOME AWESOME guy. takes time out of his own day to meet students and would always stay late after class. If you have the chance to interact with him, do it! (Ask him about his job on the hadron collider)
Really cares about his students and is very understanding. I have heard that many of the other physics teachers at UCSC are not, so I strongly recommend taking physics with Nielsen.

If this is your first time taking physics I would go with someone else. He sped through the material and only took questions related to physics more advanced than this class seriously. Between abstract lectures and homework that takes hours to finish, there is no time for you to study if you have other classes/obligations.

Dr. Nielsen is your physics professor's favorite physics professor. He expects an immersive work ethic, afterall - this is what engineering, physics, and mathematics students signed up for. Learned a lot from him, and he made the remote quarter super enjoyable!
At best takes 2-3 days to respond to an email if he responds at all, which kind of sucks. That being said hes a pretty nice guy and definitely knows his stuff

He is a nice professor, and if you have time for OH this class will be easier. But, this class is a nightmare to any working student. OH are consistently during shifts and discussions aren't much help. The homework is extremely reliant on being proficient plugging equations into excel sheets and is impossible to anyone else. Treat OH as mandatory

Homeworks take hours to finish every week. However, if you understand all the homework, you can handle the exams pretty well. He used the same question in one of the homework three times in all of his exams. His lectures are hilarious, and he's always enthusiastic about what he is teaching. Good professor indeed.

Nielsen is insanely smart and an amazing professor (had to miss class because he got flown out to work on an experiment at CERN one time). His lectures are crystal clear and he's very open to questions. If I HAD to say one bad thing about Nielsen, it'd be the computational problems he assigns for homework (essentially spreadsheet/excel problems).

Nielsen is an amazing professor who really strives to help students better understand. However, his exams are really difficult and often he doesn't put formulas, you need on the exam sheet. Also, study potential energy problems before exams he likes to use those a lot. In summary, This class will take up a lot of your time, but you'll learn a lot.

The nicest, most adorable man who ever lived. He's got dad humor out the wazoo, and is one of the greatest lecturers ever. Tests are fair. My only complaint is the computational problems on the homework, but it wasn't a class killer.
Nielson is a diamond in the ruff. He is super approachable and very nice. Tests/homework are hard, but show up to office hours/ sections and you will be in good shape.

Dr Nielsen is an amazing professor. He explains concepts really, really well and has tiny nerdy outbursts. It's impossible to not share his enthusiasm for physics. He's the kind of guy who can get you hooked on Physics. If you have a chance to learn the introductory courses from him, I'd definitely recommend him.
Dr. Nielsen is a great professor. He's always prepared, and he's great at engaging his students. His tests are quite hard but fair. Overall great guy with a huge passion for physics

Nielsen is nerdy, but passionate and not arrogant at all. He is very approachable and does examples in class, many of which are from the textbook. He trips up on math sometimes, but quickly corrects himself.

Mr. Nielsen is a good lecturer and has worked at the LHC and is well respected among his peers. The tests are difficult, and the curve is generous. But be prepared to spend some hours on the homework and make sure to take full advantage of MSI and TA hours. It really helps!
awesome professor

Prof Nielsen loves physics, and seems to hope you will too. Tests and homework are certainly difficult, but I like to think that the people who will go on to build bridges and such were thoroughly vetted. Expect to give it your utmost.

His tests are impossible to score 100% unless you have taken physics beforehand. The average of the class throughout the quarter was a 50%. It's very important to do all of the examples in the text and to understand how to do the problems. This class was harder than my engineering classes. Don't take this class unless it's required.
Really nice professor. He is patient and willing to answer any question during his office hours. He covered every topic in the exam. There are weekly homework with interesting topics.

Great professor, I think he did well explaining all the concepts. He was pretty engaging for me so I wasn't bored in class, he uses iClicker to have us participate. We had homework assigned after each lecture and sometimes one weekly homework. Weekly labs and discussions that helped understand concepts. Overall, I would take his class again.

I took his 5A last quarter! He was a good instructor. Lectures were well structured with some sense of humor. The homework is heavy but that's a very useful way to practice. He responded to Ed discussion quickly. Almost every lecture was recorded and posted on Yuja. And his grading rubric is generous.

A very good lecturer who had a good sense of humor. His midterms and exams were pretty hard, but his class curve was generous. We had a lot of homework but he was very helpful in the ed discussion forum.

I loved having him as a professor this past quarter! He was a good instructor and taught the subject material well. There's a lot of homework, but that's also what allows you to actually understand the physics you're learning. If you don't show up to lecture you won't know what you're doing. He responds very quickly to Ed discussion posts.

I think this was his first 5A class and he had previously only taught 6A. You will have daily homework that make its hard to get ahead. The midterms are doable but the final is pretty hard. Very strict about grade breakpoints and does not round or curve. Lectures are hard to follow but he does use a free online textbook that is very accessible.

He's all of what can go wrong with Physics professors. No powerpoints for clear pictures, VERY hard exams, and LOTS of homework. His lectures are just math lectures which get VERY boring because he doesn't know how to dial it back for Physics-newbies to understand what is going on. Took this class again with Arthur and passed just fine.

Homework is almost exclusively excel spreadsheets, tests are actual derivations and concepts. Grading is almost entirely tests and quizzes. Feedback on assignments is almost nonexistent, the only statement written is nonsense when something is wrong. Blamed students when first midterm had a median of 48%.

I found professor Johnson to be a solid professor for 6A. The class was very demanding with the homework load and the tests werent that easy, but his lectures were easy to follow and he was always clear on what concepts we should expect on exams. If you put in the work then youll get a good grade.

Weekly HWs were long and proof heavy, confusing wording. Reading quiz before every class. Took 50% avg on midterm to get him to slow down and make HW more doable. 65% avg. on final. 50-64 - C, 65-79 - B, 80+ - A. Helpful in OH but have to ask specific questions and keep clarifying if he's unclear. Some info in class not in book. DO NOT FALL BEHIND.

Usually spends too much time doing algebras on blackboard. Lectures provide lots of information that are not in the textbook. Hard homework problems, provide codes if plots are required. Only had two physical demonstrations. READ THE TEXTBOOK to really understand the subject, the nitty gritty matters!

Easily the worst teacher I have ever had. Lectures are a mumble-fest math vomit onto the blackboard (because in 2018 why use a doc camera and make the webcast usable for students?) Lecture notes are almost non-existent. No homework questions relate to the textbook (which blows btw). I almost dropped out because of this professor.

It was like he assumed you had not only done the reading, but understood it completely and was lecturing on some extra bonus material for funsies. Means well but is really bad at understanding what students do and do not get. Pretty caring, but homeworks take forever; I was often in the library with my study group until 4am. Cool class but rough.

He gives really tough homework. The tests were weird-a lot of multiple choice. I wish the tests were more problem solving because that's what we actually do all quarter. In lectures he spends a LOT of time doing algebra or evaluating an integral or something and doesn't explain the overall concept (usually). NOT good at answering questions.
He isn't very good at answering questions in class but is a decent lecturer. He uses a lot of slides and demonstrations which are helpful. Ready to help at his office hours.

Robert Johnson is a good lecturer. He really knows his material and it comes out when he teaches. He uses demonstrations almost every class. He's kind of bad at answering questions in lecture but people ask stupid ones usually anyway. If you do the homework, go to lecture (iclickers count), and study a few hours for each test you'll get an A.

Spends a bit too much time doing algebra on the board rather than explaining concepts. His grading system is fair, but its not as easy to get an A as in some other courses. Assigns homework problems that require way too much algebra, although maybe this is just the nature of this course. Quizes and final were straight forward and fair. Good prof.
He's reallllllly hard. Though if you keep up with all the materials and show concern for the course, he'll make sure you do well and at least pass.

Lectures are dry but clear--the problem is that Johnson is terrible at describing concepts, which is absolutely vital for physics. Lab was torture (often 20 hrs/wk), I tried hard not to fall asleep in there. He's alright with questions though often brushes you off. Hardest class I've taken, with the least payoff. Electronics never "clicked" for me.

Teacher definitely knows what he is teaching.  Lectures can be a bit on the dry side and you will spend some quality time with the book and prepping for midterm, but the tests are very conceptual and fair.  Interesting class, lab is dull.

Stefano is one of the best professors I have ever had! He never makes you feel dumb for asking questions or needing extra help. His lectures were very fun & he clearly cares about his students and wants us to succeed. He doesn't take attendance and discussions are extra credit. Lots of other opportunities for extra credit on every homework & test.

I genuinely love him so much! He is kind, compassionate, and passionate about the subjects he teaches. He is one of the best professors I've ever had on this campus and compel any students pursuing physics to take a class with him at some point. You will not regret it!

Stefano's impact on students goes well beyond physics. It's refreshing to see a professor take such pride in being a good lecturer. He encouraged us as undergraduates to go out and pursue research opportunities, even giving some students in our class research opportunities. His class is really easy, is that a good or bad thing?
I love stefano profumo

Out of all professors I've had he's been my favorite - attentive and responsive to students who ask for help & attend office hours. Sometimes hard to follow problems' steps but there's lots of practice problems and the subject is very learnable. He keeps lectures engaging, thought-provoking, and memorable!

stefano is great, but he would skip a lot of steps in class; make sure to go to office hours and his discussions if you needed extra help with explanations like I did. Overall great professor, super friendly and u can tell he cares abt his students & physics. he often engaged w students during class, & talked about his research a lot which was cool

Profumo is an amazing professor that I would gladly take again! He is very passionate about physics and research, so don't hesitate to ask lots of questions in discussion section and during office hours. In my opinion, 5D has the hardest conceptual concepts of the 5 series, but Profumo made every lecture fun and understandable.

Stefano is one of the friendliest and most considerate professors I've had. He offers a lot of support with extra credit opportunities on homework and in discussion sections. Exams are very fair, and he is very patient and understanding if you're confused about the material. If you can take a class with him, please do!

Stefano is a great professor and person. His lectures aren't as structured as Dhar but he offers A LOT of extra credit throughout the quarter (you get extra credit for attending discussion sections). My friends in this class had above a 100% for most of the quarter. However, I will not deny it; this class was difficult, especially towards the end.

This is actually for 5D but there was no option. Great professor, super friendly, funny, has very interesting lectures, and super helpful office hours and sections. Gave TONS of extra credit. Graded more by understanding of topic than correctness. If you have a chance to take a class with him, highly recommend.

I knew this would be a challenging class, but it was more challenging than I expected. I learned a lot. No shame in asking questions or refreshing on concepts. This professor was fun and seemed very caring. Homework was lengthy and hard. Exams were conceptual and not as tedious as the homework. I recommend buying the book he follows it closely.

Profumo is fantastic at teaching material, helping in office hours, and is very funny. His tests are open book with his reasoning being that real life is open book. I really wanted to give him a 5, but strangely the class was TOO easy. A year later and I don't feel like I retained the knowledge from this course I was supposed to.

Stefano is a great Professor. He is knowledgeable, friendly, and humorous. I loved going to lecture, even though it was fast paced. Tests were open note and open book, which I found was a very fair way of testing our knowledge. Overall the class was a great experience, even though I dont like math.

The lectures are pretty fast paced, but worth every moment. He keeps us motivated by telling us where exactly in our physics careers we would utilize the mathematical skill set we acquired in this class. I loved the class.

He's a great professor, test are relatively easy.  Only part annoying about the class is his use of cellphone text based quizzes when the cell signal in the lecture hall is absolutely awful, He changed those to extra credit halfway through the class. And he talks a lot about himself. But he's got a lot to talk about, runs marathons ect.
great guy, really cares about you. good instructor

Stefano is an absolutely amazing professor. 10 out of 10 would recommend. He really genuinely cares about your success in the class and opens himself to you for many opportunities to meet him during his office hours or elsewhere outside of class. Truly an inspirational professor.
One of the best professors around. Very helpful and pleasant. It's hard to imagine anyone not liking this guy.

Amazing professor. Lectures are extremely clear and organized, answered questions very well, and was a generally likeable guy. Weekly quizzes weren't a blast, but they did keep you prepared for the midterm/final. I hope to have Stefano again.

He is the best physics professor I have ever had! He moved quickly, but was very helpful if you were lost or did not understand something he went over in class. His test were tough, but do-able. He was very fair in grading, even though he does not believe in curves. I would highly recommend taking any class of his!

not a required class. Professor Smith really cares about everyone's success, and he really tries to teach as much as he can to prepare everyone in this class. My only complaint is if you don't have a background in calculus or some physics already, then it can be a challenging class. Luckily, all work can be retaken, and he's 100% there to help.

David Smith is kinda quirky, but he's really cool and smart. Professor Smith cares so much about your learning and always wants to help you when you are stuck. He spends so much time helping individual students that it can get kind of annoying for people who just have quick questions. But that is the extent of my qualms(hardly a qualm). He's great

PHYS 2 is optional, but Prof. Smith makes it so worthwhile. He's so enthusiastic about teaching, and he's rlly good at explaining concepts. The class is most entirely conceptual, and is a great refresher from HS. Also everything can be made up for full credit. I can't speak for the upper divs, but take PHYS 2.

It was advertised as a class that would teach some basic physics and what a career in it meant. He did the latter pretty well and it was informative, but covered broad concepts in short amount of time and gave homework on it. It wasn't bad, he helped the students a lot, esp w/ getting them into 5A.

I graduated 2 years ago and still think about this guy. He promised me research opportunities quarter after quarter, just to deny me each time. Eventually he just ghosted all my emails. If you are pursuing physics at UCSC, this is your sign to switch to engineering. I will die working a minimum wage job.

I enjoyed his lectures and the overall structure of the course was well thought out. 
He accused me of cheating on a quiz by means of changing my answer afterwards and asking for a regrade (who would do that??). This accusation never went anywhere, but it seriously damaged my opinion of him.

Amazing teacher who really cares for understanding of the material more than making sure you get the right answer. During the pandemic, he made the class interesting and was flexible and understanding. Course material is tough but manageable if you do all your work.

prof smith is awesome. he gives great lectures. the hw is lowkey a little tough but he has so many office hours and even holds office hours at nite. he's always willing to help and gave the whole class extra chances to redo so many questions that u got wrong on the midterms. cool teacher, if u dont like him that sounds like a u problem bro

Wait until you can get Nelson, she is a much better teacher. Mr Smith only cares about getting through the material, he doesn't care if you understand the topic or not. And whenever you ask him a question he always returns it with either I can't or he provides a question in return.
Currently in PHYS 5A and I am really enjoying it. As we are on Zoom due to the pandemic he has made class fun to be a part of.

Honestly one of the best professors I've ever had especially in more of a tougher major related class. With the pandemic he's super understanding and has formed his class and lectures around it to help the students out. He explains things super well and makes lectures fun and interesting. HIGHLY RECOMMEND taking him!

Absolutely amazing professor. It's only Week 3, and I've already laughed, cried, stressed, pulled an all-nighter - gone through the entire college class experience. I love the songs he puts on in the middle of lecture! I always look forward to his classes! Definitely take him - difficult class content-wise, but so worth it as a professor.
Very passionate and wants you to learn even if they are simple questions
He's just the best really, I understood everything and he expalins it so well! A real treat to be in his class

Very engaging lectures and topic. Had team quizzes every week based on the homework due the same day. Tended to get off topic easily through student questions. Two midterms back to back but only the better grade counted. COVID made our final online/open notes/open internet. Good curve was getting 68% in class and curved to B. Do the HW and go to OH

There is a special place in heaven for Prof Smith. He is quite the character, always radiating energy during lecture. His word problems are wacky and enjoyable, so make sure to crack a smile at them. He teaches tough, large physics courses, so don't expect an easy class. I recommend attending every lecture, and just do your damn hw!
Only weekly quizzes and NO midterms, 1 final. Enough said. Tests are TOUGH, so that he can curve heavily.

If  you love to procrastinate and study the book two weeks before the midterm. NOT the class for you. Weekly hw (hard), weekly quizzes (ehh), and no midterm. Was on my stuff until week 5 with other midterms and then I just became so behind that I'm in a hole of my own sorrow. He is a good professor, but you have to read the book for his class
No midterm, only weekly quizzes and homework and a final. Lectures have nothing to do with homework. Poor use of class time IMO

Huge regret. Do not recommend at all for GE class. Not as easy as you would think. 1 midterm 1 final. No papers. Alot of readings assigned. Reading quizzes and group assignment are given every class. Homework due once a week. HW was VERY difficult even with the help of tutor/ta/prof. Don't take unless you have a background in physics.

Really awesome passionate guy but as far as teaching goes I felt pretty lost in the course. His lectures are difficult to follow and draw from. If you're taking him I recommend relying on the textbook and resources he posts on his website. I wanted to love this class but I never knew what what was happening.

Haber puts a lot of effort into his classes, giving a TON of outside resources to help. His lectures are pretty good, but it's not always easy to find what to take away from them. Homework sets are challenging, but prepare you well. Tests are very tough but fair. Haber's a very knowledgeable and helpful guy, though not the most friendly person.

He spends allot of time talking about certain aspects of the material before he has really describes the base concepts. This makes his lectures very hard to follow. His exams are hard. His homework is really good he selects problems that reinforce concepts well. His website and external resources are amazing. Brilliant dedicated dude, bad teacher

Haber delivered a very rich, high quality physics 116A course this quarter. Solutions to problem sets and exams were always thorough and comprehensible which made learning difficult material much easier than it could have been. His was an intense, serious mathematics course and  I am glad to have had him as my professor.

Haber certainly knows mathematics in 116A. He spends class giving and deriving formulas with light proofs and without examples. He IS very technological friendly because he writes advanced mathematical handouts in LaTeX. You must take 116A if you're a Physics or Astrophysics major. Intense guy, nice, and helpful in office hours.

Brilliant guy. Obviously spends a lot of time at home deriving formulas. Spends entire class time deriving formulas. Obviously very smart, but formula derivations really aren't very important and not very helpful when it comes to learning the material. Homework difficult, harshly graded, and worth a midterm. Technologically incapable.
He is a very bright and kind professor, but I wish he can teach a little bit more on what he analyzed rather than referring to the book. Overall, he is a good professor.
He's super intelligent, but his lectures focus too much on the derivation of formulas rather than problem solving in my opinion. Still a good professor.

Lectures are pointless because he teaches right out of the book. Several times the underlying answer he gave to someone's questions is "It just is." The tests are difficult, but manageable. TA office hours are more useful than going to class.
He's a nice guy and speaks clearly, but his material is fairly useless. He generally draws his lectures from the book, with an occasional insertion of personal thought.
Smart prof, hes got mad physics skills, I think he labeled himself a theorist in class one day. Lectures are helpful, explains the concepts well.
Awesome teacher- he's really nice and concerned with his students

Intelligent and brilliant. Extremely helpful during office hours. Homework can be difficult or can be easy. Exams can be difficult but are straight forward - no tricks which so many professors love to use. Best physics professor I've ever had.

Howie is like a little kid, in a good way. He gets really into what he's saying, which keeps the class very enjoyable. He's super down-to-earth. His tests are pretty easy and homework too. Always knows what he's talking about, and theres a big curve on everything. If you like physics, you'll like Haber a lot, especially if you need a grade boost.

Nice man, somewhat disorganized lecture notes. Ridiculously intelligent, sometimes has trouble coming down to students' level. Very generous on tests (open note/book/calc). While 116A was somewhat bland subject matter, I suspect his genius is better expressed in more physicsy/conceptual classes (i.e. quantum, grad classes, etc)

I enjoyed the way he lectured, it was concise and straightforward. Very helpful and nice in office hours, he'll push you to try and workout your questions instead of giving answer right away. Exam practice problems were not similar to test but more of a guideline of the stuff you should know so be prepared to get questions that are more complex

He's not that bad, I think that the bad ratings reflect the difficulty of the class not his teaching abilities. He's a bit boring but if you actually pay attention in class, do the homework, and go to discussion, you will do succeed. He's honestly very sweet and understanding as well. You can do well in the class if you just apply yourself tbh.
literally the worst professor ever. so boring and monotonous. teaches us literally nothing in class and lowk hella cute
bad lecturer. you gotta teach yourself everythinggggg. no point of going to class.
Good physics professor, pretty light grader. Best one of the 6 series I had. Extra credit by going to class an discussion.

Super amazing professor. The homework was pretty easy problems, but the class was only graded on tests and homework. Neither were very difficult, make sure to write a lot on formula sheets, but luckily the tests were pretty similar (honestly easier) than the practice tests. Attendance wasn't mandatory but would highly recommend going.

Genuinely one of the best professors I have had at this school. He cares deeply about his students and their success—is clearly very knowledgable and explains content very thoroughly with a simple breakdown that made learning thermodynamics tolerable. Highly reccomend taking his if you have the opportunity.

Absolutely loved him for 5D. Great professor, tried at every opportunity to help students do better. Took feedback very well. Lectures were full of concepts and examples, so you understood the importance of the material and the structure of the questions.
She is amazing, and extremely helpful during office hours. Her lecturing style is very good, although a bit fast sometimes. Midterm was very good and fair, but the final was extremely difficult.

Lectures are intensive and well-paced, and I really appreciate that she gives a summary of what was previously covered in every class. She is open to all questions during lecture and can tell when students are confused. Homework come directly from lectures. Very accessible and approachable outside class, very brilliant! love this class.
I took her and she was very generous when it came to the curves and grading. The lectures were very digestible and the homework/tests were very similar to the lectures so it was very straightforward.

Did not know what she was doing, regarded to everyone I spoke to as "the worst professor i've ever had", definitely is only there for her research and put low effort into teaching. To give her some credit the course work was not too hard and she did give extensions for late homework, but the lectures were god awful, hard to understand and confusing

Nice person, but not the best professor. She has too much stuff going on to put enough effort into the class to make it a valuable learning experience during lectures. Did however think the class was a good learning experience and cool concept. Class was ridiculously easy.

Had Sue for CRSN 151B. Hands down worst class ive ever had, she clearly has zero in the class or us as students. She will take breaks in the middle of class to text on her phone or to walk to the cafe to get coffee. During our presentations she was on her phone or telling students to skip ahead bc she "didnt care" about this part. One kid cried.
She is awesome! She makes it super easy for everyone to pass. All her tests are based on the homework, so just do the homework

Alright teacher overall. She does try to make sure students understand, but its clear that phys 6a just isn't her prime subject material. Lots of "I don't remember where this came from" and "I'm not sure what I did here". On the plus side, she goes over hw in class, which I find helpful.

Despite what people have to say for her, I think she's a very nice teacher. Everyday she would review lectures from the day before. She would also go over HW problems in class when there's time. And she also shows us physical models of the material taught in the lecture. Sadly, her class is very difficult. Be prepared to study extensively.

Her tests were easy if you know the hw backwards and forwards because her tests consist of a variation of the hw questions. She tends to mumble under her breath when she is explaining something, so sit close to the front. Her notes were kind of confusing and the hw covered things we didn?t really learn in lecture. Could be very confusing at times

great teacher. i just wanted to give her a hug, she always looked so frazzled. great teaching, and amazing system of grading. huge curve and will work with you to get an A by the end of class. optional hw, easy tests. highly recommended to sharpen physics skills forgotten from high school

I'm surprised at the bad stuff about Sue. She's the best Physics prof I've had. Really straightforward, a little goofy, no surprises, fair exams straight from the homework. I expected to hate her after all the bad reviews but I'm really stoked I got her since I have to take this class.
Awesomely bad.
No Comments

Sue is not a good lecturer. She did not come to class with good lecture material prepared, and she was not helpful during office hours. My advice is that if you have her, drop the class. It doesn't matter what you need it for, drop it and take it with someone else.

If you do the homework, and know it backwards and forwards, then the tests are easy.  She gives an equation sheet for every test.  She seems really nice when she lectures, but when you talk to her in person, she is short and rude.  She's very talented and smart, but her strengths are in research, and not teaching.

Arrogant, self-centered, and disorganized.  A gifted and smart person, but a terrible teacher because she cannot interact with students without having an attitude problem.  Do the homework and know it inside out and maybe you'll get a B. But do NOT speak to her regarding grading concerns, because she hates lowly undergrads.
No Comments

You can never understand her. Her voice fades as she speaks. She will not help you during office hours, just tries to get rid of you. She never wears a bra, (really obvious), and always complains about being sick.  She seems like a complete idiot, but from what I hear, she is actually brilliant? Just study the homework.

She is a bit disorganized, but her exams are very fair.  The problems are straight from the homework.  Stay in class for the review session right before the exam, she basically does the exam problems for you.  Easy to get a B.

She writes very small and speaks softly at the end of each sentence, especially when she's making a point. Exams weren't bad as long as you knew how to do all the homework questions (which were put almost verbatim on the exams) Not very helpful but easy to get a B
No Comments

Super disorganized lectures and would commonly begin new example material 5 minutes before the end of class. A lot of and mastery quizzes, but they were nothing like the exam. Discussion material was more like the exam. Rude during office hours and sometimes not kind to ask questions to during/after lectures.

shes very nice and passionate but so disorganized. she has a bad habit of going back and forth and scribbling sm work on the slides. I stopped copying her notes down bc it only confused me and would look at her completed notes if i needed to refer to it while doing hw, even then i prob would just find a youtube video to explain.
It makes no sense to have a practice midterm with no answer key to check answers; this impedes learning. I still learned, it just took me hours longer, when I'm taking other classes as well.

Eliina is an unorganized professor. She skips slides and starts examples with 5 mintues left of class, usually went over class time The homework, mastery and reading quizzes were unhelpful for studying because they are much harder then what you need to know. Study dicussion worksheets and practice problems. Be prepared to teach yourself everything.

She is very nice, but all over the place when it comes to teaching. Her lectures are very hard to take notes on, especially on paper because she moves around the slides so much and writes everywhere. Although she does prep us well for midterms with practice problems, you learn a lot of the material on your own because the lectures are so sporadic.

Definitely the easiest and nicest choice for Physics. Shows great care for everyone, and around 60% of the grade is free with retakeable assignments/quizzes. Lectures do end up being a little cluttered, but honestly they aren't the biggest deal considering the practice questions were incredibly helpful for tests.

Probably the easiest physics class you can take. She really cares about her students and has an incredibly lenient grading system, but her lectures aren't very helpful and most of the learning for this class will be from discussion and homework.

Eliina's teaching material and explanation of what is on exams is very clear cut, so it's hard to be surprised when testing. However, she does jump around her slides and concepts a lot during lecture which can make her hard to follow. She obviously cares about her students and wants them to interact with each other to learn.

The professor is very nice and funny but the class is a little disorganized. There were 5 exams, one per 2 units and one question per unit. There's also a retake for each if you attend section. This means the final isn't cumulative and the exams are only half an hour each but they're every other week. It's a decent system but it needs some work.

Her lectures are unhelpful, I stopped attending lectures halfway through the quarter. Otherwise, tests are easy and just study off the learning outcomes to succeed. You can retake every test throughout the quarter. Unhelpful professor, but the grading style helps a lot.

Eliina is crazy and all over the place but she is very nice and its easy to pass. Roughly 50% of your grade is free points and the rest is in class quizzes with the oppurtunity to retake each one. Lectures always felt behind what we were using on assigments and I felt like I taught myself most of the material but still a pretty easy class.

All of the comments about the lectures are true. She is all over the place with her lectures and is so hard to follow. Her slides are super messy and can be difficult to comprehend. She also gets off topic ALL the time and makes no sense. This class made me feel like I had some learning disorder with the way she lectures. Take Amy Furniss!!

Very disjointed lectures that are not worth listening to. I started getting better scores in the exams (there are just 5 tests throughout the quarter but then not midterm/final) after i stopped going to lectures. The tests are pretty easy if you look at what topics are tested on the learning outcomes google sheet

she cant teach the fundamentals of physics, 5 "exercises" each worth 9%. there are retakes but the average of the last one was 18/50 lol! no answer key for regrades, gives barely any partial credit. i would avoid.

Eliinas lecturing style, not great. She is quite scattered and its challenging to follow her during class. On the other hand, her grading style will save you. She believes in second chances and you will have ample chances to make up for your grade. There are retakes for each midterm so passing the class is a breeze.

Here to offset all the good reviews. HORRIBLE teacher, scatter-brained, unprepared, and uncaring. Means on every test (5 a quarter) are 60% or lower, no answer keys for ANYTHING, discussion and office hours are useless. She jumps from topic to topic in lecture and posts other professor notes. If you want to learn any physics, take another teacher!!

Eliina got me to actually like physics! She jumps topics a lot during lectures which can get confusing, but other than that she's a great professor. Very enthusiastic and makes physics concepts easy to understand. She is super kind and understanding and also loves to show real-life applications of our learning to biology and Earth Science!

Extra credit for lecture attendance. Rambles in lecture, goes off topic/doesn't teach. 5 exams called "exercises" each 9% of your grade, mean below 60% on most. No answers keys for ANYTHING = use google and hope it's right = never confident going into exercises. Equation sheet is useless since she doesn't teach you how to use anything on it.

Eliina is a great person but this class is way too easy. If you can take the 6 series with her, take it for free As. The content is too simply taught and the exams are nowhere near hard enough for college physics. Both 6A and 6B were easier than AP physics. She has helpful and organized office hours, but I never studied more than 2 days for exams

not really worth going to lecture. really hard to follow bc shes literally all over the place. exams are ridiculously easy and exactly like the practice tests (only takes like 20-30 min to finish!). she says funny/random things and has this guy come in a lot for demos. easiest a+ of my life, but if you want to learn physics, don't take it with her.

Professor Sher is a wonderful lab professor. He's great at helping out when you're absolutely stuck in the experiment without giving away the answer. He's a tough grader but he adjusted the grading scale to ensure most people got B's/A's. The few lectures he gave were slightly sloppy, but he was always available to clear up any confusion.

Sasha is a much more fair instructor than most give him credit for. He knows the material super well and has interest in it. If you spend the time to read the textbook, go to lecture, attend discussion section/office hours, its more than possible to get an A in his class. Very fair grader and gives good curves.
a
