Hannah will be flexible as long as you communicate with her. This class has been one of my heavier courses at UCSC, but it's not unreasonable. There are two big papers, weekly quizzes, and a final exam; the exam and quizzes can be retaken as many times as you like. She does a good job explaining the concepts and is always available in office hours

Really appreciated her instruction style. She was kind to her students and gave countless accommodations and flexible deadlines for everyone. No final or midterm and just writing/projects and learning quizzes you can take as many times as you want. This was one of my favorite upper divisions' so far and I liked the subjects and material a lot.
doesn't respond to important emails on time on purpose

This class had an unrealistic amount of work :( if you have to take it make sure you have a schedule with space because this class takes a lot of time! 2 final papers that are tedious and TA's grade a little harsh. This had to be one of the most stressful classes I have had at UCSC because of all the work.

I love her as a person. Her stories & tangents are hilarious but her workload is undeniably too much. There are 2 final projects for this class including a giant paper and an expectation of a 30-minute recorded presentation with 50 slides (or 15-pg paper). Nothing really mattered in the course until the last week. Incredibly disorganized. STRESS.

Literally the best professor I think I've ever had. I was scared to take a cognitive psych class but this ended up being my favorite class because of professor Hausman. She explains things so well and is so passionate about this subject. She really is there to support you and structures learning in the most efficient way.

This professor sets very unrealistic standards for what is doable in a 10-week quarter. She assigns 2 final projects, along with weekly quizzes and reflections. She's very inflexible, and in my experience does not respond to emails in a timely manner. This is probably one of the more frustrating classes I've taken at UCSC.

I really want to give her a better score because I honestly love her. She is engaging and kind however poorly constructed this class. I have never been so overwhelm in my life. She has crazy exception of how much time we should be putting in and has given us to final projects both extremely time consuming and challenging.

Don't take this class, it's a full workload & doesn't leave you time for other classes. Has 2 final projects that separately would be enough for one class. She has unrealistic exceptions on students & believes each student should do 15 hours of work in her class per week. The weekly quizzes have unlimited attempts which is nice. I want to drop it.

Uninspiring lectures full of tangents, loves to hear himself talk. Assigns dense readings and expects you to know them despite often being confused himself. Don't take this course concurrent to other reading heavy courses because it will cause interference and mental fatigue. Grades like he is a journal you're submitting an article to. Frustrating.

To be successful you have to become his minion. Talks a lot about his connections and likes to flaunt his knowledge; goes off on emotionally charged outbursts and tangents; does not fear repercussions, because he has tenure. Likes to talk about Star Wars and compares power structures to “the Empire”, but acts like an officer would in such a regime.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Grades are based on 2 midterm and a final (section attendance as well)
Our first midterm class average was a 69 and seymour refused to curve it because "it's not a failing grade." News flash, it is. This is the first ever C I have received at UCSC and If I have him again, I might go into a psych ward. I'm serious.

I would rather be dragged by a semi truck for 100 miles on an unpaved road face down than ever take a class from this professor again. Only graded by 3 exams (all 30% of your grade), and lectures are almost entirely unrelated to test material. He failed more than half the class and refused to curve the grade at all. Truly the worse teacher at UCSC.

Professor is kind and clearly passionate about the subject, but severely overcomplicates course. Grade was made up of 3 tests (30% each) and 10% section attendance. Offers no guidance or helpful slides… for a learning and memory course. Unique circumstances caused 2/3 tests to be moved online, class would be impossible to pass if not. Do not take.

Awful professor genuinely so frustrated taking this class, definitely go to class (lecture specific info will be on the exam, and not in textbook). Textbook is the best way to learn concepts. Refuses to give extra resources, practice problems or exams, first exam this quarter class average was a 68% (prof didn't care and didn't see an issue)

I recently took my first exam, and many of the questions were definitely not as hard as people were saying. If you study using mind maps and go to his office hours, you will do great on the exams! The downside is that he doesn't explain what chapters will be on the test, and has only 3 tests and nothing else.

Nitpicks essays and often seems to misinterpret your work. Expectations are demanding yet unclear, and he remains unreceptive to feedback even as students struggle. Tangents derail lectures. Overall unpleasant—the only psych professor I've had a negative experience with at UCSC. Unless the subject is your true passion, protect your GPA.

Passionate but extremely tough grader. Only two midterms and a final determine your grade, all lecture-based. He goes on tangents, changes what's on the exam last minute, and refuses to curve or give study guides. For your GPA and sanity, avoid this class.

A charismatic guy, who is relatively captivating in lectures. BUT two midterms and a final were 90% of the grade. Tests are much harder than the lectures let on, book also sucked and he said himself he wants a different one. Class average on exams was a D and despite a very upset class, he refused to curve or give any study material/advise.

He's nice, but I agree w/ other people that he makes the class a bit harder than he should. He doesn't like to offer study guides or post answer keys but is test-heavy. He's almost never available for office hours, won't post lecture recordings, and his bar for an A and an A+ is higher than the default grading scale. He's very nice, though.

Dr. Seymour is a very approachable and caring professor. During the final I gave all I could before walking out with an incomplete exam. (Should've gone to more office hours.) He came outside to encourage me to try looking at the test one more time. Even though I was so embarrassed, his compassion and effort really stuck with me.

Travis is a cool guy and an average professor. You can tell that he really does love cognitive psych, as he tends to go on tangents during lecture and lose track of what he is doing. Nonetheless, the class itself is not made to be difficult, and Travis does a great job of keeping us on track in terms of homework and lectures.

Although this class was easy, Professor Seymour made it harder than necessary. He is a funny and kind professor, but he gets lost in lectures and tends to change his mind about the course frequently. The tests and homework were easy, but his opinions on psychology in general were controversial and almost concerning. He's fun and easy but confusing

Lectures were interesting enough, but you definitely need to go to class since his exams sometimes do consist of in-class examples. The rest are from the book, which is on Inquisitive--and is definitely not very engaging--especially seeing as how he doesn't talk about the book at all in class. He tends to go off topic sometimes. Lame dad jokes.

Professor Seymour was a nice and fun guy. You could keep retaking quizzes to get 100 on them, so you can get full points on them. Test heavy but 1/3 midterms get dropped. TA's were nice but it didn't seem like anybody wanted to be there. Tests were online and open note, just take notes in class and you'll probably be ok.

Prof Seymour is a very kind and personable guy but I would never take his class again. He had basic anatomy of the brain incorrect in his slideshow and did not notice. Also if you have DRC accommodations do not expect to get recorded lectures because he never posts them.

Travis Seymour is a very engaging lecturer. PSYC 20 is already covers interesting topics, but he elevates it. His Geon song is legendary and he tells very fun to listen to stories. Lectures were in person, but the tests were online and open book. He seemed to be experimenting with online tests, so that might not stay. I would definitely recommend.

Took this class during summer. Much easier than expected. If you did the work you got the grade. I don't think he graded too hard but then again I took the class during summer, maybe he was easier just for us?
DO NOT TAKE ANY CLASS WITH PROFESSOR SEYMOUR

He is very knowledgeable and answers questions well. He often ties material to current events, politics, and history. I went to every lecture even though half were optional because it was so interesting. He speaks clearly, but sometimes moves fast because of dense lectures.

Awesome prof, has great lectures and does lots of demonstrations. Also offers quite a bit of extra credit. 5 easy homework assignments and the final is non cumulative. Tests aren't bad as long as you make sure to study all the lecture slides ahead of time. Bryan is super caring and funny as well.

Although I don't really like cognitive psych, he had a lot of fun videos and examples during class which made it interesting. Tbh, I rarely went to lecture which I regret bc those in person were much more fun than the ones I watched online.

There's a reason everyone loves him, his lectures are great, his class is super interesting, and he doesn't assign a lot of busy work. The tests can be difficult, but he curves generously. Pop quizzes are all extra credit. Overall great guy and super fun class.

Funny and quirky professor, great lecturer. Lectures aren't mandatory but all material in exams are from lecture slides, plus he makes them very entertaining and interesting so highly recommend going anyway. Also easy surprise pop quizzes every once in a while are for extra credit points.
He is my goat. Super funny and caring. Would take him again!

I took this class in the winter, and I absolutely loved it! I went to every lecture, but they weren't mandatory. Attending Holbrook's classes is a fun and entertaining experience! There were labs that required a lot of work, but they were very interesting and enjoyable to complete. All exams were online, and we were given all day to complete them!

The professor's time management skills were awful, especially compared to other seminars. He only started working on Proposals in Week 8 and basically wasted time before. He brought up his personal issues in class, excusing his poor time management and inability to run the course effectively. By far, he is the WORST professor I have had at UCSC.

Holbrook is a wonderful professor! His lectures were some of the most informative and fun experiences I have ever had in a large-scale college class. His grading is clear and offers lots of chances to get your grade up (i.e. extra credit pop quizzes). Nothing is accepted late, but the workload doesn't feel overwhelming. Overall, HIGHLY recommend!

This professor is very chill and great! He's funny and his lectures are awesome, his sense of humor made my 1-hour commute from Hollister worth it. He's super knowledgeable and offers extra credit through pop quizzes, so attending is worth it. No phones allowed, he'll call you out! Homework is doable, and discussion section isn't mandatory.

Prof Holbrook is one of my favorite professors by far this quarter. Psych 20 was an absolute blast with him, not just because of my interest in the content, but also because he's a great professor, lecturer, and person. I super, super recommend Holbrook for any and all classes.

His class is relatively the same as his PSYCH20 except no attendance. His lectures are very informative and you should go to as many as you can. His quizzes and exams are all online. His homework is doable and interesting if you space the time needed for it. He's very knowledgeable about the subject and he likes to have fun, so learn and engage plz

One of the best professors I have ever had. Even though attendance is not mandatory, I would say go to his class because not only does he make lectures fun, but there is a of important information that he explains from the lecture slides. As long as you put in effort to make it to his class, you'll be fine.

Holbrook's lectures were so fun and engaging that even as a chronic skipper I wanted to attend class. Homework is easy and finals and midterm is all online. I would love to take one of his upper division classes one day.

Holbrook really knows how to be engaging and teach college students. He uses fun and interesting videos and visual simulations to teach core concepts in class. Lectures are recorded, but definitely go to class because it's worth it. Lectures are fun and can be really heavy with material sometimes. He will also call you out if you're on your phone!

Bryan was fun and engaging in class, having the class do some tasks that would help us understand the concepts that were being covered. Homework was due every other week and connected class concept to the real work which was really helpful. Only 2 exams, not cumulative, online, take when you can within the day it available. He don't like phones!

AWESOME PROFESSOR!!!! I have had Professor Holbrook for three different classes, and I am enrolled for one next quarter as well (that's how much I like his teaching style and classes). Online exams (weekly quizzes, one midterm, one final) and 3 Labs/Papers (fun to do). Attendance not mandatory, but still fun to go!
Dr Holbrook is kind and genuinely wants his students to understand the material and do well. I would absolutely take his class again

One of the best lecturers I've had at UCSC. Super engaging (even with topics that can get confusing/ complicated), fun, and always happy to answer questions. Lots of reading that you'll need for the mini essays + papers. Only 2 papers, and exams throughout the quarter, plus weekly (easy) quizzes. No homework. Highly recommend going to lectures!

This professor is amazing! His lectures are very fun and keep you engaged with the material. He does a lot of in-class demonstrations and examples, so I would attend the lectures if you can! However, I did find then when doing the exams, some of the information wasn't necessarily on the slides, but in the lectures.

I've taken Prof Rahal for both PSYC 109 and PSYC 100. Class content is interesting, however he has high expectations and can appear passive aggressive sometimes (especially through email). But overall he's a really good lecturer, is kind, and values student feedback a lot!

Dr, Rahal is an exceptionally knowledgable teacher, since the material in this class is literally what he researches. He is kind and explains things really well. Study the slides for tests and you should be fine. Going to office hours also helps; he is super approachable and cares a lot about your success. Material is also fun!

Prof. Rahal is AMAZING! His grading style, care for students, extra credit opportunities and homework assignments are a lot but worthwhile and they actually help. If you want a challenging but interesting class take this. Yes it has bio, but it is explained very well so don't stress :)

Ok, first, I could definitely tell he did NOT want to teach PSYC 100 back in Fall 2024, but he always represented information in a way that made sense to me. My issue with the class was that he assigns a lot of work, and on top of that, you need to take three exams. Plus, you need to complete assignments that took 5 hours.

Rahal is good at explaining concepts and happy to help clarify if there's any confusion. He's communication needs help, he sounds passive aggressive in emails (and he knows it but wont change), and wasn't clear when he wanted students repones or it a question was rhetorical. Also doesn't care about mess-ups in the research project process at all.

I had Dr. Rahal for both PSYC 100 and PSYC 109. His lectures are well organized, and you can tell that he is really knowledgeable and passionate about what he teaches. As long as you pay attention to what he says to study, you'll be fine :) He makes it very clear what to expect for his exams

Ok lecturer. Content was interesting & enjoyable, I just think he came off rude to students. I asked for clarification on why I missed a few points and he basically said do better.. which was annoying bc I just wanted feedback & wasn't trying to change the grade. Someone cried one time like wdym. He's fine but never ask questions lmao

He's chill and caring, even checked on me after a bad midterm. Exams are challenging but multiple choice, study and you'll be fine. Class depends a lot on your TA. Mine wasn't great, so the long project and grading were tough. Discussions are mandatory. He can be a bit sassy lol. He also asks for feedback, he cares about the structure of hisclass

Professor Rahal is such a knowledgeable person, and you can tell he is really passionate about the stuff he's lecturing about. Looked forward to attending lectures, fascinating content.  Heavy reading and challenging exams. Attend class and participate!

Probably one of the best professors I've had at UCSC. If you're willing to put in the work and effort this class will be easy. Course material is super interesting and the professor is really approachable. Can be blunt and direct sometimes personality wise but asks for feedback often and always is willing to improve and help students when needed.

Dr. Rahal was truly an amazing professor. His exams are pretty application heavy, so you need to understand more than just the definition of terms. However, I don't think I've learned more from a psychology course than from his class. The topics are interesting, Rahal is very knowledgeable, and he is very inspiring if you are interested in research

Psych 100 is a challenging 7-unit course,but Dr. Rahal explains research concepts in a digestible way. Please don't let the poor reviews stop you from taking this class;I think he's direct when students repeatedly don't listen. But he genuinely wants his students to succeed; none of my other classes offered a feedback form after every midterm, etc.

He's a fantastic lecturer, engaging,passionate,humble,&interested in student feedback.He creates an interactive/comfortable environment,making it easy to participate.The material is fascinating, not necessarily easy,but a doable challenge.I especially recommend, if you're interested in the mind-body connection! Get ready to interpret graphs.

Dr. Rahal is a great professor who cares about the success of his students. Lots of extra credit is provided and exam prep material is very thorough. As long as you pay attention to the lectures and ask questions when you need help there's no reason why you shouldn't succeed in this class. Exams are non cumulative and material is interesting!

Pls don't let the rest of the reviews discourage you. Material is fairly easy to understand, and the prof/TAs are very accessible to ask questions to. There is so much extra credit opportunities. 2 midterms, 1 final (non cumulative.) Exams are straight from the lecture slides, sometimes wording can be tricky. Interesting topics, I highly recommend.

Dr. Rahal is great. The class isn't gonna be an easy A but if you put in the effort it's going to go well. I truly don't care about the subject at all but his enthusiasm is infectious so it made me care. He seems genuinely invested in my learning outcome and making the class better. Great TAs too. I hope to take more classes w him in the future!

Prof Rahal was rly rude. lot of groups in my section had issues, he was very unhelpful with them. had a group completely change their measures after they had alr done the research. could've been avoided by having clearer instructions. tests were not hard but were confusing. mean avg was low. better to read the txtbook then go to lectures.

The class is a difficult one because there is a lot of material to cover in a short amount of time. The professor did a good job covering a lot of material, however, some of the concepts could have been explained better. Definitely attend section and office hours to make the best of this class and study at least 2 weeks in advance of exams!!

The class is designed to be difficult, especially the writing portion. Rahal is a good teacher, his explanations are easy to understand and his examples are very helpful. This class had a final paper, presentation, and exam along with multiple papers throughout the quarter and two midterms. Be prepared to work a lot. Not much I can say on Rahal.

Dr Rahal is a smart professor who's passionate about research. The class isn't simple or easy, but if you keep up with the work and study you'll be fine. Lectures are super helpful and make sure to focus on the vocab terms and examples.

Professor Hwang is one of my favorite professors at UCSC. She is a very good lecturer and keeps the class engaged. There are 3 exams and one major project that is worked on throughout the quarter. Each lecture has a "quiz", so keep that in mind, but graded on completion. Pay attention in lecture and you will pass the class.

Attendence taken by questions during lecture. You need to read the textbook and listen to lectures to ace the 2 exams. There is also a research paper you slowly work on throught the quarter, decent rubric to follow and help (i did PSY 100 before this class!). Decent communication on class changes or student hour chnages.

Super sweet but very strict about AI and academic honesty. Mandatory 8 am attendance, though she excused absences with medical proof. Class is interesting, but learning depends on your effort since exams are fully open-book/notes and online. It kinda seems like the only rule of the class is to show up and not use AI. Easy A for an upper division.

Dr. Cardilla is a fantastic professor. She gives you all the tools you need to be successful in this class and is extremely knowledgeable and kind. She is extremely serious about academic integrity, but quite literally shows you everything step by step and all quizzes/homework/exams are open note & book, with one week to complete every assignment.

If you're someone for whom math doesn't really click in your brain like me, CARDILLA IS YOUR SAVING GRACE. Her lectures are so easy to follow; she goes through every single step and explains why she's doing them, no matter how long you've been learning the content. The only downside is that the lecture is at 8 am and mandatory. But, WORTH IT!

Prof Cardilla is so nice, she genuinely cares about her students and wants them to succeed and also understand the material. She is willing to help you as well as the TA's. I would definitely utilize the teaching team and office hours. The lecture practice material prepares you for exams and homework. You can use anything from the class on tests/hw

Took her senior seminar as well as this class. Super fun and incredibly caring. Literally just do not cheat or use AI, the class is already good enough to pass with the lectures. Best professor I have ever had.

Professor Cardilla is one of the GOAT psychology professors at UCSC. Her lectures are straightforward from start to finish especially if you are not a stats person. Her exams and her grading policies are fair. 10/10 recommend everyone to take PSYC 181 since data analysis is practical to understanding the real world.

One of my favorite professors I've taken here. She gives you everything you need to succeed in the course, and she is (fairly) extremely strict regarding the use of AI or any other resources out of class. Follow the LPM and attend class, then you're all set. She makes stats seem easy!

Prof. Cardilla is super friendly and caring! She made stats concepts easy to understand and conceptualize, tying in lots of real-world examples that made class interesting. Very clear and stern about not cheating on assignments, which is obviously fair! She gives you all the time and resources you need to get an A, just take notes and utilize LPMs.
She's my queen I love her. So funny. The class itself is insanely easy if you've already taken a stats class but I still like going bc she's great
Just scroll down to all the positive reviews, everything is already been said. Amazing professor and really does care about the students' time, you just have to communicate.

Amazing professor who cares about you, your grade, and the content she lectures. It was an amazing class to have as an 8am as all slides are uploaded before class so it is low stress. Great story teller and is often connecting content to her personal life or asking for students' experience. Very engaging. The readings help but not needed.

Genuinely love Kim. She's a professor worth taking an 8am for, so kind and actually funny. Material is super interesting too. Grade consists of 4 things- 1 paper, 2 exams, and attendance. Tests are online, open note/book and everyone gets 6 hours. Do not expect any free extensions from her tho.

Need I say more? Kim is awesome. This class's subject matter is difficult but she makes it approachable. Required readings every week (that can pile up if you don't read them!), 2 papers and 2 exams. Tests are online + open note which is great and papers aren't too bad. I would absolutely recommend.

Professor Cardilla is an amazing teacher who makes the material engaging and easy to understand. The open-note tests and assignments, along with Unstuckstudy, made this class a breeze. Highly recommend taking it with her!
Super easy class and she cares. Answers all questions with no judgement and work was easy.

sooooo easy. she responds to emails quickly and is extremely helpful. just do the LPM and all hws and tests (open note) are identical. students got caught using ai for assignments which is just ridiculous and pathetic. an A is practically handed to you if you just do the work (only takes ~1hr/week). her upbeat attitude was admirable for an 8am

Professor Cardilla is clearly knowledgeable, but the pressure on grades impacted my feelings about the class. The heavy load of info and homework made me not like this class, when I love this subject. Almost anything and everything covered could be in exams, so it's hard to study. Just to keep in mind if you're looking to take this class with her.
Kim is an amazing professor & Psych 115 is a great foundational course for anyone interested in clinical work.

Cardilla is everything a professor should be. Smart, caring, but informative as well. If I had to write anything negative, she sometimes can make easy topics seem confusing by over explaining (we spent two whole lectures on mean, median, and mode). But that over explaining helps when it comes to difficult topics. I highly recommend her!
Kim is the best professor I've had at UCSC. She's super funny, kind, and is great at what she does. She is very clear about what is expected, and all the tests are open note and straightforward.

This class is not for the faint of heart! There is a paper (2-3 pages) due every week of the quarter and the professor does not give letter grades; they give written evaluations like "not satisfactory" (which translate to an F) and so on. Despite this, the content is amazing and she has a great perspective on cultural community in psychology.

This professor is boring, you waste most of your time in class watching her try to figure out how to use the monitor, and she gives feedback that says nothing else but "look deeper." Her lectures are boring and not insightful. She also has her own books as the class text (does not provide them makes u pay $). makes you think. I learned more from TA

Professor Rogoff shows that she cares about her students more than other professors. This being said, her class is tough and in order to receive an A most people will need to meet with her to  help with the weekly papers. I took 2 classes with her and lectures are a bit slow but really interesting.

Weekly chapter papers made the class very work heavy. Although Rogoff is knowledgeable, she primarily focused on Guatemalan-Mayan development compared to other cultures rather than delivering a well-rounded understanding of multiple cultures. I would recommend selecting an alternative course.

Trying my best to get a C but turns out it more difficult than I could think of, her opinion on the essay doesn't really help out. Even the TA might did better job of guiding. Do NOT take her courses, avoid at all cost!

While what and how she teaches is interesting, assignments are graded holistically; which in of itself isn't horrible but feedback can be vague and unhelpful, and in a setting where everything is graded for some people it might be more detrimental than anything. It's hard knowing what to improve essay-by-essay.

The class concepts were interesting. The prof is very knowledgeable and can communicate the concepts effectively. There were 8 essays (one each week starting from week 2 & ending at week 10). Qualitative grading scale, no number grades. Lots of feedback of essays. Changes your way of thinking about cultures and cultural processes. I recommend.

She is a very nice lady and is super knowledgeable about cultural development. She makes class engaging although it does not help with assignments very much. Her weekly essays are graded harshly with her alternative grade scale without letters. You will not know the final grade until you complete the class. I learned a lot, but hated the structure

Horrible professor. No one learned anything and she was overall boring to listen to and unclear abt what to study for tests. Her learning objectives are helping absolutely NO ONE pass. Shes not understanding of extenuating circumstances and often assigns reflection papers on the same day as other important assignments. Dont take this class!

Paper-based class (2pgs double spaced mostly). No exams or other assignments. One (2min) group pres in section. Gives written evaluations (no letter grade but tells you HOW to improve and honors it). Very wise lady w/Harvard ed. 30+yrs of experience in field. Learn about OTHER cultures & make travel more interesting, broaden your world perspective

This class was extremely disappointing. We were told to buy three books when we only used one (two of which were authored by Rogoff). You have to write short essays (chapter critiques) every week, which are graded confusingly with unhelpful feedback. Go see the TAs for help on essays, otherwise its impossible to know what they want.

Please take this class if you would like to ruin your GPA, please take this class if you would like to receive meaningless feedback and please definitely take this class if you would like to waste your time!!

An essay due every week, with 2 of those being longer reports. But more importantly, I ADORE Prof Rogoff. I learned many new ideas and concepts through the readings & her lectures. It is the first class I've taken that I genuinely cared more about the material than the grade. Feedback is given on each of your essays to consider for the next. 10/10!

So Rogoff isn't amazing but the class is fairly easy-just an essay a week. The only thing i didn't understand was the grading criteria for the essays which was a bit confusing. Classes felt a bit pointless though. No final exam!

If you have any amount of intelligence or proficiency in writing, do NOT take this class. Structured like a mediocre middle school cultural club, you will turn in a 2 page paper every week and be graded like you are in 7th grade, diminished and disrespected for being a better writer than her.

She's a good professor. Passionate about her research. Open to hearing different opinions. Encourages others to challenge her work. No test, not even a final. 2-page essays every week on interesting topics. Easy grader.

There's quite a bit of reading every week and they are essential for the essays. Although, you can get away with just scanning the main ideas. Go to office hours and ask for help if you need it. Rogoff is a really helpful and caring professor and just wants her students to succeed. Great class overall. I didn't expect it to be so insightful.

there's lots of reading so just make sure to keep up. Essays are assigned every week although they are only 1-2 pages and aren't that bad as long as you figure out how she wants you to structure them. overall the class isn't to hard.

Professor Rogoff is one of the most inspirational and passionate teachers that I have ever had. I am so grateful to have taken her class. She  challenges her students way of thinking, specially how one tends to think ethnocentrically and judge other cultures based on one's own cultural experience or upbringing. Overall, Rogoff is an amazing teacher

Rogoff's lecture style was dull and slow. Obsessed with the idea of avoiding ethnocentrism but believed her way of thinking was the only right way. Texts she assigned were written by her. Go against her ideas in papers and you fail but agree with them and you'll pass. No tests only papers that were about extending ideas of your own based on book

I had Kylie for my senior seminar, and I could not recommend her enough. She is the sweetest and most caring professor ever, and she made every lecture interactive. The workload was manageable, and she was always willing to help. So kind and super passionate! Definitely my favorite course I have ever taken, and a great way to end my time at UCSC!!!

Loved this class so much! It really helped me understand the details of the education system and Kylie always made lectures so fun and easy to participate in! She is also available outside of class to provide feedback, answer questions, chat, and so much more!
She cares about you take her. You will pass the class
Smart, hardworking, and attentive, Materials are organized, Comes up with original, clever concepts, very professional

Made me feel actually cared for and you can tell that she actually cares about the success of students. There is lots of reading throughout the quarter and if you miss one you might be confused later on. There is not much graded hroughout the quarter, but participate and do your best and youll pass.

I enjoyed taking Ed 60 with Prof. Kenner. We were graded off three short papers, a midterm, and a final. If you came to lectures none of the work was hard. There is assigned reading, but most of the material is covered in class. She held review sessions to go over all the key topics that were on each exam. You can tell she cares about her students.

This class was easy, interesting, and very doable. She assigns a few readings, but other than that, no weekly homework. If you don't want to go to class, at least go through the slides and go to section, you will pass. Prof. Kenner is super sweet and understanding, the only thing is her lectures can be a bit drawn out.

Love her. She will take the time to learn the entire lecture hall by name. Her class is super easy, she goes over the readings in class most of the time, so if you don't have enough time to get to them beforehand, you won't be left completely in the dark.

This class was really easy and can be passed without going to lecture, but I still recommend going because she really cares for her students! There are 2 exams throughout the quarter that are take-home (online open for about 3 hours). Her lectures are interesting, so you should go if you're genuinely interested in education.
Took her class during Fall 22, loved it!

Professor Kenner was very kind and you could tell she really cared about our success. There are two readings or podcasts assigned weekly that can be very long but it is interesting. She gives no assignments so the only things in the grade book are the midterm, final, final review paper, and maybe some extra credit. Do the readings for an A.

If you do the two readings a week and pay attention in class you will get an A. If you just go to class and study before finals prolly get a B. She is nice and cares about the material. I would recommend if you're willing to put in 5 hours a week to take EDUC60, its mostly memorization based. I followed my above advice and got an A+.

Very discussion heavy even in lectures. Lots of readings to do but other than that not much work (even the readings most of it isnt necessary to get a good grade in the class) test was somewhat difficult but overall the class wasnt too stressful. Shes good at speaking and explaining and does a good job of connecting with the class

She is very nice just a bit boring. She tries to learn all her students names and is passionate about what she teaches but she makes her class seem way more difficult than it is. She draws things out that could have been explained way faster and simpler than how she does

Lecture 3/w. Assignments tedious & redundant. Felt like there was no time to really process or digest readings. Feedback was sparse & unhelpful. You won't know grades for the entirety of the course. All my writing was good, but I was ultimately marked off because I have social anxiety and struggle with presentations. Absolutely would not recommend.
Kylie was a super nice teacher. I took STEV 26 over summer 2020 and it was a nice, 2-cred class. Not hard if you do the homework and participate.
You never know what' she grading ideology. Tutors can help you to deal with any other professor but not her! Never take her course for GE.

Not a tough grader but also never explained how we were graded/how grades were weighted. Super easy class. She is fun to listen to and doesnt lecture too long. Very organized and to-the-point. When reading, chapters are longer than you think, but the class is not super reading-heavy. Not many tests

Very nice professor and easy-going. Few assignments and fairly easy focused on transitioning to a research university. There were plently of guest speakers to introduce on campus resources to students.
Decently easy class. Pretty boring but it's required so..... just show up and do the work and you will get an A.

i loved his lectures, he used real life examples to explain stuff on the slides. his TAs respond really fast, and the prof is nice and smart. he doesn't remind about SONA hours so remember those. i would definitely retake his class again
All midterms and the final are online. It's basically based exactly on the lecture slides, and they're open notes.

Awesome class. His lectures are basically going over the readings the whole time, so if you do the readings, you don't have to go to the lecture unless you want to. The paper at the end is a little stressful, but doable. One of a kind class, considering my other friends who had Psych 1 with other professors struggled immensely.

This is the only class I actually look forward to! Lectures are mostly just reading off slides, but he still makes them interesting and engaging. The homework (usually 1 online activity per class) is pretty easy, and all of the material on the tests had been covered in lectures. Use of the textbook is basically optional.

I loved every lecture I attended, he made learning a subject I already found interest in even more enjoyable. I would love to take a class with him again and even though the lectures aren't mandatory, I found myself trying to make it to every one.

This is a class where you can easily pass without putting too much effort into it, but if you want to learn, you'll also get a lot out of it. The lectures are really interesting and he posts all his slides, which you can use on the open note tests and easily get pretty good scores. Attendance isn't mandatory as it's a giant lecture-style class.

Professor Yamashiro is an amazing lecturer and is able to clearly explain concepts while still making the content interesting. All of the tests are online as well as open note but the homework can be somewhat time consuming. Section is not mandatory and there are plenty of extra credit opportunities offered throughout the quarter.

His lectures are very entertaining and easy to follow. However, multiple things (inquizatives and zaps labs) are due after each lecture (ranging from 2 to 5 assignments). The assignments are not hard but time-consuming. You can expect to learn a lot. Exams are all online and open notes. Nothing on the exams will be hard as long as you take notes!

I've taken Prof Yamashiro twice and both times have been awesome. He doesn't complicate his class and makes it so that you-- as the student-- will succeed and end up with a good grade. He's very bright and intelligent and knows what he's talking about, also he has a great sense of humor. If you can, take him for as many psych classes as possible.
Highly recommend Jeremy if you need to take PSYCH1. Was super fun and easy and at least for me the midterm and final were online. Jeremy is also a very engaging lecturer.

definitely take this class ! the professor honestly really wants you to succeed/will make it very easy for you to do well. I am not very interested in this area of psych but he is a great lecturer and offers optional sections!

I would definitely recommend taking a class with Jeremy. This has been my easiest psyc class, but the most I have ever learned in a class. I understood the material because he is so clear. Weekly quizzes (unlimited attempts) and then the midterm and final are mostly questions seen on those quizzes. No surprises in this class. Quality learning.

Professor Yamashiro is an extremely intelligent academic, and his course was one of my favorites! Make sure you fully complete all the necessary readings because the bulk of the course is dependent on them.

Yamashiro's lectures were a bit dull and slow but informative. The information learned is quite interesting and fun. Students use an online quiz format for weekly homework which is really easy but gets you to learn the material. Grading is really easy and tests are too.
Jeremy is an amazing professor who truly wants his students to understand memory systems and narrative frameworks. Loved this class!
Pretty easy class and super chill! not a lot of homework and all the tests were online!

He is a great professor, and very lenient. The class overall was very easy, all our tests were take home and our final was a short 2-page research paper. Attendance is not mandatory, and we barely had any homework. The textbook and homework were all online.
Entertaining and engaging lecturer but not necessary for homework or tests. Tests are online and come almost entirely from the homework readings

easiest class i've ever taken! attendance is very much not mandatory, you could probably get away with going to a few lectures and still get an A. homework before almost every class, but it's pretty easy and all the answers are in the textbook. take this class even if you're not a psych major, i found a lot of material interesting!!

Jeremy is a dilf! At first I didn't like him because I had to pay $70 for a textbook but I forgive him bc I really enjoyed learning through the book. This class is very simple and easy to understand. I love the website we used for our weekly assignments bc it reminded me of a website I would use in middle school lol. Would recommend!

2 midterms and 1 final. The content is really interesting, he goes over most of it in the lecture. Still some notes from the textbook, but overall, explained everything in the recorded lectures. The textbook is long and unengaging, so use TA's kahoots and review lectures to study, and you'll be fine. Class was on a curve.

He's really chill, his lectures are pretty clear and he explains topics well. 2 midterms, 1 final, and weekly quizzes are online, open note, and lectures are recorded. Lots of biology in this class so a little confusing and detailed but like - it's online tests. Textbook seemed relatively irrelevant.

Professor Samaha is a great lecturer. He assures everyone in terms of the class content by answering the students' concerns and questions. The content is difficult since some of the concepts delve into the neurological/physiological processes of the human brain. In addition, his tests are open-book and online.

Good lecturer and makes content interest my god are his exams sadistic. That man destroyed me with his exam. BE PREPARED. It isn't good enough to understand the general concepts, you need to know the nitty-gritty stuff, especially from the book. Good luck soldier.

I took Prof. Samaha's Consciousness seminar, which had fascinating papers. The main grade revolved around a final ~9 page paper which was very open-ended and just asked you to incorporate the dense readings. The density of them made class awkward sometimes, as he would wait for us to answer questions instead of discussing in groups. Good class tho.

Jason Samaha's lectures were pretty hit or miss for me. I didn't find them very engaging, but cognitive psychology is pretty interesting. As long as you do your assignments you'll be fine. The tests are difficult and you should read the textbook(I didn't) - the questions are applying the information you learn rather than things you can pinpoint.

While lectures are interesting and engaging, the main issue is how that information is tested in exams. Exams put an emphasis on little details in the readings and insignificant bits of information rather than the important main ideas and greater themes in class. Okay class, but it's the biggest issue so far. Be PREPARED for tests.

Professor Samaha is easily the best. His exams are curved in a way that can only help you. There are weekly, no stakes quizzes you can take as many times. He is very understanding and compassionate. His lectures are interesting and engaging. I even had friends attend my lectures and they found the class interesting. I would 100% recommend him.

Professor Samaha is a funny, chill guy who is very accommodating. All his lecture slides were posted on canvas, and he records all the lectures and posts them on Yuja. He has weekly quizzes you can take as many times as you need, and there are two tests and a group paper. You need to study pretty hard for the tests, but I love this class!

You really need to study for his exams or else you won't do well in this class. He has an awesome personality and really cares about the students but your entire grade is based on a few exams and a group paper. It's difficult at times, but really good lectures and chill person.

Professor Samaha is one of the best professors I've had! He was so understanding during covid and allowed us the option to remain remote when everything went back to in person. Tests are a bit hard but if you take really good notes & study you should be okay. 3 tests & a group paper. Would definitely take him again!

Jason is a super good prof, and his lectures are rlly good and engaging, even online. The tests are multiple-choice but do def still require studying, as your entire grade is based on 3-4 things. Overall highly recommend but be careful you don't fall behind

the lectures were very well formatted and easy to understand. he gives quizzes for each couple of lectures and they're pretty easy assuming that you listened to lectures and took notes. even though cog psych is a difficult subject, jason did a really good job setting a clear foundation for his students and definitely made me less afraid of it.

Prof Samaha is by far the best psych professor Ive had at UCSC! (& Im a 3rd yr). Lectures are very thorough, and he moves through the material at just the right speed for understanding. The tests are open note/open book, & there is no homework aside from weekly quizzes, on which we get unlimited attempts. Also very nice, and helpful & respectful!

For this class, the lectures were uploaded on Yuja, and you had to watch them in order to count as attendance. The exams are based on lectures and readings. The TA's were very accessible and understanding and the professor also cared for his students. You just have to stay consistent with the readings and lectures to not fall behind!

He's obviously incredibly smart and very passionate about this subject matter, but this class was way harder than it should be. The way he designs the lectures is really difficult to follow along with and understand, especially if you're a visual learner. Tests are always 98% small details from the textbook. and rarely information from lecture.

The thing is, cognitive neuroscience *in general* is not an easy subject. It is VERY challenging to study and understand NO MATTER the teacher. You gotta sit down and just study. I have immense respect for Jason because of his attention to detail. If you wanna pursue a career in this field TAKE THIS CLASS. It'll help you in the long run!

I've had professor Samaha twice now and I absolutely loved both classes with him. With this class being online he's made lecture and exam schedules flexible enough that I don't have to stress about about failing his class because of my apartment's bad wifi. He treats his students like actually human beings and it shows compared to most stem profs.

Don't recommend taking him online, but I liked him as a professor! This was my second time taking a course with him, and I definitely felt like the online aspect impaired the experience. His tests (three total) were HARD, but he dropped the lowest grade. He had weekly quizzes that were basically free points as long as you did them.

The exams were the majority of the grade (35 percent EACH) and they were SO HARD.... Everyone I spoke to was struggling. It's not even the content that is hard. The course content was easy to understand and interesting. It's the way he words his questions on his exams. They are intentionally misleading and confusing. Why do you want us to fail??

Took F24. I was stressed during the class because of the exams that I didn't do well on (I didn't study enough), but she has a lot of assignments that cushions your grade. There's 2 papers that she splits up into different parts (rough draft, peer grading, etc), that counts for points. Clear rubric, and the concepts were interesting.

I love the way she lectures because it makes learning easy. Her lectures are pretty light and super easy to follow. She also drops a couple of your lowest quizzes and participation assignments. Exams are almost identical to quizzes just longer and the questions are super easy if you're paying attention during lecture.

Liv is an amazing lecturer and an amazing person. I really enjoyed this class even though I don't want to go into linguistics at all. This was a tough course in the sense that it challenged my thinking, but the grading wasn't necessarily hard. The only hard part for me was mandatory attendance. The grading made sense.
Attendance assignments, so come to class or know someone who's in there. Content and homework is very easy. Not the most inspiring lecturer I've had but she's good quality.

If you follow the structure of the class and the follow her instructions and keep up with the work you shouldn't have a hard time. I really enjoyed her lectures and liked how structured her class was.

This was class was tough even though I received an A I worked hard and made this class my #1 priority. The midterms and finals were tough it had everything from lecture and the readings. Also section does NOT go over lecture if anything you are working on a debate. Lectures are recorded which made it easy to study.

Never makes study guides and then gets confused when all the students fail the tests. Tough grader, lectures are walls of text on the screen. You have to kinda teach yourself. Not a great teacher in general, provides little and vague information and expects students to be a master of the concept.

The lectures were good but a few of the assignments were confusing and she did not do much to help understand.The tests were unnecessarily complicated for the time given and after the whole class told her that, she did not care.I did well with TAs grading me but she is the one that brought me down. Such a harsh grader for such simple concepts.

Prof. Boudewyn's lectures are very dense, so make sure to pay attention and take notes that will be a good reference later! Exams are a huge part of the grade, and midterm 2 is the hardest by a mile, but she's very generous with extra credit and curving. She's also incredibly helpful during office hours. I learned alot! You will too.

Honestly I love this diva. Yes, the class is lowkey difficult because it's neuroscience and there's a lot of content but she's extremely smart. Does talk fast so be prepared to take notes and pay attention to what she's actually saying. Gives a major curve at the end of the course which is so helpful.

Megan was a great professor in my opinion! She did a great job explaining hard-to-read concepts in lectures, and it was super beneficial for me to attend class, which I don't normally say. The midterms and finals were relatively easy, and she has a generous end-of-term curve. I can see psyc125 being a very challenging class, but she did a great job

Professor Boudewyn is a great lecturer, especially in a class that delves into many theories. She does talk a bit fast from time to time. However, your grade will not be finalized until the curve is applied. Her exams are not the easiest. Therefore, everyone taking PSYC 125 should go to lecture, read the textbook, and form a study group.

She curves the final cumulative grade, but you will be stressed until then. Two midterms, 50 multiple choice, and a final. She gives study guides, but my best advice is to read, not skim, the textbook. Its a lot of reading but will help you do better on the tests. She speaks super fast, so I would commonly rewatch lectures.

You will FOR SURE pass the class, there is a very generous curve. However, the nature of cognitive neuroscience can be difficult. For exams you really need to know your stuff. Read the textbook, ask questions and pay attention in lecture.

The final grade is determined by a curve, which means that the class was difficult but virtually impossible to fail: don't give up! The lectures were good and used real data. She talks fast, though. The book mirrored lectures. The exams were hard and frequent (weeks 3, 5, and 10). Study anatomical terms to keep up/understand everything. Good luck!

This class was harder than some upper-div CS classes I've taken. The class is so exam heavy and with a vague study guide, no practice questions, or useful information from lecture, you have to study everything from the textbooks. The content is so dense, it makes it impossible to memorize and my 20+ hours of studying per exam barely helped me.
Prof. Boudewyn is the BEST ever! I loved taking her class, be prepared to study though, the exams aren't too difficult if you go to class & study. I'd recommend taking her class, you learn so much.

Definitely the hardest psych classes I've taken (I'm senior standing). I learned so much and I really got a good challenge before I graduated however this class was unnecessarily stressful in my opinion. The professor doesn't give study guides, and exams are tough. Tutoring was also not provided. My class felt a little bit like a guinea pig quarter

This is probably the hardest psychology class I've taken so far, but compared to STEM classes it wasn't too difficult. Professor Boudewyn is a passionate and caring teacher who is an expert in the field. Tests were all multiple choice and fairly easy with a big curve. Lectures are a little boring but it's worth it to show up to all of them.

Specifically if you're wondering whether you should take 147b: Classes were 3hr, but we DID get to go visit prison, which was amazing. We read like 6(?) books within 10 weeks, which was crazy, so it really did drain a lot of my time. Don't take if you have a heavy course load, but was so interesting and once in a lifetime chance. Office hours help!

He's a gem. Class breakdown is 25% paper 1, 25% midterm, 25% paper 2, 25% final. Shares stories from his experience working with incarcerated people and the legal system. Exams weren't too bad and the papers weren't graded too harshly. Lots of reading though.

only two essays and two tests (midterm / final) each worth 25% of grade, and attendance mandatory. He's very passionate and experienced, but occasionally long winded, esp in his book - there's a lot of reading. Doesn't allow any tech in class, but posts notes about the class and can just study off them. also he did the stanford prison experiment.

I strongly urge anyone who has any interest in the legal system, or those who don't, to take this course. The information in the course is incredibly valuable and I feel so lucky to have been taught by Haney. He is an expert in the topic and has been involved with the material first hand. This class is amazing even though it is reading-heavy.

if you have any DRC accommodations for notetaking, just know that this professor will not accommodate them! He does this every quarter and advisers can't even help because he flat out refuses to listen or find a middle ground. He does post class notes at the end of the week, but this does not support some students' specific notetaking needs. BEWARE

Dr. Haney is great. Lectures can be a bit monotonous but the lecture material is so incredibly profound. The case studies he introduces still stick with me today and I imagine they will for a very long time. The 2 essays were leniently graded and 2 tests were very tough but I did okay on them. Lots of reading that I didn't do but I still got by!

Genuinely the best Professor I've had at UCSC. This class completely rewired my way of thinking about the prisons and criminal justice system. He is such an intelligent person and has done so much good for the community. I'd never been so invested and eager to learn in a class until I took 147A and B. I would recommend this class to anyone.

amazing, passionate, dedicated, inspiring. Dr. Haney is easily one of the best professors. loads of reading but no one actually does it all, but u can tell he is really committed and yes, he can be repetitive sometimes, but it's bc he's meticulous at his job. Not sure how he got bad reviews, 99 out of 100 people love him, and I def recommend.

His vendetta against technology (writing only for notes) and lack of utilization of canvas highlights his archaic style of teaching. His class essentially covers how socioeconomic status and race can impact the criminal justice system. I can understand why some individuals love him, but I was not one of those people. Also, lots of reading.

Easily one of the best Prof. I've had. Im in law school now and constantly refer back to the notes I took in this class! This class preapred me for law school and his content was engaging and inspirational! Take this class if you can!

The class is an easy A. That being said if you know anything about how crime effects lower socioeconomic communities then this class is beyond redundant. His book, "Criminality in context." He actually repeats the same ideas for 11 chapters. The entire book could be edited down to two at the most. He says a lot without really saying anything.

PSYC-147A was a powerful, eye-opening experience for me. PSYC-147A included engaging examples, highly impactful material, and Haney's commitment to social justice issues was evident. You will not regret enrolling, but you might regret not having enrolled sooner :)

I took both of his classes (Psych 147 A & B) and he definitely changed my perspective on many things using real evidence and first person accounts. He is logical, intelligent, and most importantly passionate. :) Definitely take his class!

Professor Haney is a great teacher who is passionate about his subject. However, his course has mass amounts of reading in a short period of time. In fact, it is nearly impossible to complete all the readings while being able to digest the material. Everyone falls behind. Lectures are important. Your grade is based on two tests and two papers.

Craig Haney is a great lecturer that even though you are required to take notes by hand I was able to keep up and stay engaged. The class is graded on a midterm test and a final with a coinciding essay due about a week before each. If you're at all interested in how our legal system functions and how it intersects with psyc I recommend this course.

Prof. Haney is one of the best professors I've ever had. He has a clear passion for teaching this subject, and it reflects heavily in lectures. He values learning the ideas and viewpoints more than little bits of knowledge as that's what's more important to him. While there's a lot of reading, this class is really worth it.

Prof Craig Haney is very inspiring and clearly conveys his passion and vast knowledge of the subject material. He is by far the best professor I've taken at UCSC. Lots of reading, and be prepared to take a lot of notes on lectures. Loved this class and would definitely recommend.

Also, he is very responsive and cares about all of his students

Professor Haney is an informational lecturer that doesn't fail to make class exciting. I was able to pass this class with a 93% without attending lectures, joining sections, and reading the book. Our final grade consists of two tests (1 midterm, 1 final) and two essays (5 pages max). Readings and test content are discussed in lecture.

Craig is an amazing professor and super inspirational. This class had 2 papers, and 2 tests each worth 25% of the grade, and there is a ton of reading, so be ready for lots of work. Took it online and he does not record lectures, so you need to attend. Also does not provide study guides so have good notes and pay attention. One of the best classes!

I took this class on zoom this quarter, and he is a very engaging professor, you can tell he cares about the subject. The class has 2 tests, and 2 papers that make up the entire grade. The tests are not too hard, the midterm was all true/false. The papers also are easy, he gives 5 different prompts to pick from. He also is very understanding.

CRAZY amounts of homework at first but then it slowed down halfway. Her classwork/homework instructions and grading is vague but I'd say it's easier than being given an exam 100%. Grading kinda depends on who you have as a TA. Courtney honestly was pretty nice, yes disorganized, but she gave so many breaks and was understanding if u talk to her.

Bonam is incredibly disorganized, and she posts confusing instructions that she herself doesn't understand. She'll tell you about 3 separate criteria for things like word length, and all or none of them could be true. Does not communicate with students or TAs, and posts everything to an external google drive bc she cant be bothered with canvas

Vague instructions & inaccessible out of class. The work isn't difficult, but it's way too much at once with no clear instructions. The canvas is also inaccessible, also said it's “too much work” to put instructions on an assignment in canvas rather than a random file in a shared google drive. Miss one class and your grade will suffer.

You're honestly not gonna learn ANYTHING from her lectures. The class is an easy A, but I wouldn't recommend taking her if you actually want to be prepared for upper-division courses. Attendance is “mandatory,” and there were 5 essays (3 of them due DURING finals week) plus 6 group worksheets. No tests or quizzes, though.
TAs did everything for her. Mandatory attendance sucked because all she does is yap. Lectures didnt talk about anything important. Just show up to section and do the assignments for an easy A

Learned NOTHING but grading was very lenient. Lectures were a complete waste of time and rubrics were overly specific but if you follow each requirement it's a guaranteed A. We're put in groups for discussion and lowkey had to learn SPSS on our own. No tests tho.

Bonam made lectures mandatory because no one showed up when they weren't. Her lectures are painfully repetitive and a complete waste of time. The class is an easy A and most assignments are just group work you do in your section so as long as you have a normal TA you'll be fine. Show up to her lectures with other work to do.

Prof Bonam was okay. She was really bad at responding at emails. She never communicated with her TAs and there was always confusion. Lectures are mandatory and she takes attendance. Attending lectures felt pointless because she went over what we read the night prior. Your grade is based on a group project you work on all quarter.

This class was very disappointing. If it weren't for the TA and lab, I would have learned nothing. She takes the whole class time to go over the Canvas page. Her explanation of topics is completely unhelpful. Thankfully, it is really easy. I did not put much time into this class and I still did well regardless of her teaching style.

Professor Bonam is a kind and sweet professor. However, her lectures were pointless since she focused on explaining the tasks regarding the Team Research Project and the Individual Research Report (IRR). PSYC100 is the class where going to a 2-hour section counts the most since doing the Team Research Project will help you write the IRR.

Lectures weren't great, just go to section/the one mandatory class to complete the project (which is a majority of your grade). Personally, my TA was amazing and really helped my group out: having a good group/TA is vital to this course. Overall, it was very well scaffolded and lots of support/instruction is given. Very sweet, but boring lectures.

Lectures are pointless and very boring, she just reads assignments. She's very nice but very unengaging, plus all work can be done in sections. Tons of tiny assignments that are hard to keep track of at times. They say this class is demanding but it is so easy to do well while doing bare minimum. TAs are great and helpful for assignments.

She's overall really nice as a person, but disorganized and often goes off topic during lecture. Her tutorials suck. I'd recommend skipping lecture, just read the slides and do the learning exercises on your own before they're due. Group projects are fine, you're really graded on your report at the end. Having a good TA carries this class.

very nice and caring person but this class structure made no sense. A lot of unnecessary busywork and going to class is absolutely pointless. should be taught as an asyc class bc its basically all independent work. Also the beg of the class is very slow and not much work at all and then the end it gets hard outta nowhere.

This class is taught like its an online class, with a lot of unnecessary busy work. Lectures don't help at all, yet attendance is mandatory. The assignments are useless and the course is basically self-taught, as the lectures don't really teach your anything. If you like learning straight off of a textbook, this is the class for you!

An in person class that was taught like an asychronous class. You have a lot of work, but it is intentional so not too bad. Attendance is mandatory, but you can fill out the attendance quiz online so you don't need to show up. The lectures are not helpful or needed at all if you read the readings.

Dr. Bonam is ok... Her lectures don't really do much for the coursework, but I went to lecture anyway because I just felt bad. Sections are really where it's at and a lot of work gets done in those, so make sure you don't miss any. Also, meet with your group outside of section because things get hard if you don't know how to code using SPSS.

If you take 100 with her, don't go to lectures; they waste time. She uses lectures to read through the week's Canvas assignments rather than teaching meaningful content, instead opting to give students extra materials outside of class. Her deadlines make no sense, she gives too much busy work, and doesn't communicate with her TAs.
Be ready for a professor who does not answer emails (or have papers graded in good time). Her classes are easy though and you learn a lot. I took two classes with her.
Professor Bonam was such a great professor!

Loved this professor so much! I was nervous about taking an online senior seminar, but people taking the class are very passionate, so I still felt involved during the lecture. Graded based on a few assignments and one class facilitation, all leading up to the final paper. If u follow the feedback the TA/prof gives you, you're guaranteed an A.

I usually don't make posts about any professors but Professor Eileen Zurbriggen is an absolutely fantastic teacher. She is extremely passionate about her work and always makes you feel like you are the priority whether that be her office hours or even submitting some assignments on your own time. I 100% recommend taking a course with her.

Really amazing professor! Very understanding about the difficulty involved in learning hard-to-hear topics. A midterm, final, and final paper are basically the grades for the class. If you go to the lecture and do the reading you will be fine for the tests, and she offers several opportunities for extra credit. Sections are mandatory.

Despite the course's intense material topics, Zurbriggen made the classroom feel like a safe space to discuss important topics. Her lectures are interesting and entertaining, and she gives plenty of examples to make the concepts easy to understand. The work is pretty straightforward, just keep up with reading and lecture material.

Lots of technical difficulties, takes forever to receive your grade, and the study guides do not prepare you for exams. Graded by two exams, one paper, and section attendance (mandatory). Nice teacher with interesting lectures, but the class felt disorganized.

Eileen was such a wonderful professor to study under. I took her senior seminar in Spring 2021, and to this day I find myself referencing old notes and course materials because it was so insightful. She approached the topic with such care, and she created a safe and productive environment for her students. One of the best professors I've ever had.
This "professor" is inept period. Get ready to suffer

She is one of the best professors I had. She goes to extra measures to make sure you are doing well in her class. The class is straightforward if you do the work: throughout the quarter you will write sections of the paper which will lead to a 7-10 page paper and a facilitation project which is making presentations for one class section.

There were a lot of readings in this class, that made it hard to keep up with (often over 100 pages a night), but interesting material nonetheless. There's one midterm, a response paper, section grade, group project (25% of grade), and final.

She's so sweet! I love that she really takes everyones opinions into consideration. The class is quite interesting--it really opens your eyes to a lot of current thing affecting us in ways a lot people aren't aware of. There is one test, one film response, one group project/presentation, and a final.
I find it interesting that there is an option for "hotness" I wonder what Eileen would say to this?

She was a great professor in psych 140T, psych and trauma class.  It was dense material; also it was often hard to discuss but she made it so safe to be in the class and talk about such difficult topics

I read reviews on here prior to taking the class, but they are DATED.  This is a hard class, not an easy A, but Eileen is a great professor.  This class is reading INTENSIVE though! You literally have to read and know everything to get an A on her tests.  On the midterm, 50% of the material was from lecture, and the rest was from the readings.

Eileen is super sweet and approachable. If you have any personal issues or troubles with the class she is very understanding, esp if you find any topics triggering. Interesting readings, 1 MC/short ans/short essay midterm, 1 5-6pg research paper, 1 MC final. Points for tests are easy to get but also easy to miss. Take advantage of the study guides!

I enjoyed the powerpoint lectures and how straightforward this class was. You get what you put into it. Easy A if you attend all lectures, complete readings, and attend section. Definitely recommend this class

She is very knowledgeable and approachable. The only thing I did not like about the class is that she had the weighting set up so missing one question on the multiple choice final was worth almost an entire percentage point for the class.
Don't shy away from this because it seems depressing- extremely eye-opening content. Readings are interesting. Mandatory participation. A couple short essays and a final project/paper.
Loved this class, alot of reading but generally easy. lecture notes are posted online. Section is mandatory.
This class was good not great. pretty much just a group discussion everyday, facilitated by other class members and movies from the 80's-90's. Easy. 20 Page group paper (yikes!)

She is a wonderful professor and a great person. I really enjoyed the class. There were no tests because it was a seminar course, but there was a lot of writing. I had fun participating during lectures. Would definitely recommend her.

Dr. Casanova is very passionate about qualitative research and teaches with that same passion and care. She is very kind, understanding, and supportive. Homework is very quick, lectures were super helpful, and she is always communicative and willing to help when there's any confusion.

This entire class was about this YPAR program. I heard about the goals of this YPAR program explained to me about 40 times throughout the quarter. I mean it was easy but I felt like I was losing grip of reality in a schizo episode where my mind would repeat "empowering youth" and "systemic inequalities". Also you gotta do a weekend youth interview.

Professor Casanova was a great professor. It was abundantly obvious she cares for her students, and really wants them to succeed. I learned a lot from this course, and wish I could take it again! Lots of opportunities to make up points, variety of assignments, and accommodating!

Prof. Casanova is very very nice! She clearly explained how to conduct qualitative research. All of the homework and lecture are not hard but very very helpful. If you do them and follow the instruction, you will succeed in the research and get a good grade. She also gives many extra credits! Love her:)
she's such a queen i love her so much. you learn a lot and it feels like she genuinely cares about you!!!

Professor C. is the only prof whom I feel genuinely cares about my mental health. She does cute mindfulness activities. Work is simplified only focusing on what is important. We watch great informative documentaries and tests have straightforward questions. Papers are two, two page and 1, four page.
Professor Casanova is a brilliant teacher. She makes it a point to clear difficulties related to course concepts and gives great feedback. I definitely recommend taking her class!

Dr. Cook is an incredibly engaging professor, which helps a lot since this is an 8 am. Exams are not online and are timed, a minute per question to be exact. They are open note and relatively straightforward. Just make sure to study and you'll be fine.

I took this in Fall '24, genuinely really enjoyed the course. She is a great lecturer and extremely engaging (especially impressive because this was an 8 am course). Light homework and online exams, as well!
She's genius honestly, one of the best professors I've had. Loved her class, loved the information, and it was cool that the textbook we have is written by her. Pretty easy to do well

Cook is a great professor! The lectures are easy to follow, attendance is mandatory but u get three free skips. Theres two quizzes each week based on the chapter reading but it's super easy. 3 film response papers. Open note, online midterm&final. However, she does not have a lab and doesn't write students letters of rec :(

She is the sweetest. Genuinely engaging, reading quizzes twice a week that are super easy and based on the textbook, midterm and final online, and 3 1-2 page film review papers (and the movies are good!!)! Super easy to succeed in this class, and made having an 8am a-okay.

Professor Cook is one of my favorite professors during my time at UCSC. Her personal anecdotes as a clinical psychologist and her guiding us to do medications make the 8 am class lectures worth attending.

I love Andrea Cook. By far the best class I've taken in my time at UCSC. yes, attendance is mandatory (you can skip 3) but she is so so sweet and I love her. the class was so so interesting and I genuinely was enthralled with every minute (which usually never happens I'm an avid class skipper) TAKE THIS CLASS.

Standard class structure with exams based on lecture slide content. Exams are open-note & book. 3 assigned movie viewings with a respective paper for each. Attendance is required, but showing up to her class is easy w/ meditation breaks & her ability to engage you with the content. Only complaint is the grade margin of A = >95% ; A- =

Prof Cook helped us get through an 8am in style. Every class she would devote time for a guided meditation. The topics are interesting albeit intuitive, and the quizzes/tests are extremely easy as they almost exclusively quote directly from the textbook or lecture. As long as you show up to most of the classes, you will be fine.

I personally would never take this professor again. They grade harshly and only allow three lecture absences even if it is a medical problem. For health psychology you would think she would be understanding towards medical issues but she is not. I would say don't stress yourself out on a class where all lecture information is available on wiki.

Maybe it's just cuz it was a new class, but 178 had a lot of potential for improvement. You can tell she has a lot of experience but sometimes it felt like the research was being heavily filtered through her opinion. Half of the lecture was random discussion, I feel like those could be saved for section so more topics can be covered in lecture.

Dr. Cook is an amazing professor, she has a lot of experience in the psych field and has the passion (and stories) to prove it. Attendance is mandatory, but (even at 8am) her lectures are interesting and personal. If you put in the effort, you will easily pass her class. She doesn't try to trick her students or make exams unnecessarily hard!!

I took Dr Cook for clinical psychology and she is honestly one of the best professors I have ever had. She is super knowledgeable, understanding, and passionate about psychology. The lectures are always interesting and you learn so much. She creates a comfortable and safe environment and makes you feel heard. You will love her and her classes.

Professor Cook succeeds at making health psychology feel like a fun topic despite having some stale topics in the course. She is very understanding, relatable, and great at story-telling in class. Her grading rubric consists of about 3 short papers and 2 tests, all of which were relatively easy as long as you put time into the assignments.
Amazing professor. The tests were online and straight from the book! Her lectures were very interesting. Overall, easy A and stress-free class.
